title: Marquette Coach Talks While His Team Acts
description: Al McGuire; the Marquette basketball coach, is many thinks to many people, and is not one to waste words.

title: Saturday's College and School Results
9 Japanese Missing at Sea
description: TOKYO, Dec, 31 (AP)Nine Japanese seamen were reported missing today after their lumber carrier sank in a calsion with a Japanese tanker in the Singapore Strait.

title: Fakhruddin V. Valika Dies, A Pakistani Industrialist
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 31 Fakhruddin Valibhai Valika, head of one of the richest families in Pakistan, died here yesterday at the age of 60.

title: New Books
description: A Harsh and Dreadful Love: Dorothy Day and the Catholic Worker Movement, by William D. Miller (Liveright, $9.95).

title: Nixon Invites Allen To the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)President Nixon called the Washington coach, George Allen, after the Redskins victory over the Dallas Cowboys today.

title: Miami, Led by Griese, Downs Steelers, 2117
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31The Miami Dolphins pay attention and that is one reason why no one has beaten them this season. The punter, Larry Seiple, noticed that the Steelers had all turned their backs on him. So he ran rather than kicked.

title: Rockets'
description: A hard rain was falling through the darkness that night 75 years ago, but the citizens began gathering early in City Hall Park, clustering in small groups at first in the pale glow of unsteady, newfangled street lights and talking quietly of the great event that was soon to overtake them.

title: Deaths
Red Smith Well, At Least, 1973 Is At Hand
description: Ring out the old! Ring in the new With a hey, nonnynonny and a view halloo! The year that is gone was freighted With sorrows, Perhaps we can hope for brighter tomorrows. So Step right up for a couple of snorts To toast the guys and the dolls in sports; Just name your poison, state your preferenceBut first, let us hail with affectionate deference Sage Frank Sullivan, upstate Kris Kringle, Copyrightholder on this sort of jingle.

title: PAKISTAN CHARTER GOES TO ASSEMBLY
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 31 Law Minister Abdul Hafiz Pirzada presented to the National Assembly in Islamabad today the draft of a constitution whose outline was approved in October.

title: Construction Industry Flouts City's New Noise Code
description: The city's new noise code, the first comprehensive effort to reduce unwanted sound here, is running into strong opposition and, in some cases, open defiance, from the construction industry.

title: New Dance Staged As First in Series By Barbara Gardner
description: If Barbara Gardner's The New Dance is a prophetic omen of what the year holds in store for dance, then stop the world, I want to get off. The work, given Saturday evening at Washington Square Methodist Church is a jumble, not a mix, of media and has the cohesion of scraps in a junk yard.

title: Fire Ruins Men's Store
description: MONESSEN, Pa., Dec. 31 (UPI)Fire destroyed the Gaudio Mens Shop last night in this Westmoreland County community, causing an estimated $125,000 damage.

title: Bridge: Life Master Pair Champions Called Best 72 Partnership
description: If there were an award for the best partnership of 1972 it would no doubt go to Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N.J. In the Summer Nationals, they successfully defended the Life Master Pair Championship title, a feat never previously achieved in the 43year history of the event. They also won a bushel of events in New York, giving Roth (subject to an appeal) the title of New York Player of the Year.

title: HARRIS S. BIGELOW
description: TRUMBULL, Conn., Dec. 31 Harris S. Bigelow, president of Profit Services, Inc., a sales management organization in New Canaan and formerly a partner in the Sales Analysis Institute of New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: SLAIN HOTEL MAID WAS WED TO THAI
description: A chambermaid who was found slain in a midtown hotel Saturday was identified yesterday as the wife of a former banker in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: Father and Son Die in Plane
description: DANVILLE, Va., Dec. 31 (AP) Two men from Ayer, Mass., died in a lightplane crash last night in a wooded area five miles north of here, the authorities said today. The victims were Charles Raymond Kern, 41 years old, the pilot, and his son Charles Brian Kern, 18.

title: SLAIN HOTEL MAID WAS WED TO THAI
description: A chambermaid who was found slain in a midtown hotel Saturday was identified yesterday as the Wife of a former banker in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: Chile Bus Plunge Kills 32
description: SAN FERNANDO, Chile, Dec. 31 (AP)  Thirtytwo persons drowned after a. bus swerved off the road and plunged into a river 90 miles south of Santiago, the police reported today. The bus was carrying 38 players and fans of an amateur soccer team. A police source said that only six persons managed to swim out of the submerged wreck and reach the banks of the Chimbarongo River.

title: Stan Freeman Belts Out Songs At the Piano in Michael's Pub
description: Stan Freeman, who wears a variety of musical hats, including, among others, that of accompanist to Marlene Dietrich, composer of Broadway musicals (I Had a Ball and Lovely Ladies, Kind Gentlemen) and recording and concert pianist, has settled into Michael's Pub, 211 East. 55th Street, for a spell of playing jazz piano and singing.

title: New Books
description: A Harsh and Dreadful Love: Dorothy Day and the Catholic Worker Movement, by William D. Miller (Liveright, $9.95).

title: And Now It's Britain That's In in Europe
description: PARIS, Dec. 31  A Parisian, invited home to dinner by some French friends the other day, was served a Christmas pudding. Lapin gallois a la Lord Snowdon is making its appearance on some French restaurant menus. The dish is simply Welsh rarebit. Hungry on the Champs Elysees? Try the Red Lion for a tasty steak and kidney pie.

title: WHALERS TRIUMPH OVER RAIDERS, 30
description: By THOMAS ROGERS

title: PRESS INSTITUTE IS CRITICAL OF U.S,
description: GENEVA, Dec. 31The International Press Institute asserted today that the Nixon Administration was attempting to chip away at press freedom through the courts and by the threats of court action.

title: MESKILL PREDICTS A BUDGET SURPLUS
description: Gov. Thomas J. Meskill declared yesterday that Connecticut was in very good shape, with a budget surplus likely for the second year in a row.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RIVER EDGE, N. J., Dec. 31Hoping to bolster fledgling interscholastic athletic programs for women, New Jersey started an experiment last spring allowing girls compete on boys high school teams in noncontact sports for a oneyear trial period.Facilities Present Problem

title: Subway Noise Threatens Reade Theater Opening
MRS. FRANK WHITNEY
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 31 Mrs. Claudia McAlpin Whitney, widow of Frank Whitney, an industrial engineer, died today at her home, 4 Hillcrest Road, here. She was 85 years old.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Census Bureau Estimates Population at 210,194,312
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)  The United States will begin the new year with a population of 210, 194, 312, the Census Bureau estimated today. The net gain in population during 1972 was 1.5 million, the bureau said, This was down from the 2.0 million of 1971 and the 2.2 million of 1970. The largest net annual increase ever recorded was 3.1 million in 1956.

title: ALABAMA CHOICE TO BEAT TEXAS
description: DALLAS, Dec. 31 (UPP The University of Alabama, which has been to more bowl games than any other college football team, will make its 14th straight postseason apearance tomorrow against Texas in the Cotton Bowl. The kickoff is scheduled for 2 P.M. (E.S.T.).

title: DR. WALTER L. PERLS, ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Dec, 31 Dr. Walter L. Perls, a retired orthopedic surgeon who served on the staff of the Hospital ford Joint Diseases in New York for many years, died here today at the age of 81.

title: Saturday's College and School Results
Metropolitan Briefs
description: NEWARK, Dec. 31 (UPI) Representatives from 16 of this city's public housing projects announced a citywide rent strike this weekend in support of two strike leaders who face jail terms.

title: Chappaqua Station Cheer Raises Spirits of Riders
REFORM DEADLINE ON POLLUTION NEAR
description: LOS ANGELES  Environmental control measures will again be a major matter of attention when state legislatures open their new sessions in January.

title: L.I.R.R. Strikers Vow to Stay Out For Equal Pact
description: Determination to continue the Long Island Rail Road strike was expressed yesterday by Anthony F. D'Avanzo, chief negotiator for the coalition of 12 striking unions of nonoperating employes.

title: Books of The Times
description: REGENESIS. By Robert Granat. 313 pages. Simon & Schuster. $7.95.

title: A Couple of 8YearOld Girls Who Made the Football Team
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.One would never suspect that Kim Houlton and Jan Pendleton, a pair of 8yearold schoolgirls, were threats to male physical superiority as exemplified by such prominent football players as Bart Starr and Terry Beasley. But they all started the same way.

title: States Lag in Hiring Black Parole Officers
description: Despite mounting pressure to increase the number of black parole officers in corrections systems across the country, only minimal progress has been made by many state governments in the efforts to recruit blacks for the jobs.

title: One Another's Burdens
description: At year's turn we account to friends and neighbors, known and hidden, because all of us are members of a larger community, but most of all we account to ourselves. If only for a passing instant in the human timeclock, we heed the Biblical injunctions: Freely ye have received, freely give. . . . Bear ye one another's burdens. . . . It is more blessed to give than to receive.

title: Meany Sees Bid to Regain Lost Purchasing Power
description: WASHINGTON., Dec. 31 (Reuters) George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., said today, that unions, representing five million workers would seek to regain lost purChasing power in contract negotiations during 1973.

title: First National Boston Gets Some Assets of Randolph
description: The First National Boston Corporation has acquired certain dataprocessing equipment and related leases from the Randolph Computer Corporation for $61million, the parent company of the First National Bank of Boston announced last Saturday.

title: ALL U.S. BOMBING BELIEVED HALTED FOR THE HOLIDAY
Hanoi's Envoy in Paris Again Urges U.S. to Sign
description: PARIS, Dec. 31  Vo Van Sung, North Vietnam's representative in Paris, asserted tonight that his country had won a strategic victory over American air power and called upon the United States to sign the ninepoint draft accord reached in October.

title: OYSTER BAY EIGHT IS REGATTA VICTOR
description: The Oyster Bay Rowing Association of Long Island captured the Elite eightoared event of the annual New Year's Eve regatta of the New York Rowing Association yesterday on the Orchard Beach lagoon in the Bronx.

title: Quadruplets Born At a Hospital Here; 3 Boys and a Girl
description: Quadrupletsthree boys and a girlhave been born here to the wife of an assistant United States attorney, and the children and mother were in satisfactory condition, New York HospitalCornell Medical Center reported yesterday. They were born Saturday morning.

title: Navajos Establish Concern to Retain Profit From Crafts
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Dec. 31The nation's largest Indian tribe has set up an economic enterprise designed to insure Oat Indian artisans and workers receive more of the profits from the sale of their handicrafts. Most of the money now goes to white middlemen.

title: BLOOD DONATIONS STEPPED UP HERE
description: Lines formed yesterday at the Greater New York Blood Program's two centers in Manhattan in response to its appeal for blood donations to alleviate an acute shortage in the metropolitan area.

title: 70 Days Battling Starvation and Freezing in the Andes: A Chronicle of Man's Unwillingness to Die
description: The following dispatch was written for the LatinAmerican news agency LATIN by Carlos Benales, chief of the agency's Chilean bureau and himself a Uruguayan. LATIN is a cooperative news agency operated by 10 of Latin America's largest newspapers. 1972 by LATIN.

title: WINGS AND STARS BATTLE TO 44 TIE
description: DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP) Mickey Redmond's 20th goal of the season earned the Detroit Red Wings a 44 tie with the Minnesota North Stars in the National Hockey League tonight. It was the Wings third tie of the week.

title: Restaurant in Nice Bombed
description: NICE, France, Dec. 31 CAP)An explosion in front of a restaurant here owned by a Yugoslav blew in the door, broke windows and damaged three cars parked nearby, the police reported yesterday, It came eight days after a Yugoslay national seriously wounded himself in Paris while manipu lating a bomb in a restaurant near the Yugoslav Embassy.

title: Miss Azuma Sings Debut As CioCioSan at Met
description: After having seen Puccini's Madama Butterfly in performances here and abroad for more than a quarter of a century, this reviewer was still naive enough to go to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night thinking that the work might actually take on a new dimension or richness with a Japanese soprano in the central role. Atsuko Azuma was making her Metropolitan debut as CioCioSan, and it was a perfect chance to find out.

title: Early Opening of Freeway Held Likely to Bring Safety Problems
description: TRENTON, Dec. 31 (UP1) A report released by Governor Cahill's office has shown that the early opening of completed portions of the eastwest freeway in West Orange would result in safety problems and possible structural defects.

title: Foes of Nixon on Vietnam Planning Steps in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 There were strong signs today that President Nixon's halt in bombing above the 20th Parallel in North Vietnam had brought him little, if any, respite from Congressional criticism of his Vietnam policies.

title: SUFFOLK MUST ACT ON PERCY SUSPENSION
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Dec. 31 New York State Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz said today he has notified Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein that Mr. Klein had the legal right to suspend County Attorney George W. Percy Jr., with pay, and to seek his removal from office, but only after a full bearing by the County Legislature.

title: Japan Premier Promises Round of Trade Reforms
description: TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 1 Premier Kakuei Tanaka, in his New Year's message to the Japanese people today, emphasized the need to restore equilibrium to Japan's balance of international payments, particularly in terms of her trade surplus with the United States.

title: HARRY P. CHARLESWORTH
description: Harry P. Charlesworth, former vice president of Bell Laboratories and retired assistant chief engineer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Saturday in Montclair, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in North Caldwell, N.J.

title: Nebraska Hopes to Make Irish 3d Straight Orange Bowl Victim
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP) The prestige of the Big Eight Conference will be on the line when Nebraska seeks its third consecutive Orange Bowl victory tonight against Notre Dame.

title: Redskins Attack Aimed At Weak Left Cuner
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  Billy Kilmer acknowledged today, that the Washington Redskins had set their pregame sights on the Dallas Cowboys secondary, specifically the left cornerback spot.

title: OIL CONCERNS SURE ON GAS DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  Most of the nation's larger oil companies say they will be able to meet the demand for leadfree gasoline by the time 1975model automobiles, the first to be designed to use such fuel exclusively, reach the market.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Verdi's La Traviata, 8.

title: Bradshaw Never Knew What Hit Him
Hope Is Reborn
description: President Nixon's decision to stop the bombing North Vietnam north of the Twentieth Parallel and send Henry Kissinger back to Paris signals a return to sanity that will be greeted with relief throughout the nation and the world. As French Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann remarked: Hope is reborn.

title: ALDEN W. BOYD, 70, EXU.S. AIDE, DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Alden Work Boyd, a forMer vice president of the furniture house of Knoll International in New York and a Government official in World War II and the postwar years, died today of lung cancer in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he had been living since his retirement in 1965. He was 70 years old.

title: After Living Varied Life, She Proved You Can Go Home Again
description: DELAPLANE, Va.  The road sign reads DIP, and that is what Route 17 does as it rolls down the hill, passes beneath the sycamore branches and crosses the narrow bridge. To the left, Crooked Run joins Goose Creek; to the right, as the land begins to rise from the flat meadow beside the stream, is the village of Delaplane.

title: 2 Top Officials in Pennsylvania Ousted in Police Wiretap Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 31 (UPI) Gov. Milton J. Shapp has dismissed state Police Commissioner Rocco Urella and forced Attorney General J. Shane Creamer to resign in the midst of a wiretap controversy. Mr. Shapp issued a formal statement today on Mr. Urella's dismissal. Mr. Creamer's resignation, which was tendered Friday, was announced today by his aides.

title: London Flu in Bay State
description: BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP)London flu has spread over southeastern Massachusetts, and absenteeism is running as high as 20 per cent in some areas, the slate Department of Public Health reports,

title: Hot Air
description: This may be an idea whose time has comeback. The oftthreatened world energy shortage, real and relentless though it may be, has become a device for justifying all sorts of pet projects from enlarging tax loopholes to helping oilrich Arabs throw the Israelis into the sea, Is there no other way?

title: Airports to Restrict Public In a New Security Move
description: Dozens of airports across the country are planning to place all or parts of their passenger concourses off limits to everyone but passengers as they prepare, under Federal mandate, to tighten security to snare potential hijacker's.

title: For Residents in Hanoi, A Full Night's Sleep
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 31The people of Hanoi were able to get a full night's sleep last night for the first time since the United States bombing began two weeks ago.

title: BLOOD SHORTAGE DELAYS SURGERY IN MAJOR CITIES
description: Blood shortages so severe as to force postponement of elective surgery exist in several major cities across the United States.

title: Ayres and Richerich Win M Narrasketuck Y. C.
description: AMITYVILLE, L.I., Dec, 31 Jamie Ayres of the National Yacht Club of Washington triumphed in the senior division of the second annual El Toro BuIlshot Regatta held at the Narrasketuck Yacht Club today. Lowry Chamberlain of the Washington club was second among the 25 boats which competed in five races.

title: Earth Week. Scheduled
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that Earth. Week 1973 would begin April 9 and end April 15. In a statement prepared for the Senate, Mr. Nelson, who founded the Earth Week observances, called on President Nixon, state officials and Senate colleagues to join in issuing the 1973 Earth Week proclamation.

title: 1,200 Pay Pearson Last Tribute At State Funeral in Ottawa Rain
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 31  Former Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson, who won a Nobel Peace Prize, was eulogized today as leader who combined the Biblical virtues of wisdom, humility and greatness.

title: Gold Retires From State High Court; Will Be a Counsel to Law Firm Here
description: Edward R. Dudley, administrative judge of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, announced a luncheon for Justice Samuel M. Gold early last month this way:

title: Pope Calls Bombing Halt Ray of Light
description: ROME, Dec. 31Pope Paul VI, though suffering from influenza, made a public appearance today to welcome as a ray of light the end of the United States bombing raids on North Vietnam and the planned resumption of peace talks.

title: BUDGET CUTS MADE IN FARM PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Farmers, who were strongly urged by the Republicans last fall to help reelect President Nixon, have seen the Department of Agriculture trim nearly $1.5billion a year from rural programs in the last three weeks.

title: Fire Ruins Men's Store
description: MONESSEN, Pa., Dec. 31 (UPI)Fire destroyed the Gaudio Mens Shop last night in this Westmoreland County community, causing an estimated $125,000 damage.

title: Honors List Is Test of Conscience for Some Britons
description: LONDON, Dec. 31Prof. Jack Tizard is a leading British authority on mental retardation. He lives in a Victorian house on Hampstead Heath with his wife and five lively and disputatious children.

title: Comic Books Can Prove Super Investment
description: Note to speculators: Forget soybeans and electronics stocks. Now is the time to switch to Shazam! and Conan the Barbarian.

title: $87Million Saving for Cars Seen in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Dec. 31  Compulsory no fault insurance for all private passenger vehicles goes into effect in New Jersey tomorrow, promising premium savings totaling $87million annually across the state.

title: WHALERS TRIUMPH OVER RAIDERS, 30
description: The New England Whalers, the highest scoring team in the World Hockey Association, put the emphasis on defense yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden and defeated the New York Raiders, 3.0, before crowd of 5,888.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RINK IN THE NEW If family elders opened the New Year with resolutions to seek to close the generation gap by spending more time with the children, a beginning of sorts could be made today at five outdoor and two indoor iceskating rinks operated by the Parks Administration in the five boroughs of the city.

title: Rockets Red Glare Marked Birth of Merged City in 1898
description: A hard rain was falling through the darkness that night 75 years ago, but the citizens began gathering early in City Hall Park, clustering in small groups at first in the pale glow of unsteady, newfangled street lights and talking quietly of the great event that was soon to overtake them.

title: Mother and 3 Children Die In a West Virginia Blaze
description: PAYNESVILLE, W. Va., Dec. 31 (AP)Three young children and their mother died today when fire swept a fourroom former school building in which they lived, the state police said.

title: 3,700 COMPLAINTS ON POLICE FILED
description: The number of civilian complaints filed against New York City policemen during 1972 has reached a record 3,700, or triple the figure of five years ago.

title: Jet's Captain Had Tumor But Was Not at Controls
Mormons Give Boston A Proper Toast to 73
description: BOSTON, Dec. 31A return to tradition marked the New Year's Eve ball given tonight by the historian Samuel Eliot Morison and Mrs. Morison for 100 proper Bostonians. It took place at 44 Brimmer Street, where Admiral Morison was born and still lives.

title: MRS. COURT WINS AUSTRALIAN OPEN
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Jan. 1 (UPI) Mrs. Margaret Court captured her 11th national title when she defeated Evonne Goolagong in in the final of the Australian open, tennis championships at Kooyong courts today.

title: JOHN RAASCH, 81, LED WHAMAKER'S
description: John E Raasch, who retired in 1966 as president of the John Wanamaker department store companies in Philadelphia and New York, died yesterday at the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived 505 Knollwood Road in Ridgewood.

title: Foes of Nixon on Vietnam Planning Steps in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  There were strong signs today that President Nixon's halt in bombing above the 20th Parallel in North Vietnam had brought him little, if any, respite from Congressional criticism of his Vietnam policies.

title: LEGALAID GROUP SUES OVER RELIEF
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Dec. 31 The Camden Regional Legal Services Bureau, a federally funded legalaid organization, is suing the Burlington County Welfare Board to block a new board policy of filing suits against welfare recipients to recover $110,000 in alleged overpayments.

title: As Britain Joins Market, Public Is Apprehensive
description: LONDON, Dec. 31After 10year struggle, Britain joins Europe tomorrow with her officials jubilant and her public apprehensive.

title: Buchanan's Talent As Guitarist Lifts 'Village Rock Show
description: The rock tripleheader Saturday night at the Villageast worked its way progressively back to the basics, and managed to provide a good deal of pleasure along the way.

title: NEWS INDEX
Paris: New Role Confronts Left Bank
description: PARISAs the bull fascinated by the cape neglects the real threat, namely the torero, Parisians who have been protesting against the intrusion of the Defense skyscrapers into the perspective of the ChampsElyses have remained curiously silent in the face of the disclosure by city authorities that the Left Bank of the Seine would soon be transformed into an express riverside drive to match the one already in service along the right bank. And yet this project is probably the deadliest blow dealt to a city which, despite the transformations brought in the last 10 years, remains every, man's second home.

title: How to Figure Whether to Take
description: Extra Allowances

title: 1972 Gets ExtraSecond Sendoff
OKLAHOMA BEATS PENN STATE, 140
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31A hard, slugging defensive battle in the 39th annual Sugar Bowl was settled by a skinny, little freshman wide receiver, Tinker Owens, who caught one touchdown pass and set up another as Oklahoma defeated Penn State, 190, tonight.

title: Mystery of the Missing Cowboy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Dallas Cowboys, who have made their reputation for computerlike efficiency, bypassed playing a cornerback with 12 years of pro football experience today, and no one, including the cornerback, seemed to know why.

title: MRS. THERESA ROHAN
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Dec. 31 Mrs. Theresa Rohan, superintendent of nurses at the Community Hospital here, died today at the hospital. Her age was 64.

title: Quadruplets Born At a Hospital Here; 3 Boys and a Girl
LAKE PLACID JUMP WON BY NAKANO
Economic Risks Vie With Britain's Hopes
description: LONDON, Dec. 31  Britain enters the European Common Market tomorrow in the hope that beyond a number of risks lies a rosier economic future.

title: 100 War Protesters Hear Outdoor Mass Near St. Patrick's
description: Shrouded in fog and dampened by a steady drizzle, about 100 antiwar protesters gathered near St. Patrick's Cathedral in midtown Manhattan yesterday to hear the Rev. Daniel Berrigan offer a prayer of thanks to God for the bombing halt above North Vietnam's 20th parallel.

title: NEW YEAR MAKES 400,000 ADULTS
description: Some 400,000 New Jersey young people were transformed into adults at 12:01 A.M. today as a new state law lowering the age of majority from 21 to 18 years went into effect.

title: Paper Industry Expansion Seen Lagging for 3 Years
description: A seller's market through 1975.

title: CRISIS IN NEW WARK SCORED BY CAHILL
description: Governor Cahill called yesterday for firmer leadership in Newark to meet problems such as crime, such as abandoned houses, such as dirty streets.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 15

title: U.S. and Nicaragua Discuss Extension of American Aid
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 31 (AP)The possibility of extending American aid to Nicaragua for six months was discussed today by President Nixon's representative and Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, who took over the direction of this country after an earthquake destroyed Managua Dec. 22.

title: Ayres and Richerich Win At Narrasketuck Y. C.
description: AMITYVILLE, L.I., Dec. 31 Jamie Ayres of the National Yacht Club of Washington triumphed in the senior division of the second annual El Toro Bullshot Regatta held at the Narrasketuck Yacht Club today. Lowry Chamberlain of the Washington club was second among the 25 boats which competed in five races.

description: Dozens of airports across the country are planning to place all or parts of their passenger concourses off limits to everyone but passengers as they prepare, under Federal mandate, to tighten security to snare potential hijackers.

title: 1972 Gets ExtraSecond Sendoff

description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Dec. 31On a rainsoaked hill where the ski riders could Nhave used water wings, Hideki akano, the compact University of Tokyo internationalist, captured the annual New Year's jumping event at this Adirondack resort today.

title: War Is Peace
description: LONDON, Dec. 31Fragment found in a dusty future corner of a time machine:

title: Shultz Says Nixon Seeks Rise in Food Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Seeking to curb rising food prices, the Nixon Administration plans efforts to increase food supplies and to stress price controls on middlemen in the industry, Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said today.

title: Redskins, Dolphins To Get $8,500 Apiece
description: Each Washington Redskin and Miami Dolphin player earned $8,500 yesterday when their teams won conference championships in the National Football League playoffs.

title: China Vows to Continue Policy Of Improving Foreign Relations
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 31Domestic progress along already established lines and the further development of foreign relations based on peaceful coexistence were the dominant themes for 1973 expressed in a statement issued in Peking tonight.

title: MRS. C. FREDERICK HILL
description: Mrs. Bertha Collins Hill, widow of G. Frederick Hill and mother of the Rev. Frederick Hill, assistant minister of St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street, died Friday at her home, 865 Madison Avenue. She was 68 years old.

title: Most Active Stocks
description: Of the total volume of 4,137,946,061 shares traded during 1972 on the New York Stock Exchange, the fifteen most active securities accounted for 488,174,300 shares, or 11.8 per cent of the aggregate sales. Individual volume and closing prices, with the net change for the year of the 15 leaders are shown in the following table. Sales are in hundreds.

title: Television
Merest Pinch
description: The first pinch of SALT II is hardly enough to whet anyone's appetite. The only apparent achievement of the Soviet and American negotiators in a month of Geneva talks was the creation of a fourman consultative commission to supervise past and future strategic arms agreements, as foreseen in last May's agreements at the end of SALT I.

title: Sports Today
description: Cotton Bowl, Texas vs,. Alabama, at Dallas. (TelevisionChannel 2, 2 P.M.) (RadioWCBS, P.M.)

title: 3 MEN HERE SLAIN IN GANGLAND STYLE
description: Three unidentified men were found murdered yesterday, three miles apart in the East Bronx. Two of the victims had been shot and their bodies dumped in gangland fashion on a vacant lot in the Soundview district at Theriot and Lafayette Avenues.

title: Klein Says Suffolk Is Short 6,000 Units for Elderly Poor
3 MEN HERE SLAIN IN GANGLAND STYLE
description: Three unidentified men were found murdered yesterday, three miles apart in the East Bronx.

title: Filion Wins Three At Delaware Oval; Ends 72 With 604
description: DOVER, Del., Dec. 31Herve Filion won three races today at Dover Downs and brought his 1972 record total to 604 victories. The 32yearold Canadian had seven drives. In his other races he finished second twice, third and eighth.

title: Milk Price to Rise And Cost Consumers Extra $10Million
description: TRENTON, Dec. 31  The price of milk goes up tomorrow in New Jersey. The increases will cost consumers about $10million more in 1973 to purchase their 950 million quarts of milk.

title: HENRY M'KNIGHT, 59, MIDWEST LAWMAKER
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec, 31  Henry T. McKnight, a former Minnesota State Senator who was a leader in conservation and the development of the model communities of Jonathan and CedarRiverside, died yesterday of a brain tumor. He was 59 years old and lived in Wayzata.

title: Subway Noise Threatens Reade Theater Opening
description: The belated opening of the Reade Theater at 1 Astor Plaza, which once was to have been the first major new motionpicture theater on Times Square in 36 years, is in doubt because of a dispute between the building's owner and the lessee.

title: 'FIRMNESS URGED ON COMMUNISTS
Norwegian Paper Closes
description: DECORAH, Iowa, Dec. 31 (UN)  The Decorah Posten, Iowa's 98 year  old Norwegian language weekly newspaper, has ended publication because of declining circulation. B. B. Anundsen, the publisher, said that the circulation, which once totaled 45,000, had declined to less than 5,000. The newspaper said that its subscription list would be taken over by another Norwegian language newspaper published in Seattle.

title: China Puts Accent On SelfReliance, Economist Argues
description: TORONTO, Dec. 31  Selfreliance rather than harsher Sovietstyle centralization has dominated the Communist Chinese economy since the 1950's, Dwight H. Perkins, a specialist in Chinese studies from Harvard University's East Asian Research Center, told the annual Conference of the Allied Social Sciences Associations last week.

title: Filion Wins Three At Delaware Oval; Ends 72 With 604
description: DOVER, Del., Dec. 31Herve Filion won three races today at Dover Downs and brought his 1972 record total to 604 victories. The 32yearold Canadian had seven drives. In his other races he finished second twice, third and eighth.

title: GEORGE SOSNICK
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (UPI)  George Sosnick, cofounder of the largest kosherfooddistributing company in he Western United States, died yesterday. He was 79 year old,

title: FASHION TALK
description: Geoffrey Beene's latest project creating the most luxurious shirts in the world. Shirt, actually. There will only be one style but it will be the quintessential shirt, Mr. Beene promises. There will be no detail, just the best possible fit and fabric, the designer explained. For example, there will be only one button on each cuff.

title: Rangers Rout Blues, 61, As Ratelle Gets 3 Goals
description: Not even Jean Ratelle's three goals last night satisfied 17,500 fans at Madison Square Garden, who waited in vain after pleading for the Rangers to Get Unger.

title: 11 Arrested in 'Juice Bar Raid; Narcotics and Weapons Seized
description: The police said yesterday that in a raid on The Zoo, an East Side discotheque catering mainly to teenagers, they had found 12 small packets of heroin, 19 bags of marijuana, two hashish pipes, four pistols, a rifle, two knives, three blackjacks and three baseball bats.

title: Sports Today
description: Cotton Bowl, Tens vs. Alabatna, at Dallas. (TelevisionChannel 2, 2 P.M.) (RadioWCBS, 2 P.M.)

title: Entries at Monticello
Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Cairo Sitins Continue
description: CAIRO, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Students at Cairo University boycotted classes and staged a sitin for the second day today, protesting the arrests last week of a number of students described by political sources as leftist or rightist extremists similar protests were reported elsewhere.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A spokesman for New Jersey correction officers denied charges of manifest racism among guards at state prisons.

title: 55 PRISONERS ACCUSE ATHENS ON APPEALS
description: ATHENS, Dec. 31Fiftyfive Greek political prisoners, in statement smuggled out of jail, today accused Premier George Papadopoulos of violating promise that they would be granted the right of appeal.

title: WINGS AND STARS BATTLE TO 44 TIE
description: DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP) Mickey Redmond's 20th goal of the season earned the Detroit Red Wings a 44 tie with the Minnesota North Stars in the National Hockey League tonight. It was the Wings third tie of the week.

title: Books of The Times
description: REGENESIS. By Robert Granat. 313 pages. Simon & Schuster. $7.95.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The City Housing and Development Administration will send out 3,772 checks totaling $8,606,160 to tenants, homeowners and business concerns forced to move during an 18month period ending last June 30 to make way for Federal building projects in New York City, officials announced yesterday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
A Disappearing Way?
description: TORONTOThe thousands of Amerlean economists who left their families between Christmas and New Year's to come north of the border for their annual professional meetings carried with them a heavy freight of worries.

title: Pasteur Sesquicentennial
Field, Bartholomew Pacing Frostbite Regatta Classes
3,700 COMPLAINTS ON POLICE FILED
description: The number of civilian cornplaints filed against New York City policemen during 1972 has reached a record 3,700, or triple the figure of five years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding your Dec. 21 editorial The 45 Percenters, while I agree that enforcing traffic laws would serve to ease vehicular congestion, I think that we need to reassess our existing laws. Noparking in the midtown area is reasonable and wise. The seemingly random designation of noparking areas in Manhattan residential areas, however, is unwise.

title: SEARCHERS RECOVER BODY IN CALIFORNIA
description: SEARCHERS RECOVER BODY IN CALIFORNIA

title: ALL U.S. BOMBING BELIEVED HALTED FOR THE HOLIDAY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 1There were indications today that the United States had temporarily halted all bombing in both North and South Vietnam in observance of a 24hour New Year's Day ceasefire proclaimed by both the Communists and the Saigon Government.

title: CRISIS IN NEWARK SCORED BY CAHILL
description: Governor Cahill called yesterday for firmer leadership in Newark to meet problems such as crime, such as abandoned houses, such as dirty streets.

title: MRS. COURT GAINS AUSTRALIAN FINAL
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 (AP) Mrs. Margaret Court routed Kerry Melville, 61, 60, today and advanced to the final of the $53,300 Australian open, a tennis title she has won 10 times.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Official confirmation of a 24hour New Year's Day bombing halt throughout all of Vietnam was expected from the United States command in Saigon. Spokesmen for the command were refusing to confirm the pause during the day, apparently following a pattern established when the command announced a 36hour Christmas pause after it had passed. The pause was in observance of a New Year's Day ceasefire proclaimed by both the Communists and the Saigon Government. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: As Britain Joins Market, Public Is Apprehensive
description: LONDON, Dec. 31After 10year struggle, Britain joins Europe tomorrow with her officials jubilant and her public apprehensive.

title: Tribal Revenge Is Revived in New Guinea's Wild Highlands
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 31  Tribal warfare has erupted in the wild highlands of New Guinea, with bloody clashes between large warrior bands armed with bows and arrows reported from a number of jungle villages.

title: Ring in the Peace
description: There is no compelling logic to celebrating the start of the New Year on the first day of January. The early Egyptians began the new cycle in September; the ancient Greeks in June. New Englanders for a while stuck to Christmas Day, Dec. 25. The Jewish New Year fluctuates between September and October. It was only in the course of the eighteenth century that Germany, Russia, England and Sweden officially adopted Jan. 1 as New Year's Day. A small child, asked when the New Year begins, is more likely to cite his or her own birthday as the consequential turn.

title: Entries at Monticello
Mrs. Somoza Runs Much of Quake Relief
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 31From the command post atop El Retiro Hill, Hope Portocarrero de Somoza marshals her forces to cope with this country's most terrible Catastrophe.

title: A BOY, 3, DONATES 50C TO NEEDIEST
description: ThreeyearOld Tony Plohoros of 815 27th Avenue, Astoria, Queens, mailed two quarters to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with the request that it help a poor child.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
Fans Are Emotional
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  Hail to the Redskins has replaced Hail to the Chief as the theme song of the nation's capital.

title: PIERRE HOLDUP MAN SHOT ON BROADWAY
description: One of the three men sentenced last week in the $3million jewel robbery of the Pierre Hotel last New York's was shot on a West Side street yesterday afternoon.

title: ELLY STONE SINGS FOR HER DEVOTEES
description: Carnegie Hall was filled Saturday evening with enthusiastic devotees of Elly Stone; they gave her cheering support and an occasional ovation, as she offered what has become her annual program there.

title: WOMAN SHOT IN EYE HELD VERY CRITICAL
description: Barbara Washington, a 22yearold mother of two children, remained in very critical condition at Kings County Hospital last night after undergoing five hours of surgery early yesterday for removal of a bullet lodged in the right side of her brain.

title: Personal Finance: A Look at 73 Taxes
description: Now that the New Year is here, it might be a good idea to consider 1973's income taxes, along with a basic question: Will you be overwithheld or underwithheld when you make out your income tax form in 1974?

title: Artist Couple Draw Line at Individuality
description: ENGLEWOOD, Dec. 31 Clare Romano, an Englewood painterprintmaker whose works are included in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney Mitseum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, was riding home one day when she was struck by the colors and forms she saw in the hard, pink, endofawinter'sday light along North Woodland Avenue.

title: State's Economic Outlook For '73 Called Favorable
description: TRENTON, Dec. 31 Favorable economic prospects are in store for New Jersey in 1973, according to a leading bank executive and a state labor and industry official.

title: MRS. ANN S. PRATT
description: Mrs. Ann Spencer Pratt, an artist, died yesterday in Canaan, Corm. She was 59 years old, lived at 130 East 67th Street and had a studio in Williamsville, Mass.

title: Repression Charged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Rev Philip Berrigan, released earlier this month after serving nearly three years in prison for destroying draft records said today that the Government had succeeded in repressing the antiwar movement. He was interviewed on the Columbia Broadcasting System program, Face the Nation.

title: Shizuma Matsuo, Chairman Of Japan Air Lines, Dies
description: TOKYO, Dec. 31 (AP)  Shizuma Matsuo, chairman of the board of Japan Air Lines, died today at a hospital here. He was 69 years old and had been treated for a gall bladder disorder.

title: Ohio to Shut Interstate a Day for Shovel Crossing
description: HENDRYSBURG, Ohio, Dec. 31Two giant earth movers are taking their last bites from hills north of Interstate 70 in eastern Ohio and, weather permitting, are about to cross this major eastwest highway on temporary earthen dike to continue their foraging on 20,000 acres of coalrich land south of the freeway in Belmont County.

title: Miami, W ashington Reach Super Bowl
description: The unbeaten Miami Dolphins, with Bob Griese directing two secondhalf touchdown drives, defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 2117, yesterday and won the American Football Conference championship.

title: JOHN H. KAUFMANN
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 31 (AP)John H. Kaufmann, an associate assistant administrator with the Agency for International Development, died of cancer yesterday. He was 53 years old.

title: BLOOD SHORTAGE DELAYS SURGERY IN MAJOR CITIES
description: Blood shortages so severe as to force postponement of elective surgery exist in several major cities across the United States. Acute shortages were first noted in New York City, where this weekend officials of the Greater New York Blood Bank Program asked surgeons to cancel all but emergency operations. Although donors have responded in sufficient numbers to increase the blood reserve to a day and a half's supply, still shortages were so low yesterday that officials said they could not effectively deal with a disaster such as an airplane or bus crash.

title: Four Shot in Belfast as Gunmen Attack a Bus Carrying Catholics
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 31Gunmen flagged down a bus carrying a dozen Roman Catholics tonight and sprayed it with bullets, wounding four persons.

title: Ohio State Threatens U.S.C. Record in Rose Bowl
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31  Almost everybody but Woody Hayes and his Ohio State Buckeyes has conceded the National Collegiate football championship to the University of Southern California. Tomorrow the Buckeyes, 14point underdogs, will to topple the Trojans in the 59th Rose Bowl game.

title: Claims in Hartford Plan Must Be Paid in 15 Days
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 31Mandatory nofault automobile insurance goes into effect in Connecticut tomorrow. Under the new law  one of the most controversial measures the General Assembly ever contended with  a person involved in an automobile 'accident will be able to collect up to $5,000 from his own insurance company for the medical bills he has paid, without resolving the question of who was at fault in the accident.

title: For Residents in Hanoi, A Full Night's Sleep
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 31The people of Hanoi were able to get a full night's sleep last night for the first time since the United States bombing began two weeks ago.

title: Murray Louis Dancers Do Their Own Things
News Summary and Index
CONTROLS PINCH STEEL INDUSTRY
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31The steel industry is entering 1973 with Government controls apparently beginning to pinch.

title: Economic Events of 72 Were Highlighted by Wall Street Records
description: Following are the highlights and a chronology of some major national economic events of 1972:

title: Study Finds TwoThirds of World Without Freedom
description: Twothirds of the world's population lives without freedom, and will continue to live that way, according to a study prepared by Freedom House. There are some countries, the study says, where citizens may lose civil and political liberties if the present trend of governmental regulation of individuals lives continues. Sweden and the Philippines were put in that category. The study also predicts that Zambia will lose its partially free status in 1973 through the elimination of all opposition.

title: Fireman Saves Woman Leaping From a Blaze
description: A 50  year  old woman leaped from her burning thirdfloor apartment in East Harlem early yesterday and was rescued by a fireman who grabbed her when she hit the edge of an aerial ladder bucket being raised to the window ledge, fire officials said.

title: NIXON CONTROLS PLEASING MANY
description: Businessmen and investors have been generally pleased with the results of the Nixon economic controls program during 1972, largely because corporate profits have soared to new highs, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average has rocketed above the 1,000 mark for the first time in its history.

title: Paul Smolen Weds Wendy Weisberg
description: TENAFLY, N.J., Jan. 1The marriage of Miss Wendy Weisberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Weisberg of Englewood, to Paul David Smolen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Smolen,took place here this afternoon in Temple Sinai. Rabbi Irwin Blank performed the ceremony.

title: Vanishing Glut
description: Less than one year after agricultural experts were predicting a world rice glut as a result of the introduction of new miracle seeds, there have been reports in recent weeks of widespread food shortages in Asia and parts of Africa. The great promise of the green revolution, which was never as green as it was sometimes pictured, appears to be fading.

title: PATH Negotiators Race Strike Deadline
description: Representatives of the Port Authority TransHudson commuter railroad and the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen were scheduled to meet with Federal mediators at 11 A.M. in an attempt to avert a strike schedtiled for one minute after midnight tonight.

title: Spain Hails a Decision by Ford To Build $290Million Plant
description: MADRID, Jan. 1A firm of fer by the Ford Motor Com. pany to build a $290million plant in Spain brightened Spain's new year weekend.

title: Major Revision of State's Courts Urged
description: A radical revamping of the state's courtsin which bail would be abolished, judges would be subject to strict discipline and courts would be run by administrative technicians, rather than judgeswas proposed yesterday by the Temporary Commission on the New York State Court System.

title: Express Unit Fills Post
description: The American Express International Banking Corporation has announced the election of Alfred N. Beadleston 3d as vice president. Mr. Beadleston served as economic and financial adviser to Secretary of State William P. Rogers for the last two years. He was previously associated with the Chase Manhattan Bank. At A.E.I.B.C., Mr. Beadleston will have general management responsibility for international banking activities in France.

title: Electronic Money Units Are Backed by Reserve
description: The Federal Reserve System has endorsed the development of a vast, nationwide network of computers to transfer money from one person to another.

title: RAIDERS BLANKED 2D STRAIGHT GAME
description: Last night's game against the Philadelphia Blazers at Madison Square Garden was a little embarrassing for the New York Raiders.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 2, 1973

title: Bowl Games
description: Southern California walloped Ohio State, 4217, yesterday at Pasadena by scoring.35 points in the last two quarters. The rout clinched national college football championship honors for the Trojans. The leader of the U.S.C. offense was Sam Cunningham, who scored four touchdowns to break a Rose Bowl record.

title: 4 Who Visited Hanoi Tell of Destruction
description: Four Americans who returned from Hanoi Sunday night with hundreds of letters from American prisoners of war described yesterday as overwhelming the destruction they had seen in the city as a result of United States bombing raids.

title: Arthur Daley
description: One of the first news bulletins of the new year hit with a sickening jolt. In the emotionless language of radio bulletins, announcement was made early yesterday that a plane on a mercy mission to stricken Nicaragua went crashing into the Carribbean and that Robert Clemente, one of the Samaritans aboard the relief plane, presumably crashed to his death with it.

title: Few in Laos Foresee End of War There As Negotiations Go On in a Ritual Fashion
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 1This is a season of wedding and parties, and the better Chinese restaurants have been ful of celebrators nearly every night.

title: WELFARE SYSTEM OVER U.S. SCORED
description: Good management of welfare programs that cost the nation about $24billion a year may be impossible under the complexities of present laws and rules, according to a Congressional staff study.

title: Clemente a Player Involved On and Off the Diamond
description: The way Roberto Clemente died had more to do with the way he had lived than all the spectabular baseball statistics for which, in due course, he will be enshrined in the Hall of Fame.

title: WOMAN VOTERS HAIL 35 FOR KEY VOTES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) Fourteen Senators and 21 Representatives voted 100 per cent in the last session of Congress on issues supported by the League of Women Voters, the league reported today.

title: CEREMONY MARKS BRITAIN'S ENTRY
description: LONDON, Jan. 1Britain's entry into the European Common Market today was formally marked by a ceremony in Westminster Abbey and informally by absenteeism among tens of thousands of British workers.

title: Pope Calls for End to Wars
description: ROME, Jan. 1Pope Paul VI, reported to he recovering from influenza, said in a brief noonday address today that war could and must be banished just as disease, illiteracy and hunger could be defeated.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Morgan Stanley Admits 2 as General Partners
description: Morgan Stanley & Co., announced yesterday the admission of Lewis W. Bernard and Archibald Cox Jr., to the banking house as general partners. They were also elected managing directors of Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc.

title: Subway Schedules In Queens Changing Amid Some Protest
description: Major changes in schedules on the Jamaica and Rockaway subway lines will go into effect todayover the objections of some of the regular users,

title: MRS. ELMER A. CARTER
description: Mrs. Thelma Johnson Carter, wife of Elmer A. Carter, former chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, died Friday at their home, 409 Edgecombe Avenue. She was a dress designer until her marriage.

title: Researchers Are Studying Ear Wax for Genetic Clues on Diseases and Body Conditions
description: For years, doctors have routinely removed plugs of wax from their patients' ears. Now, some are testing the oily, sticky substance in efforts to learn more about many diseases and physiologic conditions, including cancer, metabolism and heart disease, immunologic resistance to infections, and underarm body odor.

title: Rev. Pierce Brennan Dead; Pastor in Brooklyn Was 58
description: The Rev. Pierce Brennan, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent de Paul in Brooklyn and an Army chaplain in World War II and Korea, died Sunday after surgery in St. John's Hospital, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 58 years old and resided in the rectory, at 167 North Sixth Street in Brooklyn.

title: Expanded Common Market Fields New Executive Team
description: BRUSSELSThe newly expanded European Common Market has fielded a bigger, younger, politically more sensitive executive team for its stretch version.

title: U.S.C. Trounces Ohio State, 4217; Nebraska Scores, 406, Over Irish
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 The Southern California Trojans sewed up the 1972 national college football championship with a smashing 4217 victory over the Ohio State Buckeyes before 106,869 spectators today in the 59th Rose Bowl game.

title: 14 Haitians and 3 Jamaicans Seized by Police in Florida
description: JUPITER, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP)The police and Federal agents seized 14 Haitians and three Jamaicans early Monday after a 35foot sailboat ran aground in rough seas at Jupiter Inlet, officials said.

title: Miss Coca Injures an Eye in Crash
description: Imogene Coca, the comedienne, suffered a ruptured right eyeball in an automobile accident near St. Petersburg, Fla., early, yesterday. She was flown to New York and, after an operation last night at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, a hospital spokesman said the rupture had been repaired but the prognosis for her vision was guarded.

title: New Year's Eve Just a Busy Night for Professional Bartender
description: It is precisely midnight, the new year is beginning, and all about him people are kissing one another and breaking balloons. Mose Peracchio, however, is touched by none of it. He is adding up a check.

title: China, Showing New Candor, Reports Drop in '72 Grain Yield
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 1  Reflecting a new candor in Chinese economic reporting, Peking's official Hsinhua press agency has publicly disclosed that China's grain production for 1972 was less than in 1971.

title: HolidayCruise Business Declines Sharply Here
description: Once the two days after New Year's Day and Labor Day were the peak periods in the port's passenger shipping.

title: Vincente K. Tibbs Dies at 59; ExHead of Englewood Council
description: Vincente K. Tibbs, former president of the City Council of Englewood, N.J., died on Sun day of complications following surgery at Englewood Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 516 Shepard Avenue in Englewood.

title: An American G.I. in London Finds Success as a Designer
description: LONDONIn 1958, Hylan Booker was a 19yearold black G.I. from Detroit stationed at the smallest active combat base in England. He wanted to become a dress designer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Continuing their sevenyear fight for the abolition of the city's alimony jail and the creation of fair divorce laws in the state, 20 members and sympathizers of the Committee of Fair Divorce and Alimony Laws demonstrated for an hour in front of the alimony jail. Most of the demonstrators were men but a few women and children participated. The city's alimony jail, known formally as the Civil Jail, is at 434 West 37th Street.

title: 50 Skiers Injured in Idaho
description: BURLEY, Idaho, Jan. 1 (AP)Tan skiers were seriously injured and about 40 suffered minor injuries today when a chair lift malfunctioned at Pomerelle Ski Area about 18 miles south of here, officials said. Three physicians skiing in the area when the accident occurred began helping the ski patrol provide emergency treatmment.

title: U.S. to Sell Bonds Under New Method
description: The treasury will auction $625million of 20year bonds Thursdaythe longestmaturing issue it has sold since 1965under a new uniform price technique designed to attract investors who do not regularly bid for Government securities.

title: More Growth at Fast Pace ForecastForum Sees Inflation Problem
description: Economic growth is expected to continue at a rapid pace this year in the United States, accompanied by continuing inflationary pressures that Will pose problems for both businessmen and policy makers, according to the 26th annual Economic Formum of The Conference Board.

title: COLLEGE RESULTS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (RadioWNBC, 7:25 P.M.)

title: Walkout by 12 Unions in Its 33d Day, With Both Sides Remaining Far Apart
description: Unions and management remained far apart yesterday in the Long Island Rail Road strike. There was no sign of any break in the 33dayold impasse, the longest in the line's history.

title: Bars Roll Out The Carpet On 18YearOld Drinkers
description: SAYREVILLE, Jan. 1 There's going to be a lot of young people partying in this state from now on, said an 18yearold as she waited outside a bar New Year's Eve.

title: Nigeria Switches Currency
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)  Nigeria officially changed her currency today to the decimal system, The new notes and coins, the naira and kobo, replace pounds, shillings and pence, but will not go into circulation until tomorrow when banks reopen after the New Year holiday.

title: Israelis Strengthen Laws and Police Efforts to Fight Rise in Violent Crime
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 1Concerned by a striking increase in violent crime, particularly in the five years since the 1967 war, Israeli authorities are moving to tighten their criminal statutes and toughen their police techniques.

title: Going to Work Over Ground Zero
description: B52's have been shot down, and this turn of events Is bound to shake up the outlook of our bigbomber crews. Perhaps the outlook can stand a little shaking up, and I say this after having talked with a number of B52 fliers home on leave before the start of our latest blitz. Their mentality, I found, was that of men who considered themselves above the battle, so to speak, of operatives who felt that theirs was but to do while others died.

title: Business Briefs
description: Earnings of the nation's largest banks should increase 10 per cent this year, M. A. Schapiro & Co., Inc., a leading dealer in bank securities, said yesterday.

title: Zambia's Leader Frees 35, Including ExVice President
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 1 President Kenneth D. Kaunda has ordered the release from detention of former Vice President Simon M. Kapwepwe and 34 other members of the outlawed United Progressive party.

title: Rodgers's 4 Touchdowns. Highlight of Orange Bowl
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1  Johnny Rodgers showed why he was the Heisman Trophy winner as he led Nebraska to a shocking 406 victory over Notre Dame in the Orange Bowl tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Continuing their sevenyear fight for the abolition the city's alimony jail and the creation of fair divorce laws in the state, 20 members and sympathizers of the Committee of Fair Divorce and Alimony Laws demonstrated for an hour in front of the alimony jail. Most the demonstrators were men but a few women and children participated. The city's alimony jail, known formally as the Civil Jail, is at 434 West 37th Street.

title: Edward G. Robinson III
description: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 1 (AP)Edward G. Robinson was described in satisfactory condition today at Mount Sinai Hospital, where he was admitted Saturday night for a series of laboratory tests. The actor is 79 years old. The nature of his illness had not been determined, a hospital spokesman said.

title: George Sharp, 75, Lawyer With Will St. Firm, Is Dead
description: KATONAH, N. Y., Jan. 1George C. Sharp, a member of the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, 48 Wall Street, New York, died yesterday at Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco. His age was 75.

title: Fighting Saints Tie Aeros, 44, in Debut At St. Paul Arena
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 1 (AP) The Houston Aeros and Minnesota Fighting Saints played a 44 tie tonight in the first game at the new St. Paul Civic Center.

title: Nixon Pledges Allegiance to Redskins
description: President Nixon pledged allegiance yesterday to the Washington Redskins in the Super Bowl game against the Miami Dolphins, his choice year ago.

title: Market Place:
description: The concept is a popular one these days. Why go to a bank to earn interest in savings when you can take those same dollars and invest them more directly in the kind of securities the savings bank or commercial bank buys itself?

title: FREDERIC R. PETERSON
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 1Frederic R. Peterson, executive vice president of Laidlaw & Co., security brokers, and senior comanager of the Princeton office, died Saturday at West Palm Beach, Fla. His age was 60.

title: Major Revision of State's Courts Urged
description: A radical revamping of the state's courtsin which bail would be abolished, judges would be subject to strict discipline and courts would be run by administrative technicians rather than judgeswas proposed yesterday by the Temporary Commission on the New York State Court System.

title: One of the Jets Hijacked to Cuba Reportedly Had Nuclear Cargo
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) At least one shipment of nuclear materials sufficient to make an atomic bomb has been aboard a United States passenger jetliner hijacked to Cuba, according to an article in the January issue of The Washington Monthly magazine.

title: BULLETS' RALLY TOPS BUCKS, 8887
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 1 (AP)The Baltimore Bullets, scoreless for the first six minutes, 39 seconds, battled back for an 8887 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight. Mike Riordan's long jumper with 57 seconds left gave the Bullets the lead.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Having, over the years, offered what I assumed was terse, competent advice to correspondents on what equipment they should take with them on light tackle fishing ventures to Florida or the islands in the sun, I was unprepared for the indecision that beset me the last few days.

title: Prevention of Disputes Called Hope for Labor
description: Preventive mediation aimed at forestalling serious labor disputes and strikes is the real hope for the future in labor peacemaking, according to Frank H. Brown, who retired last week as regional director here of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: And Maybe Taxes Won't Go Up
description: No one, to my knowledge, has said a Federal tax increase is clearly inevitable, but it has, been asserted that an increase (in 1974, presumably) is all but inevitable. The reasoning is that uncontrollable expenditures will increase so much faster than tax receipts that the budget will be hopelessly out of balance for years to come, with cumulating deficits so large as to be explosively inflationary.

title: Books of The Times
description: ESSAYS IN BIOGRAPHY. By John Maynard Keynes. 460 pages. St. Martin's Press. $9.50.

title: 70 HURT IN A RIOT ON FLORIDA BEACH
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 1 (UPI)  More than 70 people were injured early today when 150 policemen battled an angry mob of thousands of New Year's revelers with nightsticks and tear gas along halfmile stretch of resort beach.

title: New Prosecutor in Bronx to Seek A Cooperative Effort With Nadjari
description: Mario Merola, who took over yesterday, as Bronx District Attorney, said he would request an interview at the earliest possible opportunity with Maurice H. Nadjari to seek cooperative effort that he said had been absent in the past in the special anticorruption prosecutor's dealings with some of the District Attorneys of New York City.

title: Williams Overseas Elects
description: Williams Brothers Overseas Company, Ltd., has announced the election as president of George C. Littlejohn. The company, which is a leading pipeline concern, also named Joseph E. Donnigan as senior vice president and manager of Eastern Hemisphere operations.

title: Bowl Games
description: ROSE

title: Thieu's Supporters Cool To Resumption of Talks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 1The announcement that the United. States and North Vietnam would resume their private peace talks in Paris next Monday has prompted a cool reaction here among supporters of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: A Man of Two Worlds
description: Tom Seaver sat by the Christmas tree yesterday in his home in Greenwich, Conn., and reflected on the life and times of Roberto Walker Clemente. He agreed that the key word in everything Clemente did for 38 years, nearby half of them in the big leagues, was passion.

title: Redskins To Notice Mumphord
description: While winning the American Conference championship and a trip to the Super Bowl on Sunday, the Miami Dolphins lost Tim Foley, their regular left cornerback on defense. Foley suffered a shoulder separation and his absence in the coming Super Bowl game relates to a strength of the foe, the Washington Redskins, like a tight jersey over a bicep.

title: THOMAS J. NEVINS
description: Thomas J. Nevins, a senior partner in the law firm of Conboy, Hewitt, O'Brien & Boardman and treasurer general of the American Irish Historical Society, died Sunday in Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 68 years old and lived at 8901 Shore Road in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: CONGRESS FACING DRIVE FOR REFORM AS SESSION NEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1With many of the aging power brokers of the past now gone, reformminded Democrats and Republicans will open their drive this week to restore Congress to a greater position of power.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: TEXAS CONQUERS ALABAMA BY 1713
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1 (AP)Alan Lowry, the Texas quarterback, bootlegged the ball 34 yards on a tiptoe run down the left sideline for a touchdown late in the fourth quarter today as the seventhranked Longhorns upset fourthranked Alabama, 1713, in the Cotton Bowl.

title: E.E.C. Lineup Is Marked By Vigor and Experience
description: BRUSSELS  Following are sketches of the men who make up the commission of the European Economic Communitythe body that administers the operations of the European Common Market. With expansion of community to nine members on Jan. 1, the commission, itself has been expanded to 13 memberstwo apiece for the four larger countries, and one for each of other five members.

title: Closed Rule
description: The opening of the 93d Congress provides a fresh opportunity to attack the problem of the irresponsible distribution of power on Capitol Hill. Leadership has have power to make the legislative process work, but that power has to be responsible and accountable. As matters now stand, the central leadership elected by the majority and minority parties has too little power and the committee chairmen chosen under the seniority system have too much.

title: MANILA BOLSTERS FORCES IN SOUTH
description: MANILA, Jan. 1 (UPI)Authorities ordered more troops to the southern Philippines today and predicted more fighting there against rebels whom the Government describes as outlaws and dissidents.

title: Lab Rats Sustained on Substitute Blood
description: BOSTON, Jan. 1Several small white rats are living in apparent contentment in a laboratory here with nothing in their blood vessels to nourish and cleanse their tissue but a milky solution of fluorocarbons and industrial emulsifiers.

title: New Year Wafts In Here in a Blaze of Sunshine
description: The essential facts for understanding Jan. 1, 1973, in the metropolitan area are these: Polar Bear Club members had to throw 20 fivepound blocks of ice into the Coney Island surf to take their normal teethchattering New Year's dip. And no children of the National Weather Service's local staff got sleds for Christmas.

title: CAROL S. JACKTER
description: Carol Susan Jackter, a daughter of Norman Jackter, vice president for distribution of Columbia Pictures, was one of those killed Friday night in the crash of an Eastern Airlines jet near Miami. She was 20 years old.

title: Steuben Glass Appoints
description: Thomas S. Buechner has been named president of Steuben Glass, a division of the Corning Glass Works. He succeeds Arthur A. Houghton Jr., chairman of Corning Glass.

title: Jersey Rolls Out Carpet for 18YearOld Drinkers
description: SAYREVILLE, N. J., Jan. 1There's going to be a lot of yoang people partying in this state from now on, said an 18yearold as she waited outside a bar New Year's Eve.

title: Redlich Names Aide
description: The City Corporation Counsel, Norman Redlich, announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph Halpern as chief of the Penalties Division of the Law Department. Mr. Halpern, assistant chief of the Penalties Division since 1966, succeeds Israel Rubin, recently elected a judge of the Civil Court.

title: Discipline in the Economy
description: Any time the President and Congress have a falling out over money, the American economy subject to their joint stewardship is bound to be caught in a political crossfire. America's last crisis of economics was provoked by the guerrilla war in Vietnam. The possibility that America may be entrapping herself in a new domestic guerrilla war in Washington has now become a clear and present danger.

title: Both Sides Gird for Renewal of Fight on Legalized Abortion, Explosive Legislative Issue
description: In 1970, when abortion on demand was legalized in New York State, its opponents, led by the Roman Catholic Church, said they had been taken by surprise.

title: Chess: With Such a Big Talent Pool Russia Has to Make Waves
description: No national championship other than that of the Soviet Union could qualify as one of the strongest events in the world even with half a dozen or more of the country's top players not competing. Three former world champions  Boris Spassky, Tigran Petrosian and Vasily Smyslovalong with Viktor Korchnoi, Efim Geller, Anatoly Karpov and Paul Keres, were among the missing in the 1972 Soviet Championship, yet it retains its supreme status.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Prisons:
description: DURHAM, N. C.Dr. Martin Groder, the young director of the new Federal Center for Correctional Research at Camp Butner, near here, looks on the traditional American prison system as a sort of lastditch welfare system for young, healthy malesmen who are ineligible for most regular welfare programs but who don't have the skills or the opportunity to earn a living.

title: PAUSE IN BOMBING IS ENDED BY U.S., OFFICIAL SINDICATE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 2  American warplanes this afternoon resumed their raids in South Vietnam and in North Vietnam below the 20th Parallel after 36hour pause to observe a New Year's Day ceasefire, American officials indicated.

title: RAIDERS BLANKED 2D STRAIGHT GAME
description: Last night's game against the Philadelphia Blazers at Madison Square Garden was a little embarrassing for the New York Raiders.

title: Soviet Defector, 21, Dies On Coast, Apparent Suicide
description: RUNNING SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)Sergei Kourdakov, a former Soviet submarine officer who defected in 1971, was found dead today, an apparent suicide, the authorities said.

title: Bombing Halt Brings Relief to B52 Crews in Guam
description: ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam, Jan. 1The halt in the intensive American bombing of North Vietnam has brought a touch of relief, but only a little letup in action to the B52 flight and ground crews here.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Peggy Hookham has decided to write her autobiography. Miss Hookham, as ballet fans throughout the world will tell you, is better known as Dame Margot Fonteyn, and fans hope she will dwell on her continuing, extraordinary 38year career.

title: Health Unit Expands Pediatric Care
description: When Mrs. Evelyn Richardson arrived at the childhealth station at the Polo Grounds housing project the other day, she was greeted with a surprise.

title: Boy Beaten Last Autumn Dies in St. Louis Hospital
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1 (AP)A 4yearold boy who had been badly beaten and whose infant brother was found beaten to death in a shallow grave, died yesterday at Cardinal Glennon Children's Hospital, the police said.

title: Georgia Newspaper Sold
description: CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Jan. 1 (AP)John T. Fleetwood, editor, publisher and owner of The Daily Tribune News and Herald Tribune, has sold the newspapers to Carnage Walls & Associates, of Montgomery, Ala. In a joint announcement today Mr. Fleetwood and Charles E. Hurley, the new editor and publisher, said the sale was effective Jan. 1, 1973.

title: A Novelist Speaks of Work and Love
description: LONDON  In her novels, short stories and screenplays, Edna O'Brien examines the everyday trials and the enduring tortures of woman's condition. But for herself occasionally the dominant note is triumph.

title: Getajetholme Triumphs on Calder Grass
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1R. E. Sessa's Getajetholme, a horse who can't get out of his own way on the dirt, but one who can almost fly on the grass, won the 64,000 William McKnight Handicap today at Calder Race Course. The Ogden Phipps entry of Daring Young Man and Outdoors finished second and third, respectively.

title: 7 Gypsies Die in Plunge
description: CAEN, France, Jan. 1 (AP)The police reported that a car Yugoslav gypsies skidded on frosty road today and careened into 16 fet of water at the port of Caen, killing seven persons.

title: Respect for the Land
description: With the awarding of an $18million contract for completing Interstate Route 684, New York State has another opportunity to build at least part of a major highway with some regard for the land and the environment.

title: A Class's Gift to Neediest Follows a Tradition
description: Ever since 1961, Class 4322 at Public School 232 in Howard Beach, Queens, has contributed to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: New Year Wafts In Here in a Blaze of Sunshine
description: The essential facts for understanding Jan. 1, 1973, in the metropolitan area are these: Polar Bear Club members had to throw 20 fivepound blocks of ice into the Coney Island surf to take their normal teethchattering New Year's dip. And no children of the National Weather Service's local staff got sleds for Christmas.

title: BROMWELL AULT OF INMONT CORP
description: Bromwell Ault, who retiree in 1971 as vice chairman of the Inmont Corporation, manufac turers of printing inks and re lated products,, died Thursday at the ColumbiaPresbyteria?? Medical Center. He was 7?? yeard old and lived at 980 Fifth Avenue and in Edgartown, Mass

title: U.S.C. Trounces Ohio State, 4217; Nebraska Scores, 406, Over Irish
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 The Southern California Trojans sewed up the 1972 national college football championship with a smashing 4217 victory over the Ohio State Buckeyes before 106,869 spectators today in the 59th Rose Bowl game.

title: A New Political Orthodoxy Is Asserting Itself in Liberal Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 1  Something enigmatic, with much sound and fury, has been going on in Yugoslavia since September, and it is hard to find any two people who can agree on a coherent, convincing explanation as yet.

title: CEREMONY MARKS BRITAIN'S ENTRY
description: LONDON, Jan. 1Britain's entry into the European Common Market today was formally marked by a ceremony in Westminster Abbey and informally by absenteeism among tens of thousands of British workers.

title: Police Identify 3 Bodies Found at 2 Sites in Bronx
description: Police detectives in the Bronx identified three bodies yesterday that had been found in two places the day before. In each case the police discounted earlier speculation that the murders were gangland executions.

title: Dakin Williams to Run
description: COLLINSVILLE, Ill., Jan. 1 (AP)Dakin Williams, a Collinsville lawyer and brother of Tennessee Williams, the playwright, announced last night that he would be a candidate for the Senate seat now occupied by Adlai E. Stevenson 3d in the March, 1974, Democratic primary election.

title: Search Is Pressed for 12 Of 15 Escaped Prisoners
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (UPI) The authorities searched tolay for 12 of 15 inmates who slipped away in a mass escape from the dilapidated Orleans Parish prison early Saturday.

title: Football Bowl Games
description: COTTON BOWL

title: Lab Rats Sustained on Substitute Blood
description: BOSTON, Jan. 1Several small white rats are living in apparent contentment in a laboratory here with nothing in their blood vessels to nourish and cleanse their tissue but a milky solution of fluorocarbons and industrial emulsifiers.

title: Books Rival Athletics at the U. of Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 1The University of Texas's preeminent football teams fill its 70,000seat stadium on autumn afternoons with admiring old graduates who come to cheer and it is hoped will keep alumni gifts flowing in.

title: Sports Today
