description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: STRIKE ON PENNSY IS SET FOR FRIDAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Negotiators for the Penn Central Railroad and the United Transportation Union met today in an effort to head off a strike scheduled to begin next Friday at 12:01 A.M. that could further cripple New York City's cornmuter rail service.

title: Israel Will Release Bodies Of 2 Terrorists, as Thais Ask
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 5 (UPI)Israel has agreed to a plea from Thailand that the bodies of two Palestinian guerrillas killed in an attempt to hijack a Sabena airliner at the Tel Aviv airport last year be returned to their families, the Thai Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Experts Confer for a 4th Day in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 5 (AP)Technical experts of the United States and North Vietnam met today for the fourth day in a row on detailed points that could be part of an Indochina ceasefire agreement. The major points must be worked out in sessions starting here Monday between Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, and Le Duc Tho, a member of the Hanoi Politburo.

title: Screen: Tangled Motives:'Spider's Stratagem' at the New Yorker The Cast
description: "The Spider's Stratagem" is an elaborate, theatrical plot uncovered by the son of a murdered anti-Fascist hero, 30 years after the murder, when he is called back to his father's town by the dead man's former mistress. In a series of curious, dreamlike encounters with the mistress and with the men who were his father's comrades, the young man discovers that his father had been a traitor to what seems to have been a comic opera plot on Mussolini's life.Much more than his "Partner," which was shown at the 1968 New York Film Festival, Bernardo Bertolucci's "The Spider's Stratagem" recalls the Stendhalian world of his best film, "Before the Revolution," which also had to do with self-deception, political action compromised and motives almost hopelessly tangled. The settings, too, are similar, provincial towns that seem to be millions of miles from where the real action is taking place.The film's color photography is extraordinarily lovely for, like the conspirators within the film, Bertolucci has a weakness for the purely theatrical effect. Of the players, I particularly liked Alida Valli, as the aging mistress, a tough, lean lady who lives in a style fitting an impoverished princess, but who walks around, barefooted and untidy, like a peasant."The Spider's Stratagem," which has opened at the New Yorker Theater, was shown at the ninth New York Film Festival. The following excerpts are from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared Sept. 18, 1970, in The New York Times.

title: Boys' 3Story Fort in Princeton Falls To a Powerful Foe, the Zoning Board
description: PRINCETON, Jan. 5  A group of youngsters who built a fort out of fence rails, shutters, shingles and a lot of imagination ran afoul of something last night that never existed in their wildest dreamsa Zoning Board of Adjustment.

description: EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 5 (AP)Quintuplets three girls and two boyswere born today to Mr. and Mrs. James Baer of Northbrook, the young couple's first children.

title: Kerry's Brother Charged
description: LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 5 (AP) The brother of John F. Kerry, an antiwar leader, and another man were formally charged yesterday with breaking and entering in connection with an incident during Mr. Kerry's campaign for Congress last year. Cameron Kerry and Thomas J. Valley were ordered in Lowell District Court Thursday to appear before Middlesex Superior Court on the charges.

description: BONN, Jan. 5The perennial problem of West Germany's coal industryhigh costwas highlighted this week by the threat of the country's biggest coking coal user to back out of the federally sponsored Ruhr Coal Company.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The Treasury announced today the imposition of special countervailing duties on imports of tires from a plant in Canada of the French Michelin company.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 5  The leader of a fiveman delegation of legislators whom President Nguyen Van Thieu is sending to Washington next week says their mission will be to persuade Congress to keep providing and even to increase American military and economic assistance to South Vietnam if there is no peace soon.

title: ALUMINUM PRICES RAISED BY ALCOA
description: The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it would raise prices for aluminum rigid container sheet, beginning with orders and shipments Feb. 16.

title: Business Booming at Blood Center
description: The newest S.R.O. spot on the East Side does not play music and serves only orange juice and coffee. Yet people wait in line two hours to get in.

title: L.I. Man, 24, Is Arrested On MurderAttempt Charge
description: ROOSEVELT, L.I., Jan. 5 (UPI)A 24yearold Long Island man was arrested last night and charged with attempted murder following a barroom dispute in which he allegedly tried to shoot his adversaries, according to the Nassau County Police.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JANUARY 6, 1973
description: President Nixon told a bipartisan group of Congressional leaders at a White House breakfast yesterday that although he knew many of them objected to his Vietnam policies, he was determined to do what he regarded as necessary to achieve a proper kind of settlement. He said that he was neither optimistic nor pessimisticonly hopefulabout the prospects for a negotiated agreement in the ceasefire talks, which resume on Monday between Henry A. Kissinger and Le Due Tho. [Page 1, Column 1.1

title: PROTESTS PLANNED FOR INAUGUARATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Calling for an inauguration of conscience, two antiwar organizations announced plans today to cosponsor a demonstration in Washington on Saturday, Jan. 20, Inauguration Day.

title: Steel Importers Elect
description: Ernst Wimpfheimer has been elected president of the American Institute for Imported Steel, a trade association that represents the $2,5billion steel import industry. He had served in similar capacity in 19621963. Mr. Wimpfheimer succeeded Victor V. Shick of the Indussa Corporation. The group's program aims to foster trade and use within this country of imported steel.

title: Britain Is Willing to Limit Her Fish Catch Off Iceland
description: THE HAGUE, Jan. 5 (AP) Britain said today that she was prepared to limit her fish catch off Iceland if it was acceptable to both sides in the controversy over fishing rights.

title: On the British Seafront, Kosher Cuisine With an English Accent.
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England  Green Park is on East Overcliff Drive, but it is not out of Jane Eyre or Wuthering Heights. In fact, it is rarely out of anything. This is the site of the ever abnormal granary, the perenlally bubbling soda bottle, the eternally enticing kishka.

title: LIVE BEEF, HOGS, PORK BELLIES OFF
description: Prices for live beef cattle, hogs, pork bellies and potatoes closed yesterday below their recent highs.

title: Court and Congress to Clash on Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A major collision between Congress and the Supreme Court is developing over the enactment of new rules of evidence for the Federal court system.

title: Truman Honored By World Notables At Cathedral Rites
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5With solemn words and music, Government officials and diplomats mourned and memorialized Harry S. Truman here today.

title: When Dealing With a Horse Around the House
description: KRIPPLEBUSH, N. Y. They had whinnied while galloping around their living rooms. In school, both were great doodlershorses' heads a specialty. Both read the kind of nauseatingly beautiful stories about little girls who awaken on their birthdays to find a horse, a real horse, in the stable.

title: An End to the War? Who Needs It?
description: WASHINGTONHenry Kissinger's statement on the reasons for the failure of peace negotiations has made one thing perfectly clear. In the same way that we have been unable to explain the reason for American military involvement in South Vietnam, we are now unable to explain in precise detail the type of peace we are seeking. We ought not blame Mr. Kissinger or his fellow negotiator from North Vietnam for failure to achieve peace in Southeast Asia. The fact is that none of the combatants has compelling reasons to end the war at this time.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTVALE, N. J., Jan. 5Howard Larson, president of the Boating Industry Association, said recently that 20 per cent of the nation's population (about 42 million persons) enjoyed boating in some form or other. It is hoped at least, that they enjoy it.

title: U.S. GROUP FAILS IN CHINA MISSION
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 5An American academic delegation has apparently met no success in efforts during a visit to Peking to arrange regular cultural exchanges between China and the United States.

title: RANGERS OPPOSE NEMESES: SABRES
description: The Buffalo Sabres, the precocious expansion team that has perfected the knack of embarrassing the New York Rangers, come to Madison Square Garden this afternoon with the objective of beating the Rangers for the fourth time in four meetings this season. The Sabres are the only team in the National Hockey. League that has defeated the Rangers three times.

title: AntiDefamation League Barred in Arab Group Title
description: State Supreme Court Justice George C. Mantzoros ruled yesterday that an organization callng itself the Arab AntiDefaznation League may no longer use that name,

title: POLICE CHIEF LAUDS A NOBAIL PROGRAM
description: ENFIELD, Conn., Jan. 5 (AP) The Police Chief here says threemonth experiment in releasing certain pretrial suspects without cash bond has worked.

title: MISS HIGGINS LEADS MIAMI GOLF WITH 68
description: MIAMI, Jan. 5 (AP)Pam Higgins tied the women's record at the Doral Country Club's Red Course today with a fourunderpar 68 to take the firstround lead in the $30,000 Burdine's invitation golf tournament.

title: Methadone Death Laid to Confusion Over 2 Marerros
description: A 16yearold boy, whose death was apparently caused by a Bellevue physician's prescription of methadone, was given the drug because he had been mistaken for another person of the same name, according to Dr. Milton Helpern, the, city's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: JERRY BUTLER SINGS SOUL AT COPACABANA
description: Jerry Butler, the black soul singer, opened at midtown's Copacabana club (a room becoming more expansive but not less expensive) with a show that could be slotted easily into Harlem's Apollo Theater and illustrating the changing and perhaps increasing audience for soul music. Butler, who carries a fourgirl singing group and his own musicians with him, is known as the Iceman, tribute to his alleged cool approach to his work.

title: DR. SAUL D. SCHIFF
description: Dr. Saul D. Schiff, a podiatrist, who had practiced in the Wall Street area for 40 years, died Thursday in Miami. He was 65 years old and lived at 7949 210th Street in Flushing, Queens.

title: Tomorrow Is Christmas For Eastern Orthodox
description: The Rev. Joseph Kreta, his wife and two boys will fast today until the first star appears in the evening sky.

title: $55.2Million PhoneRate Rise Approved for New Jersey Bell
description: NEWARK, Jan. 5The Board of Public Utility Commissioners announced today that it had approved with only minor variations a $55.2million tariff increase for the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company that, among other things, includes a rise of almost 100 per cent in new residential and business telephone installations.

title: Health Services Chief Is Seeking $48.1Million Drug Budget Rise
description: The head of the city's Health Services Administration asked yesterday for an 80 per cent increase over the present $63.1million budget of the Addiction Services Agency to intensify and broaden the attack on the drug abuse problem here.

title: Soviet Rebuffs Western Appeals To Ease the Exchange of Ideas
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 5The So. viet Union today rebuffed demands by some Western nations for easier EastWest exchanges as a part of the era of improving political and economic relations.

title: BIG BOARD MOVE SET ON RAPIDAMERICAN
description: The NeW York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would suspend trading in the $3.15 cumulative preferred stock of the RapidAmerican Corporation, which recently merged with the Glen Alden Corporation. The suspension will be effective before the market opening Monday after which application will be made to the Securities and Exchange Commission to delist the issue.

title: U.S. ASKS REHEARING ON I.B.M. DOCUMENTS
description: The Justice Department yesterday petitioned the United States Court of Appeals to hear new arguments on its plea for access to 1,200 documents of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Connecticut Seeks Funds
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 5 (AP)State Labor Commissioner Jack A. Fusari is being sent to Washington in an attempt to obtain $809,000 in frozen Federal funds, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill announced today. These funds are vital for the operation of Connecticut's employment service and unemployment compensation program, the Governor said.

title: TV: An Intelligent Discussion of Population Issue
description: Once again the subject is population, or at least those aspects of the subject covered by the Population Commission in a special report to President Nixon last spring. An official film version of the report was shown on public television several weeks ago. It was disappointing, primarily because it was too broad and too slick, almost divertingly pretty.

title: CLEMENTE PLANE NOT OVERLOADED
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 5 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board said today the crash that took the life of Roberto Clemente probably had been caused by mechanical error.

title: Stockton, With 136, Leads Los Angeles Golf by a Shot
Earlier Efforts and Errors in War on Drugs
description: Most of the daylight robberies, dazing holdups, cruel murders and similar crimes of violence are now known to be committed chiefly by drug ad dicts, who constitute the primary cause of our alarming crime wave.

title: PRESIDENT INSISTS ON A PROPERKINIY OF VIETNAM PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 President Nixon told a group of Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders today that although he knew many of them objected to his Vietnam policies, he was determined to do what he regarded as necessary to achieve a proper kind of settlement.

title: Coalition Fears Reported Housing Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A coalition of organizations interetted in housing programs asserted today that a reported plan for a moratorium or cut in funds for model cities and urban renewal programs would be disastrous economically as well as socially.

title: CURTAILMENT PLAINS ORDERED FOR GAS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 5  The Texas Railroad Commission has ordered that all intrastate natural gas utilities file curtailment programs with the commission by Feb. 12.

title: MARY H. PATTERSON
description: Mrs. Mary Hagelin Patterson, a novelist and the wife of Sam Patterson, also a novelist, died yesterday of cancer in New York Hospital. She was 44 years old and lived at 651 14th Street.

title: Sandra Ross Has Nuptials
description: Miss Sandra Jeannette Ross and Russel Harold Herman Jr., son of Mr. Herman of Atlanta and the late Mrs. Madelyn Beck Herman, were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. John R. Gosney performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: NIXON INCREASES SCOPE OF DUTIES FOR 3 IN CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5President Nixon announced today that he was placing into effect, as far as he was able by Executive order, the Government reorganization plan that he pro.posed in early 1971 but Congress declined to enact.

title: Bible Read in 85 Hours
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Jan, 5 (UPI)  More than 30 United States Governors, Senators, Representatives, and foreign dignitaries, including Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethopia, read the Bible in 85 hours and 29 minutes in the fourth annual New Year's Bible reading. The reading, in live and prerecord'1 ed shifts, was held at the headquarters of the Voice of Prophecy, the radio agency of the Adveatists.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Mrs. Forrester Dies
description: Mrs. Mae Forrester, mother of Maureen Forrester, the Canadian contralto, died Wednesday in the Baycrest Hospital, Toronto. She was 76 years old and lived in Montreal, Surviving are two sisters and two other daughters.

title: Many Nicaraguans Want To Return to Capital Site
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 1There is almost nothing left to the center of this lakeside capital but gay Christmas tinsel fluttering over piles of smashed concrete and charred rubble.

title: PRESIDENT INSISTS ON A PROPER KIND OF VIETNAM PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5President Nixon told a group of Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders today that although he knew many of them objected to his Vietnam policies, he was determined to do what he regarded as necessary to achieve a proper kind of settlement.

title: Art of Male Vanity Seen in a Show, Him
description: It is sufficient, as a recommendation, to say that the exhibition called Him at Cordier & Ekstrom, 980 Madison Avenue at 76th Street, is a worthy successor to She, an exhibition held two years ago at the same gallery and greeted with huzzahs. Him's satirical comment on male vanity (not explicit in the works of art, but inherent in their selection and combination), together with a scrupulously demanding standard of quality from object to object, gives the show a combination of virtues comparable only to that of its predecessor.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market advanced yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Tishman Elected Head Of Real Estate Board
description: The Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., has announced that Robert V. Tishman, the president of Tishman Realty & Construction Co., Inc., has been elected chairman of its board.

title: What Other Countries Do
description: A severely punitive approach to addiction, as recommended Wednesday by Governor Rockefeller, is not unknown in other parts of the world, where traffickers are occasionally shot.

title: COOP CITY MARKET GETS 95 VIOLATIONS
description: A food market in CoOp City in the Bronx has been issued 95 violations, 89 of them for selling shortweight fruits and vegetables, Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson announced yesterday.

title: THOMAS P. PAPROCKI, SPORTS CARTOONIST
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan 5  Thomas P. Paprocki, who drew a daily sports cartoon land wrote an accompanying sports column for The Associated Press for almost 35 years until he retired six years ago, died yesterday on the way to Atlantic City Hospital. He was 171 years old.

title: San Francisco: City That Waits to Die
description: Authorities don't know exactly when, according to a television documentary called San Francisco: The City That Waits to Die, but that metropolitan area, devastated by an earthquake in 1906, will definitely be dealt another such major blow. So contends a small army of seismologists, scientists, engineers and government spokesmen in the hourlong program to be televised tomorrow night at 9 over WNEW and repeated next Saturday at 5 P.M.

title: Witness in Mafioso Tax Trial Admits Past Perjury
description: A major witness in a taxevasion case acknowledged yesterday that he was awaiting trial on bribery charges, that he had failed to file incometax returns and that he had lied under oath to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: The Story Mr. Zero Tells
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y.He lives in a backwater Vermont town and works at a nearby ski resort as laborer and handyman. A sturdy, roughlooking New Englander of about 60, his eyes narrow when he talks as though he were concealing a poker hand. But if you watch his face closely you see that they are hurt eyes, angry eyes.

title: WILBUR DE PARIS, BANDLEADER, 72
description: Wilbur de Paris, bandleader and trombonist who played New Orleans jazz more than 50 years, died Wednesday in Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 72 years old and had his studio at 17 Sixth Avenue.

title: Canadians Deplore Raids In Unanimous House Vote
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 5The Canadian House of Commons voted unanimously today to deplore the recent United States air attacks on the Hanoi and Haiphong areas and to urge Washington to refrain from further bombing there.

title: Cougars Farm Out Knibbs
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP)  The Chicago Cougars of the World Hockey Association sent a wing, Darrel Knibbs, to their Rhode Island Eagles club in the Eastern League today.

title: PALOCZIHORVATH, AUTHOR, 64, DIES
description: LONDON, Jan. 5  George PalocziHorvath, the writer who was forced to flee Hungary twice, died here Wednesday at the age of 64.

title: Legal Aid Sues to Bar Change in Arraignment
description: The Legal Aid Society sued in State Supreme Court yesterday to bar Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy from carrying out regulations that would eliminate the need for policemen making arrests and complaining witnesses from appearing at arraignments of defendants in the city's criminal courts.

title: ROCHE SCORES 46 IN NETS' VICTORY
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 5Jim Chones walked up to John Roche in the Nets' locker room after the game tonight and said, Man, that was the greatest exhibition of shooting I've ever seen.

title: Knicks Rout Braves
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 5Bill Bradley, making up for his absent roommate, Dave DeBusschere, led the Knicks to a 129106 victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight by scoring 38 points, his high for a sixseason career in the National Basketball Association.

title: JEROME B. GLUCKSMAN
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 5Jerome B. Glucksman, who since 1960 headed his own interior design firm at 211 East 43d Street in New York, died this morning in New Rochelle Hospital, He was 47 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Architect Testifies He Drafted Remodeling Plans for Cantwell
description: TRENTON, Jan. 5 John J. Boyce, who served as an architect for the New Jersey Department of Defense, testified today that he drew up a set of homeimprovement plans for Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell while the officer, now retired, commanded the New Jersey National Guard.

title: Music: The Watts Way
description: Andr Watts, the current young idol of the keyboard, was the soloist Thursday night with the New York Philharmonic under Pierre Boulez, and he departed from his usual round of romantic music to play Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto. It ended the same anyway, for he played the Beethoven in a romantic manner, and it was an interesting performance, if one not completely realized.

title: QUARRY WINS IN 7 IN RING COMEBACK
description: Terry Quarry, who announced his retirement from the ring last July, a month after losing to Muhammad Ali for the second time, scored a seventhround technical knockout over Randy Neumann last night in his comeback before a crowd of 6,190 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Notes on People
description: Without fanfare, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California stopped flying on commercial airliners 10 months ago because of the possibility of hijacking. Mr. Reagan's office disclosed that he has not been flying on scheduled commercial planes because we felt it was foolhardy for the state ... to take a chance on the Governor being on a plane that was hijacked. A Reagan assistant, Edwin Meese 3d, said, The hijacker looks at the Governor in the seat, and immediately the ransom goes up. He says to himself, whoopie, look what I have here. For months the Governor traveled on rented airplanes, and last week the state announced it was leasing a twinengine Cessna sixseater for two years for $398,906 to fly Mr. Reagan around. The Governor and his wife were also said to have abandoned their policy of never flying together in the same plane for fear that a crash would leave their two children parentless. Their daughter Patti is now 20, and their son Shipper is 14.

title: Truman Honored By World Notables At Cathedral Rites
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5With solemn words and music, Government officials and diplomats mourned and memorialized Harry S. Truman here today.

title: Students Set Fires in Dacca
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 5(Reuters)  Government supporters in the Bangladesh Students League tonight set fire to the national headquarters here of the proMoscow National Awami opposition party. They also burned the headquarters of proMoscow student unions and threw stones at the offices of the proChinese Revolutionary Students Union and the Moscoworiented Communist party.

title: People in Sports: New Rx Is No CureAll
description: When Rick DeMont returns to competition this weekend, the 16yearold swimmer will be using an asthma medicine that would have passed the drug tests at last summer's Olympics in Munich.

title: Dr. Kalma J. DeJuhasz, Diesel Research Authority
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 5 Dr. Kalman J. DeJuhasz, retired professor of engineering, research at the Pennsylvania State University and an authority on diesel research, died Tuesday. He was 79 years old and lived at 423 West Park Avenue.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none.)

title: Trial Set for Man Believed Connected To Smuggling Ring
description: BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 5The trial of a 31yearold man believed linked to a ring allegedly using the bodies of Americans killed in Vietnam to smuggle heroin into the United States was set yesterday for March 12 by Federal Judge James R. Miller Jr.

title: G.M. Share of Auto Sales Slipped in '72
description: DETROIT, Jan 5The General Motors Corporation's share of United States passenger car sales slipped in 1972, while the three other domestic manufacturers increased their shares. G.M. took 51.7 per cent of the market in 1972, compared with 53.6 per cent in 1971. The Ford Motor Company increased its share to 28.6 per cent from 27.4 per cent. The Chrysler Corporation went to 16,3 per cent of sales from 16 per cent and the American Motors Col.poration moved to 3.4 per cent from 3 per cent.

title: Disciplinary Reason Is Given In Bucksvs.Wali Jones Case
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 5 (AP)The president of the Milwaukee Bucks conceded today that the club's suspension of Wali Jones, a guard, was for disciplinary as well as medical reasons.

title: New Lawmakers Welcomed
description: WASHINGTON, Jain. 5 (AP) President wind Mrs. Nixon welcomed freshmen numbers of Congress and a Whit, House reception tonight.

title: Antiquated Rules
description: Brooklyn Assemblyman Stephen Solarz, now a declared candidate for the borough presidency, intends to delay his campaigning for this office long enough to renew an old battle in Albany. For several years now, Mr. Solarz has been leader of a group of relatively young and liberal Democratic legislators intent at least in this instance on nothing more radical than making possible some deliberation in the process of enactment of laws for the State of New York.

title: Dave Anderson
description: After nearly 14 months, the New Yorkization of Earl Monroe is now complete. Dancing Harry has rejoined him. It's as if the trade between the Knicks and the Bullets included a performer to be named later, meaning Dancing Harry, who moved recently to New York from Baltimore, the best step of his career. Under a floppy cap, he will materialize out of the audience tonight at Madison Square Garden, hoofing to the accompaniment of the organ when there's a timeout and when the spirit moves him. The spirit is Earl the Pearl, the inimitable, the dancer in sneakers when time is in.

title: HEART CANCER CITED IN TRANSPLANT CASE
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 5 (UPI)Doctors at the St. Louis University Medical Center said today that the death of Missouri's first heart transplant patientwas due.partly to cancer in the heart he received.

title: 2 Suspended Patrolmen Seized On Charges of Receiving Graft
description: Two suspended patrolmen were arrested yesterday on charges of receiving unlawful gratuities, following a fourmonth investigation into the theft of $15,000 worth of electrical equipment.

title: INCENTIVES URGED FOR U.S. INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI)  Senator Clifford P. Hansen, Republican of Wyoming, proposed today increasing the depletion allowance for domestic coal mines from 10 to 15 per cent as an incentive for larger coal proddction.

title: EXCHICAGO OFFICIAL ADMITS EMBEZZLING
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP)Fred D. Hubbard, a Chicago alderman who vanished for months with funds for a minority hiring program, pleaded guilty today to embezzling $100,000. He was sentenced to serve two years in prison.

title: SteppedUp Bombing Stirs Cedar Rapids
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Jan. 5Almost three years ago a new sign in this city's Butterfly Cafe advised those without shirt or shoes to stay out. Sooner or later, a waitress explained, those filthy kids get on your nerves. She was referring to a small band of college students holding one of this wellgroomed city's few protests against the Vietnam War. Down the street Mayor Donald J. Canney was calling the American invasion of Cambodia a reasonable step and denouncing student protests that produce a violence of their own.

title: Pop Music: At the Apollo
description: Harlem's Apollo Theater has long been the home of black musicians and entertainers, and it still is. But social tensions and timidity have cut down on white attendance. Which is a great pity  for the whites  if Thursday's early show is any indication of the quality of productions there.

title: A PAPERTV SALE NETS 115 MILLION
description: FORT WORTH, Jan. 5 Agreement in principle to sell one of Texas's largest privately owned publishing and broad. casting organizations for $115million was announced here day.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Public Employment Relations Commission yesterday said that a ballot dispute had been resolved and that the Council of New Jersey State Colleges had won the right to represent faculty members at eight state colleges by a single vote.

title: Police Still Searching For Kidnapped Baby
description: The police had nothing new to report yesterday on their search for a weekold baby abducted from his Brooklyn home Wednesday by a hammerwielding woman.

title: ROCKEFELLER 4TH TO HEAD COLLEGE
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 5  John D. Rockefeller 4th, whose term as West Virginia's Secretary of State expires Jan. 15, said today that he had accepted the presidency of West Virginia Wesleyan College in Buckhannon, a town of 6,300 population in the central part of the state.

title: CHILDCARELEAVE FOR MEN BACKED
description: A schoolteacherparent should be entitled to a leave of absence to bring up a new baby, according to the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: New York and California Republicans To Vie for Seat on House Rules Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5With the blessing of Governor Rockefeller, Republican Representatives from New York are preparing to do battle with California Republicans for a seat on the House Rules Committee in the new Congress. When the Republican committeeassignment operation be gins next week, the New Yor plankers plan to make a major effort to put Representative James F. Hastings, Republican of Allegany, on the Rule Committee. At stake is the Rules Committee seat vacated by Representative H. Allen Smith, Republican of California, who did not seek reelection last fall, and the California Republicans are expected to seek to retain Mr. Smith's seat for one of their own, possibly Del. Clawson.

title: Saigon Catholic Group Forms ProGovernment Political Party
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 5Spurred by President. Nguyen Van Thieu's last de cree requiring reorganization of South Vietnam's political parties within the next three months, a group of Roman Catholic politicians have created a new organization they call the Tu Do (Freedom) party.

title: Methadone Death Laid to Confusion Over 2 Marerros
description: A 16yearold boy, whose death was apparently caused by a Bellevue physician's prescription of methadone, was given the drug because he had been mistaken for another person of the same name, according to Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Knicks LineUps
description: AT GARDEN8 P.M.

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: January 5, 1973

title: BALL QUITS AS HEAD OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) President Nixon accepted today the resignation of Social Security Commissioner Robert M. Ball, completing a virtual cleanout of the Health, Education and Welfare Department's top management.

title: KITTY HAWK SAILOR ENTERS GUILTY PLEA
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 5 (UPI)file third man to face a courtmartial for his part in the race riot aboard the Kitty Hawk last October pleaded guilty today to two charges.

title: Adams, Huff in Senior Bowl
description: MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 5 (AP)Utah State's brilliant passing battery, Tony Adams and Tom Forzani, and the national rushing champion, Pete Van Valkenburg of Brigham Young, help make the North a slight favorite over the South in the 24th Senior Bowl football battle tomorrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Presidential Power and Responsibility

title: Painterly Subtleties Fill Work of Scott
description: The British painter William Scott, who will observe his 60th birthday on Feb. 15, is an artist of uncommon distinction  not only the best painter of his generation in England, but one of the best anywhere. Although he is not as wellknown in New York as his work warrants  10 years have passed since his last oneman show herehis stature has long been recognized in European art circles.

title: Egypt's Students: Privileged but Rebellious
description: CAIRO, Jan. 5The students who vented their discontent here this week are Egypt's privileged class of the future and, to a lesser degree, of the present.

title: Cycle Gang Members Held
description: EL PASO, Jan. 5 (AP) Three members of a motorcycle gang were ordered held without bond on murder charges yesterday after a man who said he was an informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified that he witnessed the execution of two men on Dec. 22. The witness, whose name was withheld, said Preston Tarver, 22, and his brother Mel, 17, were beaten by members of the Bandidos and then killed by the club's president.

title: Prof. Russell R. Larmon, 75, Eisenhower H.E.W. Aide, Dies
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 5Russell R. Larmon, professor emeritus of administration at Dartmouth College and Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Eisenhower Administration, died last evening. He was 75 years old.

title: VOMAN WINS DIVORCE ON SPOUSE'S SILENCE
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. (UPI)A swat in the face with a fish is not as cruel as being scorned by years of silence, judge ruled in a divorce case here.

title: 3 WIDOWS GETTING HOUSE GRATUITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The widows of three Representatives lost in airplane crashes in the last four months are receiving taxfree Congressional gifts of more than $40,000 each because their husbands died in office.

title: 2 Capital Papers Excluded At White House Reception
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI)  The White House excluded The Washington Post and The Washington StarNews today from the 13member press pool selected to cover President Nixon's reception for new members of Congress tonight.

title: Lawyer Implies Nixon Aide Was Overheard in Wiretap on Democrat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A lawyer implied in court today that leading Republicans learned through illegal wiretaps about a conversation between one of President Nixon's campaign aides and a Democratic official.

title: Trying to Decide What to Believe
description: Last month the United States left the peace talks and launched the most intensive bombings in history. What President Johnson had rejected as uncivilized, President Nixon embraced, Reserving, so far, the use of nuclear weapons, he has applied the full force of United States air power to force Vietnam to accept his terms.

title: Airports Start Thorough Screening of All Passengers
description: United States airlines began yesterday, in the most widespread program of personal searches in the nation's history, to inspect every item carried onto their 14,000 daily flights and to scan all of their 500,000 daily passengers with electronic weapon detectors.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OVERFLOW Overflow audiences are routine, but an overflow performance is not, and that's what will take place at 8 tonight, starting in the third floor Carnegie Recital Hall and moving at 11, the hall's closing time, one flight down to the Blue Room in the same building at Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: JOHN H. BENOIT
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I., Jan. 5 John H. Benoit, who was appointed to the Nassau County district court bench in 1971, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 52 years old and lived in his community.

title: U.S. Backs ChildCare Leaves For Men in a School Case Here
description: A schoolteacherparent should be entitled to a leave of absence to bring up a new baby, even if the teacher is a man, according to the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York State Board for Dentistry yesterday withheld approval of the use of acupuncture in destistry, stating that it considers the procedure experimental and should be tried as a research tool under controlled conditions.

title: British Treasury Bill Rate Posts Decline to 8.2787%
description: LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury bills fell to 8.2787 per cent from 8.3088 per cent last week.

title: CELTICS TROUNCE HAWKS 126 TO 108
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (UPI)The Boston Celtics coasted to a 126108 National Basketball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: GUARD IS ACCUSED OF ABETTING RIOT
description: A correction officer testified yesterday that another officer tried to dissuade rebelling inmates from releasing prison guards taken hostage during the Tombs riot in October, 1970.

title: Film: Tittle Mother, Eva Peron Story
description: The easy availability of hardcore pornography in so many conventional motionpicture theaters has had the odd effect of beaching the oldfashioned, softcore, sexexploitation film, the sort of movie beyond which (it used to be regularly exclaimed) it will be impossible to go.

title: Screen: CineDance
description: Most serious dance films, except the very best, become a contest between dance and film in which, if we are lucky, dance wins. Of course, the very best dance films, like George Stevens's sublime Swing Time and Hilary Harris's excellent 9 Variations on a Dance Theme, prove that movies sometimes can be a genuine synthesis of the arts. But the proposition still holds, and I think it is amply demonstrated by the seven short films in a program called CineDance, which opened last night at Film Forum. Swing Time isn't on the program, naturally, but Hilary Harris's film ??. And it may be taken as a standard by which everything ?? stands or falls  mostlyalls.

title: No Salvation In Silence
description: LONDON, Jan. 5  An American banker who took a Christmas holiday in Europe said afterward, with rather a dazed air: People kept asking me why we were bombing Hanoi. I did not know how to answer, or explain why people like me could not do anything about it.

title: Waterfront Unit Says 5 Airlines Deflate Their Reports on Thefts
description: The Waterfront Commission accused five major airlines yesterday of deliberately falsifying records of carog thefts to give the misleading impression that such thefts had been dramatically reduced by airlinesecurity measures.

title: DR. EARL YEOMANS; LED TEMPLE SPORTS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 (AP) Dr. Earl R. Yeomans, who as athletic director for 25 years, starting in 1927, built Temple University into a major college sports force in the East, died, today at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: Canadians Deplore Raids In Unanimous House Vote
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 5The Canadian House of Commons voted unanimously today to deplore the recent United States air attacks on the Hanoi and Haiphong areas and to urge Washington to refrain from further bombing there.

title: Australia Divided on Union Boycott of U.S. Shipping
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 5 Australians are sharply divided over the boycott of Americon shipping by extreme leftwing unions here in a protest against the bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Jet in Service After Hoax
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (UPI)A Trans World Airlines jumbo jet that was detoured to South Dakota because of a bomb hoax yesterday was back in service today. The plane was diverted from a Madrid  to  New  York flight because of a wouldbe extortionist's threat that it would blow up if it descended below 3,200 feet. It landed safely at Ellsworth Air Force Base, 3,276 feet above sea level.

title: Market Summary
Massive Bombing: The Hard Choice
description: WASHINGTONIt's far more popular these days to criticize President Nixon's bombing decision than to defend it. This is especially so when, after so many agonizing years of war, peace had seemed so tantalizingly near.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: JERSEY CENTRAL PRESSES FOR AID
description: LEBANON, Jan. 5Gordon Fuller, general manager of the Central Railroad of New Jersey said today that he did not see how the state could let the railroad drop its commuter service.

title: Weekly Lottery Action Nearly Triples Revenue
description: ALBANY, Jan. 5 (AP)The revenue from lottery tickets has almost tripled since New York State replaced the $1aticket monthly lottery with a 50centticket weekly drawing, the State Tax Department said today.

title: Injured Whale Taken To Aquarium in Truck
description: An injured 11foot, 900 pound whale found on a beach at Beach Haven Tuesday was being taken yesterday in a sling on a truck to the New York Aquarium at Coney Island.

title: FOUR PIER SHEDS LEVELED BY FIRE
description: A smoky fivealarm fire destroyed a series of four abandoned pier sheds on the Hudson River in lower Manhattan last night and forced the police to halt all traffic on the West Side Highway from 23d Street to the Battery for several hours.

title: LITTON AIDE GETS PLEA ON NAVY JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Gordon W. Rule, already in trouble with the Navy following his remarks about the former president of Litton Industries, Inc., is depending on a member of Litton's board of directors to help him get his job back.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: 54 in Row for U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5The University of California, Los Angeles, overcame a firsthalf stall, scored the first 9 points in the second half and went on to crush Oregon, 6438, tonight for its 54th straight victory. The Bruins led by only 1814 at halftime. Bill Walton, tripleteamed most of the night, wound up with 6 points, his low total as a Bruin.

title: EAST GERMAN TIES GRANTED BY 2 MORE
description: BERLIN, Jan. 5Diplomatic recognition was granted today to East Germany by the Netherlands and Luxembourg, the second and third members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Common Market to do so.

title: COLUMBIA BEATEN BY YALE, 7664
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 5Yale's basketball team ended a fivegame losing streak tonight, defeating Columbia, 7664, despite 27 points by the Lions' Bob Evans.

title: Alexander Sprunt Jr. Dies; Ornithologist and Author
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 5 Alexander Sprunt Jr., an ornithologist and author, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 74 years old.

title: Amnesty and Terror
description: President Kaunda of Zambia has begun the New Year with an act of compassion and conciliation that other heads of government in Africa and elsewhere would do well to emulate. He has released from detention former Vice President Simon Kapwepwe and 34 other members of the banned United Progressive Party.

title: Subsidy Criticisms Dim Housing Hopes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Housing production is expected to continue at a high rate through 1973, but there are uncertainties ahead that could greatly alter the picture over the long range.

title: A Rapid Sterilization Process Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A process patented this week is described by its inventor as an important breakthrough in the continuous sterilization of food, drug and milk containers and medical instruments.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 2.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week was an estimated 12.1 billion tonmiles, 2.1 per cent above the like 1972 week.

title: PANAMA TO INVITE SECURITY COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 5Panama has informed Security General Waldheim that she will invite the Security Council to meet in Panama March 15 to 21, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: DR. ALFRED MOSCARELLA
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan, 4Dr. Alfred S. Moscarella, who had practiced general medicine and then surgery in Rockland County, New York, for nearly 35 years before he retired in 1970, died Monday in Margate Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Quiet Requiem for E.P. Recalls Turbulent Life of Embattled Poet
description: The memorial held for Ezra Pound by the Academy of American Poets was billed as A Quiet Requiem for E. P. And though quiet is not the word usually applied to the embattled poet or his turbulent career, the evening at the Donnell Library Center turned out to be one of warm reminiscences, mirthprovoking anecdotes, readings and a brief look at his achievement.

title: SUSPECT IS SOUGHT IN BRONX SLAYINGS
description: The murders of two men whose bodies were found in vacant lot in the Bronx on New Year's Eve were attributed by the police yesterday to a fight for control of a Bronx social club.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon told a bipartisan group of Congressional leaders at a White House breakfast yesterday that although he knew many of them objected to his Vietnam policies, he was determined to do what he regarded as necessary to achieve a proper kind of settlement. He said that he was neither optimistic nor pessimisticonly hopefulabout the prospects for a negotiated agreement in the ceasefire talks, which resume on Monday between Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho. [Page 1, Column 1.].

title: U.S. Awaits First Soviet Oil Since '45
description: The first cargo of Soviet oil to be imported here since the end of World War II is scheduled to arrive at an East Coast port early next month.

title: Antiques: Furnishings of the Shakers
description: NEW LEBANON, N. Y.The Shakers have long since departed the sprawling North Family Dwelling here, emptying its many pine cupboards, shutting down, for the last time, its robust iron stove and closing the doors on its five floors of sunwashed rooms and airy corridors.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: THURSDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: A Man Seen With T eacher On Slaying Night Is Sought
description: The investigation into the murder of a 28yearold schoolteacher focused yesterday on locating a definite suspecta young man who, the police said, was seen entering the woman's West Side apartment building with her the night she was stabbed.

title: Soviet Rebuffs Western Appeals To Ease the Exchange of Ideas
description: MOSCOW, Jan, 5The Soviet Union today rebuffed demands by some Western nations for easier EastWest exchanges as a part of the era of improving political and economic relations.

title: Sheriff Asked for Briefs On Farr Bid for Freedom
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (UPI) Sheriff Peter J. Pitchess was asked by Justice William O. Douglas yesterday to submit briefs on William Farr's request that he be released from jail pending appeals of his case.

title: SAMUEL POPE
description: BOSTON, Jan. 5 (AP)Samuel Pope, chief of the Boston Fire Department from 1936 to 1946 and the man who directed operations at the 1942 Cocoanut Grove nightclub fire on which 491 persons perished, died yesterday at his home. He was 83 years old.

title: Counterfeit Bills Seized
description: CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 5 (UPI)  Federal, state and local agents raided two lake front cottages early today and seized between $7million and $10million in counterfeit $20 bills. Five persons were arrested in the raid, which also nected a printing, press and the plates for the almost perfect bils.

title: Business Booming at Blood Center
description: The newest S.R.O. spot on the East Side does not play music and serves only orange juice and coffee. Yet people wait in line two hours to get in.

title: NIXON INCREASES SCOPE OF DUTIES FOR 3 IN CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5President Nixon announced today that he was placing into effect, as far as he was able by Executive order, the Government reorganization plan that he proposed in early 1971 but Congress declined to enact.

title: The Cedars of Lebanon Flourish In a Storehouse of Antiquity
description: Lebanon, which some believe was the Garden of Eden, is only about 30 miles wide and 95 miles long. Those measurements make it one of the world's smaller countries, but it can also be thought of as the world's largest museum. It is filled with the remains of history, ruins and temples that served preBiblical man, the Greeks, Romans, Crusaders and Ottomans.

title: BICKER, $26, WINS SANTA ANITA RACE
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP) Bicker, a 121 shot, moved up in a stretch drive today and flashed past Royal Owl to win the $61,800 Malibu Stakes for 4yearolds at Santa Anita.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The city's office rental situation improved somewhat in 1972 over 1971, figures made public last week showed. However, the picture was marred during the week by the announcement of two major corporate moves to suburban sites.

title: Times Printing EndWar Ad Signed By 192 on Its Staff
description: An advertisement in which 192 staff members of The New York Times urged Congress to end immediately all American involvement in the Indochinese war is published today in the News of the Week in Review section of The Times.

title: Corsicans of France Are Feeling the Sting of Publicity Given to Criminals
description: PARIS, Jan. 6The Corsicans of France, much Iike the ItalianAmericans in the United States, are becoming increasingly sensitive about their collective reputation.

title: Issues in the L. I. R. R. Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Long Island Rail Road and 12 Unions repregenting 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, electrical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as Well as some supervisors.

title: NEWS OF BELFAST CALLED DISTORTED
description: Frank McManus, a member of the British Parliament from Northern Ireland, said here yesterday that he was trying to counteract the distortion of news of Northern Ireland reaching this country.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Homosexual Wins Fight to Take Bar Examination in Minnesota
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 6Jack Baker, an outspoken leader of the Gay Liberation Movement, has been ruled eligible for the Minnesota bar examination by examiners who found that he did not fraudulently obtain the license with which he entered into a homosexual marriage.

title: PAGE PURSE GOES TO SETON HANOVER
description: YONKERS, Jan. 6Seton Hanover, one of the finest 2yearolds in the nation in 1970, but a disappointment the last two seasons, got his 1973 campaign under way in high style tonight. He raced away from seven rivals in capturing the featured $7,000 Fleetwood Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Tucker and Merrill:. They're Still Here?
description: IN an atmosphere charged with gags, raucous laughter and slaughtering of the Queen's English, two Runyonesque cronies named Richard Tucker and Robert Merrill are reminiscing. Behaving not the least like distinguished elder statesmen of the operatic arts, they come on more like veterans of the vocal wars who still have a few gold battles to fight. Tucker, in particular, lets off steam by the bucketful as he alternates between playing pundit and pagliaccio. In the former guise, he points to my tape recorder and solemnly announces, You can hold this for posterity, ya know. I suppose he is right because both men are legends in their own time. As paragons of vocal longevity, they are secure in their positions, more than willing to share the secrets of their success, and not averse to offering advice to young warriors. The problem is, they haven't found toomany takers.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Tempo Quickens for Jazz Trumpeter
description: BELLE MEADOver the last 10 years, Ed Polcer, who lives with his wife and two children in an old farmhouse on Route 206, has been a purchasing agent for the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, for Magnus Organs and, currently for Ronnie's Packaging of South Plainfield. On weekends and sometimes on week nights, he has played jazz trumpet with a variety of groups around New Jersey, developing an enthusiastic corps of followers who are amazed that he is not playing fulltime and does not have a national reputation.

title: Presidential war: See if you can fixany limit to his power
description: Allow the President to invade a neighboring nation, whenever he shall deem it necessary to repel an invasion, and you allow him to do so, whenever he may choose to say he deems it necessary for such purposeand you allow hint to make war at pleasure. Study to see if you can fix any limit to his power in this respect.... If, today, he should choose to say he thinks it necessary to invade Canada, to prevent the British from invading us, how could you stop him? You may say to him, I see no probability of the British invading us but he will say to you be silent; I see it, you don't.

title: Chemicals: How to Plan?
description: There can be no doubt, that the chemical industry just finished its best year since 1966.

title: Mrs. Maiugani's pot roast
description: Anita Malugani's stracotto con maccheroni

title: Part of Clemente Plane Found by Navy Divers
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 6 (AP)  The fuselage and tail section of the plane that carried the baseball star, Roberto Clemente, and four other men to their deaths was found today, but four bodies still were missing. The cockpit had been found yesterday, a Navy spokesman said.

title: Four Arab Guerrillas Left $324 Hotel Bill in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK Thailand, Jan. 6 (AP)Four Arabs who occupied the Israeli Embassy last week and held six Israelis hostage for 19 hours left behind a hotel bill for $324 and a reputation as big tippers.

title: Smoke Is Visible 32 Miles In Bayonne OilTank Fire
description: A huge oiltank fire in Bayonne sent black smoke billowing for miles yesterday while causing damage estimated in the millions of dollars. No injuries were reported.

title: Women, With New Consciousness, Strive to Advance
description: As Florynce Kennedy, lawyer, once put it: If I'm lying on the ground with a car on my ankle, I wish people wouldn't speculate as to how long the car's been there and who put it there and go to the public library to tell me how much it weighs. I would want them to get it off.

title: 2,000 Books Given to Tenafly
description: TENAFLY  The Tenafly High School library has received close to 2,000 items from the literary collection of the late Prof. Richard V. Chase of Columbia University. Included are an original edition of Ezra Pound's letters, first editions of works by Mark Van Doren and Lionel Trilling and a number of books on Herman Melville, Nathaniel Hawthorne and Emily Dickinson.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Srandard Times

title: On Birdwatching
description: ATLANTIC CITYThe New Jersey shore, from Sandy Hook south to Atlantic City and Cape May, is not the place most people choose for a day of recreation in winter. Hotels and restaurants are shuttered and locked, boats in marinas huddle together at anchor, a cold, wet wind howls much of the time and beaches and boardwalks are empty and silent.

title: The Ten Worst Movies Of 1972
description: THIS is the week to be churlish, to turn that smile upside down. To encourage a kind of cab drivergrumpiness and to nourish unfair biases. To use blunt instruments on sinners. To be negative in as decisive a way as possible. To be insincerely alarmed and saddened by secondrattiness. To cite failure wherever found. To be, above all, frank, letting the chips fall where they may.

title: Pilferage on Rotterdam Docks Drops as Jobs Become Scarce
description: ROTTERDAM, The Netherlands, Jan. 6 (AP)  Tough times have arrived for lightfingered longshoremen in the world's laigest port, where pilfering has become as pervasive as it is on the docks of New York.

title: Caso Seeks Tax Stability
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive who has just started the last year of his threeyearterm as head of the county government, is looking forward to a year of continued tax stability, a year of preservation of the suburban quality of our environment and Improvement in mass transportation problems.

title: A Belleville Church Marks 275th Year
description: BELLEVILLE  Members of the Belleville Reformed Church took a journey through history a few weeks ago while observing the church's 275th anniversary.

title: Nitty Gritty's Country Dirt
description: ON a hot afternoon last June, I was in Canaan, Conn., sitting on some patchy yellow  brown grass in front of a rickety old farmhouse that was some five miles from the nearest paved road. Several hundred people had gathered there for a country music festivala nice turnout, considering there were no bigname musicians among the pickers and footstompers performing up on the porch of the old house. When I got up and walked around between sets, I saw little jam sessions every twenty yards or so, with stringy longhairs in carefully faded full Levi costume trading harmonies with southern fried, goldenskinned, slickbacked shorthairs in Sears Roebuck glossy colors. Down came the barriers; at least for that muggy afternoon if you could pick your instrument, all right.

title: In Korea, officials curse, intellectuals cheer
description: SEOUL. He writes with a toughness that has enraged the leaders of his country and resulted in mass arrests and trials. He pierces the walls of hypocrisy and corruption around him with the force of a meat axor the subtlety of a needle. He evokes the national tragedy of his people but does it so cleverly that his readers often laugh instead of weep. He has been arrested and tried, held without trial, committed to a tuberculosis sanitarium, hunted and followed ever since a small magazine published his epic satire, Five Bandits, nearly three years ago. After the publication of another poem, Groundless Rumors, he went into hiding in an obscure hotel room while more than 150 of his friends were seized and questioned about his whereabouts.

title: China Sees European Bloc Checking U.S. and Soviet
description: PEKING, Jan. 6 (Reuters)China has depicted the enlargement of the European Common Market from six nations to nine as an important step by Western Europe toward checking the political and economic ambitions of the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: More Than Elaine May's Daughter
description: TALK about your incipient yentas! Lila, who gets her walking papers on her honeymoon in Elaine May's film, The Heartbreak Kid, wears her nascent yentadam proudly, like a badge. Her fingernails are talons of scary silver. Her clothes are expensive, all wrong, and belong on someone aged 60. Her hair style is a cross between early Shirley Temple and late Charley's Aunt. She talks too much, and in a register that moves from scratch to screech. She eats when she shouldn't and what she shouldn't, and when she eats it, it dribbles down her chin. Lila, crazy in love with Lenny, the heartbreak kid, is not merely a mess, she's a slob.

title: Rizzo's First Year: Crime Off Slightly
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6Frank L. Rizzo, selfproclaimed toughest cop in Anierica, became Mayor of Philadelphia a year ago this week after pledging a lawandorder ad ministration that would restore safety to the city's streets.

title: Airlines Face Uncertainty on Regulation and Fares
description: The nation's airlines appear to be jetting into an era of fundamental changes for much of the industryand the traveling public. But the airlines can't see yet just where the changes are taking them.

title: Joanne Carlucci to Wed
description: NEWARK, Jan. 6Mr. and Mrs. Vito Carlucci have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanne Lucille Carlucci, to Larry Philip Picatello, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alphonse Louis Picatello.

title: Softness Detected In Rental Market
description: In any recital of New York City's Ws, acute housing shortage is a constant refrain. Tenants' groups invoke it when calling for better protection, and landlords' groups cite it when arguing for fewer restrictions.

title: Is That the Way to End the Vietnam War?
description: I WAS made seriously uncomfortable in the theater twice last week, both times by a naive strain of what I suppose we've got to call triumpha??ism. That is to say, I was twice asked to believe in much too easy a victory.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Jan. 12Vintage Sports Car Club of America dinner meeting at Hotel Elysee, 60. East 54th Street, New York, 8 P.M. Information: Syd Stoldt, phone (201)4871400 during day.

title: Amer. Hokey League
description: FRIDAY NIGHT'S GAMES.

title: Point of View
description: Merchants have no country. The mere spot they stand on does not constitute so strong an attachment as that from which they draw their gains.

title: Where Are the . . . ? Metropolitan Art Museum Tells It All in a 320Page Guide, Called First in a Century
description: Even the most seasoned visitor to the Metropolitan Museum cannot always find his favorite p'ip'a, Mihrab or figure of Avalokitesvara. He might also have to ask a guard the way to the highly publicized Greek vase that the Metropolitan recently purchased.

title: New &Novel
description: My Stillness

title: DR. THOMAS CAIRNS OF THE NEW SCHOOL
description: Dr. Thomas D. Cairns, who retired as professor of philosophy at the New School for Social Research in 1969, died Thursday in BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1245 Park Avenue.

title: Medical Team Assails Alabama On Treatment of Ill Prisoners
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 6 An investigating team from the Medical Association of Alabama, in a report released today, criticized medical treatment of prisoners in the Alabama penal system as grossly inadequate.

title: New PlumbingGroup Chief
description: Melvyn S. Fein, a graduate of Cornell University and a professional engineer who is president and chief executive officer of Wachtel, Duklauer & Fein, a subsidiary of National Kinney Corporation, was elected president of the Association of Contracting Plumbers of New York City yesterday. He sudceeds another engineer, William J. Murphy.

title: POMPIDOU ENTERS FRENCH CAMPAIGN
description: PARIS, Jan. 6With his own leadership at stake and the workability of French political institutions threatened, President Pompidou is plunging into the election campaign, which is growing daily in intensity and will reach its climax in March with voting for a new National Assembly.

title: William Dunn to Marry Miss Hansbury
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Jan. 6Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Aloysius Hansbury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Alexandra Hansbury, to William Dunn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Dunn also of Short Hills.

title: Capitalism LivesEven in Naderland
description: ROW of neckties in blinding prints is strung against a wall in the modest offices of The Center for Study of Responsive Law in Washington, D. C., which is more or less the headquarters for the elusively ubiquitous Ralph Nader. What do they signify in the cause of consumerism, a visitor wonders.

title: Regionalism Is Key In Retail Expansion
description: The estimated $120billion worth of outlays for apparel, general merchandise and home furnishings made by Americans in 1972 may be inviting a new era of competition among the country's biggest retailers in the next few years.

title: South Wins Hula Bowl, 173, in a Game of Turnovers
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 6 (UPI)The South, capitalizing North miscues, scored a 173 victory today in the 27th annual Hula Bowl football game.

title: Overnight Mutual Funds for Surplus Assets
description: Two young money managers at the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association faced a nettlesome problem several years ago: how to get maximum return on money that was earmarked for mortgage loans, loans whose closing date could only rarely be predicted in advance.

title: India Names Chief of Staff To Take Army Command
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 6 (AP)The Indian Government has named a new army Chief of Staff to succeed Field Marshal S. H. F. J. Manekshaw.

title: Illegal Taps on Employe Phones Laid to F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)  Congressional investigators said today that Federal Communications Commission officials illegally monitored some office phones of commission employes during five weeks of 1970 in a secret effort to plug a suspected leak of information.

title: Pop
description: I HAVE not seen the movie yet. I did not want my Lady Sings the Blues (Motown M758D) soundtrack album review to be influenced by what so many people are calling a real tour de force screen performance by Diana Ross. In this age of multimedia explosions, I hold the oldfashioned opinion that a record should stand as a record. The medium is the grooves. The success of Lady Sings the Blues has inspired two Billie Holiday reissues, Strange Fruit (Atlantic SD 1614) and Lady Love (United Artists UAS 5635). And, lest we forget where Diana Ross herself began, there's a brand new Supremes album, The Supremes (Motown M756L). All of these LPs show that, despite her portrayal of Billie Holiday, Diana Ross remains closer to the glossy pop Supremes than to the genuinely moving Lady Day. A singer can interpret a songwriter, not another singerparticularly if that singer has the genius of Billie Holiday.

title: Ecological Retrenching
description: WASHINGTON  On the Federal environmental front, this is expected to be a year of consolidation In the Administration and enforcement of the two major pieces of legislation  large parts of which the Administration opposedin the last four years: the Clean Air Act of 1970 and the 1972 amendments to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act.

title: MEDICAID COST DIP HOPED FOR BY CITY
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton said yesterday that the city hoped to stave off any need for a deficiency appropriation for Medicaid and welfare expenses, despite the fact that they are presently running at an annual rate of $100million more than budgeted last June.

title: MICHIGAN SUCCEEDS AT OHIO STATE, 6862
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 6 (AP)  Campy Russell, the sophomore star, scored 23 points and led Michigan to 6862 basketball victory over Ohia State in a Big Ten opener today. It was Michigan's first triumph on the Buckeye court in 18 years.

title: Election Contributions Pose Awkward aeries for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON  In collecting a record total of about $45million for his reelection campaign  often spectacularly and in part secretly from corporate executives  President Nixon's political moneymen may also have raised potentially awkward questions about the Administration's future dealings with business:

title: Dr. Sabin Leaves Post At Weizmann Institute
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 6 (AP) Dr. Albert Sabin, who developed the livevirus, antipolio vaccine, will spend 1973 as a Fogarty Scholar at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., Children's Hospital officials here say.

title: Coupon Clipping For the Masses
description: I decided to go East and learn the bond business. Everybody I knew was in the bond business, so I supposed it could support one more.The Great Gatsby.

title: Advertising Agencies Buoyed by Marketplace Vitality
description: It looks good for the advertising people this year. But then, after what they've been through, why shouldn't it?

title: Son to Scheinmans
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Jan. 6 A son was born Dec. 23 to Mr. and Mrs. Alan G. Scheinman at Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park. The child has been named Greg Evan.

title: 17 STATES REPORT RESPIRATORY ILLS
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 6, (AP) Influenza or upper respiratory diseases have been reported in 17 states, with flurelated deaths in some areas of the country, the national Center for Disease Control reported yesterday.

title: Haiphong Visitor Finds Factory Zone in Ruins
description: HAIPHONG, North Vietnam, Jan. 6Recent American air raids virtually razed Haiphong's industrial zone, one of North Vietnam's biggest concentrations of factories.

title: U.S. Consul in Managua Dies of Bullet Wound
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 6 (UPI  James P. Hargrove, the 44yearold Consul in Managua, has died of a bullet wound in the head, the United States Embassy announced today.

title: Farmers Weigh SaleLeaseback
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I.When he settled sin Bridgehampton 30 years ago Remi Wesnofske, a farmer, thought he had finished running from developers who had forced his grandfather off his New Hyde Park farm at the turn of the century and gobbled up his father's property in Hicksville after World War II. The South Fork was 100 miles from New York, and, Mr. Wesnofske believed, safe from suburban sprawl.

title: Garden City Hotel Facing Demolition
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.The old, vacant Garden City Hotel, once the symbol of elegance in this affluent village and the subject of heated controversy by its residents, is expected to be demolished this month.

title: But What Has Been Gained?
description: Dr. Kissinger is off to Paris again, and if he is genuinely in search of compromise settlement of the war rather than a negotiated victory, everyone must wish him well. But what, it is fair to ask, has been gained since he and President Nixon broke off the talks in midDecember and launched the massive carpetbombing of Hanoi?

title: THE MIDWEST
description: KANSAS CITYAgriculture is the economic lifeblood of midAmerica, and things on the farm are looking up for 1973.

title: SEA GEESE FOUND DECLINING IN EAST
description: Fewer brant than ever before have returned to winter quarters along the Eastern Coast, a statebystate survey shows.

title: Plane Toll Rises to 100
description: MIAMI, Jan. 6 (UPI)The death toll in the New Year's weekend crash of an Eastern L1011 TriStar rose to 100 today when one of five patients suffering from gas gangrene died. The Miami Heart Institute said that Luis Bancroft, 22 years old, of Union City, N. J., a passenger on the plane, died at 12:30 A.M.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth S. Hallowell Marries in Rhodesia
description: Miss Elizabeth Smith Hallowell and Laurence Vivian Jeffery were married yesterday in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Ruwk Rhodesia.

title: 2dRanked Maryland Wins
description: CLEMSON, S.C., Jan. 6 (AP) Secondranked Maryland defeated Clemson, 7975, tonight for its ninth straight victory. It was the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball opener for both teams.

title: Met College Hockey
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: Caroline C. Butler Becomes Engaged
description: MENTOR, Ohio, Jan. 6Mr. and Mrs. John Grier Butler have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Cooke Butler, to Edward Justin Condon of Denver, son of Mrs. Mildred A. Condon of Sayville, L.I., and Frank D. Condon of Seaford, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: 71,441 Billboards Removed In Year in Drive by Volpe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe announced today that 71,441 billboards had been removed from the nation's highways and said he expected that the removal of billboards would be greatly accelerated.

title: Point of View
description: Perhaps the most remarkable thing about the current wageprice controls is their widespread popularity. There is hardly a single recognized spokesman for business or labor who publicly favors terminating controls, although there have been some suggestions for modification.

title: $65,082 IS GIVEN TO AID NEEDIEST
description: The 61st annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund neared the $600,000 mark yesterday with the addition of $65,082.67 in accumulated Income from estates and trusts and $14,212.72 in daytoday donations.

title: Growth Pinches College Soccer
description: College soccer, like many other sports, suffers from expansion problems. This week's coaches' convention in New York faces several highly sensitive issues that directly result from the sport's explosive growth.

title: HETHERINGTON GAINS IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan, 6The Rev. Bob Hetherington, a former Yale player from Buffalo, defeated Mohibullah Khan, a professional at the Harvard Club in Boston, 1512, 1615 915, 158, in gaining the semifinal round of the 12th annual William White Memorial Cup open squashracquets tournament today at the Merion Cricket Club.

title: Report From Part One
description: It frightens me to realize that I had died before the age of fifty, I would have died a Negro fraction, writes Gwendolyn Brooks in this autobiographical volume.

title: SAN QUENTIN BARS EASED SECURITY
description: TAMAL, Calif., Jan. 6  The first strike by inmates at San Quentin Prison since 1968 is all but over, but officials insist they cannot satisfy the demands of the convicts without easing security at the institution.

title: Shot in Head, She's All Right
description: POMONA, Calif., Jan. 6 (UPI)Prudence V. Johnson, 54 years old, narrowly escaped serious injury when she was shot in the head by a bandit. She told the police that a man and a woman had entered the Oasis Bar she operates and had taken $139.27 from the cash register Wednesday. She said they had ordered her to lie on the floor, then shot her in the head. The bullet merely grazed her scalp, knocking her unconscious.

title: Twentieth Century Faith
description: Margaret Mead, America's anthropologist laureate, is both child to the 20th century and parent. She has devoted her threescore years and ten to the proper study of mankind, and is preeminently qualified to address herself to man's faith, hope and survival. This she does, in these 16 collected pieces, written between 1953 and 1971, which comprise the 25th volume of the Religious Perspectives series.

title: Queen to Visit Canada Twice
description: LONDON, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Queen Elizabeth will visit Ottawa during the British Commonwealth heads of government conference Aug. 210, Buckingham Palace said. She also plans a 10day visit to centennial celebrations on Prince Edward Island and in Kingston, Ontario, from June 25 to July 5.

title: Arizona Court to Take Up Case Of 194 Unfiled Divorce Decrees
description: PHOENIX, Jan. 6  The Arizona State Supreme Court has agreed to dispose of 194 old divorce decrees that have never been filed and therefore are riot officially valid.

title: 4 Consumer Organizations Oppose F.D.A. on Nitrites
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) Four major consumer organizations have protested what they called the Food and Drug (Administration's refusal to bar the use in food of sodium nitrite and nitrate, believed to combine with other compounds in the stomach to form a potent cancercausing substance.

title: Tannenbaum Troth
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, L. I., Jan. 6  Mr. and Mrs. Arnold A. Tannenbaum of Massapequa Park have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lesley Joyce Tannenbaum, to Irwin E. Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Marcus of East Meadow.

title: Veteran Faces Trial in Hijacking
description: When a judge and jury convene in San Francisco tomorrow to weigh air piracy charges against a young Vietnam veteran, they will sift through psychiatric evidence that underscores the difficulties of assessing the mental state of the nation's growing number of skyjackers.

title: Market Lore For the Fans
description: WALL STREET AND THE STOCK MARKETS. By Peter Wyckoff. Chilton Book Company. 304 pages. $10.

title: Point of View
description: Should the economy perform this year as generally anticipated  a 6 per cent growth in real gross national productthe shortterm outlook for all forms of domestic transport (railroads, motor carriers, inland water carriers and airlines) is for better results than in either 1971 or 1972.

title: Moving of a Drug Suspect From Nevada Sought
description: Extradition proceedings were being prepared yesterday to bring here from Las Vegas a Staten Island man who was being held in what is believed to be a record $5million bail as a narcotics suspect.

title: Queens Keeps Role As King Of Parks
description: If you want to visit the Queens headquarters of the Parks Department on the slowest day of the year you might try the Saturday of New Year's weekend. Absolutely deadsville.

title: Rail Labor Chaos
description: The bankrupt Penn Central Railroad, waiting tin cup in hand for a big new infusion of Government cash, threatened with a systemwide strike at midnight next Thursday that could push it over the line into total collapse.

title: Solutions to last week's puzzles
Harry Bridges
description: The Rise and Fall of Radical Labor in the United States. By Charles P. Larrowe. 416 pp. Westport, Conn.: Lawrence Hill & Co. Cloth, $8.95. Paper, $3.95.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Not everyone is aware of the fact that there have been occasions over the years when I actually produced predictions of uncanny accuracy in these presumptious peeks into the future. When the gods endowed Cassandra with the gift of prophecy, it was fated that no one would believe her. That's my problem, too. But here goes anyway.

title: News Summary and Index
Revamping By N.C.A.A. Is Planned
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 6 (AP)The National Collegiate Athletic Association may make drastic reorganization changes at its 67th annual convention in Chicago Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

title: Phillies to Get First Pick In the Draft Wednesday
description: Baseball's 24 major league teams dip into the freeagent spool again this week with the annual winter draft of free agent prospects.

title: Our Man at While House
