description: WASHINGTON  Bluechip businesses with problems in Washington can go for help to a number of people in the White House, but one of the most soughtafter is Peter Mangus Flanigan.

title: Art
description: CHECKING the catalogue of Brazilian Baroque: Decorative and Religious Objects of the 17th and 18th Centuries, a radiant exhibition at the Renwick Gallery in Washington., I see that there are 96 objects in a show that impressed me as a small one. I'd have said 50 at most.

title: Movies
description: READING the New York film critics is often like traveling through the looking glass. Recently I was astonished by the reviews of Bob Rafelson's The King of Marvin Gardens.  perhaps the worst set of reviews on any major film released in 1972. According to The Times' count, the critical breakdown was one favorable review, five mixed, and 15 unfavorable. Yet the movie was directed by the same Bob Rafelson who, two years ago, won the New York Film Critics Award for his direction of Five Easy Pieces.

title: Recovery Staged By New York City
description: New York City, the colossus on the Hudson that for decades dominated all other major American cities both in the growth rate and most other economic indicators only to enter a recessiontype decline in 1969, is slowly recovering.

title: Miss Korman Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester Korman of Forest Hills, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Sue Korman, to Sheldon Harvey Greenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Greenberg of Douglaston, Queens. The wedding will take place in July in Temple Israel in Lawrence, L. I.

title: One win, Two losses
description: At a Midget League football game I watched recently I saw a man berate a little lineman for missing a block until the boy wept. Like too many American men these days, that parent took the game much too seriously. So do C. Paul Jackson and Roy Hoopes in their books. George Sullivan, on the other hand, seems to have a relaxed appreciation of football, which he displays stylishly in PRO FOOTBALL'S PASSING GAME (Dodd, Mead, $4.25).

title: Patricia Elliott And A. G. Neal Are Betrothed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Dr. and Mrs. Lloyd Elliott have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Elliott, to Arthur Geary Neal, son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Leslie Neal of Ithaca, N. Y. The wedding will take place here April 18.

title: Will Johnny Be Up to Paar?
description: HE'S back, or will be tomorrow night at 11:30, and the big question is, can Jack slay the giant Carson and bring ABC's latenight ratings pleasingly up to Paar? No one, least of all Jack Paar, is being uncool enough to bill this event as a clash of the talkshow titans (SEE Carson ad lib while shooting his cuffs! SEE Paar's dimple fill with tears!). But the confrontation between ABC's new Jack Paar Tonite and NBC's old but good as gold Tonight show with Johnny Carson, promises to be a final shootout between the man who made the talk show go and the man who kept it going.

title: New Zealand P.G.A. Title Won by Nagle for 5th Time
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 6 (AP) Kel Nagle of Australia won the New Zealand Professional Golfers' Association tournament for the fifth time, firing a final fiveunderpar 66 today for a 72hole total of 275 and a onestroke victory.

title: Jordan Cuts Defense Outlay, But Her '73 Budget Is Record
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 6 (AP) Jordan has trimmed her defense budget for 1973, it was announced here today.

title: Francis T. Kolars, 72, Dies; Taught English at Hunter
description: Francis T. Kolars, who taught English and shortstory writing at Hunter College for many years, died yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center of an aneurism suffered the day before. He was 72 years old and lived at 325 Germonde, Avenue, West Nyack, N.Y.

title: Arizona Abortion Appeal
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 6 (AP) A Court of Appeals decision upholding Arizona's antiabortion law will be taken to the state Supreme Court, an attorney for plaintiffs in the original case announced. Stanley Feldman said he would ask the high court to strike down the statute outlawing most abortions as violation of the civil rights of women and physicians.

title: MICHAELIAN'S JOB IS ENTICING MANY
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 6 One year from now, Westchester County will inaugurate its first new County Executive in 16 years, and a political struggle is developing over who will succeed Edwin G. Michaelian in the $49,000ayear post he has held since 1958.

title: Pouring Over Grammar
description: It is a mystery to the common reader why publishers constantly bring out books riddled with grammatical mistakes. The golibledygook appearing daily in newspapers indicates that typesetters no longer bother to set type correctly, and possibly proofreaders no longer bother to read proof carefully, but do editors no longer edit?

title: Mary Malsin Planning Marriage
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 6  Miss Mary Malsin and Robert Lord Merrow plan to be married here on Feb. 3. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Malsin of CrotononHudson and Starksboro, Vt., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Griswold Merrow of Noroton, Conn., and Mass.

title: 2 Fordham Free Throws Sink Holy Cross, 62 to 60
description: Kevin Moriarty, a sophomore, sank a pair of free throws with one second remaining to give Fordham a 6260 victory over Holy Cross last night at the Rose Hill gym.

title: L. I. Legislators Gain Key Posts
description: ALBANYThe Long Island legislative delegation won a useful beachhead in its annual battle for more school aid this week when State Senator Leon E. Guiffreda of Suffolk was named chairman of the Education Committee.

title: Return of The Native
description: ON Jan. 16 in Carnegie Recital Hall, Schubert's Winterreise cycle will be sung by Norman Foster. The American baritone's name will ring a bell with those who know lieder recordings or who have seen him in filmed versions of the operas, Bluebeard's Castle and The Merry Wives of Windsor. Otherwise, he is probably unknown to the rest of America for the good reason that he has spent his adult life in Europe. While its focus has generally been music and singing, his career has been varied, never developing enough in one area to make his name familiar on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Meskill Assailed for Asking Death for Drug Repeaters
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 6 (UPI)The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's call for the death penalty for twiceconvicted drug pushers was a return to the jungle. The organization said it would seriously consider defending a drug pusher condemned to die in the electric chair.

title: ExAddicts' Parents Clean New Daytop Center
description: Arthur Berman, a parent of a young former narcotics addict, stood yesterday on the second floor of an elegant old midManhattan building, awaiting assignment to a cleanup detail.

title: David Bruce Anderson to Wed Robin Kinnear, Fellow Student
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 6Mr. and Mrs. James W. Kinnear 3d have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Robin. Wood Kinnear, to David Bruce Anderson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bruce Murray Anderson of Blacksburg, Va. The wedding is planned for June 16.

title: Yorty Begins 4thTerm Bid, Bars Reply to Opponents
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (UPI) Mayor Sam Yorty, 63 years old, embarked on a race yesterday for a fourth term but said he would not respond to his opponents' charges.

title: Donna Dooley Wed to Jonathan Burr Frederick Iselin to Marry Sallie Drury
description: Miss Donna Lee Dooley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Dooley of Pompano Beach, Fla. and Hawley, Pa., was married here yesterday morning to Jonathan Lee Burr, son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Burr of Wellesley Hills, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John J. Murray in the Roman Catholic Chapel of Faith, Hope and Charity. services for Florida PalmAire Corporation, was formerly vice president and general manager of the. Plaza Hotel in New York. The bridegroom's father is vice president and chairman of the board of the Istron Corporation, manufacturers of scientific instruments.

title: Of Space and Time
description: JANUARY stems from the Roman god Janus, represented by two heads, one looking forward, the other back. Looking forward, there are the forthcoming United States issues already described in this column. Looking back, there is the era of the Apollo space flights, just ended. This has prompted inquiries as to why there is no commemorative planned to mark the great Apollo program as a whole. To be sure, the program is ended, and the United States does not usually celebrate demises. But such a great triumphant national endeavor does not just slip away and what has been learned from the Apollos is just beginning to unfold, so the inquiring voices are likely to grow.

title: Harpsichords Built In Hopewell Shop
description: HOPEWELLBon voyage parties were given here two weekends in a row recently for a harpsichord that went to Paris.

title: BIIFFMO RAUJIES
description: The Buffalo Sabres, a team that works out in hotel ballrooms and jogs around parking lots, showed off their physical prowess yesterday in sending the Rangers to a 41 defeat.

title: One man's long journey From a oneworld crusade to the department of dirty tricks
description: What if he should get out of his hole and explain the matter reasonably to both sides? Fellow human beings, he would begin. There are very few of us here who in private life would kill a man for any reason whatever. The fact that guns have been placed in our hands and some of us wear one uniform and some another is no excuse for the mass murder we are about to commit. There are differences between us, I know, but none of them worth the death of one man. Most of us are not here by our own choice. We were taken from our peaceful lives and told to fight for reasons we cannot understand. Surely we have far more in common than that which temporarily separates us. Fathers, go back to your children, who are in need of you. Husbands, go back to your young wives, who cry in the night and count the anxious days. Farmers, return to your fields, where the grain rots and the house slides into ruin. The only certain fruit of this insanity will be the rotting bodies upon which the sun will impartially shine tomorrow. Let us throw down these guns that we hate. With the morning we shall go together and in charity and hope build a new life and a new world.

title: Forecasters' Word Is Boom
description: Every economic decision implies a prediction. In some societies, a witch doctor reads the future in a cast of a handful of bones; in many countries, quite substantial businessmen take no major action without consulting the stars, the cards or a crystal ball at their favorite seer's. In the United States, great corporations rely on a league of economic forecasters armed with computers fed by the largest flow of data known to history.

title: ALLIGATOR HUNTS IN FALL ASSAILED
description: The National Audubon So ciety accused the state of Louisiana yesterday of undermining public confidence in the whole Federal endangeredspecies program by permitting premature reopening of the hunting of alligators.

title: NEW ENGLAND
description: BOSTON  Creaking with age, the New England economy still lags behind other regions of the country, and economic leaders here are urging a major overhaul of the entire system.

title: Piggyback Tax Collections in the Offing
description: Would life he less complicated for individual taxpayers each April 15 if they filled out a single tax form to meet both Federal and state filing obligations?

title: Chess: The Only Thing Permanent Over the Board Is Change
description: Lines of play come into and lose favor in often bewildering cycles, prompting some observers to conclude that they are nothing but fads. Emanuel Lasker, who held the world championship for a recordbreaking 27 years, from his victory over Wilhelm Steinitz in 1894 to his defeat at the hands of Jos Raul Capablanca in 1921, perpetually turned a deaf ear to reports that this or that move refuted one opening or another.

title: Denver Tops Creighton
description: DENVER, Jan. 6 (AP)The University of Denver, shaking off 30 turnovers, outshot and outrebounded Creighton today for a 7061 college basketball victory. The Pioneers' John Johnson had 23 points and 16 rebounds to lead in both categories.

title: Survey Reports 5% Cost Increase
description: The Turner Construction Company's Building Cost Index for the fourth quarter of 1972 showed a 5.7 per cent increase over the corresponding period in 1971.

title: Longshoremen Boycotting 7 Australian Ships in U.S.
description: Seven ships carrying Australian goods are tied up in United States ports from Boston to Tampa, as American longshoremen retaliate for an Australian boycott of American shipping.

title: Senator Asks Constituents Their Feelings on the Press
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, has sent his constituents a questionnaire on their feelings toward the news industry and press freedom.

title: Complementary views of the Nigerian civil war
description: It is perhaps in part a tribute to the remarkable reconstruction and reconciliation which has taken place in Nigeria since its civil war that the memory of that war has quickly receded from the American consciousness. For the Nigerian civil war was one of the greatest fratricidal conflicts in modern history, comparable in size and cost with the American and Spanish Civil Wars. It lasted for two and a half years (July 1967 to January 1970) took a toll of between half a million and a million Nigerians and cost $1.4billion.

title: Getting Along With I. B. M.
description: During the nineteensixties Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs was the wry way to describe the computer industry. Snow White was the International Business Machines Corporation, which had the major share of the market, while the Seven Dwarfs were the other major computer manufacturers.

title: Spock Mugged
description: A New Year's toast, in decaffeinated tea, to the vanishing liberal. Under heavy fire from absolutely everybody, the liberal craftily went out of existence some time ago; and the only people who still claim the title are conservative politicians, labor leaders for Nixon and Americans overseas.

title: Pickings for Jets, Giants
description: Unless some trades are made before the National Football League draft takes place on Jan. 30, the New York Jets will have 20 choices coming in the 17 rounds and the New York Giants 15.

title: Eminent Britons
description: The writer of these reviews is the author of The Offshore Islanders: England's People from Roman Occupation to the Present.

title: Japanese Prince Sets Tour
description: TOKYO, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Crown Prince Akihito and Princess Michiko will visit Australia and New Zealand for about 20 days starting May 10, the chief Cabinet secretary, Susumu Nikaido has announced.

title: 7 DEAD AT HOTEL IN CATSKILLS FIRE
description: Seven hotel employes, including five women, were killed early yesterday in a fire that swept through their living quarters in the Catskill Mountain hamlet of Kerhonkson, near Kingston, N.Y.

title: A. H. S. A.'s 3Day Convention Will Begin Here on Thursday
description: About 400 delegates and officials are expected to be on hand for the opening session of the 56th annual convention of the American Horse Shows Association at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel on Thursday.

title: McFall of California Is Chosen As the House Democratic Whip
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6John J. McFall of California was named today as majority whip of the House of Representatives, the No. 3 spot in the House Democratic leadership.

title: Miss Rita Faye Rubinstein Is Married
description: Miss Rita Faye Rubinstein of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Rubinstein of Skokie, Ill., was married here yesterday evening to Bernard Richard King, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice King of New York. Rabbi William Kloner and Cantor Robert Spiro officiated at the ceremony in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza.

title: Law
description: The battle lines were being drawn last week for what may shape up to be the most significant legal donnybrook in years. A committee appointed by Chief Justice Warren Burger and chaired by Prof. Paul Freund of the Harvard Law School recently made public its proposal to have Congress create a National Court of Appeals. Its function would be to screen all petitions for review now filed in the Supreme Court. Under the proposal, only a few hundred of the more than 3,000 cases currently filed in the High Court would come to the attention of the Justices; the remainder would be finally denied by the new court.

title: W. Palm Beach to Open The Boat Show Season
description: The West Palm Beach (Fia.) Sport, Boat and Vacation Show, the first major boat show of the year, will open at the West Palm Beach Auditorium on Thursday and will run for four days.

title: ROYAL AND REGAL 10LENGTH VICTOR
description: MIAMI, Jan. 6Jimmy Croll is racing at Calder Race Course for the first time this winter and the trainer could not be happier. Croll has started horses in six stakes at the meeting. He has won four of them and just missed winning the other two.

title: IAN FINKEL RAISES XYLOPHONE'S STATUS
description: Ian Finkel would obviously like to see the xylophone become a popular recital instrument, and he is trying to do something about it. On Friday night, he appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall with his brother, Elliot, a pianist, to play a program that showed enterprise in creating a concert repertory for the xylophone.

title: New London Theater Is First in 15 Years
description: LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP)The New London Theater, the first major theater constructed in the British capital in 15 years, has opened, a decade after a Yugoslav architect, Paul Tyrtkovic, first conceived it with a sketch on a coffeebar napkin.

title: Economic Upturn Through Decade Appears Possible
description: THE United States is in the midst of a new economic boom that may prove to be unrivaled in scope, power and influence by any previous expansion in its history. The momentum developed since the cyclical contraction of 196970 has become so broad and so balanced that an upturn reaching toward the next decade is a distinct possibility  if some serious pitfalls can be avoided in the coming year.

title: Auto Show to Open April 7
description: The 17th annual International Automobile Show, one of New York's harbingers of spring, will open Saturday, April 7, and run through Sunday, April 15, at the New York Coliseum.

title: A Transit Legend Lives in Brooklyn
description: Beneath Atlantic Avenue, near the East River, are the dank remains of a shortlived transit glory. Here, in the eighteenforties, Brooklyn proudly built the world's first subway. Its locomotives huffed and puffed barely 11 years before angry citizens hooted them off the scene.

title: Britain Salutes Market In Fanf are for Europe
description: LONDON, Jan. 6Paris is a beast of city to be in, proclaimed a short, stout actor in a ruffled coat and knee breeches.

title: Pretty enough to stop the presses
description: It's easy to stop the presses if you're all dressed up for Junemoon nights. If you're planning an island vacation or even thinking blissfully about next spring and summer, here's a selection of styles from the boutique collections of leading Seventh Avenue designers.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stocks finished the first week of 1973 in moviescript fashion for a bull market. When the closing bell rang Friday afternoonin a trading floor still adorned by Christmas decorationsthe market stood at its highest level in history.

title: Dance
Never put money into the background
description: What's the secret of creating smashing surroundings in rental apartments without spending a fortune? Designer Ronald Bricke offers advice that many New Yorkers can take to heart. It works, as his own twobedroom apartment shows. Never put money into the background. Forget about expensive wall coverings and fragile fabrics that will need replacing because of use, soil or boredom. (His walls are washed with white, all seating slipcovered and the floors stained in a tile effect.) This designer invests in accent pieces and an occasional antique that can move to new surroundings or be sold with very little, if any, depreciation at a later date. (The antique Italian mirror, the focal point of the dining space, is an example). Ingenuity helps, too. And Bricke has a lot of that. Witness the railroad kitchen stenciled with large blueandwhite checks, the idea borrowed from a restaurant in North Italian village and the Eastern fantasy of bedroom with patterned dacron voile.

title: In The Land of Opportunity Not All Share in the Boom
description: NEW ORLEANSBy the traditional gauges of the business world, the South is booming and promises to go on booming. Not everyone in the South, however, is sharing in the prosperity.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe key element in the productivity equation is the worker, and the noneconomic needs of the worker have been forgotten, said Senator Edward M. Kennedy at Senate hearings on job alienation last summer.

title: Strauss Bids Connally Return to Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The Democratic National Chairman, Robert S. Strauss, extended an open invitation today to fellow Texan John B. Connally to return to this party and bring with him his constituency.

title: Thomas Hardy And British Poetry
description: The thesis of the first of these books is that Hardy is the chief influence on 20thcentury British poetry. It is a surprising thesis but, as you would expect from Davieauthor of the best book written about Ezra Poundit is worked out in exemplary fashion. The influence is of several kinds: he sees Hardy as, stylistically, a selfconscious technician (doing a piecision job on stanza and meter), and politically, a liberal scientific humanist. He traces the influence of Hardy's attitude on British poets from Auden to the comparatively little known Roy Fisher. It appears sometimes in the attachment the British have to elaborate stanzaic form, but much more in their concern for being true to the limitation of common sense and in their distrust of large poetic claims. Both in his description of general patterns in Hardy's poetry and in close analysis Davie is more accurate and more helpful than any other critic I have read. And I certainly end up persuaded that Hardy has been the central though least acknowledged influence on modern British poetry.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: If the quinity of turgid tomes (recommended in your Christmas issue as significant books of 1972) is truly the result of a consensus on the part of your staff, I recommend firing the lot of them.

title: Solitary Confinement Is Barred Without a Hearing for Prisoner
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. (AP)A Federal judge has ruled that prison inmates have a constitutional rightto a bearing and counsel before being subjected to solitary confinement.

title: Headliners
description: Their pride pricked by a rash of critical barbs, New York State's judges have developed somthing of a thin skin in recent months. Last week they felt the lasha call for a radical revamping of the court system. The call game in a report issued by a commission created by the Legislature in 1970. Among the proposals: Toughened procedures for disciplining judges; centralization of the courts under administrative technicians rather than judgesand the total abolition of bail. No other state dispenses with bail, but the commission found that its use denies equal protection by imprisoning the poor and releasing the wealthy. The way in which bail is now set was also attacked; judges, said the commission, do not rely on statutory criteria.

title: Dayton Tops Xavier, 9882
description: CINCINNATI, Jan.. 6 (A)Don Smith scored 44 points, 32 in the first half, to lead Dayton to a 9882 college basketball victory over Xavier of Ohio today. Xavier was led by Connie Warren with 23 points.

title: This May Be the Year for Tennis Without Politics
description: Chris Evert begins trading cups for cash, Ken Rosewall and John Newcombe will seek to restore Australia's faded tennis fortunes, and Stan Smith, the world's No. 1 player, will find out how tough the weekly tournament circuit can be.

title: A Dean Named at Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 6 (AP)Dr. Kenneth P. Goodrich, 39 years old, vice president and provost of Macalester College in St. Paul, has been appointed dean of Syracuse University's College of Arts and Sciences, effective July 1. He will succeed Dr. Nathan Ginsburg, who has been acting dean since last summer.

title: DecisionMakers Assess National Priorities
description: ELI GOLDSTON, president, Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates: Learning how to contain inflation at about 3 per cent per annum without high unemployment and without impairment of personal or economic freedom. Above 3 per cent inflation transfers income to the strong unionized labor, oligopolistic companies and restrictive professional groupsfrom the weakunorganized labor, welfare and pension recipients and tenants. We must devise better stratagems to limit inflation than high joblessness or abandonment of personal mobility.

title: Floating Auto Insurance Rates Face Uncertain Future
description: After a long, and often ruthless campaign to weed out the bad and the unwanted, automobile insurance companies are once again actively looking for customers.

title: BUILDING IS DELAYED ON SMALL CARRIERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (Reuters)The Defense Department has postponed for at least a year the building of a new class of miniaircraft carrier, called the sea control ship, a pet program of the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., informed military sources said yesterday.

title: Cahill to Ask Moratorium On DriverInsurance Card
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7 (UPI)Governor Cahill has announced that he would ask the Legislature on Tuesday to approve moratorium on the requirement that drivers carry proof of auto insurance with them.

title: Winter Is Unusually Mild Around Leningrad So Far
description: MOSCOW, Jan, 6 (Reuters)Mushrooms are growing in forests near Leningrad and buds are swelling on the trees because of an exceptionally mild Russian winter, according to the Soviet press agency Tass.

title: SHIP BLAZE QUELLED IN CHESAPEAKE BAY
description: NORFOLK, Va., Sunday, Jan. 7A 560foot freighter was on fire in the Chesapeake Bay about 40 miles north of here last night, the Coast Guard said, but no serious injuries were reported as three cutters and two other ships helped battle the flames.

title: Nassau Housing Is Down
description: Nassau County had a sharp decline in the annual rate of residential construction in the last decade and a switch in emphasis from singlefamily to multifamily homes.

title: Whale Dies in Aquarium Here After Capture at Beach Haven
description: The whale captured alive after being washed ashore Wednesday at Beach Haven, N. J., died at the New York Aquarium yesterday. It was the third stranded whale to have died here recently.

title: Miss Spruance 3Set Victor
description: Gretchen Spruance of Wilmington, Del., won the second annual women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Columbia University Club yesterday by defeating Gail Ramsay of Philadelphia. The scores were 1510, 1510, 159.

title: CHARLES P. NOONAN
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 6Charles P. Noonan, former national sales manager for the Packard Motorcar Corporation and a former vice president of the Chrysler Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 25 Tokeneke Trail. He was 57 years old.

title: Letters: Palmy Past
description: To The Editor:

title: Jimmy Jemail of News Retires as Questioner
description: Jimmy Semail, the inquiring fotographer of The Daily News for more than half a century, has retired, it was announced yesterday.

title: Detroit Lists 10Rounder
description: DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP)Al (Blue) Lewis, a Detroit heavyweight, will meet Charlie (Giant) Reno of Seattle in 10round bout Jan. 22 at Olympia Stadium before the closedcircuit telecast of the Joe FrazierGeorge Foreman world heavyweight championship match.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Hunting Waterfowl
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass, Sometime after midnight, the wind died and a soft, wet snow began to fall, a snow that made the familiar drive along the edge of salt ponds and a day at 5 A.M. strange and mysterious.

title: U.S. SCHOLARS END A VISIT TO CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 6Prof. Alexander Eckstein, leader of a United States delegation that has just visited China to discuss ChineseAmerican cultural exchanges, said here today that prospects of a gradual expansion of exchanges look very promising although the delegation reached no agreement with the Chinese on concrete plans.

title: An Irish Dog Fancier Makes Mark With German Shepherd
description: Ireland is famous for its wolfhounds, terriers and setters. But none of these breeds has brought fame to Denis J. Smyth, the 69yearold director and secretary of the Irish Kennel Club. Smyth was one of the first Irishmen to show the German shepherd in his country. I saw some when I was visiting in London, in 1926, he recalled. The next year bought Garryowen of Dunema. I made a champion of him and later finished several others.

title: Restaurant Not World, Is a Stage In Oranges
description: EAST ORANGE  The tors Cafe Theater, with only 22 small tables and 97 chairs crammed into it, seems like the smallest theater in captivity. Converted from a restaurant, it is tucked in back of Zigler's Liquor Store, at the corner of Munn and Central Avenues, and so playgoers, if they like, can pick up their own bottles and sip while watching a show.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: LIFE and Black movies are inextricable. Black Americans are people. And people of America in particular. If the silver screen fantasies are any measure of their identity, then they are no more and no less than American, and its associated systembuilt on greed and not need.

title: 46 Million People in 9.21 Million Boats
description: When a new year begins, boating experts usually bang heads, with one set looking back into 1972 and the other set concentrating on what's coming up in '73. Let's look at both sides. A record 46 million people participated in recreational boating last year, and they spent a record $3.9billion doing it, according to two industry trade groups, International Marine Expositions, Inc. (Marex) and the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers (N.A.E.B.M.).

title: MEAT PRICES HERE UP 1020C IN 1972
description: The veal cutlet seems to have become something of a status symbol.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Consolidated Edison announced yesterday that a $110million temporary rate increase for electric, gas and steam service would go into effect next Wednesday. A Con Edison spokesman said the increase, averaging 7.7 percent, was being made in accordance with the Public Service Commission's order authorizing the increase. It is subject to refund if the P.S.C. disallows a permanent increase.

title: Homo Improvement
description: SEVERAL recent studies have shown that most of the homes now standing do not have enough insulation. As a result homeowners are consuming more fuel than they shouldthus adding unneccessarily to the already high cost of home maintenance, while also adding to the problems of air pollution and energy shortages.

title: McGovern's Total is Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) A late change in the official Presidential vote in California trimmed 273 votes from Senator George McGovern's total for that state. Three weeks after the election, the California Secretary of State's office listed Mr. McGovern's vote in the state as 3,476,120. The official McGovern vote subsequently was revised downward to 3,475,847.

title: Wisconsin Upholds Award In Disguised Policeman Case
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 6 (UPI) In Wisconsin, police officers in disguise must make a reasonable effort to identify themselves when making arrests or be liable for damages, the state's Supreme Court has ruled.

title: State Study Says Busing Fails to Integrate Schools
description: A special legislative commission has concluded that compulsory busing alone is failing as a means of integration and that that failure has resulted in a major cause of academic unrest.

title: Harry's Lovely Farewell
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Every once in a while, something happens in the capital of the United States which reminds us of the continuity of American life, heals our tragic misunderstandings, and connects our religious past to the modern secular age.

title: Metal Producers Find Benefits as Well as Battles in Pollution Campaign
description: The metals and mining industries are inextricably involved in meeting the demands of environmentalists to clean up the manufacturing processand the involvement is expected to increase.

title: The World
description: Britain and Market

title: Snowman Left Tracks, Scientist in Nepal Says
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 5 (Reuters)The abominable snowman reportedly walked within one foot of the tent of two American explorers in a remote area of eastern Nepal on Dec. 20.

title: Home for the Aging Reaffirms Its Roots
description: High on a hill overlooking its own park on 167th Street, between Findlay and Teller Avenues in the Bronx, the main building of the Daughters of Jacob Geriatric Center, with its eight wings radiating from a central core like the spokes of a wheel, has been a neighborhood landmark since 1916.

title: Overseas Dialing for Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Japan's International Telephon and Telegraph Company plan to adopt an automatic dialing system for calls to the United States and Europe by the ?? of March, the company said

title: Music: Now We Have the Halaphone
description: Remember those early, innocent days in 1959 when stereo recording was introduced? When the engineers had the joy of recording PingPong balls: left speaker, middle, right speaker? Tap, tap, tap, and your head was moving left to right. Onward goes time, and instruments are more and more sophisticated, and now we have the halaphone.

title: WALL STREET
description: It's the time of the year for crystal ball gazing in Wall Street, when stock market analysts are looking ahead and making decisions about the investment outlook.

title: SQUIRES CONQUER COLONELS, 113109
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 6 (AP) Julius Erving scored 4 points in the last minute tonight as the Virginia Squires defeated the Kentucky Colonels, 113109, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: President Nixon has announced his Intention to ask Congress to extend authority for price and wage controls beyond April 30, 1973, when the present statute expires. Administration spokesmen have indicated that there may he extensive changes of the control regulations now in effect under the Phase Two program.

title: Miss Morrison Plans Wedding
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Jan. 6 The engagement of Miss Pamela Jean Morrison to Bradford Hammond Warner, son of Mrs. Bradford Newman Warner of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mr. Warner, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Morrison Jr. of Bay Shore.

title: Australia Traffic Toll Drops
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 6 (Reuters)The first full year of compulsory seatbelt wearing in New South Wales state has helped produce a fall in the traffic death rate per 10,000 registered vehicles from 6.9 in 1971 to 5.7 last year, according to figures released here.

title: New PlumbingGroup Chief
description: Melvyn S. Fein, a graduate of Cornell University and a professional engineer who is president and chief executive officer of Wachtel, Duklauer & Fein, a subsidiary of National Kinney Corporation, was elected president of the Association of Contracting Plumbers of New York City yesterday. He succeeds another engineer, William J. Murphy.

title: Prospects Clouded For Labor Accords
description: WASHINGTON  This is the worst year yet for crystalball gazing, said one longtime expert on collective bargaining when asked to comment on prospects for labormanagement peace in 1973.

title: The President's Power
description: The relief that millions in the United States and other nations felt over President Nixon's decision to halt, or rather to suspend, the terror raids against Hanoi and Haiphong has an ironic overtone. Its implication is that the more indiscriminate the weapons, the greater will be the appreciation when they are stilled. It is a policy of so escalating the pain that any letup gives the appearance of moderation and mercy.

title: Judge Says War Objectors May Earn V.A. Benefits
description: BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP)Conscientious objectors who satisfactorily complete two years of alternative service are entitled to the same educational benefits as military veterans, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Signs of Bus Compromise Seen As Meskill Joins Strike Talks
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 6  With faint signs of compromise in the long, complicated dispute that has kept buses idle in much of Connecticut for months, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill has joined personally in talks with the negotiating committee of local officials.

title: Destroyer Mishap Fells 2
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 6 (AP)  A shell exploded prematurely yesterday in one of the two 5inch guns of the guided missile destroyer Henry B. Wilson, injuring two crewmen, the United States command reported. A spokesman said today that the crewmen were not seriously hurt and were evacuated to an Army hospital in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam.

title: SOUTH SETS BACK NORTH, 33 TO 30
description: MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 6The South beat the North in the Senior Bowl game today, 33.30, and top honors went to Chuck Foreman, a 6foot3inch, 205pound running back from Miami of Florida. Foreman, who comes from Frederick, Md., won the new automobile as the most valuable player in this exciting game, one played well by the 56 college seniors who had only a week to practice as team units.

title: Bay State Toll a Record
description: BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP)  A record 988 persons were killed in Massachusetts traffic accidents during 1972. The fatality toll was 80 more deaths than in 1971, and it exceeded the previous record of 953 set in 1934, a spokesman for the state Registry of Motor Vebicles said.

title: ATLANTA SOCCER WILL BE REVIVED
description: The Omni Group, which owns the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association and the Flames of the National Hockey League, announced yesterday that it had purchased the franchise of the defunct Atlanta Chiefs of the North American Soccer League.

title: GAMBLING LAW DUE FOR TEST IN HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 6Hawales new penal code, which went into effect New Year's Day, will face an early test of its provisions permitting social gambling.

title: SCIENTISTS FEEL LIFE IS POSSIBLE ON SATURN MOON
description: Although the earth's moon is dry and lifeless, scientists are reporting new evidence that some satellites of other planets in the solar system are covered with water ice and may have thin atmospheres and that at least one might support lower forms of life.

title: Suzanne Lloyd Will Be Bride
description: FOX CHAPEL, Pa., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Francis Lloyd Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Landon Lloyd, to Richard Gardner Canfield Jr., son of Mrs. Canfield of Pittsburgh, and the late Dr. Canfield. The wedding will take place on May 19 at the Fox Chapel Episcopal Church.

title: State Using Old Tires To Seal Highway Joints
description: In an effort to improve the landscape as well as the riding qualities of New York State's highways, the State Department of Transportation has embarked on a program to use 200,000 pounds or more of rubber from discarded automobile tires as a sealant for joints and cracks in the state's roads.

title: F.D.A. Rescinds Approval Of Drug Used for Vertigo
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration has withdrawn marketing approval for the controversial drug Serc after an investigator reportedly concluded that it actually increases episodes of vertigo, the ailment it was designed to treat.

title: Meskill's Flying Bill
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 6 (AP) Gov. Thomas J. Meskill yesterday paid a bill for $931.25 for his recent flight training, which brought him his private pilot's license. The bill, based on 62 hours, 5 minutes of flying time during training in the stateowned 1966 Cessna 172, was given to Meskill by the State Department of Transportation.

title: Census Data on Burlington
description: Oneeighth of Burlington County's over25 residents have completed four years of college, according to the Census Bureau. In an analysis of 1970 census figures, the bureau also found that 60 per cent of the over25 group were high school graduates.

title: Police Issue a Sketch of Witness They Hope Will Identify Killer of Teacher in West Side Apartment
description: Police detectives investigating last week's knife slaying of 28yearold Roseann Quinn in her West Side apartment said yesterday that they were searching for a witness who might be able to identify the killer.

title: Three out of live new businesses fail in the first two and a half years of operationTwo guys who made if with their Umbroller
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N.Y. Like many young executive dropouts in recent years, Alexandre Goodwin and Deaver Brown were willing to risk financial security for the kick of making it on their own. In November, 1970, the two young men, who had been friends in high school, quietly left their jobs to establish a company in Westchester County. Goodwin, at the age of 25, had been earning $14,000 a year as a lawyer with the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department in Washington; Brown was 26 and making $25,000 annually as a rising young product manager with mammoth General Foods in White Plains, N.Y.

title: NASCAR Season Opens Jan. 21
description: What, so soon? It seems like only yesterday that falling leaves signaled the end of the 1972 racing season, and already we are on the threshold of the 1973 schedule. Two weeks from today the season starts with tbe loud bang of 427inch engines as bruitish, 4,000pound latemodel stock cars run in the 11th annual Winston Western 500 at Riverside, Calif., 60 miles east of Los Angeles.

title: EAST STARS WIN W.H.A. GAME 62
description: QUEBEC, Jan. 6 (AP)John McKenzie, Larry Pleau and Jim Dorey scored in the second period today in helping the East Division to a 62 victory over the West in the World Hockey Association's first AllStar game.

title: Nicklaus and Palmer Join Hogan, Jones and Hagen in Golf's Top 5 Poll
description: Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer have been voted among the five greatest golfers in a national poll of golf writers.

title: Israeli Intellectuals Demand Abolition of Censorship of Theater
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 6A campaign to abolish governmental censorship of the theater has been started by 145 of Israel's leading writers and intellectuals. Their drive came in the wake of the banning of a controversial play that satirizes the Israeli Establishment.

title: The Blue Room: Restored Again To Its 1817 Style
description: WASHINGTONIn the summer of 1814, when the United States was at war with Great Britain, and enemy troops were drawing close to Washington, Dolley Madison sat alone in the White House listening to the sound of the cannons.

title: The FoliesBergere at the Age of 55: It Is What It Used to Be
description: AMERICANS in Paris rarely go there nowadays, though the FoliesBergre was the place to go in the 1920's, when George Gershwin wrote An American in Paris. Today people go to the Lido, the Crazy Horse and other in spots; the FoliesBergre, on the unfashionable rue Richer, has a faint dmod flavor.

title: The Imperative Of Image
description: PARISImage is an inexact word to apply to a country's international status but nevertheless the concept has an ultimately vital effect in the arcane art of policy. This concept has now become primordial for the United States and it is obvious no democratic government can ignore its existence.

title: G.I. DRUG USE SEEN RISING IN EUROPE
description: BONN, Jan. 6The use of hard drugs by young American soldiers stationed in Europe is increasing at an alarming rate, according to two United States Congressmen who have been investigating the problem here.

title: Larry Brown Named N.F.L.'s Best by A.P.
description: Larry Brown of the Washington Redskins was named yesterday as The Associated Press's most valuable player in the National Football League.

title: Song: With Nostalgia
description: A good song is hard to find (to paraphrase a good prewomen's lib song) but al most three dozen good songs were found for a program called All the Things They Were in Gershwin Theater at Brooklyn College Friday evening. It was presented by the Institute for Studies in American Music, a division of the Brooklyn College department of music.

title: 140 Church Groups Join In Huge Evangelical Drive
description: More than 140 church groups in the United States and Canada, including most of the major denominations, began last night what is said to be the biggest evangelical campaign ever undertaken ecumenically.

title: New Skill: VendingMachine Repair
description: FRANKLINVILLE  The youth appeared to be tampering with the pinball machine. He would put in his quarter, but the machine would not light up for him.

title: FOUNDATION ASKS STUDIES ON POLICE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Police Foundation said today that many methods and standards used by policemen patrols, investigative details, height and weight requirements and limits on the use of womenhave not turned out to be the best ways of' fighting crime.

title: Insurance Official Backs Payments for Acupuncture
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 6 (UPI)  Americans who have medical and hospitalization insurance probably can collect under it for Chinese acupuncture treatments, Herbert S. Denenberg, Pennsylyania's Insurance Commissioner, said this week.

title: Recordings
description: WHITHER Montserrat Cabana An odd question, perhaps, considering the fact that she is securely positioned in the world of opera as one of today's half dozen or so bigleague sopranos. Yet during the past eight years, since that concert performance of Lucrezia Borgia with the American Opera Society in April 1965 catapulted her to stardom literally overnight, the Caball career has followed a rather haphazard course and still seems curiously unfulfilled. This opinion is shared to some extent by those behindthescenes people who have played a large part in presenting Caball to the publicparticularly so at RCA, the company that sponsored her first international recordings and now has high hopes that Norma, both the new recording (RCA LSC 6202, three disks) and next month's Met performances, will give Caball the kind of sweeping critical and public triumph that has eluded her (in New York at any rate) since Lucrezia.

title: Kelly Quits U.S.C. Five
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (UPI) Victor Kelly, 5foot6inch University of California guard, said last night he had quit the Trojan basketball team and planned to transfer to another school at the semester break.

title: 7 Co to Trial Tomorrow in BreakIn at Democratic Offices
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Watergate case is set to move into court on Monday, and after six months of intensive inquiry and speculation a formal, official airing of the politically explosive affair is at hand.

title: Southern Slugger Returns $6.20 in Sprint at Lincoln
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Jan. 6 (AP) Southern Slugger, the 21 favorite rallied from far back and pulled away in the stretch today in winning the $5,000 allowance feature before a crowd of 8,013 at Lincoln Downs.

title: FRAZIER EXCELS
description: The Knicks bade farewell last night to Madison Square Garden for 19 days and, as usual, their dear old home court was the scene of another New York victory. The Knicks' sixth player  the capacity crowd of 19,694  cheered a 116106 triumph over the Houston Rockets.

title: U.S. MAY REDUCE ITS WELFARE ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Officials of the Nixon Administration are studying a proposal that would have the Federal Government turn over to the states responsibility for many of the health, welfare and educational programs created by the Kennedy and Johnston Administrations.

title: Bank Ends Experiment In Electronic Shopping
description: SYOSSET, L. I.For Hempstead Bank, the first day of the New Year meant the official end of the paperless banking service that was offered at its branch here.

title: Canadiens Regain Lead, Beat Golden Seals, 5 to 0
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (UPI)A twogoal performance by Guy Lafleur and Ken Dryden's fourth shutout of the season led the Montreal Canadiens back into first place in the National Hockey League's East Division tonight as they beat the California Golden Seals, 50.

title: Phobia Project Seeks Freedom From Fear By ALICE MURRAY
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I.The hundred and one secret fears that can paralyze the flow of daily life are blandly itemized here on a list called the Hillside Hospital Fear Inventory.

title: Miss Barbara Mar Wed to David Pong
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6In Grace Episcopal Cathedral here this afternoon, Miss Barbara Mar of Hong Kong was married to David Pong, an assistant professor in the department of history at the University of Delaware. Canon James Pun performed the ceremony. The Right Rev. James TeMing Pong, Episcopal Bishop of Taiwan and father of the bridegroom, gave the benediction.

title: No Council Hearings
description: The City Council has not scheduled any public hearings for this week.

title: The Economic Censuses Count, Too
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6This week, three years after the decennial counting of heads, tke Census Bureau has begun its periodic count of bombs, mittens, slaughtered hogs and just about every other aspect of the immense American economy.

title: Controls Face Key Test
description: WASHINGTONThe year 1973 looms as a time of crucial testing of the Nixon Administration's proposition that by combining fiscal restraint with continued wageprice controls it can curb inflation while the economy chalks up another year of brisk growth.

title: Travel Notes: To Honolulu and Back for $218
description: AFTER all the skirmishing by airline officials over fares, the public now gets a chance to shop for ticket bargains. The opportunity comes today with the announcement of details of a plan by United Air Lines to slash fares by up to 61 per cent between New York and the West Coast and Honolulu starting from June 1. United's, program takes advantage of the ruling last fall by the Civil Aeronautics Borad that allows all travelers, not just members of affinity organizations, to fly on lowcost nonscheduled charter flights.

title: Approach of ElectronicMoney Age Spurs Sharp Debate Among Bankers
description: The age of electronic money, which has long been heralded by financial visionaries, is at long last slowly beginning to dawn.

title: Schenk Leads Speed Skating
description: THE HAGUE, Netherlands, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Ard Schenk of the Netherlands, winner of three gold medals at the 1972 Olympic winter games at Sapporo, Japan, led the general classification after the first day of a twoday professional speed skating leagues' championship meet for the World Cup today. Schenk's times were 41.06 seconds for 500 meters and 7 minutes 34.86 seconds for 5,000 meters.

title: Peking Loan to Congo
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, Jan. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)China has agreed to lend the Congo Republic nearly $400,000, the Brazzaville radio Ireported today. The agreement was signed here yesterday.

title: GOLF LEAD SHARED BY MISS PRENTICE
description: MIAMI, Jan. 6 (AP)Joann Prentice, who considers herself at the twilight of her career, and young Pam Higgins shared the lead today after two rounds of the 54hole Burdines invitation golf tournament with fourunderpar 140s.

title: Engineering College Aids Minorities
description: NEWARK  It may take many years before the results are felt, but an unusual advancestudy program for high school students at Newark College of Engineering has the future in mind.

title: New Leaders for a New Wall St.
Suffolk Legislators Counting Votes
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.The 18 members of the Suffolk County Legislature have plunged into what promises to be a busy legislative year but more than any single bill or type of legislation, the 1973 session promises to be one dominated by politicsfor this is the year the voters will decide who remains and who leaves that body.

title: Montauk Manor To Reopen
description: MONTAUK, L. I.Montauk Manor a lofty 200room landmark hotel here on the East End of Long Island, will reopen as a hotel this summer for the first time since 1964, officials of Hilton Inns, Inc. and a contracting concern said last week.

title: Teen Arts Fete Expanding
description: TRENTONFor the last three years, the New Jersey Teen Arts Festival has been fostering teenage involvement in the arts through local and statewide festivals. However, TAF gained official status in September, when it became an agency of the state's Department of Education, and it is now in the process of expanding its operations and revising its festival program.

title: Louisiana Slates Election To Fill Seat Held by Boggs
description: BATON ROUGE, Jan. 6 (AP) Gov. Edwin Edwards has officially called for a March 20 election to fill the vacant Congressional seat of Democratic Representative Hale Boggs, who has been missing in a flight over Alaska since Oct. 16.

title: ANDERSON TOPPLES NEWCOMBE IN UPSET
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 6 (AP)Mal Anderson, 37 years old, upset John Newcombe, 57, 64, 64, 64, in the semifinals of the $19,000 New South Wales open tennis championship today.

title: Will Success Spoil Stanley, Idaho? A Frontier Town Sells Its Privacy for Dollars
description: All I care about tourists is their money ... We're so happy when summer and the hunting seasons are over. We're just neighbors in the winter.

title: Is U.S. Energy Flagging?
description: WASHINGTON  Whenever the shortage of fuels and electric power is discussed these days, someone invariably asserts that what this country needs is a national energy policy.

title: Miss Franco Sets Nuptials
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 6  Mrs. Redington Franco of West Hartford and Kennebunk Beach, Me., and Dr. John E. Franco of West Hartford, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherin Anne Franco to Addison Bliss Marsh of Hartford.

title: President, Planning Budget, Seeks to Avert Inflation
description: WASHINGTONThe Federal Government's economic policy in 1973 will be dominated by the struggle to control its own spending.

title: House G.O.P. Backs President in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The House Republican Conference voted 135 to 7 today to support the efforts of President Nixon to negotiate an end to the Vietnam war.

title: The New York Times Book Review
description: FICTION

title: Tax Relief for the Elderly in Focus
description: The time has come to stop talking about the impact of property taxes on older Americans and to act in their behalf.

title: Youth Views Business in Many Lights
description: BERKELEY, Calif.Maybe we're not respresentative, Bob Godfrey said. We're not the pseudointellectuals. But, on the other hand, we take it all seriously. He was describing his attitude and those of two fellow business students, Steve Wong and Arthur Louie.

title: Miss Ricci Fiancee Of John Stewart 3d
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 6  Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Ricci have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Melissa McLaughlin Ricci, to John M. Stewart 3d, son of Mrs. Kingsley Swan Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. and the late John M. Stewart.

title: THE FAR WEST
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For nearly 70 years since the great earthquake and fire, San Francisco has grown and prospered. And although it is still perched precariously on the San Andreas Fault that shook it down in 1906, the city, with its spirit of optimism, continues to build.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Brooklyn Needs Site To House Port Zone
description: The city's Economic Development Administration is actively looking for a new home for a valuable port asset  Foreign Trade Zone No. 1.

title: Point of View
description: The renewal of decaying sections of our cities remains one of the most crucial problems facing the nation, and we have reached another turning point in the history of our efforts to solve it.

title: 16 NAMED BY NIXON TO PANEL ON WOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) President Nixon has announced the appointment of 13 women and three men to a new advisory committee on the economic role of women.

title: Youth, 16, Honored In World Of Science
description: In the third grade Van Wedeen concocted some mischievous stink bombs. In the fifth grade he devised an artificial heart. Later, in the seventh grade, he created a mechanical arm with two different types of hands.

title: Rising Costs Spur Welfare Reform
description: It was no mere coincidence that California and New York City cracked down on welfare and then saw their credit ratings lifted last year.

title: Sing a Song of Money
description: THE ROTHSCHILDS, the musical saga a the international banking family ?? racked up 507 performance on Broadway, is getting ?? new lease on lifeas a movie Its producer, Hillard Elkins will coproduce the film with 20th CenturyFox, with shoot ing to start late this year ?? such locations as Frankfurt London, Paris and Rome. ?? befits the Rothschilds, ?? budget will be about $5million.

title: Business
description: The newspaper ads proclaim gifts galore! and outstanding values! Tall windows are decked out with flashy displays of gleaming alarm clocks, cutlery sets, blenders, electric blankets and footballsall winners with the customers queueing up four and five deep on the main floor.

title: Retailers Seek Answers
description: On Tuesday, several prominent Seventh Avenue producers will face some searching questions by retailers at a meeting of the Youth Fashion Guild on why many apparel orders are not filled, why deliveries are late and perhaps most important why there are continuing problems of inadequate quality and workmanship in apparel.

title: Linda Verner Married
description: RED BANK, N. J., Jan. 6Miss Linda Bradford Verner, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Vincent Lawrence of Rumson and the late William Stebbins Verner, was married this afternoon to Brien Carl Combs in the First Presbyterian Church of Red Bank by the Rev. Dr. Charles S. Webster. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Clarence Carl Combs of Scobeyville.

title: No Indictments to Be Given In Death of an Electrician
description: A Bronx grand jury has voted not to indict anyone in the death of Jorge Gallardo, 26yearold Bronx electrician, during a demonstration by drivers of gypsy cabs in the South Bronx last September. Several drivers had charged that the man was thrown from a roof by two policemen.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: OUTLOOK CLOUDY ON PAROCHIAL AID
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6The prospects for new forms of state aid to parochial schools are highly uncertain as the 1973 legislative session begins, largely because many of the laws passed here in the last three years to help the nonpublic schools have been ruled unconstitutional or are still in the courts.

title: In Trade, Year of Europe
description: WASHINGTONThe new year will usher in major developments, in international monetary and trade negotiations aimed at reforming the rules that govern economic relations among nations. Final results are not so predictable.

title: Education
description: At Saint Paul High School in Chicago, the students study English, social studies and religion in their parochial classrooms; but when it comes time for their classes in such subjects as mathematics, science and foreign languages, they walk two and a half blocks to a public school, John F. Kennedy High School. Through a dualenrollment program, every student at Saint Paul is also a student at Kennedy.

title: Writs Against Reporters Arouse Debate
description: The recent wave of subpoenas and contemptofcourt citaations against newsmen has provoked intense discussion over how far government can go before it interferes with the public's right to a free flow of information.

title: Commodities Turn Volatile
description: Commodity traders, analysts and speculators were catching their breath after one of the most eventful years in memory.

title: Bronx Practical Nurse, 60, Is Killed Boarding Train
description: A 60yearold practical nurse going on vacation to Georgia with her grandniece was killed yesterday when she fell between the platform and a moving train at the Pennsylvania Railroad Terminal.

title: Super Bowl Back at Original Site
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6The Super Bowl returns to its original home, the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, next Sunday. The sixyear absence seem ingly has made a lot of hearts fonder.

title: ST. JOHN'S BEATS DAVIDSON, 7877
description: DAVIDSON, N. C., Jan. 6 (UPI)Bill Schaeffer hit a jump shot with four seconds remaining tonight to give St. John's a 7877 basketball victory over Davidson.

title: Art Notes
description: MAY graffiti abound on our building facades; may museums not dispose of their treasure

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: A Guidebook In French for Peripatetic Pups
description: THE negative way of traveling with a dog in France is to thumb through a Guide Michelin and note those establishments marked with a drawing of a dog's head with a slash through it. That insulting sign stands for Accs interdit aux chiens, which in rough, even cruel, translation means, Keep that smelly, barking hound away from here. We have paying guests. Any hotel or restaurant without the antidog symbol will, presumably, welcome travelers with dogs. But what a way to plan a dog's wellearned vacation! How negative! How depressing!

title: Where Lies Tomorrow?
description: Throughout history men have come to believe, from time to time, that they have mastered the world, are the possessors of this earth and the rulers of the life upon it. And repeatedly the artificial world of their own making has reached a point of arrogance and alienation where it became necessary to find some way back, some answers to the questions Where are we? and Where lies tomorrow?

title: Mrs. Marcos Has Surgery
description: MANILA, Jan. 6 (UPI)Mrs. Ferdinand E. Marcos, wife of the President, has undergone minor surgery for removal of a tendon suture, the Government announced. Mrs. Marcos, who was stabbed by an attacker Dec. 7, was healing very satisfactorily, the Government said.

title: 2 Enter Race Against Leone
description: A threeway race for the Democratic nomination for Borough President has erupted in Brooklyn and the field may well be expanded before the primary voting on June 20.

title: Sports Complex Worries Rutherford
description: RUTHERFORD  Many of this community's residents are worried about the sports complex to be built in the Hackensack meadowlands, where the football Giants are expected to play in 1975, because plans call for Rutherford to house a part of the perimeter of the complex, including a housing development and a network of roads.

title: SHOP TALK
description: GARFIELDUntil this becomes a perfect world, the problem of what to do with electric shavers that don't work, but look too new to throw away, will continue to exist.

title: The basic Woody Allen joke:
description: I am writing this piece because in a moment of notsocareless rapture I recently reviewed the movie Everything You Always Wanted to Know About SexBut Were Afraid to Ask, and caned its creator, Woody Allen, the most important comic talent now working in this country. An editor of this magazine then called up and asked me to defend, if I could, that statement.

title: Bridge
description: Forty years ago the first match ever billed as a world championship was played in London. Bridge historians have deprived it of world rating, since it was a private promotion rather than an effort by a world organization, but the point could be argded. An international trophy was at stake, the Schwab Cup, and the intention was to enlarge the competition in later years to include other countries.

title: Sophia Loren Gives Birth To Her 2d Son in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Jan. 6 (AP)The screen actress Sophia Loren gave birth today to her second son. The 8pound baby was delivered by a Caesarian section at Geneva's Cantonal Hospital, where the first son of the actress and her husband, Carlo Ponti, was born almost four years ago.

title: N.B.A. LineUps
description: AT MILWAUKEE

title: Dr. Meriwether Makes a Call
description: Dr. Delano Meriwether calls it my usual schedule, which means getting out maybe once or twice a week to train for his track and field experience.

title: 4 New Sickle Cell Clinics Open, Bringing Total to 15
description: The opening of four more sickle cell testing clinics, bringing the city's total to 15, was announced yesterday by Health Services Administrator Gordon Chase.

title: U.S. Reports Strikes on Caches in North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 7 (Reuters)  American bombers raided the North Vietnamese panhandle again yesterday, the United States command said, striking targets near key junctions and storage areas of military equipment destined for the South.

title: 3 Switch to Work In an Ancient Art
description: MEDFORD, L. I. Three men who abandoned whitecollar jobs to join in an ancient craft have kept the art of woodcarving alive here in the Sun King Sign Shop Building on Route 112 north of Patchogue. The three partners in the enterprise work collectively under the name Chip Fyn.

title: Winds Defeat islanders, 40, for Edwards's 3d Shutout of Season
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 6 The spectacle of 41yearold Alex Delvecchio outskating two kids just about half his age was the real highlight of the Detroit Red Wings' victory over the New York Islanders at the Nassau Coliseum tonight. The Detroit outfit had a relatively easy task against the firstyear Long Island sextet, winning by the score of 40.

title: Science
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal scientific establishment, a vast, complex, untidy and shapeless collection of brains and gadgets, was beginning to feel last week somewhat like the bastard at the family picnic. Word seeped out of the White House of yet another bleak budget year for the medical and space programs while more scientific leaders left Federal serviceincluding the science adviser to the President himself, Dr. Edward E. David Jr.

title: Block Island Gets Gift To Help Find Doctor
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. L, Jan. 6 (AP)An anonymous donor has improved Block Island's chances of locating a permanent town physician by giving them $10,000 for remodeling and renovating the doctor's quarters.

title: Track Writers Group Will Meet Tomorrow
description: The Track Writers Association will hold its first weekly meeting of the year at noon tomorrow at Mamma Leone's Ristorante, 239 West 48th Street. Meetings will be held each Monday through May, except for a onemonth spring recess.

title: Elizabeth Stribling Plans Bridal
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 6Mrs. Thomas Earle Stribling of Atlanta has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Miss Elizabeth French Stribling of New York, to William Charles Mitchell Kivlan. He is the son of Mrs. Edwin Gerard Kivlan of New York and the late Mr. Kivlan.

title: Sites Selected for Six Parks on Erie Canal
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6Governor Rockefeller announced today that the Office of Parks and Recreation had chosen sites for six parks and three hiking trails on state lands adjoining the state canal system, as part of a pilot recreation project.

title: For Jefferson And Liberty
description: Americans are a FuturePeople. They look constantly ahead, rarely behind, and then usually to congratulate themselves (though they are not alone in that). American children, cultured for Tomorrowland, have at present little interest in history. This is felt to be a lack and perhaps it is. To stimulate such interest, maybe in answer to the requests, both of librarians and teachers, publishers are now issuing books with a lively and more personal view of history. Leonard Falkner's For Jefferson and Liberty is one such book.

title: HOWARD WORTHAM, INVESTMENT ADVISER
description: Howard F. Wortham, who retired two years ago as chairman of the board of the Trainer, Wortham & Co., investment counseling organization here, died Friday at his home, 575 Park Avenue. His age was 81.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 7, 1973

title: Neville Bryan, William Peltz Are Betrothed
description: Judge Frederick van Pelt Bryan of the Southern District of New York and Mrs. Bryan of New York and Wingdale, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Neville Farquharson Bryan, to William Hun Peitz, son of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Peitz of Manchester, Vt., and Martha's Vineyard, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: THIEU TAKES POWER OVER CIVIC GROUPS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 6 (AP)President Nguyen Van Thieu has issued a decree giving the Government power over almost every kind of association.

title: JOB SAFETY SUIT ANGERS U.S. AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 George C. Guenther, head of the Occupational Safety, and Health Administration, has accused a minority of national labor leaders of trying to scuttle the Federal job safety program by preventing the Labor Department from turning enforcement authority over to the states.

title: Dave Anderson
description: On the scoreboard at Three Rivers Stadium last Sunday, the Miami Dolphins were leading the Pittsburgh Steelers, 2117, in the final minutes of the American Conference championship game. In the excitement of their offensive huddle, several Dolphins were babbling suggestions.

title: IVORY COAST USES TV IN CLASSROOMS
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 3 A brighteyed secondgrader, Pierre Koussi, speaks better French than many students in the sixth or seventh grades, to the delight of educational planners.

title: House to Hire Lawyer To Fight Common Cause
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The House voted today to hire a lawyer to defend it against suits by organizations including Common Cause, which calls itself a natonal citizens lobby.

title: OHIO PUPPY WINS SPANIEL FUTURITY
description: Six weeks ago Mrs. Carla Morgan, a housewife from Dayton, Ohio; bought a black cocker spaniel pup, Juniper Jam a DAL from Ina Ginsberg of Newton Center, Mass., the breeder.

title: A Wary Kean Is Still Speaker
description: TRENTONNow that the Democratic majority in the Assembly has apparently abandoned any immediate hopes of seizing majority control, the legislative session that begins here Tuesday wil winess a major precedent. For the first time since New Jersey's new Constitution was adopted in 1947, the presiding Assembly Speaker will succeed himself in office.

title: When All the Laughter Died in Sorrow
description: Lance Rentzel is a se'fdescribed golden boy who once seemed to have everythingbrains, good looks, welltodo parents, a rare talent for football and a beautiful, famous wife, entertainer Joey Heatherton. But Lance also had a serious mental problem; it eventually led him to expose himself on two different occasions to little girls, and to destroy much of the glamorous existence he once knew. Certainly the contrast between Rentzel's glittering life as a celebrity and his furtive exhibitionism in parked cars in Minneapolis and Da'las will hold a frightening fascination for some readers; perhaps there is even a dark and meaningful psychological drama in Rentzel's story.

title: Cavaliers, With Wilkens Registering 36 Points, Topple Lakers by 108 to 93
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 (AP)Lenny Wilkens scored 36 points and triggered a thirdperiod surge as the Cleveland Cavaliers sent the Los Angeles Lakers down to their third straight defeat, 10893, today.

title: Consumer Horizon Hazy
description: WASHINGTONProspects for a more relaxed regulatory atmosphere in President Nixon's second term, once rather clear, have become clouded with the approach of the Inauguration.

title: Mrs. Marks Has Son
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Fredric Marks of Todt Hill, S. L, on Nov. 27 at St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond, West Brighton, S. I. The child, the couple's fifth, has been named Michael Damon. Dr. Marks is a plastic surgeon.

title: Mrs. Knauer Reported Keeping Consumer Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI)President Nixon has asked Virginia H. Knauer to stay on as his consumer adviser, Adminstration sources said today.

title: Tho's Remarks in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 6Following, in an unofficial translation from the French, are excerpts from a statement made today by Le Duc Tho, the North Vietnamese negotiator, upon his arrival in Paris for the resumption of the private peace talks with Henry A. Kissinger:

title: The Whales Commuter Line: 6,000 Miles Long, and No Strikes
description: POINT LOMA, Calif.  The flat blue glitter of the Pacific makes your eyes swim a bit if you keep staring out there through your binoculars, but you've got to keep searching, scanning that blank sea surface out beyond the greenbrown kelp beds, sweeping back and forth until suddenlyover there to the right, maybe two miles outyou see shooting, angling up out of the water a mottled, shining monster, a good 20 feet of him poised there for a split second before he crashes back into the sea in an explosion of spray.

title: THE OPENINGS OF THE WEEK
description: LOOK AWAYTonight, Playhouse, 6:45. A play by Jerome Kilty. Starring Geraldine Page and Maya Angelou.

title: State Acts to Aid Assigned Risks
description: TRENTONFor years, insurance companies in New Jersey have been baffling state officials and infuriating motorists by refusing to issue automobile insurance at standard rates to certain drivers, many of whom have clean driving records.

title: Jane Byrd Sargeant Married To Ian McCurdy in Virginia
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 6Miss Jane Byrd Sargeant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Harris Sargeant Jr. of Newport News, and Ian Aarison McCurdy, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Aarison McCurdy of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., were married here at noon today, the 28th wedding anniversary of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Press Galleries Elect
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The results of the election of a new executive committee of the Congressional Periodical Press Galleries were announced yesterday. Elected were David Secrest of Business Week, Don Smith of U.S. News & World Report, Earl Abrams of Broadcasting Magazine, Robert Horowitz of Army Times Publications, Sam Shaffer of Newsweek, Neil MacNeil of Time and George Cullen of the Bureau of National Affairs.

title: Fire Fatalities Declined Here in 1972
description: The number of fire alarms, fires and fire fatalities decreased slightly here last year, marking the first time in 14 years there has been an annual decline in all three categories.

title: Canucks Suspend Lalonde
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6 (UPI)Bobby LaLonde, center for the Vancouver Canucks, was suspended indefinitely yesterday by Coach Vic Stasiuk for not participating in a practice drill.

title: Consumers Spur Industry Response
description: THE Whirlpool Corporation spent $45million in 1972 to run its consumer services operation, including a warranty program, parts replacement and customer complaint servicing.

title: CLARKE CAPTURES BOWLING ON COAST
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 6Allie Clarke of Akron, Ohio, who barely qualified for the championship round, defeated Don Johnson, also of Akron, in the final today to win the $65,000 San Jose open, the first event on this year's Professional Bowlers Association tour.

title: Anne Sheehan Wed To Thomas Schick
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 6 The marriage of Miss Anne Elizabeth Sheehan to Thomas Schick, both of whom are with the International Business Machines Systems Development division in Raleigh, N. C., took place here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed in the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. George F. Mosher, by the Rev. George Van Arnam, a cousin of the bride and Methodist chaplain of State Universities of New York, and Rabbi Michael Robinson of Temple Israel, CrotononHudson.

title: Something Fanny's Going On
description: WILLIAM KING, who is showing sculpture at the Dintenfass Gallery, and John Wesley, who is showing paintings at Elkon, are two very funny artists. For sheer humorin nearly all the dictionary's definitions of the wordthey are matched by few other modern Americans. Not that they have a lot of competition. While much of modern American art may fairly be described as witty, little of it has aspiredor condescendedto be primarily humorous. We Seem as a nation to be afflicted with a belief that high art and funniness, except of a pointed intellectual type, don't mix.

title: METHADONE KILLS TWO CITY INMATES
description: Two new deaths involving methadone overdoses in city institutions were disclosed yesterday, and one was under investigation by the Bronx District Attorney.

title: Computers Emerge From Recession
description: In 1972 the computer industry bounced back from the first recession in its short but profitable history and it now expects a period of expansion that will extend well into the middle of this decade.

title: Edited by WILL WENG
description: ACROSS

title: Fed's Man Of Fervor
description: Andrew F. Brimmer, who is halfway through his 14year term as a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, still recalls that he always wanted to be a newspaperman.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read the article Pigeons Seize a Balcony and Gain Foe [Dec. 10] with interest, but I think the city of Karlsruhe, Germany, has a better solution to the pigeon problem than any of those suggested.

title: Cleveland Transit Funds Sought by Bondholders
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 6This city's municipally owned transit system could be forced into financial difficulty by the holders of $8.78million in mortgage bonds who are seeking immediate repayment. Bankruptcy or receivership would be a possibility, although such an outcome is viewed as unlikely.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Americans, judging from Olga Hesky's LIFE SENTENCE (Doubleday, $4.95), are not the only ones worried about Them. We get a lot of talk about Them, especially from rightwing groups.
