Nobody knows exactly who They are, but whoever They are, They control our lives. They are in cahoots with the Commies. Or They control the press. Or They dominate the country, making things rough for the little man.

title: Rhode Island Five Victor
description: KINGSTON, R.I., Jan. 6 (AP)Steve Rowell scored 28 points, including 16 in the second half, as Rhode Island posted an 8664 Yankee Conference basketball victory over Maine today.

title: Miss Keelyn Mulvey Is Betrothed
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Mulvey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Keelyn McKeever Mulvey, to Peter Campbell Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Pelham Manor. The wedding is planned for April.

title: WAGE DEMAND CUT IN L. I. R. R. STRIKE
description: An offer by 12 unions to reduce their wage demands, and to make new productivity proposals in an effort to end the Lonnb Island Rail Road strike without necessitating an increase in fares led to a resumption of bargaining talks yesterday, the 38th day of the walkout.

title: Miss Harriet Zagor Affianced to Jeffrey A. Kelman
description: The engagement of Miss Harriet Jane Zagor, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Zagor of Elmhurst, Queens, to Jeffrey A. Kelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Kelman of Jamaica Estates, Queens, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A wedding in May is planned.

title: Bert Jones: A Blue Chip Among Aces
description: MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 6 The consensus of the pro scouts is that the players in today's Senior Bowl football game represented a bluechip group of athletes who will be snapped up quickly at the National Football League's draft of the college stars on Jan. 30.

title: Miss Merritt Plans Bridal
description: Miss Marjorie Fox Merritt, a teacher at the Agnes Irwin School in Rosemont, Pa., will be married March 24 in Philadelphia to Blake Willcox Robinson, who is with the investment management department of the Provident National Bank in Philadelphia.

title: Photography
EBB OF LIBERALISM SEER IN CHURCHES
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5The theological and social liberalism that dominated mainline religious institutions in the nineteensixties has run its course and is now giving way to an emphasis on providing meaning for the lives of individual believers.

title: Eric Erdheim to Wed Judith Ellen Cooper
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Jan. 6Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell J. Cooper have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ellen Cooper, to Eric Erdheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Erdheim of West Hempstead, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Judges Imposing Penalties as Alternatives to Jail Sentences
description: Richard Jacques of St. Clair, Mich., was duck hunting recently when he shot a rare Polish mute swan. The 17yearold boy said that he had mistaken the swanone of only 50 such birds in Michiganfor a goose. Found guilty, he could have been sentenced to six months in jail and fined $500.

title: Welfare reform: born, Aug. 8, 1969; died, Oct. 4, 1972A sad case study of the American political process
description: WASHINGTONWhen welfare reform died quietly in the U. S. Senate last Oct. 4, there was little overt mourning.

title: Savoy Names Cocktail For Common Market
description: LONDON, Jan. 6 (UPI)The Savoy Hotel has announced the creation of a Common Market cocktail to celebrate Britain's entry into the European Economic Community.

title: Traffic Toll Drops in Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Japan's traffic death toll of 15,918 last year was the first drop below 16,000 in three years, the National Police Agency said. Deaths declined 442 from 1971's total of 16,360 the agency said.

title: When It Comes to Trot Handicapping, All Systems Are Go, Some for Broke
description: It was her first time at a racetrack, and Debbie Troeller didn't need any handicappers or pastperformance charts to tell her why she should bet on a pacer named My Lisa.

title: Black Economists Are Found to Be Bearish on America
description: One of Harlem's 300,00 residents is Mrs. Benni Fowler. To begin to under stand the economic situation for most of an estimated million black Americans to have seen her four year ago and to see her now.

title: The New Steelworkers
description: On a Greyhound speeding through a dark, icy night toward Chicago, I return to old memories of packing lunch bags and pulling on greasy overalls each morning before rushing desperately to beat the factory time clock months and months of this drudgery my reward for temporarily dropping out of a Chicago high school during the mid1950's. Now I head once more toward that muscular city on the lake, to struggle again with time clocks and lunch bagsthis time driven not by necessity but curiosity.

title: Jack Spreads A Little Sunshine
description: IF you were Jack Albertson, and you'd just scored a triumphant Broadway success at the age ofwell, at the age of Jack Albertson, no one would blame you for displaying just a bit of exultant selfsatisfaction, a touch of the Olympian humility or hauteur affected by some unquestioned Stars.

title: Stamps
description: THE Soviet Union, which in half a century has become the other superpower, is observing philatelically the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

title: Sports Week
description: WednesdayNets vs. Carolina, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L. I., 8:05 P.M.

title: Collected Poems of John Wheelwright
description: Long overdue, the publication of these fourvolumesinone helps to redeem a great loss. One September day in 1940 a drunken driver struck and killed the man who, in the words of Austin Warren's introduction, was one of Boston's spectacular divertissements ... the current representation of its wit and audacitythe apostolic successor to Mrs. Jack Gardner and Amy Lowell, Father Van Alen of the ... Church of the Advent, and H. T. Parker, music critic for The Transcript and sole male resident of the Hotel Vendome. The loss was not Boston's alone. John Wheelwright's death at the age of 43 removed from a particularly volatile literary generation a writer who might have given quite another case and perhaps a different dimension to the of the forties and fifties.

title: IOWA, IN OVERTIME, UPSETS MINNESOTA
description: IOWA CITY, Jan. 6 (AP)  A layup by Rick Williams and two free throws by a reserve guard, Glen Angelino, in the closing seconds of overtime tonight pushed Iowa to a 6562 triumph over Minnesota the defending Big Ten Champion.

title: The Men Who Matter in Economic Legislation
description: WASHINGTONThere are 535 members of Congress, each holding one vote. But, given the seniority system, the structure of committees, the political variables, and the differences in and interests of the Congressmen, control over economic legislation lies in relatively few hands.

title: Collombin Is Victor In Cup Downhill; Cochran Takes 7th
description: GARMISCH  PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 6 (AP)  Roland Collombin of Switzerland, who failed to finish in yesterday's practice runs and complained of the heavy fog shrouding the course, raced through the dense fog today and won the men's downhill ski race in the World Cup series.

title: Lovell to Quit NASA For Job in Industry
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 6 (AP)Capt. James A. Lovell Jr., the world's most experienced astronaut, announced today that he was retiring March 1 from the space agency and from the Navy to become an executive with a Houston corporation.

title: Costello Out of Claghorn, by Webster
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Christmas brought napalm from Santa and, for comic respite, the New Year brought Congress staggering back to Washington. We recognized the scene at once, out of Shakespeare: that gory business done with Duncan, enter the porter drunk and full of high silliness to calm the audience with laughter for a long haul of horror.

title: It's Official
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Congress made it official today: President Nixon won the Presidential election two months ago.

title: Miss Taylor Wed Upstate
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 6  Miss Christina Taylor and Steven James Thomas were married here this afternoon in the Trinity Episcopal Church by Rev. Elliot Metcalf.

title: Fowler McCormick Dies at 74; ExChairman of Harvester
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Jan. 6  Fowler McCormick, former chairman of the board of the International Harvester Company, the world's largest manufacturer of agricultural implements, died here today after a lingering illness, company officials announced. He was 74 years old.

title: AROUND THE
description: SOME NEW ANNUALS AND VEGETABLES

title: ALLIGATOR HUNTS IN FALL ASSAILED
description: The National Audubon Society accused the state of Louisiana yesterday of undermining public confidence in the whole Federal endangeredspecies program by permitting premature reopening of the hunting of alligators.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Profit Rises Seen, But How Much?
description: Profit Rises Seen, But How Much?

title: Education of Toddlers Explored at Glassboro
description: GLASSBOROThe nationwide need for quality daycare centers has spawned an experimental program at the Bozorth Early  Education Demonstration Center on the Glassboro State College campus. What makes the program unusual is that the 15 children enrolled in it range in age from 10 months to 2 years.

title: BARGE RAMS BRIDGE ON THE MISSISSIPPI
description: HELENA, Ark., Jan. 6 (AP) A runaway fuel, barge battered away at a bridge over the Mississippi River today as State and Federal workers tried to plug a leak that had allowed some 600,000 gallons of diesel fuel to drain into the river.

title: Brustein in London
description: LONDON. UNTIL a short time ago, the only scandal in the English theater was its paucity of interesting playsbut now a scandal of major proportions has broken out over the production of John Arden's The Island of the Mighty at the Aldwych by the Royal Shakespeare Company. Originally conceived in 1966 as a trilogy for television about the historical King Arthur, then canceled by the BBC for lack of funds, the work was later rewritten for the National Theater of Wales to commemorate its opening. When The Island of the Mighty proved too vast for the resources of the projected Welsh theater as well, the RSC agreed to produce the play in a shortened version, and Mr. Arden proceeded to cut it down to four hours, meanwhile reworking the material in collaboration his D'Arcy.

title: Environment on the Hill
description: There is good reason for the 93d Congress to break new ground in the national advance toward a tolerable environment. The physical quality of American life was a significant factor in some fifty Congressional contests in the last election. Expenditures of over $1.5 billion for environmental improvement were approved directly referendums and other expressions of voter opinion. And of 57 Congressional and gubernatorial candidates endorsed by the League of Conservation Voters, 43 were winners at the polls.

title: MARIN G. WOLFERT
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Jan, 6Martin G. Wolfert, director of management development and executive staffing for North American Philips Corporation, died of a heart attack here on Wednesday, He was 58 years old and lived at. 2818 Lindenmere Drive, Merrick, L. I.

title: Hanoi Under the Bombing: Sirens, Shelters, Rubble and Death
description: The writer of the following article is a professor of law at Columbia University MIA recently returned from a visit to Hanoi. A retired brigadier general, he was the chief United States counsel for the prosecution at the Nuremberg war crimes trials and is the author of several books, including Nuremberg and Vietnam: An American Tragedy.

title: Duncan Forbes Will Marry Miss Elouise Conway June 23
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 6The engagement of Miss Elouise Conway to Duncan Forbes Will has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Conway of Bronxville and Key Biscayne, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Forbes Will of Osterville, Mass.

title: CALIFORNIA TURNS TO '74 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 The California Legislature will convene at noon Monday, with its opportunities for accomplishment beset by problems and political concerns.

title: Disarming Shift
description: President Nixon has lost an able and effective public servant with the resignation of Gerard C. Smith, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and chief negotiator for the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Berghorn Captures Class A Ski Jump At Bear Mountain
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 6Chuck Berghorn carried l off the larger silver Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial Trophy here today, but he expressed the desire for tighter skijumping competitor when the 28th annual Torger Tokle Memorial Tournament is staged here on the 50meter slope.

title: GUNMEN GET $6,000 IN MIDTOWN OFFICE
description: Two armed men got away with $6,000 in cash and a quantity of jewelry after holding up 25 people Friday in the offices of Johnson and Hanchard, an architectural firm that occupies the ninth floor at 49 West 45th Street.

title: CaveatVendor Or, a Tale Of 3 Cities
description: Our consumer protection is a tale of three cities: Washington, Albany and New York.

title: Restaurant Owner slain
description: The 29yearold owner of a restaurant in East Harlem was shot and killed last night by one of two holdup men, the police reported. Angelo Cotto, owner of the restaurant at 1875 Lexington Avenue, at 117th Street, was pronounced dead at 10 P.M. at Metropolitan Hospital, the police said. The two holdup men escaped.

title: COWBOYS' RETRIAL NEAR IN COLOMBIA
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 6  Five years ago, a group of nomadic Cuiba Indians accepted a range boss's invitation to a meal beside a ranch house far out on the Colombian llanos  prairies that stretch unroaded and unfenced from horizon to horizon.

title: Livingston Students Aid State Agencies
description: PISCATAWAYMore than 125 of the students enrolled in Livingston College's department of urban planning and policy development are earning course credits for the time they spend working in various state agencies and municipal governments.

title: FIRE KILLS VAGRANT IN TRUCK HE LIVED IN
description: An elderly man believed to be a vagrant was killed last night when an abandoned panel truck in which he had been living for about two years was destroyed by fire in the Port Richmond section of Staten Island, the police said.

title: Michigan Editor Named
description: LANSING, Mich., Jan. 6 (AP)  Benjamin Burns, 32 years old, has been named managing editor of the Lansing State Journal. He was assistant managing editor.

title: The Nation
description: ALBANYState and local bureaucracies are swollen and unresponsive. Too many policies and programs are made by bodies unconcerned with how to raise the money to implement them. The court system is a shambles. There is a reign of fear because of crime and drugs. The taxpayers are (you guessed it) irate.

title: Barbara Smith Engaged
description: ROCHELLE PARK, N. J., Jan. 6  Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Barbara Ann Smith, daughter of Mrs. Frank E. Smith and the late Mr. Smith, to Ronald Kent Miller, son of Mrs. Kenneth Miller of Creskill and the late Mr. Miller.

title: Food Makers Sample Diversification
description: Beatrice Foods is now turning out camping trailers and selling insurance. General Mills, maker of Wheaties, is now a builder of trainsof the Lionel toy brand. And Swift & Co. is drilling for oil.

title: Nixon to Seek Cut In Size and Cost Of Government
description: WASHINGTONWith his last election safely behind him, President Nixon, now more than ever, is expected to try to leave his mark on history. While it seems likely to be true, in his second term as in his first, that he will see his greatest opportunities for historic achievement in foreign policy, the outlines are also emerging of a Nixonian commitment to a fundamental reordering of the Government's relations with its own citizenry.

title: Movie Marathon Salutes Dr. King
description: RIDGEWOOD  Last January, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McNeil and their five children were invited here to see The Black Experience, a film marathon honoring the life and work of Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Mother of Six Fulfills a Dream: Graduates as Registered Nurse
description: Mrs. Edna Rattray Appleton, a former practical nurse, fulfilled a dream of many years when she recently became a registered nurse after completing a hospital training program designed to upgrade employes.

title: Errant Youngsters Get a Helping Hand
description: HACKENSACK  Sixteenyearold Mary G. was brought to Juvenile Court for running away from home and stealing from a neighbor. The judge gave her a suspended sentence and turned her over to a probation officer. The officer, in turn, assigned Mary to a volunteer worker.

title: Aussie Yachts Finish 1, 2, 3 In World 420's Fourth Heat
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 6. (AP)  Anders Wangel and his 13yearold son, Chris, led a onetwothree Australian finish today in the fourth heat of the World 420 yachting championships.

title: DEAD SEA SCROLLS TO APPEAR AGAIN
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 6The publication of the Dead Sea Scrolls is expected to be resumed shortly after a fiveyear hiatus as a result of a compromise quietly negotiated between Israeli authorities and an international board of scholars entrusted with the manuscripts.

title: A New Message, an Old Theme
description: TRENTON  On Tuesday Governor Cahill will meet his constitutional mandate to communicate to the Legislature, by message at the opening of each regular session, the condition of the state and shall in like manner recommend such measures as he may deem desirable.

title: Rebecca L. Royer Is Bride in Jersey
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Jan. 6 In Temple EmanuEl here this evening, Miss Rebecca Louise Royer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Fleck Royer, became the bride of Peter Neal Michaelson. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Michael Michaelson of New York. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff performed the ceremony.

title: Michigan State Five Victor Over Northwestern, 9077
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. (AP)  Michigan State held Northwestern scoreless for the first seven minutes, then held off two Wildcat rallies to win, 9077, in a Big Ten basketball game today.

title: Rae Haller Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Haller of Riverdale, the Bronx, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rae Haller, to James M. Eisdorfer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Eisdorfer of Cedarhurst, L. I. His father is a deputy chief inspector of the Police Department and commanding officer of its Special Operation Division. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Miss Holland Gordon Wilson Betrothed to John Cramp Jr.
description: SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 6  Announcement has been macle by Mr. and Mrs. Kendrick R. Wilson Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Holland Gordon Wilson, to John Bruce Cramp Jr., son of Mrs. Wilma Cramp of Washington and the late Mr. Cramp of Philadelphia. A June wedding is planned.

title: Textiles in an Age of Technology
description: NEW BERN, N. C.The newest of textile fiber installations in this old Dutch town points to the direction in which the textile industry is headed.

title: Killy Wins Giant Slalom For First Victory as Pro
description: MOUNT SNOW, Vt., Jan, JeanClaude Killy, once the pride of France's crack Alpine racing ski teams, swept back into competitive focus this afternoon with an impressive victory in the LincolnMercury professional giant slalom in nearzero weather.

title: A Day Book
description: Robert Creeley says in his Day Book: Variance of emotional occasion in English voicesfor myself, American, etc. Therefore awkward at times to know where one is. And for myself (English, etc.), the awkward thing is that I know where am: with the Englishman who was baffled by Creeley's persistent hero William Carlos Williams: English critics don't feel he is a poet at all, but the most unexpected American critics will be found speaking of him with tender reverence; they feel he is a kind of saint. He has renounced all the pleasures of the English language, so that he is completely American; and he only says the dullest things, so he has won the terrible fight to become completely democratic as well. William Empson there caught an enduring cluster of things: the relation of being a free poet to being an American, a saint and a democrat.

title: Yonkers Ceremonies to Honor Super Bowl on Jan. 19
description: Trackside ceremonies honoring Super Bowl, the winner of the 1972 triple crown of trotting, will be staged at Yonkers Raceway Jan. 19. The champion trotter's owners, Mrs. Rachel Dancer and Mrs. Hilda Silverstein, and the trainerdriver, Stanley Dancer, will participate in the program.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: During these past few years the American Stock Exchange, taken as a whole, has been outstanding insofar as anticipating problems and successfully moving to meet them.

title: Paterno Spurns Patriots And $1.3Million Contract
description: Joe Paterno, Penn State's head football coach, turned down yesterday a $1.3million, sixyear contract to be coach and general manager of the New England Patriots of the National Football League and all but closed the door on any future professional offers that might come his way.

title: Market Analysts, Bullish or Bearish, Chart Strategies
description: This article on the stock market in 1973 is based on a recent luncheon interview with three investment men who represent different aspects of Wall Street. Vartanig G. Vartan, stock market reporter for The New York Times, conducted the interview.

title: An Anthology Of TwentiethCentury Brazilian Poetry
description: Edited, with an introduction, by Elizabeth Bishop and Emanuel erasil. 181 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $11; paper, $3.45.

title: Raise for Steelworkers
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6 (AP)Twenty thousand United Steelworkers, mostly in the copper industry, have received a threecent hourly pay adjustment under the costofliving escalator clause in their current contract, the union has an nounced here. Most of the workers covered by the automatic pay rise, which was effective Jan. 1, are employed by nonferrous metals firms in the west and midwestern United States.

title: Shazar Is Honored as He Prays At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue
description: Wearing a prayer shawl and a dark felt hat, ?? 83yearold President, Zalman Shazar, joined 400 worshipers for Sabbath services at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue yesterday morning.

title: Paramus Getting Art Technology Center
description: PARAMUSWhat is believed to be the first such museum of its kind in the countrythe Museum of Art Technologyis scheduled to open here on Feb. 10.

title: Gardens
description: Some significant trend! have been growing in gardening in the past few years, particularly in plants available. Now, as the new year begins, we asked some of the observers and producers of these plants to tell us what is happening. Here is what they have to say:

title: Italy's Premier Goads His Bloated Bureaucracy
description: ROME, Jan. 6Premier Giulic Andreotti has heralded the new year with a circular to the for pid legions of Italy's Governwent workers exhorting them to be thrifty, efficient and impartial.

title: DRUG ARRESTS UP, KEEINDIENST SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Department of Justice, in its annual yearend review of activities, lists a record number of indictments and convictions against organizedcrime figures and sharply steppedup arrests In narcotics cases.

title: JACKSONVILLE FIVE TRIUMPHS BY 12078
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 6 (UPI)Jacksonville hit a blistering 63 per cent from the floor for a 6736 halftime edge today and coasted to a 12078 victory over Southwestern Louisiana.

title: ACROSTIC PUZZLE
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then trans fer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the pattern. Black squares Indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation rending from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: Barton's Sweetens Downtown Plan
description: While urban decay and rising taxes are driving other industries out of New York, the owners of Barton's Candy Corporation have not only decided to stay, but also to help revitalize the area around their plant at 80 DeKalb Avenue in downtown Brooklyn.

title: In Praise Of Footnotes: Scholarship And Sensibility
description: SCHOLARS are different from you and me: they know more. About some things, anyway. We tend at times to forget that behind the headlinemaking news of auctions, acquisitions and exhibitions and the less publicized but no less fateful shifts in current taste and perspectives on the past, there is a good deal of continuous, painstaking and imaginative research of a kind that rarely makes news on its own, that is seldom even known beyond a small circle of specialists intellectually equipped to evaluate it.

title: From AfricaWhere His Roots Are
description: PIANIST Randy Weston, whose new group makes its debut Friday at Carnegie Hall, is one black American who has translated the rhetoric of African roots into reality. Weston, 46, whose father is Panamanian, was born and raised in Brooklyn; he has performed in 15 African countries and since 1967 he has lived in Tangier, Morocco. The port on Africa's northwestern tip has adopted Weston as one of its own; his African Rhythms Club has become an institution there, and this past September Tangier hosted an international festival of AfroAmerican music organized by Weston and an ad hoc committee of Americans and Moroccans.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Politics Mixes With Games Opening in Nigeria Today
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 6With great excitement and preparations, this dirty, teeming, sweltering city is putting on its best face to welcome the thousands of visitors arriving for the second AllAfrica Games, which start tomorrow.

title: TWIXT TRIUMPHS AT LIBERTY BELL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 Twixt raced to a halflength victory over Dan Lasater's Knightly Belle in the $33,475 Tuscarora Stakes for fillies and mares today at Liberty Bell Race Track.

title: Music
description: EVERY December, as faithful as Christmas, as welcome as roast goose with chestnut stuffing, comes the Music Calendar published by the C. F. Peters Corporation. Peters is a famous publisher of music, old and respected, based in Frankfurt, known for its monumental list of composers (the house was founded in Leipzig in 1812 and Beethoven was among its first clients; Peters published some of his important works) and its fine printing.. Peters has branches everywhere, including, of course, New York.

title: Lifetime at Stove Reaps Rewards
description: PALISADES, N. Y.  His first memories are linked with his mother's warm, sunny porch on Martha's Vineyard and large, wooden salad bowls filled with beach plums ready for pitting.

title: The Standard Form for Leases Is Confusion
description: The standard, printed apartment lease is probably the most widely distributed legal document in this country, and perhaps the least understood. In an effort to define the terms in a rental arrangement, it is likely to cover subjects the landlord and tenant will never experience. Its critics maintain that it is no boon to the tenant, and statutory interpretations favorable to tenants have in many cases superseded its provisions.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IT WAS the year that Howard Hughes, the last elusive tycoon, came out of hiding and yet remained hidden, midst hoax, securities registration and even an earthquake. It was the year of the strong dollar; yet the price of gold reached $70. It was the year that Polaroid got all the publicity and Kodak got the profits. It was the year of price controls; yet businessmen loved it. It was the year that Poland finally agreed to redeem her preWorld War II bonds.

title: Revitalized S.E.C. Is Ready for Action
description: WASHINGTONWhen William J. Casey took over as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission in March, 1971, few persons would have predicted that, 19 months later, he could be credited with having presided over one of the broadest and most timely revitalizations in the agency's 38year history.

title: Mrs. Meyers Has Son
description: A son was born Nov. 29 to Rabbi and Mrs. Lawrence Meyers of Jerusalem in the HadassahUniversity Hospital there. Mrs. Meyers is the former Miss Leah Nessa Nadich, daughter of Rabbi Judah Nadich, of the Park Avenue Syangogue and Mrs. Nadich of New York. The child is named Natan Menachem.

title: BOWIE DASH GOES TO EVIL INTENTION
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 6Evil Intention, owned by Mrs. Howard Y. Haffner of Charlottesville, Va., won the 12th running of the $24,950 E. Palmer Heagerty Stakes today.

title: An American Family Lives Its Life on TV
description: ALL too infrequently does television offer us a slice of life without first embalming it in a solution of predictable packaging and preconceptions. But starting this Thursday at 9 P.M., WNET/13 will present a series of 12 weekly episodes called An American Family, surveying seven months in the life of the William C. Louds. The series chronicles the trivia of the Louds' daily routine as well as their crucial failures to reach out to each other across the empty spaces that make this affluent middleclass family such a fragile composition of fragments.

title: Miss Raeburn Fiancee of Peter Wicker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Abner Raeburn of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Joann Raeburn, to Peter Carleton Wicker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton Forbes Wicker of Millbrook, N. Y.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: CAMBODIA PRINTS LON NOL THOUGHT
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 6We have chosen the way of revolution, the revolutionary spirit and the revolutionary process.

title: the traveler's world
description: WHEN we left the sudsy saga of the North Atlantic airlines last week, they were scurrying around preparing to file new air fares with the Civil Aeronautics Board to replace the International Air Transport Association tariffs that will expire Feb. 1. As that episode ended, some airline executives were gloomily predicting a price war because the I.A.T.A. airline members could not agree on a new schedule of price fixing. However, more experienced observers of the aerial scene were convinced that the boys would, as usual, close ranks and compromise.

title: Elise Frazier, Alan Woodward Set June Bridal
description: BELMONT, Mass., Jan. 6Dr. and Mrs. Shervert Hughes Frazier Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elise Frazier, to Alan Cox Woodward, son of Dr. Richard Horace Woodward of Wellfleet, and the late. Mrs. Woodward. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Television
description: AS four newspaper reporters, so far, have been sent to jail by various courts, White House spokesmen are smearing certain aspects of the news on the commercial networks as ideological plugola and elitist gossip and the new president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is methodically eliminating national news and public affairs programing from public television.

title: Kamel Youssef Fiance of Miss Gardner
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. David J. Gardner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Marion Gardner, to Kamel S. Youssef of Boston. He is a son of Mrs. Sobhy Youssef of Alexandria, Egypt, and the late Mr. Youssef who was director of the Port of Alexandria. The wedding will take place in May.

title: Ann Kathleen Abernathy Bride
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 6Miss Ann Kathleen Abernathy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Herman Abernathy of Wilmington, was married this afternoon to Robert John Stetson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Stetson of Winnetka, Ill.

title: Malik Criticizes U.N. Staff On IsraeliSponsored Letter
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 6Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet delegate, has charged in a letter to Secretary General Waldheim that proIsraeli members of the United Nations staff had insisted on issuing a document that slandered the Soviet Union.

title: HighSpirited Get Free Coffee in L.I.
description: COMMACK, L.I.  More than a dozen Long Islanders spent New Year's Eve on the Long Island Expressway here, giving out free coffee to motorists who spent the evening celebrating the arrival of 1973 in more traditional ways.

title: Mailbox: A Vote for La Prevoyante
description: I am deeply disturbed over the results of thoroughbred racing's consolidated poll for 1972. Denying La Prevoyante the horse of the year crown is a marked injustice. Here is a filly, member of the socalled weaker sex, who, in her first year of competition, did what every owner, trainer, breeder, and other concerned parties fleetingly dream ofwent unbeaten, unsurpassed, en route to closing out the season with a perfect record of 12 impressive and exciting triumphs in as many starts.

title: U.S. Pact to Curb Hijacking Gains Support in World Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (Reuters)The United States has gained about 15 sponsors and supporters for its proposed new international antihijacking treaty, State Department officials said today.

title: The New York Times Book Review
description: A fallen press lord is as dangerous as a wounded buffalo. That is one lesson of the book that is Britain's current publishing sensation: The Cecil King Diary, 196570. Political sensation, too, with juicy plums for the party careerist, the social critic and the jaded journalist. Practically no person or institution in the British Establishment comes out of the King diary in one piece:

title: The President
description: WASHINGTONWhile most Americans were preparing to ring in the new year, last Sunday night, President Nixon returned unexpectedly to the. White House from his weekend retreat at Camp David and retired well before midnight. At 7:30 A.M. on New Year's Day, he went to his oval office, found the door locked and summoned a startled White House policeman to let him in. This picture of the President, wandering alone through a nearly empty mansion on a festive holiday, seemed in keeping with the cloak of isolation in which Mr. Nixon has wrapped himself.

title: Senate Vote Calls on Nixon To Report Impounded Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Senate passed legislations today that would require President Nixon to give Congress by Feb. 5 an accounting of all appropriated funds that he had impounded.

title: Aussie Takes Grand Prix
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 6 (Reuters)John McCormark of Australia fought off mechanical trouble and a dogged challenge by an Englishman, Alan Rollinson, to win the New Zealand Grand Prix today.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: You don't get something for nothing, said Max Loundenback, president of the Indianapolis Jaycees. You have to work at something to make it work. You have to put out a little extra effort if you want to be successful.

title: ROBERT GRANNIS, NEWSMAN, DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Robert M. Grannis, a former newspaper editor and since 1960 public relations aide of the Republican National Committee who had served as a speech writer for President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died today in Arlington, Va. He was 69 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: Letters
description: I have been a prisoner at the Allenwood Federal Prison Camp for the past four months. Only recently have had the pleasure of reading the farce (Castrated: My eight months in prison, Dec. 3) spread across your, pages by Ralph Ginzburg.

title: Declining Birth Rate May Spell Widening Prosperity
description: WASHINGTONThe rapidly declining birth rate may not be good news for the people who bronze baby shoes, but it is likely to mean prosperity for almost every other aspect of the economy.

title: Big Israeli Aircraft Plant Is a Supermarket of Planes
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 30 The thousands of tourists who arrive at Tel Aviv's airport every day fly right over one of the sites of booming modernday Israel, one that is not listed in any of the guide books.

title: John Claude McConnell Fiance Of Miss Marjorie Susan Geller
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Geller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Susan Geller, to John Claude McConnell, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Wilkinson McConnell of Trumansburg, N.Y. Dr. McConnell, former president of the University of New Hampshire, teaches economics and industrial labor relations at Cornell University and Ithaca College.

title: Christopher Dixon Weds Miss Saslaw
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Jan. 6Miss Barbara Saslaw and Christopher Palmer Dixon were married here this afternoon in the Vassar Alumnae House by the chaplain of Vassar, the Rev. George Williamson.

title: Bridgeton Expanding Zoo
description: BRIDGETON  Not long ago, Governor Cahill was invited to shake hands with an unusual visitor to his office. Her name was Maggie, she weighed a trim 100 pounds and she wore a coat that most women would envy.

title: Auto Makers Face BlueCollar Blues
description: DETROITThere were the safety blues, then the pollution blues, but this year the automobile industry will be struggling with the bluecollar blues.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONFERENCE BOARD'S consensus on the economy predicts a 6 per cent gain in real G.N.P. for 1973 vs. 6.4 per cent in 1972; also a 6.7 per cent gain in industrial production and a 13 per cent gain in capital spending.... Auto makers are planning to build 915,000 cars this month, up 28 per cent from 714,000 in January, 1972.... Sales United States Savings Bonds totaled $6.2billion last year, highest of any year since 1948.

title: Illinois Quintuplets Are Fair Four Receive Formula Feeding
description: EVANSTON. Ill., Jan. 6Mr. and Mrs. James Baer had their first five children last nightthree girls and two boys.

title: FUNSETH, ON 207, LEADS BY STROKE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8Rod Filnseth, a golf pro who seldom wins a tournament but often comes up with a great round, shot a courserecord 65 today and took a onestroke lead in the $135,000 Glen Campbell Los Angeles open. He had 207 for three rounds. Sam Snead and David Graham were tied for second.

title: The Congress
description: WASHINGTONThe United States Congress, like Carl Sandburg's fog, has grown accustomed to creeping into the capital on little cat feet. Thus it seemed that, comparatively speaking at least, the new 93d Congress had pounced, on Washington last week with the fury of a January storm.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television progrants was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Firefighters Set Awards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)  The International Association of Firefighters announced today it would award $4,500 in its annual contest for the best newspaper, magazine, radio and television stories and photographs illustrating the professional life of firemen.

title: The Tragic Sense
description: A French reporter remarked to me, When my country lost a war and most of an empire at Dien Bien Phu, we simply said, We lost a war. Why is it that the United States cannot say that?

title: Miss Deitz Fiancee Of J. G. Milmoe Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Deitz of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Deitz, to J. Gregory Milmoe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Milmoe of White Plains.

title: U.S. CITES CAUSE OF ALASKA CRASH
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board says that the 1971 crash of a 727 jetliner in Alaska that killed 111 persons, probably was caused by a premature descent through the area's rugged terrain.

title: HANOI NEGOTIATOR, ARRIVING IN PARIS, TAKES RIGID STAND
description: PARIS, Jan. 6  Le Duc Tho, North Vietnam's peace negotiator, arrived here today for further talks with Henry A. Kissinger and immediately displayed an uncompromising stance against what he described as unreasonable American demands.

title: Maurice Thatcher Dies at 102; Oldest Former Representative
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Maurice H. Thatcher, the oldest surviving former member of Congress, died here today at the age of 102.

title: G.M. Test Device Down to Federal Pollution Level
description: DETROIT, Jan. 6  The General Motors Corporation has reported that it has experimentally reached some of the low pollution levels required by the Government for automobiles in 1975.

title: Jazz: Variety of Stylists Plays the Blues
description: Youth culture filled Philharmonic Hall to capacity Friday evening, showing that occasionally this erratic mass movement can show tribute where it is properly due. Appearing in a Blues Variations concert were Muddy Waters and John Lee Hooker, two seminal figures in the modern blues world, and Mose Allison.

title: Airline Ticket Agent Fined
description: BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP) Broadus S. Durant, of Los Angeles, an airline ticket agent, has been fined $5,000 in Federal court for conspiring to transport stolen and falsified airline tickets in interstate commerce. A twoyear prison sentence was suspended on condition that Durant pay the fine in installments over a fiveyear probationary period.

title: Natural Gas Shortage Chills Some Areas in the State
description: Barring any long cold wave, most Jerseyans can expect to come through the winter with enough heat and power to keep their homes cozy and working places operational. But the warmth rising from that oil burner in the basement may well become costlier before long, and, in some cases, scarcer as well.

title: RHODESIANS FEAR GUERRILLA DRIVE
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Guerrilla attacks against whiteowned farmhouses and the burning of stores and shanties of blacks just before Christmas have revived fears of an offensive by foreignbased black nationalists against Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's Government.

title: Numismatics
description: RE controversies a sign of vigor in a hobby? Or can they create an impression of lively interest while actually having a negative effect? It's a subject for longterm debate (and this column is open to that). One thing, however seems beyond debate: there are a number of intensely controversial issues current in our hobby.

title: East End Paper Is a Family Tradition
description: SAG HARBOR, L. I.While this eastend village is perhaps best known for its whaling history, it also happens to be the birthplace of the hometown newspaper on Long Island.

title: Libya Offers Scholarships To Train Uganda Soldiers
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 6The Libyan Government has offered President Idi Amin training scholarships for 300 Uganda soldiers and airmen. The offer was conveyed to the President by Mahmoud Saad, charg d'affaires here.

title: Clinic Gives Free Leal Advice to Poor in Bergen
description: TEANECK  Free legal advice is now available to Bergen County residents at the Legal Clinic sponsored by the Bergen County chapter of the New Jersey Student Union, the only such clinic in the state.

title: A Soap Opera Mainstay Is Moonlighting as Singer
description: I spend the afternoon with your wife, Don Stewart tells, the men in his audience at th& Rainbow Grill, where he is currently singing. Chances are he is right because Mr. Stewart has been appearing in the longrunning television soap opera Guiding Light for four years, five afternoons a week. Before that he understudied Robert Goulet in Camelot.

title: Anderson and Mrs. Court Win Aussie Tennis Titles
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 7 (AP)  Mal Anderson, in his seventh bid for the title, and Mrs. Margaret Court won the singles championships today in the $19,000 New South Wales open tennis tournament.

title: KISSINGER ARRIVES IN PARIS TO RENEW CEASEFIRE TALKS
description: PARIS, Jan. 7Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight to resume the talks on a Vietnam settlement that were broken off last month amid accusations of obstructionist tactics from both the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Low  Voltage Fixtures
description: Those waterfalls, fountains and diadems of light filling a back room of an East Side showroom with extraordinary sparkle, look far too decorative to ever be functional.

title: Peregrine Falcon Center Of Global Rescue Effort
description: PROVO, Utah, Jan. 7An international group of ornithologists and environmentalists has begun a breeding project designed to repopulate the peregrine falcon. Once considered one of the most numerous birds of prey, the peregrine falcon has almost disappeared from the American scene and is considered a threatened species in every other corner of the globe.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Schindler Wins 6Mile Run
description: Jim Schindler of Bedford, V.Y,. won the sixmile Road Runners Club of New York run yesterday in Central Park.

title: Linda Kramer Wed To Murray Evans
description: LAWRENCE, L.I., Jan. 7 Miss Linda Marie Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Z. Kramer of Woodmere, was married this afternoon to Murray S. Evans. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Evans of the Bronx.

title: Scribner Era a Study in Perils of Reform
description: We are in a new ball game, Dr. Harvey B. Scribner told New York City's 65,000 teachers and supervisors in September, 1970, just eight days after he had taken office as the first Chancellor of the newly decentralized city school system.

title: Curriculum Revision: A Continuing Process
description: Ten years after a fundamental revision of the teaching of mathematics with its emphasis on sets, another major revision is in the works for the elementary schools of New York State. The swing is back to a stress on computational skills, including oldfashioned arithmetic drills.

title: East German Family Escapes
description: LUBECK, West Germany, Jan. 7 (UPI)An East German family of three fled across the frontier into West Germany today undetected by border guards, the customs office said. The man had served in the East German Army and knew the border sector through which the family escaped.

title: Part of Deegan to Close
description: A section of the Major Deegan Expressway in the South Bronx will be closed in both directions between 11 P.M. and 6 A.M. for three days beginning tomorrow. The Police department said traffic would be diverted from the highway at West 167th Street and at Fordham Road to enable construction work on a bridge at West 179th Street, near the Bronx campus of New York University.

title: James Gould Retiring Jan.31 As President of Music Hall
description: James F. Gould, president and managing director of the Radio City Music Hall, the country's largest movie theater, and a member of its staff since it opened in 1932, will, retire Jan. 31. A successor will be named shortly.

title: Nonreaders in Big Cities
description: Millions of American schoolchildren are poor readers. While they are scattered throughout the country, the largest concentration of poor readers are in the poorest sections of our big cities. In suburban public schools attended by children from affluent families, from 0 to 5 per cent of the third graders are still nonreaders. In contrast, at the other end of the socioeconomic spectrum, 35 to 50 per cent of the third graders in most innercity schools are nonreaders.

title: Why Latin? New Answers Evolving
description: Never in the 600 years since the Renaissance first put the Latin and Greek classics at the center of the curriculum has this venerable and battlescarred subject been in such ferment as today. Time is running out for the traditional role of the classical languages.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Recycling the City
description: Lewis Mumford once described the city in history as the place where the diffused rays of many separate beams of life fall into focus, with gains in both social effectiveness and significance. Looking now at the New York of today, he could express only dismay.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made pay. able to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 8, 1973

title: New Work, New Living Setups: A New Nuns' Story
description: The three nuns at St. MichaelSt. Edward's Church in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn used to fit the stereotype. They taught in Roman Catholic schools.

title: WindWhipped Fire Destroys Pier Shed
description: A fouralarm fire whipped by 40mileanhour winds off the Hudson River destroyed an abandoned pier shed on the Lower West Side early yesterday morning and sent huge clouds of smoke billowing over downtown Manhattan.

title: Hospital Pacts Scored by Controller
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday criticized the affiliation contracts between municipal hospitals here and voluntary hospitals that help staff them. He charged the city had lost more than $1.2million in potential interest income.

title: Shelling on Golan Heights
description: TEL AVIV, Jan, 7 (Reuters)  A number of shells were fired across the SyrianIsrael, ceasefire line at Israeli positions in the central Golan heights tonight, but there were no casualties, military sources reported here. Earlier, Israeli Army patrol came under smallarms fire from Syrian territory in the same area, and the soldiers returned the fire, the spokesman said.

title: Employes' Parents Await Word Of Victims in Catskill Hotel Fire
description: The grieving parents and friends of six New York City teenagers missing in a weekend fire that swept through an employes' dormitory at a Catskills resort hotel in Kerhonkson, N.Y., learned yesterday that it would take state officials several days to determine with certainty whether the youths were among seven persons killed in the blaze.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While the actions of the Navy in the case of Gordon Rule are quite appropriately being called into question, the issue he seemed to have been so foolishly disciplined overhis objection to the appointment of Roy Ashhas not received the attention it deserves.

title: 5 Missing After Fire Destroys Historic Hotel in Rutland, Vt.
description: RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 7 (UPI) Fire destroyed the landmark Town House Hotel early today in icy, below zero temperatures, collapsing the roof and leaving only one wall of the 140yearold building standing. Five of the 30 registered guests were missing and feared dead.

title: Horse Show Awards
description: AT MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I.

title: Solzhenitsyn: A Financial Statement
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn has been deprived by Soviet authorities of all normal means of financial support. He is not permitted to publish in the Soviet Union. Funds due from abroad may be transferred only through the Soviet State Bank, which pockets a large per cent as tax. Several American writers who have large sums of rubles due them in Moscow have offered these funds to Solzhenitsyn for his support. The following commentary, by the official Soviet Novosti agency, seeks to counter the facts of the Solzhenitsyn case, painting a picture of him living a life of luxury and leisure.

title: Panel Suggests a Black As Newark Schools' Head
description: NEWARK, Jan. 7A citizens panel has recommended that the next superintendent of this city's troubled school system be a black educator from outside Newark.

title: Teachers In Dilemma
description: Anyone who has served in American elementary or secondary schools during the last 15 years must be punchy by now from the continual jabs directed at the educational system since the date nineteenfifties. In 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1 and seemed on its way to control of space. If only the United States had had more rigorous basic education, teachers were told, would not have been Number 2.

title: Lon Nol Says U.S. Vows Full Support
description: PHNOM PENH, Jan. 5President Lon Nol says the Nixon Administration has promised Cambodia resolute support in the future for her fight against Communist aggression.

title: Julie Gaines Bride Of William Shapiro
description: Miss Julie Ann Gaines was married yesterday to William A. Shapiro at the home of her mother, Mrs. Adeline Gaines of 1025 Fifth Avenue. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Lloyd Tannenbaum of Huntington, L.I.

title: 250 Irish Here Greet Lynch With Boos
description: Their bagpipe reeds had frozen and could not make a sound, but about 250 demonstrators put on a noisy protest just the same yesterday against John Lynch, Prime Minister of the Republic of Ireland.

title: Engineering Schools Try to Mold a Broader, More Humanistic Graduate
description: The image persists that engineering education is narrow, rigid, and mechanistic; that it creates people who are insensitive to human needs and the quality of life; that engineering graduates cannot or will not work on the problems of society.

title: 3 KILLED IN CAROLINA AS BUS OVERTURNS
description: SMITHFIELD, N.C., Jan. (UPI)  Three persons were killed and about 30 injured today when a New YorktoMiami Greyhound bus ran off the road and overturned on Interstate 95. A state trooper said the driver had apparently fallen asleep at the wheel.

title: Farm Prices and Crop Yields Hit Records
description: THOMPSON, Iowa  For most livestock raisers and grain farmers, like Dwight Winkleman, 1972 was a vintage year, and 1973 could be as good or better.

title: The Humanities, Viewed as a Crucible for Higher Education
description: It would be curious if scientists did not study science, if artists did not practice the arts. Yet humanists need not and often do not specialize in the humanities. It would likewise be curious if those who work in science and the arts were not scientists and artists. Yet those who work in the humanities need not be and often are not humanists. This anomalous situation has a historical explanation.

title: Quintuplets Pass Safely Through Crucial Period
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 7At the age of two days, the five children of Mr. and Mrs. James Baerthe world's latest set of quintuplets  safely passed through their most crucial period of life today, according to their doctor.

title: Visiting Greek Aide Stirs Civil Rights Protest Here
description: About 75 demonstrators, including the actress Melina Mercouri, attempted yesterday to present a letter to the Greek Deputy Premier demanding the release of political prisoners in Greece.

title: 16 Bombs Explode in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Jan. 7 (UPI)Sixteen bombs exploded simultaneously in Lisbon yesterday, the second such attack within a week, the police said. There were no casualties. Pamphlets found near the scene of each explosion called for opposition to Portugal's occupation of Angola, Mozambique and Guinea. On New Year's Eve, 10 bombs exploded throughout the city.

title: Theater: More About Mrs. Lincoln
description: Admittedly it is pure chance, but by now I feel I know more than I need to know about Mrs. Lincoln. Last night at the Playhouse Theater, Jerome Kilty's play Look Away opened, and I was almost tempted to. We have had three plays about Mary Todd Lincoln this season, and, while this is quite possibly the best, it frankly found me in an unreceptive mood.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MADISON, N. J., Jan. 7At 24 years old, John Thurston is perhaps the youngest head coach in college basketball. At first glance he doesn't look like a winner and he isn't, at least not yet. His handsome face reddens when he talks about losing, a new experience for him. He also blushes when complimented about his athletic achievements as student or when he praises one of his players.

title: Detroit Manhunt Stirs Controversy
description: DETROIT, Jan. 7  Detroit's police are conducting a mas?? manhunt for three men sought in the killing of one po??man and the wounding of five. One of the suspects is also sought in the killing of one civilian and wounding of another.

title: Returnable Bottles Barred
description: GARDNER, Mass., Jan. 7 (AB)The Gardner Board of Health has banned the use of returnable plastic milk containers by retailers because, officials say, the opaque containers cannot be inspected properly at processors' plants. The Health board's agent, Joseph N. Ares, said cotton swabs had been found in returnable bottles, and that some persons had apparently used the containers to carry gasoline before returning them.

title: JoAnn Prentice Wins by a Stroke
description: MIAMI, Jan. 7 (AP)JoAnn Prentice won the $4,500 top prize in the Burdine's invitation golf tournament by one stroke today over her roofnmate, Beth Stone, who missed a twofoot putt at No. 17 and an eightfoot attempt at 18.

title: Kindergarten Then and Now
description: Kindergarten in New York's public schools, if failing memory serves, used to be a rather pro forma affair. You could take a child from one and seat him in another and he would still be coloring, carefully, within the line. There was an air of formality, not as ceremonially rigid as in the first grade but perceptible just the same. It was the first step on a road that everyone took, an initiation of sorts into the world of convention and authority.

title: Unionism and the Content of Education: What Are the Bounds?
description: When university professors and school teachers pin union buttons alongside their Phi Beta Kappa keys, is the inevitable next step a union label on the content and conduct of American education?

title: Redskins Depart Quietly
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI)  Deliberately avoiding fanfare, the Washington Redskins left today for Los Angeles and their final week of preparation for the Super Bowl battle with the Miami Dolphins. Coach George Allen had the squad bused directly to their chartered plane without having to go through Dulles Airport where a wellwishing crowd might gather.

title: Journalism Schools Are Thriving
description: It seems at least a minor miracle that the arts of communicationalthough they have been surveyed half to death by the social scientists and consistently snubbed by the academic purists for their ostensible lack of rigorshould continue to attract the intelligent young, in steadily increasing numbers.

title: CUNNINGHAM EXCELS IN COUGAR TRIUMPH
description: DENVER, Jan. 7 (AP)Billy Cunningham and Gene Littles rallied the Carolina Cougars to a 113111 victory over the Denver Rockets tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Coexistence in History Class
description: The teaching of history in colleges and universities in 1972 would probably not startle a returning graduate nearly as much as it would have five years ago. The curriculum reformers and the traditionalists are living with one another better; the charlatans and pompous fools are being driven from both houses, and students are less likely to assume that good politics makes good historians. Things are quieter than they have been in the recent past, but there have been real changes in the last five years.

title: The Education of Manly Fleischmann
description: When Governor Rockefeller and the State Board of Regents invited me in October of 1969 to head a special commission whose task was to find out how New York State might get better public education for less money, my first reaction was a mixture of surprise and disbelief.

title: Records: Rameau Opera
description: The fad for baroque music that began in the 1950's has lasted to today, but it is a fad built primarily on Italian or Italianate instrumental music of the period, and on Bach. Neither the French baroque, some of the harpsichord repertory aside, nor baroque opera in general has enjoyed similar popular favor in our time, and French baroque opera has been pretty much beyond the pale altogether.

title: Special Programs for Adults
description: What is continuing education?

title: T. H. CARRUTHERS 3D
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 7Thomas H. Carruthers 3d, a breeder of wire fox terriers, cattle and gaited horses, died today at his home in suburban Glendale. He was 67 years old.

title: 2 Upsets Thin Unbeaten Ranks to Five
description: Minnesota was the firit to learn Saturday night that the Big Ten Conference basketball title was up for grabs. The Gophers, with nine straight victories and a sixthplace national ranking, ran into one of the halfdozen good Big Ten teams and were beaten by Iowa, 6562, in overtime.

title: Defender of the Aged
description: In his decade as Social Security Commissioner, Robert M. Ball has demonstrated both administrative competence and social imagination of a high order. He came into the vast Federal insurance program for protection of the aged and disabled not long after its establishment 1937, His subsequent career entitles him to rank alongside the late Arthur J. Altmeyer, the first head of the Social Security system, as an official who knew how to translate dreams into an efficient, corruptionfree program.

title: 2 Super Bowl Tickets To Go to Yonkers Fan
description: YONKERS, Jan. 7Franco Harris, the National Football Conference's rookie of the year, will draw the name of the winner of two seats to next Sunday's National Football League championship game at Los Angeles tomorrow during. Super Bowl Night at Yonkers Raceway.

title: S.W. Louisiana Coach Calls N.C. A.A. Charges Political
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 7The basketball coach of the University of Southwestern Louisiana said today that charges of mass recruiting violations against his school were either political or picayune and had grown partly from his success in enrolling black players in the Deep South.

title: Eric Andersen's Direct Style Brought to Fare in Faithful
description: It is possible to discern in Eric Andersen's performance all the fads and fancies, strengths and realities that followed the young folkoriented singerwriter through the 1960's. Andersen, who appeared at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night as part of the Great Performers series, will write songs of overtheedge romanticism (in one a lady's bosom is whispering life's golden secrets to him) and yet also sweep away this rococo with material such as Faithful.

title: The New Math Faces a CounterRevolution
description: A decade ago the then new math was all the rage. Set theory was sweeping over all obstacles in the nation's elementary and high schools, while visionaries talked of teaching Diophantine equations to eighth graders and affine geometry to 16yearolds.

title: HANOI CASUALTIES STILL BEN FOUND
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 7 (Agence FrancePresse)A week after the biggest bombing raids Hanoi has experienced since the Indochina war began, cleanup squads were still finding bodies in the rubble today.

title: Arkansas Oil Spill Threatens Wildlife And Water Supplies
description: HELENA, Ark., Jan. 7 (AP) An oil slick threatened wildlife and posed some danger to water supplies in downstream Mississippi River communities today as three barges continued to dump fuel oil into the river.

title: NONIE SCHIPPERS, CONDUCTOR'S WIFE
description: Mrs. Nonie Phipps Schippers, wife of Thomas Schippers, the conductor, died Saturday here, after a long illness. She was 34 years old and lived here and in Cincinnati.

title: The Limits Of Power
description: LONDON, Jan. 7 In the Washington clich, 1973 was to be the Year of Europe. President Nixon and Henry Kissinger would repair America's economic and strategic relations with her old allies. As an earnest of that intention, the President would likely make a grand tour of Western Europe himself.

title: Idaho Sheepmen Denounce Ban On Poisoning Range Predators
description: BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 7 (UPI) Idaho sheepmen complain that an order to stop poisoning predators may mean the end of sheep raising in the West.

title: NORTH WINS, 106 ON A LATE SCORE
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP)A 16yard touchdown pass from Louisville's John Madeya to Nebraska's Jerry List enabled the North to beat the South, 106, today in the American Bowl college football game.

title: Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Personal Finance
description: If it is pleasurable to the businessman, it probably should be taxed as a hobby and not as a business. This is essentially the Puritan attitude taken by the Internal Revenue Service in many recent cases.

title: ECONOMIC RULINGS DUE IN HIGHER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7The Supreme Court faces a series decisions of critical importance to business, industry and the nation's economy as President Nixon's second term approaches.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DEATH AND LIFE OF MALCOLI'4 X. By Peter Goldman. 438 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $8.95.

title: Courses Tailored to Student Interests
description: During the last decade, college and university catalogues have grown fat with course listings that depart radically from the traditional liberal arts curriculum based on readings in history, literature, mathematics, science and the classics.

title: Advertising: New Food Monthly
description: Triangle Publications, whose little TV Guide has grown in the last 20 years in circulation and advertising while mass circulation giants were sinking into oblivion, has formally announced its newest publishing venture.

title: Riverboat Damaged by Fire
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 7 (AP)Fire started by a short circuit caused an estimated $2,300 damage today to the Delta Queen, the nation's only remaining overnight passenger riverboat, officials said. The fire occurred near the officers' quarters on the top deck of the boat. No injuries were reported.

title: Rhode Island Bill on Judges
description: PROVINCE, R. I., Jan. 7 (AP) A bill has been introduced in the Rhode Island Legislature that would require judges to retire at the age of 70.

title: HANDYMAN PLAN OFFERED BY L.I.R.R.
description: Negotiations to end the Long Island Rail Road strike focused yesterday on management's desire to save on labor costs by creating a new job category to be known as composite mechanic which would, in effect, be that of an oldfashioned handyman with several skills.;Union negotiators have made a new counterproposal that would go part way toward the railroad's goal by permitting workers to take on a few minor extra chores outside their own crafts.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: CONNECTION FIGURE SEIZED IN HIJACKING
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 7 (UPI) One of the central figures in the 1962 French Connection smuggling case was arrested today and charged with conspiring to act as a fence in the hijacking of a truckload of women's clothes last Oct. 31.

title: Geography Renaissance
B52's Raid Supply Routes South of the 20th Parallel
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 8United States B52's bombed highways, rivers and canals in the southern part of North Vietnam over the weekend in what was described as a campaign to keep war supplies from the enemy in South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

title: U.S. Makes Films On Alcohol Abuses
description: A series of 12 color films dealing with the use and abuse of alcohol is being prepared under auspices of the United States Office of Education for distribution during the 197475 school year.

title: State Hires ExF.B.I. Man to Hunt Missing Fathers
description: A Federal agent who has specialized in criminal investigation has been hired by the state to head a new, intensified program for tracking down deserting fathers whose families are being supported by public welfare.

title: Appeal by Soviet Jews
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 7 (AP)  A group of Soviet Jews has urged a reduction of the sentences given to 34 persons convicted in the 1970 Leningrad hijacking plot in light of the nation's new hijacking law, Jewish informants reported today. Those sentences ranged up to 15 years. The new decree sets death as the maximum penalty in the event of deaths or bodily injury, and 15 years for an accident or other grave circumstances. The 1970 plot was foiled before it could be carried out.

title: Art Study Demonstrates Diversity
description: To speak of education in the fine arts in the nineteenseventies is to speak of a great many different enterprises on a great many different levels of experience, yet there is one rule that seems to apply to all these diverse activities: There are more of them, affecting the consciousness of a larger number of people, than ever before.

title: Joan Jonas Dances As Organic Honey, Fictional Woman
description: Organic Honey is Joan Jonas's fictional female creature who organzes her life into images and symbolic mime. Saturday evening at the Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, Honey was in a lonely introspective mood in Organic Honey's Vertical Roll.

title: The Bombing Of Queens
description: Any resemblance to reality In the following dispatch Is purely coincidental.

title: New Civics Stresses Practical Politics
description: When the Binford Junior High School band began to play the national anthem, Susan Vaughan rose to her feet and stood at attention, behaving exactly like her friend, her father, and several hundred other people attending the basketball game that evening. But unlike most of the other people in the gymnasium, Susan thought about why she was standing. As the band played, Susan whispered to her friend, Do you know why we are standing?

title: BUCKS VANQUISH LAKERS BY 9992
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 7 (AP)Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 13 of his 37 points in the fourth quarter today and sparked the Milwaukee Bucks to a 9992 National Basketball Association victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Transportation News and Weather appear on Page 53. TV News on Page 107.

title: Notre Dame Five Defeats Kansas in Overtime, 6664
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 7 (UPI)  Gary Brokaw sank a field goal and Dwight Clay made three free throws in overtime today to give Notre Dame a 6664 victory over Kansas.

title: A Nation Unready for Le Grand Richard
description: WASHINGTON  When President Nixon tries to pass himself off as an American Disraeli, do not be beguiled. It's Charles de Gaulle, with his supreme contempt for the legislative branch of government, whom Mr. Nixon really admires.

title: Continuing Hassle Over How to Read
description: The current cycle of change in reading instruction began In 1955 with the publication of Rudolf Flesch's book, Why Johnny Can't Read. While the work was oversimplified and faulty in some respects, the main thesis was sound: that the wholeword approach to beginning reading instruction, advocated by most reading specialists and used almost everywhere in the country at that time, was wrong in theory and inferior in practice to a phonics approach.

title: Nixon to Ask for Seed Money To Continue Research on SST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7John D. Ehrlichman, assistant to the President for domestic affairs, disclosed today that President Nixon's new budget would contain a little seed money to continue some research on a supersonic transport plane.

title: Gas Kills Baby in Home
description: LANSDALE, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP)  The police said today that carbon monoxide gas escaping from an underground landfill fire killed an infant and placed thee members of his family In critical condition. The police said 10monthold Brian Geiger, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Geiger of Harleysville, was found dead in the family home yesterday. His brother, Drew, 2, and his parents were unconscious when rescuers broke into the home. The police said they were apparently overcome during he night.

title: FIGHTS, PENALTIES HELP RANGERS TOP PEEN, 3 TO 0
description: The way the Rangers have been playing latelyerratically they need all the breaks they can get. So they gratefully accepted an odd one last night at Madison Square Garden that started them toward a 3.0 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Body of Mount Vernon Man Found in Pelham Bay Park
description: The body of a 55yearold man from Mount Vernon, N.Y., who had been shot three times in the back was found yesterday morning near the golf course in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx.

title: METHADONE KILLS 2 MORE IN JAILS
description: Two more names were added yesterday to the list of inmates and patients in city institutions whose deaths involved methadone. The total of recently disclosed deaths now stands at five.

title: FoulAir Masks Ordered Near Venice
description: PORTO MARGHERA, Italy, Jan. 6Enveloped by clouds in many shades of gray and baneful yellow, this industrial mainland suburb of Venice has become a place of fears and tensions.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Transportation News and Weather appear on Page 53. TV News on Page 107.

title: Lester W. Perrin, 86, Dies; Former Investment Banker
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., Jan. 7Lester W. Perrin, a retired partner of Lazard Freres & Co., investment bankers, died yesterday. He was 86 years old and lived here.

title: Kahane Apologizes for Bid To Druses to Leave Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 7  Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the Jewish Defense League, apologized formally today to Israeli Druses for having urged members of their community to emigrate from Israel.

title: Lena, Black Cocker, Is Named Best at National Spaniel Show
description: The topwinning black cocker spaniel of 1972 served notice that she would be hard to beat again this year, when she was named best in show at the first major event of the 1973 season in the East.

title: HARRY SUBER
description: Harry Suber, a traveling representative of the American Federation of Musicians and former treasurer of Local 802 here, died yesterday at his home, 205. West 54th Street. His age was 74.

title: As First American Hostess of the Met, Betty Chapin Seems to Be Ideally Cast
description: Music has always been important; her family makes pianos, the man she married studied with Nadia Boulanger, three of their four sons play at least one musical instrument and she herself used to play the harp. Still, Mrs. Schuyler Chapin, who was Elizabeth Steinway, says she never dreamed that she would be sitting four or five nights a week in a box at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: British Flu Toll Nears 1,000
description: LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) Britain's influenza epidemic has killed nearly 1,000 people this winter and shows signs of worsening in many parts of the country, the Health Ministry reports. Figures showed that 473 people died in the last week of December, the worst toll for the period in three years, according to ministry figures published yesterday.

title: MORRIS M. MARKS
description: Morris M. Marks, supervising accountant in the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, died yesterday at the New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospital. He was 55 years old.

title: Markets Uneasy on Fed's Credit Policy
description: The curtain will rise this week on the first significant corporate and taxexempt bond offerings of 1973, with the backdrop one of uneasiness about the direction of credit policy.

title: Hitler Car Is Sold at Auction for $153,000
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 7For $153,000, Earl Clark got exactly the exhibit he wanted for his Pennsylvania amusement parkthe 1940 Mercedes 770K touring car that carried Hitler through the streets of Berlin and the newspapers and newsreels of the world.

title: Meriwether I eriwether Takes Sprint Title Again In Eastern Regional
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 7Dr. Delano Meriwether, the suspenderclad Boston hematologist, successfully defended his sprint championship and four meet and fieldhouse records were broken in the fourth annual United States Track and Field Federation Eastern regional indoor meet at Dartmouth College, which ended early this morning.

title: Job Outlook for Graduates Is Termed Best in 4 Years
description: Job prospects for this year's college graduates are the best in four years, according to two major surveys.

title: PAUL E. MASON DIES; AUSTRALIAN HERO, 71
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 7Paul Edward Mason, one of the most celebrated of the coast watchers, a group that aided Allied forces in the Pacific during World War II under conditions of extreme personal danger, died last week in Brisbane. He was 71 years old.

title: Public Policy Schools Attuned to Modern Complexities
description: Over the last few years, many leading American universities have created new graduate professional schools of public policy or added programs in that field in existing schools of public administration.

title: State Will Intensify Searches For Missing Welfare Fathers
description: A Federal agent who has specialized in criminal investigation has been hired by the state to head a new, intensified program for tracking down deserting fathers whose families are being supported by public welfare.

title: Shazar Backs Israel's Chief Rabbinate
description: Israel's President, Zalman Shazar, urged Jewish spiritual leaders yesterday to give moral support to the authority of the Chief Rabbinate's offices in Israel concerning religious questions in that country.

title: Bronx Band to Perform for the Nation
description: New York City's Official Teenage Marching Ambassadors of Musical Goodwill From the Concrete Canyons of the Capital City of the Worldless flamboyantly known as the Knickerbocker Drum and Bugle Corpswill become on Jan. 20 the first New York City parade unit, at least in recent memory, to march at a Presidential inauguration.

title: FoulAir Masks Ordered Near Venice
Quake Toll in Managua Reported to Pass 10,000
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 7 (UPI)The Government said today that the death toll in the earthquake that wrecked most of Managua Dec. 23 had passed 10,000 and that an unknown number of dead were still under the rubble.

title: Wards Island Minister, Wife Tied and Robbed
description: Three men, one of them armed with a sawedoff shotgun, forced their way into the nondenominationed Protestant rectory affiliated with the Manhattan State Mental Hospital on Wards Island last night, according to the police, and tied up a minister and his wife, escaping with cash, jewelry and a color television set.

title: Transportation Union Plans Scholarships for Members
description: The United Transportation Union announced yesterday the establishment of a scholarship program that will enable union members under age 26 to go to college.

title: ... And a Week in the Life of John Rafferty
description: John Patrick Rafferty begins a typical week in the company of Abraham Lincoln, Jefferson Davis and Alexander Stephens.

title: Jersey CleanAir Panel Offers A Plan to Curb Pollution Perils
