description: TRENTON, Jan. 7The New Jersey Clean Air Council warned today that air pollotion may already be affecting the health of many of New Jersey's citizens and issued a broad series of findings and recommendations for reducing pollution.

title: Educating the Handicapped
description: When Manly Fleischmann reported in midOctober that educational services for 459,000 handicapped children in New York State were deplorable, he was making public a fact long known to professional educators and to parents of the children.

title: School Role In Poverty Contested
description: Almost from the day the first penniless immigrant alighted on these shores, the American credo has maintained that the bumpy road to the good life was open to any man with the brains, the perseverance and the chance to develop his talents. The liberal, egalitarian notion that lack of good schooling for the poor tends to reinforce the barriers between economic classes has fueled the drive to desegregate and reform American school systems.

title: Marcos Orders Return To Stringent Regulations
description: MANILA, Jan. 7President Ferdinand E. Marcos today announced a return to the stringent controls and methods of the initial period of his martiallaw regime.

title: Collombin Takes 2d Downhill, Leads World Cup Ski Standing
description: GARMISCH  PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 7 (AP)  Roland Collombin of Switzerland won his second downhill ski race in two days today and took first place in the World Cup standings.

title: British Football Results
description: RUGBY UNION

title: Bridge: System That Beat the Italians Was Prematurely Advertised
description: Perhaps the most controversial bridge book of 1972 was Play Bridge with the Aces, by Ira Corn Jr., a 224page Fawcett paperback selling for 95 cents.

title: New Growth in Linguistics Produces Clarity, Confusion and Controversy
description: During the last two decades, the field of linguistics has grown phenomenally and has undergone a genuine revolution in content. The revolution, in fact, has already produced its revisionists.

title: Passaic Is Beset by Chronic Urban Problems
description: PASSAIC, Jan. 7  Milton Bodner's shoe store in the heart of the bustling downtown shopping area on Lexington Avenue here is less than a mile from the bodega on Monroe Street that Rodabaldo Rodriguez sold recently after putting seven years of hard work into it. Financially, the two stores could not be further apart. Mr. Bodner just closed the books on what was the most successful year in his store's 48year history.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Assembly Place at Stake TodayResidents of six Hudson County communities go to the polls today to elect a successor to Assemblyman Silvio Failla, who was murdered in September during a robbery on a street in Neptune Township.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Detectives seeking a witness who might be able to identify the last known companion of 28yearold Roseann Quinn, the teacher who was slain in her apartment on Manhattan's West Side last week, said yesterday that they had received a moderate number of telephone tipsbut no solid leadsin response to a request for public assistance.

title: Burns in Basel Rate Talks
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Jan. 7 (AP)European central bank governors and Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the United States Federal Reserve Board, reportedly discussed today concerted action to prevent interest rates on both sides of the Atlantic from climbing. Dr. Burns and other central bankers, however, said they would not comment on their informal talks during their stay here.

title: Remedial Training: Is It Here to Stay?
description: Seven years ago, when he was a 16yearold high school dropout, Miguel Rivera came to New York City from Puerto Rico in search of opportunity. Like many other Puerto Rican immigrants, he was a long time finding it.

title: Third Government Minister In Australia Attacks Nixon
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Jan. 8A prominent member of Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's Government has accused President Nixon of false pretentions, double dealing and a mentality of thuggery in his Vietnam policy.

title: A MAN WHO DRAGGED PATROLMAN IS SLAIN
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 7 (UPI)A patrolman shot and killed a 22yearold drug suspect today after the suspect allegedly slammed his car door on the patrolman's arm and drove off, dragging him 150 feet.

title: Job Outlook for Graduates is Termed Best in 4 Years
description: Job prospects for this year's college graduates are the best in four years, according to two major surveys.

title: Joan Rifkin Wed To Alan Sellers
description: Miss Joan Rifkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Rifkin of Great Neck, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Alan Bennett Sellers, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Sellers of New Orleans. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony in the Terrace Room at the Plaza.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Sniping Case Bears Similarity To Texas U. Incident in 1966
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 7 (UPI)The sniper attack from atop a New Orleans hotel today was similar in some way to Charles Whitman's killing of 16 persons on Aug. 1, 1966, from the University of Texas tower here.

title: The Problems of Paris in January
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.A peculiarly virulent combination of ill will and misunderstanding seems to plague all dealings between Vietnamese and Americans. Nowhere is the malaise more apparent than in the disastrous series of negotiations which ended last month.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Red Smith
description: When they uncovered the pleasant little city Herculaneum, which had been buried by the eruption Vesuvius in A.D. 79, they found handwriting on buildings advertising the betting secrets of Elvius the Charioteer, undoubtedly a harness race driver who had been ruled off. This should remind horse players and subway riders that touting and graffiti are both ancient art forms .... Furlong originally meant a furrow long, the length of furrow in an ordinary field, or about 40 poles or rods. A rod is 5 yards, so the original furlong Sports measured 220 yards. Today a furlong or oneeighth of a mile, or 220 yards ... Chances are George Washington took The Times bath when his stallion, Magnolia, lost race at Alexandria, Va., to a colt owned by Thomas Jefferson but the Father of Horse Traders got even when he swapped Magnolia, then also nine years old to Light Horse Harry Lee forWashington's diary notes5,000 acres of Kentucke land .... Custer's last mount, the horse that carried him into battle on the Little Bighorn on July 25, 1876, was a thoroughbred named Vic, by Austerlitz out of Mary K ....

title: Merrill's Gift: Rightness of Phrase
description: There was never any doubt as to James Merrill's poetic strengths: a superb ease in the handling of the lines, a formal burnished finish to the verse, a supple blending of thought and image that is almost witty in its success. His gift for the rightness of phrase has remained with him. He writes of the sea serpent hoses of the fire truck, the one lariat glance that takes in everything, of autumn that reddens the whole mind.

title: New Work, New Living Setups: A New Nuns' Story
description: The three nuns at St. MichaelSt. Edward's Church in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn used to fit the stereotype. They taught in Roman Catholic schools.

title: 2 Upsets Thin Unbeaten Ranks to Five
description: Minnesota was the first to learn Saturday night that the Big Ten Conference basketball title was up for grabs. The Gophers, with nine straight victories and a sixthplace national ranking, ran into one of the halfdozen good Big Ten teams and were beaten by Iowa, 6562, in overtime.

title: college Graduates Face Paradox in Job Market
description: A paradox confronts today's college graduate. The demand for people to fill jobs that have typically been held by college graduates is growing rapidly and is expected to continue to grow rapidly in this decade, as in recent decades. No decline in the demand for college graduates is anticipated, since, in a knowledge society, we are not likely to see the lessening of the demand pressure from the labor market for persons with everirrcreasing levels of educational attainment.

title: Open Classroom Found To Be No Instant CureAll
description: An oldfashioned elementary school on New York's West Side had enthusiastically adopted the open corridor version of the open classroom approach to learning. In each room, children were still grouped according to their ages  kindergarten in one, first grade in another, second grade in the next, and finally third grade.

title: Pentagon Concedes Navy Violated Law By Deficit Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 7 The Department of Defense has conceded that the Navy broke the law governing Congressional appropriations of funds on three separate occasions by mismanagement, poor judgment, inadequate bookkeeping and the pressures of the Vietnam war.

title: 10 Die in New Orleans Hotel Sniper Fire; gunman Is Slain by Police in Helicopter
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7The police gunned down a sniper atop a 17story hotel where 10 persons died and a dozen were wounded today in a barrage of bullets and fire. But they said another sniper was holed up in a stairwell near the roof.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: YESTERDAYS GAME

title: Whole Word and Phonics Methods
description: No single picture or illustration can convey fully how schools go about teaching reading. But the two shown here offer some idea.

title: Fallen Leaves From Jersey Town Help Build Park in the Bronx
description: Five tons of topsoil from Tenafly, was transported over the weekend to a rundown neighborhood in the Bronx by a local unit of the National Guard so a small community park could be developed.

title: SelfReform in Medical Education
description: Students entering today's medical schools are likely to find a great fement within the institutions, The medical schools are responding to society's rising expectations for better health, and the pace of change is accelerating rapidly.

title: FUNSETH WINNER IN COAST TOURNEY
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (UPI) Rod Funseth, who had won only one tournament in 12 years on the Professional Golfers' Association tour, shot a twounderpar 69 today to take the $135,000 Glen CampbellLos Angeles open by three strokes. He finished with a 72hole total of 276, eight under par.

title: RefugeeAid Unit Bids U.S. Take More Uganda Asians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 7United Nations and United States officials have been told that 1,800 stateless Asians expelled from Uganda last fall are still waiting in European camps for resettlement and that their predicament is becoming grave.

title: Indiana Selects Corso As Head Football Coach
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 7 (UPI)  Indiana University today named Lee Corso, 37, as football coach. Corso rebuilt the University of Louisville football program to national standing in four years.

title: A Garage Sale' Attended by Thousands
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7A couple of thousand people tramped through Barbara Howar's house this weekend, looking for bargains in a garage sale she had billed as the intact contents of a Georgetown house.

title: Baraka Terms Kawaida Dispute A Power Struggle of Whites
description: MONTCLAIR, Jan. 6Imamu Amirl Baraka, the spiritual leader of the Kawaida Temple, charged tonight that the controversy over the building of Kawaida Towers was a power struggle among whites in Newark's North Ward.

title: Nixon Back at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House Sunday today after spending the weekend at his wintry retreat at Camp David, Md. Aides said he had spent a portion of his day working on his inaugural address with one of his chief speech writers, Raymond K. Price Jr.

title: 36 Nations Open African Games
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 7African youth went on parade today before more than 50,000 cheering spectators at the opening ceremonies of this continent's largest sports spectacular, the second AllAfrica Games.

title: Business Schools Shift Focus From Theory to Practice
description: Graduate schools of business or management vary broadly in their approach to the educational learning process. They are essentially a post World War II product. In the nineteenfifties, studies sponsored by the Ford and Carnegie foundations characterized business schools as essentially vocational and touched off a strong drive to achieve academic respectability. A strong, highly academic research thrust became the primary yardstick of excellence and courses developed more of a base in discipline and theory.

title: Amer. Hockey League
description: SATURDAY'S GAMES

title: TRAIN KILLS MAN AND 4 CHILDREN
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 7A 29yearold resident of a nearby suburb and four children were killed there today when their station wagon was struck broadside by a 24car freight train at a grade crossing, the police reported.

title: Evasive Budget Surplus
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7The 1973 Legislature convened last week faced with at least one pleasant prospectan anticipated budget surplus by the end of the state fiscal year on March 31. But there is no agreement on how much that surplus will be, with estimates ranging from Governor Rockefeller's low of $66million to a sincerevised estimate of $550million by the Assembly Democratic minority l e a d e r,

title: The Lesser Risk ...
description: The key to success in the peace talks which resume in Paris today lies not only in Hanoi, as the Administration has asserted, but in the White House. The end of the long American involvement in Indochina requires a tough but inescapable decisiona decision to acknowledge at last the United States cannot impose a political solution in Vietnam by any acceptable military means.

title: Games, Toys, Films, Cassettes and Multimedia Kits Flood the Schoolroom
description: Every parent of schoolage children has firsthand evidence of the rising tide of educational artifacts surging through United States schools and homes. Parents of preschoolers, too, are being inundated with educational games and toys that purport to do everything from raising a child's I.Q. to developing socially adjusted 2yearolds.

title: Sabich Beats Killy, but Loses Pro Final to Stuefer
description: MOUNT SNOW, Vt., Jan. 7A victory by Harald Stuefer, whose unusual contortions give him the appearance of a fastmoving corkscrew, and an early defeat of JeanClaude Killy were the big items at the $10,000 LincolnMercury Pro Ski Classic today.

title: Pentagon Concedes Navy Violated Law By Deficit Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 The Department of Defense has conceded that the Navy broke the law governing Congressional appropriations of funds on three separate occasions by mismanagement, poor judgment, inadequate bookkeeping and the pressures of the Vietnam war.

title: How Much Can a Teacher Learn by Teaching?
description: After a quarter century of teacher shortages, the supply of new teachers for the elementary grades and for many high school subjects is now outrunning the demand by a substantial margin. School systems that were begging for applicants until two years ago can at last choose among candidates.

title: KISSINGER ARRIVES IN PARIS TO RENEW CEASEFIRE TALKS
description: PARIS, Jan. 7Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight to resume the talks on a Vietnam settlement that were broken off last month amid accusations of obstructionist tactics from both the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Hot Courses on Campus: Dreams, Yoga and I Ching
description: Next term, the psychology department at the 11yearold Sonoma State College in California will offer for the first time a course entitled Fantasy, Dreams and Imagination of Women.

title: Lag Found In Tempo Of Reform
description: It Is frequently said that ours is sick society, and this may be so. But it is awfully hard to arrive at a cons vincing conclusion, because one of the ills we are certainly suffering from happens to be acute hypochondria. We become so feverishly excited at every fine imperfection in the functioning of our various institutions that one never knows whether a crisis is real or imaginary.

title: RESERVE BANK ASKS STRONGER CONTROLS
description: The Nixon Administration's wage and price controls should be strengthened since inflationary expectations, although diminished, are by no means dead, according Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: GOVERNOR'S BILLS TO COMBAT DRUGS COMING THIS WEEK
description: Governor Rockefeller, acting swiftly to gain passage of his new antinarcotics proposals, will submit bills to the Legislature tomorrow or Wednesday to implement the stiffer penalties.

title: Six Were Killed in Fire in Same Hotel in 1971
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7The Downtown Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge, where a fire and gun battle occurred today, was the scene of a fire in July, 1971, that killed six persons in the earlymorning hours.

title: Lebanon Suspends Ouster of American Militant
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 7The Lebanese Government, after protests had been made in the press and in university circles, today suspended the deportation of an American academic who has militantly opposed United States policies in Vietnam and the Middle East. The case will be reviewed.

title: 1,000 Get the Truth About Heart Risk
description: LONG BRANCH, Jan. 7A heavyset man, his jaw drooping and his head slightly shaking, stared at the 35 on his heartattack risk factor sheet.

title: Fred George Clark Dead at 82; Led a Conservative Foundation
description: Fred George Clark, who in 1939 founded the American Economic Foundation, an organization at 51 East 42d Street that promotes political conservatism through lectures, pamphlets and books, died yesterday at his home, 45 Sutton Place South. His age was 82.

title: Pope Hopes New Talks Will End Vietnam War
description: ROME, Jan. 7 (Reuters)Pope Paul VI today expressed the hope that the resumed negotiations in Paris would bring a conclusive end to the war in Vietnam.

title: Inquiry Links an S.I. Man Held In Las Vegas to a Cocaine Ring
description: An alleged conspiracy involving traffic in millions of dollars worth of cocaine in such cities as Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington and Miami has been the subject of the investigation in which Staten Islander has been held in $5million bail in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Nixon Reported Planning to End the Community Relations Service, a Racial Mediation Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7The Nixon Administration plans to dismantle the Community Relations Service, an agency created under the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to mediate racial disputes, White House sources have reported.

title: Law Schools Seek Breadth and Depth
description: To an increasing number of college graduates, law offers the possibility of reforming society from within the system while at the same time providing a rich variety of job opportunities. As a result, there are virtually no empty places in the nation's law schools. Huge numbers of applicants are being denied admission by schools they would not have deigned to consider only a few years ago.

title: Serrano Case Unresolved
description: Last year this Annual Education Review highlighted the Serrano case, a landmark lawsuit in California in which that state's Supreme Court had held that the system of financing public education through local property taxation was unconstitutional because it discriminated against children living in poor towns.

title: HardPressed Prep Schools Struggle With a Stereotype
description: Prep schools? Few institutions today suffer from a more unhappy stereotype. In the public mind, all boarding schools are lumped together and perceived as places of snobbery, mannered elitism, and academic conservatism. Of course, alas, some schools, being quite out of touch with the times, deserve that image. But many do not, being pedagogically lively and socially and racially diverse institutions. However, the public is not accustomed to making such distinctions, and the stereotype remains.

title: James Merrill Is Awarded Bollingen Prize in Poetry
description: The Bollingen Prize in Poetry, one of the prestigious literary awards in the nation and sometimes a controversial one, was awarded yesterday to James Merrill, a poet with a considerable reputation among readers of poetry but not well known otherwise. It carries with it a cash stipend of $5,000.

title: The Ash Appointment
description: mittee that the dropping of Mr. Ball does not signify an Administration desire to politicalize Social Security. Perhaps his greatest contribution was keeping that multibilliondollar program totally free from any taint of politics.

title: Decorated Soldier Asks Discharge as Objector
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 7 (UPI) A former security guard of President Kennedy who was a muchdecorated Green Beret in Vietnam said today that he had become a conscientious objector and had set a personal withdrawal deadline of Jan. 15 from the Army.

title: Deposed Head of Shubert Empire, in Battle to Regain Power, Sues to Oust 3 Successors
description: Lawrence Shubert Lawrence, who was deposed as head of the Shubert empire, has asked the State Supreme Court to oust his successors, order new election of the board and appoint a referee to supervise an accounting of the triumvirate that rules that nationwide theater and realestate business.

title: GOVERNOR'S BILLS TO COMBAT DRUGS COMING THIS WEEK
description: Governor Rockefeller, acting swiftly to gain passage of his new antinarcotics proposals, will submit hills to the Legislature tomorrow or Wednesday to implement the stiffer penalties.

title: For Ph.D.'s, No End to Lean Years
description: Worry about supply and demand and about quality continues to plague American doctoral education midway through the academic year 197273.

title: New House Whip John Joseph McFall
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7A tinkling of tea cups can be heard each day around six o'clock in the afternoon in Room 2346 of the Rayburn House Office Building. That is when Representative John J. McFall, Democrat of California, pauses while signing letters to constituents and tending to other routine chores to enjoy a cup of tea with his staff and any other friends that might happen to drop in. Sharing a spot of tea typifies the man many classify as a congenial, low, key, hardworking Con gressinan from California's San Joaquin Valley who was appointed Democratic whip in the House of Representatives yesterday.

title: Complaint Phones Ring While Teeth Chatter
description: Ringing phones at the city's Central Complaint Bureau and 16 degree temperatures yesterday served as proof that winter was here, with temperatures reaching their lowest of the season so far.

title: Candidate Quits as Pastor
description: The Rev. A. Kendall Smith, head of the task force on racism of the Council of Churches, City of New York, yesterday announced his resignation as pastor of the Beulah Baptist Church, 125 West 130th Street. His recent decision to run as an independent candidate for Mayor had prompted political pressures that forced him to leave the pastorate that he had held for five years, the 36yearold Mr. Smith said. He added that petitions were being circulated for his candidacy as an independent in the November election.

title: The Computer Evolves Into a Powerful Liberal Arts Tool
description: Modern computers are only 25 years old, and yet computer science has become an important new profession. Someday there may be as many computer scientists in the United States as lawyers or doctors. Therefore, colleges and universities very early designed curriculums for the future computer scientist. But the wide use of computers in liberal arts courses is a recent development.

title: Learning From the Poor
description: Jerry Lovejoy went to a small, segregated elementary school in Greeleyville, S. C., before taking all the honors in high school and going on to Dartmouth College. Last fall, he began his sophomore year by going back to an allblack elementary school as a teacher's aide at P.S. 22, in the heart of Jersey City's ghetto. He figures that when he returns to Dartmouth this week, he will have done the seventh graders he helped teach a little good, and learned a few things himself, as well.

title: French Discounter Finds His Consumerism Pays Off
description: PARIS, Jan. 7  Max Thret said it publicly, which had never been done before in France. The movie cameras of the Paillard company of Switzerland were outmoded, and some of what Paillard said in its advertising was false and misleading.

title: TV: Witt KreenAkrore Indians in Amazon Jungle
description: The Tribe That Hides From Man is about the search for KreenAkrore Indians in the Amazon jungles of Brazil. The tribe is still hiding from man, presumably meaning contemporary civilization. But, in focusing on the search, the television documentary provides a fascinating anthropological tour of the Amazon.

title: Schindler Wins 6Mile Run
description: Jim Schindler of Bedford, N.Y. won the sixmile Road Runners Club of New York run yesterday in Central Park.

title: At P.S. 24, the Old and New Combine
description: Newsy News, a program that helps students develop their poise, speech, writing and knowledge of the world, is broadcast daily at 10:30 A.M. over the intercom of Public School 24 in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: 10 Dead in New Orleans Sniper Attack; Police in a Copier Kill Gunman at Hotel
description: NEW ORLEANS, Monday, Jan. 8After a day of terror in which 10 persons were killed and 13 wounded by snipers, New Orleans policemen, in a borrowed Marine helicopter, last night killed a sniper with red tracer bullets.

title: New Interest Awakening In Foreign Area Studies
description: The beginning of the nineteenseventies has seen a resurgence of international studies among American scholars.

title: Man With a Hammer Mars The Doors of St. Patrick's
description: A man scrawled illegible words on the bronze doors of St. Patrick's Cathedral late Saturday night and pounded on the doors with a sledge hammer, causing several dents, the police reported yesterday.

title: Seminaries Turn Pragmatic
description: Most graduates of Protestant and Roman Catholic seminaries in this country begin their ministerial careers with solid grounding in classical disciplines, like theology, church history and Biblical exegesis. But can they run a local church?

title: Passaic Is Beset by Chronic Urban Problems
description: PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 7Milton Bodner's shoe store in the heart of the bustling downtown shopping area on Lexington Avenue here is less than a mile from the bodega on Monroe Street that Rodabaldo Rodriguez sold recently after putting seven years of hard work into it. Financially, the two stores could not be further apart. Mr. Bodner just closed the books on what was the mbst successful year in his store's 48year history.

title: All About the Changes at Manhattanville
description: A few years ago, Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in Purchase, N. Y., was a small, Roman Catholic, liberal arts college for wellmannered young ladies with wealthy fathers.

title: Perrot Takes Slalom
description: KRANJSKA GORA, Yugoslavia, Jan. 7 (UPI)  Claude Perrot of France won a slalom race today and strengthened his lead in the European Cup. Perrot, second in both heats, had a combined time of 98.67 seconds. Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, who won the giant slalom yesterday, was second with a combined time of 98.71. Alfred Matt of Austria was third in 100.05 seconds.

title: A New Trend Benefits Neediest
description: Scores of contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund emphasized during the recent holiday season that they gave money to the annual appeal instead of sending out Christmas cards.

title: Language enrollment Leveling Off After Postwar Upsurge in Demand
description: Since the time a century and a half ago when Lgrenzo Da Ponte, Mozart's librettist, hung out his shingle as a professor of Italian in New York City, American education has maintained a lovehate (or perhaps yearningfrustration) relationship with the teaching of the modern foreign languages.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: A Week in the Life of Natalie Wright...
description: School is not the most important thing in life to Natalie Genette Wright, a 5 foot 2 inch 15yearold who every weekday morning travels by bus and subway from her home in the highrise Riverton apartments on Harlem's 135th Street to John F. Kennedy High School, 90 blocks uptown, where she is a ninth grader.

title: The World of Work on Academic List
description: Nineyearold Henry Kiel, using a jig saw, cuts a large map of Mexico from a piece of plastic board as part of a social studies project at the Jackson Avenue School in Hackensack, N. J. In another part of the unusual classroom Wilfred Wei, also 9, uses a manufacturerdonated camera to shoot some pictures for a slide film being produced by the thirdgrade group.

title: Plea Made For pet
description: Somewhere, in that vague morass of rhetoric that has always characterized descriptions of liberal education, one always finds a mention of values. The true purists insist on Intellectual values, but there have always been educators, particularly among founders of small liberal arts colleges in the nineteenth century, who likewise stressed moral values as one of the finest fruits of their educational process, especially if their colleges were inspired by religious group.

title: A New Trend Benefits Neediest
description: Scores of contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund emphasized during the recent holiday season that they gave money to the annual appeal instead of sending out Christmas cards.

title: New Methods of Teaching Science Put Emphasis on Discovery
description: Radical changes have occured during the last decade in the teaching of the hard sciences of physics, chemistry and biology.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fouralarm fire whipped by 40mileanhour winds off the Hudson River destroyed an abandoned pier shed at the foot of Chambers Street on Manhattan's Lower West Side yesterday morning, casting a pall of smoke over the downtown area.

title: Italian Reform Seeks to Spur LowRent Housing
description: ROME, Jan. 7During the last 23 years Italy's main agency for low  rent housing has deducted more than $5billion from workers' wages but has built only 390,000 lowrent homes. The reason for the lag was bureaucratic bunOn.

title: Detroit Manhunt Stirs Controversy
description: DETROIT, Jan. 7  Detroit's police are conducting a massive manhunt for three men sought in the killing of one policeman and the wounding of five. One of the suspects is also sought in the killing of one civilian and wounding of another.

title: Belfast Fruit Broker Deals in Turmoil
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland We have a shipment of 12,000 pounds of pears from France. Are you interested?

title: Iceland Curbs Fishing Boats
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Jan. 7 (AP)Icelandic gunboats cut the trawl wires of three trawlerstwo British and one West Germanin a weekend flareup of the dispute over fishing limits off Iceland.

title: Bronx Band to Perform for the Nation
description: New York City's Official Teenage Marching Ambassadors of Musical Goodwill From the Concrete Canyons of the Capital City of the Worldless flamboyantly known as the Knickerbocker Drum and Bugle Corpswill become on Jan. 20 the first New York City parade unit, at least in recent memory, to march at a Presidential inauguration.

title: Housing Subsidies Likely to Continue, Mills Tells Builders
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 7Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that a Federal subsidy program for moderate and lowincome housing was likely to be continued without interruption, despite reports that the Nixon Administration was considering suspending the program for 18 months.

title: Garelik Denounces Report Of His Taking Gratuities
description: In uncharacteristically fiery fashion, City Council President Sanford D. Garelik opened a public counterattack yesterday on the Knapp Commission's allegation that he took gratuities from businessmen he dealt with officially while he was a policeman.

title: Kissinger Tests 707C Jet
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) The new Boeing 707C that is scheduled to take over as the Presidential aircraft next month flew Henry A. Kissinger to Paris today on its first official mission, The jet Air Force 27000, was piloted by Col. Ralph Albertazzi, President Nixon's pilot, who will take it through several more shakedown flights before he certifies it for Presidential use.

title: ... As Others See Us
description: O Wad some Pow'r the giftie gie us To see oursels as others see us! It wad frae monie a blunder free us An' foolish notion.

title: What Is an Educated Person?
description: If we consider just the bare formalities, an educated person in 1973 should begin by earning a bachelor's degree from a good fouryear college. He should also possess a graduate or professional degree as well as a certificate attesting to at least a year or two of postgraduate study.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: STONE WINS JUMP AT BEAR MOUNTAIN
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 7Larry Stone, the 27yearold Salisbury, Conn., ski juniper, won the 28th annual Torger Tokle Memorial tournament today with a leap of 148 feet.

title: Mrs. Meir to Visit Nixon
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Jan. 7 (AP)President Nixon will meet with Premier Golda Melt of Israel on March 1, the White House announced today. She will be in the United States for a private visit at the time.

title: Sniping Case Recalls Slayings From Texas U. Tower in 1966
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 7 (UPI)The sniper attack from atop a New Orleans hotel today recalled Charles Whitman's killing of 16 persons on Aug. 1, 1966, from the University of Texas tower here.

title: Bethlehem Celebration Ends
description: BETHLEHEM, Israeli OccupiedJordan, Jan. 7 (AP)The Greek Orthodox Patriarch Benedictos I returned to his seat in Jerusalem today, signaling an end to Christmas celebrations by Eastern Orthodox churches in Bethlehem. Eastern Orthodox communities celebrate Christmas by the Julian calendar.

title: Winchester Takes Bonspiel, Beating Ardsley Rink, 158
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N. Y.; Jan. 7The Winchester, Mass, Curling Club rink, the defender, won the 38th annual bonspiel for the Douglas Medal at St. Andrew's Golf Club today. Winchester defeated the Ardsley Curling Club in the final, 15.8.

title: Moscow Pitting Tuchman Book Against Solzhenitsyn's
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 7The Soviet Union has published a translation of The Guns of August, a book by Barbara W. Tuchman that deals with the origins of World War I, apparently to counter the impact of August 1914, the novel by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, which has been barred by the Kremlin.

title: Extra Foreign Pay Of Company Aides Is Debated in Study
description: Extra compensation is still the rule for American business executives serving their companies in foreign countries, although there is some debate whether the financial aid is necessary.

title: Times Names Publisher's Aide
description: Nathan W. Goldstein, circulation director of The New York Times, will become a special assistant to the publisher on Jan. 15, The responsibility for circulationdepartment operations will be transferred to the circulation manager, Frank H. Adams.

title: STATE PARK PLAN IMPERILED BY SUIT
description: PATERSON, Jan. 7A suit to foreclose a mortgage on 3,200 acres of virgin land that the state hopes to buy for a park could force the state to pay more for the land than it has been planning.

title: 2 Die of Methadone
description: The names of a Pikers Island inmate and a Tombs prisoner were added yesterday to the growing list of deaths involving methadone taken by persons in city institutions. Details, Page 17.

title: REACTION MIXED ON DRUG PENALTY
description: Governor Rockefeller's proposal for mandatory life sentences for harddrug dealers drew fresh scorn and praise yesterday.

title: Swedish Chilliness Toward U.S. Is Limited to Vietnam
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 6 Swedes are out this weekend enjoying the mildest winter in 300 years and gathering signatures on a petition backed by all political parties calling for an end to the Vietnam war.

title: TV: I Am Joe's Heart
description: If I Am Joe's Heart, a halfhour program on the abuse and care of a vital human organ, is any indication of what to expect on television from the Reader's nigest Association, then it's welcome back to the fold. Based on a widely acclaimed article by J. D. Ratcliff, this is the first solo production by the magazine, which was involved in a TV series back in the early fifties. More newones, reportedly, are on the way.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Henry A. Kissinger arrived in Paris yesterday to resume the talks on a Vietnam settlement that were broken off last month amid accusations of obstructionist tactics from both the United States and North Vietnam. We expect the talks this time will be serious and worthy of the yearnings of the people all over the world for an early end to the war, Mr. Kissinger said on his arrival at Orly Airport. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Press Club Plans to Give Rockefeller a Membership
description: Governor Rockefeller, a supporter of laws to protect newsmen's confidential sources, will be given an honorary membership in the New York Press Club on Jan. 18, the club announced yesterday.

title: British M.P. to Ask Nader Not to Boycott Drug Maker
description: LONDON, Jan. 7 (UPI)Jack Ashley, the Member of Parliament who led the fight to compensate parents of children deformed by thalidomide, said today that he would ask Ralph Nader, the American consumer advocate, to call off plans for a boycott of the company that manufactured the drug in Britain.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHOWPIECE The Roxy Theater was a palatial affair at 50th Street and Seventh Avenue, a splendid rococo, or should it be baroque, at any rate real fancy, commercial cathedral that showed its wares in the dark but made going in and out a soulful experience, particularly if you made it before 1 P.M. and got in for 25 cents.

title: Varieties of Educational Experience
description: IN THIS SECTION

title: Stars Halt Rally by Nets And Triumph, 113 to 104
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 7The New York Nets continued to suffer through life without Rick Barry today when they dropped a 113104 decision to the Utah Stars for the 14th defeat in their last 17 games.

title: N.E.A. Surveys Teacher Needs
description: In its first nationwide survey of the needs and problems of teachers, the National Education Association has found that four difficulties outrank all others in their effect on a teachers' ability to teach.

title: 2 Die of Methadone
description: The names of a Bikers Island inmate and a Tombs prisoner were added yesterday to the growing list of deaths involving methadone taken by persons in city institutions. Details, Page 17.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 7 (AP)The Soviet Union national hockey team swept its fourgame series with Western Hockey League clubs by routing the Portland Buckaroos, 114, last night before a crowd of 10,492 in its final appearance in the United States.

title: Hawks Foil Late Thrusts And Defeat Bruins, 5 to 4
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP)Dar Maloney and Cliff Koroll scored a pair of goals each today to pace the Chicago Black Hawks to a 54 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League contest.

title: Eastern Hockey League
description: SATURDAY'S GAMES

title: Issue and Debate
description: The New York Stock Exchange has been called the world's most expensive private club. A few years ago a membership, or seat, sold for more than $500,000 and lately seat prices have been hovering just under $200,000.

title: HUSSEIN PRODS U.S. FOR MIDEAST STEPS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (Reuters)King Hussein of Jordan asked the United States today to take new, positive steps toward ending ArabIsraeli differences in the Middle East. He said that a breakthrough to peace might be near.

title: Damaged Ship at Norfolk
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 7 (AP)The containership Seatrain Ohio, arrived at a shipyard today for an inspection of fire damage in her engine and boiler rooms. The blaze occurred last night in Chesapeake Bay. No one was injured.

title: Credit Markets: Corporate Issue Lags
description: The bond market took the course of least resistance yesterday and declined as the first significant new corporate issue of the year met only a lukewarm response from investors.

title: Lovett Replaced by Jeter As Va. State Football Pilot
description: PETERSBURG, Va., Jan. 8 (AP)Virginia State College announced today the resignation of its football coach, Walt Lovett.

title: Indicted Suffolk Attorney Removed From All Duties
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Jan. 8Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein today removed County Attorney George W. Percy Jr. from all administrative and decisionmaking responsibilities.

title: H. J. Kenner, ExHead Here Of Better Business Bureau
description: H. J. Kenner, who was manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York from its organization in 1922 to his retirement at the end of 1947, died yesterday in Tuscola, Ill. He was 85 years old.

title: ACQUISITION IS SET BY NATIONAL CITY
description: The First National City Corporation announced yesterday that it had completed an agreement announced on July 14 under which it acquired the Acceptance Finance Company, St. Louisbased consumer finance company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Rights Panel Hears of Job Bias on ExAddicts
description: Of 50,000 former heroin addicts still under treatment, in the city, 30,000 are unemployed because they are wrongly considered high risks, Health Services, Administrator Gordon Chase said yesterday.

title: MRS. BILDERSEE
description: Mrs. Ada Kogan Bildersee, teacher and librarian in the public schools for 42 years until her retirement last September, died Sunday at New York Hospital. Her age was 61 and she lived at 205 West End Avenue.

title: Student Dies Fighting Fire
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 8 (AP) A University of Wisconsin student died today while fighting a fire in a 10story home for the aged where he worked. Allen Philipsen, 22 years old, of Kimberly, a worker at Allen Hall Residential Care Center, died of smoke inhalation, officials at Madison General Hospital said. Firefighters evacuated residents of the home. There were no other injuries.

title: CATHERINE B. STERN, TEACHER, AUTHOR, 79
description: Dr. Catherine Brieger Stern, who contributed to the modern theory of teaching elementary mathematics and reading, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 12 West 96th Street.

title: Psychiatrist Says Hijacker Is Pretending to Be Insane
description: A psychiatrist asserted yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn that a confessed airliner hijacker had systematically evaded prison for years by cleverly feigning insanity.

title: ROMNEY DISCLOSES HALT IN SUBSIDIES FOR NEW HOUSING
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 8George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, announced today that the Nixon Administration had halted virtually all new commitments to subsidize lowand middleincome housing construction.

title: AMOSKEAG CO. BUYS BONDS IN THE B. & M.
description: BOSTON, Jan. 8Frederic C., Dumaine, president of the Amoskeag Company, announced today that Amoskeag had purchased $10.3million of the $14.2million in bonds held by four insurance companies in the bankrupt Boston & Maine Railroad.

title: Wrecking Crews
description: A titfortat battle over the Vietnam war between waterfront unions in the United States and Australia has been making a mess of relations between the two countries.

title: Monopoly Makers Defend the Game's Cheap Streets
description: Rushing to the defense of American tradition and legions of playmoney millionaires the makers of Monopoly have fired off an indignantly worded protest to Atlantic City against a proposal to rename Mediterranean and Baltic Avenues.

title: COUNTER STOCKS SHOW ADVANCE
description: Most stocks on the overthecounter market advanced yesterday while prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed.

title: Woodstock Jesuit College Here, Experimental Seminary, to Shut
description: Woodstock College, the Jesuit seminary here that has been conducting an experiment in theological education, will close permanentlyat least in its present formon or before the end of the academic year.

title: Cahill Seeks Transit Unit To Take Over Toll Roads
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8  Governor Cahill will urge the Legislature tomorrow to take a bold step forward by approving a masstransit agency that would absorb New Jersey's major toll roads and ultimately channel their profits into a unified masstransportation program throughout the state.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Salt Water Flies, by Kenneth E. Bay (J. B. Lippincott Company, 158 pages, illustrated, $8.95) fills a long empty voiduntil its publication no book devoted entirely to the subject was available.

title: Federal Court Jury Picked In Chicago for Kerner Trial
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP)A jury of six men and six women was selected today in Federal District Court for the trial of Otto Kermer, a Federal appeals judge and former Illinois Governor.

title: Paul Webbink, 69, ExOfficial Of Social Science Council, Dies
description: Paul Webbink, who retired in 1970 as vice president the Social Science Research Council, died Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. His age was 69.

title: FINANCIAL PLAN SET FOR HANOI HOMELESS
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Tan., 8 (Agence FrancePresse)The official Hanoi newspaper Nhan Dan said today that the Government and the ruling Communist party had adopted financial measures to ease the plight of those made homeless by American bombings. At the same time, Nhan Dan emphasized a need for personal and local initiative.

title: TV Review
description: Several of yesterday's TV soap operas were interrupted for what appeared to be a typical Actionsuspense melodrama, complete with policemen, terrorists, rifles and gunfire. The action, however, was live, direct from the Howard Johnson Motel in downtown New Orleans.

title: Gain in Consumer Credit Set Record in November
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The total amount of consumer credit outstanding rose by a record $2.1billion in November, to a total of $153billion, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Soviet Sporting Arms Deal
description: The Universal Container Corporation said yesterday that its Universal Sporting Goods subsidiary had reached an agreement in principle with V/O Raznoexport, a Soviet foreign trade association, to he the exclusive distributor of Russianmade sporting and hunting arms in the United States. The agreement is contingent upon the granting by the United States of the mostfavorednation principle to the Soviet Union.

title: Saturn Rocket Going to Pad
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Jan. 8 (UPI) The Saturn 1B rocket that will launch the pilots for the first Skylab space station will be moved to the firing pad tomorrow for preliminary checks, The rocket is scheduled to take off May 1 with three astronauts, Capt. Charles Conrad, Sr., Dr. Joseph P. Kerwin, a commander, and Comdr. Paul J. Weitz, all of the Navy, aboard a modified Apollo command ship. The Skylab will be launched unmanned a day earlier by a large Saturn 5,

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: POLICS JUSTIE. SCORED BY CLARK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI)  Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, asserting that a paramilitary concept of law enforcement prevails in America, said today that the present system should be replaced by one using policemen accepted as civil servants working for the people.

title: Shazar Ends Visit Here With Appeal for Funds
description: President Zalman Shazar of Israel ended a fiveday visit here yesterday with an appeal to Jews in the United States to help Israel absorb an influx of Soviet Jews. He left for home last night from Kennedy International Airport.

title: N.C.A.A. Expects Delay In S. W. Louisiana Case
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP)The National Collegiate Athletic Association, assembling for the 67th annual convention that begins Thursday, indicated tonight that it probably would be unable to act on its expected investigation of the Southwestern Louisiana basketball team's alleged violations of the N.C.A.A. recruiting code.

title: Bonn Naming Peking Envoy
description: BONN, Jan. 8 (AP)  Informed sources said today that West Germany's first ambassador to mainland China would be Rolff Pauls, who is now the Ambassador to Washington and was Bonn's first Ambassador to Israel. He was expected to be replaced in Washington by Berndt von Staden of the Foreign Ministry.

title: Miss Goolagong A 60, 63 Victor In New Zealand
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 8 (AP)Evonne Goolagong, beaten yesterday in the final of the New South Wales tennis championship, won her first match in the New Zealand [open championship today. The 21yearold Aussie easily beat Lindsay Blatchford of Britain, 60, 63.

title: Cheap Streets Defended by Monopoly Makers
description: Rushing to the defense American tradition and legions of playmoney millionaires, the makers of Monopoly have fired off an indignantly worded protest to Atlantic City against a proposal to rename Mediterranean and Baltic Avenues.

title: Crash Victims in Andes Will Be Buried at Site
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 8 (AP)The Uruguayan Air Force announced today that an official party would go into the Chilean Andes to bury the remains of 29 people killed in a plane crash and avalanche last October.

title: Market Place:
description: Investors are familiar with those disclaimers that appear at the bottom of brokerage house recommendations. When they are read with care, it's a wonder the investor is willing to buy recommended stock at all.

title: Philadelphia Teachers Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 Philadelphia's public school teachers went on strike today for higher pay.

title: MAN WITH CYANIDE SEIZED AT AIRPORT
description: A New Jersey laboratory technician was arrested at La Guardia Airport yesterday and charged with attempted hijacking after he had allegedly tried to board an Eastern Airlines jet with two bottles containing cyanide gas.

title: Insurance Company Fined Over Delays on Complaints
description: CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 8 (AP)  The State Insurance Commissioner, John Durkin, said today that the Pennsylvania Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia had been fined $2,500 for failing to maintain an adequate procedure to process and respond to policyholders' complaints.

title: One Shot Dead in Quarrel After Parking Lot Accident
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 8 (UPI)A man was shot to death today in the parking lot of the General Motors assembly plant here.

title: Father of Quintuplets: I Lost Track After Three
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 8I just sat there on the hall floor, watching the incubators come out of the delivery room and go down to the nursery and come back to the delivery room and go down to the nursery, again and again.

title: Summer Home of John Hay To Become Wildlife Refuge
description: NEWBURY, N. H., Jan. 8 (AP)  The New Hampshire lakefront estate where the author of the United States' open door policy in China spent his summers will be given to the Federal Government for a wildlife refuge.

title: 700 Guards to Be Added To Force in City Schools
description: The city school system is planning to add about 700 security officers to its staff by the end of February  thereby doubling the size of the present school safety force  in an effort to combat crime and violence in and around schools.

title: Soviet Lofts Unmanned Craft, Luna 21, on Path to the Moon
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 8The Soviet Union launched another unmanned spacecraft toward the moon today, continuing an active program of lunar exploration now that the Apollo project in the United States has ended.

title: Random House in Deal For Ballantine Books
description: Random House has acquired Ballantine Books, publishers of massmarket paperbook originals and reprints, for approximately $6.4million, payable in installments from Jan. 2, 1974, through Jan. 2, 1978. The announcement was made here by Robert L. Bernstein, president of Random House, who said an agreement had been reached with lntext, Inc., Ballantine's parent company since 1969.

title: People and Business
description: Albert T. Sommers, senior vice president and chief economist of The Conference Board, is bullish on America for 1973. One of the segments of the economy on which he is most bullish is retailing.

title: Police Seek Clues to Cause Of Fatal Blaze in Catskills
description: KERHONKSON, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP)The state police questioned survivors and sifted through ashes and charred ruins today looking for clues to what touched off the weekend fire that killed seven young resort workers in this Catskill Mountain hamlet.

title: Steel Export Pact Is Upheld by Court
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 8 (Reuters)  A Federal court judge today refused to block an agreement under which foreign steel manufacturers agreed to limit their exports to the United States.

title: S.W. Louisiana Triumphs; Illinois State Also Wins
description: UNIONDALE, L. L, Jan. 9The Nassau Coliseum presented its fourth college basketball program tonight and once again pro scouts and the player agents had a field day and made up a large part of the announced crowd of 3,017.

title: Australian Union Calls Off 2WeekOld Boycott of U.S. Ships
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 9 (AP)The Australian Maritime Union today called off its boycott of United States shipping, imposed two weeks ago in protest over American bombing of North Vietnam.

title: L. O. IRELAND, SET UP AN ACCOUNTING FIRM
description: Lloyd O. Ireland, a certified public accountant and a founder last year of Sprague, Diggins & Ireland, Inc., died Sunday in the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow. He was 45 years old and lived at 332 West Neck Road in Lloyd Harbor, L. I.

title: ATLANTIC FARES CUT BY B.O.A.C. TO $145
description: LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP)British Overseas Airways Corporation today announced cuts in its roundtrip fares across the Atlantic on regularly scheduled LondonNew York flights to a new low of $145.70 in the low season.

title: A Colony of Bees Lives in a Town House on West 87th St.
description: It was late last summer, and the Congdons were in the country, when a swarm of bees, clinging, to a traffic sign at Fifth Avenue and 17th Street, appeared on their television screen. They. looked at one another with instant foreboding.

title: Israelis and Syrians Fight Air and Artillery Battles
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 8Israel and Syria fought extensive air and artillery battles today after Israeli planes struck at Syrian targets in what a military spokesman described as reprisal for guerrilla attacks on the Golan heights.

title: BOARD 18 ADOPTS SCHOOL REZONING
description: Community School Board 18 In the CanarsieEast Flatbush sections of Brooklyn voted last night to go ahead with the adoption of its monthold rezoning plan for three junior high schools after School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner withdrew an order that it prepare a new proposal.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: LEGISLATURE GETS BILLS ON TRANSIT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8Governor Rockefeller today sent to the Legislature bills providing for a $650million mass transportation construction program by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The New Jersey Legislature has already passed and Governor Cahill has signed the counterpart measures.

title: Solzhenitsyn Is Denied a Divorce, but Renews Attempt
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 8  Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prizewinning novelist, has lost a 14month effort to win a divorce although he has been living with a second woman for more than three years and she has borne him two sons.

title: Books of The Times
description: VISIONS OF CODY. By Jack Kerouac. Introduction by Alien Ginsberg. 398 pages. McGrawHill. $8.95.

title: Little Progress Reported In U.S.Soviet Arins Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Wellplaced Administration officials said today that the United States and the Soviet Union had failed to make any significant progress in their latest round of talks on the limita tion of strategic arms.

title: Ohio Derby Worth $100,000
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 8 (AP) The Ohio Derby will carry a $100,000 purse again this year, officials of Thistledown race track announced today. The 1mile race for 3yearolds will be run June 16.

title: Hospital Patients' Bill of Rights Backed
description: An individual's right to choose death by rejecting medical therapy and a patient's right to obtain a full explanation in clear, concise terms of his medical condition were affirmed in a 12point Bill of Rights that the nation's leading hospital association issued yesterday.

title: REV. DR. FRED FIEDLER
description: The Rev. Dr. Fred J. Fiedler, who retired in 1959 as secretary of the Board of World Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America, died Saturday in Jackson Heights, Queens, where he lived. His ago was 81.

title: F.P.C. ASKS A CURB ON NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Federal Power Commission proposed today a system of rationing scarce natural gas supplies that would give first priority to homes and small commercial consumers.

title: Discussion Stops on Philippine Charter
description: MANILA, Jan. 8  Public discussion of the proposed new Philippine Constitution has ended as a result of an order by President Ferdinand E. Marcos yesterday, banning free debate on the charter and calssifying the spreading of rumors as subversive.

title: UMBERTO TUPINI, 83, ITALIAN EXSENATOR
description: ROME, Jan. 8Former . Senator Umberto Tupini, who was Mayor of Rome in 195657, died here yesterday. He was 83 years old and had been living in retirement since he gave up his seat in Parliament four years ago.

title: PANAMA BOXING IN STATE OF WAR
description: PANAMA CITY, Jan. 8 (AP)  Panama retaliated against the World Boxing. Council today for withdrawing recognition of Enrique Pinder as bantamweight championit withdrew recognition of the World Boxing Council.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Those tubular metal frames on chairs and tables and beds and shelving systems get fatter all the time, a far cry from Marcel Breuer's slim pipes that he adapted for use in chairs from the handlebars of bicycles almost 50 years ago.

title: Fillmore Is Saluted For Education Work.
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 8 (AP)Dr. McAllister H. Hull Jr., dean of the Graduate School at the State University at Buffalo, praised President Millard Fillmore today for his work in education. The dean spoke at a ceremony at Fillmore's grave site in Forest Lawn Cemetery.

title: The Mandatory Illusion
description: Hardliners and civil libertarians are predictably at one another's throats in New York, following Gov. Nelson Rockefeller's announcement that he will seek mandatory life sentences with no possibility of parole and no plea bargainingfor pushers of hard drugs. But for once, these arguments of right and wrong may be laid aside for the simple reason that the Governor's proposal is demonstrably unworkable, unless accompanied by unimaginable court and prison expansion.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8If more coaches followed Mike Curry's example, New Jersey's top highschool athletes would all be staying home and competing for Garden State colleges.

title: Advertising: Marketing Books
description: Harold Levine, who is president of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt and who would like to get his hands on a book account, says that, while everything else in the publishers' marketplace has changed in the last 40 years, book advertising has remained the same.

title: TALKS ON L.I.R.R. END IN IMPASSE
description: Negotiations to end the Long Island Rail Road strike broke up here last night with a spokesman saying there was no progress to report in the 41day walkout.

title: Track Coach Demanding More Events for Women
description: A top women's track and field coach charged yesterday that promoters of major indoor meets in the United States were discriminating against women athletes and contributing to the problems facing the sport for the 1976 Olympics.

title: Aide to Lynch Reports Progress on U.S. Investment
description: Prime Minister John Lynch of Ireland expects to announce several major new investments, in his nation by American corporations before ending his visit; here Thursday, according to Kevin Rush, the Irish Consul General in New York.

title: Arthur Daley The Wrong End
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 8Whenever Paul (Bear) Bryant mentions his playing days at the University Alabama, he turns uncharacteristically modest and makes a point of saying, I was at the wrong end. No one knew I existed because our other end was Don Hutson. As even the most backward student should know, the fleet Hutson went on to become a legend with the Green Bay Packers, while Bryant later, gained fame of a different sort as coach of his alma mammy.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: G.I. Manpower in Vietnam Down by 100, but May Rise
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 8 (UPI) American military strength in Vietnam declined by 100 men and dropped to an overall total of 24,000 last week, but military sources said today that it might increase slightly before it declined once more.

title: Airport Building Burns
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 (AP) An accidental fire destroyed the administration building at North Philadelphia Airport today. The airport is largely used by private planes and shorthaul commuter traffic.

title: A Colony of Bees Lives in a Town House on West 87th St.
description: It was late last summer, and the Congdons were in the country, when a swarm of bees, clinging to a traffic sign at Fifth Avenue and 17th Street, appeared on their television screen. They looked at one another with instant foreboding.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Civil Servant
description: Sometimes a city is diminished by the death of a man whose name is not a household word or a symbol of power. Samuel Ratensky was what might be called an uncommon bureaucrat, a planner who worked within the systemthe city's leveling and standarddefeating housing agencieswith a wise, lowkey realism, bending rules wherever possible to the achievement of ideals. He was a gentle fighter of quick strength for better housing and planning, and ultimately for the people of New York.

title: Father of Quintuplets: I Lost Track After Three
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 8 I just sat there on the hall floor, watching the incubators come out of the delivery room and go down to the nursery and come back to the delivery room and go down to the nursery, again and again.

title: F.C.C. and 13 Other Agencies Bar Eavesdropping on Workers
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 8 (AP) In the aftermath of a case involving the Federal Communications Commission, 13 other Federal agencies have assured Congress that they do not secretly listen to their workers' phone calls and the commission says there will be no repetition of a 1970 eavesdropping episode disclosed by a Congressional committee.

title: C.B.S. AND AGENCIES OPPOSE BAN ON ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) The Columbia Broadcasting System and major advertising agencies opposed today a proposal before the Federal Communications Commission to ban all commercials from children's television programs  a move endorsed by citizens' groups.

title: TWO KNICKS NAMED TO ALLSTAR TEAM
description: Dave DeBusschere of the New York Knicks and Pete Maravich of the Atlanta Hawks will be in the National Basketball Association's AllStar game lineup for the first time at Chicago, Jan. 28.

title: VANDERBILT BOWS TO FLORIDA, 8072
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP)A freshman, Gene Chy, led Florida to an upset victory over nationally ranked Vanderbilt, 8072, tonight in a Southeastern Conference basketball game. Shy, a 6foot5inch forward, scored 24 points, hitting on nine of 14 shots and six of nine free throws.

title: RUPERT N. GRESHMA
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 8 (UPI)Rupert N. Greshma, a lawyer who once was a member of the advisory group on taxation of the House Ways and Means Committee, died today. He was 80 years old.

title: On Adolph Zukor's 100th Birthday, Paramount Throws Nostalgic Party
description: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 8 Adolph Zukor, the patriarch of Paramount Pictures, celebrated his 100th birthday here last night at a banquet that aroused memories of shimmering movie palaces, stars waving goodby on the Super Chief and a fabled town that massproduced myths for the world.

title: Kuwait Signs Participation Pact; World Bank Votes for Iraq Loan
description: The Government of Kuwait signed a participation agreement yesterday under which it will receive an initial 25 per cent interest in existing concessions on its territory.

title: Philadelphia to Get Soccer Franchise, League Indicates
description: North American Soccer League owners and officials disclosed yesterday that the award of a franchise to Philadelphia was just about definite, but will not be announced before Friday.

title: 3 Testify to Doing Work For Retired Guard Chief
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8  A plumber, an electrician and a ditch digger testified today that they had done work on the home of Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell when he was commander of the New Jersey National Guard but that they were paid in full at going contractor rates.

title: NEW STOCK RULE IS ASKED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today an addition to its series of safe harbor rules defining conditions under which small companies may offer and sell intrastate securities without complying with the registration requirement of the securities act.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 8 (UPI)Euonymus closed strongly through the stretch at Bowie today to win the $10,000 allowance feature at 1 116 miles for fillies and mares.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: KISSINGER MEETS THO FOR 4 HOURS AS TALKS RESUME
description: PARIS, Jan. 8  Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho resumed negotiations for a ceasefire here today.

title: Curb on Protests by Students Feared in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  Two commissions appointed by Prime Minister John Vorster's Government have been studying universities and student organizations and are expected to report on them during the session of Parlia1 ment that begins early in February.

title: Yale's Poor Little Lambs Aid Neediest
description: Yale University's poor little lambs who have lost our way and its little black sheep who have gone astray sent a check for $25 the other day to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: KISSINGER MEETS TM FOR 4 HOURS AS TALKS RESUME
description: PARIS, Jan. 8  Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho resumed negotiations for a ceasefire here today.

title: Bridge: Way Winners Are Cashed May Require Some Thought
description: Cashing winners is usually a pedestrian business of no great interest, but occasionally the precise sequence in which the winners are cashed may require some thought. If you wish to test yourself, cover the EastWest hands in the diagramed deal.

title: Hamilton Deplores HousingFund Cutoff
description: Deputy Major Edward K. Hamilton characterized as a grossly irresponsible act the withdrawal of Federal housing funds announced in Houston yesterday by George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Convict, Freed on Error, Held in California Slaying
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI)A San Quentin convict who won an early release from prison 14 months ago because of a clerical error was arrested yesterday in connection with the slaying of a 50yearold grandmother.

title: In 32Hour Siege, Police Weighed Many Tactics
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 (AP) The police considered and discarded everything from a frontal assault to helicopter landings and even the use of flame throwers in their 32hour attempt to kill or capture the sniper or snipers in the Downtown Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge.

title: Disease Report From Coast
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI)  The California Public Health Department today reported 57 deaths from influenza and pneumonia in the state's 11 largest cities in the first week of 1973. Dr. James Chin, chief of the Bureau of Communicable Diseases, said the number of deaths in the cities, which account for about 30 per cent of California's population, approached the epidemic threshold.

title: Da Nang Bombing Error Embarrasses U.S. Aides
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 8The latest accidentalbombing incident of the Vietnam war is causing particular embarrassment here among American officers who have been defending the Navy and Air Force against Hanoi's charges of striking civilians.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Cutback in West Virginia
description: FAIRMONT, W. Va., Jan. 8 (UPI)The Monongahela Power Company and three of its affiliates today asked about one million customers in five states to limit the use of electricity temporarily until one of its generating units was placed back in operation. The company said the unit at its Fort Martin power station near Morgantown, W. Va., was lost temporarily today when a boiler developed a leak.

title: Nonprofit Fund Pays City
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday praised the 20th Century Fund, a propertyowning taxexempt foundation, for its sixth annual payment of $12,000 to the city for municipal services it received free of charge last year. The trustees of the nonprofit institution voted the payment because of a social responsibility to our fellow residents for the municipal services rendered to us.

title: Study Says Car Pollution Curb Could Add $860 to the Price
description: DETROIT, Jan. 8  PolluLion control systems for automobiles could add $860 to the price and operating costs of cars by 1976, according to a report presented to a convention of the Society of Automotive Engineers today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Shakespeare Roles Get Equity Award

title: RAIDERS BEATEN IN OVERTIME, 65
description: Playing a scrambling, catchup kind of hockey, the New York Raiders twice rallied to tie the Quebec Nordiques last night at Madison Square Garden, only to lose in suddendeath overtime, 65.

title: HEALTH SERVICES SEEK MORE FUNDS
description: Health Services Administrator Gordon Chase submitted to the Bureau of the Budget yesterday what he described as a modest request for $290million to pay for his agency's operations in the 197374 fiscal year.

title: Retailers Weigh Consumerism
description: Merchants from across the country were warned at a meeting here yesterday that they were faced with a demand for zero defects, They were told that the American public wants to know, if we can pinpoint a projected location on the moon, why can't we make a zipper that always works or a car that can be fixed?

title: Equity Financing
description: The El Chico Corporation said yesterday it had withdrawn a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last spring in connection with a proposed offering of 280,000 common shares. The company said that overthecounter market conditions were such that it did not seem desirable at this time to make the offering. El Chico closed yesterday, at 8 bid, 8 asked.

title: Alitalia and Chinese Airline Exchange Route Privileges
description: PEKING, Jan. 8 (Reuters)China and Italy signed an agreement today enabling their flag airlines to fly between the two countries and to destinations beyond, an informed source here said.

title: Debris and Broken Glass Litter Street Below Hotel Roof Where Sniper Died
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 (UPI)At dawn today, the only movement on the top floor of the 17story Downtown Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge was torn, dirty curtains flapping in the breeze from the shattered windows.

title: Cahill Seeks Transit Unit To Take Over Toll Roads
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8  Governor Cahill will urge the Legislature tomorrow to take a bold step forward by approving a masstransit agency that would absorb New Jersey's major toll roads and ultimately channel their profits into a unified masstransportation program throughout the state.

title: Wilkins Terms Blacks in State of Siege
description: American Negroes are under a state of siege launched by the executive branch of the Federal Government, according to Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: 11 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH INSPECTIONS
description: The Health Department yesterday released the names of 11 foodprocessing establishments that it said had violated the Health Code.

title: Recital by Tucker and Merrill Is Marked by Stirring Vocalism
description: Richard Tucker and Robert Merrill joined the Metropolitan Opera before Sir Rudolf Bing, but in many ways they can be considered sympotomatic of the Bing achievement.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Housing Moratorium Ends In Westchester on Jan. 15
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 8The latest moratorium on the State Urban Development Corporation's plans in Westchester expires one week from today. Although the announcement from Washington this morning of a freeze on federally subsidized housing has cast doubt on the future of this and other housing programs, officials of the state agency said late today that they still expected the nine towns to comply with the Jan. 15 deadline for submitting plans for low and moderateincome housing for the U.D.C.'s approval.

title: Nixon, at 60, Gives Formula for Living: Never Slow Down
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8On the eve of his 60th birthday, President Nixon said the way to thwart advancing age was to avoid boredom, look to the future andabove allto have young people around.

title: Democrats Choose Two Top Financial Officers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Two successful businessmen one of whom apparently did not contribute to the Presidential campaign of Senator George McGovern  today were appointed top financial officers of the debtburdened Democratic party.

title: Supreme Court to Rule on Challenges to Power of Federal Agency to Bar Drugs Not Proved Effective
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a group of legal challenges to the power of the Food and Drug Administration to keep ineffective drugs off the market.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)Nourrhedine Boutagou won the men's 200meter butterfly event tonight to give Algeria the first gold medal of the second allAfrica games. But the Egyptians winners of all the gold medals in the first games held in 1965, ended the day with three gold, two silver and two bronze medalsall in swimming at the Olympicsized pool.

title: Some Realistic Movie Prizes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The New York film critics have opened the awards season by pronouncing Cries and Whispers the best film of 1972. It is a Bergman film from Sweden. Nobody outside Scandinavia has seen it except the New York film critics, and the prize need not detain us since, if your town is anything like Washington, the film will not arrive until the second Agnew Administration.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Athens Officially Becomes a Home Port for Ships of U.S. Navy
description: ATHENS, Jan. 8Athens today formally became the American Navy's largest home port in Europe.

title: Unified Korean Team Seen For Next Olympic Games
description: OSAKA, Japan, Tuesday, Jan. 9 (AP)A North Korean sports official said today that North and South Korea could possibly send a unified team to the next Olympic Games, scheduled for Montreal in 1976.

title: Two Tombs Guards Testify CoWorker Encouraged Rioters
description: Two corrections officers testified yesterday that a fellow officer had urged inmates not to end their riot in the Tombs in October, 1970.

title: Saigon Parliament, 6950, Clears Bill to Curb Parties
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 8 (UPI)The lower house of Parliament today approved a bill sponsored by President Nguyen Van Thieu meant to help cut back the number of political parties.

title: GOVERNOR ASSAILS DRUGBILL CRITICS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8On the eve of the submission to the Legislature of his narcoticsoffense sentencing proposals, Governor Rockefeller today castigated judges who said last week that the plan would be unworkable.

title: NORTH STARS TIE ANADIENSAT 33
description: MONTREAL, Jan., 8 (UPI)Buster Harvey's powerplay goal with less than seven minutes to play tonight allowed the Minnesota North Stars to earn a 33 draw with the Montreal Canadiens in the National Hockey League.

title: Leeds & Northrup Elects
description: The Leeds & Northrup Company has named David T. Kimball, 45 years old, as its president and chief executive officer, effective Feb. 1. He succeeds George E. Beggs Jr., 56 years old, who will become chairman, a new post. Mr. Kimball is now president of Tasker Industries.

title: Housing Aide Named
description: Irving Wise, director of management for the New York City Housing Authority since 1960, was named yesterday to be general manager. Mr. Wise, 61 years old, who has been with the agency for 33 years, succeeds Marcus Levy, who is retiring after 35 years. He will be repsonsible for the supervision and management of the authority's 194 public housing developments and for construction programs.

title: ExCoach Is Leaving With Honor
description: When Southern Methodist University dismissed Hayden Fry as head football coach at the end of last season, most of, the Mustang players and many students and alumni protested in vain. Fry's last S.M.U. team had a 74 wonlost record and many persons felt he was treated unfairly. But Willis M. Tate, chancellor of S.M.U., stood by the decision and Fry is now the coach at North Texas State. However, Chancellor Tate yesterday announced that an anonymous S.M.U. fan had established a scholarship fund honoring Fry. The first donation was $20,000 to recognize Fry's sense of sportsmanship and fair play.

title: Antiaircraft BuildUp Is Reported by Hanoi
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 8 (AP)North Vietnam announced today that hundreds of antiaircraft units had been formed by the home guard and militia in the Hanoi and Haiphong regions.

title: 5,000 Autograph Hunters Force Redskins to Retreat
