description: A 23yearold man was arrested in Indianapolis yesterday in the stabbing murder of Roseann Quinn in her West Side studio apartment last week. The police were led to him through a friend wholike the suspecthad been seen with Miss Quinn the night she was slain.

title: DRTHOMAS S. SEXTON
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 9 Dr. Thomas S. Sexton, a senior vice president and a director of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his office. He was 59 years old and lived in Granby.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number, yesterday was:

title: ARTHUR G. PRANGLEY
description: SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 9Arthur G. Prangley, vice president and corporate counsel of the Amerace Esna Corporation, New York, died Friday in the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 67 New England Avenue here.

title: Man Killed as Store Falls
description: JACKSONVILLE, N. C. Jan. 9 (UPI)The rear of a sprawling onestory department store collapsed yesterday, killing one man and injuring two others. The dead man, Perry Lee Guthrie, 28 years old, was an employee of the Furniture Fair store.

title: TRAIN CUTS HINTED IN AMTRAK BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) The Nixon Administration is formulating an Amtrak budget for the next fiscal year that will force cancellation of many longdistance passenger train routes unless Congress interyenes.

title: Protests on Monopoly Street Names May Cause Sponsor to Return to Go
description: A tidal wave of support for the preservation of Baltic and Mediterranean Avenues appeared to be gathering yesterday, two days before a vote by the Atlantic City Commission on a proposal to rename the thoroughfares that have been fixtures on Monopoly boards for 37 years.

title: Netherlands Bars Proposal To Recall Envoy From U.S.
description: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 9 (Reuters)A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry today rejected the proposal put forward yesterday by 120 leading citizens that the Dutch Ambassador in the United States be recalled as a protest against the American bombings in Vietnam.

title: Top Japanese Diplomat Seen as Envoy to China
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9 (UPI)Heishiro Ogawa, a longtime diplomat who currently heads the Foreign Ministry's Foreign Service Training Institute, is most likely to be named Japan's first Ambassador to Communist China, the Kyodo news agency said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Two athletes who spurned huge bonuses from the California Angels to continue playing college ball were expected to be among the top selections in baseball's annual fretagent draft here today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Court Refuses Admission to Bar Because of a 1955 Homosexual Arrest
description: The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has denied admission to the bar to a 47yearold homosexual who 16 years ago was disbarred in Florida after his arrest on a sodomy charge.

title: Plan for E. 51 st St. Bridge Stirs a BigBusiness Feud
description: A public dispute between two bigbusiness neighbors on Park Avenue will come up in private before the Board of Estimate today  amid hints that the board will try to avoid an immediate decision.

title: Big 6' Cities Seek State Crime Funds
description: Top police officials from the state's six biggest cities gathered at Police Headquarters here yesterday in preparation for an intensive lobbying effort for money from Albany for local law enforcement.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Order by Pentagon Bars Comment on Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Pentagon has forbidden all Department of Defense employes, civilian and military, to comment on the resumption of the Vietnam peace negotiations.

title: A 200M.P.H. Lap at Indy 500 is in Sight
description: This looks like the year of the 200milesanhour lap at Indianapolis, and one of Dan Guerney's Olsonite Eagles may be the first to clock it. The 57th running of the Indianapolis 500 on May 28 will be interesting also for the competitiveness of the field. With the mailing out of entry forms for the million  dollar race, a quick survey shows at least 38 cars on st age, more than enough to fill the traditional 33 starting positions. By the April 15 deadline, entries are expected for perhaps 75 cars; from that field 33 starters will be qualified.

title: Soviet Article Reassures Indians
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9A Soviet journal specializing in Far Eastern affairs has moved closer than ever to endorsing India's position in the Indian border dispute with China, according to Indian officials here.

title: Russians Report Brief Conversion of Hydrogen Gas Into Metal While Under Explosive Compression
description: Soviet scientists have reported converting the gas hydrogen, very briefly, into a metal. The conversion occurred, they say, under explosive compression at 2.8 million times atmospheric pressure at sea level.

title: TV: Heroin Addicfion in the Newborn
description: The Littlest Junkie will be shown on WABCTV tonight at 7:30. Written and narrated by Geraldo Rivera, the newsman, the halfhour special report is about heroin addiction in infants born of addicted mothers. It? is subtitled, with chilling irony, A Children's Story.

title: DETROIT IN ATTACK ON CLEANAIR ACT
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9Two automobile makers opened sharp attacks today on Federal pollution control standards set for 19751976 cars.

title: Retailers See Electronic Aids
description: A young retailer, C. Robert Gilberg of Joseph's Department Store of Fremont, Ohio, paused uncertainly yesterday morning at the entrance to the retail exhibit floor of the New York Hilton Hotel. In order to decide which exhibit booths to visit, he had to decide first on his priorities of interest.

title: Athens Accuses 13 Civilians Of Plot to Kidnap U.S. Envoy
description: ATHENS, Jan. 9The Government tonight ordered a special courtmartial for 13 civilians charged with conspiring to commit crimes, including the kidnapping of Henry J. Tasca, the United States Ambassador to Greece.

title: DR. JOEL SCHWEIG, A DERMATOLOGIST
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 9Dr. Joel Schweig, a dermatologist in New York for 48 years until his retirement, in October, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 305,300 shares of Alexander's,. Inc., common at $9 a share was made yesterday by Morgan Stanley and Oppenheimer & Co. The company's stock closed at 9, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Buyers Get $ 1.2Million Award In BurglarAlarm Controversy
description: More than 3,400 consumers who were allegedly cheated by a burglaralarm company will get either an immediate refund or a cancellation of their debt in a settlement announced yesterday by Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson, Justice Edward Thompson and United States Attorney WhitNorth Seymour Jr.

title: URT. CONDEMNS SCHOOLS' REPORT
description: The United Federation of Teachers yesterday condemned the report of the Fleischmann Commission as serving no useful function and paving the way, for the destruction of the New York City public school system.

title: SOVIET TO SET UP POLLUTION AGENCY
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9  The Soviet Union announced today that it would set up a national environmental protection service to monitor air and water pollution throughout the country.

title: U. S. Letting Pilots Pursue Foe North of 20th Parallel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Pentagon officials said today that American pilots were being permitted to cross the 20th Parallel in pursuit of North Vietnamese jets that attempt to attack United States B52's and other bombers operating south of the 20th Parallel.

title: COMMODITY UNIT GETS MORE POWER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) On a 54 vote the Supreme Court today broadened the authority of the Commodity Exchange Commission to consider antitrust claims against members of the nation's commodities exchanges.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: PRIZE BEHAVIOR FIRST AT BOWIE
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 9 (UPI) Prize Behavior took the lead shortly after the start and led the rest of the way to win the feature race for 3year old fillies today at Bowie.

title: Jury Selection Will Open RaceFixing Trial Today
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Jan. 9 Jury selection will begin here tomorrow morning in the Sullivan County Court of acting County Judge Robert C. Williams for three men indicted for allegedly attempting to fix the May 11, 1972, superfecta at the Monticello Raceway.

title: Nixon at 60: Quiet and Contemplative
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9President Nixon quietly observed his 60th birthday today in continued silence and isolation so far as his conduct of the Vietnam War is concerned.

title: Penn Central Strike Is Put Off 30 Days; L.I. Talks Collapse
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Friday's deadline for a strike against the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company was postponed for 30 days today at the request of Assistant Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr.

title: Rockefeller to Seek More Aid for Arts
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9Governor Rockefeller will seek a $2million to $3million increase in state aid in the coming year for financially troubled museums, orchestras, ballet and theater companies and other cultural institutions, legislative sources said today.

title: Dempsey Named Coach
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 9 (AP)Ray Dempsey, an assistant coach at Bowling Green, was named head football coach today at Youngstown State University, succeeding the late Dwight Beede.

title: Pipe Bombs Shake 2 SexFilm Houses; 50 Patrons Routed
description: Incendiary devices were exploded late last night at two midtown movie houses specializing in sex films. No injuries were reported, the police said, but some damage to the theaters occurred.

title: Women's Pro Head Sues U.S.L.T.A. as Unfair
description: In what might become a precedentsetting case testing the power of tennis associations to ban players from sanctioned tournaments, Mrs, Gladys Heldman filed a complaint yesterday against the United States Lawn Tennis Association, charging six counts of antitrust violations and unfair competition.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: U.S JURY INDICTS JERSEY DEMOCRAT
description: NEWARK, Jan. 9A Federal grand jury today charged John A. Kervick, New Jersey State Treasurer from 1958 until 1970, with having extorted $113,200 from a consulting engineering concern that did business with the Delaware River Port Authority, the New Jersey Highway Authority and the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

title: Dempsey Named Coach
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 9 (AP)Ray Dempsey, an assistant coach at Bowling Green, was named head football coach today at Youngstown State University, succeeding the late Dwight Beede.

title: Power Plea Is Canceled
description: FAIRMONT, W. Va., Jan. 9 (AP)Officials of the Monongahela Power Company canceled today their request to one million customers in a fivestate area to reduce their use of electrical power voluntarily. A spokesman said that Monongahela had made arrangements to buy power from other nearby companies that will be enough to meet the expected peak loads.

title: MERCHANT IS ROBBED OF $200,000 IN GEMS
description: A midtown diamond merchant was beaten and robbed of more than $200,000 in unset gems yesterday by three men who forced their way into his office on the 15th floor at 62, West 47th Street after one of them posed as a mailman carrying a special delivery letter.

title: Syracuse Names Schulte Dean of Newhouse School
description: Henry F. Schulte, author and former United Press International correspondent and editor, was appointed today dean of the Syracuse University S. J. Newhouse School of Public Communications, effective Monday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: MORE CUTBACKS IN ROUSING LISTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)  The Administration has broadened its crackdown on subsidized housing by cutting off new applications for cutrate housing loans for lowincome rural families.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: DEMOCRATIC CLUB INDUCTS PARLEY
description: James A. Farley, known to many fellow members of his party as Mr. Democrat, was elected an honorary life member of the National Democratic Club at a dinner last night marking the last hurrah of the party's ornate clubhouse.

title: Laotian Peace Talks Wane as Communists Step Up Military Efforts
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 9With Communist forces on the offensive in several key parts of Laos, negotiating teams from the two warring sides held another fruitless meeting today and hopes for a peace settlement appeared to have receded.

title: People in Sports: Starr Ends Ties With Football
description: Bart Starr, the quarterback who led the Green Bay Packers to the heights of National Football League supremacy in the nineteensixties, announced yesterday he was leaving professional football to concentrate on business and his family. The 39yearold Starr ended his playing career last summer because of recurring arm injuries. He spent the 1972 season as an assistant coach, sending in plays to the quarterbacks.

title: Helms Reported to Say China Nears Status of Superpower
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Richard Helms, the Director of Central Intelligence, has reportedly told Congress that China may be approaching the status of a superpower because of advances in weapons technology.

title: L.I. SAN AJUSED OF A RENT SCHEME
description: A Long Island realestate opaerator has been indicted in Brooklyn, charged with collecting rents from welfare clients living in buildings he did not own.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: PRODUCERS RAISE PRICES OF COPPER
Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: $18 Gifts to Neediest Stand for Life
description: The Hebrew word for life is chai. The two letters in chaichet, 8, and yad, 10add up to 18 because letters, in Hebrew, have numerical equivalents.

title: Suspect Seized in Indiana In Teacher's Slaying Here
description: A 23yearold man was arrested in Indianapolis yesterday in the stabbing murder of Roseann Quinn in her West Side studio apartment last week. The police were led to him through a friend wholike the suspecthad been seen with Miss Quinn the night she was slain.

title: Nixon's SelfMade Trap
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Even after all the bitter criticism of President Nixon's decision to bomb Hanoi during the Christmas holidays, there is still a fundamental philosophic difference here over both the bombing and the criticism.

title: New Books
description: All My Enemies; by Rosemary Harris (Simon &Schuster, $5.95). A novel of suspense.

title: Thais Expel 2 Americans For Desecrating a Buddha
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 9 (Reuters)  Thailand expelled two Americans today after they served six months in jail for desecration of a Buddha statue, the police said.

title: Senate Panel Criticizes Exchange SellRegulation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  A staff study of the Senate Securities Committee reported today that because of opposition by the New York Stock Exchange and inaction by the Securities and Exchange Commission, there was no effective means of controlling operations of market specialists.

title: Colbert Gets Slugger Award
description: HOUSTON, Jan, 10 (UPI)Nate Colbert, who tied a major league record with five home runs in a doubleheader last season, will receive the Eddie Dyer Slugger of the Year Award Jan, 26 from the Houston Baseball Writers Association. Colbert, a San Diego Padre, batted in 13 runs and had seven hits in the two games against the Atlanta Braves Aug. 1, 1972. He hit .250 for the season with 38 home runs and had 111 runs batted in.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A stabile designed by Alexander Calder for the Archives of American Art will be presented to two members of the Archives national board of trustees and their wives for outstanding service. The presentation will be made next Tuesday.

title: Saigon's New Chief Spokesman Hoang Duc Nha
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10When Hoang Duc Nha first proposed to his wife, Tam, her family vehemently opposed the marriage. He is only a poor engineer working in a Government office, he has no future, friends recall that her parents said at the time. They suggested a wealthy doctor instead. But she thought better of the tall, boyishly goodlooking Mr. Nha and agreed to the match she was right.

title: Penn State's 2dHalf Rally Sets Back Columbia, 6152
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Jan. 10Ron Brown scored 11 of his 13 points in the second half as Penn State rallied to beat Columbia, 6152, tonight.

title: Governor Asks $255 Million for Unexpected Costs
description: ALBANY, Jan, 10Governor Rockefeller sent the Legislature a deficiency budget today in which he requested $255.5million in spending authorizations for the current state fiscal year that were not anticipated when the 197273 budget was approved last April 1.

title: One Cantwell Indictment Is Dismissed by the Court
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10Mercer County Judge Samuel D. Lenox Jr. today granted a defense motion to dismiss one of three indictments against Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell.

title: SCRIBNER OFFER POSES LEGAL ISSUE
description: The Board of Education's effort to buy up the contract of School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has apparently run into a legal obstacle, heightening speculation that Dr. Scribner will remain in office until his contract expires on June 30.

title: Miles Kirkpatrick Quits Post as F.T.C. Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Miles W. Kirkpatrick, the Federal Trade Commission chairman who gave the agency a new consumer orientation and expanded antitrust policies, has resigned with almost four years remaining in his term.

title: Chess: Perplexity Can Turn Awry Enterprises of Great Pith
description: The average player is often perplexed by the apparently erratic approach toward pawngrabbingespecially in the openingon the championship level. At times no risk, however great, seems to be allowed to stand in the way of capturing that precious pawn; at other times no more than a barely discernible cloud on the horizon seems to be enough to stay the hand of even the greediest pawnsnatcher.

title: MiniCourses at Hunter High: Comic Books and Conversational Chinese
description: Melissa Singer and Karen Gumbs are lecturing on comic books this week. They have 11 students in their class of varying ages, and by the end of the week, the 13yearold teachers will have devoted something more than three hours to explaining the history and background of one of their favorite pastimes.

title: ONE KILLED, 6 HURT IN VILLAGE BLAZE
description: A woman tentatively identified as Estelle Baraz died yesterday in a fire at 53 West 11th Street that reportedly started when another tenant of the 15apartment building looked under a bed with a lighted match.

title: Tape Used in Effort To Prove Hijacker Is Feigning Insanity
description: A Federal prosecutor sought yesterday to use the recorded words of a confessed hijacker to convince a jury that the hijacker had devised one of the biggest hoaxes society has ever seen in leading psychiatrists to believe he was insane.

title: Senator Announces Inquiry Into Funds for Grumman
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)Charging there has been a clear evasion of the law, Senator Harry F. Byrd, Independent of Virginia, announced today a hearing by a Senate Armed Services subcommittee will be held next week to investigate 54million that he said the Defense Department had made in loans to the Grumman Aerospace Corporation.

title: 5 Groups Back Arbitration Bill As L.I.R. R. Talks Remain Off
description: Business and civic groups met In Mineola, L. I., yesterday to press for Federal legislation that could help end the Long Island Rail Road strike.

title: Family Blessings Spur $25 for Neediest
description: Richard and Margaret Gummere of 325 Riverside Drive sent $25 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in enormous gratitude for the blessings accorded them and their family.

title: 500 Killed, the Syrians Say; Israelis Term Report a Lie
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Government sources said today that Israeli raids in Syria on Monday killed more than 500 civilians, including many women and children.

title: Hearing Postponed On Bridge Proposal Over East 51st St.
description: The Board of Estimate agreed in executive session yesterday to postpone a hearing scheduled for today on an application to build a controversial bridge over East 51st Street.

title: Fleming Set for 4th Super Bowl
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 10There have been six Super Bowl games and Mary Fleming has played in three of them, earning $37,500 in prize money. He will play in his fourth on Sunday when Fleming's team, the Miami Dolphins, opposes the Washington Redskins in the Los Angeles Coliseum. Four Super Bowls will tie the record held by a former teammate of Fleming's, Herb Adderley of the Dallas Cowboys, who made $52,500 from those games.

title: Role of Banks in Federal Reserve System
description: Just what obligation do the nation's 13,933 commercial banks have to support the Federal Reserve Systemnot only with words, but with membership? Especially in the case of smaller banks, membership in the central bank often means a dollarsandcents cost to bank shareholders. The question is a live one. Some moderately large banks have pulled out of Federal Reserve membership in recent months in order to take advantage of liberal state laws and regulations that give bankers greater opportunity for profit in their daytoday operations.

title: Sports Nevvs Briefs
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 10Probus Management, Inc., a professional athletes' business agency accused of having failed to live up to the financial management contracts of 11 football players, was ordered today to open its books to the State Attorney General.

title: U.S. PUTS OFF PLAN FOR ABORTION FILM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) The Government has halted temporarily plans to distribute to public schools and colleges a controversial population film advocating legal abortion the Administration's top population experts said today.

title: Designer Grew Up in U.S., but Found Home in Togo
description: LOME, TogoThis sweltering seaport capital of a West African sliverstate is not one of the fashion capitals of the world, but it seems no one has told Beverly Majors. She works like she thinks it is.

title: Peak of Fear 29Hour Hijacking Ordeal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10They just told me they were going to start killing people and throwing them out the windows, the pilot recalled. So I went ahead and pushed the power up on the plane. I didn't think it would get off the ground.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Personal Finance
description: A wife can sometimes be a moneysaving asset on business trips, according to two recent court decisions. A United States District Court and a United States Court of Appeals have upheld two husbands who deducted expenses of their wives on business trips in making out their income tax returns.

title: Danish and Swedish Ships Try to Contain Oil Spill
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 10 (Reuters)A dozen Danish and Swedish ships using dispersants tried today to contain a fivemilelong oil slick less than 12 miles off the western coast of Sweden.

title: CHAPS ARE VICTORS OVER Q'S, 124111
description: DENVER, Jan. 10 (AP)Rich Jones and Bob Netolicky sparked the Dallas Chaparrals to a 124111 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Peace Groups Say They Have Permit For Capital March
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Representatives of peace groups have announced that they have obtained all the necessary permits for the planned March Against Death and for Peace in Vietnam scheduled for Inauguration Day, Jan. 20.

title: Eugene Klein to Sell Stock In National General Corp.
description: The American Financial Corporation announced yesterday that it plans to acquire additional shares of National General Corporation to bring its holdings up to about 43 per cent and that a tender offer to National General stockholders or merger of the two companies is expected to follow. American Financial, a diversified financial holding company with about $1billion in assets, said it will purchase about 1 million shares of National General from Eugene V. Klein, chairman of National General and other members of management.

title: The Screen: Dr. Phibes Rises Again
description: To recapitulate: when we last saw him (in The Abominable Dr. Phibes, released here in 1971), the abomininable Dr. Phibes was climbing into his wellappointed London tomb. The soundtrack orchestra was playing Over the Rainbow, and the doctor was preparing to awaitin a state of suspended animation that perfect conjunction of the moon with the other planets before rising again.

title: State Drug Panel Scored Scope of Governor's Plan
description: The chief counsel to the special state commission drugs sent Governor Rockefeller's staff a confidential memorandum last week outlining possible practical and constitutional flaws in the Governor's proposed drug laws and insisting that a distinction be drawn between the smalltime addict pusher and the bigtime drug dealer.

title: 6 Mayors Ask State for $200Million to Fight Crime
description: Asserting that street crime has become their No. 1 problem, the Mayors of the state's six biggest cities announced yesterday that they were seeking $200million from the state for local law enforcement.

title: CAUTION IS URGED ON COMMISSIONS
description: Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, said last night that Congress should move slowly and cautiously in any efforts to bring about freely competitive commission rates in Wall Street.

title: Music: Folk Star's Solo
description: Al Anderson, a singer and guitarist, illustrates some of the complexity of the recording business. Mr. Anderson who opened Tuesday evening at Gerdes Folk City, 130 West Third Street, is a fullfledged member of the group, NRBQ. But he also records as a solo performer for another recording label. Therefore, when he makes albums with NRBQ, he is not allowed to sing solo.

title: Brooklyn Diocese Issues Its First Financial Report
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn today issued its first financial report, showing total assets of about $60million  of which only $3million was said to be readily available.

title: State Drug Panel Scored Scope of Governor's Plan
description: The chief counsel to the special state commission on drugs sent Governor Rockefeller's staff a confidential memorandum last week outlining possible practical and constitutional flaws in the Governor's proposed drug laws and insisting that a distinction be drawn between the smalltime addict pusher and the bigtime drug dealer.

title: Vietnam G.I. Rabies Victim
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10 (AP)An American soldier, bitten by a dog in his barracks, died early today. He was they first United States serviceman to die of rabies in Vietnam, where the disease exists in epidemic proportions.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In Connecticut, the Goverhoes Commission on Tax Reform yesterday proposed re forms with the prospect that by holding to moderate increases in spending the state could continue to delay im posing an income tax for years.

title: LEGAL
description: NOTICE 15 HEREBY GIVEN THAT on December 15, 1972 the stockholders or Index 1 und, Inc., a Massachusells corporation, authorlzed the sale or substantially all of the assets or Index Fund, Inc. to Pilgrim Fund Inc., a Maryland corporation, and the dissolution of Index Fund, Inc. pursuant to the Business Corporation Law of Massachusetts.

title: MEATS AND EGGS UP SHARPLY HERE
description: Prices for meat, eggs and some vegetables in the city's supermarkets have jumped con siderably in the last month as the result of rapidly rising wholesale prices. But the average shopper's attitude seems to be: So what else is new?

title: Geothermal Energy Held A Vast World Reservoir
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10Energy experts from around the world met here this week and generally agreed that one of the most promising new sources of relatively nonpolluting power is the natural heat of the earth's coregeothermal energy.

title: JUSTICES AFFIRM BANKRUPTCY FEE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Anyone who wants to go into bankruptcy, no matter how poor, must pay the $50 in legal fees set by Federal law, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Program to Aid Kidney Victims Faces Millions in Excess Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Congress and the White House may have to decide whether the saving of 5,000 American lives each year is worth Federal outlays of $1billion annually.

title: CITY TOLD TO OUST 95 IN U.S. PROGRAM
description: The city was told yesterday by the Labor Department that at least 95 municipal employes hired under a Federally funded emergency employment program were ineligible and must be dismissed.

title: C. MERCER TEMPLETON
description: C. Mercer Templeton, a former song and dance man on Broadway and in vaudeville, died Tuesday at Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Maplewood, N. J.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 2 Americans Lend Homes for Talks
description: PARIS, Jan. 10 The two Americanowned residences in the Paris area where recent private Vietnam talks have been conducted were selected because members of the United States Embassy liked them and thought them big enough, their owners said today.

title: Arthur Daley
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 10The oldest surviving member of George Allen's collection of elderly citizens on the Washington Redskins is Jack Pardee. The trail blazer for the famed Over the Hill Gang had been Sonny Jurgensen, aged 38. As if he were really an old crock, however, Sonny cracked up during the season and left it up to Pardee to use his seniority in leading the Skins in their inexorable advance toward Medicare and the Super Bowl.

title: Art: First Part of Whitney Biennial
description: About threequarters of the first of three installments of the new biennial exhibition of American art at the Whitney Museumsuccessor to the Whitney annuals that have been held since 1932opened to the public yesterday in the garden floor of the museum at Madison Avenue and 75th Street. Still to come are the works that will fill the first, second, third and fourth floors of the museum.

title: KISSINGER AND TM CONFER A 3D DAY; NO PROGRESS SEEN
description: PARIS, Jan. 10  Henry A. Kissinger met for four hours with Le Duc Tho today on Vietnam ceasefire, and technical experts working on secondary issues held an allday session.

title: COALITION BACKS HOUSING SUBSIDY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10A coalition whose membership ranges from mortgage bankers to welfare mothers laid plans today for a drive against the Nixon Administration's suspension of Federal housing subsidies.

title: Program to Aid Kidney Victims Faces Millions in Excess Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Congress and the White House may have to decide whether the lives of 5,000 Americans are worth Federal outlays of $1billion a year.

title: Like a Colossus
description: No wonder Elliot L. Richardson took refuge in discreet silence when members of Congress, at his Cabinet confirmation hearing, asked substantive questions about his policy views. By now, he knows that policy in this Administration is the absolute preserve of Richard M. Nixon and the janissaries around him in the White House.

title: Records: Stockhausen
description: Karlheinz Stockhausen, Germanically messianic, has received a mixed press in America. His music, always avantgarde, has grown steadily further out over the last 20 years, which offends the conservatives. His apparent modishness and his unwillingness to give proper credit to his influences offend the progressives. And his calmly mystical selfconviction repels as many as it attracts.

title: MURPHY SHIFTING 97 OF HIS 110 MEN IN WALL ST. AREA
description: Commissioner Plans Report on Thefts of Narcotics Before End of Month Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that 97 of the 110 policemen assigned to the precinct covering the Wall Street area would be transferred as a result of an investigation of an alleged shakedown of street peddlers.

title: EUGENIA SODERBERG
description: Eugenia Soderberg, a Swedish novelist and journalist, died at her home here Tuesday night. She was 69 years old and lived with her husband, Dr. Hugo Perls, at 128 Central Park South.

title: Father Yanitelli Is Installed in Port Authority Post
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10  Governor Cahill today installed the president of the second best Jesuit college in the United States as a member of the Port of New York and New Jersey Authority. That is how Mr. Cahill referred to the new commissioner, the Rev. Victor R. Yanitelli.

title: People and Business
description: In the summer of 1968, there were headlines in the financial press when two partners and an employe of one of the Big Eight accounting firms were found guilty in Federal Court here of conspiring to issue false financial statements and of mail fraud. There were more headlines that fall when the accountants, with the firm of Lybrand, Ross Bros. & Montgomery, were fined a total of $17,000.

title: Raiders Top Blazers, 41, As Ferguson Gets 2 Goals
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 (AP) The New York Raiders, with a tough checking defense and two goals from Norm Ferguson, posted a 41 victory over the Philadelphia Blazers in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: Airline Crash Hearing Set
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UPI)A hearing into the runway collision of two passenger planes in which 10 persons died at O'Hare International Airport last month will open next Wednesday, the National Transportation Safety Board announced today. In the collision, a North Central Airlines DC9 struck a Delta Airlines Convair 880 while taking off in fog.

title: U. S. and Cuba at Odds on Hijacking Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The State Department said today that while the recent exchange of proposals with Cuba for a treaty to deter hijacking had produced some movement, unresolved differences remained.

title: Loopholes Seen in Plan to Prevent Overdeveloping Adirondack Park
description: POTSDAM, N. Y., Jan. 10An influential citizens group charged at a hearing here tonight that there were dangerous loopholes in the proposed plan to protect the vast Adirondack Park that could allow developers in through the back door.

title: Magic Magic Mountain Yields Gold for Swiss's Wand
description: LONDONDERRY, Vt., Jan. 10  They laughed at Hans Thorner when he opened his Magic Mountain ski center late in 1960.

title: Bills' Dooley Resigns
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 10 (AP) Jim Dooley resigned today as linebacker coach of the Buffalo Bills of the National Football League. No reason for the resignation was given.

title: Race Brawl on Ship In Southeast Asia Sept. 7 Is Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)  A previously unreported racial brawl aboard a Navy ship in Southeast Asia has resulted in charges against 10 marines, the Marine Corps has disclosed.

title: Britons Meet East Germans
description: LONDON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)Britain has been in contact with East Germany in the last few days about arrangements for talks on diplomatic relations, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

title: Booth Papers Agree to Buy Parade Publications
description: Booth Newspapers, Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed in principle with the Whitney Communications Corporation to acquire Parade Publications, Inc., publishers of Parade magazine.

title: Ban on Midtown Taxi Cruising Sought to Meet Pollution Curb
description: A ban on taxicab cruising in midtown and downtown Manhattan, as well as severe restrictions on parking in the busiest areas of the city, will be proposed today by state and city environmental authorities as the only ways to meet Federal air pollution standards here by the 1977 deadline.

title: British Civil Servants Protest Heath's Wage Freeze
description: LONDON, Jan. 10  Thousands of Government employes, including clerks and secretaries in Prime Minister Heath's own Cabinet Office, stopped work today to hold meetings and rallies protesting pay losses they are suffering under Mr. Heath's 90day wage and price freeze.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: SLAYING SUSPECT RETURNED TO CITY
description: John Wayne Wilson, the suspect in the West Side murder last week of Roseann Quinn, was flown in from Indianapolis yesterday afternoon and charged with homicide.

title: Amer. Hockey League
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Fire in Financial District Injures 6, Ruins 3 Stores
description: A smoky, twoalarm fire destroyed a shoe store, a women's apparel shop and a stationery store on the streetlevel floor of a 32story office building in Manhattan's financial district yesterday afternoon, injuring six persons.

title: Books of The Times
description: D'ANNUNZIO. By Philippe Jullian. 366 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $12.95.

title: Whitehead Asserts Nixon. Bill Does Not Seek to Curtail Television Freedom
description: Clay T. Whitehead, the 34yearold director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, sent shock waves through some segments of the broadcasting industry last month when he condemned Ideological plugola and elitist gossip in network news programs and warned that station managers and network officials who fail to correct imbalance or consistent bias in the networks or who acquiesce by silencecan only be considered willing participants, to be held fully accountable ... at license renewal time.

title: Iowa State Aide Named
description: AMES, Iowa, Jan. HI (AP)Charlie Lyle, an assistant football coach at the University of Tampa, was named to a similar position at Iowa State today by the new head coach, Earle, Bruce. The 32yearold Lyle is the fifth member of Bruce's staff hired since the former Tampa coach accepted the top Iowa State job Jan. 3.

title: Blues Recall Merrick
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP)The St. Louis Blues recalled Wayne Merrick, a center, from. the Denver Spurs today to replace Fran Huck, who is out with the flu. Denver of the Western Hockey League is an affiliate of the Blues of the National League.

title: Dumbbell Victory
description: The Appellate Division, in a 3to2 ruling, has upheld the Civil Service test which asked two women audiovisual staff members at Hunter College to lift a 25pound barbell above their heads with one hand. The examiners justified the requirement on the grounds that the candidates' duties included handling 25pound projectors.

title: Advertising: Homelife Bow Due
description: TV Guide, with its 18 million circulation, one of the lowest costperthousand advertising rates in publishing and a 15cent cover price, is in for some competition from a little magazine with a similar format and a lower cost per thousand that will be given away free. And it is being bankrolled by a group of men with years of publishing and packaged goods experience.

title: PARTIES CRITICIZE RHODESIAN MOVE
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 10The Rhodesian Government's decision to close the border with Zambia has generated unexpectedly strong criticism by other political parties here.

title: Senator Hughes Suggests Delay in Confirmation of Nixon Cabinet Nominees So We Can Stop the War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Senator Harold E. Hughe raised today the possibility of an attempt to hold up Senate confirmation of President Nix on's new Cabinet nominees so we can stop the war.

title: CharterStudy Panel Is Briefed By Connor on Staten Island Visit
description: The state commission on revising the City Charter turned its attention to Staten Island yesterday, taking a bus tour led by Borough President Robert T. Connor, who told the members his borough was still young enough to straighten out its problems.

title: Sonics Discharge Nissalke as Coach; Assistant Promoted
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 10 (AP)Tom Nissalke was relieved of his duties as coach of the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association today and replaced by the assistant coach, Morris (Bucky) Buckwaiter.

title: Emperor's Screens Lent For Namban Art Display
description: Namban Art, an exhibition opening to the public today at Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, boasts a number of firstsfirst exhibition in the West of Namban art (Art of the Southern Barbarians), first exhibition outside Japan of several of the 76 objects on loan, first public exhibition anywhere of several others and, in all probability, the reception of the first work of art ever to arrive in a crate lined with purple velvet quite aside from the contents being on personal loan from Emperor Hirohito of Japan.

title: CENTRAL SERVICE HINGES ON PARLEY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10  The trustee of the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey will meet Friday with Governor Cahill in a move that could pave the way for continuing the carrier's passenger service past its scheduled termination on Jan. 21.

title: $350,000 in Gems Stolen From Altar Of Brooklyn Shrine
description: Two diamondstudded golden crowns and other jewels valued at $350,000 were reported stolen yesterday from an altar painting in a Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: New York Library Forms A Truman Memorial Fund
description: The New York Public Library has established a Harry S. Truman Memorial Fund to acquire materials relating to the life and work of the former President, who died last month.

title: Marijuana and Two Seized In Search of House Upstate
description: BIG FLATS, N. Y., Jan, 10 (AP)A search of a house in this community near Elmira resulted yesterday in the seizure of more than 64 pounds of marijuana worth $32,000, the state police reported.

title: Freight Rate Rise Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an annual freight rate increase of $27.7million for Southern trucking companies. The I.C.C. said the 1 to 3 per cent increase for truckers of the Southern Motor Carrier Rate Conference would be effective Tuesday.

title: Concern by Networks
description: In his Indianapolis speech and in a recent interview with editors and reporters of The New York Times, Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House's Office of Telecommunications Policy, has limited himself to broad generalities on overall broadcasting policy. Both his insistent avoidance of specifics and his coupling of the proposed communications bill with an attack on some aspects of television content have triggered, apparently with calculation, intense debates on the motives of the Nixon Administration.

title: U.S. Center Set Afire
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 10 (AP)  Arsonists set a fire early today in Amerika Haus, the. United States Government's cultural center, damage to hooks and furnishings was estimated at more than $30,000. Amerika Haus has been a frequent target of protests against the Vietnam war.

title: Phoenix Golf Loses Jamieson, Weiskopf; Play Starts Today
description: PHOLNIX, Ariz., Jan. 10 (AP) Jimmy Jamieson and Tom Weiskopf, United States World Cup teammates, had to withdraw from the $150,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today, but a strong field remained for tomorrow's start of the 72hole event.

title: Dolphins Switch Sites, Keep Field TopSecret
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 10 (UPI)Don Shula, trying to keep one step ahead of the unusually heavy rain and George Allen's spies, switched the Miami Dolphins practice session today to a secret site, somewhere in southern California,

title: B52 PILOT FACES MILITARY INQUIRY
description: OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 10 A 30yearold B52 pilot and crew commander is facing a possible courtmartial on a charge of refusal to fly a combat mission over North Vietnam, the United States Strategic Air Command headquarters here said today.

title: MORE COMPANIES LIFT COPPER PRICE
description: Several United States and Canadian copper producers announced yesterday that they were following the lead taken Tuesday by the Phelps Dodge Corporation in increasing the price of copper by 2.5 cents pound.

title: Monticello Handle Down
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10 (UPI)The average daily handle at Monticello Raceway's fallwinter meeting fell by more than $64,000 a night, the State Tax Department announced today. Commissioner Norman Gallman said the track had an average handle of $334,257 for its 36day meeting last year, compared with an average handle of $398,494 for the 15day meeting in 1971. The total handle for the 1972 fallwinter meeting was $12,033,261, compared with $5,977,410 in 1971. State revenue was $850,932 compared with $418,037 in 1971, Gallman said.

title: GUARDS AT TOMBS ACCUSED IN RISING
description: Faced by rioting inmates at the start of the October, 1970, disturbances in the Tombs, a number of correction officers retreated, according to Charles McElhone, an assistant deputy warden, despite his pleas to back us up.

title: Business Briefs
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Directors of the H. J. Heinz Company today approved management proposals divesting the food processor of certain foreign operations, including all of its Mexican assets, and withdrawing from direct farming activities conducted by an Oregon subsidiary.

title: A.T.&T. Stock Touches Highest Level Since '69
description: American Telephone, selling at its highest price since 1969, served as the star yesterday of a rather skittish stock market.

title: Laotians Government Troops Quit Strategic Saravane
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 10The southern Laotian town of Saravane was abandoned by Government troops yesterday in the face of a crushing Communist artillery barrage, military sources here reported today.

title: Music: A Pianist's Feat
description: A young pianist who plays Beethoven's Diabelli Variations as capably as Etsuko Tazaki did on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall is, in one sense, not going anywhere: She is already there. The Tokyoborn pianist, a graduate of the Juilliard School who has been winning prizes on the international contest circuit in recent seasons, gave the famously difficult variations on Diabelli's waltz a technically deft, rhythmically propulsive and formally lucid performance.

title: Swede Takes Ski Race
description: TRENTO, Italy, Jan. 10 (AP)  Thomas Magnusson of Sweden today won the 30kilometer ski race, the second event of an international crosscountry week at the Alpe de Siusi winter resort. His time was 1 hour 18 minutes 46.3 seconds. He took the 15kilometer opening event Monday.

title: Retailers See a Strong, but Difficult, 1973
description: As the end of the 1972 fiscal year nears on Jan. 31, merchants from around the country expect a strong retailing year in 1973 that will be burdened by rapidly rising expenses that they cannot pass on because of price controls.

title: Peak of Fear: 29Hour Hijacking Ordeal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 They just told me they were going to start killing people and throwing them out the windows, the pilot recalled. So I went ahead and pushed the power up on the plane. I didn't think it would get off the ground.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Council Takes Peace Stand
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 10 (UPI) The City Council voted yesterday to urge Congress to cut off funds for the war in Indochina if peace is not reached by Jan. 20. The council has a 5to4 Republican majority.

title: F.B.I. to Revive Government Liaison
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, continuing his reorganization of the bureau, has reestablished a unit for maintaining an intelligence liaison with other key Government agencies.

title: Diamond Merchant Robbed Of $60,000 in Unset Gems
description: A 45yearold diamond merchant was forced into a Lower East Side hallway yesterday afternoon and robbed of a pouch that he said contained $60,000 worth of unset gems, the police reported.

title: 5 OFFICIALS NAMED IN BRIBERY CASES
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10  Five public officials from Monmouth and Ocean Counties were indicted today on charges relating to bribery or illegal acceptance of money.

title: A New York Antipoverty Worker Would Transfer Some Poor Jews to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 10S. Elly Rosen, executive director of the Association of Jewish Antipoverty Workers in New York, said here today that he would recommend that his organization sponsor a program to move some of New York's poor elderly Jews to Israel.

title: Milk Aide Says it Lawyer For Nixon Sought Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10President Nixon's personal lawyer has been identified in court papers as a major solicitor of the dairyfarm campaign contributions that followed the Nixon Administration's decision to raise milk price supports.

title: Pennsy Lawyer Stresses Need For Cash to Keep Trains Going
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 (AP)A lawyer for the bankrupt Penn Central Company said today that America's largest railroad may have to stopits trains at the end of February if it does not get some fresh cash.

title: Cahill's Transit Plan
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10For almost two decades as Governors of New Jersey sped along the New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway they have tried to figure out ways to tap the bulging profits of the authorities that run the two toll roads. They saw the tolls as a transportation revenue bonanza. Governor Robert B. Meyner, a Democrat, attempted to use the toll road profits for capitalizing other general transportation ventures, including other highways, in 1954, but his proposal was defeated by the Legislature.

title: BOSTON BANK LIFTS OPERATING EARNINGS
description: The First National Boston Corporation, the largest bank in New England and the parent company of the First National Bank of Boston, reported that operating earnings increased 4.3 per cent in 1972 to $42,1million, or $3.51 per share, from $40.4million, or $3.37 per share the year before.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: VERNON, N. J., Jan. 10A lot has happened since 8yearold Tom Donahue first ran as a thirdgrader at Brooklyn's Holy Name Grammar School. But something that happened that first year set the trend for the future.

title: Colbert Gets Slugger Award
description: HOUSTON, Jane 10 (UPI)Nate Colbert, who tied a major league record with five home runs in a doubleheader last season, will receive the Eddie Dyer Slugger of the Year Award Jan. 26 from the Houston Baseball Writers Association. Colbert, a San Diego Padre, batted in 13 runs and had seven hits in the two games against the Atlanta Braves Aug. 1, 1972. He hit .250 for the season with 38 home runs and had 111 runs batted in.

title: WATERGATE TRIAL HEARSHUNT OFFER TO PLEAD GUILTY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10E. Howard Hunt Jr., a onetime White House consultant who became a central figure in the Watergate affair, offered today to plead guilty to charges that he conspired to spy on the Democrats last year.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: King Timahoe, an Irish Setter, Makes White House His Domain
description: King Timahoe, Pasha and Vicky are probably the least publicized residents of the White House, but they are among the most popular, according to Traphes Bryant, kennelman at the White House from 1960 until he retired last March. Bryant was guest of the Dog Fanciers Club members at their luncheon in the McAlpin Hotel yesterday. Vicky, a miniature poodle, and Pasha, a Yorkshire terrier, are longtime pets of President and Mrs. Nixon. King Tim, however, didn't make his appearance until 1969, just after the President was inaugurated. The Irish setter was a gift of the White House staff.

title: 180Million T.W.A. Case Against Hughes Is Upset
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Howard R. Hughes, the mysterious billionaire recluse, won a stunning $180million victory over the airline he once controlled, Trans World Airlines, in the Supreme Court today.

title: 50 Killed in Tornado in Argentina
description: SANTA FE, Argentina, Jan. 10 (Reuters)  At least 50 people were killed and 300 injured today when a tornado cut a 300yard wide swath through the farming town of San Justo, the police reported.

title: LEGISLATURE GETS DRUGPUSHER BILL
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today formal bills for increasing drugtraffic penalties that were true to his controversial demand for drastic punishment, including mandatory life sentences for drugdealers and drugusers who commit violent crimes.

title: Nets End Cougars' Winning Streak at 11
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 10The New York Nets, with a patched backcourt, halted the Carolina Cougars' 11  game winning streak, the longest of the American Basketball Association season, in a 10593 upset tonight at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Lyn Lary, Yankee Shortstop; In Major Leagues 12 Years
description: DOWNEY, Calif., Jan. 10 (UPI)  Lyn Lary, a Yankee shortstop who later played for the Red Sox, Senators, Browns, Indians, Dodgers and Cardinals in a 12year majorleague career, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old. His widow, Mary, and a son, Tom, survive.

title: Zooming Food Prices
description: The almost incredible jump in wholesale food prices last month is a serious setback to the Administration's antiinflation program. Even though special factors helped account for the December leap of 5.2 per cent in the food index, the sharp upward trend of wholesale food prices through all of the last quarter and the belatedness of Administration moves to expand 1973 food supplies indicate that this will be an expensive year at the supermarket.

title: Woman, 71, Killed in Fire; Queens Restaurant Burns
description: A 71yearold woman was killed in a fire in her Upper East Side apartment last night.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Japan's Envoy Is in Peking
description: TOKYO, Jan. 10 (UPI)Japan's first minister to Communist China, Yuichi Hayashi, arrived in Peking today to assume his post, The Kyodo news agency, in a dispatch from Peking, said that Mr. Hayashi was met at the airport by Chinese Foreign Ministry officials. He will serve as charge d'affaires until an ambassador arrives. Chinese charg d'affaires is enpeeled to arrive in Japan shortly.

title: N.C.A.A. PUNISHES 4 OF ITS MEMBERS
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Council placed Centenary College of Shreveport, La., on indefinite probation today and declared ineligible for varsity competition five of Centenary's basketball players, including Robert Parish, 7foot freshman who was recruited by many colleges last year.

title: City Fears U.S. Freeze on Subsidies May Cut Out Neighborhood Programs Budgeted for $110Million
description: City officials expressed grave concern yesterday over the possibility that, neighborhood programs budgeted for $110million for the fiscal year beginning July 1 would have to be terminated because of the recently announced freeze in Federal subsidies.

title: Milk Aide Says a Lawyer For Nixon Sought Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10President Nixon's personal lawyer has been identified in court papers as a major solicitor of the dairyfarm campaign contributions that followed the Nixon Administration's decision to raise milk price supports.

title: Farm to Supermarket, Egg Is a Victim of Inflation
description: Up, up and away the prices go. Eggs, traditionally a means to stretch the grocery budget, are now giving consumers one more reason to grumble about the toll of inflation.

title: Administration Shifts On Hijacking Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)Apparently reversing a position it took a week ago, the Nixon Administration said today that it ddi not believe that a mandatory death sentence should be imposed for coldblooded, premeditated crimes including plane hijackings.

title: Tougher Sentencing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Some people are saying Governor Rockefeller goes too far in wanting to lock up every drug dealer forever. Some say President Nixon's Justice Department shows too much love for the noose in asking Congress to bring back the death penalty, even for hijacking.

title: Hiring of ExAddicts Is a Duty, Companies Tell Rights Hearing
description: Personnel directors for some of the city's largest private employers  among them New York Telephone, Consolidated Edison and Metropolitan Lifetold a hearing of the city's Human Rights Commission of plans and fears involved in the hiring of large numbers of rehabilitated drug addicts.

title: British Civil Servants Protest Heath's Wage Freeze
Connecticut Plan Seeks Equitable School Taxes
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 10A plan to make school expenditures less dependent on local property taxes is a key elementand one of the most controversialin the program unveiled here today by the Governor's Commission on Tax Reform.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOLMES SITE There is much eyeball  rolling and highorder emoting in The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes, the dramatized reading now unfolding Thursdays through Saturdays at the White Horse Inn, Second Avenue and 89th Street (TE 19750). The fun takes place in the tiny room on one side of this cheery Irish bar, a room that has been fitted with a stage that is the size of a big soapbox and long benches at which you may sit and drink or eat as you watch.

title: Leo E. Schwarzstein, Began Yonkers Ferry Line in '23
description: Leo E. Schwarzstein, founder and president of the Yonkers Ferry, which operated between Yonkers and Alpine, N.J., from 1923 to 1956, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Doctors Hospital on Tuesday. He was 74 years old and lived at 327 Lantana Avenue, Englewood, N.J.

title: James Henle, 81, Former Head Of the Vanguard Press, Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10James Henle, president of Vanguard Press from 1928 to 1952, died yesterday at Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: MISS PROELL FIRST IN DOWNHILL AGAIN
description: PFRONTEN, West Germany, Jan. 10 (AP)Annemarie Proell of Austria won her fourth World Cup downhill ski race of the season and second in two days today.

title: Gabe Paul of Indians Joins Yankees as a Part Owner
description: The New York Yankees identified their new owners yesterday and added a surprise: The syndicate was expanded this week to include Gabe Paul, who has been running the Cleveland Indians for the last dozen years.

title: Admiral Calls Gordon Rule Loner, Defends Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Navy's fifth highest ranking admiral described Gordon W. Rule today as a loner who would not work with the team and defended Mr. Rule's transfer to a minor job by describing the new cost as importaut.

title: KISSINGER AND THO CONFER A 3D DAY; NO PROGRESS SEEN
description: PARIS, Jan. 10  Henry A. Kissinger met for four hours with Le Duc Tho today on a Vietnam ceasefire, and technical experts working on secondary issues held an allday session.

title: Tests and Ailments Ignored
description: Recently, a patient went to his physician for a checkup. The physician apparently diagnosed the patient's ailment as anemia and prescribed an iron compound. He also ordered extensive, expensive medical tests involving liver pathology.

title: SNIPER ELUDES HUNT IN SUBWAY TUNNELS
description: A sniper on a Brooklyn street, who fired at a passing police patrol car in the Fort Greene section early yesterday, triggered a sixhour search of the streets, a nearby park and subway tunnels.

title: TV: Antonioni's China, Feast of Visual Contrasts
description: Tonight at at 9 o'clock the American Broadcasting Company is presenting a twohour news special called Michelangelo Antonioni's China. Produced for RAI, Italy's broadcasting network, it is less a probing documentary than a remarkable travelogue, in the best sense of that battered word.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Lincoln Repertory Plans Guest Year
description: Next season the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center will, for the first time, book a series of outside productions into the Vivian Beaumont instead of originating production within its own company. In making the announcement, Clarke Coggeshall, president of the Repertory Theater board, emphasized that this was an interim program for one year only, the 197374 season.

title: Supervised Citizens' Units Are Polled in Philippine Referendum
description: MANILA, Jan. 10  Citizens' assemblies newly organized throughout the Philippines by the Government began six days of meetings today to carry out a kind of national referendum on the martiallaw administration of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jesuit Sworn In as Port Commissioner

title: Nixon to Ask Extension Of WagePrice Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10White House sources confirmed today that President Nixon would ask Congress for a simple extension of the Economic Stabilization Act as it now reads. The law is the basis for the current wage and price controls.

title: KICKBACKS FOUN ONIEDICAL TESTS
description: An unethical but not illegal arrangement between many physicians and laboratories in which the doctors receive kickbacks for ordering unnecessary, expensive tests for patients has cost the city more than $4million a year in Medicaid payments, an audit by the city's Health. Department disclosed yesterday.

title: Eastern Hockey League
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: LAWMAKERS FACE CONSUMER ISSUES
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10The three main consumer issues facing the Legislature this year are registration of television repairmen and automobile repair shops, repeal of the prohibition on the advertisement of prescription drug prices and the licensing of debtcollection agencies, Peter M. Pryor, chairman of the State Consumer Protection Board, said today.

title: GOVERNMENT ACTS TO INCREASE FOOD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) The Administration announced today major new moves to spur increased production of meat and grains in the face of continued rising food prices.

title: South Korea Arrests 3 Critics Of President Park for Bribery
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 10 The Seoul district prosecutor's office announced today that three former opposition members of the National Assembly had been arrested and indicted for trial on charges of taking bribes from businessmen.

title: PRICES RETREAT IN AMEX TRADING
Wood, Field and Stream
description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West IndiesA soft wind came off the Caribbean, the stars of the Southern Cross were low on the horizon, and walking the long, white sand beach in front of the Royal Palms Hotel one could easily imagine the time when pirate ships and vessels of the Spanish and English fleets sent their long boats ashore in the evening to gather the huge green sea turtles that would provide them with much needed protein.

title: 400 ASIAN TRADERS TOLD TO QUIT KENYA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 10 (Reuters)The Kenyan Government told more than 400 Asian traders today to wind up their businesses here and leave the country by June 1.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF BEEF SET HIGHS
description: Live beef cattle again set record highs in prices of futures contracts on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday. The rising prices are bad news for housewives in terms of prospective, higher beef prices.

title: FRANK GIVES UP N.B.C. NEWS POST
description: Reuven Frank is being replaced as president of N.B.C. News by Richard C. Wald. Mr. Frank will stay on at the National Broadcasting. Company as an executive producer of news programs.

title: Chilean Senate Impeaches Allende's Finance Minister
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 10 (AP)The Oppositioncontrolled Senate impeached another Cabinet member tonightFinance Minister Orlando Millas, a Communist.

title: Notes on People
description: Spinach salad was served in the White House Blue Room Tuesday night during the dinner celebrating the 60th birthday of President Nixon, but the absence of iceberg lettuce from the menu did not mean, the White House said, that the Nixons had joined the lettuce boycott. Cindy Shumaker of Mrs. Nixon's press office said spinach was served for variety's sake. She added that They've had iceberg lettuce several times since the United Farm Workers Union announced the boycott in 1970.

title: INTEREST RATES ON BONDS CLIMB
description: A broad crosssection of interest rates climbed another notch yesterday, reflecting continued nervousness about inflation and the steps that the nation's money managers might have to take to combat it.

title: Defining War Crimes
description: The North Vietnamese Government has consistently charged that American military operations in Vietnam are war crimes, and this accusation plays a very important part in the way they describe the war, both to themselves and to others. In 1965 and 1966, when American bombing in North Vietnam began, their Government repeatedly threatened to try captured American airmen as war criminals, under the Nuremberg precedents, but in recent years this intention, if ever seriously entertained, appears to have been abandoned.

title: LEAFS TURN BACK ISLANDERS, 4 TO 2
description: TORONTO, Jan. 10 (UPI) Paul Henderson scored a pair of goals, the 200th and 201st of his National Hockey League career, to pace the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 42 victory tonight over the New York Islanders.

title: 180Million T.W.A. Case Against Hughes Is Upset
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Howard R. Hughes, the mysterious billionaire recluse, won a stunning $180million victory over the airline he once controlled, Trans World Airlines, in the Supreme Court today.

title: Their Master's Voice
description: The members of the Senate Armed Services Committee should not have been unduly surprised by Elliot Richardson's refusal to reveal his personal views on the recent carpetbombing of Hanoi. The nominee for the post of Defense Secretary has already demonstrated his capacity as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare to serve the President by unflinchingly abandoning opinions of his own. Having silently acquiesced in Mr. Nixon's policies on busing, he is now equally discreet on the matter of bombing, except to say that he approved of strikes against military targets in Hanoi. Adopting the precise idiom that has apparently been codified by Defense Secretary Melvin Laird as the allpurpose reply to all questions, Mr. Richardson said that he would not get into the negotiation trackthe new official way of saying that to discuss the bombing of Hanoi would hurt the talks in Paris.

title: DE LATORRE'S GUITAR BLENDS OLD AND NEW
description: Rey de la Torre has been giving recitals here since 1942, and if his hair has gotten somewhat gray his playing style has not changed nor has his interest in new music for the guitar. He appeared again here Tuesday night in Tully Hall, performing in the delicate, introspective manner that is distinctly his.

title: Navy Puts 1st Woman in Pilot Training
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  A fighter pilot's daughter with a B.S. in computer science and the Navy rank of lieutenant today became the first woman to be assigned to pilot training in the United States Navy.

title: VINCENT J. SALIERNO
description: NEWARK, Jan, 10Vincent J. Salierno, president of the Victory Optical Manufacturing Company, died of a heart attack last evening at St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 69 years old and lived in West Orange.

title: Press Curbs Charged By Journalism Group
description: The New York chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, tthe nanational journalism society, called on President Nixon yesterday to lift what it said were obstacles being placed in the way of freedom of the press.

title: Opel President Announces Record in 1972 Production
description: BONN, Jan. 10  Alexander A. Cunningham, president of the Opel Company, a General Motors subsidiary in West Germany, said today that 1972 was the most successful year in one hundred years of Opel history. Before building cars Opel produced bicycles, carriages and various household devices.

title: Colt Industries Increases Profit 28.1% in Year
description: Colt Industries, Inc., whose Crucible Steel Corporation business accounts for almost half of its total sales, last year had its best sales and earnings since 1969, reflecting mainly the improved performance of the steel division.

title: Bridge: '73 Regional Championship Is on Today at Grossinger's
description: The first Regional Championship of 1973 for players in the New York area begins today at Grossinger's, N. Y. Scheduled major events in this TriState tournament are: today, Men's and Women's Pairs, 2:15 and 8:30 P.M.; tomorrow, Masters Pairs, 2:15 and 8:30 P.M.; Saturday, Open Pairs, 2:15 and 8:30 P.M.; Sunday, Swiss Teams, noon and 5 P.M.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Rogers Voices Regrets To Lynch Over Protests
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)Secretary of State William P. Rogers has telephoned John Lynch, the Irish Prime Minister, to express regret over demonstrations staged against him in New York, the State Department said today.

title: Belfast Office Building Bombed; Machine Gunner Hits Army Post
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 10 (UPI)A 50pound bomb carried in a shopping bag exploded today in a downtown Belfast office building, blowing out the front of the structure and wrecking dozens of offices. There were no casualties, the police said.

title: WILLIAM RANSOM, TUFTS PROFESSOR
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 10William R. Ransom, who retired as a professor of mathematics at Tufts University in 1950 at the age of 75 after a halfcentury of teaching, died yesterday in the Winchester Hospital. He was 97 years old.

title: Thais to Allow U.S. Force To Stay After CeaseFire
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 10. (AP)The Thai Government has agreed to a United States request to keep American troops and aircraft in Thailand after a Vietnam ceasefire, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said today.

title: ANCONA RALLIES IN FINAL STRIDES TO CAPTURE 600
description: Bobby Ancona, who has been using the street in front of his house as a practice track in recent weeks, surprised Dennis Walker and Tom Ulan in the 600yard run last night at the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior championships.

title: Staten Island, Too?
description: LONDONI am surprised at how pleasantno, not pleasant but poetic, evocative, mysterious and extraordinaryall the new buildings in Manhattan are. Out of scale to what was, they make their own smoky relationship to what is. I am surprised that they lookabove allbeautiful. They are not judgeable in any terms but their own, which is all we ask of anything. Take me as I am, not as I was or was meant to be or might have been. It establishes a whole new list of qualities to implement judgment, to enhance life even on this granitefooted life raft. And New York is above all, alive. How could we have doubted it, even at this distance?

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Market Place: Bank Trust Unit Role Assessed
description: It is widely believed that the mutual fund money managers are the men who are quick on the trigger in Wall Street. Whenever a big block of stock changes hands, the reporters and market observers scurry to the record books to check out the holdings of mutual funds in an attempt to nail down the seller.

title: Tuesday Night Fight
description: Tokyo  Koichi Wajima, 152 pounds, Japan and Miguel de Oliverira, 153, Brazil, drew, 15 rounds; Wajima retained world junior middleweight title.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: MRS. ALFRED HOLTZ, ASIA SOCIETY AIDE, 54
description: Mrs. Betty Belt Holtz, assistant education director of The Asia Society and a leading member of its Indonesia Council, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 141 East 89th Street.

title: ILLINOIS WILL GET $1BILLION TOWN
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10Plans were announced today for a $1billion residential, commercial and manufacturing development on 3,900 acres 34 miles west of Chicago's Loop.

title: CETIS CONQUER ROKETS, 128107
Equity Financing
description: The Duke Power Company offered three million shares at $23 each. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., and the First Boston Corporation managed the underwriting group.

title: WATERGATE TRIAL HEARSHUNT OFFER TO PLEAD GUILTY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10E. Howard Hunt Jr., a onetime White House consultant who became a central figure in the Watergate affair, offered today to plead guilty to charges that he conspired to spy on the Democrats last year.

title: Mrs. Meir and Others to Go To Paris Despite Pompidou
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 10 (UPI) Premier Golda Meir's office said today that she has not changed her plans to visit Paris this weekend despite criticism by President Pompidou.

title: American ExNun Held By Bolivia as a Guerrilla
description: An American former nun, arrested in Bolivia for belonging to a subversive organization, has been held in jail for more than five weeks because she will not reveal the identities of other members of the clandestine group.

title: MURPHY SHIFTING 97 OF HIS 110 MEN IN WALL ST. AREA
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that 97 of the 110 policemen assigned to the precinct covering the Wall Street area would be transferred as a result of an investigation of an alleged shakedown of street peddlers.

title: All Aboard
description: Not even our generous planning for exasperatingly normal delays had prepared us for a twentyminute period during which four No. 104 buses, bound for the United Nations via 42d Street, but not a single No. 10 bound for downtown, stopped at 44th Street and Broadway. Giving up on public transportation, we hailed a cab and asked to be taken to Penn Station.

title: Atlantic County Engineer Gets 5 Years and Fine for Bribery
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Jan, 10 Patrick J. Doran, the former County Engineer of Atlantic County, was sentenced today to five years in prison and fined $10,000 for extorting more than $150,000 from contracting and engineering concerns that sought county business.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Italy's RadioTV Network Is Being Rocked by Political Dispute
description: ROME, Jan. 10The state radio and television network, one of Italy's most important centers of political power and patronage, is being rocked by disputes over who is in control.

title: G.M. CITES MS IN CLEANAIR CARS
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10The General Motors Corporation said today that antipollution equipment to meet tough Government rules for 1975 and 1976 would add $275 to a newcar price, the lowest estimate yet made in the automobile manufacturing industry.

title: Business Increases Spending Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Businesses expect to increase their spending on new plants and equipment 13 per cent in 1973, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The Dance
description: The New York City Ballet presented a new eveninglength version of George Balanchine's Harlequinade for the first time Tuesday night at the State Theater.

title: Rams' Rentzel Arrested On Marijuana Charge
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP)Lance Rentzel, the Los Angeles Ram wide receiver, was arrested today and booked for investigation of possession of marijuana for sale, a West Los Angeles police spokesman said.

title: Sniper's Roommate Questioned By F.B.I. and Then Released
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10$Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation questioned today the roommate of Mark Essex, the slain New Orleans sniper, but released him without charges.

title: Clayton Service Today
description: A memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Philip B. Clayton, founder of the Winant and Clayton Volunteers, will be held at St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street, today at 3:30 P.M. The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, retired Bishop of New York, will preside.

title: Sadat Under Fire
description: Clashes last week between students and police in Cairo reflect the dangerously deepening frustrations of a society caught in an unbearable but apparently unalterable nowar, nopeace situation which leaves Israel's forces sitting on the Suez Canal in control of a large chunk Egyptian territory.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: FANNY MAY SETS UP NEW MORTGAGE PLAN
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 10 (Reuters) The chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association, Oakley Hunter, announced today a new program for mortgage financing that would offer a convertible standby commitment for conventional mortgages.

title: Widow Wins a Million In New Jersey Lottery
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10 (AP)A 44yearold widow and mother of four sons won $1million today in the New Jersey lottery.

title: B52 PILOT FACES MILITARY INQUIRY
description: OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 10  A 30yearold B52 pilot and crew commander is facing a possible courtmartial on a charge of refusal to fly a combat mission over North Vietnam, the United States Strategic Air Command headquarters here said today.

title: 3d Teacher Strike in 4 Years Closes 650 Schools in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Jan, 10  This city's 650 public schools were closed today as members of the Chicago Teachers Union struck for higher wages, smaller classes and a shorter school year.

title: KICKBACKS FOUND ON HEALTH TESTS
description: An unethical but not illegal arrangement between many physicians and laboratories in which the doctors receive kickbacks for ordering unnecessary, expensive tests for patients has cost the city more than $4million a year in Medicaid payments, an audit by the city's Health Department disclosed yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) The resignation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation assistant director, Dwight J. Dalbey, who served the agency as legal counsel, was announced today. Mr. Dalbey emphasized in a letter of resignation to the acting director, L. Patrick Gray that the action had long been planned. In a handwritten postscript on the letter of acceptance, Mr. Gray told Mr. Dalbey, I have valued highly and appreciate deeply your advice and counsel.

title: New Version of Concorde Makes Its Maiden Flight
description: TOULOUSE, France, Jan. 10 (AP)  A new version of the Concorde, the FrenchBritish supersonic airliner featuring quieter, more powerful, smokefree engines, made its maiden flight today for an hour 45 minutes from Toulouse Airport.

title: U.S FIGHTER LOST IN RAID ABOVE DMZ
