description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 11 (AP)  A United States fighterbomber was lost over North Vietnam yesterday as American planes flew their heaviest raids over that country's southern panhandle area since bombing was halted above the 20th Parallel on Dec. 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Questions for Court and Country

title: Kansas Hometown Baffled by Violent End to Life of Mark Essex
description: EMPORIA, Kan., Jan. 10The 1967 edition of The ReEcho, the student yearbook of Emporia Senior High School, was just about the most prized piece of property in town today.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: CarInsurance Card Delay Signed

title: School Ousts Armed Pupils
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (UPIThe Board of Education has approved the expulsion of four pupils for carrying guns in school. The vote was 6 to 1.

title: Philadelphian Is Slain
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 (AP) Alvin Helmus, a 30yearold postal employe, was shot to death and his wife wounded in a fight last night with the superintendent of their North Philadelphia apartment building, the police report. William Heacock told Investigators he fired three times when Mr. Helmus tried to stab him with an icepick.

title: $100,000 in Gems Stolen From a Brooklyn Church
description: Two diamondstudded golden crowns and other jewels valued at nearly $100,000 were reported stolen yesterday from an altar painting in a Roman Catholic church in Brooklyn.

title: SLAYING SUSPECT RETURNED TO CITY
description: John Wayne Wilson, the suspect in the West Side murder last week of Roseann Quinn, was flown in from Indianapolis yesterday afternoon and charged with homicide.

title: MISS PROELL FIRST IN DOWNHILL AGAIN
description: PFRONTEN, West Germany, Jan. 10 (AP)Annemarie Proell of Austria won her fourth World Cup downhill ski race of the season and second in two days today.

title: Mud Blocks Yosemite Road
description: EL PORTAL, Calif., Jan. 10 (UPI)A steep cliff, weakened by two days of steady rain, collapsed last night, sending mud, trees and boulders crashing down on highway 140, just inside the boundary of Yosemite National Park. There were no injuries.

title: Ailing Right Ankle Will Keep Namath Out of the Pro Bowl
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 10Because of an ailing right ankle, Joe Namath of the New York Jets will not play for the American Conference allstar team in the Pro Bowl game in Dallas Jan. 21.

title: OIL IMPORT CURES ARE CHALLENGED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Citing shortages of heating oil, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, suggested today that it was time to end mandatory quotas on oil imports.

title: Yanks' New Owners Got Deal They Couldn't Refuse
description: The Yankees have so many new owners that Michael Burke, the general partner who will run the club, met most of them for the first time when the small army of executives and lawyers gathered for breakfast at the Carlyle Hotel yesterday.

title: People in Sports: Tiny Is Big AllStar Choice
description: Although he is considered small at 6 feet 1 inch and weighs only 155 pounds, Nate (Tiny) Archibald could hardly be overlooked by the panel of writers and broadcasters who pick the National Basketball Association's AllStar squads. The flashy guard of the Kansas CityOmaha Kings, who is leading the league in scoring and assists, was named almost unaminously to the West squad yesterday. Last season, even though he wound up as the No. 2 scorer in the N.B.A., he narrowly missed making it.

title: F.B.I. Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) The resignation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation assistant director, Dwight J. Dalbey, who served the gency as legal counsel, was announced today. Mr. Dalbey emphasized a letter of resignation to the acting director, L. Patrick Gray that the action had long been planned. In a handwritten: nostscript on the letter of acceptance. Mr. Gray told Mr. Dalbey. I have valued highly and ?? deeply your ad??.

title: Wide Tax Reform Asked in Connecticut, With Aid to Poor Towns and to Industry
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 10  The Governor's Commission on Tax Reform proposed broad changes today in Connecticut's tax structure, including a plan to take from the rich towns and give to the poor and another to inject new life into industries by lifting some of the burden of taxation from them.

title: Navy CoWorkers Recall Marked Change in Essex
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 10Mark Essex was described today as a happygolucky youth and a darned good sailor until two or three months before his discharge from the Navy two years ago for bad behavior.

title: EYPT CAPTURES 8TH SWIM CROWN
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 10 (AP)Egypt held its strong lead in swimming competition at the second AllAfrica Games today, breaking an African record to take the men's 800meter freestyle relay in 8 minutes 30.7 seconds.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: STAKES winning & stakes elacod broodmaro 1961 in foal to hold favorites, Also 2yr old filly by Dancers Image. This Mare, $100,000 the pair, Call Lew Plaskett at (401) 4679111.

title: JF MURPHY & SALT PLAYS TIGHT MUSIC
description: JF Murphy & Salt, a rock band that appeared for one night only at Max's Kansas City on Tuesday evening, makes tight, disciplined music. The sextet is dominated by Jack Murphy, who composes the songs and sings them at the piano in an effectively whiskyish barroom baritone. The other musicians, particularly the versatile Ron Allard, seem accomplished enough, and the arrangements sound on the whole inventive.

title: Rapist Denied Bail by Virginia Judge
description: LYNCHBURG, Va., Jan. 11 (AP)A judge denied bail here today to a black man twice convicted of rape and barred from his courtroom the suspect's attorney, William M. Kunstler.

title: Brutal Politics of War
description: PARISIt may prove historically correct that the Communist Tet offensive of 1968, a military failure, was indeed North Vietnam's first real victory over the United States in the Indochina war, and that the American bombing attack on Hanoi and Haiphong in December, 1972, despite demonstrable Communist losses in striking power, provided them a second major triumph.

title: li New Jersey Sports. An Offseason Game
description: When Bob Davis was a senior at Neptune (N. J.) High School he had a decision to mapplay basketball or football. He chose football..

title: Fly in the Milk
description: The story of the Nixon Administration's deal with the milk lobby continues to unfold. In 1971, the White House reversed the Agriculture Department and ordered an increase in the Federal price support for milk. The milk producers thereupon contributed more than $400,000 to the Nixon campaign chest.

title: J. C. Snead's 62 at Phoenix Leads Douglass by Stroke
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 11 (AP) J. C. Snead, a 30yearold nephew of famed Sam Snead, shot a brilliant eightunderpar 62 today for the firstround lead in the $150,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

title: Corona Case Goes to the Jury After Final Prosecution Plea
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 11A jury of 10 men and two women began deliberation at 11:40 A.M. today in the trial of Juan V. Corona, the 38yearold Mexican national charged with the largest multiple murder in the nation's history.

title: UNITAS IS EAGER TO KEEP ACTIVE
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Jan. 11 (UPI)Johnny Unitas, Baltimore's fading 39yearold quarterback, still wants to play football and the Colts are going to let him do thatfor somebody else.

title: Kings Set Back Warriors On Green's Free Throws
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 11 (AP) Johnny Green sank two free throws with 10 seconds remaining tonight to help the Kansas CityOmaha Kings beat the Golden State Warriors, 109108, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: TV: On Paar's Return
description: With a predictable barrage of publicity fanfare, Jack Paar returned to television this week and, at least in the course of his first three 11:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. shows, ran into trouble, both in overall content and in some important audience ratings.

title: Employers See No Effect On Rail Wage Talks Here
description: Two local railroad wage disputes in which Federal wage guidelines figured prominently will not be affected by the lifting of controls, managements said.

title: Dimout on Controls
description: President Nixon's decision to abolish mandatory controls over wages and prices in more than threequarters of the economy threatens a reversion to the donothing formula for combating inflation that preceded his New Economic Policy of seventeen months ago.

title: Nixon's New Cabinet.
description: The new Nixon Cabinet is up before the Senate these days for confirmation, and more often than not it is a painful sight. For the new boys, reaching for the most prestigious jobs of their lives, face the most searching Questions about what they really believe, and somehow they have to try to be faithful to themselves, to the President who has nominated them and to his policies, which they may or may not approve.

title: Dodgers Promote Wade
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 (AP) Ben Wade of Pasadena, Calif., was promoted today to the post or director of scouting for the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: MEYNER AND FIVE DEFEND CANTWELL
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, three retired general officers and two retired colonels testified today in the trial of James F. Cantwell that the retired major general was a man of unques tioned integrity, an outstanding officer and an excellent administrator.

title: Dublin Jails Leader of Sinn Fein For 6 Months as I. R. A. Member
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 11  Ruairi O'Bradaigh, president of Sinn Fein, the political movement of the Provisional Wing of the Irish Republican Army, was sentenced to six months' imprisonment today under tough new antiI.R.A. law adopted by the Irish Parliament last month.

title: REPORTER FREED IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11William T. Farr, a Los Angeles newspaperman who has spent 48 days in jail rather than reveal his sources for an article, was ordered released today in the interest of justice by AsIsociate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court.

title: MONEY EXPANSION REPORTED BY FED
description: Historically high rates of monetary expansion have been evident in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: Governor and Rose Meet To Discuss Fusion Mayor
description: Two longtime political foes, Governor Rockefeller and Alex Rose, the Liberal party leader, met privately on Wednesday to discuss the possibility of agreeing on a mayoral candidate, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Charles Flanders, 65, Dead; Drew Lone Ranger Strip
description: Charles Flanders, an illustrator and cartoonist who drew The Lone Ranger comic strip for 30 years for King Features, died Wednesday in Palma, Majorca. He was 65 years old and had lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: Problems Are Multiplying for Bickering Sonics
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 11 (UPI)The Seattle Supersonics owner, Sam Schulman, said today he hoped he could avoid another terrible blunder like his choice of Tom Nissalke as head coach of his National Basketball Association team.

title: S.E.C. Unit to Oversee Foreign Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Creation of a new Office of International Corporate Finance with responsibility for supervising security offerings by American companies to foreign investors as well as offerings by foreign issuers here was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Manila Reports Support for Marcos on Charter
description: MANILA, Jan. 11Government officials said today that a pattern of strong support for the martiallaw administration of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was emerging from the meetings of officially organized citizens' assemblies that began yesterday throughout the Philippines.

title: MANDATORY WAGEPRICE CONTROLS ENDED EXCEPT IN FOOD, HEALTH, BUILDING FIELDS; NIXON CALLS FOR VOLUNTARY COMPLIANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 President Nixon ended mandatory wage and price controls today  except for those involving food, health care and construction  and replaced them with a system relying mainly on voluntary cooperation. He also ended all Federal rent controls. The actions were effective immediately.

title: JetHijacking Jury Here Split 11.1 After 7 Hours
description: The jury in the jethijacking trial of Garrett B. Trapnell adjourned shortly after 6 P.M. yesterday after failing to reach a verdict in seven hours of deliberation.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: NEW YORK

title: INMATE TESTIFIES IN TRIAL OF GUARD
description: A state prison inmate who was in the Tombs during the October, 1970, rebellion there testified yesterday that a correction officer was locked in a closet by the inmates because he knew karate.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 12, 1973

title: Text of Nixon's Message and White House Summary on New Controls Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Following are the texts of President Nixon's message to Congress on Phase 3 of the wageprice control program, as transmitted by The Associated Press, and of a White House summary of the new program:

title: GHANAIANS TAKE AFRICAN SPRINTS
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 11 (AP) Alice Annum of Ghana broke her African record today in winning the 100meter dash at the second AllAfrica Games. Her time was 11.72 seconds. Rose Asiedua, also of Ghana, was second.

title: CreditMarkets Drop Offsets Early Gains
description: Disclosure of the Administration's Phase 3 economic plan sent bond prices into retreat yesterday, more than offsetting an early attempt to rally.

title: Harrods Plans to Open a Manhattan Store
description: Harrods, Ltd., the largest store in Britain, is planning to open a store in Manhattan that would be its first in the United States.

title: An Arab Campaign Is Damaging Israel's Standing in Black Africa
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 11 Israel's political standing in black Africa has been eroded sharply in recent months by a determined and wellfinanced Arab campaign to ostracize her in the continent diplomatically.

title: UTILITY GETS ASSENT FOR OVERHEAD LINE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11 (UPI) Orange and Rockland Utilities won approval from the Public Service Commission yesterday to overhead a 138kilovolt power line about five miles through Rockland County.

title: Monopoly Players Prevail in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 11For millions of Monopoly players, those sentimental highrollers of playmoney capitalism, today was a victory for tradition and the underdog for Mediterranean and Baltic Avenues.

title: Blood Reserve Lifted To a TwoDay Supply
description: Blood donations in the last few days have brought the Greater New York Blood Program's inventory to 2,400 pints, or two days' supply. The program makes blood available to 282 hospitals in New York City, in nearby counties in New York State and in northern New Jersey.

title: Fire Toll 6 in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (AP) A fire at the Rault Center Nov. 29 claimed its sixth victim yesterday when 26  year  old Lloyd Caldwell, an employe of New Orleans Public Service, Inc., died of burns. Three women died after jumping from a window on the 15th floor to the roof of a building eight stories below, a man was found dead in a 14thfloor hallway, and another woman who leaped died almost a month later.

title: Loews Directors Lift Dividend And Study Reinvestment Plan
description: Directors of the Loews Corporation again raised the quarterly dividend by the allowable amount, as proposed to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday preceding the board session. The dividend is 29 cents a share, payable Feb. 1. An increased quarterly of 28 cents plus a 6cent extra was paid last November.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Moscow Fears a Thaw
description: Pravda's senior foreign affairs commentator, Yuri Zhukov, is a frequent and familiar visitor in the West. Only a few weeks ago he made the latest of his many trips to this country and exchanged ideas with numerous Americans, When he is in Moscow he has full access to Western publications and their ideas. He is a veteran member of the Soviet Communist party whose loyalty and discretion have been proven over and over.

title: State's Drug Panel Backs a Hard Line Against Traffickers
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11The chairman of a special state commission on drugs said today that the commission would soon recommend to the Legislature new penalties for drug traffickers that were tough but not as severe as those being sought by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Truck Tonnage Off 5.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 5.9 per cent below last year.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Virginia Squires, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L. I., 8:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 10 (cable), 8 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 8:05 P.M.)

title: 112 Policemen Were Killed In Line of Duty Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the number of police officers killed on duty last year declined 11 per cent from 1971.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball SCORING LEADERS
description: More News Of Sports On Page 30

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Bugner Tapped, on Back, by Louis

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Nets Will Oppose Squires On Coliseum Court Tonight
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 11Julius Erving and the Virginia Squires are back at Nassau Coliseum tomorrow night to do battle with the New York Nets.

title: DISNEY TO ACQUIRE WRATHER HOTEL UNIT
description: Walt Disney, Productions, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Wrather Corporation's Disneyland hotel and related facilites in Anaheim, Calif., for 187,061 Disney common shares and $100,000 cash.

title: City Votes $391,000 for Project Despite U.S. Freeze on Funds
description: Despite a cutoff of Federal funds with which to build it, a brand new public housing project was started on its way by the Board of Estimate yesterday.

title: Hart, Schaffner & Marx Steps Up Profits
Hunt Admits All 6 Charges As Judge Bars Partial Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11E. Howard Hunt Jr., a former White House consultant, pleaded guilty today to all six charges against him in connection with the breakin and alleged bugging of the Democratic national headquarters.

title: Business Briefs
description: BONN, Jan. 11Worried about rising prices and swiftly expanding money supply, West Germany's central bank applied the credit brakes today, raising the key discount rate half a percentage point to 5 per cent, effective tomorrow.

title: UTILITIES BACKED ON A WIDER ROLE
description: WASHNGTON, Jan. 11The Securities and Exchange Commission approved by a 2to2 split decision today diversified investments by intrastate utility holding companies in nonutility ventures but within narrower limits than in the past.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 543
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (AP)The Soviet Union today launched Cosmos 543, the newest unmanned satellite in the topsecret series. Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported that Cosmos 543 was in an orbit with a high point of 206,9 miles, a low point of 131,1 miles and an angle of inclination of 65 degrees. The first orbit took 89,7 minutes.

title: Operating Earnings Lag ShownBy Bank of New York Company
description: The Bank of New York Company, Inc., a registered bank holding company consisting of eight banks including The Bank of New York, reported a drop in operating earnings to $26.67 million, or $4.24 per share, from $27.5million, or $4.34 per share in 1971. Net income for 1972 was down to $26.7million, or $4.26 per share, compared with $27.6million or $4.36 per share for the year before.

title: Slight Impact Seen On Rents in the City
description: President Nixon's abolition of Federal rent guidelines yesterday will have little immediate effect in New York City because many tenants are protected by city rent controls.

title: IRA KING WILKIN
description: NAPA, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP)Ira King Wilkin, former president and board chairman of the Zellerbach Paper Company, died Tuesday at his home here. He was 69 years old.

title: Train to Remain as Head Of Environmental Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) Russell E. Train said today that President Nixon had told him he will remain as chairman of the President's Council on Environmental Quality.

title: 9 Brooklyn Youths Indicted In Assault on Passengers
description: Nine Brooklyn youths were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn grand jury on charges of terrorizing passengers aboard a subway car late last month. The indictments accuse the youths of robbery in the second degree, grand larceny in the third degree and assault.

title: Knicks Set Back Hawks For 8th in Row, 122107
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 11 The famed team defense of the Knicks cooled off Pete Maravich and his hotshooting Atlanta Hawk teammates in the second half tonight at the Omni and New York scored its eighth straight victory, a 122107 decision which ended almost two years of New York frustration here.

title: Reagan Reports Surplus of $850Million
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 11Gov. Ronald Reagan told the California Legislature today that the state had an $850million surplus and that it should be returned to the people who paid it in the first place. A fight over his proposal appeared likely.

title: Screen: Lennon and Yoko in Imagine
description: The private lives of culture heros, like the private lives of most of us, normally offer a richer field for gossip than for enlightenment Imagine, the somewhat autobiographical new movie by John Lennon and Yoko Ono, doesn't mean to be gossip, nor even enlightenment, but rather a kind of meditation on how a couple view their privacy. Since the privacy of John and Yoko is very close to publicity, I suppose they may be excused a certain penchant for public demonstration in the ways they view how they live, what they think, what they feel above all, what they

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $684million, up 1 per cent from the year earlier $679million. Total retail store sales were about $7.5billion up 3 per cent from the year earlier $7.2billion.

title: Jet Liner Averts Crash
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 11 (AP)A Trans World Airlines jetliner with 82 persons aboard landed here safely yesterday after a part from one of its three engines fell from the plane over Colorado, an airline spokesman said.

title: Queens Man Loses Bid to Ban Abortions in City Temporarily
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court today denied an application for a temporary restraining order that would have prohibited abortions in New York City until a pending challenge to the legality of the 1970 New York state law is decided by the High Court.

title: Dissent in Manila
description: When President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law in the Philippines last September he promised to curb insurgency and other lawlessness, to end corruption and to create a new society based on social justice.

title: Wood Field and Stream: First Sea Turtle Farm
description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West IndiesIn centuries past, vessels sailing in Caribbean waters would put in at the Cayman Islands for fresh meat in the form of green turtles.

title: Ohio Parents Make Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)  Parents of Ohio parochial school children today appealed to Justice Potter Stewart to allow them to apply for tax credits of $90 a child. The Ohio law permitting tax credits was struck down last month as unconstitutional cry a threejudge Federal court in Columbus.

title: Bowa Signs Phils' Pact
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 (AP)  The Philadelphia Phillies signed Larry Bowa, shortstop, to a twoyear contract today. Terms were not annonnced.

title: Steelworker Fights Ban
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11 AP)Samuel Stokes, dropped rom the ballot as a candidate or vice president of the United teelworkers of America, said oday that he would seek an injunction in Federal court to stop the printing of ballots. Mr. Stokes, 59 years old, of Columbus, was disqualified Tuesday from the election because, the union said, he had not paid his dues for much of the last five years. Mr. Stokes denied it.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball
description: SCORING LEADERS

title: MARY J. KELLEY
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 11Mary J. Kelley, who retired in 1957 after teaching 47 years in the oneroom Little Red School House on Carter Street here, died Thursday in Stamford Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived at 129 Carter Street.

title: Canadian Exports Increase
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 11 (REUTERS) Canada's exports in November rose to $1.9billion from $1,5billion in the same month a year earlier, according to Statistics Canada today, Total exports, including reexports, Amounted to $2.021billion ih November, up from $1,6billion a year earlier.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The first Playbill 500 Awards to Broadway shows reaching 500 performances were presented to five hits yesterday at a luncheon ceremony at the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street.

title: Ballet Theater's Rollicking Toppelia
description: American Ballet Theater has a rollicking production of Coppelia. Since Enrique Martinez's staging succeeds so admirably in its goal of entertainment, certain questions could well go unasked. Still, it is curious that the pas de deux in Act I ends differently for each cast from year to year, that the male variations for Franz never seem exactly the same for each dancer and that Carla Fracci still has difficulties with the Scottish dance.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: B52 Pilot Who Refused Mission Calls War Not Worth the Killing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11The B52 pilot who balked at bombing North Vietnam after his 175th mission said today that he had refused because the goals do not justify the mass destruction and killing.

title: Parishioners Again Pray for Return of Church's Gems
description: Che corragio [what gall], muttered Giuseppa Augusta, the tears streaming onto her raincoat. What is this world coming to? First the Piet, now this. Who would do such a thing?

title: Redskins' Aide Reported Man the Eagles Want
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11McCormack is busy here working with the Washington offensive line that will oppose the Miami Dolphins in pro football's ultimate game at the Los Angeles Coliseum on Sunday.

title: Chile Rations Food And Calls Shortage Politically Inspired
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 11 (Reuters)The Chilean Government is to ration food in an attempt to overcome shortages that it charges have been created by political opponents in the hope of overthrowing President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Parishioners Again Pray for Return of Church's Gems
description: Che corragio [what gall], muttered Giuseppa Augusta, the tears streaming onto her raincoat. What is this world coming to? First the Piet, now this. Who would do such a thing?

title: KISSINGER AND THO CONTINUING TALKS
description: PARIS, Jan, 11While Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho continued their closeddoor talks a few miles away, both Saigon and the Vietnamese Communist delegations reverted to stiff demands today at the weekly formal peace talks here.

title: L.I. Marijuana Convictions Overturned
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 11A threejudge state appeals court has reversed the conviction of Lawrence Tate, a former executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, and his 19yearold daughter, Cindy, on charges of maintaining a criminal nuisanse, obstructing governmental administration and possession of marijuana.

title: Brazil Says That Her Forces Have Broken Up Guerrilla Unit
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11  Brazilian authorities announced last night that Government security forces had succeeded in virtually dismantling an urban guerrilla movement that at one time was held to be the bestorganized in Brazil.

title: One Small Step Starts Ski Tyros on the Way
Israel Lists 53 Killed in '72 In Combat and Terrorism
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 11 (AP)Nineteen servicemen and 34 civilians were killed in combat and terrorist incidents in Israel and in or at the borders of the occupied Arab zones during 1972, the military command reported today.

title: Teachers In Philadelphia Ordered to End Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  Judge D. Donald Jamieson of Common Pleas Court ordered public school teachers today to end a strike that has paralyzed the city's school system, but union leaders vowed to disregard the judge's ruling.

title: J. C. Snead's 62 at Phoenix Leads Douglass by Stroke
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 11 (AP) J. C. Snead, a 30yearold nephew of famed Sam Snead, shot a brilliant eightunderpar 62 today for the firstround lead in the $150,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

title: NIXON FUND PANEL MUST FACE COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The Justice Department today charged President Nixon's campaign finance committee with eight violations of Federal law in failing to record and report $31,300 that it had allegedly given to one of the defendants in the Watergate bugging trial.

title: The Cost of Alcoholism in State Is Put at $400  Million a Year
description: NEWARK, Jan. 11A grout of business executives were told here today that alcoholism in New Jersey was costing then $400million to $500million a year and that efforts to attach and reverse the disease had barely scratched the surface.

title: Voices and Bodies Produce the Sound On Workshop's Bill
description: Kirk Nurock's Natural Sound Workshop, which appeared Wednesday evening at the WBAI Free Music Store, (359 East 62d Street), is not afraid of living up to the last word of its name. Founded in September of 1971, this is indeed still a workshop, and Wednesday's hourplus program included what sounded like nearly every kind of concerted sound manifestation 20 people could make, using nothing but their voices and bodies. Some of the results made more coherent and esthetically agreeable sense than others, but what was really even more important was the openly experimental nature of the occasion.

title: 2 Museum Shows Offer Comparisons
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has opened two small exhibitions this week that are of considerable interest in themselves and of particular interest in relation to each other. One is a painting exhibition, concentrating on a small selection of 19thcentury American landscape paintings. The other is a photography exhibition, and is called, interestingly enough, The Painterly Photograph, 18901914. Both are drawn mainly from the museum's own collections.

title: StudentSpy May Lose Credits for Political Job
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Thomas James Gregory, the college student who became a political spy, may not graduate as soon as he had planned.

title: LIQUORI RETURNS TO TRACK TONIGHT
description: Marty Liguori takes the first giant strides in resuming his track and field career tonight, but he will not be alone in the search for the championship magic that carried him to the top of the world.

title: Navy Withdraws Charge
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 11 (UPI)The Navy dropped today one count of assault against the fourth defendant to be tried on charges stemming from a race riot aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk. The trial judge dismissed the charge against Seaman Arnold Petty, 19 years old, of Philadelphia, after a defense witness testified the defendant could not have been involved.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: The winning number is: 949790

title: Japan's Foreign Minister Stresses Ties With the U.S.
description: TOKYO, Jan. 11 (UPI) Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira said today that United StatesJapanese relations, were his most important foreign policy subject and rejected calls for revising the two countries' security treaty.

title: More Lobbyists for Saigon To Be Sent to Washington
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11  President Nguyen Van Thieu has increased the size of the special mission being sent to Washington to appeal for continued American support.

title: John Marshall Jr. of Yale, Taught Clinical Psychiatry
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 11Dr. John D. Marshall Jr., associate clinical professor of psychiatry at the Yale University School of Medicine, died here last night at his home of a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

title: New Cost Panel Chief John Thomas Dunlop
description: In the early stages of the Nixon Administration's Phase 2 attack on inflaton, Dr. John T. Dunlop, the Harvard economist who was in charge of the Construction Industry Stabilization Committee, had frequent and open clashes with the members of the Pay Board. They insisted that he adhere to the board's wage guidelines in judging construetion industry contracts, and he in sisted on near autonomy. When the smoke of these battles had cleared, Dr. Dunlop retained the authority he wanted. And the result was that, while construction wages were only slightly reduced, a measure of order had been brought to what was generally acknowledged to be chaotic collective bargaining in the construction industry.

title: Compounding Confusion
description: As peace talks continue in tight secrecy in Paris, public confusion over the Administration's objectives in Indochina has been compounded by the conflicting testimony of Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird and his designated successor, Elliot L. Richardson.

title: White House Insists Head of F.T.C. Quit Of His Own Volition
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)  The White House insisted today that the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Miles W. Kirkpatrick, had resigned of his own volition and had not been pushed out by the Administration.

title: Equity Financing
description: GambleSkogmo Inc. said yesterday its invitation for tenders of 500,000 shares of its own common would not be extended. The tenders expired on Wednesday. The company said that more than 500,000 shares were tendered. All shares tendered will be purchased at $36.50 a share. The company's stock closed yesterday at 36, up 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: People in Sports: Two Riders Win A wards
description: Neal Shapiro of Glen Head, L. I., a member of the United States Equestrian Team, and Mrs. Nancy Bonham of Trabuco Canyon, Calif., were named horseman and horsewoman of the year yesterday by the American Horse Shows Association.

title: Compassion Inspires a Gift to Neediest
description: Compassion is perhaps the most essential human virtue, Elizabeth Bacharach wrote in a letter to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, yet one doesn't hear much about it anymore.

title: A.B.C. LateNight Show To Allow Criticism of TV
description: The American Broadcasting Company's new late night series, Wide World of Entertainment, will include an occasional 90minute TV Time feature, described as television's examination of itself. The first program will be seen Feb. 1.

title: A Spanish Jesuit's Best Seller Hails Marx and Attacks Rome
description: ROME, Jan. 11The current best seller in ecclesiastical bookstores here is a slim volume by a Spanish Jesuit who, teaches at the Pontifical Gregorian University and praises Karl Marx as a prophet.

title: An Indian Leader Pledges Return of U. S. Property
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 The documents, paintings and other property taken from the Bureau of Indian Affairs after its fourday occupation by Indians last November will be returned by Feb. 10, a negotiator for the group said today.

title: Judge Sets Findings Date For WPIX License Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) A Federal Communications Commission hearing on a challenge to the broadcast license of WPIXTV, New York City, ended today after two and half years.

title: ROCKETS TRIUMPH OVER Q'S, 113.109
description: DALLAS, Jan. 11 (AP)Ralph Simpson and Warren Jabali, keyed a seconhalf rally as the Denver Rockets erased a 15point deficit and defeated the San Diego Conquistadors, 113109, tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Lid on Wages Feared
description: Many labor union leaders welcomed the removal of most compulsory wage and price controls yesterday and the shift to what appears to be a more flexible, selfadministering system of Phase 3.

title: Council Remapping Opposed at Hearing
description: Most speakers at a hearing that overflowed the Blue Room at City Hall yesterday urged Mayor Lindsay to veto a reapportionment bill that would increase the City Council membership to 43 from the present 37.

title: Alcoa Unveils New Process
description: The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday a new electrolytic method of producing primary aluminum that it said would sharply reduce costs of electricity and labor and at the same time eliminate undesirable environmental emissions.

title: F.T.C. Plans to Survey Supermarket Price Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission announced a plan today to survey supermarket prices and make its findings public to help buyers deal with what a spokesman for the agency called an explosion of discount price claims.

title: Hunt Admits All 6 Charges As Judge Bars Partial Plea??
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11E. Howard Hunt Jr., a former White House consultant, pleaded guilty today to all six charges against him in connection with the breakin and alleged bugging of the Democratic national.

title: Bridge: Assuming Neutral Position Can Be a Delicate Matter
description: To adopt and publicize a position of neutrality can be a delicate matter for a bridgeplayer as well as for a nationstate. And unfortunately, one's partners and wouldbe allies do not always get the message.

title: BETHLEHEM PLANS FURNACE REOPENING
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday it planned to reactivate some open hearth steelmaking furnaces at its Lackawanna. N. Y., plant. Robert M. Jordan, general manager of the Upstate plant, pointed out that only about half of the furnaces in the number two open hearth shop are equipped with proper air pollution control devices. He said these arc the ones that will he! reopened as soon as possible.

title: Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Following are questions compiled by The New York Times about economic policies announced by President Nixon today and tentative unofficial answers, some from staff members of Cost of Living Council:

title: Records: Yoko on Apple
description: Reviewing the recorded product of John Lennon and Yoko Ono in their more daring and experimental phases, which have been full of electronic feedback and discordant screaming, has builtin danger. One British critic found this out when, receiving an incomplete advance copy of one album, he reviewed 18 minutes of an engineer's test signal as some musical Zen statement.

title: Severe Weather Curtails Paper Concerns' Output
description: Severe weather conditions in the South have forced a number of paper companies to curtail their operations in the area. Since prolonged rains and ice storms have made logging impossible, many companies are exhausting their wood inventories.

title: DETECTIVE ADMITS A PERJURY CHARGE
description: The detective said by law enforcement officials to be a key figure in the intricate web of police corruption allegedly set up by Hugh Mulligan, the gambler and reputed fixer, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to perjury, and criminal contempt.

title: A HARVARD DEAN TO HEAD COUNCIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) President Nixon today announced the appointment of a 10member labor  management committee to advise the Cost of Living Council on wage standards.

title: TOP WEIGHT GOES TO SECRETARIAT
description: Secretariat, owned by the late Christopher T. Chenery,'s Meadow Stable, heads the list on the Free Experimental weights, released by the Jockey Club yesterday. Kenneth Noe Jr., handicapper for the New York Racing Association as well as for the Jockey Club, has assigned the colt 129 pounds. The highest rated filly on the list is JeanLouis Levesgue's undefeated La Prevoyante.

title: Public TV Corporation to Take A Firmer Control of Programing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The Corporation for Public Broadcasting announced plans today to take over from the Public Broadcasting Service firmer control of programing financed by the corporation.

title: Heavy Raids on North's Panhandle Area Go On
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan 12 (AP)United States planes kept up heavy raids on the southern panhandle of North Vietnam yesterday while ground action reportedly tapered off in South Vietnam.

title: BLACKS PROTEST DETROIT MANITUNT
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10  Black residents of this city accused the police today of frightening and harassing them in monthlong manhunt for three alleged killers.

title: People and Business
description: Last March, Joseph L. Kaufman and James J. Maguire were candidates in the first contested election for the post of vice chairman of the American Stock Exchange. Mr. Maguire was the winner after Mr. Kaufman withdrew and he held that position until the exchange was reorganized last fall.

title: Single Women Against a Dangerous City
description: These are some of the tims: Kitty Genovese, Janice Wylie, Emily Hoffert, Patrice Leary, and now, Roseann Quinn.

title: Nixon's Fight on Inflation Full of Anomalies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The Nixon Administration's program for stopping inflation by direct controls on wages and prices has always been full of anomalies.

title: NORTH STARS GAIN TIE WITH BRUINS
description: BOSTON, Jan. 11 (AP)Two rival goalies, Eddie Johnston of Boston and Gil Gilbert of Minnesota, turned in spectacular performances tonight as the Bruins and the North Stars battled to a 11 National Hockey League tie.

title: N.C.A.A. IS SCORED FOR OLYMPIC ACT
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11The Eastern College Athletic Conference, with 206 member colleges and universities, will challenge the right of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council to withdraw the N.C.A.A. from membership in the United States Olympic Committee.

title: Cambodia Assembly Target Of RocketFiring Pushcarts
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 11 (AP)Terrorists using icecream pushcarts as rocket launches fired two 107mm. rounds at the National Assembly building today.

title: PACERS AND ROCKETS REGISTER VICTORIES
description: DALLAS, Jan. 11 (AP)George McGinnis hit a short jump shot with 45 seconds left tonight to give the Indiana Pacers a 107106 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals in an, American Basketball Association game. In the first game of a doubleheader, the San Diego, Conquistadors lost a 15point lead and the Denver Rockets romped to a 113109 victory.

title: PLANE CRASH HELD SURPRISE TO CREW
description: MIAMI, Jan. 11 (AP)  The sole survivor from the flight deck of a jetliner that went down in the Florida Everglades with the loss of 100 lives says he believes the cockpit crew died without knowing that a crash was imminent.

title: BEAME SAYS OTB IS OVERSPENDING
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame accused the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation yesterday of having too many executives and spending too much money for rent, food, parking, entertainment and telephone service.

title: Some Officials Surprised
description: Business executives generally applauded President Nixon's move to Phase 3 yesterday as good step toward a less rigidly controlled economy. Some were surprised that it had come so soon.

title: C. EGERTON WARBURTON
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11C. Egerton Warburton, a director of the Devon Horse Show, died Thursday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr.

title: Britain Discloses Her Timetable For the Next Phase of Controls
description: LONDON, Jan. 11As President Nixon abolished wage and price controls, the British Government disclosed today its timetable for extension of its controls on wages and prices.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 133.4 from 131.9R last week.

title: Europe Weighs Nixon's Move Arid Worries About the Dollar
description: PARIS, Jan. 11The modification of wage, price and rent controls in the United States and higher lending rates in Europe have started caution signals blinking over the dollar in the Continent's financial centers.

title: It's a Peach of a Restaurant
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are raised both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: ARMY RESHUFFLES COMMANDS IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 The Army announced today what it called its most sweeping reorganization since 1962, involving commands within the United States that consist of more than a million men on active duty and in the reserves.

title: STATE TO ADD JOBS IN SHIFTS BY ARMY
description: Unlike some other states, New Jersey will gain civilian Government jobs in the vast reshuffling of the Army command structure announced yesterday in Washington, with 635 jobs being lost at the Picatinny Arsenal in Dover, but about 2,000 gained at Fort Monmouth, near Long Branch. Two other New Jersey installations affected are Fort Dix and the 52d Air Defense Artillery Brigade in Highlands, but the changes there are relatively minor and will consist mainly of transfers of military personnel.

title: Ringing a Change on the Lowly Potato
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Sabres Bow to Rangers In First Home Loss, 42
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 11At long last, for the first time in the five games they have met this season, Pete Stemkowski and the New York Rangers beat the bustling Buffalo Sabres, a thirdyear expansion club. It was a hardfought 42 victory tonight in Memorial Stadium, with Stemkowski scoring three goals the last into an empty net with one second left to play.

title: B52 Pilot Who Refused Mission Calls War Not Worth the Killing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11The B52 pilot who balked at bombing North Vietnam after his 175th mission said today that he had refused because the goals do not justify the mass destruction and killing.

title: The Siege of Hanoi: III
description: The longcontinued war, and especially American bombing in North Vietnam, have naturally had a profound impact on the educational system. For some time the big new Polytechnic, and other buildings of the University of Hanoi, have been closed, as well as most of the city's secondary schools. Faculties and students have left the city, but the educational process for North Vietnam's six million students continues in the provinces, under a system described by the minister as dispersed concentration  a phrase by which he meant to describe studentfaculty study groups of ten to twenty persons.

title: Governor Asks U.S. Law to Let State Settle the L. I. R. R. Strike
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11  Governor Rockefeller has urged President Nixon to ask Congress to amend the Federal Railway Labor Act so that New York State can invoke its own remedies to settle the Long Island Rail Road strike.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TO EACH HIS OWN One of the few festivals not being called a festival is a brace of concerts, tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 2:30, at the Manhattan School of Music's large auditorium, 120 Claremont Avenue, near West 120th Street. The programs are free to the public and are sponsored by Region II of the American Society of University Composers, an organization whose name says about all that is needed about what it's aboutpeople who write music and are associated with colleges. A feature of the concerts, which stress the contemporary, is that each of the 10 or 11 composers was asked to choose the music that he wanted played and also to drum up the people to play it. It is the sort of moment that tests a composer's close ties to the performing community. Each of the works, therefore, has a different set of players; the largest ensemble is the trio that will perform the contribution by David Maslanka, of the State University at Geneseo. The others are all singles or doubles.

title: Family Says Essex Was Seeking Justice
description: EMPORIA, Kan., Jan. 11The parents of Mark James Robert Essex, identified as the New Orleans sniper who shot and killed six persons there before being killed himself, today pictured their so as a black youth embittered by racial discrimination in the Navy and who lashed out at society in a frustrated fury.

title: Mine Safety Penalty Procedure Revised
description: WASHINGTON, San. 11The Bureau of Mines has revised its procedure for imposing penalties for safety violations on the owners of coal mines because of adverse comments from the mine operators, a Genleral Accounting Office report disclosed today.

title: Bernstein to Conduct Inaugural Day Peace Concert
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra will play Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture at the Inaugural Concert at Kennedy Center in Washington next Friday evening. And the same evening Leonard Bernstein will conduct Haydn's Mass in Time of War in Washington Cathedral, in a program that will have former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy as speaker and Francis B. Sayre, cathedral dean, presiding. The event, called A Plea for Peace, is one of many such activities being planned here and in the capital to coincide with the inauguration festivities.

title: Paris: Where It Stands
description: AUSTIN, Tex.As negotiations resume in Paris, it may be worth looking back at what has apparently transpired in the last several months.

title: Evidence in New Orleans Indicates Another Sniper
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 The New Orleans Police Department has evidence that there were at least two snipers and possibly three in the Downtown Howard Johnson Motor Lodge last Sunday and Monday, and that the six people killed and 15 wounded by gunfire at the motel were shot from two different weaponsa .44caliber semiautomatic rifle and a bolt action rifle.

title: Church Council Is Sending Medical Supplies to Hanoi
description: GENEVA, Jan. 11  The World Council of Churches announced today that it was sending $300,000 in medical supplies to the North Vietnamese Red Cross. The council also provides relief aid to South Vietnam.

title: Surprised Consumer Activists Voice Their Fear Over Phase 3
description: Ralph Nader, Bess Myerson, Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal and Erma Angevine never thought highly of Phases 1 or 2. But they, and some other consumer activists, expressed fear yesterday that, from their point of view, Phase 3 might be even worse.

title: You May Go Home Again, Briefly
description: CINCINNATIIt was 9 o'clock on a Friday evening when I saw him get out of a shiny red car in our driveway. Thanks for the ride! he called cheerily as the driver backed out. A young man with curly black hair tied back in a pony tail, he dropped his bedroll and pack beside the house and rang the bell. Before my husband opened the door, I saw the girl with wide brown eyes and long hair standing behind my son.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Walter Zirpolo, former Mayor of Woodbridge, N. J., and Robert E. Jacks, former president of the Woodbridge Council, were sentenced in Middlesex County Court in New Brunswick to two to six years' imprisonment on briberyconspiracy charges. Judge John B. Molineux also fined Zirpolo $3,000 and Jacks $2,000.

title: Music: Johnny Mercer at Town Hall
description: Johnny Mercer, the songwriter and singer, got this season's weekly 5:45 Interludes at Town Hall off to an easygoing start Wednesday with a casual lowkeyed performance of more than a dozen of his songs.

title: Continental Recalls Tires
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) Continental Tire Company is recalling some 2,500 imported tires, produced at its plant in Stocken, West Germany, in January, 1971, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

title: ARMY RESHUFFLES COMMANDS IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 11 The Army announced today what it called its most sweeping reorganization since 1962, involving commands within the United States that consist of more than a million men on active duty and in the reserves.

title: DIVIDEND CURB SEEN IN ACCOUNTING SHIFT
description: S. Hayward Wills, chairman and president of the GAC Corporation, said yesterday the changes adopted by the Accounting Principles Board for landdevelopment companies might prevent the company from meeting requirements for continuing dividend payments on its preferred and preference shares.

title: EDUCATION BUDGET EXPECTED TO CUT MANY PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 President Nixon's education budget for the next fiscal year will propose the elimination or phasing out of many popular education programs, according to reports and documents reaching Capitol Hill.

title: District 18 Board Adopts Plan Scribner Resisted
description: On a vote narrowly divided between East Flatbush and Canarsie members, Community School Board 18 voted last night to formally adopt its original rezoning plan for the racial rebalancing of three junior high schools.

title: Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Following are questions compiled by The New York Times about economic policies announced by President Nixon today and tentative unofficial answers, some from staff members of Cost of Living Council:

title: Compassion Inspires a Gift to Neediest
description: Compassion is perhaps the most essential human virttie, Elizabeth Bacharach wrote in a letter to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, yet one doesn't hear much about it anymore.

title: 2 GHANA SPRINTERS TRIUMPH IN GAMES
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 11 (AP) Alice Annum of Ghana broke her African record today in winning the 100meter dash at the second AllAfrica Games. Her time was 11.72 seconds. Rose Asiedua, also of Ghana, was second.

title: Red. Smith
description: The tall man at the bar was Dick Stuart, the batter they used to call Stonefingers or Dr. Strangeglove, when he tried to play first base. The quiet man at a table for two was Mike Cowles of the publishing family and the pretty lady a few tables away was Fran Alison of Kukla, Fran and 011ie. Frank Gifford, who for 12 years took everything people like Chuck Bednarik could dish out in the National Football League, limped in on the ankle he broke trying to slide downhill. Bowie Kuhn was there with his shadow, Joe Reichler, and the Yankees' Bob Fishel was accompanied by Marsh Samuels of Cleveland. Some of the Yankees' new owners probably were scattered around, since they seem to be scattered everywhere. It was lunch hour in Toots Shor's and somewhat less cluttered than usual, much like the day when thoughtful poet returned to his office and wrote:

title: Lid on Wages Feared
description: Many labor union leaders welcomed the removal of most compulsory wage and price controls yesterday and the shift to what appears to be a more flexible, selfadministering system of Phase 3.

title: Piano Kennedy Sang On Is Sold to Tune of $1,300
description: There had been a mob scene that day just before the 1960 election, Joe O'Connor recalled, when John F. Kennedy stopped in at the National Democratic Club at 233 Madison Avenue, near. 37th Street.

title: NIXON FUND PANEL MUST FACE COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The Justice Department today charged President Nixon's campaign finance committee with eight violations of Federal law in failing to record and report $31,300 that it had allegedly given to one of the defendants. in the Watergate bugging trial.

title: Local Draft Selections
description: Here is a list of the players the Yankees and the Mets selected in Wednesday's free agent draft:

title: Whitehead Says Bill on TV Would Restore Equilibrium
description: Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, reiterated yesterday that the Administration's bill to change the broadcasting laws would restore equilibrium to the broadcasting system.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 55,231 Deer Killed in State
description: ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 11 (AP) New York State huntqs killed a total of 55,231 der during the fall of 1972, including a record total of 1,596 deer taken by archers, the Environmental Conservation Department announced today.

title: Cahill Rejects Proposal to Build Oil Superport in Coastal Waters
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11  Governor Cahill tonight rejected as unacceptable an Army Corps of Engineers proposal to construct a deepwater oil superport in coastal waters off New Jersey.

title: Britain Reports Rise In Her Trade Deficit
description: LONDON, Jan. 11 (Reuters)Britain reported today her foreigntrade deficit widened in December, the final month before she joined the European Common Market, to 93million $218.6million) from 81million ($190.4million) in November.

title: Brezhnev Sees Vietnam Drawing to a Conclusion
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11Leonid I. Brezhnev, preparing to begin two days of talks on European security and other issues with President Pompidou of France, declared today that the Vietnam affair is drawing little by little to its conclusion.

title: Cahill Rejects Plan For Oil Superport Proposed by Army
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11  Governor Cahill tonight rejected as unacceptable an Army Corps of Engineers proposal to construct a deepwater oil superport in coastal waters off New Jersey.

title: Mrs. Meir Cancels Her Role In Paris News Conference
description: PARIS, Jan. 11 (AP)Premier Golda Meir of Israel has canceled her scheduled appearance at a news conference at the end of a private gathering of the Socialist International, the Israeli Embassy said today.

title: Port Authority Budgets $30Million for Mass Transit
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey took the first steps yesterday toward implementing its new masstransportation role as it adopted an $827million budget for 1973.

title: Democrats in Congress Call Move Premature, but Republicans Hail It as Timely
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Democrats in Congress said today that President Nixon's decision to ease wage and price controls was premature, but Republicans on Capitol Hill generally hailed the announcement as timely.

title: 2 Redskins Hope History Will Repeat in Super Bowl
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 11 In their dotage, the Washington Redskins might shout Hip, hip, hooray on cue from Coach. George Allen, but in reality they are professionals who look to the Super Bowl for the money involved.

title: Paternity Leave Granted To Berkeley City Employes
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 11 (UPI)City employes whose wives give birth may now obtain a fiveday unpaid paternity leave. Expectant mothers are already allowed six months' unpaid leave.

title: Upstate Utility Is Granted Rate Increase of Over 2%
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11 (AP)The New York State Electric & Gas Corporation, serving more than a half million customers throughout upstate New York, has received state approval for rate increases of slightly more than 2 per cent.

title: BOY ASKS ADMISSION TO JUVENILE SCHOOL
description: PLAINFIELD, Ind., Jan. 11 ((UPI)A 13yearold boy who was released from the Indiana state school for boys 11 months ago has asked to be readmitted, saying he has been mistreated by his parents, who he says are involved in drug trafficking.

title: Trudeau Defeats NoConfidence Motion in Parliament
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 11  Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau's minority Liberal Government, with the help of two opposition parties, easily defeated a formal Conservative motion of nonconfidence tonight. The vote was 148 to 107.

title: LEGISLATOR URGES MARIJUANA STORES
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 11 (UPI)A freshman Connecticut lawmaker is calling for full legalization of marijuana to be sold in local package storetype pot shops.

title: Details of Model's Slaying Given as L.I. Trial Opens
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 11The prosecution described in detail today the fatal stabbing and burning of a former New York City model who had been scheduled to be a key Government witness in a narcotics case in Manhattan.

title: MILTON. KRAMER, 57, OF HERTZ PUBLICITY
description: Milton D. Kramer, vice president and director of public relations of the Hertz Corporation, died yesterday at his office. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Theater: Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard Opens
Sears Signs $100Million Lease for Space in Times Square Area
description: In a major expansion of its fashion buying headquarters, Sears, Roebuck & Co. has signed a 25year, $100million lease for space in a new skyscraper in the Times Square area.

title: American League to Let Pitcher Have a PinchHitter and Stay In
description: The oweners of the 24 major league baseball teams took a radical step yesterday to put more punch into the game. They voted to allow the American League to use a designated pinchhitter, who may bat for the pitcher without forcing him from the game.

title: 3 Children Killed in Brooklyn Fire
description: Two brothers and a sister, the eldest 5 years old, were killed yesterday afternoon in fire that engulfed their secondstory bedroom in a tenement in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Washington and Hamilton Hair Stolen With Mourning Lockets
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11  The, police here are conducting an intensive search for George Washington's hair and for hair of Alexander Hamilton, Elizabeth Schuyler Hamilton, and Johannes van Rensselaer, his fatherinlaw.

title: Car Output Is Up for Week
description: DETROIT, Jan. 11 (Reuters) United States car production for the week was estimated at 205,567 units, according to the trade paper Automotive News today.

title: Special Lottery Offers $200 a Week for Life
description: First prizes of $200 a week for life will be awarded in a special New York State lottery for which $2 tickets may be purchased beginning Jan. 17, it was announced yesterday.

title: Monopoly Players Prevail in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 11For millions of Monopoly players, those sentimental highrollers of playmoney capitalism, today was a victory for tradition and the underdog for Mediterranean and Baltic Avenues.

title: N.C.A.A. IS SCORED FOR OLYMPIC ACT
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11The Eastern College Athletic Conference, with 206 member colleges and universities, will challenge the right of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council to withdraw the N.C.A.A. from membership in the United States Olympic Committee.

title: SADAT MEETS TITO FOR A DAY OF TALKS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 11President Anwar elSadat of Egypt arrived in Yugoslavia today for a day of talks with President Tito amid expectations of new endeavors by Cairo toward breaking the deadlock in the conflict with Israel.

title: KISSINGER AND THO CONTINUING TALKS
description: PARIS, Jan. 11While Henry A. Kissinger and Le Due Tho continued their closeddoor talks a few miles away, both Saigon and the Vietnamese communist delegations reverted to stiff demands today at the weekly formal peace talks here.

title: Needham Again Assails Third Market
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, attacked the third market last night as a vehicle used by institutional investors to hide their trading in violation of the public interest.

title: Weinberger Vows to Fight Artificial School Busing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) Casper W.Weinberger pledged today that as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare he would oppose busing for artificial racial balance in schools.

title: Phase 3: A Step Back
description: In its Phase 3 wageprice control system, the Nixon Administration has taken a big step back toward where it began in 1969, but it has not gone all the way.

title: William C. Eisenhardt, 57; Led Queensboro Library
description: William C. Eisenhardt, president of the Queensboro Public Library since 1971, and a Queens civic leader, died Wednesday of a heart ailment at his home, 67 Biltmore Road in Massapequa, L.I. His age was 57.

title: NIXON AIDE DENIES ANY BUGGING LINK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)  A White House aide who worked with two men charged in the Watergate case told Congress today that he had no knowledge of the bugging incident and never discussed it with the pair.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: 2 Redskins Hope History Will Repeat in Super Bowl
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 11 In their dotage, the Washington Redskins might shout Hip, hip, hooray on cue from Coach George Allen, but in reality they are professionals who look to the Super Bowl for the money involved.

title: Clements Won't Rule Out ABomb Use
description: WASHINGTON. Jan 11 William P. Clements Jr., nominated by President Nixon to be Deputy Secretary of Defense, said today he would not rule out the use of nuclear weapons over North Vietnam.

title: Suit Here Alleges Job Bias In Civil Service Fireman Tests
description: Civil Service Commission examinations for city firemen discriminate against blacks and Puerto Ricans, the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund charged yesterday in a suit in Federal District Court.

title: Witnesses Describe Ravages Of Crime in Garment District
description: Rampant crime in the midtown garment center has caused a loss of jobs, the closing of many establishments and the moving of numerous concerns to other areas, witnesses at an informal hearing yesterday told two state legislators.

title: 2 ExWoodbridge Aides Get 2 to 6 Years in Bribes
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 11 (AP) Walter Zirpolo, and former Mayor of Woodbridge, Robert E. Jacks, former president of the Woodbridge Council, were sentenced in Middlesex County Court here today to two to six years' imprisonment on briberyconspiracy charges.

title: Black Policeman Is Slain In a Community in Alabama
description: HURTSBORO, Ala., Jan. 11 (UPI)A black policeman, the first ever in this eastcentral Alabama community, and a homeless oddjobs man who was warming himself inside city hall were shot to death early this morning.

title: 3 in Masks Hijack Truck With $100,000 in Goods
description: A truck that had picked up a $100,000 cargo off clothing and watches at Kennedy International Airport yesterday was hijacked by three masked men, two armed with pistols, according to the police.

title: Killing of Kangaroo Curbed by Ban on Some Exports
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 11 Australia announced a ban on the export of kangaroo hides and meat today, to take effect April 1.

title: The Harvard Club Votes 2,097 to 695 To Accept Women
description: The Harvard Club, for 107 years a male preserve, voted yesterday to admit women as members.

title: INSURERS IN PACT WITH SOVIET UNIT
description: Ten leading American insurance companies, preparing for what is expected to be a major increase in trade with the Soviet Union, disclosed here yesterday that they had concluded an agreement with a Sovietowned insurance company based in London. It will permit American insurers to cover American property in the Soviet Union and American exports to the Soviet.

title: Youth With Pellet Pistol Killed in Police Shootout
description: A 19yearold youth was shot to death by the police in his East Harlem apartment early yesterday, by policemen who said he had fired a pellet gun at them.

title: City, in Unusual Move, Revokes 2 Contracts for Rikers I. Work
description: In a highly unusual move, the Board of Estimate yesterday revoked two signed city contracts totaling $4.1million and held by the Mansfield Contracting Corporation of Queens for work on Rikers Island.

title: EDUCATION BUDGET EXPECTED TO CUT MANY PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11President Nixon's education budget for the next fiscal year will propose the elimination or phasing out of many popular education programs, according to reports and documents reaching Capitol Hill.

title: SENATORS DEMAND NOMINEES' PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Senate Democrats demanded today that President Nixon's Cabinet nominees pledge. as a prerequisite to confirmation by the Senate, that they would appear before Congressional committees to explain Administration policies.

title: Businessmen and Economists Foresee a Moderate Increase in Corporate Profits
description: Corporate profits will probably rise moderately as a result of the Nixon Administration's relaxation of profit margin controls, businessmen and economists said yesterday.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Notes on People
description: Beginning next month, there are expected to be 35,000 men and one woman working as pilots on major Scheduled United States airlines. The woman will be 33yearold Emily Howell, just hired by Frontier Airlines of Denver, as a second officer to help fly its Boeing 737's. The airline and the Air Line Pilots Association said that would make Miss Howell the only woman pilot working for a scheduled American carrier, exclusive of air taxis, and probably the first woman in American aviation history. There are a few women in such jobs abroad, but American women have had difficulty accumulating the required flight time to qualify as pilots. Most men get the time by flying in the services. Miss Howell put in her air time as a flight instructor air taxi company pilot.

title: Soviet Begins Census of Prized Sable, Preyed On by BlackMarket Poachers
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11The Soviet Union announced today that it had begun the first national count of its sable population. The highly valued animal represents one of the country's most important natural resources.

title: Movie Writer Is Indicted
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 (UPI)A United States District Court grand jury yesterday indicted Norman S. Wexler, 46 years old, who wrote the script for the hit movie Joe, on charges of interfering with an airliner's crew. Mr. Wexler was arrested here on Dec. 14 after allegedly shouting obscenities at a stewardess while on an American Airlines flight from New York.

title: SWEDISH KING CALLS RAIDS MERCILESS
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 11 (UPI) King Gustaf VI Adolf of Sweden called today for immediate peace in Vietnam and said that the United States must not resume its merciless bombing of Hanoi and Haiphong. Speaking from the throne on the occasion of the opening of Parliament, the 90yearold King said:

title: Sulphur Price Rise Slated By Pennzoil's Duval Corp.
description: The Duval Corporation, the mining subsidiary fo the Pennzoil Company, said yesterday that it will increase its suphur prices.

title: Lady Romayne Grimston Is Bride
description: Lady Romayne Grimston, daughter of the Earl and countess of Verulam, of Gorhambury, St. Albans, England, was married in London yesterday to John Bockstoce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Bockstoce of Hartford and York Harbor, Me.

title: Mrs. King, Mrs. Court In Field for Tour Opener
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King, Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia and 10 other players have been given berths in the $25,000 tournament here next week that opens the 1973 women's professional tennis tour.

title: POLICE SAY SUSPECT KEPT MUGGING DIARY
description: A teenaged youth charged with a mugging yesterday was said by the police to have kept a meticulous written list of some 30 prior assaults on elderly Bronx women, under the heading, Official Holdup Rec ord.

title: Ernest Angell, Lawyer, Dead; Former Chairman of A. C. L. U.
description: Ernest Angell, for many years national chairman Of the American Civil Liberties Union, died yesterday at his home, 156 East 66th Street. He was 83 years old and had been suffering from a heart condi tion.

title: MARCUS DUFFIELD OF HERALD TRIBUNE
description: GUILFORD, Conn., Jan. 11Marcus Duffield, for many years a writer and editor for The New York Herald Tribune, died in New Haven Hospital today. He was 69 years old and lived at 39 North Street.

title: Red Smith
description: Sport of The Times

title: Oil Show Set in Budapest
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) The Commerce Department said today that United States oil and gas drilling and production equipment would be displayed for sale in Budapest May 18 to 28.

title: WIDER RESEARCH IN ENERGY ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The chairman of the Federal Power Commission, John N. Nassikas, said today that the United States should increase its energy supplies through expanded research, exploration on Federal lands and price and tax breaks for producers.

title: Sabres Bow to Rangers In First Home Loss, 42
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 11At long last, for the first time in the five games they have met this season, Pete Stemkowski and the New York Rangers beat the bustling Buffalo Sabres, a thirdyear expansion club. It was a hardfought 42 victory tonight in Memorial Stadium, with Stemkowski scoring three goals, the last into an empty net with one second left to play.

title: DR. EDGAR A. DAY
description: Dr. Edgar A. Day, executive vice president of International Flavors & Fragrances and a vice president of I.F.F., Inc., died Wednesday of a heart attack at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 44 years old and lived in Rumson, N. J.

title: Live Cattle Futures Set Records; Wheat Drops on Rise in Acreage
description: Despite the excitement and confusion about the lifting of acreage restrictions and the easing of price controls, live beef cattle quietly made new record highs yesterday in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Wrestler Collapses, Dies
description: GREELEY, Colo., Jan. 11 (AP)  A 15yearold junior high school wrestler collapsed while working out with a teammate tonight and died moments later. Witnesses said Tony Barber rolled onto his back during a practice match and died while being rushed to a hospital. The cause of death was unknown.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: HEALTH PANEL CITES 10 FOOD VIOLATORS
description: Ten food establishments said to have seriously violated the city's Health Code are on a list made public yesterday by the Health Services Administration.

title: Plan to Relax U.S. Controls Brings Gains
description: Stock prices soared yesterday in response to President Nixon's relaxation of wageprice controls and profitmargin limitations under Phase 3.

title: Macon Buses to Run Again
description: MACON, Ga., Jan. 11 (UPI)With a $25,000 state grant, reduced fares and revised routes, Macon's bus system will go back into operation Monday for a 60day trial period. The Bibb Transit Company stopped running Dec. 31, claiming a loss of about $15,000 a month.

title: AMEX ADVANCES ON PHASE 3 NEWS
description: President Nixon's announcement that controls under Phase 3 would be largely voluntary touched off a sharp rally on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading yesterday.

title: Zambia Is Retaliating Against Neighbors
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 11.Zambia, caught in an economic and political conflict with both Rhodesia and South Africa, announced retaliatory moves against them both today although the action is likely to have serious repercussions on her shaky economy.

title: Slight Impact Seen On Rents in the City
description: President Nixon's abolition of Federal rent guidelines yesterday will have little immediate effect in New York City because many tenants are protected by city rent controls.

title: Some Officials Surprised
description: Business executives generally applauded President Nixon's move to Phase 3 yesterday as a good step toward a less rigidly controlled economy. Some were surprised that it had come so soon.

title: Dining Out in Jersey.
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Music: A Reminder of Mendelssohn's Mastery
description: In these seasons of Mahler and Bruckner symphonies, of Ring operas and long postserial works, the Mendelssohn program that William Steinberg conducted on Wednesday in Carnegie Hall floated in like a tulip leaf on a mountain freshet. A Mendelssohn program! The Ruy Blas Overture and the Italian Symphony, the G minor Piano Concerto and the Violin Concerto. And this Pittsburgh Symphony program served to remind everybody once more what a complete master Mendelssohn was.

title: Football Coaches Swarm In Chicago Seeking Jobs
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11Lee Corso, the newly named Indiana coach, and Frank Lauterbur of Iowa got together at the American College Football Coaches convention this week and reminisced about four years ago when Corso's fortunes were on a downturn At the gathering in Los Angeles in 1969, Corso had barely missed being named backfield coach at U.C.L.A. after feeling confident he would get

title: Orders Affecting Food Prices Will Be Cleared by Cost Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Orders that have been issued for years without publicity by the Agriculture Department affecting local prices of fruits, vegetables, milk and some other products will be subject to clearance in the future by the Cost of Living Council, it was announced today.

title: Swarm
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11Lee Corso, the newly named Indiana coach, and Frank Lauterbur of Iowa got together at the American College Football Coaches convention this week and reminisced about four years ago when Corso's fortunes were on a downturn At the gathering in Los Angeles in 1969, Corso had barely missed being named backfield coach at U.C.L.A. after feeling confident he would get the position.

title: UNITAS IS EAGER TO KEEP ACTIVE
description: NEWPORT BEACK Calif., Jan. 11 (UPI)Johnny Unitas, Baltimore's fading 39yearold quarterback, still wants to play football and the Colts are going to let him do thatfor somebody else.

title: CITY TO DISMISS 95 AND REPAY U.S.
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton said yesterday that 95 municipal employes who had been improperly hired under a federally financed emergency  employment program would have their jobs terminated by next Monday.

title: 10 Drug Suspects Indicted On Perjury Charges Here
description: Myles J. Ambrose, head of the Federal Office for Drug Abuse Law Enforcement, announced perjury indictments against 10 alleged narcotics traffickers here yesterday and said the perjury charges were a new method of attacking the heroin trade.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Rights Unit Refuses Doctors' Plea

title: Networks Oppose End of Children Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 The three major television networks opposed a proposal to ban commercials from children's programs in hearings before the Federal Communications Commission this week.
