title: Advertising: Kirkpatrick Praise
description: Advertising industry leaders, who have weathered frequent and heavy attacks from the newly aggressive and innovative Federal Trade Commission during the last two years, had nothing but kind words yesterday for Chairman Miles W. Kirkpatrick, who announced his resignation Wednesday.

title: HUNTINGTON PLANS SCHOOL SHAKEUP
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Jan. 11 The Huntington School District said today that it was redistricting its school system to achieve the racial balance ordered by State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist.

title: Paternity Leave Granted To Berkeley City Employes
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 11 (UPI)City employes whose wives give birth may now obtain a fiveday unpaid paternity leave. Expectant mothers are already allowed six months' unpaid leave.

title: RAIDERS DOWNEI BY NATIONALS, 4
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 11 (AP)The Ottawa Nationals received quick openingperiod goal frog Rick Sentes and went on to do feat the New York Raiders, 4in a World Hockey Associatio game tonight.

title: Flag Penalty Is Upheld
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 11 (UPI) The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals upheld yesterday the twoyear probated sentence of a Houston man for wearing United States flag on the seat of his trousers.

title: Books of The Times
description: JOHNNY, WE HARDLY KNEW YE. Memories of John Fitzgerald Kennedy. By Kenneth P. O'Donnell and David F. Powers with Joe McCarthy. 434 pages. Little, Brown. $8.95.

title: Australian Aide Would Pattern Some Laws After Those in U.S.
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 12The Attorney General in Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's new Cabinet has announced that he will confer with officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington on the formation of a similar agency in Australia, to correct what he calls a chaotic national lawenforcement system.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: VOICE PLANTS There's an allBrecht program at 3 tomorrow afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Street, and the first 100 or so people to show up before 2 P.M. will get in freeand get a job for the performance with the Brooklyn Philharmonia (ST 32434).

title: 2 More Phils Accept Pacts
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) Greg Luzinski, hardhitting outfielder, and Craig Robinson, a rookie infielder, agreed to terms today with the Philadelphia Phillies. The Phillies have eight players in the fold for the 1973 season.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE APPROVES A RISE IN DISCOUNT RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Federal Reserve Board approved today an increase in the discount rate from 4 per cent to 5 per cent at all 12 Federal Reserve Banks. The new rate takes effect on Monday.

title: Killebrew, Twins Aided by Experiment
description: Instead of the lesserknown players who usually are called upon to pinch hit, American League baseball fans may see such pinchhitters as Harmon Killebrew, Tony Oliva, Boog Powell, Frank Robinson and Al Kaline this coming season.

title: Dr. Oswald T. Allis Dead; Scholar On Old Testament
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12Dr. Oswald T. Allis, an Old Testament scholar and one of the founders of the Westminster Theological Seminary here in 1929, died today at his home in Wayne. He was 92 years old.

title: U.C.L.A. WINS NO. 56, BEATING STANFORD
description: STANFORD, Calif., Jan. 12Larry Hollyfield, a forward scored 10 points early in th?? second half tonight to give top ranked University of Californi Los Angeles, a big lead an send the Bruins to an 8267 Pa cific8 basketball victory ove Stanford. It was the Bruin 56th straight victory since th?? 197071 season.

title: McCandless Reported Out as Princeton Coach
description: J. L. (Jake) McCandless has resigned after four years as Princeton University's head football coach, The Associated Press reported last night.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Gerald Slavis, Ad Manager For Esquire, Is Dead at 34
description: Gerald Slavis, vice president and national advertising manager of Esquire magazine, died Thursday evening of undetermined causes. He was 34 years old and lived at 460 East 79th Street.

title: HORSE SHOWS HIT NEW HIGH IN '72
description: The American Horse Shows Association sanctioned 1,019 events last year  the first time the organization has recognized more than 1,000 shows.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: JERUSALEMThe Jerusalem Prize, Israel's international literary prize, has been awarded this year to Eugene Ionesco, the French playwright and philosopher.

title: Evolution On Trial Out West
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Opposition to teaching evolution still lives, and powerful efforts are in progress to introduce the divine creation story into officially approved California science textbooks. These efforts were opposed at a hearing Nov. 9 by representatives of major religious faiths, including Christians, Jews and Buddhists.

title: ROCKETS BEATEN BY KNICKS, 1041 03
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 12  Earl Monroe, who insists that his value to the Knicks involves more than scoring, did a lot of scoring and at the right times tonight to give the New Yorkers a breathtaking 104103 triumph; over the Houston Rockets at Hofheinz Pavilion.

title: More Guilty Pleas Hinted Amid Watergate Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Watergate trial was held in strict secrecy today, and there were a number of indications that some of the six defendants wanted to change their pleas to guilty. Interest centered on four men from Miami, arrested in the offices of the Democratic National Committee on June 17 and subsequently charged in an indictment with conspiracy, eavesdropping and burglary.

title: France Sides With Soviet On European Talks Issue
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12France joined the Soviet Union today in opposing the American view that the calling of a European security conference should depend at least partly on progress in forthcoming EastWest talks on force reductions in Central Europe.

title: France Is Pressing To Step Up Economy
description: PARIS, Jan. 12The scene: A Paris butcher shop. The characters: The butcher, a man in his 50's, and two regular customers, a fiftyish German resident and an American.

title: TV Review
description: If you haven't seen Marlene Dietrich's cabaretstage act, basically the same one she has been doing for 20 years, you may be interested in the onehour special Marlene DietrichI Wish You Love, which will be shown on the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight at 10. The act is certainly worth seeing once.

title: A 15Year Sentence Imposed for Attempt To Bribe I.R.S. Man
description: NEWARK, Jan. 12 (UPI)A Federal judge today sentenced Carmen Ottilio, a millionaire Paterson demolition contractor, to 15 years in prison and fined him a total of $61,000 for attempting to bribe an Internal Revenue Service agent and for tax fraud.

title: Thomas Williamson Weds Miss Joyner
description: Miss Virginia Winfield Joyner and Thomas A. Williamson, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd by the Rev. Thomas Bauer.

title: JULIUS P. MOLNAR, 56, BELL EXECUTIVE, DIES
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 12 Julius P. Molnar, executive vice president of Bell Telephone Laboratories and a director of Bell and of the Sandia Corporation, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 84 Countryside Drive.

title: Violent Writing Found on Sniper's Wall
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan, 12Mark James Robert Essex, the dead New Orleans sniper, was discovered today to have lived in a small apartment whose walls were covered with revolutionary graffiti.

title: Records: Jazz Reissues
description: Roulette Records, a major jazz label in the nineteenfifties that went into a decline along with jazz in the sixties, has recently been delving into its vaults to bring back recordings made 10, 20, even 30 years ago by Count Basie, Art Tatum, Stan Getz, Charlie Parker and an impressive list of jazz stars. Under the overall title Echoes of an Era, the reissues are packaged in bargainpriced twodisk sets selling for $5.98.

title: 60 U. S. Judges Gather in Ossining to Study Problems of Sentencing
description: OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 12More than 60 Federal judges from New York and New England have retreated into the tranquillity of the Crotonville countryside north of here to study the troubling problems of sending people to prison.

title: Largest Mezzotint, by Close, Shown
description: The heady air of experiment and improvisation is one of the characteristic features of contemporary art. Oftentimes, this sense of strenuous effort brings forth if not a mouse, at least something less than one might have expected.

title: A New Tremor Shakes Managua, Causing Panic
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Tan. 12 (UPI)Another earth tremor shook Managua today, causing little damage but bringing panic to thousands of survivors of the Dec. 23 quake that cost some 10,000 lives.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (Reuters)Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that President Nixon's new relaxed wage and price control system might force the Federal Reserve Board to tighten the money supply to help curb inflation.

title: The Working of Glass: Ten fears of Growth For a Neglected Art
description: One day, a little more than 10 years ago, a ceramist named Harvey Littleton became fired up about glass. Although for decades craftsmen had been experimenting with just about every material that could be rendered into shape by human hinds, glass had been almost completely neglected. This was because no one had seen a way around the technological difficulties for the individual artisan who might want to produce it.

title: Connecticut. Buys Xerox In First PBW Trading
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12Robert I. Berdon, Treasurer of Connecticut, went onto the floor of the PBW Stock Exchange here today to make Connecticut's first stock trade since the state became a member of the exchange on Dec. 13.

title: A Manila Suburb Votes Languidly for Marcos Plan
description: MANILA, Jan. 12The citizens' assembly today in Barrio La Huerta, on the southern outskirts of Manila, was a quiet, rather dutiful affair somewhat resembling a high school graduation ceremony in a small town in the United States.

title: Books of The Times
description: FRANTZ FANON. A Critical Study. By Irene L. Gendzier, 300 pages. Pantheon. $10.

title: JUDGE CASTIGATED ON BENCH CONDUCT
description: The United States Court of Appeals here yesterday castigated a Federal judge in Brooklyn, Georg Rosling, for conduct that it said seriously prejudiced a defendant at his trial on a narcotics charge. It reversed the conviction and ordered a new trial.

title: Washington vs. Miami: Newspapers Wage Battle of Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP)On the theory that the pen is mightier than the forward pass, two newspapers are waging a Super Bowl battle of their own, trading printed blows more jolting than a crackback block.

title: FLAMES VICTORS, 10; TAKE SECOND PLACE
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 12 (AP)The Atlanta Flames, getting superb goaltending from Dan Bouchard and a secondperiod goal from Larry Romanchych, moved into second place in the National. Hockey League Western Division tonight with a 10 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Final Knapp Report
description: The final report of the Knapp Commission investigating charges of police corruption in New York City found that the corruption which pervaded the law enforcement establishment here was repeatedly ignored by officials at high levels of public service.

title: MILLIONS ANSWER ITALY STRIKE CALL
description: ROME, Jan. 12  Millions of Italians deserted their jobs today in a general strike called by the nation's three major labor organizations to press for social reforms.

title: Floo?? Savings Figured
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 12 Final calculations show that the Tennessee Valley Authority's flood control operation on the Tennessee River in December ??verted an estimated total of $10million in damage at Chattanooga.

title: Poetry the Zenith Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 12  Seven chanters of poetry sat stiffly around an ornately covered table before Emperor Hirohito and Empress Nagako in the Imperial Palace here this morning and intoned:

title: Search for Geothermal Energy On Public Land May Stir Fight
description: A new battle between environmentalists and energy producers is likely to erupt this year when the Department of the Interior seeks to le se public lands in the West for the exploration of geothermal energy resources.

title: Court, Overruling State, Gives Gay Alliance Right to Incorporate
description: State Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, yesterday reaffirmed the right of a group of homosexuals known as the Gay Activist Alliance to receive a certificate of incorporaion under that name.

title: Wide Drug Detection Program Being Set Up in Harlem School
description: A drug detection program that would call for intermediate school students in Harlem to submit to urinalysis to determine whether they are using drugs is being prepared with the aid of a White House agency.

title: CATTLE FUTURES REACH NEW HIGHS
description: Day after day, cattle futures have been setting new highs, and yesterday was no exception. The new high became 43.25 for February delivery cattle on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, exceeding Thursday's high of 42.85.

title: Dance: Van Dantzig's Monument for a Dead Boy
description: The new production of Rudi van Dantzig's Monument for a Dead Boy, which American Ballet Theater offered at the New York City Center Thursday night, seems dated.

title: Sports Today
description: St. Francis at St. John's, 8 P.M. (RadioWRVR, 8 P.M.); Iona at St. Peter's,. 8:15 P.M.; Manhat tan at Seton Hall, 8. P.M. (Radio WFUVFM, 7:45 P.M.); Buffalo at Fairleigh Dickinson, 8 P.M.; Cornell at Columbia, 8 P.M. (Radio  WKCRFM, 8 P.M.) (TelevisionChannel 10 (cable), 9:45 P.M.., delayed tape).

title: Bingo Fans Find New Stop on the West Side
description: Gertrude and Beatrice Bachrack like the place because it's close to home, but they don't go for the upsidedown T's. Sarah Smith couldn't care less about the T's as long as she has her goodluck charms with her.

title: A.T.H. FILES PLAN FOR RATE INCREASE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The American Telephone and Telegraph Company formally filed with the Government today proposed schedule of rate increases on service between states that will add $145million a year to its income.

title: CHILE CRITICIZES KENNECOTT MOVE
description: BONN, Jan. 12  The Goveminent of Chile emphasized here today damage to its economy that could be caused by an injunction obtained in Hamburg by the Kennecott Copper Corporation of America. The injunction blocks delivery of 3,000 tons of copper.

title: Behind Watergate
description: An air of unreality surrounds the Watergate political espionage trial. The prosecution, in presenting its case, went out of its way to portray the defendants' alleged offenses as something of a Republican protectivereaction strike against villainy anticipated from President Nixon's Democratic opposition. Earl J. Silbert, the Assistant United States Attorney, said in his opening statement that the assignments given to the defendants resulted from concern that extremists might disrupt campaign appearances by Cabinet officers and others serving as surrogates for Mr. Nixon.

title: FRANK E. FISCHER
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 12Frank E. Fischer, who retired in 1955 as a senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died today in Mountainside Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Upper Montclair.

title: NAVESINK TO GET AN 11ACRE PARK
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, Jan. 12Monmouth County will acquire an 11acre tract on the Navesink Highlands southwest of Sandy Hook for development as a county park, Joseph C. Irwin, director of the county's Board of Freeholders, announced here today.

title: Music: Of 1799 and 1914
description: Two choral works: more than 100 years apart, completely different in mood and textureand yet they complemented each other so perfectly. Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic, on Thursday evening, presented a program consisting of Haydn's Theresienmesse and Stravinsky's The Nightingale. This is the season, it will be remembered, during which the Philharmonic is taking a close look at both composers.

title: 2 TowTruck Operators Found Guilty Of Perjury at Hearing of Knapp Panel
description: Two Queens towtruck operators have been found guilty of perjury for having testified before the Knapp Commission that two policemen gave them 14 traffic tickets in a matter of hours when they refused to bribe them.

title: B52'S AGAIN BOMB AREA NEAR SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 13 (AP)Traditional enemy staging areas northwest of Saigon were heavily bombed yesterday by United States B52 bombers.

title: MEANY ROLE CITED IN ENDING FREEZE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12President Nixon's decision tc drop most mandatory antiinflation controls was described privately by labor officials to day as a major victory for George Meany that would do much to promote labor peace in 1973.

title: JUDGE CASTIGATEDON BENCH CONDUCTV
description: The United States Court of Appeals here yesterday castigated a Federal judge in Brooklyn, George Rosling, for conduct that it said seriously prejudiced a defendant at his trial on a narcotics charge. It reversed, the conviction and ordered a new trial.

title: Greece Said to Plan End Of Direct U.S. Arms Aid
description: ATHENS, Jan. 12A qualified source reported today that Greece had decided to give up direct United States military aid, which was set at about $15million for 1973.

title: N.B.C. to Adapt Zoo Gang By Gallico in New Series
description: The National Broadcasting Company has acquired television rights to a sixpart adaptation of Paul Gallico's novel The Zoo Gang as the first miniseries it will present in the 197374 season.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Asia Biggest Source of Brain brain to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The brain drain of scientists, engineers and physicians immigrating to the United States has accelerated in recent years, but Asia has replaced Europe as the main source of this incoming technical manpower.

title: Structure of ProteinBuilding Molecule Determined
description: The shape of a class of molecules that play an essential role in all life processes has been determined by a group at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: 41 of 518 Who Applied Start Training to Be State Troopers Sunday
description: SEA GIRT, Jan. 12  More than a year ago, 518 men submitted applications to become New Jersey state troopers. On Sunday, the 41 who survived the written, physical and psychological tests will start the 14week course at the State Police Academy here.

title: Chong Jun Taek Dies at 61; North Korea Vice Premier
description: TOKYO, Jan. 12 (AP)Vice Premier Chong Jun Taek of North Korea died of an undisclosed illness yesterday, Peking's official press agency, Hsinhua, reported today, quoting North Korea's Central News Agency. He was 61 years old.

title: Guerrilla Units Reelect Arafat as Head
description: CAIRO, Jan. 12 Palestinian uerrilla leaders ended six days of heated debate here today with the reelection of Yasir Arafat as their chairman, but with the dream of unified military and political action as remote as ever.

title: Persian Room Tries to Revive Past
description: The staff of the Persian Room, the printed announcement read, is pleased to announce that it has prevailed upon the management of the Plaza to return the Persian Room to the Persian Room.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 1.3%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week was an estimated 13 billion tonmiles, 1.3 per cent above the corresponding 1972 week.

title: Roy Ruggles Johnson, 89; Broke Jim Thorpe Story
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 12 (AP)  Roy Ruggles Johnson, former newspaperman who broke the story of Jim Thorpe's professionalism in 1913 in The Worcester Telegram, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital here. He was 89 years old.

title: TURK EDWARDS, 65, OP FOOTBALL PANE
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 12 (AP)Albert Glenn (Turk) Edwards, a member of the football Hall of Fame, died Wednesday at his home in suburban Kirkland. He was 65 years old.

title: TEXTBOOK DISPUTE SETTLED ON COAST
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 12The State Board of Education decided today that social science textbooks  and not science textswere the proper place for discussing in elementary schools the philosophy of man's origin.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 13, 1973

title: Block Watchers Get First Crime Class
description: The Police Department gave the first lesson in crime detection yesterday to a class of doormen, building superintendents and business executives who have volunteered to watch their blocks as part of the city's midtown cleanup drive.

title: Jeweler Says 2 Robbed Him of $83,000
description: A 42yearold jeweler from Rockland County said he was robbed of $83,000 in cash in Queens yesterday while on the way to return the money to people on whose behalf he had been supposed to buy jewelry. The money was to be returned, he said, because the purchase fell through.

title: JAMES M. MORTON, 56, NEWSMAN, U.S. AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) James Geary Morton, an adviser in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations and a former vice president of the Hearst Publishing Company, died today of cancer. He was 56 years old.

title: Stocks and Bonds Show Sharp Drop
description: The stock market and the bond market fell sharply in active trading yesterday as the investment community took second  and harder  look at the possible implications of the Phase 3 economic program.

title: SQUIRES TRIUMPH OVER NETS, 10393
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 12The way the Nets played basketball tonight, their opposition, the Virginia Squires, didn't need a coach. In fact, the Squires didn't have one for the second half.

title: WEEKEND SESSION PLANNED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Jan. 12Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc The conferred for six and a half hours today in a suburban villa, and they are to continue their private talks on a Vietnam ceasefire tomorrow morning.

title: CHEMICAL MAKER RAISES EARNINGS
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, Cleveland, a leading producer of chemicals, oil, gas and minerals, reported yesterday increased earnings and sales for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year ended Dec. 31, 1972

title: AUGUSTUS W. PHELPS
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 12Augustus W. Phelps, founder of Phelps Fenn & Co., 39 Broadway, New York, invest ment securities and a leader in municipal bonds, died yesterday at the White Plains Hospital. His age was 82.

title: Reaction to Baseball Change Mixed
description: The designated pinchhitterbaseball's most radical innovation in threequarters of a century, became the talk of the town yesterday, three months before his debut in the American League.

title: CITY WITHDRAWING FROM HIRING PLAN
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city was immediately withdrawing from the New York Plan, established two years ago to increase the number of minority workers in the buildingconstruction trades, because the city was very disappointed with the plan's results.

title: OKONITE COMPANY IS SEEKING SIMPLEX
description: An agreement in principle for the acquisition of the Simplex Wire and Cable Company by the Okonite Company, a subsidiary of OmegoAlpha, Inc., was announced yesterday.

title: East Germans Fleeing to West Despite Relaxation of Tension
description: BONN, Jan. 12West Germany's policy of improving relations with its neighbors to the east has had the unexpected effect of encouraging more and More East Germans to risk their lives' in fleeing to the west.

title: State Reports Sharp Drop In Its DailyLottery Sales
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12  Sales of tickets in the New Jersey daily lottery, which opened with a flourish and fanfare last November, have dropped from $2.5million a week to about $1million.

title: 60 U.S. Judges Gather in Ossning to Study Probems of Sentencing
description: OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 12More than 60 Federal judges from New York and New England have retreated into the tranquillity of the Crotonville countryside north of here to study the troubling problems of sending people to prison.

title: Soviet Aid to Cuba
description: Cuba's new economic aid agreement with the Soviet Union indicates that Moscow has decided to become receiver in bankruptcy for the Cuban economy. Repayment of the several billion dollars Cuba owes the Soviet Union has been postponed until a 25year period beginning in 1986, a formula that suggests the debt is really being written off as unrepayable. Moscow has also promised additional credits to cover Cuba's unfavorable balance of trade during 19731975, plus over $300 million in technical and economic aid, and a sharp increase the price the U.S.S.R. pays for Cuba's key export, sugar.

title: Daily Newspaper Closes
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. Jan. 12 (AP)The Home Journal, a daily newspaper on St. Thomas Island for 21 years, ceased publication today. J. R. Smith, chief executive officer of Modern Press, Inc., which owns the newspaper, said that it would be replaced by a new weekly paper called The Weekly Journal. Mr, Smith said that overwhelming economic problems made the production of a daily prohibitive.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 68CENT INCREASE IN THE REALTY TAX IS PREDICTED HERE
description: The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday predicted a record 68cent increase for each $100 of assessed valuation in the city's real estate tax for the 197374 fiscal year, which starts July 1.

title: Screen: 'The First Circle':Solzhenitzyn Novel on Prison Adapted The Cast
description: "The First Circle" is a very sad film. Not because of the austerity of its place and time (a special Soviet prison camp for scientists in the late 1940's), nor because hopelessness would seem the only rational philosophy under a tyranny as effective as Stalin's. Rather it's because the movie is such a wan and ineffectual testament to the novel it is based on, as well as to the life and career of its extraordinary author, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the 1970 Nobel Prize-winning Soviet writer.Aleksander Ford, the 64-year-old Polish film maker who wrote and directed the film, has a reputation for serious work that goes back to the late 1920's. Mr. Ford, who left Poland in 1968 to live in Israel, has also lived and worked in the Soviet Union, leading one to believe that "The First Circle" would, at least, look and sound right. But it doesn't.It's an international mess. It was filmed in Denmark, mostly with what I assume to be Scandinavian actors, who apparently mouthed English dialogue that was later dubbed in a variety of accents, some so alarmingly American that the way the actors say their lines makes what they say sound even worse, like the dialogue in a Hollywood prison melodrama of the 1930's."We can make you talk if we want to," the camp superintendent says to a prisoner who the government wants to have invent "the absolute encoder." Or (with a snarl): "We'll shoot you like a dog. You'll never get away!"The absolute encoder, which sounds as if the movie wanted to talk like Flash Gordon, is a device ordered by Stalin so that no one can bug his telephone conversations. Its also the peg around which the melodrama proceeds, in lurching starts and fits, introducing us to various inmates and, through flashbacks, to their earlier lives.By trying to cram so much of the 580-page novel into a film of conventional length, Mr. Ford has gotten hold of practically nothing. A lot of events and characters are there, but the tremendous range of experience and emotion is gone. So are the novel's sense of heroisin, of history, of magnificent mission. Instead, awkward actors stand about in costumes in which they don't seem overly at ease, being photographed in the blunt, bright reds and greens and blues that I associate with Denmark's soft-core porn features, playing, essentially, good guys and bad guys with an often ludicrous solemnity.Even though they fail as films, some adaptations of great novels may work to the extent that they excite that they excite enough enough curiosity to send one to the novel itself. "The First Circle," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts is such a clinker it just might shrivel the interest of anyone unfamiliar with Solzhenitsyn's work. The effect, though not the intent, is anti-intellectualand it's fairly unforgivable.

title: Corona Jury Ends Second Day Of Deliberation on Mass Killing
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 12A jury of 10 men and two women continued today to deliberate the fate of Juan V. Corona, 38yearold Mexican national accused of murdering 25 migrant farm workers. The case went to the jury at 11:45 A.M. yesterday.

title: Brewers Sign Draft Choice
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 12 (AP) The Milwaukee Brewers signed Michael Robinson today. He was their top draft choice it the regular phase of Wednesday's free agent draft. Robin, son is a 19yearold lefthanded hitting outfielder.

title: RANGERS OPPOSE BLUES IN ST. LOUIS
description: The New York Rangers, with spirits lifted by Thursday's 41 victory over the Buffalo Sabres  the first in their five meetings this season  move on this afternoon to meet the St. Louis Blues in St. Louis Arena. The Rangers have beaten St. Louis three out of three this season, but the Dec. 20 game was costlyTed Irvine and Gene Carr were injured then and still are out of the lineup.

title: Surge of Price Increases Forecast by Businessmen
description: A surge of price increases is likely in the weeks ahead following President Nixon's relaxation of economic controls, businessmen and economists predicted yesterday.

title: A Modest Proposal
description: LONDON, Jan. 12Good firm penal laws being the foundation of a sound polity, only the knavish or peevish would complain of the object presently sought by that great figure of the American colonies, Governor ROCKEFELLER. He has asked for laws condemning all who deal in narcotic drugs to imprisonment for the remainder of their lives, with no compromise at their trial nor hope of relief from their sentence.

title: Walkowitz Work Shows New Aspects
description: When the American painter Abraham Walkowitz died in 1965 at the age of 84, he seemed to many observers of the art scene one of those artists who, though once admired as pioneer exponents of the modern movement in this country, had not succeeded in producing notable oeuvres of their own. The art public had grown used to thinking of Walkowitz, if it thought of him at all, as the man who could not stop painting pictures of Isadora Duncan. He had become a name one could safely ignore.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: G.E. and Soviel Sign Pact For Technology Exchange
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12  The Soviet Union and the General Electric Company, one of America's industrial giants, signed wideranging agreement here today for joint development of electricpower generating technology.

title: Surge of Price Increases Forecast by Businessmen
description: A surge of price increases is likely in the weeks ahead following President Nixon's relaxation of economic controls, businessmen and economists predicted yesterday.

title: WINE TALK
description: CADAUJAC, France Six years ago, a group of American businessmen came to this little town on the southern outskirts of Bordeaux and bought themselves a wine business.

title: TV Producers Cite Harm in PrimeTime Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) Producers of television shows said today that the ban on network shows in the nation's 50 top markets during the first hour of prime viewing time has done more harm than good.

title: Clark Ends Nis Holdout, Rejoins Bullets Tuesday
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 12 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets announced today that the National Basketball Association club and its holdout star, Archie Clark, had agreed on a contract.

title: A.H.S.A. Sanctioned 1,019 Shows in 72
description: The American Horse Shows Association sanctioned 1,019 events Iast year  the first time the organization has recognized more than 1,000 shows.

title: West German Reserves Fall
description: FRANKFORT, Jan. 12 (Reuters)  West Germany's net monetary reserves declined by about one billion marks ($320million in the week ended Dec. 31 to 74.4 billion marks ($23.8billion).

title: Bridge: City and Jersey Players Share TriState Honors
description: New York City and New Jersey shared the honors in the opening day's play at the TriState Regional Championships at Grossingers, N. Y. on Thursday.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Houston Lighting & Power Company said yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 1,500,000 common shares. The company said the offering is expected Feb. 6 and would be underwritten by a group managed by Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter. The company's stock closed unchanged at 50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Nixon Administration Aides Insist Nuclear Weapons Will Not Be Used in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Nixon Administration moved quickly today to reaffirm that the United States had rejected the use of nulear weapons in the Vietnam war.

title: Band Greets Girl After Surgery
description: MT. OLIVE TOWNSHIP, Jan. 12  Elevenyearold JanAnn Westerink came home for a visit today and was greeted by hundreds of children from seven schools and a marching band.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Rutgers and Town to Mount Patrols

title: WEEKEND SESSION PLANNED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Jan. 12Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho conferred for six and a half hours today in a suburban villa, and they are to continue their private talks on a Vietnam ceasefire tomorrow morning.

title: TV: Tom Brown Crosses Atlantic
description: Judging by the high standards of the imported serials from Masterpiece Theater, television viewers would have every right to expect a firstrate version of Tom Brown's Schooldays. Introduced by Alistair Cooke, the first of the five 60minute chapters goes on tomorrow night at 9 over WNET/Channel 13. The British Broadcasting Corporation production will be presented through a grant from the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: By Drawing on Experience, Police Artist Gets His Man
description: Most days start the same for Patrolman William McCormack. He tucks his pistol into his holster under his civilian jacket, takes the 40minute subway ride from his home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and receives casual morning greetings from his buddies in the ramshackle old police, building at 400 Broome Street.

title: Antiques: Tiffany Vogue
description: Seldom has a decorative arts revival moved as swiftly, proved as pervasive or sparked as many reproductions, outright fakes and innovative expressions in crafts as Art Nouveau.

title: Lady of Late Adds Color With Vocals By Meredith Monk
description: Past musical scores for dance Swan Lake, for instancehave emerged to stand on their own, and Thursday night at Town Hall Meredith Monk, herself a dancer, offered her music for William Dunass Our Lady of Late in concert. The result was an extraordinarily consoling, meditative experience.

title: GUARD EXPLAINS MOTIVES IN RIOT
description: A correction officer indicted on several charges growing out of the October, 1970, riot at the Tombs testified at his trial in State Supreme Court on the motives for a speech he made during the rebellion.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 12There is a tall tale going around the St. Peter's campus here that Juan Jiminez is the tallest Cuban on earth.

title: Nixon Flies to Florida To Work on Messages
description: HOMESTEAD AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP)President Nixon flew to his Florida home today to work on his inaugural and State of the Union messages.

title: CarMishap Victim Lay In a Ravine 10 Hours
description: CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP)A 50yearold Queens College librarian whose car jumped a low stone wall in this rural Putnam County community last night lay unnoticed in a ravine for 10 hours in subfreezing weather, the police reported.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Sport of The Times

title: Switch Regulates Power Surges
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12A General Electric Company engineer was granted three patents this week for switching devices that are expected to benefit producers and users of electrical equipment ranging from doorbells to ignition points in cars to heavy industrial transformers. The inventions belong to the G.E. family of metal oxide varistors which insulate at low voltage and conduct at high voltage, and can keep power surges from damaging a television set or a giant computer.

title: Two Groups Seek a Study Here Of Raids on Illegal Latin Aliens
description: Two groups aiding immigrants and four Representatives from the city called yesterday for an investigation of alleged dragnet raids by immigration officials searching for illegal LatinAmerican aliens.

title: More Guilty Pleas Hinted Amid Watergate Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Watergate trial was held in strict secrecy today, and there were a number of indications that some of the six defendants wanted to change their pleas to guilty. Interest centered on four men from Miami, arrested in the offices of the Democratic National Committee on June 17 and subsequently charged in an indictment with conspiracy, eavesdropping and burglary.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Paris Security Tight as Mrs. Meir Arrives
description: PARIS, Jan. 12  Premier Golda Meir of Israel arrived here today for a twoday unofficial gathering of world Socialist leaders that the French Government has pledged it will officially ignore.

title: Investigation Is Urged of Raids Made to Find Illegal Latin Aliens
description: Two groups aiding immigrants and four Representatives from the city called yesterday for an investigation of alleged dragnet raids by immigration officials searching for illegal LatinAmerican aliens.

title: Pittsburgh Warehouse Fire
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12 (UPI) A warehouse fire marked by explosions and fanned by high winds ravaged three blocks of homes and stores last night, showered bricks and glass into the streets and forced the evacuation of a home for the aged. There were no reported injuries. Damage was expected to be in the millions.

title: SOVIET MOONCRAFT BEGINS LUNAR ORBIT
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12The Soviet Union's latest unmanned mooncraft, Luna 21, went into orbit around the moon today in preparation for a series of maneuvers that may take it to the surface on Sunday.

title: J.C. Snead Leads by 3 Strokes at Phoenix With 129
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 12 (AP)J. C. Snead carded a 67 today and stretched his lead three strokes with a 129 total after 36 holes in the $150,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The chief negotiator for the unions on strike against the Long Island Rail Road yesterday criticized Governor Rockefeller's proposal to amend Federal law to allow the state to impose its own remedies to settle the strike. Calling the idea ridiculous, the negotiator, Anthony F. D'Avanzo, said it would force the unions to go through all Federal procedures and then have to start all over again with parallel state procedures.

title: MEANY ROLE CITED IN ENDING FREEZE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12President Nixon's decision to drop most mandatory antiinflation controls was described privately by labor officials today as a major victory for George Meany that would do much to promote labor peace in 1973.

title: Wide Drug Detection Program Being Set Up in Harlem School
description: A drug detection program that would require intermediate school students in Harlem to submit to urinalyses is being prepared with the aid of a White House agency.

title: Subsidy Increased To Prolong Service By Jersey Central
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12  Governor Cahill today authorized an additional $470,000 subsidy for the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey to keep passenger service for its 15,000 daily commuters running until March 23.

title: Reserves of Gas Down for Fourth Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The Federal Power Commission today reported that reserves of natural gas dropped 17.1 per cent In 1971, decreasing for the fourth straight year.

title: Les Halles Dead at 200, A Victim of Progress
description: PARIS, Jan. 12Wholesale butchers did their last day's work in Les Halles today, finally closing down the central market, of Paris, which had fed the city for the last 200 years.

title: UNWED MOTHER WINS RULING IN ADOPTION
description: ALBANY, Jan. 12 (AP)An unmarried Albany mother, in a case reminiscent of the Baby Lenore case, has been backed by New York's highest court in her battle to regain custody of the 2yearold son she had surrendered for adoption.

title: ALLEN TO RE FINED FOR CONCEALMENT OF PLAYER INJURY
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Jan. 12At this annual news conference two days before the Super Bowl, Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, said today that George Allen, coach of the Washington Redskins, had been fined twice for breaking league. rules since he became coach early in 1971, and was in line for a third assessment.

title: Olympic Champions in K. of C. Track Meet Tonight
ROME ENVOY URGED FOR POST IN SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The State Department has recommended to President Nixon that Graham A. Martin, the departing Ambassador to Italy, be named Ambassador to South Vietnam to replace Ellsworth Bunker, who plans to retire after almost six years in Saigon, a department official said today.

title: Corporation Tutors Help Underprivileged
description: Five major corporations here have developed a program of tutoring underprivileged children in the corporation's offices so that the children could learn from the everyday world of work.

title: Welfare Rolls Expanded By 81,000 During August
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) A total of 81,000 persons joined the nation's welfare rolls last August, the Government announced today. It was the largest increase in five months.

title: Jersey Reports Drop in Sales Of Tickets for Its Daily Lottery
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12  Sales of tickets in the New Jersey daily lottery, which opened with a flourish and fanfare last November, have dropped from $2.5million a week to about $1million.

title: 2 Athena Missiles Tested
description: GREEN RIVER, Utah, Jan. 12 (AP)Two Air Force Athena missiles were launched early today from the White Sands Missile Range's launching complex near here. Both research vehicles impacted on the missile range in south central New Mexico as programmed, officials said.

title: By Drawing on Experience, Police Artist Gets His Man
description: Most days start the same for Patrolman William McCormack. He tucks his pistol into his holster under his civilian jacket, takes the 40minute subway ride from his home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and receives casual morning greetings from his buddies in the ramshackle old police building at 400 Broome Street.

title: ALLCOST WINNING SCORED BY UDALL
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 12Stewart L. Udall, a former Secretary of the Interior, attacked anythingtowin attitudes of bigtime college athletics today before members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, including representatives of some colleges he singled out for special criticism.

title: THEODORE N. NELSON
description: Theodore Norden Nelson, manager of purchasing for the GAF Corporation, died here Thursday. He was 64 years old and lived in Mountainside, N.J.

title: Ali Delights Pupils Here at a Tribute to Dr. King
description: Muhammad Ali  expansive, proud and sometimes boisterous bounded onto the stage at the Intermediate School 117 auditorium in East Harlem yesterday, drawing screams of surprise and delight from students, who raised their arms in the victory sign.

title: NOMINEES PRESSED ON FUTURE MEETINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12Senate Democrats continued today to ask nominees for major Presidential appointments for promises that they would come hack to Congress when called and answer questions.

title: Staffs of 2 Agencies Confident of Getting Other Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12On the day after President Nixon announced the elimination of her Government job, Patricia Valley was going about her work with the stoic confidence of a nurse assisting in her tenthousandth operation.

title: DR. ROY A. NIHOS, HISTORIAN, 76, DIPS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan, 12Dr. Roy F. Nichols, retired dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences of the University of Pennsylvania and a 1949 winner of the Pulitzer Prize in history, died at his home yesterday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Rise in Inventories Pace Continued in November
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The recently increased pace of inventory accumulation by business continued in November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: RAILROADS WARY OF FUEL SHORTAGE
description: A spokesman for the Association of American Railroads said yesterday that train service could be curtailed soon if the nationwide fuel shortage is not eased.

title: Domestic Open Skies...
description: Something good is in the air, in the complex and slowly developing field of domestic and international satellite communications. In these, the Columbus years of satellite exploration and application, it is important to keep our eyes on a constant goal: How can this enlarged spectrum of opportunities best serve the people of the world?

title: DR. L. F. LARIONOV
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (Reuters) Dr. Leonid F. Larionov, a Soviet pioneer in cancer research, has died after a brief illness, the Health Ministry newspaper Medical Gazette said today. He was 70 years old.

title: Fumes Drive 500 Out
description: LITTLETON, Colo., Jan. 12 (AP)  Acrid fumes spewing from a ruptured pipeline forced the evacuation of 500 residents from their homes in this Denver suburb last night. Dr. William McKinnel Jr., research adviser at the Marathon Oil Company Research Center, said a pipe containing sulphur trioxide apparently ruptured, sending dense black smoke and fumes over a 20block area.

title: Alex D. Reeves, 42, Dies; Hill & Knowlton Executive
description: PLANDOME MANOR, L. I., Jan. 12Alex D. Reeves, a vice president of Hill & Knowlton, Inc., the international publicrelations and public  affairs counseling organization, died yesterday at, his home, 51 Circle Drive. He was 42 years old.

title: POVERTY AGENCY PACES MORE CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Office of Economic Opportunity, already far smaller than when it was the flagship agency of President Lyndon B. Johnson's war on poverty, is about to be cut further, Nixon Administration sources said today.

title: MELVILLE HARRIS
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 12Melville Harris, a New York lawyer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in New Rochelle Hospital today. He was 57 years old and lived at 312 Surrey Drive.

title: Art: Master Drawings From Oxford
description: It's rare, but there is such a thing as an exhibition of such high quality that any comment beyond a list of its contents is likely to be redundant. The Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, opened such an exhibition Thursday, Old Master Drawings from Christ Church, Oxford.

title: Belfast Woman, 70, Killed Accidentally By British Soldiers;
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 12 (Reuters)A 70yearold widow died here today after she was shot near her home when British troops fired at a man believed to be a sniper belonging to the Irish Republican, Army.

title: IN NOCONTEST PLEA, TURNER FINED $2,500
description: CLEARWATER, Fla. Jan. 12 (AP)Glenn W. Turner, Orlando businessman, pleaded no contest today to five misdemeanor charges involving his Dare To Be Great company and was fined $2,500. The action headed off a second trial on more serious charges.

title: Bethlehem Steel Will Hire 350 to 400 at Lackawanna
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 12 (AP)The Bethlehem Steel Company said it planned to add 350 to 400 employes to its work force of more than 11,000 in nearby Lackawanna by reactivating six longidle openhearth furnaces.

title: S.E.C STRENG THENS DISCLOSURE RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Securities and Exchange Commission strengthened its disclosure requirements today for companies using bigbath accounting practices that distort earnings reports by writing off accumulated past charges against a single year's income.

title: Dove Index Off by 12.34 Points In Busy Day
description: The stock market, which rallied vigorously on Thursday in response to the unveiling of Phase 3 economic controls, took a second look yesterday at the program and then dropped sharply in active trading.

title: Stanley Glaubach Is Dead at 48; An Illustrator for Time Covers
description: Stanley Glaubach, graphic designer and artist, whose scultpured caricatures of politicians and other persons In the news were widely reproduced as illustrations in magazines and newspapers, died yesterday of a heart attack in his studio, 84 University Place. He was 48 years old and lived at 24 Oakdale Lane in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Cahill Raises Central's Subsidy To Prolong Commuter Service
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12  Governor Cahill today authorized an additional $470,000 subsidy for the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey to keep passenger service for its 15,000 daily commuters running until March 23.

title: People in Sports: Post On Braves to Robinson
description: The longexpected dismissal of Paul Richards from his job as the Atlanta Braves' vice president for baseball operations was made official yesterday when Bill Bartholomay, the board chairman, named Eddie Robinson to fill the post.

title: Canarsie Sends Scribner Plan To Rezone He Opposed in Past
description: The community school board for the Canarsie and East Flatbash sections of Brooklyn submitted its controversial rezoning plan to School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner yesterday, asserting that it would provide the greatest likelihood of a peaceful schoolcommunity atmosphere in which learning would take place.

title: Smith Vaults 178, u.S. Indoor Mark
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 12Steve Smith, who failed to clear 16 feet at the Munich Olympics, set an American indoor record in the pole vault tonight with a leap of 17 feet 8 inches during the National Invitation track and field meet.

title: Thief Gets Cash and Jewels In Luxury Apartment Holdup
description: A man who pretended to have asthma gained entry into an apartment and robbed an 18yearold woman and her maid in an exclusive residential building at 860 United Nations Plaza was being sought yesterday by the police.

title: MORE RESIGNATIONS ACCEPTED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) The White House announced today that President Nixon had accepted the resignations of three more top Pentagon officials.

title: Mandatory Quotas Opposed by Dent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (Reuters)  Frederick B. Dent, President Nixon's choice for Secretary of Commerce, today opposed mandatory acrosstheboard quotas on all foreign goods.

title: Bonds in Slump on New Fears of Inflation
description: Credit Markets

title: The Conflict Over the Delaney Clause
description: WASHINGTONThe Delaney clause, a controversial foosafety law enacted in 1985 by Representative James Delaney, Democrat of New York, to keep cancercausing chemicals out of food, is about to be breached. So the food industry trade journals, claiming support of the Food and Drug Administration, would have us belive. The F.D.A. has the discretion a set tolerances or safe levels derived from doseresponse tests on animals or human subjects. The Delaney clause makes an absolute exception for cancercausing substances.

title: Son Is Arrested in Slaying Of Dream Books Publisher
description: A 30yearold man was charged in Bronx Criminal Court yesterday with killing his father in what District Attorney Mario Merola said was a dispute about the family publishing business.

title: Mrs. Boggs Will Run For Her Husband's Seat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP)Mrs. Lindy Boggs announced today that she would be a candidate for the Louisiana Congressional seat of her husband, the House majority leader, Hale Boggs, who was lost on an airplane flight in Alaska Oct. 16. A special election has been called for March 20, with a primary Feb. 3.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE APPROVES A RISE IN DISCOUNT RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Federal Reserve Board approved today an increase in the discount rate from 4 per cent to 5 per cent at all 12 Federal Reserve Banks. The new rate takes effect on Monday.

title: Havlicek Paces Celtic 133109 Rout of Hawks
description: BOSTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) John Havlicek's 25 points paced the Boston Celtics to a 133109 rout of the Atlanta Hawks tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Thinking Unthinkable, Speaking Unspeakable:
description: The prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages in this country was called The Noble Experiment, among other things. It did a lot to destroy our respect for policemen, who were expected to enforce laws which were stupid and unpopular. The war in Vietnam might aptly be called Noble Experiment II, since it is a similarly narrowminded adventure in virtue: It has left us with a secret and unjust contempt for our soldiers, especially our airmen. That contempt will become less and less secret as time goes by.

title: 2 ACCUSED HERE OF AN ARSON PLOT
description: Two men who are said to have collected $325,000 in insurance in the last 10 years as a result of about 75 mysterious fires were arrested yesterday on ?? chargs in connection with a fire that destroyed an 18room house in Lawrence, L. I., last November.

title: A RADIO PROJECT SHIFTED BY NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12Secretary of Defense Melvin L. Laird has directed the Navy to concentrate on Texas as the prime site for the possible construction of Project Sanguine, a controversial billiondollar communications system.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los Angeles  Mario Roman, 141 pounds, Mexico, knocked out Jose Lujan, 138, Mexico, 6 rounds.

title: Chile Takes Control Of All Wheat Sales; Rationing Is Planned
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 12 (UPI)The leftist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens took control of wheat sales today in a found political and social move to strengthen planned rationing of at least 30 basic food items.

title: C.E. and Soviet Sign Pact For Technology Exchange
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12  The Soviet Union and the General Electric Company, one of America's industrial giants, signed wideranging agreement here today for joint development of electricpower generating technology.

title: SCHMIDT RESIGNS AS LIONS' COACH
description: DETROIT, Jan. 12 (AP)Joe Schmidt, a defensive superstar who never found coaching as easy as linebacking, resigned today as head coach of the Detroit Lions after six seasons of attempting to mold a champion team.

title: Dunlop and Meany Own Shares in Resort Project
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 12 (AP)  John T. Dunlop, named by President Nixon to be director of the Cost of Living Council, is an investor along with George Meany, president of the labor federation, and other labor figures in a Caribbean resort development.

title: Multiple Wagering Resumed
description: SALEM, N. H., Jan. 12 (AP)  Rockingham Raceway reinstituted perfecta and superfecta multiple wagering tonight. Ray Poirier, track publicity director, said a ban imposed Jan, 1 had resulted in a onethird drop in attendance and a decrease in the mutuel handle of about 50 per cent. Poirier said the state which had been losing $6,000 to $8,000 a night in taxes, had agreed to rescind the ban.

title: 68CENT INCREASE IN THE REALTY TAX IS PREDICTED HERE
description: The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday predicted a record 68cent increase for each $100 of assessed valuation in the city's real estate tax for the 197374 fiscal year, which starts July 1.

title: Ellsberg Jury Completed in Dramatic Court Scene
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12At the end of a morning of drama and high tension, ten women and two menincluding a badly wounded Vietnam veteran who wants the war to end nowwere selected today to be the jury in the Pentagon papers case.

title: A Condominium Developer To Return Purchase Fees
description: The developer of a condominium project in Rockland County agreed yesterday to return $555,870 to 18 condominium purchasers after State Attorney General ouis J. Lefkowitz charged that they were sold using false, fraudulent and misleading literature.

title: EARNINGS RESTATED BY CONTROLS CORP.
description: The International Controls Corporation, a New Jersey electronics concern once headed by Robert L. Vesco and still controlled by him, said yesterday that it had restated its previously reported ninemonth results.

title: People and Business
description: Ireland's Prime Minister, John M. Lynch, returned to Dublin yesterday after spending a week in the United States trying to promote American investment in Ireland.

title: GUARD EXPLAINS MOTIVES IN RIOT
description: A correction officer indicted on several charges growing out of the October, 1970, riot at the Tombs testified at his trial in State Supreme Court on the motives for a speech he made during the rebellion.

title: Officials Weigh Problems In Making Phase 3 Work
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Government's economic stabilization staff began pondering today a multitude of questions about how Phase 3 of President Nixon's antiinflation campaign will work in practice.

title: ELIZABETH M. SELLERS
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12 (AP)Elizabeth Mellon Sellers, daughter of the late Thomas Alexander Mellon Jr., died yesterday at West Penn Hospital. Her age was 69.

title: SmokePurge System at World Trade Center Passes Test of Fire
description: A small fire at the World Trade Center put the downtown complex's special smoke purge system to the test yesterday afternoon, and It worked, belching smoke out of the South Tower of the 110story building and causing alarm in the neighborhood.

title: Miss Holtzman Given Judiciary Post Made Vacant by Her Defeat of Celler
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12Elizabeth Holtzman, the 31yearold Brooklyn Democrat who unseated Representative Emanuel Celler, the 84yearold chairman of the House Judiciary Committee last year, will follow in Mr. Celler's footsteps on the Judiciary Committee. The Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee, who make committee assignments for the Democrats in the House, decided this week to put her on judiciary.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL SHOWS RISE IN NET
description: The Crocker National Corporation the parent company of the $7.3billion Crocker Bank in San Francisco, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings in the fourth quarter of 1972 were $9.4million, or 91 cents a share, up 5.7 per cent from the $8.9million, or 85 cents a share earned in the final three months of 1971.

title: Shrinking Da Nang Base Has Severe Morale Problem
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 (UPI)When United States jets accidentally bombed this big allied air base on Monday, the resident American servicemen took itin stride.

title: COURT NARROWS CANTWELL CHARGE
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12  Two charges that Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell did willfully and knowingly obtain from the State of New Jersey a thing of value not lawfully and justly due him Were dropped by the court today as the trial of the retired head of the state's Defense Department approachedthe Mercer County trial jury's deliberations on a verdict.

title: Dining Out In New Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, dcor and service (four triangles to none.)

title: The Dangerous Reactors
description: SAN FRANCISCOIf a nuclear reactor loses its coolant, the fuel can become a hot atomic puddle and melt out into the environment to produce a possible catastrophe involving perhaps a million deaths. The threat of such cataclysmfrom failure of design or operation, from act of God or saboteuris great enough that the Atomic Energy Commission requires backup emergency cooling system sound enough to prevent the disaster.

title: Governor Calls Brennan A Great Labor Leader
description: Peter J. Brennan, who is awaiting confirmation as Secretary of Labor, was praised by Governor Rockefeller last night as a great labor leader, a patriotic American and a man with tremendous concern about equal opportunity for all.

title: CITY WITHDRAWING PROM HIRING PLAN
description: Mayor Lindsay announced, yesterday that the city was immediately withdrawing from the New York Plan, established two years ago to increase the number of minority workers in the buildingconstruction trades, because the city was very disappointed with the plan's results.

title: 3 Democratic Economists Back Phase 3 Structure and Principles
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The last three Democratic chairmen of the President's Council of Economic Advisers approved today the basic structure and principles of President Nixon's Phase 3 antiinflation program for influencing prices and wages.

title: An American Family Sees Itself on TV
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.Why would a family allow a camera crew to spend seven months filming the intimate details of its life and then show the results on national television?

title: 3 Landlord Groups File a Suit Against City's Rent Program
description: The city's program for gradually increasing controlled rents was denounced yesterday by representatives of three large realestate groups who said they were going to court to seek relief from what they termed its ineptitude and unfairness.

title: FLU NOW EXCEEDS EPIDEMIC LEVEL
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 12 (UPI)The Center for Disease Control said today that deaths from influenza and pneumonia this winter across the country had moved above the epidemic threshold for the first time.

title: Notes on People
description: Jacob D. Beam, the United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, is retiring from the Foreign Service. The 64yearold career diplomat has held the Moscow post since March, 1969. Neither the American Embassy in Moscow, nor the State Department, indicated who might be the new Ambassador after Mr. Beam leaves Jan. 24. Mr. Beam was Ambassador to Poland from 1957 to 1962, then served as deputy director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency before becoming Ambassador to Czechoslovakia in 1966. In Prague, he was considered to have distinguished himself representing Washington during the Sovietled invasion of Czechoslovakia in August, 1968. In Moscow, he was known as calm, affable, firm and, standing about 6 feet 2 inches tall, he usually towered above his colleagues in the diplomatic corps.

title: Chris Evert Tennis Togs: Netting a Bundle at Age 18
description: In the last two years of her booming tennis career, Chris Evert has been called many things: America's Sweetheart, Little Miss Sunshine, Miss Chrisma, and Cinderella in Sneakers.

title: Brothers Get Long: Terms For Supermarket Holdup
description: Two brothers, convicted last Nov. 14 of the armed robbery of a Brooklyn supermarket in 1971, were given long prison terms yesterday after they were described by Justice Louis B. Heller as two Jesse James brothers who were a danger to the community.

title: Policeman Wounded as He Goes To Check on a Family Quarrel
description: A patrolman was shot in the right shoulder yesterday afternoon as lie entered an apartment on the Upper West Side with an elderly man who had complained that his son, a Bronx County probation officer, had assaulted him in a family dispute.

title: AMEX DROP SERTS 8MONTH RECORD
description: The American Stock Exchange incurred its biggest loss in over eight months yesterday in heavy trading.

title: Australian Press Appoints
description: The appointment of George T. McGann as United States manager and editor of Australian Consolidated Press, Ltd,, was announced yesterday. Mr. McGann replaces J. B. Davies, who has retired. Australian Consolidated Press operates number of newspapers, magaines and television stations.

title: CarMishap Victim Lay In a Ravine 10 Hours
description: CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP)A 50yearold Queens College librarian whose car jumped a low stone wall in this rural Putnam County community last night lay unnoticed in a ravine for 10 hours in subfreezing weather, the police reported.

title: Sun to Block Satellite
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP)Pioneer 10, the unmanned satellite bound for Jupiter, will be out of touch with its controllers here for three days next week because of massive radio interference from the sun, the Ames Research Center said today. The interference Monday through Wednesday will occur when the earth, sun and Pioneer 10 are positioned in a straight line, with the sun between the earth and satellite, a spokesman said.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: More East Germans Are Fleeing to West
description: BONN, Jan. 12West Germany's policy of improving relations with its neighbors to the east has had the unexpected effect of encouraging more and more East Germans to risk their lives in fleeing to the west.

title: InauguralConcert Work Deleted as Not in Spirit
description: A work composed for the official inaugural concert to be played by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Kennedy Center in Washington on Jan. 19 has been deleted from the program by the Presidential Inaugural Committee.

title: DR. PHILIP COSGROVE, SCHOOL PRINCIPAL
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 13Dr. Philip J. Cosgrove, principal of the Morris Avenue School in Rockville Centre since 1966, died today in Nassau Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Hempstead.

title: Miss Hoffman Fiancee
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., Jan. 13The engagement of Miss Hildergarde Hoffman to Henry Agatstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Agatstein of Flushing, Queens, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Hoffman. The future bride's mother is managing editor of the BookoftheMonth Club.

title: City's Election Board Moves To Guarantee Orderly Voting
description: The city's Board of Elections faced with one of the most difficult election years in its history and under fire following, widespread irregularities in last year's primary and general electionshas made a series of moves in an effort to insure an orderly mayoral primary, runoff and regular election this. year.

title: State Seeks to Refine School Goals
description: TRENTONThe first of a series of volunteer task forces will be convened here on Jan. 30, their purpose being to help the state define the goals of quality education and achieve them in the classroom.

title: Glassboro Educating New Breed Of Teacher
description: GLASSBORO  Glassboro State College is educating a new breed of high school English teacher, one trained to combine the traditional English curriculum with the recent emphasis on communications and the mass media.

title: Women are pursued, tortured, enslaved, raped and in one instance devoured by men
description: A note of warning: The brief review that follows is a survey of 10 secondtofifthrank Gothic novels newly reissued in an ambitious and praiseworthy series. The 17 uniform red and black volumes, totaling 6,154 pages are before me on my table, flaunting, 17 times, the redbat emblem which, in the obligatory shorthand of publishing industry bookdesigners signals the buyer that the book he sees is meant to be scary. In fact, most of the novels in this series are infinitely more interesting for the terrors about love and death that they conceal or soothe than for any they actually induce.

title: Pots and Pans and Eggs
description: THE exhibition of recent paintings by the British artist, William Scott, now on view at the Martha Jackson Gallery, 32 East 69th Street through Feb. 10, not only offers us the work of a highly talented artist, last seen here a decade ago, it also recalls an interesting bit of cultural history.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER BLUES, 5 TO 3
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 13A pair of firstperiod goals by Steve Vickers within 48 seconds and agile goaltending by Eddie Giacomin lifted the New York Rangers to a 53 triumph over the St. Louis Blues in a nationally televised National Hockey League game today.

title: New Bagel Shaper Takes a Page From Rube Goldberg
description: Two million bagels were baked and sold last year at Bagel Stop, at 69th Road and Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills. The bakery expects to sell considerably more than that this year, but there will be a difference because the bagels will not be made by hand as they have been for decades.

title: The Super Bowl? What Super Bowl?
description: Irene Lopez plans to skip Super Bowl VII today so she can go skydiving at the Ripcord ParaCenter in Medford, N.J.

title: The essay on essays, for instance, is a model of the genre
description: I feel about Thrall & Hibbard as E. B. White once did about Strunk (& White), that it is a work of peculiar art and distinctive value not frequently enough acknowledged. My own copy of A Handbook to Literature is the 12th of I do not know how many printings of the first (1936) edition, and it was bought secondhand for $1, marked down from $1.75, about 15 years ago. My fondness for that battered book, which has survived a halfdozen moves, undoubtedly has something to do with the fact that it helped me pass strategic (factual) exam at an early stage in my graduate education, but were it not such a useful vade mecum to the study of literature, it could not have been the help it was. So far as I am concerned, Thrall & Hibbard has no match among ready reference books, if what one wishes is conciseness without parsimony.

title: The Young Meet the Old and Both Learn
description: UNIONDALE, L. I.  Although old age tends to be a frightening mystery to many of the young, a group of college students is confronting the effects of aging in a course taught entirely at the county oldage home.

title: Miss Linda Greene, Editor, Betrothed
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., Jan. 13Miss Linda Greene, education editor and reporter for The Asbury Park Sunday Press, plans to be married Feb. 25 to Lawrence W. Feinberg, a reporter for The Washington Post.

title: JOSHUA SPRAYREGEN
description: Joshua Sprayregen, a former assistant corporation counsel for the city and an early Zionist leader, died Thursday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 93 years old and lived here.

title: Watergate Mystery, Comedy, etc. And Dirty Tricks
description: WASHINGTON  Scandal, like a lot of other things, never quite made it as an issue in the 1972 Presidential campaign. Last week, with the election two months past and the Inauguration at hand, there were some footnotes and some entirely new chapters in the scandal dossier.

title: Dorothy Toby, Alexander Coxe To Wed April 7
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Jan, 13Miss Dorothy Carroll Toby and Alexander Brown Coxe of New York, Tulane University graduates, have made plans to be married April 7 in Summit, N. J.

title: Suffolk to Test New Potato
description: ITHICA, N. Y.  After 16 years of experiments, a new kind of potato has been developed here that promises to outproduce existing potatoes on the farm, to taste better, and to resist the golden nematode, major potato pest on Long Island.

title: Lee McCarthy Bride of S. K. Huber
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Jan. 13 Miss Lee C. McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. McCarthy, was mangled here this afternoon in the chapel of the Congregational Church of Manhasset to Stephen Kurt Huber. He is a son of Dr. Annita Huber of Kingg Point, L. I., a psychiatrist, and of Dr. Wolfgang Huber of Palo Alto, Calif., founder and vice president of Diagnostic Data, Inc.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SEVERAL highly dramatic developmentsnot all of which were pleasant and favorableoccurred in the economic and political worlds last week. These events raised serious questions about the influence they will exert on the course of the nation's economy 1973, a year that many analysts have predicted could turn out to be historic.

title: Frank B. Gilbert Will Marry Miss Ann Hersh on April 8
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 13Mrs. Louis Hersh has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Hersh of Philadelphia, to Frank Brandeis Gilbert, son of Mrs. Jacob H. Gilbert of New York and the late Mr. Gilbert.

title: PUZZLES
description: ACROSS

title: DYE IS WINNER AT 1,000 YARDS
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 13Byron Dyce outran a stellar field and won the invitation 1,000 run tonight, at the Knights of Columbus track met which marked the sport's debut at the Nassau Coliseum. Dyce's time was 2 minutes 10.7 seconds.

title: Doctors Urge Repeal of Laws on Rubella Vaccination
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13An editorial in one of the nation's leading medical journals advocates the repeal of laws requiring the vaccination of young children against rubella, also known as German measles.

title: Supercabinet
description: When Mayor John Lindsay reorganized various small departments into a few larger and seemingly more logical units, Robert F. Wagner, his battlescarred predecessor, dryly commented: Superagencies are all right if you can find supermen to run them. After seven years on the firing line at City Hall, Mayor Lindsay would probably concede today that there is some merit in that comment.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: May I correct some of the misstatements of fact in John Lewis Gaddis's review of my book, Peace in the Balance?

title: Arts Are Brought to Bergen Pupils
description: RIDGEWOOD  Harold Lieberman, a jazz trumpet player, raised his horn, and out came the first few bars of Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.

title: Oxford, Miss., Which Faulkner Transcended, Is As He Left It
description: I write about Oxford because it's all I know. I've lived here all my life and anytime I've been away I come back as soon as possible. William Faulkner

title: CITY ACTS TO RAISE SAFETY IN SCHOOLS
description: Mayor Lindsay announced three steps in school security yesterday that he said would help bring a sense of peace and stability to city classrooms.

title: Man Who Cared Is Remembered
description: Norman N. Weiss, a teacher of Puerto Rican history in Public, School 1 in the Bronx, told his pupils about the life of Roberto Clemente, the Pittsburgh Pirate player who died in a plane crash taking relief supplies to Nicaragua. As a followup exercise the children, all 9 years old, submitted letters entitled Why the world should remember Roberto Clemente. These were some of the letters.

title: LowPolluting Car Developed by Pratt
description: A team of students from Pratt Institute has developed a relatively safe, lowpolluting automobile.

title: CORONA STRICKEN AWAITING VERDICT
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 13A jury of 10 men and two women continued today to deliberate the fate of Juan V. Corona, the 38yearold Mexican national accused of mass murder.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS INTEGRATION AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The public has become so distracted by misleading emphasis on school busing that the nation's commitment to quality education for disadvantaged children is in jeopardy, the majority of a special Senate subcommittee said today.

title: Commercials Against Commercials? Why Not?
description: Writing on this page on Dec. 24, Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, took a negative view of a Government proposal to permit countercommercialscommercials that would rebut the claims of the commercials regularly shown to viewers. Mr. Goodman said the proposal threatens to cripple broadcasting by driving away advertisers who pay not only for entertainment programing but also for news and public affairs coverage. The proposal, he concluded, is the complete antithesis of the public interest. In this article, Nicholas Johnson, of the Federal Communications Commission, defends the proposal.

title: Headliners
description: Gesundheit!

title: Rumania Stresses Heavy Industry
description: BUCHAREST  This independentminded Communist country pushed industrial development hard in 1972, and plans to push it even harder in 1973. Rumania is holding firm to a conviction that steel, machinebuilding, chemical production and other components of heavy industry are an essential base for secure sovereignty and a modem society.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Employment is up nationally and so is the helpwanted advertising index but for unemployed professionals  engineers, scientists and technicians  it is still largely a buyers' market as far as jobs are concerned.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Drug Panel, Concluding a 6Nation Tour, Calls For a SteppedUp Drive
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 13The chairman of the United States National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse said here today that the war on drugs should be stepped up on three levelseducation, rehabilitation and police action.

title: For Bloomfield, Parking Is a Problem
description: BLOOMFIELDOur community is based on stability, says Town Administrator H. Joseph North. Only about 1 per cent of our homes are sold each year, and about half of Ahem are bought by other Bloomfield residents. One of our biggest concerns right now is zoning. In March, we will rezone to protect our residential neighborhoods from drive  in restaurants and large apartment structures.

title: Paperbacks
description: FICTION

title: The New Society
description: WASHINGTON  In approximately six months one of the great social experiments of the postWorld War II era willbegin. On July 1 an allvolunteer armed force will come into existence. The most obvious aspect of this experiment is that no one really knows for certain how the military will be affected.

title: Brooklyn and Queens Groups Seeking School District Changes
description: When New York City's School Decentralization Law took effect in 1970, it was to undergo a threeyear test period. Now as the period draws to a close and the terms of the original schoolboard members expire, moves are under way to make changes in decentralization before the next school boards are elected in May.

title: SUPPORT BY CITIZENS CLAIMED BY MANILA
description: MANILA, Jan. 13Government sources said today that citizens' assemblies now meeting throughout the country were continuing to show strong support for President Ferdinand, E.
