Marcos's martiallaw regime and favored his establishing a revolutionary government if this was necessary to carry out reforms he has initiated.

title: AUDIT ASSAILS CITY ON MEDICARE BILLS
description: State auditors have said in a report they believe the city's hospital system failed to bill for substantial amounts of money owed it for services to Medicare patients given ambulatory care at outpatient clinics.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES EFFECT OF COMPOZ
description: Compoz, which is advertised as the largestselling nonprescription sedative for temporary relief of simple nervous tension, has been found in a carefully controlled study to be no more effective than aspirin or a milksugar placebo.

title: Temple's Defense Stymies Fordham Quintet, 79 to 57
description: Temple's tenacious zone defense harassed Fordham into 35.3 per cent fieldgoal accuracy last night and the Owls rolled to a 7957 victory. It was the Ram's first loss at home in two years.

title: Teller Consults Thais On NuclearDug Canal
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 13 (AP)Dr. Edward Teller, the American scientist regrded as father of the hydrogen bomb, has arrived in Bangkok to discuss whether it would be possible to cut a canal across the Kra Isthmus in southern Thailand by means of nuclear excavation.

title: Phase 3 or Phaseout?
description: In announcing his Phase 3 wageprice program, President Nixon has made a switch almost as shocking as when he announced his wageprice freeze on a Sunday night in August a year and a half ago. But this time he has zigged back toward his original philosophy.

title: 30 Members of Three Street Gangs Donate Blood Here
description: Members of three street gangs donated a pint of blood each yesterday at the New York Blood Center, at 310 East 67th Street.

title: How America's Goose Was Cooked
description: PERHAPS the most significant aspect of Alistair Cooke's manypart program America is that this first major and extensive examination of American history ever done on television was left for the British to conceive. Only when the BBC got moving did major American corporationsTimeLife Films and subsequently Xerox and NBCjoin in a project which no American group had ever had the vision and courage to undertake. Although Cooke's series, as revealed in the first four episodes, leaves much to be desired, we are surely getting more than we deserve. It may indeed seem churlish to raise negative questions. Yet, the picture of our own heritage presented to millions of Americans is too serious a a matter to be passed over with a courteous bow.

title: Point of View
description: PARIS  I am inclined to thinkas strongly as everthat the setting up of an international monetary system based as much as possible on a gold standard would be the most rational solution to the world's monetary problems.

title: The Beautiful World of Este Lauder
description: At 39, Leonard A. Lauder has replaced his mother as president of Este Lauder, Inc., the $100million cosmetics company bearing her name.

title: No Day for the Tube to Conk Out
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13lt will take 180 National Broadcasting Company employes and $200,000 in oneday expenses to bring the Super Bowl game into America's living rooms, but only five of these people will be seen or heard in public.

title: Medicarelessness
description: Congress, which voted last year to extend Medicare benefits to patients needing renal dialysis or kidney transplants, is learning to its dismay that in roughly a decade this provision may require annual expenditures of a billion dollars. Even so knowledgeable a Congressional specialist on health problems as Representative Paul G. Rogers of Florida has admitted publicly that we in Congress had no idea that costs would be anywhere near that large.

title: ONE JUROR BALKS IN HIJACKING CASE
description: A lone juror holding out for acquittal in an airplane hijacking trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn demanded yesterday to be excused from further deliberation because, she said, she had been subjected to insults and physical, verbal and emotional pressure to change her mind.

title: Dianying, Electric Shadows
description: We swim easily in our mass entertainment sea. We have come to take such things for granted: popular TV shows, the big games, recordbreaking movies, bestselling books, daily newspapers. We don't usually bother to analyze them, though we may point out an occasional peccadillo, such as the dirty movie ousting the Western, the amount of advertisements in a halfhour television show, or the gladiatorial aspects of a bigtime football game.

title: Wine Makers Toast Vintage Prices
description: A sudden and apparently unquenchable thirst for wine is sweeping the developed nations of the world, wreaking major changes in the wine market and creating vast new opportunities for wineproducing countries.

title: Yugoslays: Global Engineers
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia One of the resulting economic benefits of Yugoslavia's nonaligned political position between East and West is reflected in a striking growth of the country's construction and engineering activity in developing countries that remain wary of political influences from either side.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Seventh Avenue is looking to youth to stimulate interest in women's apparel and to combat competition from imports.

title: Costs The Bill Could Have Been Worse
description: In no area does President Nixon's approach to voluntary wageprice controls present a greater anomaly than in the field of healthcare prices.

title: Brooklyn's TV Station Is Honored
description: At the annual awards presentation of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences Friday night, a group of schoolteachers who run a television station in Brooklyn were a bit disappointed that they did not win an Emmy, though they had received four nominations.

title: New and Recommended
description: COLLECTED POEMS OF JOHN WHEELWRIGHT, edited by Alvin H. Rosenfeld. (New Directions, $12.50.) The resurrection of a neglected American poet who produced a body Of work of charm, gravity and invention.

title: Sugar Loaf Makes Its Way, Literally
description: GREED, it sounds suspiciously like a puton. Only in some Disneyfied version of America could there be a craftsmen's village called Sugar Loaf, whose chief character is a rosynatured Arkansasborn duckhunting woodcarver named Jarvis Boone, a descendant of Daniel Boone. But as it happens there is a woodcarver named Jarvis Boone, a descendant of Daniel, and he does live in a place called Sugar Loaf, which does happen to be a village of craftsmen. Well, almost.

title: Fight Shaping Up on Tax Credit for Catholic Students
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 13A sharp emotional struggle is shaping up over renewed attempts to provide Federal aid for Roman Catholic and other nonpublic education.

title: THIEU SAID TO BAR A HANOI PROPOSAL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13  A legislator closely associated with President Nguyen Van Thieu said this week that before the latest round of Paris peace talks began North Vietnam had proposed a compromise on the issue of Saigon's sovereignty by a draft article referring to three state administrations, as parties to the accord.

title: In Search Of Dracula
description: Hair grows on the palms of Dracula's hands. His ears are long and pointed. His red eyes glare out from under thick eyebrows that meet over a knife of a nose. His red, swollen lips are flagrant against the nacreous glimmer of his face, with its extraordinary pallor, its long, white mustache, its prominent teeth. His breath is rank. He dresses always in an indecent black. He is centuries old and unnaturally strong.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: I FEEL it is important to reply to Hilton Kramer's two recent articles covering the Sam Francis exhibition which I organized. Mr. Kramer has failed to review the artist's work, opting instead to add another sorry chapter to a long and predictable story between Mr. Francis's generally accepted accomplishment and the seeming inability of, some New York critics to admit to his significance.

title: WAR PROTESTS HELD IN TWO BOROUGHS
description: Antiwar groups in Manhattan and Brooklyn took advantige of the sunny, relatively K'arm afternoon yesterday to Walk through neighborhoods to protest the continuation of the war in Vietnam.

title: Mary Cooke to Wed
description: MEDIA, Pa., Jan. 13Mr. and Mrs. M. Todd Cooke have announced the engagement of Mr. Cooke's daughter, Miss Mary Marshall Cooke, to Alan McDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace McDonald of Deerfield, Mass. Miss Cooke, daughter also of the late Mrs. Mary Toland Cooke, and her fiance are seniors at Stanford Olivereity.

title: Jazz
description: Groups led by two musicians who draw on their African heritage In somewhat different ways were heard in a joint concert Friday night at Carnegie Hall. Randy Weston's African Rhythm drew very directly on contemporary African melodies, rhythm and styles, while the music of Hubert Laws's AfroClassic Ensemble was touched only peripherally by African influences.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y, 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Miss Hammill Fiancee
description: EASTON, Conn., Jan. 13Mr. and Mrs. M. Willett Hammill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Willett Hammill, to Raymond James Moskal of Ringwood, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Moskal of Dundee, N. Y. Miss Hammill is descended frbm Marinus Willett, an early Mayor of New York. Mr. Moskal teaches at the RamapoIndian Hills High School in Franklin Lakes, N. J.

title: Prof. Maureen Ann McDermott Weds
description: PARK RIDGE, N. J., Jan. 13 Miss Maureen Ann McDermott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. McDermott of River Vale, was married here this afternoon to Barry Craig Westerland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emery H. Westerland of Mahopac, N. Y.

title: Lumber Costs Smashing Control Barriers
description: Lumber and plywood prices, which rose sharply last year, are expected to continue their spiral in 1973, with higher costs being passed on to the buyers of new homes.

title: The Mideasta Developing Investor
description: BEIRUT, LebanonThe Arab Middle East holds the strange position among developing nations of having more money than it knows how to use inside the region.

title: Europeans Reexamine Goals
description: PARISThe world became a smaller place in 1972, but Western Europe became a little bigger. The globe contracted as the United States stepped across Iron and Bamboo frontiers to search for sounder economic and political relationships with the Soviet Union and China.

title: State Panel Deplores Waste and Duplication in Social Services
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13A state commission now in its fourth year of studying the state's Department of Social Services has found a vast bureaucracy pouring billions of dollars year into thousands of overlapping public and voluntary social agencies without any clear idea of what is happening with the money.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: More Nuclear Power Will Be Lighting Up Those Long Swedish Nights
description: STOCKHOLMThe sun is a reluctant visitor to Stockholm at this season of the year. It comes for just a few hours each day. It is niggardly with its light. And there is no real warmth in its smile.

title: Major Disparities in U.S. Sentencing Here Are Found in a Study
description: OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 13 Dramatic disparities in prison sentences were emphasized in a Federal sentencing study released today by United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr.

title: Russi of Switzerland Is First In World Cup Downhill Skiing
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 13 (AP)Bernhard Russi, an Olympic gold medal winner, and Roland Collombin, the World Cup leader, gave Switzerland a 1, 2 sweep today in a downhill ski race that was marked by four spectacular spills.

title: Seed Catalogues Suggest House Plant Growing
description: THE most popular time to sow houseplan seed is now when new seed catalogues temp gardeners with exciting list ings and the days begin to lengthen again.

title: Blackout in Westchester Affects 4,900 in 3 Towns
description: Some 4,900 Consolidated Edison customers in sections of Rye, Harrison and Mamaroneck in Westchester County were blacked out last night when 13,000volt feeder cable failed.

title: Court Backs Dropped Teachers' Fight
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn has ruled that the appeals process available to nontenured New York City school teachers who have been dismissed from their posts is unconstitutional.

title: Lag in Real Growth Vexes Anxious Italy
description: ROMEItaly's crisis could be defined in a brief phrase, the president of the proud Fiat Motor Company, Gianni Angnelli, said recently: Zero profits.

title: Paris Riot Police Disperse AntiMeir Demonstrators
description: PARIS, Jan. 13Heavy elements of French riot policemen ripped into scattered groups of demonstrators protesting the presence of Premier Golda Meir of Israel here today as Socialist leaders from 18 countries opened a twoday meeting of the Socialist International.

title: DR. JOHN E. MATHEWS
description: GLOVERSVILLE, N. Y. Jan. 13 (AP)Dr. John E. Mathews, superintendent of the Gloversville Enlarged School District since 1966, died today. He was 51 years old.

title: Sports Week
description: BASKETBALL

title: When Dolley Madison Was Belle of the Ball
description: WASHINGTON  President James Madison complained that he would rather he home in bed, and more than a century later Calvin Coolidge did stay home in bed....

title: Laver Choice in Tennis
description: MIAMI, Jan. 13 (AP)Rod Laver will be in his usual role as favorite Wednesday when the 1973 tour of World Championship of Tennis opens with the $50,000 Saga Bay Tennis Classic here. Laver, tennis' career leading money winner, has been topseeded for the event at the University of Miami.

title: What Makes Poseidon Fun?
description: ARK movies are easy to describe: a group of assorted characters (two of each is the accepted way) are put aboard an ocean liner, in an airplane, or maybe on a bridge that clearly looks unsafe to us but to no one within the film. In short order (the shorter the better for this sort of thing to be successful), the bridge collapses, the ocean liner starts sinking, or the airplane threatens to crash (though two out of three times it doesn't), which is the easiest way to explain survivors in Ark Movies about airplanes, most air crashes being so fatal. This is also the factor that makes Ark Movies about airplanes seem such gyps.

title: JAKE M'CANDLESS QUITS PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 13 Citing differences of opinion with various Princeton officials, including the new athletic director, Jake McCandless resigned today as coach of the school's football team.

title: Recordings: From Marx to Merman
description: HE is not the leering, nervy, cynical, quickwitted, fasttalking con man who loped through those 13 film comedies made between the years 192949. nor is he the leedlerinresidence who blithely insulted the contestants and then suggested that they say the secret word during a 14year reign as quizmasterringleader of You Bet Your Life. The mellow Groucho Marx of An Evening with Groucho (A&M SP 3515, 2 disks) is an 82yearold comedian who suddenly felt the urge to work again and wound up in concert at Carnegie Hall on May 6, 1972 before a multiaged audience of fanatical Marx Brothers fans.

title: Rebecca Young Plans Nuptials
description: WHITFORD, Pa., Jan. 13The engagement of Miss Rebecca Lukens Young to Christopher M. Royston has been announced by her father, John Randolph Young. Mr. Royston is a son of Mrs. John P. Royston of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mr. Royston.

title: Los Angeles Faces Auto Curbs
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13The Environmental Protection Agency, under court orders, will prescribe drastic measures Monday for alleviating smog in Los Angeles by 1977.

title: HighWire Record Set
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI)Karl Wallenda, 67 years old, broke the world's indoor long distance highwire walking record last night by going 640 feet along a onequarterinch cable 120 feet above the floor of the Astrodome. It took him 12 minutes.

title: Minority Leader Praises Administration on Shipping
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) Gerald R. Ford, Republican of Michigan, the House minority leader, said this week that the Administration had a record of solid achievements in its efforts to rebuild and revitalize the United States merchant marine and maritime industry.

title: Yonkers Judge's Home Is Target of Fire Bomb
description: A milk bottle full of gasoline exploded in front of the home of a Yonkers judge last night, setting fire to a row of evergreens and scorching some columns on the portico.

title: Thieu Asks an Invasion of North If Paris Peace Negotiations Fail
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam, in an interview made public today, said that if ctrrent peace efforts failed, the United States and South Vietnam hould step up the war in all possible ways, including an invasion of North Vietnam.

title: EFTA Forgotten But Not Gone
description: GENEVA  Forgotten but not gonethis reversal of the old saw aptly describes the fate of the European Free Trade Association now that it has virtually submerged itself within the broader zone of economic integration of Western Europe.

title: Redskins 2Point Choice In Football's Showdown
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13  Mercury Morris and Larry Brown, two running backs whose skill and style set the pace for their teams, will largely determine the outcome of tomorrow's Super Bowl game between the Miami Dolphins and the Washington Redskins.

title: Letters: Greenland
description: To the Editor: The most interesting article on Greenland in the Travel Section of Dec. 10 (... Misnamed Greenland Plays for Draw With the Ice, by Warren Unna) did not mention one of the best ways, not only to get there, but to enjoy Greenland when once there.

title: Anne M. Reiss Fiancee Of John McCormack 3d
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 13Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Julian Reiss have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Mary Reiss, to John William McCormack 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McCormack Jr. of Boston and Falmouth, Mass. The couple plan to be married in June.

title: North Stars Trounce Islanders by 81
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 13 (AP)Minnesota, with Dean Prentice getting a goal that tied him for 11th place in the National Hockey League's career scoring list, routed the New York Islanders, 81, tonight.

title: Are These O'Casey's Brawling Irish
description: SOMEBODY at the Vivian Beaumont is going to have to teach people to brawl. Or, rather, someone is going to have to introduce the actors in Sean O'Casey's The Plough and the Stars to one another so that they can mingle long enough, brush shoulders hard enough, breathe clown one another's necks often enough to want to brawl. The text requires that these Dubliners go to it wherever they arelit pubs, on timeworn front stoops, in bulletridden attics and on the slightest or mightiest of provocations. A wife fighting for possession Of her husband's conscience will do battle as fiercely, and is physically, as a couple of crones squabbling over the baby carriage each needs if she is going to manage a spot of looting. Claws go out to grip shawls or uniforms. But the players at the Beaumont have a tentative reach. They attack on cue, having memorized the play, but there is neither strength in the thrust nor solidity in the resistance. They are so many puppies shaking lifeless rag dolls.

title: Shula: Tough, Practical And a LowKey Coach
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13When he was a teenager, Don Shula finished another football game on the playgrounds of Painesville, Ohio, and snatched his jacket off a ledge where he had secured it with a brick. Shula forgot about the brick, which broke his nose.

title: Aborted Everglades Jetport Has FlightaMinute Traffic
description: THE EVERGLADES, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP)  A bird flapped out of a thicket as a 727 jetliner roared out of the clouds to land on a twomile strip carved in the sawgrass sea of the Everglades.

title: To Allen, Winning Is Living
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 George Allen received his master's degree in physical education from the University of Michigan in 1948 and the title of his thesis was A study of outstanding football coaches' attitudes and practices in scouting. The document had 176 pages of appendices.

title: McGuire Key Base In NATO Exercise
description: McGUIRE MR FORCE BASE  Fourengine jet transports loaded with troops and cargo began moving through this base last week as part of the Reforger IV exercise taking the Army's First Infantry Division from Fort Riley, Kan., to three North Atlantic Treaty bases in Germany.

title: Music: Bananafish Park's Sound
description: A block and a half from the Narrows, under the twinkling lights of the Verrazano Bridge, lies Bananafish Park, Bay Ridge's home of rock n roll and other contemporary music.

title: 10 Killed in Kampala Fire
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan, 13 (AP)A gasoline truck overturned in the center of this East African city today and a crowd quickly gathered to collect leaking fuel, Then someone dropped a lighted cigarette and the truck burst Into flame. Officials reported that 10 persons had been burned to death and 70 others were taken to hospitals with severe burns.

title: Mel Schumacher to Wed Alphon Moore
description: The engagement of Miss Alphon Joanne Moore, daughter of Mrs. Andrea E. Moore of Chappaqua, N. Y., and Carroll G. Moore of Stamford, Conn., to Mel A. Schumacher of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Schumacher of Williamsville, N.Y., and Balbao Island, Calif has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I believe whatever Waverley Root tells me. My respect for the writer of The Foods of France is unlimited. If he tells me that the food at Paul Bocuse's is fantastic, I'm sure it is.

title: Religion
description: Margo Bloom and seven other students from Hampshire College left recently on a sixweek trip to Europe. But instead of visiting museums and other usual tourist attractions, they are visiting the sites of World War H concentration camps. The mass killing of six million Jews by the Nazis was an event that changed what we call Western civilization, Miss Bloom said in explaining the unusual itinerary.

title: Australian Plans Mass Directed at Aboriginals
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 13 (UPI)  The Rev. Hilton Deakin says he will celebrate a special mass next month in Melbourne to pray for more goannas and other lizards and for full water holes.

title: Grimm's Chauvinist Pigs!
description: Are fairy tales harmless reading fare for children? No, say the proponents of a fair deal for little girls. Most of these tales, the critics say, teach the gospel of a sexist, male chauvinist society.

title: Lindsay Proclamation Is Tribute to Dr. King
description: Mayor Lindsay issued a proclamation yesterday praising the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as an extraordinary human being and designating tomorrow as Martin Luther King Day. Jan. 15 was the civil rights leader's birthday.

title: Ondine Takes Early Lead In 3,500Mile Yacht Race
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 13, ReutersThe American racing ketch Ondine swept into an early lead when 39 yachts left Table Bay today at the start of the 3,500 nautical mile CapetowntoRio de Janeiro race.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Play It Again, Woody
description: NOW that the winningly wicked Woody Allen has told you Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex, he's set to tell you everything you always wanted to know about a not excessively sexy clarinet player who blows his cool over a delicious, pleasuremad dilettante. Allen's new movie, which he describes as a romance between two people who are an unlikely match and who are at one another's throat from the beginning, will be called Sleeper and is based on an original screenplay by Allen and Marshall Brickman. Jack Grossberg will producd the film for Jack RollinsCharles Joffe Productions awl, like Sex, Sleeper will fly the United Artists ??nner.

title: Let it ruin, let it pour
description: With the kind of weather we've been having this winter, the most useful part of anyone's wardrobe is rainwear. And then there are all those spring showers to look forward to! Brave them in a classic raincoat done the Haiston way, a floral coat tailored by Anne Klein, a battle jacket and jeans by Bill Blass or a safari jacket and skirt from Calvin Klein.

title: Why Radcliffe women are afraid of success
description: Research by Matina Horner, now Radcliffe's president may help explain why. She asked college students, male and female, to write brief stories based on almost identical cues. Below, one typical male Q and A (at left) and four feminine responses.

title: Biggest Jerusalem Hotel
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 (AP)The 600room Diplomat Hotel, Jerusalem's largest, has been opened on the former border between Israel and Jordan, Israel captured the area in 1967.

title: ADVOCACY AGENCY FOR CHILDREN URGED
description: A $97,000 study commissioned by the Federal Office of Child Development has concluded that that agency should stop administering child welfare programs and start seeing that other agencies do.

title: Yugoslav Puzzle
description: Yugoslavia is enveloped in troubles these days, and the measures being taken to meet those troubles are producing evergreater astonishmentand concern. The news from Belgrade in recent months has dealt with widespread political purges, growing economic difficulties, a minicultural revolution almost reminiscent of Peking's experiment in this direction and even some unaccustomed saberrattling at that most unlikely of targets: small, peaceloving and neutralized Austria.

title: Rita Wasserstein to Be Married
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Wasserstein of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Wasserstein, to Kenneth E. Warner, son of Mrs. Arthur G. Warner of New York and Pittsfield, Mass., and the late Mr. Warner.

title: HOWARD IS UPSET BY LOSS OF TITLE
description: The National Soccer Coaches Association of America ended its threeday convention here yesterday with 351 in attendance seemingly happy and one, Lincoln Phillips, Howard University's coach, bitter.

title: PENN FIVE DOWNS PRINCETON, 5853
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13Pennsylvania took a hesitant step toward the Ivy League basketball title today by defeating Princeton, 5853, in a regionally televised contest before 5,300 spectators in Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Italy's Pollution
description: ROMEAcross the lagoon from the old city of Venice, the huge petrochemical complex in Porto Marghera regularly sends out fumes that pollute the air over the whole area. Residents of Venice cough and wipe their eyes. whenever La Margherina, the easterly breeze from the mainland; wafts the fumes to St. Mark's Square.

title: WNTI: AllGirl Radio Station in 5th Year
description: HACKETTSTOWN  I know that no one is listening to me, declared 19yearold Heather Still about her weekly radio program on WNTI, the Centenary College FM station. I'm closed up in a little booth, and I'm sure I'm the only one listening to me.

title: Natural, Not Special Ties
description: LONDONWhen Prime Minister Edward Heath visits President Nixon in Washington Feb. 1 and 2, it will be the first time he has seen the American chief of state not only as head of the British Government but also as representative of one of nine partners in the European Community which the United Kingdom joined just a fortnight ago.

title: How Do You Photograph A Cry or a Whisper?
description: WHEN a director dies he becomes a photographer. So said John Grierson, the late British film critic and pioneer of the documentary form, of the Josef von Sternberg  Charlie Chaplin 1926 film, A Woman of the Sea. He went on: If one cannot by taking thought add a cubit to one's stature, one can no more by great gifts of photography add power to a feeble story.

title: Good, Better, Best, Bette!
description: THEY carried her onstage New Year's Eve in a sedan chair with draped windows; all you could see was a leg waving through an opening in the red velvet.

title: Sihanouk Gets New Pledge Of Assistance From China
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 13 (Reuters)  China renewed her pledge today of military and economic aid to the Cambodian exile government of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: New Help for Consumers
description: MOUNT HOLLYTwo weeks before Christmas, an army of volunteers swooped through area stores, its purpose being to bar the sale of toys deemed unsafe by the Food and Drug Administration. The same volunteers art; now touring supermarlots with a twofold purpose: to determine which ones have unit pricing and to ascertain specific products on which there are wide price differences.

title: '73 Vatican Yearbook Counts 2,172 Dioceses
description: ROME, Jan. 13  The Roman Catholic Church, as of last Nov. 30, had 2,172 dioceses throughout the world, of which 464 were archbishoprics and the remainder bishoprics.

title: Drug Users'Relatives Call Governor's Plan Too Hard on Youths
description: Parents and other relatives of young people who have been involved inand in some cases killed bydrug abuse share the feeling that Governor Rockefeller's proposed drug laws are unduly harsh on youthful addictpushers.

title: Infant Addicts
description: Millions of New Yorkers were reminded last week of a local horror that does not go away: the everrising numbers of infants born addicted to drugs. There on the television screen appeared one example after another of what the WABC report called The Littlest Junkie.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The extraordinary runup in United States farm and food prices  an annual rate of 24 per cent in the last half of 1972, as measured by the wholesale price index  has finally begun to ring some bells here. Among other things, it threatens to wreck the whole antiinflation program.

title: A School for Officials
description: PRINCETONThe days when an amateur could stand for election to public office Or win an appointive post, and get by on his good looks, political connections or native intelligence, are apparently numbered in New Jersey.

description: TEL AVIVCompare these Costs:

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST CITES ORDINATION
description: The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, rabbi emeritus of Temple EmanuEl, the largest Reform Jewish congregation in the world, commemorated the 50th anniversary of his ordination to the rabbinate the other day by sending $50 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Court Test Due for L. I. Rule Barring Handbills
description: ISLIP, L.I.  The Town of Islip will go to court soon in the first legal test of its new ordinance banning the distribution of advertising is becoming more common here as rising postal rates force merchants to find other methods of distribution rather than the mails.

title: Mary Jo Schwalbach, Artist Wed
description: Miss Mary Jo Schwalbach, an artist, was married here yesterday afternoon to Ira Gitler, a writer.

title: New Man in House Knows Ups, Downs
description: WASHINGTONWhen he was attending Georgetown University Law School here in 1953, Angelo D. Roncallo got a parttime job running the House members' elevator at the Capitol.

title: The Folklore of Modern Painting
description: PRINCETON, N. J. OF the painters who made up the first generation of American Abstract expressionists, Robert Motherwell has had in some respects the most manysided career. Trained originally in philosophy, he has long been active as a writer, teacher, lecturer and editor  the new series of Documents of 20thCentury Art, which the Viking Press is now publishing under his editorship, is the most ambitious thing of its kind anyone has yet undertaken  and, in a more general way, he has functioned as a spokesman both for the art of his own generation and for modern art itself more energetically than any other artist in our history. Were his own paintings completely unknown to us, he would still have a place albeit a very different place  in the art history of our time.

title: Europeans Find New Ways to Save
description: Now that the wave of offshore mutual funds that swept across the Continent during the nineteensixties has receded, washing away millions in investments, where are Europeans putting their money?

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Beirut Replaces Cairo As Publishing Mecca
description: BEIRUTThe new, sevenstory headquarters of Al Hawadess, the most successful Arablanguage weekly, stands here as a symbol of the shift of the publishing center of the Arab world from Cairo to this Lebanese capital.

title: Ballet: Fille Mal Gardee Natalia Makarova Dances Lise With Zest and Humor in Romanoff Production
description: Natalia Makarova is that rare creature, a ballerina who is both funny and sexy. Both aspects were well to the fore Friday night at the New York City Center, where Miss Makarova returned to American Ballet Theater dancing Lise in La Fille Mal Garde.

title: Vatican Forms New Panel To Study Needs of Family
description: ROME, Jan. 13The Vatican has announced the creation of a new international Committee for the Family. The body is designed to study and coordinate all efforts to meet the needs of family life in all parts of the world.

title: Was That Fish Icelandic or British?
description: LONDONThe question of who has the right to the fish in the waters of a country's continental shelf has concerned the United Nations the International Court of Justice, the European Economic Community and a number of the world's maritime nations in the last year.

title: Sports
description: Will it bring Mickey Mantle back? Will it fatten the financial average of some of the shaky clubs? Will it lead baseball to football's twoplatoon systemone for offense, one for defense. Will it bring on the specialists?

title: MANHATTAN BEATS ARMY TRACK TEAM
MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market soared on Thursday and then plunged on Friday to end a turbulent week as Wall Street sought to assess the new look in economic controls under Phase 3.

title: French Try Hard To Match No.
description: PARIS  France has the highest growth rate in Western Europe, and President Pompidou's aim is to keep the boom going, not least because of the National Assembly elections coming up in the spring.

title: Trade News
description: The Lambert Brussels Real Estate Corporation and Loeb Rhoades Investment Banking Company have completed the purchase of the BarbizonPlaza Hotel at 106 Central Park South between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue for approximately $11million.

title: The World
description: LONDON  Let them eat Mackerel!

title: PRICE RULE EASED FOR FOOD STORES AND PROCESSORS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Although the food industry remains subject to mandatory controls in Phase 3 of President Nixon's economic stabilization effort, the new regulations have in fact softened the price rules for food processors and distributors.

title: Vislocky Company Shows Freshness In a Spunky Dance
description: It's odd to find oneself enjoying those parts of a dance concert that require a lesser order of physical skill more than those that are obviously more technically accomplished. But the choreographic organization of Dorothy Vislocky's full company pieces had greater freshness than her smaller scaled work, Refractions. She appeared with her company Thursday evening at the Theater of Riverside Church.

title: Combat Ready Triumphs By 4 Lengths, Pays $8.60
description: NEW ORLEANS, Tan. 13 (AP) Leroy Moyers guided Combat Ready to a fourlength victory today in the $20,000 Mississippi Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

title: Tower to Bowser... Over
description: READINGTON Wher Marilyn Solberg leaves her house in the morning to teach at South Plainfield High School, her husband Tho?? gathers up. Heldig, their 6 monthold collie, and heads for the offices of nearby Sol?? berg Airport. Within minutes man and dog are aloft in Mr Solberg's Cessna 150, with Heldig in the passenger's seat and her master set to begin his morning traffic reports for Station WBRW in Somerville.

title: POLL FINDS CRIME EXCEEDS REPORTS
description: A new Gallup poll indicates that actual crime is considerably higher than reported crime.

title: Israel vs. Syria
description: JERUSALEM  The high, desolate plateau has the haunted quality of an old battlefield. The rocky fields are dotted with concrete bunkers built by Syrian soldiers a generation ago. The ceasefire line is marked by the hulking silhouettes of Israeli sandbag emplacements and the small, white shelters of United Nations observers. Israeli farmers plow their fields in armored tractors, stopping now and then to toss aside an old mortar casing or a coil of barbed wire.

title: When a House Changes Hands, There Are A Few Little Extras
description: You have finally bought the ideal house at a price you think you can afford. You have obtained a mortgage, and now you and the seller and couple of lawyers are sitting in an office ready to close the deal.

title: Vietnam
description: Henry A. Kissinger, arriving in Paris aboard a special Mr Force plane, said: President Nixon has sent me back to make one more major effort to conclude the negotiations.

title: Spain Discovers World of Exports
description: MADRID  Iberiamart, or the World Trade Center of Spain, has just opened its doors here and a better demonstration of how the Spanish economy has advanced would be hard to find.

title: Aiken Is Skeptical On Vietnam Pact But Hopes for Best
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Senator George Y. Aiken declared today that President Nixon faces an awful lot of trouble in Congress unless Vietnam peace talks bring a settlement by Inauguration Day, next Saturday, or soon after.

title: Ralph Wood to Marry Miss Karen Murray
description: CHILHOWIE, Va., Jan. 13  Miss Karen Murray, a candidate for a master's degree in speech pathology at Emory University in Atlanta, plans to be married here in June to Ralph K. Wood, who is in his second year at Emory's Law School.

title: K.C. Jones Keeps Making Music Despite Decline of Q's
description: When K. C. Jones was a Boston Celtic he would keep his teammates. loose and entertained in the locker room. If he wasn't mimicking the way rival players walked and talked, he was leading the Boston Celtics in singing.

title: Catholic Schools Seek New Answers
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.At first glance it is the typical open classroom. Children, individually or in small groups, are at work at tables with adults, or in chairs arranged in semicircles, or in clusters on the floor.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 14, 1973

title: At Issue in Britain: The Growth Rate
description: LONDON  Anthony Barber, Chancellor of the Exchequer, predicts confidently that Britain's economic output will grow 5 per cent in 1973, more, than double the rate of recent years.

title: IRISH FIVE UPSETS MARQUETTE, 7169
Brooklyn Boy, 14, Is Held for Killing Girl, 13, With Gun
description: A 14yearold boy was arrested last night after he allegedly shot and killed a 13yearold girl in her apartment in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: SIR FRANCIS FOGARTY
description: ELSTEAD, England, Jan. 13 (AP)  Sir Francis Fogarty, Irishborn pioneer of the Royal Air Force and onetime aide to Queen Elizabeth II, died at his home in this Surrey village yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Ever squeezed by a unicorn?
description: James Thurber's delightful fable about the unicorn in the garden, the husband who saw it eating the roses, and the excited wife who tried to have him locked up but ended up in a straitjacket herself, has a bridge parallel. The unicorn of bridge theory is what the French call le squeeze unicolore. In English this is a onesuit squeeze, a descriptive term that's dull compared to unicorn squeeze, which conveys the right technical idea as well as the idea of great rarity.

title: KISSINGER ENDS USEFUL SESSIONS WITH THO AND RETURNS TO REPORT; SAYS NIXON WILL DECIDE NEXT STEP
description: PARIS, Jan. 13Henry A. Kissinger left Paris tonight to report to President Nixon after six days of what he described as very extensive and very useful negotiations with the North Vietnamese envoy, Le Duc Tho.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Long Island Rail Road strike entered its 46th day today with no negotiations scheduled and no end to the walkout in sight. A. Alfred Della Corte, a Federal mediator, suspended the bargaining indefinitely last week when he found the negotiators for the railroad and the 12 striking unions in a stalemate on productivity and wage issues.

title: Hunters Finding More Deer in Suffolk
description: RIDGE, L. I.As Suffolk County enters its second and final week of the deer hunting season, sportsmen are reporting that the deer are generally healthier than in recent years.

title: Rhodes Plans to Run Again For Ohio Governor in '74
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 13Former Gov. James A. Rhodes announced today he will run for Governor again in 1974.

title: Economics Bridges Golden Delta
description: BRUSSELSThis year the Son of a leading Rotterdam shipping family, the van Beunicens, married the daughter of Leo Delwaide, the head of Antwerp's port administration. The event, which would have been impossible 25 years ago, still raised many eyebrows in 1972.

title: West German Team Is Ranked No. 1 in Horse Show Jumping
description: West Germany dominated the international show jumping world as no team has done before.

title: Miss Mary C. Babcock Affianced
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 13Miss Mary Christine Babcock, employment manager for the Hospital for Special Surgery In New York, plans to be married April 14 at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York to William Clore Fray Jr., a member of the executive personnel department at Macy's, New York.

title: Talent Bank Enlivens Classes
description: TEANECKTeachers here are making frequent and sometimes extraordinary use of the Board of Education's unusual resource bank, some thing known as Operation Community Talent.

title: Art
description: THE exhibition called Him, now at Cordier & Ekstrom, 980 Madison Avenue, is a sort of bridegroom to the one called She, which made its debut at the same gallery two years ago. What next? One about kids called Those or Them? Possibly, but it would have a hard time living up to its parents, and I suspect that the parents themselves, like so many couples who found themselves swindled by biology during the prepill centuries, would be appalled to discover that they had become the latest victims of nature's old shell game. For the females in She were primarily sirens rather than breeders, while the males in Him are primarily peacocks. It is wonderful to imagine all the strutting and preening of their mating dances, but there is no question as to where their interest lies. It lies in strutting and preening, rather than in the anticlimax of consummation and its dire consequences.

title: Susan Schreuder To Be June Bride
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 13Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Schreuder have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Schreuder, to Edward Charles Leber 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leber 2d of Blauvelt, N. Y.

title: Stone Scores at Bear Mountain With Leaps of 151 and 144 Feet
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan 13Larry Stone, the 27yearold builder from upstate Woodstock, saved his best effort to day, for his final leap to earn top honors on Palisades Interstate Park's 50meter hill.

title: McGovern Will Miss Inauguration of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) Senator George McGovern will not be in Washton for President Nixon's inauguration on Jan. 20. The defeated Democratic Presidential candidate will leave Washington on Monday to lecture at Oxford University in England and return eight days later. His wife, Eleanor, who campaigned vigorously, will go with him.

title: GRAFITTI SCORES AT CALDER TRACK
description: MIAMI, Jan. 13Louisa D'A. Carpenter's Grafitti proved much the best in the $25,000added Miss Tropical Handicap at Calder race course today, taking the lead early and scoring a 5length victory.

title: China: reports and guesses, memories and theories, games and art
description: When you ask a Chinese today about the Cultural Revolution, he is apt to reply, as many did to me last summer, that it was the most profoundly moving event of his life. It had changed his philosophy, his view of himself and his relationship to his fellow men. But when you asked him how this had been accomplished, he was usually vague and not at all certain and often wound up saying: There are many things we do not yet understand about it.

title: HOSPITAL CASES LINKED TO SMOG
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Jan. 13Student researchers at the University of Montana have reported results of a twoyear study that showed a correlation between smog and hospital admissions for respiratory illnesses.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: H.E.W. AIDE CHOSEN FOR JUSTICE POST
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP)President Nixon selected a young California attorney today to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.

title: FLA. STATE RALLY BEATS CINCINNATI
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP)Benny Clyde scored 25 points to bring Florida State from behind today as the Seminoles beat Cincinnati, 7874.

title: 4 Watergate Defendants Reported Still Being Pai
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13At least four of the five men arrested last June in the Watergate raid are still being paid by persons as yet unnamed, according to sources close to the case.

title: Friday And Robinson
description: In 1719 Daniel Defoe, the first of the new journalists, turned out a best seller. It was a persuasive report of a sturdy Briton's shipwreck on a desert island from which he wrested an adequate living for nearly three decades. In the later years a faithful slave assisted. This story, well suited to an era of the Empire's flowering, celebrated rugged resolve that dispels doubt and fear, certainty of a Higher Power's approval, unquenchable optimism and prudent magnanimity.

title: Sudden Death Will Settle Tie
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13The Super Bowl game between the Miami Dolphins and the Washington Redskins will be played to a suddendeath finish if the teams are tied at the end of regulation 60 minutes.

title: An Austrian Industry Born at 75
description: VIENNALife began at 75 for the Austrian paper industry. Last year, as the industry celebrated its centennial, insiders remembered just a quarter of a century ago that Egon Gotthilf Rothblum had injected life into a warravaged business.

title: The Transit Police Seeking Recruits; 1st Drive Since '70
description: The city's transit police are looking for new applicants this, month.

title: Community Service Can Replace Prison Under British Law
description: LONDON, Jan. 13 (Reuters)Until a couple of weeks ago, 20yearold Peter Giles, found guilty of possessing marijuana, might have found himself in a jail cell or paying a heavy fine.

title: AROUND THE
description: Gardeners are lookingrather demurely at '73. The sogginess of '72 is too damp in their memories. A generous refund  all around would be a fitting gesture from the weatherman (men?).

title: Keeping House in a Parking Lot
description: What does one do if his home is in Bethpage, L. I. and a strike against the Long Island Rail Road cuts off his normal means of commuting to his midManhattan office? Ernest Lemley, not wanting to fight the rushhour traffic, moved into the city with a mobile home.

title: Henley Named Back of Year
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 13 (AP)Terry Henley of Auburn, the leading rusher in the Southeastern Conference last season, was named today the Southeastern back of the year by the Atlanta Touchdown Club.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, B.W.I.Gentle swells greeted us as we left George Town at sunset in Sam Ebanks's 16footer, outboardpowered skiff, and gentler yet was the warm night breeze coming off the tropical shore.

title: H. Rap Brown and 3 Others Go on Trial Tomorrow
description: H. Rap Brown, the black militant leader, and three codefendants from St. Louis, are scheduled to go on trial under rigid security precautions tomorrow in State Supreme Court in Manhattan after 13 months of court delays and postponements.

title: A Man Who Really Knows Israel Describes His Favorite Tours
description: JERUSALEMOf all the places to which I take friends who visit me in Israel, the favorite is the walkway atop the wall of the Old City in Jerusalem. None of the official tours seem to include it, but a walk on the wall is one of the most picturesque and inspiring experiences in the Holy Land, not only for visitors but also for residents. I take it myself, almost every time I return to Jerusalem. But, like several of my favorite excursionsto the ruined seashore castle at Athlit with its quiet beach or to the graves of the Maccabees at their ancestral home in Modin  the walk seems to be overlooked by most tourists.

title: BOYS RICA BREAKS RECORD IN RELAY
description: Doug Terry, the coach at Boys High, used an allcity football end on his twomile relay team yesterday. If he hadn't had an outstanding runner such as Bill Dabney on the anchor leg, the experiment would have failed.

title: Music
description: MICHAEL TILSON THOMAS, who has a more ideas about programing than an IBM systems man, is coming to Carnegie Hall on Thursday with the Boston Symphony and an affair that he calls a Spectrum Concert. This is a fancy name for a program that is built on unusual combinations of instruments. It opens with an Overture for Double Orchestra by Johann Christian Bach, and proceeds to Bartk's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celeste. Steve Reich's Four Organs for rock organ quartet and maracas ensemble (try to top, that one!) and ends with Liszt's Hexameron for six pianos and orchestra.

title: Nixon Tells of His Work: A Life Without Relaxing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13It's important to live like Spartan, President Nixon was saying, to have moderate eating and drinking habits.

title: N.C.A.A. Scraps 1.6 for a Scholastic Ruling
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 13The National Collegiate Athletic Association revised its controversial academic requirement for athletes today so that a boy must now achieve a high school grade average of 2.0 (based on 4.0 as perfect) to be eligible for intercollegiate competition and an athletic scholarship at an N.C.A.A. institution. This 2.0 grade is equal to a 70 or f mark at most high schools.

title: Eastern Hockey League
description: FRIDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Black graduates of the United States' most prestigious business schools do not have the chance to reach the heights in the American corporate world that their white peers have.

title: Teams' Figure Comparisons
description: Individual statistics compiled during the regular season by leading members of the Miami Dolphins and Washington Redskins.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Easter Standard Time

title: For the Touring Hypochondriac: Kos Will Cater to Every whim
description: HUNGRY American seated himself at a seaside restaurant on the Greek island of Kos, encountered a waiter flashing a new gold tooth and tried to order three different main dishes on the menu. The waiter's refusals were polite but firm, and the first course was a short lecture.

title: Encountering Directors
description: Bergman shot The Seventh Seal in 35 days and imagined himself afterwards saying to the world, Here is a painting; take it, please; Antonioni thinks people, all of us, talk too much (his films show the remedy); everybodyTruffaut, Renoir, even De Sicalikes the work of JeanLuc Godard, though nobody can agree about much else. If that is the kind of thing you want from directors, well, this is obviously the book for you. Charles Thomas Samuels goes after his quarries doggedly and often a little recklessly, a point to which I shall have to return. But the enterprise at all events is a mixed one, part gossip and part revelation, and it necessarily involves Mr. Samuels in some double takes.

title: Pistons' Foster Out 10 Days
description: DETROIT, Jan. 13 (AP)The Detroit Pistons have lost a starting forward, Fred Foster, for at least 10 days as the result of a severe sprain of the right ankle suffered in last night's 113104 National Basketball Association loss at Seattle.

title: Robert Avino to Wed Susanne M. Krollage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Krollage of Elmhurst, Queens, and Miller Place, L. I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanne M. Krollage of New Dorn, S. I., and Elmhurst, to Robert Avino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Avino, also of New Dorp.

title: Secret Art Trade Cost Metropolitan 6 Pictures, Not 2, as First Reported
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, in a secret trade of paintings with a private gallery that caused a sensation in the art world when it was partly disclosed last year, actually gave much more than was reported at the time.

title: Woman Is Chosen in India To Head Science Congress
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 13 (UPI)A woman has been elected president of the Indian Science Congress for the first time since the group was founded 60 years ago.

title: East Germany Is Like west Germany15 Years Ago
description: FOR a widely unrecognized and often unacknowledged entity, it has a lot of names: the Soviet Zone, East Germany, Mitteldeutschland, the German Democratic Republic. A selfconscious state, it never misses an official opportunity to refer to its half of Berlin as BerlinCapital of the German Democratic Republic. A visitor arriving last year after the ratification of West Germany's treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland, after President Nixon's visits to Peking and Moscow, 11 years after the Berlin Wall and one year after Walter Ulbricht's replacement as East German party leader, wonders what he will find, What will the texture of life be like? How do the people think, live, speak, act? An 18day visit cannot produce definitive answers to complex questions. Here, instead, are one man's impressions.

title: Essex, Called a Loving Man, Buried Amid Militant Symbols
description: EMPORIA, Kan., Jan. 13Mark James Robert Essex, identified as the New Orleans sniper who shot and killed six persons, was buried today in ceremonies that mixed appeals for nonviolence with the militant symbols of black nationalism.

title: News Summary and Index
Kansas State Pins First Defeat On 5thRanked Missouri, 7055
description: MANHATTAN, Kan. Jan. 13 (AP)Kansas state led from start to finish as the 17thranked Wildcats beat fifthranked and previously unbeaten Missouri, 7055, tonight.

title: What a Sock in the Midriff Did for Jan
description: ONE of Jan DeGaetani's sharpest memories of her student days at Juilliard is the time her singing teacher hit her. I was studying with Sergius Kagen, a wonderful teacher whom I miss very much, singing Brahms song for himI don't remember exactly which one. The song moved me and suddenly I began to cry. He came up and hit me in the gut, hard, with the back of his hand and said, If you'd been doing what you should have been doing, I'd be the one crying, not you. So, when I had to sing at his funeral a few years later, I remembered that and got through it somehow.

title: 1,562 Youths Seized in '72 For Their Graffiti Work
description: The police arrested 1,562 youths for defacing subways, buses and public places with graffiti, an aide to Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

title: CARDINAL CENTO, CHURCH DIPLOMAT
description: ROME, Jan. 13  Fernando Cardinal Cento, a leading church diplomat for more than 30 years, died here this morning in the old Palace of the Apostolic Chancery, where he lived. He was 89 years old.

title: In Defense of Children's TV
description: One morning a few years hack, I'm told, a group of ladies sat around a living room in a Boston suburb and wondered how to turn a kaflee klatch into something of worthier purpose. What they hit upon, finally, was the improvement of children's television. And what they have accomplished since has rattled the bones of network TV  an industry that does $75million a year in the sale of weekend kid shows alone.

title: GEORGE MELLK
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 13 George Mellk, senior vice president of the Glemby Company, which operates leased beauty salons in department stores, died yesterday at the age of 57.

title: Legislative Notes: TakeHorne Pay Perturbs Lawmakers
description: TRENTONThere are few absentees on the opening day of a New Jersey legislative session.

title: Discussion Set on Hempstead Harbor Tract
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I.The tugowar between those who are trying to develop some of the few remaining large tracts of land on Long Island, and local residents who are trying to keep things as they are will get another pull here tomorrow night when a plan to develop a 1,000acre sandpit is discussed.

title: STATE'S BUDGET DUE ON TUESDAY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13Governor Rockefeller will submit his proposed budget for the 197374 state fiscal year on Tuesday to a Legislature already trying to figure out the precise amount of an anticipated revenue surplus and how to spend it.

title: News Given Out With Smile
description: One of the few nice things you can say about the Long Island Rail Road strike is that Jack McNamara of Forest Hills Queens, is seeing some of the guys he grew up with or watched grow upfellows who have moved further out on the Island.

title: New & Novel
description: The title makes you think of someone as contemporary as the coelacanth, but there is nothing pass about Dr. Alex Hewitt, crack diagnostician.

title: Miss Vander Veer to Wed
description: SYOSSET, L. I., Jan. 13Mr. and Mrs. John H. Vander Veer 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Martha Louise Vander Veer, to David G. Spaulding, son of Mrs. Appelgate Spaulding of Flint, Mich., and George G. Spaulding of Port Washington. A spring wedding is planned.

title: EVONNE GOOLAGONG GAINS TENNIS FINAL
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 13 (AP)Evonne Goolagong defeated the No. 1 Japanese player, Kazuko Sawamatzu, 63, 61, and advanced to the women's final of the New Zealand open tennis championships today.

title: Plans for Convention Center Set
description: Final design renderings for the convention center scheduled to be built on the Hudson River waterfront between 43d and 47th Streets are virtually complete, according to Thomas F. Galvin, chief officer of the city's Convention and Exhibition Center Corporation.

title: MRS. FRED CRANE
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 13Mrs. Gwen Kirchner Crane, formerly chairman of the Board of the Elizabeth Daily Journal, died today in a nursing home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 34 years old, the widow of Fred L. Crane, former owner and publisher of The Journal.

title: Television
description: THE Nixon Administration is concerned about television. That much is clear. Patrick Buchanan, Presidential assistant, has candidly described the basis for that concern: In terms of power over the American people, you can't compare newspapers to those pictures on television. They can make or break a politician. It's all over if you get chopped up on the networks. You never recover. The newspapers can beat the hell out of you and you've got no problem.

title: 1,000 Pigeons Highlight Shows Within the Show
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13One thousand pigeons, borrowed from pigeon fanciers in nearby Orange County, will be one of the features in the Super Bowl's pregame ceremonies tomorrow. So will the crew of Apollo 17, and a choir of boys and girls five to seven years old from a ghetto area of South Chicago. Andy Williams, Vicki Carr, Sammy Davis Jr., if he can shake off the flu, will take in the halftime show.

title: Betting Agent in Nigeria Moonlights in Forecasts
description: ENUGU, NigeriaUbani O. Ubani, the soothsayer who threw soccer pools here into turmoil in 1971 by successfully predicting results for four weeks in a row, says now that he is a wiser man but not a wealtheir one. He did not bet himself.

title: Before VII: II Dramas, IV Routs
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13Of the six Super Bowl games gone by, only two had high drama and suspense right down to the end while the other four were routs. The two memorable ones were the Jets' 167 victory over the Colts, who were favored by 18 points in 1969 at Miami, and the Colts' 1613 decision over the Cowboys in the last five seconds in 1971, also at Miami.

title: Movies
description: THE STALLS smell of manure and horse sweat, the stands of spilled beer and caramel popcorn. The four odors mix with a delicate sweetsour rancidness, and the ferris wheel glitters in the dark.

title: A Building Boom for Nuclear Power Plants
description: The men who make and sell nuclear power plants are convinced that they've finally won over the nation's utilities.

title: Sniper
description: NEW ORLEANSA nation inured to visual violence may have found new benchmark last week: the dramatic network television coverage of police attempts to dislodge a sniper from the roof of the highrise Howard Johnson's Motel across from the New Orleans City Hall.

title: Hockey Nets Youthful Skaters
description: COMMACK, L. I.  At 5 A.M. each Saturday, 6yearold Danny Smith slips into his parents' bedroom and gently taps his father on the head:

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Casey, Teacher in Rye
description: YONKERS, Jan. 13  Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Casey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bernadette Katherine Casey, to John Robert Mulheam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mulheam of Bronxville. The wedding is planned for August.

title: WALL STREET
description: Investors have been abandoning mutual funds in droves for more than a year now in an obvious display of disenchantment with the stock market and the performance of the fund industry.

title: PAF Playhouse Still Open
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I.A professional repertory theater here, threatened with closing because of a $50,000 debt, will remain open because of a dramatic campaign that raised 70 per cent of the needed funds.

title: LIBERTY RACE WON BY CHANCE MILTIE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13A threehorse stretch duel was won by Chance Miltie, a 91 outsider in the $28,275 Germantown Handicap today before a seasonhigh crowd of 20,589 fans at Liberty Bell race track.

title: 25 HURT IN ULSTER TAVERN BOMBING
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 13 (AP)A bomb exploded tonight in a Belfast tavern crowded with Roman Catholics. The police said that 25 persons had been injured and that some were in serious condition after being trapped in the wreckage.

title: Law
description: Cadets and midshipmen at the four military academies have at least one thing in common with each other and with all other service personnel: They are theoretically protected by a Uniform Code of Military Justice that guarantees them the right to fair trial, to legal counsel and to the various other rights that comprise due process of law.

title: Celler Looks Back On Years in Politics
description: When Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn completed the last of his 50 years in the House of Representatives earlier this month, he left office with sparkling personal memories of nine Presidents and countless Senators and fellow Congressmen. But local politics and the folks back home earned a very special niche, too.

title: Stocks' Glitter Lures Greeks
description: ATHENSThe Greeks, riding the crest of Europe's current economic boom, are breaking away from traditional forms of investment in gold and housing to explore new and more lucrative outlets.

title: Robert Snedeker Marries Frances Muth
description: RUXTON, Md., Jan. 13Miss Frances Hilda Muth of Washington was married here this afternoon to Robert Dunbar Snedeker, senior vice president of Texas International Airlines in Houston. The Rev. David Gearhart, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr. Thomas Whelan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated in the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: Mrs. Phyllis Campbell Wed to Robert Lynn
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 13Mrs. Phyllis Lord Campbell, widow of Charles K. Campbell, was married at her home here this afternoon to Robert P. Lynn of New York, senior vice president, general counsel and a director of Burlington Industries, Inc.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: Rhodesia
description: SALISBURYStung by five months of guerrilla incursions by exiled African nationalist groups based in Zambia, Rhodesia last week closed her frontier with her northern neighbor. The Government of Premier Ian Smith, which seized independence from Britain in November, 1965, said the border would not reopen until Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda's Government agreed to stop harboring terrorist movements.

title: Housing Aide Is Named
description: John V. Sanderson has been appointed to succeed Howard Stein as deputy commissioner of code enforcement, the Housing and Development Administration announced yesterday. His annual salary was given as $27,954. Mr. Sanderson formerly worked as a district manager in the Office of Neighborhood Government in the WakefieldEdenwald section of the Bronx.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES EFFEGT OF COMPOZ
description: Compoz, which is advertised as the largestselling nonprescription sedative for temporary relief of simple nervous tension, has been found in a carefully controlled study to be no more effectivn than aspirin or a milksugar placebo.

title: As Massachusetts went
description: BOSTON. On election night, I went to a televisionwatching party at a spacious Manhattan duplex. By the time I arrived, the networks' electronic tote boards were already crackling with decisive portents of the Nixon landslide. I began working on a fifth of Jack Daniels. Over in the corner, a stockbroker was saying what a great thing the President's victory would be for the market. In a sullen stupor, I sank into a couch to watch one state after another sign on for Four More Years.

title: LATE PACER RALLY BEATS Q'S, 108107
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 13 (AP) The Indiana Pacers, rallying in the waning moments tonight, continued their unbeaten record against the San Diego Conquistadors with a 108107 American Basketball Association victory. It was the Pacers' seventh triumph against the Q's.

title: Buckley Questions ChinaStudies Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Senator James L. Buckley has asked the New York State Education Department to explain a Chinastudies curriculum being developed for New York State schools and colleges that the Senator contends could constitute subtle propaganda for Peking.

title: For Father Of the Bride, Bill Is Only $3,100 (Plus)
description: MORRISTOWNIt would be our pleasure to have you join us for the weekend, said the elaborately inscribed invitation announcing the marriage of Miss Dorothy Glazer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Glazer, to Dr. Joel Rock at the Governor Morris Inn in Morristown.

title: Transit Fares Going Up, Service Going Down
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP)Riders on Chicago Transit Authority buses and trains face a 5cent fare increase beginning Feb. 1 and a reduction in service.

title: Follmer Heads 1972 AllAmerican Racing Team
description: It couldn't happen to a nicer guy: George Follmer, who won two major roadracing championships last season, has won the Jerry Titus Trophy for 1972, emblematic of the leading position on the season's AllAmercan Racing Team, The trophy winner and allstar team are chosen in balloting of members of the American Auto Racing Writers and Broadcasters Associ ation, Follmer, driving a Porsche sportsracing car, won the CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup, ending the fiveyear domination of the McLarens; in an American oMtors Javelin, Follomer won the TransAmerican Championship for small sedans.

title: Susan Young, Teacher, Engaged
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 13Mr. and Mrs. Robert Young have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Young to Gregory Alexander Sandomirsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander G. Sandomirsky of Orange, Conn. The couple plan to marry May 19 in the Presbyterian Church here.

title: Agnes L. Wang, Teacher, Plans To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Miss Agnes Louisa Wang to William Wallace Atterbury 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. FuYen Wang of New York, parents of the prospective bride. Her fianc is the on of Mrs. L. Rodman Page Jr. of Radnor, Pa., and Mr. William Atterbury Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and a grandson of the late Mr. Atterbury, onetime president of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

title: Rome Improvement
description: Ever since the Home Repair Clinic was started as a regular feature of this column some months ago, the flow of readers' letters has increased steadilybut unfortunately space limitations have not permitted answering all of them on this page. In an effort to catch up on this backlog of unanswered questions, the entire column this week is being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of these pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not be published herebut who will, nevertheless, find their answers below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column.

title: Morocco Executes 11 for Role In Plot to Assassinate Hassan
description: RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 13Eleven Moroccan Air Force officers and noncommissioned officers were executed by firing squad this morning for their part in the aerial assassination attempt on King Hassan II last August.

title: Schaeffer Excels As St. John's Five Downs St. Francis
description: St. John's turned back a stubborn St. Francis team, 9372, in the 60th contest of one of New York's oldest basketball rivalries last night before 3,888 fans at the winner's Alumni Hall in Jamaica.

title: The Winter Antique Show
description: The Winter Antique Show, now in its 19th year, which opens on Tuesday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, is acknowledged by dealers and collectors alike to be this country's most important antique exhibition and sale. Its 59 exhibitors are a crosssection of the carriage trade dealers whose clients include almost all the serious collectors, decorators, museum and restoration committee representatives, competing dealers and buyers from England and the Continent.

title: INFLATION
description: INFLATION has rather suddenly become the overriding economic, social and political problem throughout Europe and the Middle East.

title: Honor for an Old Scout
description: BOSTON, Jan. 13 (AP)Jeff Jones, 75 years old, a retired major league scout, was named today to receive the seventh annual Doc Gautreau Good Scout Award at the Boston Baseball Writers' 34th annual dinner Jan. 25.

title: Paul Foster Clark, 80, Is Dead; ExPresident of John Hancock
description: NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 13Paul Foster Clark, retired president and chairman of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, died here Thursday. He was 80 years old and formerly lived in Brookline.

title: Charlotte DiDio Is Wed on a Boat
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13Mrs. Charlotte Barbour DiDio and Henry Thorndike Chickering Jr. were married aboard the Magic Lemon, the bridegroom's 22foot sailboat, here this morning. They had to stay within the threemile limit in order for the ceremony, performed by Municipal Judge Richard Sluggert, to be legal in the State of Florida.

title: The nononsense school vs. the pleasegivemebackmynonsense school
description: I'm going to try to steer clear of words describing sex manuals as a penetrating study, a hard look, a glimpse into the yawning cavern. As for the old brutally frank and honest, at this point a little obfuscation and circumlocution would be something to brag about.

title: What Best Sellers Sell
description: He was a brute, but she loved him, loved him for his very brutality, and superb animal strength. And he was an Arab! A man of different race and color, a native...She did not care. But before you're asphyxiated by laughter at The Sheik (1919), lost in the spasms that Ed Wynn called a fiveminute belly, do consult Claud Cockburn's splendid study, Bestseller, which ranges from 1900 to 1939. (Published by Sidgwick & Jackson, London.) Convinced that best sellers are politically important, since they reveal the moods, needs, and fears of a society at a given time, Cockburn writes social history which defies those who insist that only great literature can characterize its period.

title: Chinese Art Show Opening in Suffolk
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.East meets the East End today when a three weeklong show on Chinese Arts and Culture opens at Guild Hall.

title: The Reaction
description: How successfully Phase 3 restrains the wageprice spiral will depend on how soon and how hard the Nixon Administration cracks down on unions and companies that exceed its antiinflation standards. That was the judgment last week of ranking economists of every political persuasion, plus a considerable crosssection of sophisticated experts in industry and labor.

title: 6 Jewish Groups Charge Colleges With Reverse Bias
description: Charging continued reverse discrimination against white males in college admissions and hiring practices, sit national Jewish organizations have sent what they say are 19 new examples to the United States Department of Health, Education and. Welfare.

title: Schmitz Vote Tops 1 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) Former Representative John G. Schmitz, the California Republican who ran for President as the American party nominee after Gov, George C. Wallace of Alabama was shot last May, got more than a million votes from 36 states on Nov. 7, a new compilation of minor party ballots showed today. His total was 1,095,266, which included votes in states where his name was on the ballot and several where he received writen votes.

title: West Germany: No Economic Catastrophes, but No Miracles Either
description: BONNAt the beginning of 1972 some seriousminded observers of the West German economic landscape were talking of a possible recession. At the end of 1972 some of these same seriousminded men were hollering to the heavens about an inflationary 6.4 per cent rise in the costofliving index.

title: How Fokker Competes
description: THE HAGUE, the NetherlandsThe Fokker Aircraft Company, the Dutch entry in the fiercely competitive planebuilding industry, is in a difficult transition period.

title: JOSEPH R. BERNSTEIN
description: Joseph R. Bernstein, executive director of the Rockland County Mental Health Association since 1956, died of cancer Thursday in Memorial Hospital. His age was 59, and he lived in Pomona, N. Y.

title: The security of Social Security
description: WASHINGTON. A funny thing happened to your taxes on the way to 1973. Congress passed the biggest Federal increase since the Korean war (and that one was temporary), and hardly anybody peeped except a few intellectuals. This was happening at the time of the taxpayers' revolt at Federal, state and local levels. It was at the time when even George Wallace was appealing to sense of frustration in the middle and lowermiddle classes, telling them the tax system was unfair. It was an election year.

title: Mrs. Leydon Bride Of R. L. Augenblick
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Mrs. Elizabeth Rivinus Leydon of Lahaska, Pa., widow of Rear Adm. John K. Leydon, was married here this afternoon to Robert L. Augenblick, president of the Investment Company Institute.

title: August Bridal for Lynn H. Philip
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Philip of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Hope Philip, to Howard Mark Helfand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Helfand of West Hartford, Conn.

title: ANTHONY DAVIS HURT IN AN AUTO ACCIDENT
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 (AP)Anthony Davis, Southern California's sophomore tailback, underwent successful surgery (today to repair a left Achilles tendon partly severed in a traffic accident. Dr. Frank Jobe, who headed the team that performed the surgery, said: There is no indication that his career will be hampered.

title: Pinelawn Cemetery of L.I. Will End Ground Burials
description: The Pinelawn Memorial Park and Cemetery of Pinelawn, L. I., has announced that ground burials will be discontinued and that all interments will be made by management personnel on a temporary basis in the Pinelawn Garden Mausoleum.

title: Art: Focusing on Works by Women
description: The exhibition Women Choose Women, which has opened at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, is billed as the first major museum exhibition in New York to focus on the work of women artists. Its function is both political and esthetic, On both scores, it should be said, it is successfulwith qualifications.

title: Crusading Is Awarded Coast Victory After Foul Claim
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 13 (UPI)Crusading captured the 35th running of the $56,350 San Carlos Handicap at Santa Anita today after Kennedy Road was disqualified and placed second.

title: New York Plan A Falling Out Among Fathers
description: The New York Plan was established two years ago with a number of proud fathers officiating at the birthincluding Mayor Lindsay and Peter Brennan, head of the Building Trades Council. The Plan: A cooperative venture joining government, industry and labor in a yearlong program to hire and train 800 minority workers for craft jobs long regarded as lilywhite.

title: Engineer Fiance Of Jane C. Blair
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Jan. 13Mr. and Mrs. William Draper Blair Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Coleman Blair, to John Herbert Gelston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Gelston of Massapequa, L. I.

title: Italy Restricts Jet Overflights to Protect Art at Assisi From Sonic Booms
description: ROME, January 13The conservationist movement scored a success this week when the Italian Air Force pledged to avoid the sonic booms that have shattered stainedglass windows and crumbled frescoes in central Italy.

title: Graduates
description: Over the past several years, the job outlook for students graduating from college has not been exactly bright. The economic recession, the declining demand for teachers and various demographic factors combiped to tighten up the job market.
