title: City Employes Face Crackdown On Sick Leaves and on Lateness
description: The city is tightening controls over sick leaves and lateness by its employes, with asserted illnesses running at the rate of 9.73 days a year. Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton said he would like to see the figure down below 8.

title: South Bronx: A jungle Stalked by Fear, Seized by Rage
description: The fire hydrants are open, even in this biting cold weather town pumps tIrat provide the sole water supply for drinking, washing and sanitation for thousands of tenants in 20 per cent of the housing in the area. When one hydrant freezes over, the residents pry open another.

title: VOTE ON ABORTION SOUGHT IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 14Support appears to be growing for enactment by the New Jersey Legislature of a bill that would permit abortions only to save a mother's life. Pressure by public groups could force a vote on the bill in this sensitive legislative election year.

title: The Poison Lobby
description: A year ago, President Nixon wisely issued an executive order banning the use of cyanide, strychnine, and other systemic poisons to kill coyotes and other predators on the nation's public lands. Shortly thereafter, William Ruckelshaus, the Environmental Protection Administrator, blocked their use on private lands as well, by prohibiting the interstate shipment and sale of these deadly chemicals.

title: Dispute Over Bill to Protect Venice Endangers Italian Cabinet
description: ROME, Jan. 14A longsmoldering dispute over the future of Venise is approaching a parliamentary showdown that may endanger the Government of Premier Giulio Andreotti.

title: U.S. CRIME REPORT CALLS FOR REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 14The National Advisory Commission on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals, in a report issued today, recommended the elimination of plea bargaining within the next five years as one of hundreds of recommendations for change in the nation's courts, police forces, corrections systems and community attitudes.

title: TRENTON READY FOR FISCAL BILLS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)A series of financial measures, including a proposal to allow savings institutions to make installment loans just as banks do, is ready for consideration in the State Legislature tomorrow.

title: U.S. Jewish Chiefs To See Mrs. Meir On '73 Aid to Israel
description: American Jewish leaders have been invited by Premier Golda Meir of Israel to confer with her this month in Israel concerning her nation's economic needs and its development program for this year.

title: Two Planes Land Safely One on Top of Other
description: NASHUA, N. H., Jan. 14 (AP)  Two light airplanes ended up piggyback today when one, landed on top of the other while they were attempting to land.

title: Paul Robert Freyd Dead; A Marketing Consultant
description: Paul Robert Freyd, a marketing and management consultant who had been a vice president for marketing at the advertising agency of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Inc., died Saturday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at Wood Drive, Montauk, L.I.

title: FASHION TALK
description: If you're invited to an ambassador's dinner, a royal wedding or an inaugural ball and there's a George Stavropoulos dress in your closet, you don't have to worry about something appropriate to wear. The haute couture tradition is being carried on in the silk organdie, jersey and chiffon dresses of the transplanted Greek designer who has been thriving in New York for more than 10 years.

title: Deborah Miller a Bride
description: Miss Deborah Leah Miller, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Israel Miller of the Bronx, was married yesterday at the Statler Hilton, to Norman Simon Kram, son of Mr, and Mrs. Leo Kram of Manhattan. The bride's father, who is vice president for student affairs at Yeshiva University and president of the American Zionist Federation, performed the ceremony.

title: New Orleans Sniper
description: A week after six persons were slain by sniper fire at a New Orleans hotel, two questions are unanswered: Was there more than one sniper? If so, how was an escape made past a swarm of policemen? A study of what is known about the case appears on Page 18.

title: DORATI CONDUCTS 3 POSTROMANTICS
description: Top echelon cellists are sometimes loath to schedule Bloch's Schelomo because it is shorter than a standard concerto, and Don Quixote by Strauss because so much of the spotlight is shared with other solo instrumentalists, not to mention the orchestra as whole.

title: OPPOSITION RISES TO AMENDMENT ON EQUAL RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Ratification of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution no longer looks like a sure thing.

title: CRAMPTON WINNER OF PHOENIX OPEN
description: PHOENIX, Ariz. (UPI) Bruce Crampton, an Australian, got a birdie on the 18th hole to win the $30,000 first prize today in the $150,000 Phoenix Open.

title: No. 1 Fan Dismayed By Defeat
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP)  President Nixon watched with dismay today as his favorite football team, the Washington Redskins, lost to Miami, 147, in what he called One of the best Super Bowl games ever.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT IS OFF TO BRITAIN
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14  Zhores A. Medvedev, the biologist and dissident whose forced detention in a Soviet mental hospital in 1970 stirred wide protests, has left for a year's study in England with his family, friends disclosed tonight.

title: Martin Luther King Day
description: Public schools will be closed today here and in numerous cities, including Newark, Chicago, Los Angeles, St. Louis and Atlanta, to mark the birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Details are on Page 32.

title: Test of Mail Distribution Succeeds in Pennsylvania
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 14 (AP) The post office at Allentown will continue to handle Sunday mail for the Scranton, WilkesBarre, Hazelton, Pa., and Binghamton, N.Y. areas, postal officials announced yesterday.

title: Hosick Wins Bear Mt. Ski Jump
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 14  In what one baseballminded park official described as the continuation of a pitchers' duel, Jack Hosick, the 19yearold student from Boonton, N. J., and Larry Stone, the 27yearold housebuilder from nearby Woodstock, today continued their close skijumping rivalry.

title: Pressures to Plead Guilty Alleged in Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14A source close to the Watergate case said today that four of ithe five defendants were under what he termed. great pros(sure to plead guilty to charges of eavesdropping on the Democratic National Committee headquarters in Washington last June.

title: New Soviet Film Depicts U.S. as Land of Violence and Inequities
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14As the Soviet Government negotiated a broad agreement for technical cooperation with The General Electric Company last week, Moscow television treated its viewers on three successive nights to a new feature film, Washington Correspondent, seemingly dedicated to the theme that the United States is a land of violence that kills its public leaders.

title: Brazil Reduces Rate of Inflation Sharply
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 14 Brazil's once rampant inflation has slowed markedly in the last decade, and the Government has set a new target to reduce it further.

title: Music: Foss on Brecht
description: Lukas Foss did Bertolt Brecht proud yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, combining two short operas to Brecht texts by Weill and Hindemith with some extraordinary renditions Of Brecht songs by Nina Simone.

title: KNICKS WIN, 8684, FOR 10TH IN ROW
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 14The New York Knicks were not artistic successes as they made less than onethird of their shots, but they put the ball in the basket when they had to and defeated the Seattle SuperSonics tonight, 8684, to extend their winning streak to 10 games.

title: Jazz: Winter's Consort
description: The Paul Winter Consort used to be an unusual and interesting jazzbased ensemble:and it may still be if one is to believe its latest recording, Icarus, on the Epic jabel. But the performance it gave this weekend at the Villageast, Second Avenue and Sixth Street, where it shared the stage Friday and Saturday nights with Miles Davis's group, suggested that a drastic and disappointing change has taken place in the group's musical outlook.

title: Papua Leader, Worried by Strife, Calls for Delay in Independence
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 14 Alarmed by spreading tribal violence, the head of the semiautonomous government of Papua New Guinea has urged Australia to postpone the setting of a date for the independence of the sprawling, largely primitive island territory.

title: U.S. Weapons Spending Is High in Relation to Ads
description: Although the Department of Defens espends tens of billions of dollars buying weapons and related equipment each year, its 25 top suppliers spent a total of only $2,301,705 to advertise their deadly wares in, the seven leading military trade journals in the last two years.

title: Week of Tension Ends
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Sundays are generally quiet herea siren or two each hour, church chimes spreading in the dirty air and little morebut today brought a new low to the city's noise level.

title: ADM. DERBY, 83, LED COAST GUARD SCHOOL
description: WESTON, Mass., Jan. 14 (AP)  Vice Adm. Wilfrid Neville Derby, former superintendent of the Coast Guard Academy, died yesterday at his home. He was 83 years old.

title: The Many Invitations to Inauguration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 A select group of about 200,000 Americans are finding oversized, creamcolored envelopes protruding from their mailboxes. Inside, each discovers an engraved invitation to attend and participate in the inauguration, and a small slip of paper stating that the suitableforframing invitation is just a souvenir.

title: Chou Meets With Heykal
description: TOKYO, Jan. 14 (AP)Premier Chou Enlai and other ranking Chinese officials met today n Peking with a delegation of Egyptian newsmen led by Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, editor of the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram, the Chinese press agency Hsinhua reported.

title: Lois Farfel Of N.B.C. Wed
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 14Miss Lois Farfel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron J. Farfel, was married here this afternoon to George Stark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Stark of Paris.

title: For Sir Noel It Was an Evening of Memories and Old Friends
description: Sir Nol Coward did not have to wonder last night where he'd heard that song before.

title: British Football Results
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Hiker on Anthony's Nose Is Rescued by a Copter
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Jan. 14 (AP)A Columbia University graduate student with a broken leg was lifted off the cold, windy peak of Anthony's Nose by a helicopter last night, after spending six hours on a ledge.

title: Pakistan Releases Rightist
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 14 (AP)Agha Shorish Kashmiri, editor of the rightwing weekly newspaper Chatan, was released today after five months of detention during which he staged a 26day hunger strike.

title: Hearings Set This Week On Big Offshore Oil Port
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14Opposition to an oil superport off New Jersey or Delaware by Governors Cahill and Russell W. Peterson will not deter the Army, Corps of Engineers from conducting a final round of pubIic hearings on the question this week, a spokesman for the Philadelphia district of the corps has said. The question is one of national policy and would be decided by Congress and the Administration, he added.

title: Paterson Reacts to Its Role in XRated Movie
description: PATERSON, Jan. 14As long as East 41st Street, Paterson, does not become a West 42d Street, New York, many neighbors of Alfred Sole say that what Mr. Sole does is Mr. Sole's business.

title: We'll Be Back, Says Allen After Uttering Prepared Alibi
description: LOS ANGELES Jan. 14It took George Allen, the Washington coach, only a few sentences to put before the American public his carefully prepared alibi after his team's 14.7 loss to undefeated Miami todaybut many of his players spent the next hour pointedly rejecting the idea.

title: Washington, D.C., Gets Control of Bus System
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)At 2 A.M. today the nation's capital obtained public ownership of its local bus systemthe first stage do a unified transportation system combining buses and subways under one public agency.

title: Mrs. Meir to Visit Pope in First Such Call by an Israeli Premier
description: ROME, Jan. 14Premier Golda Meir of Israel will meet with Pope Paul VI tomorrow in the first visit to the head of the Roman Catholic Church by the head of the Israeli Government.

title: WrongHouse Raid Terrifies Family
description: WINTHROP, Mass., Jan. 14 Fifteen burly policemen, carrying rifles and handguns, broke down two doors and poured into the home of the William Pine family last Tuesday.

title: 10 WOMEN' HONORED FOR ACHIEVEMENTS
description: Mademoiselle magazine yesterday announced awards to 10 exceptional young women for achievement in various fields in 1972, and a special award to the actresses of the National Theater of the Deaf.

title: Divorce Insurance Gains Varied Support in State
description: The idea of divorce insurance, to be taken out immediately before or after marriage, is gaining increasing interest among feminists, lawyers and legislators. The insurance would be used primarily to insure adequate child support in the event of a divorce, but it could also be used by childless divorced couples and, should the marriage be a lasting one, be converted to other uses.

title: Bridge: It's Hard for the Defenders To Visualize Closed Hand
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., Jan. 14The biggest ever tristate regional championship, with more than 1,500 tables in play in the fourday tournament, ended here tonight. Winners of major titles Friday and yesterday were Mark Blumenthal of Philadelphia and Matt Granovetter of Jersey City in the master pairs and Norman Humer of Waltham, Mass., and Bernard Miller of Malden, Mass., in the open pairs.

title: New Auto Right Make For Scott
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14Jake Scott, whose two interceptions sparked the defensive unit in the Miami Dolphins 147 victory, was awarded a Dodge Charger by Sport magazine today as the most valuable player of the Super Bawl game.

title: New Orleans Sniper
description: A week after six persons were slain by sniper fire at a New Orleans hotel, two questions are unanswered: Was there more than one sniper? If so, how was an escape made past a swarm of policemen? A study of what is known about the case appears on Page 18.

title: NIXON SENDS HAIG TO SAIGON TO TALK ABOUT CEASEFIRE
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 14 President Nixon sent Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. to Saigon tonight to consult With President Nguyen Van Thieu about the Paris negotiations on Vietnam ceasefire.

title: Gay Alliance Seeks to Revive Rights Bill in Council
description: Eight members of a City Council committeea majority have signed a Gay Activists Alliance petition for reconsideration of a bill twice defeated in committee that would bar discrimination against homosexuals in employment and housing.

title: Pakistan Releases Rightist
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 14 (AP)Agha Shorish Kashmiri, editor of the rightwing weekly newspaper Chatan, was released today after five months of detention during which he staged a 26day hunger strike.

title: Albright Acting to Close State Banking Loophole
description: Harry W. Albright Jr., the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that he had moved to close a Loophole in state law that has allowed two prominent international financiersMichele Sindona and Edmond J. Safra to take control of banks in New York without regulatory approval.

title: TV's Super Variety Show
description: Thousands of television sets tuned to the Super Bowl game yesterday in parts of New Jersey, Connecticut, Westchester and Long Island, were affected by atmospheric conditions which created picture interference.

title: Peron Views Barred on Air
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 14 (UPI) The military government has ordered radio and television stations not to broadcast the political opinions of former President Juan D. Pern, network officials said today. The prohibition referred to comments made abroad about the elections by persons not involved in the electoral process. Mr. Peron, who returned to Spain last month, spent 17 years of exile before his recent brief visit to Argentina.

title: Losers Win The Battle Of Banners
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 (AP)  If the bedsheet brigade meant anything, Washington was the overwhelming favorite among the fans today. And in the pregame workout nearly an hour before kickoff, the Redskins drew loud cheers from the halffilled stands when they took the field. Minutes Iater, when Miami appeared, booing was the predominant. sound.

title: A Priest Is Named Director Of Research at City Aquarium
description: Dr. George D. Ruggieri, a marine biologist who is also a Jesuit priest, has been appointed director of the New York Aquarium's research laboratory, an institution that has assumed everincreasing importance in recent years as man has come to recognize the havoc pollution can wreak on marine life.

title: IRRIGATION FUNDS TERMED FRUITFUL
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 12Seated in a multimilliondollar airconditioned civic auditorium in the center of a teeming metropolis, the Governor of Arizona cocked a sardonic eye at a Presidential study panel this week and told its members they would be meeting in a grove of mesquite trees if it had not been for Federal irrigation subsidies.

title: CHARLES HARSANYI
description: CAPE CORAL, Fla., Jan. 14 Charles Harsanyi, an artist noted for his New England seascapes, died today in Fort Myers. He was 67 years old and lived at 546 Coral Drive.

title: 1972 Heart Fund Campaign Gets Record $50.9Million
description: The American Heart Association has announced that contributions to the 1972 Heart Fund campaign totaled $50.9million, a record and an increase of $5.4million over 1971, according to The Associated Press.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: MRS. MEIR TO VISIT POPE PAUL TODAY
description: ROME, Jan. 14Premier Golda Meir of Israel will meet with Pope Paul VI tomorrow in the first visit to the head of the Roman Catholic Church by a head of the Israeli Government.

title: Northeast Is Bracing Itself For Possible Energy Crisis
description: The muchtalkedabout energy crisis became a reality last week in some other areas of the nation, and it could still happen in the Northeast if the weather turns sharply colder.

title: Fire Lieutenant Succumbs At East New York Blaze
description: A fire lieutenant collapsed while fighting a onealarm fire in an abandoned Brooklyn building yesterday, and died on his way to a hospital, the police said.

title: While Thousands Weep
description: PARISIn the Vietnamese way, his voice remained soft and conversational despite the emotion of his thoughts.

title: RCA WILL PRODUCE NEW TAPE SYSTEM
description: The RCA Corporation announced over the weekend that it planned to begin commercial production of its Selectavision color video tape playerrecorder system. William C. Hittinger, executive vice president of RCA consumer and solid state electronics, said units would be produced later this year at the color TV plant at Bloomington, Ind.

title: Press Club Joins Nader In Antisecrecy Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) The National Press Club and Ralph Nader's Center for Study of Responsive Law announced today the establishment of a press information center designed to fight Government secrecy.

title: Susan First and Daniel Pollack Of Law Firms Here Married
description: The marriage of Miss Susan J. First, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward First of New York, to Daniel A. Pollack took place yesterday afternoon at the St. Mortiz. The bridegroom is the son of Judge Milton Pollack of the United States District Court, Southern District, and. the late Mrs. Lillian Klein Pollack. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: Ship Abandoned in Atlantic
description: PARIS, Jan. 14 (AP)  The French container ship Mont Laurier was ordered abandoned today atfer 30foot waves sent resin pouring from barrels into the engine room, where it caught fire. Sixteen crewmen were picked up by ships standing by in one area, about 300 miles northwest of the Azores island of Corvo. Six crew members were reported missing.

title: EGYPTIAN AIRLINE BUYING U.S. JETS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 14Egypt's international airline, Egyptair, will be reequipped with American, rather than Russian passenger jets worth more than $50million through financing arranged by an American investment banking firm.

title: Personal Finance: Home Mortgages
description: If you have been thinking of buying a home but haven't really gotten serious about it because you don't think you have enough money for the down payment, you may be delaying unnecessarily.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
The Coach Who Has the Last Laugh
description: In the often overdramatic world of professional where coaches exhort their teams each week to win one for the Gipper, and where lockerroom truisms like Winning Is Everything are hailed as philosophy, Don Shula usually cooled it.

title: Ford Orchestra Aid: Success Story
description: One of the most carefully kept secrets in American musicthe outcome of the Ford Foundation's historic 1966 plan to distribute $80.2million among 61 American symphony orchestrasis out at last. All but a handful of the participating orchestras succeeded in raising the required matchinggrant challenge funds by the deadline set for the project, June 30, 1971.

title: DEFAULTING RISES IN STUDENT LOANS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 14An unexpected 30 per cent increase in the number of students defaulting on education loans has prompted the New York State Higher Education Assistance Corporation to seek additional help in tracking them down.

title: 2 STEALS BY WEST HELP CARERS WIN
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 14 (AP)Jerry West stole the ball from Pete Maravich in the final minutes today and led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 102100 victory over the Atlanta Hawks in a National Basketball Association game.

title: A DEALER IN HEROIN EXECUTED BY MANILA
description: MANILA, Monday Jan. 15 (UPI)A military firing squad today executed a Chinese printer convicted of having refined and marketed millions of dollars worth of heroin in the Philippines during the last 10 years.

title: HANK FORT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Eleanor Hankins Fort, a songwriter whose Look with Pride on Our Flag, was dedicated to President Nixon and will be played at the inaugural celebration, died yesterday. She was 59 years old.

title: Soviet Planing to Develop Its Deposits of Gas and Oil
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14As the United States appeared to be having second thoughts last week about widely publicized Siberian gas deals, the Soviet leadership affirmed its determination to develop the Siberian oil and gas areas on its own, if necessary, by sending Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin on an inspection tour.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VOICES In 1969, The Children's Crusade, a choral composition written by Benjamin Britten, set to a Bertolt Brecht text (translated by Hans Keller), had its pr'e niere in England. Tonight and tomorrow at 8, the work, for children's voices (it's about Polish children lost in the snow as a result of Nazi machinations), will be done for the first time in this country at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 64th Street (TE 82022).

title: Ballet: 1930's Soviet Work on French Revolution
description: Thanks to some recent diplomacy, a ballet such as China's Red Detachment of Women has received unexpectedly wide publicity. Few persons outside the ballet world, however, are familiar with one of its direct ancestorsThe Flames of Paris, a Soviet ballet choreographed in 1932 by Vassily Vainonen to music by Boris Asafiev.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reHeat prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: RESERVE BANK HERE NAMES HIGH AIDES
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday the appointment of Richard A. Debs and Thomas M. Timlen, Jr. as senior vice presidents of the bank. Both had been vice presidents.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MADISON, N.J., Jan. 14It's no wonder the campus at Drew University is buzzing about the basketball team. Drew may enjoy its first winning basketball season since 194344.

title: Pressures to Plead Guilty Alleged in Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14A source close to the Watergate case said today that four of the five defendants were under what he termed great pressure to plead guilty to charges of eavesdropping on the Democratic National Committee headquarters in Washington last June.

title: POLICE DRUG AIDE ASSAILS JUDICIARY
description: Only 2 per cent of those arrested in New York City on serious narcotics charges are being sent to prison for a year or more, according to the head of the police narcotics division.

title: Coops Assert Freeze Imperils Program
description: A group representing 40,000 families in moderateincome cooperatives here disclosed yesterday a citystateFederal legislative program to help provide more housing and then said the plan was endangered by the Nixon Administration's freeze on new commitments to subsidize low and middleincome homes.

title: U.S. Reports MIG Felled By Jet Above 20th Parallel
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 14 (UPI)A United States Navy fighter plane flying north of the 20th Parallel over North Vietnam shot down a North Vietnamese MIG17 after a dogfight, the United States command said yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: New Spas Fill the Prescription
description: Three times a week Robert Guglielmo of Rosedale, Queens, goes to a midtown exercise salon where he spends 40 minutes pedaling a stationary bicycle and stepping on and off a Small stool.

title: CASO CRITICIZES UNIONS IN STRIKE
description: Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso asserted yesterday that major responsibility for the continuation of the Long Island Rail Road strike rested with the 12 striking unions.

title: YOUTH IS ARRESTED IN POLICE CAR THEFT
description: A 20yearold youth was arrested yesterday in the Holland Tunnel after he had apparently stolen a Port Authority police car from Newark Airport.

title: JOBLESS PROBLEM FOR EXG.I.'S EASES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)  Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson told President Nixon today that unemployment among Vietnam war era veterans in effect no longer constitutes a national problem. He credited the Administration's campaign to find jobs for the returning servicemen.

title: South Bronx: A Jungle Stalked by Fear, Seized by Rage
description: The fire hydrants are open, even in this biting cold weather town pumps that provide the sole water supply for drinking, washing and sanitation for thousands of tenants in 20 per cent of the housing in the area. When one hydrant freezes over, the residents pry open another.

title: Miami Wins in Bowl for Perfect Season
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14The big scoreboard in the Coliseum flashed the message over and over, The Dolphins Are Super, at the end of the Super Bowl contest today, and indeed the Miami team had played an almost perfect game in defeating the Washington Redskins, 147, for a perfect season and the championship.

title: Uograding Plan Led to MonopolyStreet Proposal
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 14 Arthur W. Ponzlo, the Commissioner of Public Works who was rebuffed publicly by Monopoly fans when he suggested renaming Baltic and Mediterranean Avenues, was explaining why he did it.

title: FRONTIER INCIDENTS CITED BY ZAMBIA
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 14 Zambian officials charged today that Rhodesia had created further tension along the ZambianRhodesia frontier by provoking a series of border incidents.

title: Australian Journalist Is Released by Chinese
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Monday, Jan. 15 (Reuters)Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced today that Francis James, an Australian journalist who had been missing in China since November, 1969, was on his way back to Australia.

title: Figurines of a Phoenician Goddess Found in Wreck Off Israel
description: About 2,500 years ago, a merchant ship sank within sight of the ancient Phoenician coast, north of the present Israeli city of Haifa. The cargocommonplace then, but of great archeological interest today  included earthen vases and votive figurines of the Phoenician goddess Tanit.

title: BLUES SET BACK ISLANDERS BY 21
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 14In a bruising battle between two angry clubs, the St. Lou's Blues finally won a game and the Islanders lost another their 11th straight.

title: Lear Motors Gets Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency has awarded a $900,000 contract to Lear Motors Corp. of Leareno, Nev., to develop steam engine.

title: NIXON SENDS WIRES TO SHULA AND ALLEN
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 14 (UPI)  President Nixon sent, telegrams tonight to both Super Bowl coaches, offering congratulations to Don Shula and his Dolphins and condolences to George Allen and the Redskins.

title: The Many Invitations to Inauguration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Sometime this month, A select group of about 200,000 Americans are now finding oversized, creamcolored envelopes protruding from their mailboxes. Inside, each discover an engraved invitation to attend and participate in the inauguration, and a small slip of paper stating that the suitableforframing invitation is just a souvenir.

title: National Anthem Incident Stirs Track Fans
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 14Once again an incident of alleged misconduct during the playing of the national anthem has marred a track meet.

title: Pennsylvania Meeting Called
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 (AP) Gov. Milton J. Shapp has called for a special meeting of the Pennsylvania Congressional delegation in Washington Tuesday to discuss proposed cutbacks in Federal jobs in Pennsylvania.

title: Cost of a Day in the Hospital Now Averages $105.30
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The average cost of a day's stay in one of the nation's general hospitals shot upward past $100 in 1972 and is expected to continue to rise this year.

title: 2 More Mobil Plants Struck
description: DENVER, Jan. 14 (UPI)Some 600 members of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union struck Mobil Oil Company plants today in Torrance, Calif., and Ferndale, Wash., joining 1,500 union members on strike at Mobil's Beaumont, Tex., plant in a dispute over new contracts.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Don Fullmer Wins on Points
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Jan. 14 (AP)Don Fullmer of Salt Lake City, brother of a former middleweight boxing champion, Gene Fullmer, scored a 10round decision over Billy (Nitro) Treeman of Philadelphia last night.

title: City RetirementPlan Cost Seen Doubling in 10 Years
description: A civic group said yesterday that the cost of the city's municipal retirement programs would more than double and very possibly triple over the next decade, from the present $750million to $3billion a year even without any more liberalizing of benefits.

title: Transit Policeman Shoots And Wounds Holdup Suspect
description: A transit patrolman shot and captured an armed holdup suspect early yesterday after the man fled into an IND subway station at 125th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue to escape from two pursuing city policemen, the police reported.

title: Details of New Orleans Shootout Emerge, but Two Crucial Questions Remain
description: The following article was written by John Kifner and was based on renorting by Mr. Kifner, Paul Delaney, Douglas E. Kneeland and Martin Waldron.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: World's Poorest Found to Be Isolated Farmers
description: PARIS, Jan. 14What is it like to live in a poor country, one of the 25 poorest in the world?

title: Thought I Gava Game Away, Says Miami's Yepremian
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14In his relief over the Miami victory today, Garo Yepremian sighed.

title: Claim for Payment By East Germany Renewed by Jews
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 Representatives of European Jews meeting in London demanded today that East Germany indemnify Jewish victims of Nazism, following the example set by West Germany.

title: Ambrose Haddock Dead at 77; Served on Criminal Court Here
description: Ambrose J. Haddock, who was a police captain when he was appointed a magistrate by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1939 and subsequently was a Special Sessions and Criminal Courts justice until his retirement at the end of 1965, died Friday in Corona, Calif., where he was, living with a son. He was 77 years old.

title: PATH Aims to Grow into New Commuter Line
description: If all goes according to plan, the Port Authority Trans Hudson (PATH) rapidtransit system will more than double in size within five years. In the process, it will change from a shorthaul conveyor of other railroad's passengers into a fullfledged commuter line.

title: Rangers Top Flyers, 52
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14Exhibiting a deft passing game that was mindful of some of the better New York teams the past, the Rangers swept over the Philadelphia Flyers,

title: Luck and Kindness Assist the Neediest
description: A little bit of luck and the kindness of two good Samaritans brought a total of $40 recently to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Nancy Troy told the fund that on Dec. 27her birthdayshe found a $10 bill on the street.

title: Magee Trial to Resume
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 (AP)The prosecution opens tomorrow in the murderkidnapping trial of Ruchell Magee, the San Quentin Prison convict charged with killing a judge in the 1970 Mrain County courthouse violence. The jury of seven men and five women has been sequestered at a hotel since Jan. 5.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, JANUARY.15, 1973
description: President Nixon sent Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. to Saigon yesterday to consult with President Nguyen Van Thieu about ceasefire negotiations. Henry A, Kissinger gave the President a report on his six days of meetings with Le Duc Tho in Paris. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Issues in the L.I.R.R. Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, electrical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as well as some supervisors.

title: Burma Finally Admits U.N. Drug Team
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14Burma, reluctant for many years to take outside help in curbing opium trafficking, has accepted a United Nations team of narcoticscontrol experts. The group, led by Dr. Sten Martens, chief of the United Nations Division on Narcotics, arrived last week.

title: It Was MiamiType Day
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 (AP)  Super Bowl fans today chatted about the weather, calling it a Miamitype day as temperatures soared into the SO's. However, hack in South Florida, where the Dolphins reside, it was a chilly 40 degrees.

title: Waverly Consort Offers Music of Tudor Courts
description: Music of the Tudor Courts from Henry VIII to Elizzabeth I is not the kind of concert title impresarios hold in particularly high esteem, but Saturday night at Tully Hall it looked like a winner.

title: David Cox Weds Miss Spielman
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 14Miss Patricia Ray Spielman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Spielman, was married here this afternoon to David Gray Cox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollister Burton Cox of Port Washington, L. I., and Alexandria Bay, N. Y. The Rev. Dr. Frederic Fox, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Mayfair Farms.

title: Martin Luther King Day
description: Public schools will be closed today here and in numerous cities, including Newark, Chicago, Los Angeles, St. Louis and Atlanta, to mark the birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Details are on Page 32.

title: BOMBS ULSTER KILL 3 POLICEMEN
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 14Three policemen were killed and three injured by two bombs in Northern Ireland today.

title: Luck and Kindness Assist the Neediest
description: A little bit of luck and the kindness of two good Samaritans brought a total of $40 recently to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Redskins Rejected Use of Onside Kick In Hope of Break
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14With 2 minutes 7 seconds left in the Super Bowl game today and behind by 7 points, why did the Washington Redskins forgo an onside kickoff to try to get the ball back from the Miami Dolphins after scoring their touchdown?

title: Husky Oil Picks President
description: Directors of Husky Oil, Ltd., have picked James E. Nielson as president, while his father, Glenn E. Neilson continues as chairman. The younger Mr. Nielson, who has been executive vice president of the company since 1971, is a graduate of the University of Wyoming and served three years as a naval officer before joining the company on a permanent basis in 1958. His father organized the company in 1938.

title: William F. Davidson, 68, Dealer In Western American Art, Dead
description: William Francis Davidson, a dealer who pioneered in the placing of Western American art in specialized museums, died yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: Salt Lake City, 3 Others Bidfor '76 Winter Games
description: GENEVA, Jan. 15  Salt Lake City and three European vacation sports centers became today the official candidates to host the 1976 Winter Olympic Games rejected by Colorado voters in a referendum last November.

title: Making War, Not Love
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15President Nixon's order for the Christmas carpetbombing of Hanoi and Haiphong was perhaps the most imperial military decision in American history, although its purpose was diplomatic. It was not taken during a declared war, or in a domestic emergency such as Lincoln had to deal with, or in general consultation with Congress and the United Nations, as was Harry Truman's decision to defend South Korea, or even with the dubious authorization of the Tonkin Gulf Resolution upon which Lyndon Johnson relied. Mr. Nixon's bombing decision apparently was not discussed even with his own Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Jury Gets Case Today of Guard Charged in 1970 Riot in Tombs
description: The case of Earl Whittaker, a suspended correction officer accused of having encouraged inmates who rebelled at the Manhattan Men's House of Detention in October, 1970, goers to the jury today.

title: TEACHERS' STRIKES GO ON IN 2 CITIES
description: A teachers' strike will keep Chicago's public schools closed today with both sides still divided on major issues, while the strikebound Philadelphia school district opened special classrooms yesterday for seniors in eight high schools in that city.

title: Thieu's Daughter to Wed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15 (Reuters)The 18yearold daughter of President Nguyen Van Thieu is to be wed Friday. Newspapers published a twocolumn announcement of the approaching marriage of Miss Nguyen Thi Tuan Anh and Nguyen Tan Trieu, son of the director of the national airline, Air Vietnam.

title: Thomas Finletter Weds Mrs. Geist
description: Mrs. Eileen Wechsler Geist of Paris, formerly of Pittsburgh, and Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary; of the Air Force, were married Saturday in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, in the study of the justice of the peace there.

title: Next for Dolphins: Persuading Morrall and Kiick to Stay
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15Despite the Miami Dolphins' unbeaten record, Jim Kiick and Earl Morrall were uncertain today about remaining with the Super Bowl champions. Coach Don Shula hoped to persuade both of them to return next season.

title: Stock Prices Plummet
description: Stock prices registered their fourth largest decline yesterday in more than two years. Traders' fears were attributed to prospects of renewed inflation and uncertainty about President Nixon's Phase 3 economic plans. The DowJones industrial averaged slumped 13.77 points to close at 1,025.59. Earlier in the day, prices had climbed on Vietnam peace hopes. DeDetails on Page 51.

title: Strict Auto Curb on Coast Doubted by Ruckelshaus
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15Although its administrator indicated he did not expect such a measure to be put into effect, the Environmental Protection Agency formally proposed today an 80 per cent reduction in auto travel in the Los Angeles, basin, to be made effective through gasoline rationing.

title: From Children, Coins for the Neediest
description: A stream of pennies, dimes and, dollars from children wanting to help other children has flowed in recent days into the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Grand Jury Asks Improvement Of Conditions in Morris
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 15 (AP)  A Morris County grand jury issued a presentment today that called for improved conditions at the county jail, including the hiring of a fulltime warden.

title: Traders Display New Concern on Outlook
description: The credit markets displayed additional fear yesterday that the pace of inflation might accelerate under the Phase 3 economic plans while the markets largely ignored what seemed to be increased prospects for peace in Vietnam.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES SHOW ADVANCE
description: Traders awaiting the Department of Agriculture's report due after the close of trading yesterday bid up the January soybean contract, but the other months remained steady in a quiet session on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Jun. 15The Supreme Court took the following action today:

title: ENGLISH BOXERS BEAT U.S., 6 TO 5
description: In an international match that almost went down to the last bout before a decision was reached, England's national amateur boxing team defeated the United States team, six bouts toa five before a crowd of about 1,000 in the Felt Forum last night.

title: Notes on People
description: Governor Rockefeller, who has often talked of the need to keep skilled professionals working in New York State, announced that he had hired former Gov. Russell Peterson of Delaware to head  new state commission. Mr. Peterson's hiring came just a fortnight after his term as Governor expired. A Republican, Mr. Peterson was defeated for reelection in November. His salary for the new post was not disclosed.

title: WNBCTV to Drop Four News Shows Seen on Sundays
description: Television station WNBC will drop four of its Sunday public affairs programs late next month and replace them with Sunday, a live magazineformat series to be seen from 10 A.M. to noon.

title: 16 Die as Turkish Bus Falls
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 15 (AP)A bus fell over a cliff in a snowstorm last night near the Black Sea town of Zonguldak and officials reported today that people were killed and 25

title: Missing Yachtman Found
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Jan. 15 (AP)A retired Navy commander who had been the object of a 20,000squarmile search in the Atlantic has been found safe drifting in his yacht off the Florida coast, the Coast Guard said today. The Coast Guard said that Newell Varney of Vinal Haven, Me., had been spotted Saturday drifting in his yacht, Trouble, by a tanker off Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Trying to Pick Up the Pieces When a Child's Home Life Fails
description: For many of them, the juveniles labeled Persons In Need of Supervision (PINS), there was little shock and no real anger when their parents took them to court. Hostile, frustrated and unhappy, they were, nevertheless, aware that they were pushing the limits.

title: Student Strike in Madrid
description: MADRID, Jan. 15 (AP) Several thousand students at Madrid's three universities went on strike today to protest sharp increase in transportation and meal costs, sources at the universities said. The students said they would not end their walkout until prices were brought back to December's levels.

title: B.O.A.C. ASKS $185 ON LONDON FLIGHT
description: New York  to  London fares Said to be the lowest ever offered by a scheduled airline were put forward yesterday by the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

title: Lawyer Gets Five Years In CocaineSmuggling Plot
description: A Los Angeles lawyer, convicted of conspiring to smuggle cocaine from Colombia, got a fiveyear prison sentence in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Suit Seeks to Force an Election To Fill 2 Vacant Senate Seats
description: TRENTON, Jan. 15  The League of Women Voters of New Jersey asked the State Superior Court today to order the State Senate to call a special election to fill two vacant Senate seats in Morris and Union Counties.

title: Pepsico Plan Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission voted today to reject a settlement offer from Pepsico, Inc., concerning its acquisition of the Rheingold Corporation last year, the agency announced.

title: FREED AUSTRALIAN REACHES HONG KONG
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Jan. 16 (Reuters)An Australian journalist, Francis James, detained for more than three years in China on charges of spying, walked across the border into Hong Kong today after being departed by the Chinese Government.

title: P.S.C. PLAN OFFERS PNON&AIDCNRRGE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15A Public Service Commission representative recommended today that the New York Telephone Company be allowed to charge for local information calls if the number requested was in the local directory. In return, he suggested, the company should reduce the basic monthly charge.

title: Law Gives Mental Patients Rights, but Worries Others
description: Psychiatrists, judicial officials and community leaders are watching the state's controversial new mentalhygiene law to see how well it does what its supporters claim for it: strike a balance between the civil rights and needs of patients and the rights of the community.

title: Nixon's Call to Shula Is Blacked Out
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15Don Shula, the coach of the Super Bowl champion Miami Dolphins, was congratulated by President Nixon today.

title: Mayor's Trophy Game Set for Shea May 10
description: The 11th annual Mayor's Trophy game between the Yankees and Mets was scheduled yesterday for Thursday night, May 10, at Shea Stadium.

title: ENLARGED COUNCIL VETOED BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay vetoed a bill yesterday that would have created six City Council districts to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on the Council, contending that there had not been sufficient notice, awareness and debate by the public on the bill.

title: Court to Hear School Plan In Richmond and Suburbs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 ??he Supreme Court agreed today to answer one of the most ??ontroversial questions raised ??y school desegregation: Whether a judge may merge a ??eavily black city system with ??eparate white districts in the ??uburbs to produce a measure ??f racial balance.

title: V.F.W. to Honor Stennis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, will receive the Veterans of Foreign Wars 10th annual Congressional Award for outstanding service to the nation. The presentation will he made March 6 in Washington.

title: Chess: Bishops of Opposite Color, So Near and Yet So Far
description: Bishops of opposite are the only pieces on hoard that must follow totally separate tracks, making contact with other  which is what Spassky meant when he of his divorce that he and first wife were like bishops opposite colors.

title: Pension Mushroom
description: Municipal pension costs, which have, nearly tripled in the last decade, are likely to triple again in the next decadeto a staggering $2.9 billion a yesreven if the city puts a clamp on further liberalization of the generous retirement programs now authorized.

title: Deduction on Home Repairs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI)  Representative Bob Casey, Democrat of Texas, introduced legislation today to allow a $750 tax deduction for home repairs. Mr. Casey said he had 62 cosponsors, and many other House members had verbally given their support. The bill would allow a homeowner to deduct up to $750 a year for the cost of repair or improvement to his residence. Rental housing owners would be allowed rapid amortization over five years for the cost of rehabilitating rental housing.

title: Stock Prices Plummet
description: Stock prices registered their fourth largest decline yesterday in more than two years. Traders' fears were attributed to prospects of renewed inflation and uncertainty about President Nixon's Phase 3 economic plans. The DowJones industrial av eraged slumped 13.77 points to close at 1,025.59. Earlier in the day, prices had climbed on Vietnam peace hopes. Details on Page 51.

title: CROSSWORD. PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: East Europeans Begin Strategy Session
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 15Foreign ministers of the seven Warsaw Pact countries gathered here today for an unannounced meeting evidently intended to map strategy for the separate EastWest negotiations taking place in Helsinki and Geneva.

title: Paine, Webber Net Up
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., one of the nation's largest investment houses, disclosed yesterday that it had experienced a sharp increase in revenues and earnings in the final quarter of calendar 1972.

title: DYE WILL ENTER WANAMAKER MILE
description: Byron Dyce will be running in at least one indoor track meet every weekend for the next two months, perhaps more concerned with the crowd than with his competition.

title: U.S. Hijacking Case Ends in a Mistrial
description: Federal District Judge George Rosling in Brooklyn declared a mistrial yesterday in the trial of Garrett B. Trapnell, who had admitted hijacking a Trans World Airlines jet last Jan. 29, but contended he was insane at the time.

title: Drill Instructor Back on Duty
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 15 (AP)The Marine Corps said today that a 23yearold drill instructor had been found guilty of pouring dot water on a recruit but is back to work after being fined $100. The penalty was unusually light because of the excellent past service of the instructor, Sgt. Henry Gonzales, a spokesman said.

title: CHESS MATCH IS SET TO BREAK 3WAY TIE
description: A threeway match to break the tie for the United States chess championship will be played Feb. 3 to Feb. 11 in Chicago, the United States Chess Federation announced yesterday.

title: GUILT IS ADMITTED IN L.I. DEATH CASE
description: MINEOLA, LI., Jan. 15The murder trial of Barry Glen Lipsky, accused of killing a former New York City model who was to have been a key Government witness in a narcotics case, Was interrupted in Nassau County Court here today when the defendant pleaded guilty to the lesser charge of firstdegree manslaughter.

title: Assembly Adopts Curbs On Use of Word Masseur
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15The Assembly today approved a bill that would restrict the use of the word masseur or masseuse to those who meet the standards of education, experience and Moral character now required by the state for licensed masseurs and masseuses.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: SwissEast German Ties
description: GENEVA, Jan. 15Switzer land and East Germany will open embassies in each other's capital on Wednesday, the Swiss Foreign Ministry announced today. The announcement marked the completion of negotiations undertaken by the two countries after their agreement last month to establish diplomatic relations.

title: BERNARD J. CIANCA
description: Bernard J. Cianca, a partner in the accounting firm of Touche Ross & Co., died of complications of influenza on Sunday at his home, 150 East 69th Street. He was 57 years old.

title: Rita Dimitri Offers Continental Songs With Bit of Patter
description: Even at less than their best, performances of French chansons can be pleasant indeed, something like aural postcards that recall old journeys. On Sunday evening, Rita Dimitri, who normally appears at La Chansonette, a supper club on Second Avenue, brought a mixed bag of Continental popular songs of the last few decades to Tully Hall, and the occasion seemed to provide a good deal of calm pleasure for her transplanted clientele.

title: Out of the Quagmire?
description: President Nixon's decision to halt all offensive military action against North Vietnam is a promising gesture. It reinforces the cautious optimism voiced by both sides after six days of marathon peace talks in Paris last week between Presidential aide Henry A. Kissinger and North Vietnam's chief negotiator, Le Due Tho.

title: A. B. C. SUPPORTS PRIME TIME RULE
description: The American Broadcasting Company recommended to the Federal Communications Commission yesterday that the F.C.C. retain its controversial prime times access rule for television for at least another two years.

title: PUBLIC CAUTIONED ON HYPERTENSION
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 15Many Americans are risking their lives because of what they don't know about their own high blood pressure, experts said here today at a national conference on that health problem.

title: CYRIL B. JUDGE
description: Cyril B. Judge, of New York and Newport, R.I., where he taught at St. George's School from 1910 to 1927, died yesterday in Newport Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 807 Fifth Avenue and in Newport.

title: DR. WILLIAM ENGEL, BEGAN STUDENT FUND
description: Dr. William Engel, a retired physician who was a benefactor of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, died Saturday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 84 years old and had been residing there and in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

title: Romney Agrees to Head Voluntary Action Center
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 15George Romney, who is leaving President Nixon's Cabinet after four years as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has agreed to become the chairman and chief executive officer of the National Center for Voluntary Action.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SENIOR CLASS The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, 120 Madison Avenue, between 30th and 31st Streets (MU 6.9244), is, it says, the oldest Englishspeaking school for teaching acting (there's an older French one), going back to 1884. The school has 300 students going for degrees in the twoyear course and about 1,000 in all, including others who attend evening sessions. Every school year, the senior students, directed by faculty or outsiders, put on a dozen plays using the two small 200seat theaters in the academy's Georgianstyle landmark home, built by Stanford White in 1905. The new season gets under way today with Scenes From American Life, by A. R. Gurney, repeated Thursday at 2. Tomorrow, there's Tennessee Williams's Summer and Smoke (repeated Friday) and Jan. 23 and 25, Lorraine Hansberry's To Be Young Gifted and Black. And so on through April, Because the theaters are small and the students have first call on seats, followed by professional directors, agents and suchlike, the shows are not open to the general public. But there are seats for the Friends of the Alumni of the school, a group that you may join by paying $10, which gets you into the series for the whole year, You cannot get in at the door today, but you may arrange to be a friend by writing or by calling first.

title: Judge Declares a Mistrial in Hijacking Case Herc
description: Federal District Judge George Rosling in Brooklyn declared mistrial yesterday in the trial of Garrett B. Trapnell, who had admitted hijacking a Trans World Airlines jet last Jan. 29, but contended he was insane at the time.

title: Australian Ballet In Film of Quixote
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaRudolf Nureyev's film of Don Quixote, with the Australian Ballet, breaks new ground in both the cinema and the dance. The production, its filming recently completed, is expected to bring luster to the Australian image in the lively arts.

title: U.S. Program Brings 9 Foreign Educators to Study State's Methods of Teaching
description: BERGENFIELD, Jan. 15New ideas and programs planted in New Jersey's public schools may soon be sprouting in faraway places like Nepal, thanks to the Federal Fulbright exchange program under which Binoy Chandra Gurung and eight other foreign educators are studying the American way of teaching in the state.

title: Block Is Investment By ISADORE BARIVIASH
description: The Loews Corporation, conglomerate with holdings in the tobacco, theater, hotel and realestate fields, has acquired 848,700 shares of the common stock of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., or about 10 per cent of the retail company's outstanding stock.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West IndiesHurtling three feet above the windchurned waters of Frank Sound on Grand Cayman's south shore, a muscular, silvery tarpon of 35 or 40 pounds shook his head violently and threw the small plug I was using 10 feet in the air.

title: People and Business
description: Lord Erroll of Hale, a former British Minister of Power and former President of the Board of Trade, will become chairman of the Bowater Corporation on Feb. 5. As chief executive officer of the giant worldwide paper, pulp and board producer, Lord Erroll, who is 58 years old, will succeed J. Martin Ritchie, 55, who is retiring

title: Leading Soviet Dissident Starts A Year of Research in Britain
description: LONDON, Jan. 15 (Reuters)  A leading biologist, Prof. Zhores A. Medvedev, better known as a leader of Soviet political dissidents, started work today at Britain's National Institute for Medical Research.

title: MRS. RALPH H. SCHUST
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Jan. 15Mrs. Hannah Sovereign Schust, wife of Ralph H. Schust, retired vice president and director of Sunshine Biscuit Company, died Saturday in Nassau Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived on Dogwood Lane.

title: 30Day Rule on VoterResidency Gains
description: TRENTON, Jan. 15a resolution that would give New Jersey voters a chance to reduce the sixmonth voterresidency requirement to 30 days passed the Assembly 650 today and was sent to the Senate.

title: Zenith Workers Strike
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (Reuters) The Zenith Radio Corporation said today that color television production at its Springfield, Mo., plant had been halted by a strike of 3,360 members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON; N.J., Jan. 15  You either have the horses or you don't, and by luck we have them.

title: Cabinet Nominees Advance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (Reuters) The Senate Commerce Committee approved today the nominations of two Cabinet officerstrederick B. Dent as the new. Secretary of Conunerce and Claude S. Prinegar as Secretary of Transportation. The full Senate must still tote on the nominations.

title: Shah to Visit Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 15 The Shah of Iran will start a twoday private visit to Pakistan tomorrow at the invitation of President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

title: WALTER A. MOOS
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 15 (AP)Walter A. Moos, a leading art dealer, died Friday at the age of 46.

title: From Children, Coins for the Neediest
description: A stream of pennies, dimes and dollars from children wanting to help other children has, flowed in re tent days into the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: CASO FILING SUIT IN L.I.R.R STRIKE
description: Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso will file an action in Brooklyn Federal Court today seeking to compel the Long Island Rail Road and the striking unions to resume train service while negotiations continue.

title: Garden Track Meet Will Drop U.S. Anthem to Avoid Incidents
description: Amid growing controversy over whether it should be played at sports events, the national anthem has been dropped from the Olympic Invitational track and field meet at Madison Square Garden.

title: Gangs Spread Terror in the South Bronx
description: A 37yearold drug pusher is fatally struck by six bullets that shape a cross on his body. A bus is invaded and its driver held at gunpoint while passengers are relieved of wallets, watches and other valuables, Wild West style, A runaway girl is crippled after being beaten with belts and chains.

title: AMEX DEPRESSED BY LATE SELLING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market dropped sharply yesterday after late selling pressure erased most of the earlier gains in active trading.

title: Gangs Spread Terror in the South Bronx
description: This is the second of four articles on the South Bronx.

title: Patient and His Doctor: quandary for Medicine
description: Fifteen years ago Milton Blackstone was clearly at the top among entertainment publicists. A clever, personable man whom friends called a genius, Mr. Blackstone guided Eddie Fisher to stardom and was the acknowledged manbehindthescenes whose ideas converted Grossinger's from small summer hotel in the Catskills to an international yearround resort.

title: Prison Is Experienced By 21 Probation Officers
description: HADDAM, Conn., Jan. 15After he was led from his cell in the old Haddam Jail, Tom Mauriello ventured a thought on a longaccepted reason for putting men behind bars.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon, citing progress made in the ceasefire negotiations in Paris, suspended bombing, mining, shelling and all other offensive action throughout North Vietnam yesterday. The White House press secretary announced the suspension after several hours of consultations between the President and Henry A. Kissinger. But United States reconnaissance of North Vietnam continues. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: West Point Boy Wounded In His Home by Pistol Shot
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 15 (AP)The 16yearold son of an Army sergeant was in serious condition today in West Point Army Hospital after being shot in the face with a .22caliber pistol he and two friends were handling, a military spokesman said.

title: Raid by the Police On Wrong House Brings an Apology
description: BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP)The State Public Safety Commissioner, John J. Kehoe Jr., publically apologized today to the people whose house was mistaken for a heroin factory and raided by the police last week.

title: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The proposed solution of added controls, more review personnel and new agencies of the Congress [editorial Dec. 26] will not cure the problems of our national defense procurement system. It is based on a belief that the problem is rooted in the evils of a militaryindustrial conspiracy, phony budgetary practices and bought contracts.

title: CENTRAL ORDERED TO KEEP RUNNING
description: NEWARK, Jan. 15Federal Judge Anthony T. Augelli today ordered passenger service on the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey extended for 60 days beyond the scheduled Jan. 21 cutoff after the state agreed to put up $470,000 in additional subsidies for the line.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ITHACA N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP)Academic disqualifications and a walkout by one player have reduced the troubled Cornell University basketball team to seven members, it was disclosed, today.

title: 9 Angry Men and Women Assail The Juror Who Wouldn't Listen
description: The drinks were soothing and the free shrimp was delicious. But the words spoken by the nine persons standing around the bar at Foffe's yesterday were bitter.

title: TankerTugboat Collision
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 (UPI) The Coast Guard reported today that a tankertugboat collision in heavy fog on the Mississippi River had set 14 barges adrift and grounded the tanker. The tanker, Naess Mariner, of Liberian registry, reported to be carrying a cargo of crude oil, was grounded on the east bank of the river. There were no injuries.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Plant Ruined and 7 Hurt By Blasts in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 (AP) Three explosions rocked South Philadelphia early today, destroying a meat packing plant, shattering homes and injuring at least seven persons.

title: Javits Backs Transit Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, joined move today to provide Federal subsidies for urban mass transit systems that operate at a loss. Mr. Javits said that he had become a cosponsor with Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, of legislation that would set up an $800million twoyear transit fund.

title: WARREN WADE DIES; ACTOR, PRODUCER, 76
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 15 Warren Wade, a retired actor and broadcasting executive, died yesterday in a nursing home here. He was 76 years old and had lived at the Actors Fund Home.

title: Control Data Seeks Broad Base
description: Known through the last decade as the world leader in the manufacture of super computers, the Control Data Corporation has moved recently to become a broadbased company, a kind of supermarket for computer services.

title: Kolton Asks Job Equality In the Securities Industry
description: Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that the exchange would undertake broadbased program to upgrade employment opportunities for women and minority groups at the Amex and in the securities industry in general.

title: Garden Track Meet Will Drop U.S. Anthem to Avoid Incidents
description: Amid growing controversy over whether it should be played at sports events, the national anthem has been dropped from the Olympic Invitational track and field meet at Madison Square Garden.

title: Artists' Gathering Spot Closing in the Village
description: There is nothing remarkablelooking about the Village Drugs store on Seventh Avenue South at Bleecker Street, which will close at the end of this month, after 35 years. The walls are a shabby drugstore green, and along one wall there are shelves of the usual lotions, creams, rinses and pharmaceutical paraphernalia. In the aisle there are wire racks stacked with paperback books.

title: The Times Bars Support to Panel for Monitoring News Media
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, announced yesterday that The Times would refuse to cooperate with the press council being set up by the Twentieth Century Fund to monitor the performance of the national news media.

title: U.S. BEGINS TRIAL OF MAUL AIDE
description: An assistant district attorney from Queens went on trial with two codefendants in Federal court here yesterday on charges of quashing a criminal case for a bribe of $15,000.

title: MANUGUERRA SINGS A SPLENDID RENATO
description: The new element in Saturday night's Un Ballo in Maschera at the Metropolitanand quite the best aspect of the performance  was Matteo Manuguerra's Renato. Mr. Manuguerra has become something of a sleeper in the Met's baritone ranks and he must now be classified as one of the company's finest singers.

title: Schwartz, in Lyricists Series, Tells of Pitfalls in Song Writing
description: The Lyrics and Lyricists series opened its third season Sunday evening at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue at 92d Street, with the youngest lyricist it has over offered and the one with the shortest track record.

title: Canada Alerts Observers for Vietnam but Has Some Tough Demands of Her Own
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 15Canada is prepared to begin moving peacekeeping force of as many as 1,450 military personnel into Vietnam within 10 days of a ceasefire agreement, officials in the Department of External tffairs say.

title: BUS SERVIECE OPENS ALONG NAUGATUtJK
description: ANSONIA, Jan. 15A small, experimental bus service for four towns in the Naugatuck Valley got a noisy reception from 300 angry bus drivers when it started early last week.

title: Dr. King and the Movement Are Recalled As His 44th Birthday Is Observed Here
description: Observances yesterday of the 44th birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. evoked the spirit of the civil rights movement, and at the same time indicated disquiet at what one speaker called the resurgence of the racist ethos in the country.

title: 51% in Survey Say That Crime Has Increased in the Last Year
description: More than half or all those who were interviewed in a recent Gallup Poll believe there is more crime where they live than there was a year ago.

title: Two Bombings in Milan
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 15 (Reuters)  Two powerful bombs went off here at dawn today, one damaging a branch office of the extreme rightwing National Vanguard Movement and the other partly wrecking a tavern. No one was hurt and it was not known whether the incidents were related.

title: PRESIDENT HALTS ALL BOMBING, MINING AND SHELLING OF NORTH; POINTS TO PROGRESS IN TALKS
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 15 President Nixon, citing progress made in the ceasefire negotiations in Paris, suspended bombing, mining, shelling and all other offensive action throughout North Vietnam today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: GUSTAVO THOM SCORES IN SKIING
description: ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 15 (UPI)Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, the Alpine skiing World Cup champion the last two seasons, scored a clearcut victory in a giant slalom today for his first triumph of the season.

title: BRANDT AND PARTY MAKE PEACE APPEAL
description: BONN, Jan. 15 (AP)Chancellor Willy Brandt and his Social Democratic party appealed today for a swift end to the war in Vietnam and welcomed the halt in United States bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Wall St. Uneasy Over Inflation and Phase 3
description: Stock prices broke sharply yesterday  registering the fourth largest decline in more than two yearsas fears of renewed inflation and uncertainty about Phase 3 stalked Wall Street.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell, former head of the New Jersey National Guard, was found not guilty last night of two charges of misconduct in office.

title: Stage: Shaw's Don Juan in Hell at 70
description: When one stands out of joint with current dramatic history, one can either fake it or admit it. I prefer to admit it. Most people who have an opinion on the matter regard George Bernard Shaw as one of the great playwrights of this century. I do notbut it seemed as well to mention this at the outset, and perhaps to discuss the performance and background of last night's play at the Palace Theater, before entering my minority report on the play itself.

title: SECRET DRAFT HELD BY A.B.A. MEMBERS
description: The American Basketball Association yesterday held a secret draft by telephone here of collegiate basketball players. Two draft rounds were held, with both seniors and underclassmen selected, The Associated Press learned. The names of only two players picked in the draft were immediately learned.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Text of White House Briefing on the War
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 15 (UPI)  Following is a transcript of a briefing today by Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, in which he announced a halt in all military operations over North Vietnam:

title: TV: A.B.C.'s Yeasty Night Strangler
description: Even with that title, grab The Night Strangler. This madeforTV thriller is a yeasty surprise, blending laughs, local color (Seattle) and real chills. The 90minute program goes on tonight at 8:30 over the American Broadcasting Company.

title: Greece Is Giving Up Cash Grants From the U.S.
description: ATHENS, Jan. 15  Greece announced tonight that for the first time since American military aid began 25 years ago she was giving up cash grants from the United States.

title: Philippine Supreme Court Is Asked to Block Charter
description: MANILA, Jan. 15Opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos have asked the Phillippine Supreme Court for help in their efforts to block the Government from putting into effect a new constitution that they denounce as authoritarian. A hearing has been scheduled Wedneday.

title: Pompidou Visits African Territory
description: DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, Jan. 15 (AP) President Pompidou of France arrived in this African dependency today on a visit that will later take him to Ethiopia.

title: International League Votes To Adopt PinchHitter Rule
Housing Freeze
description: The Administration's decision to freeze new Federal commitments to subsidize construction of low  and middleincome housing has drawn strong protests from home builders, mortgage lenders, state and local officials, and Democratic Congressmen. But the real hardship resulting from the cutoff will be to families of low and moderate income hoping to find decent places to live that they can afford.

title: Miss Gould Is Aussie of Year; Swim Ace, 16, Coming to U.S.
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 15 Shane Gould, the 16yearold swimming star, was named Australian of the year by a national committee today. The honor conferred on the blonde athlete has been given previously to Prime Ministers, among others.

title: Senate Leaders Hail End to Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Senate leaders of both parties today applauded President Nixons decision to stop the bombing of all of North Vietnam.

title: I.B.A. TO SELL UNIT TO CONTROL DATA IN SETTLING SUITS
description: The Control Data Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday settlement of Control Data's antitrust suit against the computer giant, and I.B.M.'s subsequent counterclaims.

title: Owners Waited Like Vultures, Dismissed Penguin Coach Says
description: After Coach Red Kelly was dismissed by the Pittsburgh Penguins, one of the owners explained: After working with someone for a year and a half, your opinions on how he can do a job change: Kelly was a year and a half into a fiveyear contract. He got his club, which has never been particularly imposing, into the playoffs twice in the last three seasons. It currently is in the midst of a very tight playoff battle in the National Hockey League's West Division. Kelly, whose strongest expletive is hang (as in The referee can go to hang), was in uncharacteristically bad humor after the dismissal.

title: P.S.C. PLAN OFFERSPHONEAID CHARGE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15A Public Service Commission representative recommended today that the New York Telephone Company be allowed to charge for local information calls if the number requested was in the local directory. In return, he suggested, the company should reduce the basic monthly charge.

title: Senator's Brother Killed
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Jan. 15 (AP)State. Senator Alfonso Montoya, 44 years old, was killed in a highway accident 19 miles north of here yesterday. He was a brother of United States Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico.

title: 4 MORE ADMIT GUILTAS SPIES IN WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Four of the six remaining defendants in the Watergate trial pleaded guilty today in Federal Court to spying on the Democrats during last year's campaign.

title: Small Saigon Paper Sole Key to Thieu Views
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15Rare is the Vietnamese in Saigon who buys Tin Song, the small proGovernment afternoon newspaper. But at 4 P.M. every day, when Tin Song rolls off its antiquated presses, all the foreign embassies and news organizations in town rush to get copies.

title: A World West of Yale
description: The awarding of the Bollingen Prize for Poetry, one of the richest and most prestigious in the nation, to James Merrill underlines once again the tendency of the administrator of the prize, the Yale University Library, to reward poetry that is literary, private, traditional. Two decades have passed since an exception was made in the case of William Carlos Williams in 1953.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West IndiesHurtling three feet above the windchurned waters of Frank Sound on Grand Cayman's south shore, a muscular, silvery tarpon of 35 or 40 pounds shook his head violently and threw the small plug I was using 10 feet in the air.

title: U.S. Said to Bomb North Until Deadline
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 16 (UPI)American planes reportedly continued bombing the southern panhandle area of North Vietnam yesterday right up to the time that President Nixon's order halting bombing and shelling went into effect.

title: Ulster Is Threatened With Widened Curbs After Police Deaths
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 15The British administration in Northern Ireland threatened today to impose tighter security restrictions on the entire community in an attempt to deal with a new increase in terrorism.

title: Music: Delays Mar Rock Concert at Philharmonic
description: Rock n roll concerts in New York, on too many occasions, run with the same regard for time as the Long Island Rail Road. The usually efficient Philharmonic Hall slipped up badly Sunday evening when Flash, Dr. Hook and Earth, Wind and Fire appeared.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Semi  Tough, Dan Jenkins's best  selling novel about professional football, will be produced as a Broadway musical next season by David Merrick, who has purchased the stage rights.

title: EARNINGS MIXED FOR 3 BIG BANKS
description: Three of the nation's largest banking concerns reported yesterday their earnings for the Fourth quarter and for the full year of 1972, The results were mixed and lacked any conclusive pattern.

title: 8 U.S. Journalists Enter China for a 3Week Tour
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 15 (AP)A group of eight American journalists and writers crossed into China today for a threeweek tour of Peking, Shanghai, Canton and other major cities.

title: VIOLATIONS LAID TO CLINTON OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The Securities and Exchange Commission today named the Clinton Oil Company of Wichita, Ran., and 18 present and former officers and directors in a complaint alleging repeated willful violations of Federal securities laws.

title: JURY DEADLOCKED IN TRIM OF CORNY
description: VACAVILLE, Calif., Jan. 15A jury of 10 men and two women said today that it was deadlocked 8 to 4 in the trial of Juan V. Corona, the 38yearold Mexican national accused of murdering 25 migrant farmworkers.

title: Miss Makarova Excels in Coppelia
