description: Harmonizing the sunny, endearing side of Swanilda and her less appealing destructive inclinations is the task of great interpreters of the role in Copplia. On Sunday afternoon, American Ballet Theater's Natalia Makarova combined these elements of the heroine's character into a warm and wittily mischievous portrait at City Center.

title: World Steeplechase Mark Tied By Jipcho in AllAfrica Games
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  Ben Jipcho of Kenya equaled the world record of 8 minutes 20.8 seconds in the 3,000meter steeplechase today at the AllAfrica Games.

title: 18.6% Rise in '72 Net
description: The International Business Machines Corporation posted record worldwide consolidated net earnings last year of 1.28billion, equal to $11.03 a share, according to yesterday's preiminary report.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The aim of the unofficial game that started yesterday on the seventh floor of Abraham & Straus is to find the bed. And anybody who figures out even half of the ingenious spacesaving solutions (without help, of course), gets high marks for discernment.

title: Mrs. Meir Confers With Pope in Vatican
description: ROME, Jan. 15  Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Pope Paul VI met in the Vatican for an hour today and discussed peace efforts for the Middle EAt, the status of Jerusalem and the question of Palestinian refugees.

title: $95Million Price Tag On Phase 2 Operation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)The Nixon Administration spent about $95million to administer Phase 2 wageprice controls, the Cost of Living Council estimated today.

title: Bridge:
description: The Swiss team championship, which concluded the tristate regional championships at Grossinger, N. Y., Sunday night, had a surprise result. Four young men previously unknown to bridge fame, Stephen Paskin and Tom Triffon of Albany, Ralph Wahl of Orange, N. J., and Fred Melman of East Orange, N. J., won eight straight matches, thus heading a field of more than 200 teams, which included many international stars.

title: I.R.M. TO SELL UNIT TO CONTROL DATA IN SETTLING SUITS
description: The Control Data Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday settlement of Control Data's antitrust suit against the computer giant, and I.B.M.'s subsequent counterclaims.

title: SIDNEY W. SOUERS INTELLIGENCE AIDE
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15  Rear Adm. Sidney W. Souers, U.S.N.R., retired, the first executive secretary of the National Security Council and the first director of a forerunner of the Central Intelligence Agency, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived here.

title: Interior Aide to Retire Feb. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) The Interior Department has announced the retirement on Feb. 1 of Ralph W. Snyder, acting director of the Office of Oil and Gas. His successor has not been named.

title: Two Infants Calm for Hours In Car Lost as Father Drinks
description: A nightcap in a local bar turned into a near nightmare for a young Harlem father yesterday morning.

title: Cantwell Acquitted In Misconduct Case
description: TRENTON, Jan. 15  Maj. Gen, James F. Cantwell, former head of the New Jersey National Guard, was found not guilty tonight of two charges of misconduct in office.

title: Amer. Hockey League
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Advertising: Suds With a Status
description: It's always interesting to see how an ad agency will handle a new beer accountwill it go after the heavy drinker (a la Schaefers' when you're having more than one) or the sophisticated intellectualwho doesn't drink beer (as with Freberg's unsuccessful Ballantine effort)?

title: Tax Rise Would Drive UpRent And Utilities, Businessmen Say
description: Leading businessmen, including spokesmen for Consolidated Edison and the New York Telephone Company, predicted yesterday that rent and utility costs would continue to rise in the city because of increasing realestate taxes.

title: 2 Community College Officials Accused Of Illegal Link to a Publishing Concern
description: Associate Dean George M. Halpern of the New York City Community College and Prof. James P. DeLuca, chairman of the school's graphic arts department, were accused by the New York City Board of Ethics yesterday of a conflict of interest in operating a publishing company whose books were required reading for all graphicarts students at the college.

title: Freeport to Increase Price of Sulphur
description: The Freeport Minerals Company said yesterday that it had notified customers of a sulphur price increase of $3 a ton applicable in the Gulf Coast region, on the South and Middle Atlantic Coast and in the Mississippi River area north to St. Louis.

title: ALBERTASKS STUDY OF UNITS IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Responding to complaints of dwindling Congressional power, House Speaker Carl Albert called today for the first sweeping study of House committee structure in more than a quarter of a century.

title: Patient and His Doctor: Quandary for Medicine
description: Fifteen years ago Milton Blackstone was clearly at the top among entertainment publicists. A clever, personable man whom friends called a genius, Mr. Blackstone guided Eddie Fisher to stardom and was the acknowledged manbehindthescenes whose ideas converted Grossinger's from small summer hotel in the Catskills to an international yearround resort.

title: ENLARGED COUNCIL VETOED BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay vetoed a bill yesterday that would have created six City Council districts to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on the Council, contending that there had not been sufficient notice, awareness and debate by the public on the bill.

title: F.T.C. GIVEN DATA ON COLD REMEDIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Sixteen makers of popular cough and cold remedies reported under Government order today what is in their products that prompts them to advertise the way they do.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A former judge and a public relations executive will compete today for the Republican nomination to succeed Millicent H. Fenwick in the State Assembly. Mrs. Fenwick resigned to become State Consumer Affairs Director.

title: FOOD PRICE UP 0.6% HERE IN NOVEMBER
description: Retail grocery prices in the New York and northeastern New Jersey area increased 0.6 per cent in November, a month in which they normally decline.

title: MONEY GROWTH RATE TOPPED FED GOALS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Federal Reserve's open market sought at its meeting of Oct. 17 to reduce the rate of growth of the nation's money supply, but later events showed that it did not succeed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Associate Dean George M. H. Halpern of the New York City Community College and Prof. James P. DeLuca, chairman of the school's graphic arts department were accused by the City. Board of Ethics of a conflict of interest in operating a publishing company whose books were required reading for all graphicarts students at the college.

title: Unreasonable Search
description: At 10 o'clock of a weekday morning fifteen men, armed to the teeth, break into the home of the William Pine family in Winthrop, Mass., by smashing the doors. Mrs. Pine and her teenage daughter, in uncomprehending terror, plead for mercy. Her husband, who holds night job, awakens in his upstairs bedroom to stare into the muzzle of a gun. Through Mrs. Pine's panicked mind flashes the almost forgotten story, told to her as a little girl, of how Nazi stormtroopers had routed her grandparents out of bed in their native Poland and murdered them thirty years ago.

title: Law Gives Mental Patients Rights, but Worries Others
description: Psychiatrists, judicial officials and community leaders are watching the state's controversial new mentalhygiene law to see how well it does what its supporters claim for it: strike a balance between the civil rights and needs of patients and the rights of the community.

title: Artists' Gathering Spot Closing in the Village
description: There is nothing remarkablelooking about the Village Drugs store on Seventh Avenue South at Bleecker Street, which will close at the end of this month, after 35 years. The walls are a shabby drugstore green, and along one wall there are shelves of the usual lotions, creams, rinses and pharmaceutical paraphernalia. In the aisle there are wire racks stacked with paperback books.

title: 5 OF 7 DENY GUILT IN ARMS SMUGGLING
description: ALEXANDRIA, La., Jan. 15 (AP)Five of seven men accused of an international plot to smuggle warmaking materials out of the United States entered not guilty pleas at arraignment proceedings today.

title: Justices to Weigh Dispute on Clean Air Standards of U.S. and the States
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Government can require states' to keep all their, air as clean as it is now, even if it is much cleaner than Federal pollution standards require.

title: In Italy, Abortions Are Easyfor Rich
description: ROMEIt is easier for a girl to have an abortion in Italy than in any other Western country where abortion is outlawed, commented an American who had helped find doctors for two fairly welloff foreign women.

title: Haig, in Saigon, Begins Talks With Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 16 General Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's special envoy, arrived in Saigon this morning, reportedly to present President Nguyen Van Thieu with copies of a draft of a new Vietnam peace accord.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 15 (Reuters)The enlarged Common Market met its first major problems today when Foreign Ministers of the nine European Economic Community countries failed to agree on the main topic at their first working meeting here.

title: Mr. Richardson's Turn
description: McLEAN, Va.Deterrence, our sole protection from a nuclear attack or blackmail, requires not only sufficient retaliatory weapons to make the initiation of war inconceivable, but also a national attitude that leaves no doubt in the minds of both our potential foes and our allies that we will not submit to intimidation.

title: Watergate Judge Is Called Firm and Nonpartisan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Early this afternoon after four more defendants had pleaded guilty and, the Watergate seven had diminshed to the Watergate two, one of the trial spectators turned to a companion and cracked: This judge will have a trial even if there are no defendants left.

title: Moore Succeeds Himself
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Jan. 15 (UPI)Arch A. Moore, Republican, today became the first West Virginia Governor to succeed himself in more than 100 years. In his inaugural address he stressed the utter failure of the Federal Government to respond to states' needs. Governor Moore was the beneficiary of a constitutional amendment that restoredfor the first time since 1866a West. Virginia Governor's right to seek reelection.

title: PRESIDENT HALTS ALL BOMBING, MINING AND SHELLING OF NORTH; POINTS TO PROGRESS IN TALKS
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 15 President Nixon, citing progress made in the ceasefire negotiations in Paris, suspended bombing, mining, shelling and all other offensive action throughout North Vietnam today.

title: Wrecking Ball Hits at Garden City Hotel
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 15  Celebration, sadness, nostalgia and even, a touch of comedy were mingled as demolition of the historic Garden City Hotel under the pounding of a threeton wreckers' ball began here today before a crowd of 200 people.

title: Meskill Picks Mrs. White, ExCity Editor, as an Aide
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 15 CAP)Susan White, former city editor of The Winsted Evening Citizen, has been appointed an administrative assistant to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill.

title: People in Sports: Coach Wanted
description: After six years during which his teams compiled wonlosttied record of 22383, Bill Pace resigned yesterday as football coach and athletic director at Vanderbilt University. There are other opportunities I want to explore and I also feel it's in the best interests of all concerned, said Pace whose Commodores had only one winning season under his tutelage. I have no ill feelings. My only regret is that I didn't have a better record.

title: The Art of Dying: II
description: WASHINGTON  Throughout all ages man has struggled to avoid, deny or embellish death, for death has always been regarded as a personal enigma which defies explanation. Although some religions have brought death and its surrounding fears into the open and offered transcendent reasons for accepting it, by and large it has remained a taboo topic. Men have feared to discuss it openly and to acknowledge that death is part of life.

title: Safety Gap
description: A Federal judge has upset, at least temporarily, an Administration effort to nullify the deadline set by Congress for strict enforcement of new job safety standards.

title: Covent Garden Plan Saves Some of Old
description: LONDON, Jan. 15The British Government approved a major redevelopment plan for historic Covent Garden today, but rejected some of the features that had worried conservationists.

title: Records: By Pat Boone
description: Pat Boone is a survivor. Back in 1955 he was making cover versions (copies) of rhythm n blues hit single reords, softening them for mass  audience consumption and being very successful. He was wearing white shoes (a trademark) and refusing to kiss his leading ladies in films, for fear of condemning his fans and their Swoon With Boone buttons to moral purgatory.

title: A.B. C. SUPPORTS PRIME TIME RULE
description: The American Broadcasting Company recommended to the Federal Communications Commission yesterday that the F.C.C. retain its controversial prime times access rule for television for at least another two years.

title: Heavy Snow Falls in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 15The Israeli Army was called out today to take relief to hilly areas, including Jerusalem, disrupted by heavy snow. The forecast tonight was for more snow with a thaw tomorrow bringing a danger of flooding.

title: LINDSAY IS SCORED ON SCHOOL SAFETY
description: The City Council's Committee on Health and Education charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's recent proposals for improving school security were meaningless, costly and a sop to frightened parents and students.

title: FOOD PRICE UP 0.8% HERE IN NOVEMBER
description: Retail grocery prices in the New York and northeastern New Jersey area increased 0.6 per cent in November, a month in which they normally decline.

title: Shooting of Upstate Girl, 8, Laid to Use of Father's Gun
description: MADRID, N. Y., Jan. 15 (AP)An 8yearold St. Lawrence County girl who died yesterday of a gunshot wound may have been playing with a revolvor from her father's gun rack, sheriff's deputies said today.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: ExAlderman Gives Up
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (UPI) Former Alderman Fred Hubbard surrendered today to Federal marshals to begin a twoyear prison sentence for embezzling $100,000 from a program to bring minority groups into the construction industry.

title: Officials' Mistrust Is Evident in Wake Of N.C.A.A. Parley
description: By GORDON S. WHITE Jr.

title: Conservation Bill Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) The chairman of the House Agriculture Committee introduced legislation today to reinstate a $225million soil conservation program killed by the Nixon Administration last month. Representative W. R. Poage, Democrat of Texas, submitted the measures that would order the Administration to spend the same amount of money that Congress approved last year for the Rural Environmental Assistance Program.

title: The Mystery Guest Of Honor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Scene: A temporary White House somewhere in North America. The producers of the Inauguration are meeting with the President of the United States.

title: HAROLD DELANO
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 15Harold Delano, a publisher of he former Cordage Trade Jourial, who later was with Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., died yesterday here. He was 86 years old and formerly lived in Brooklyn.

title: Irish and Israeli Consulates In Boston Destroyed by Fire
description: BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) A general alarm fire today in a fivestory business building destroyed the offices of the Irish and Israeli consulates.

title: $8Million Grumman Christmas Bonus May Have Come From Navy Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The. Defense Department's general counsel told a Senate subcommittee today that the Grumman Corporation had paid its traditional $8million Christmas bonus to workers last month and that the money could have come from the $54million the Navy had advanced to the company.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon, citing progress made in the ceasefire negotiations in Paris, suspended bombing, mining, shelling and all other offensive action throughout North Vietnam yesterday. The White House press secretary announced the suspension after several hours of consultations between the President and Henry A. Kissinger. But United States reconnaissance of North Vietnam continues. [Page 1, Column 8.].

title: Air Pollution Study Assesses Plant and Crop Damage
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Jan. 15  American growers lose $132million each year because of air pollution damage to crops and plants, according to a new study by Stanford Research Institute.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Tax Rise Would Drive Up Rent And Utilities, Businessmen Say
description: Leading businessmen, including spokesmen for Consolidated Edison and the New York Telephone Company, predicted yesterday that rent and utility costs would continue to rise in the city because of increasing realestate taxes.

title: MISS CLODES SHOWS A WARM PIANO TONE
description: Maria Clodes is a sensitive and sensible pianist. Her Town Hall recital late Sunday afternoon underscored the fact and gave more than a glimpse of her fleet technique, warm tone and thoughtful musicianship as well.

title: 9 Angry Men and Women Assail The Juror Who Wouldn't Listen
description: The drinks were soothing and the free shrimp was delicious. But the words spoken by the nine persons standing around the bar at Foffe's yesterday were bitter.

title: SELECTION GOES ON FOR ELLSBERG PANEL
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15The process of selecting the six alternate jurors in the Pentagon papers case continued today, with the expectation that it will be completed by Wednesday. None were selected today.

title: Q.E. 2's Chef Lost Overboard
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 15 (UPI)An unsuccessful search for a chef lost overboard from the cruise ship Queen Elizabeth 2 was suspended tonight. The United States Coast Guard here said the crew member, who was not identified, was apparently lost overboard early today somewhere in the middle of the Caribbean between 75 miles northnorthwest of Aruba to 100 miles south of Haiti. The luxury liner turned around on her course as soon as the loss was discovered to search for the man.

title: Red Smith
description: It might surprise Pete Rozelle to learn that there is a Super Bowl that never has a dull moment. For Super Bowl, the horse, things are so exciting that on the day he started his new career he fainted dead away. In his new career he is a lover. The owner of the world mile record for 3yearold trotters won his last 18 races, took the triple crown by sweeping the Hambletonian, Yonkers Futurity and Kentucky Futurity, was chosen 3yearold champion and trotteroftheyear in landslide elections, was syndicated for $1million and finally retired to stud on Hanover Shoe Farm near Gettysburg, Pa. His first date was a comely and wellbred lady named Reneged, a daughter of the Hambletonian winner, Hickory Smoke. Super Bowl was still just a 3yearold, a big bashful kid from the country. In his confusion he passed out cold. Hal Jones, Hanover's stallion master, slapped his face until the colt woke up, looking sheepish. Since then, Super Bowl has been attending to duty cheerfully every Monday, Wednesday and Friday.

title: 20,000 in Capital Suburb Protest School Busing Plan
description: OXON HILL, Md., Jan. 15 (UPI)An estimated total of 20,000 white parents and students turned out in freezing temperatures yesterday at a rally protesting racial school busing in their prosperous Washington suburb.

title: Moore Succeeds Himself
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Jan. 15. (UPI)Arch A. Moore, a Republican, today became the first West Virginia Governor to succeed himself in more than 100 years. In his inaugural address he stressed the utter failure of the Federal Government to respond to states' needs. Governor Moore was the beneficiary of a constitutional amendment that restoredfor the first time since 1866a West Virginia Governor's right to seek reelection.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE QUEST FOR MIND. Plaget, LviStrauts, and the Structuralist Movement. By Howard Gardner. $76 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: U.S. Cuts Force in Vietnam To 23,800, a Drop of 200
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15 (UPI)Two hundred American servicemen left Vietnam for home last week, dropping United States troop strength there to 23,800, the United States command said today.

title: VI PASTOR FACES SECURITIES CURBS
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 15The multimilliondollar empire of the Rev. Rex Humbard, which includes a New York girdle factory and a Michigan college, is being threatened by security commissioners in Ohio and several other states.

title: PISTONS VANQUISH BLAZERS, 112101
description: DETROIT, Jan. 15 (AP)Dave Bing and Bob Lanier led a fourthperiod spurt as the Detroit Pistons defeated the Portland Trail Blazers, 112101, tonight to snap a threegame National Basketball Association losing streak.

title: State Moves to Protect Part of Appalachian Trail
description: TRENTON, Jan. 15The Legislature authorized the State Department of Environmental Protection this evening to acquire control of a segment of the Appalachian Trail in New Jersey and protect it from impending commercial development.

title: Marriages
description: MODEL/RUZOWMr. and Mrs. Theodore Ruzow announce the wedding of their daughter Elleen Andrea to Michael Model.

title: Writers Honor Bobby Allison As 1972 Driver of the Year
Copier Sales Gain Cited
Industrial Output Surged Last Month
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Industrial production rose strongly in December for the fifth consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Mrs. Meir Confers With Pope in Vatican
description: ROME, Jan. 15  Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Pope Paul VI met in the Vatican for an hour today and discussed peace efforts for the Middle East, the status of Jerusalem and the question of Palestinian refugees.

title: A BREWER PROGRAM OF BACH AND HANDEL
description: Edward Brewer, a young harpsichordist who made his debut in 1966, appeared here Sunday night at CAMI Hall, His program included major harpsichord pieces by Bach and Handel, minor ones by SweeIinck and Byrd, and sonatas for oboe by Handel, Bach and Telemann, for which he was most capably joined by his wife, Virgina Brewer.

title: 4 MORE ADMIT GUILT AS SPIES IN WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Four of the six remaining defendants in the Watergate trial pleaded guilty today in Federal Court to spying on the Democrats during last year's campaign.

title: St. John's Has a Surprise Star
description: Few would argue this has been a college basketball season of surprises. Who would have thought Florida State, with all its talent, would lose three games or that Alabama would be leading the Southeastern Conference with Kentucky and Tennessee around?

title: Strict Auto Curie on Coast Doubted by Ruckelshaus
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15Although its administrator indicated he did not expect such a measure to be put into effect, the Environmental Protection Agency formally proposed today an 80 per cent reduction in auto travel in the Los Angeles basin, to be made effective through gasoline rationing.

title: DR. PEROLAF THERMAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 (AP)Dr. PerOlaf G. Therman, director of experimental and clinical investigation at the Institute of the Pennsylvania Hospital, died yesterday at his home in Rosemont.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Idaho Power Company said yesterday had filed with the securities and Exchange Commission for a planned public offering of 750,000 common shares to be sold Feb. 13. The company's stock closed at 34, down , on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: STOCK EXCHANGES ORDERED TO ADMIT INSTITUTION FIRMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered all stock exchanges to accept as members any brokerage firms doing a predominantly public I business.

title: Westchester Towns Pressed on Housing
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 16The State Urban Development Corporation plans to proceed with its controversial ninetown housing plan in Westchester County, Edward J. Logue, president of the state agency, said today.

title: U.S. Exhibits Stoned in Spain
description: MADRID, Jan, 16 (Reuters)Youths stoned windows and threw gasoline bombs at two American automobile showrooms here today in protest against the Vietnam war, police sources said.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Auto Union to Seek Contract Reopener Clause to Protect Wages
description: DETROIT, Jan. 16  Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that the union would seek the right to reopen its next contract with the auto industry at any time to protect itself against Government interference under the third phase of wage and price controls.

title: Zoo Animals Visit Children at a Hospital in Harlem
description: A slithering but friendly fourfoot boa constrictor, a curious screech owl, a prickly hedgehog, a very nosey ferret and two cuddly young white rabbits visited the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Medical Center yesterday.

title: Howmet Unit Head Named
description: Theodore Operahll was named yesterday president of a new gas turbine components group at the Howmet Corporation. This was the first step in series of moves planned to restructure the company around its major activities.

title: Books of The Times
description: UNDERSTANDING THE NEW BLACK POETRY. Black Speech and Black Music as Poetic References. By Stephen Henderson. 395 pages. Morrow. $9.95.

title: Women Troopers Ahead?
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16New Yorkers can soon expect to see women state troopers. Governor Rockefeller said in his budget message today that the first appointment of women troopers would be made possible with the elimination of the requirement that applicants must be male.

title: NEW ORLEANS BLACK DIES IN POLICE CHASE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 (AP) A man being chased by the police was shot to death in a black housing project today, and a large crowd quickly gathered to hurl taunts at the police, including one promise that a sniper would return to the city.

title: U.S.Canada Oil Talks Gain
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Canadian and United States energy negotiators are understood to have made quiet progress behind a curtain of secrecy toward an agreement for sharing continental oil supplies in an emergency.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The top 20, with points floured on a 1098.7654321 basis for first through 10th places (firstplace votes In parentheses) and wonlost records through games of last Saturday.

title: Advertising: Finding Statistics
description: Advertisers spent some $22.5billion to spread their words last year and will probably, go to $25billion this year. That's a lot of money isn't it?

title: Accused U.S. Airman Gets Two Sentences in Athens
description: ATHENS, Jan. 16A United States Air Force private began serving two and a half years for attempted robbery here last night and a further term of four and a half months he had received for burglary was affirmed today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Churches Press Businesses on African Holdings
description: Six Protestant church organizations are renewing a campaign for full disclosure and close scrutiny of American corporate investments and activities in southern Africa, it was announced yesterday.

title: No Jurors for Brown Trial Have Been Selected Yet
description: No jurors were selected as of yesterday in the trial of H. Rap Brown, the black militant, and three codefendants charged with holding up a West Side bar Oct. 16, 1971 and attempting to murder policemen in an ensuing gun battle.

title: Soviet Luna 21 Lands on Moon, Delivering Lunokhod 2 Craft for Exploration
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 16The Soviet Union's latest unmanned moon craft, Luna 21, made a successful soft landing today and delivered the Russian's second remotely controlled roving vehicle to the surface of the moon.

title: Five Laotian Communist Leaders Leave Vientiane Peace Talks for Consultations
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 16In a development evidently related to reports of progress toward a Vietnam ceasefire, five leaders of the Communist delegation at peace talks here left today for consultations in their headquarters at Samneua.

title: HOUSE UNIT CHIEF FACES CHALLENGE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, said today that he would challenge the reelection of Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California, as chairman of the House Government Op erations Committee.

title: Sky Marshal Plan Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) Senator Richard S. Schweiker, said today that the Federal sky marshal program, aimed at deterring airline hijacking, was a complete flop and urged Congress to stop providing money for the program. The Pennsylvania Republican said at a news conference that the $40milion to $60million set aside for the program should be used instead to pay for Federal guards at airport boarding gates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: State Control of Job Safety and Health?

title: SENATORS PRESS NIXON ON SECRECY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Senate Democratic Policy Committee, in a fresh challenge to President Nixon's authority, decided today to try to limit the Administration's use of executive privilege to avoid giving testimony to Senate committees.

title: ExJustice Joseph M. Callahan Of State Supreme Court Is Dead
description: Joseph M. Callahan, a forme State Supreme Court Justic and Associate Justice of th Appellate Division, died yester day at his home in Southamp ton, L.. I. He was 87 years old.Mr. Callahan, who was th father of Civil Court Judge Al fred J. Callahan, retired from the Supreme Court bench in 1955 and was appointed by Gov. Averill Harriman as More land Act Commissioner to in vestigate operations of th workmen's compensation stat utes.

title: Congress Orders President To List Impounded Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The Senate completed Congressional action today on measure requiring President Nixon to submit to Congress by Feb. 10 a list of all Federal funds impounded since last July 1.

title: Kertesz Conveys Poetic Significance of Details
description: The career of Andr Kertsz is one of the longest most distinguished of living photographers. Among professional peers, Mr. Kertsznow 78 years old and a resident of New York since 1936  has long been knowledged as one of master artists of the photographic medium. Yet his career has been a difficult one, and work has remained, until very recently, remarkably littleknown to the American public. For this reason, as well as for its intrinsic quality, the exhibition opening today at the Hallmark Gallery, Fifth Avenue at 56th Street, is an event. Entitled Andr Kertsz: Themes and Variations, it brings us more than 200 pictures surveying an achievement that had its beginnings in the artist's native Hungary on the eve of World War I and continues unabated today.

title: Metropolitan Finds Odalisque Not by Ingres; Will Rehang Painting With a New Attribution
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art says that one of its most popular paintings, Odalisque, attributed to Ingres, is not by Ingres after all.

title: Sanderson Will Take $1Million
description: Derek Sanderson again received an offer he couldn't refuse and he will take $1million not to play hockey for the Philadelphia Blazers.

title: Woman Dies in Plunge
description: A 74yearold woman fell or jumped to her death yesterday from her 15thfloor room in the apartment building at 208 West 23d Street, formerly the Carteret Hotel. The woman, identified as Madeline Love, had lived alone in the building since 1957.

title: Mrs. Richard L. Wright, 73, Widow of Magazine Editor
description: BOSTON, Jan. 16  Mrs. Gertrude Albion Wright, widow of Dr. Richard L. Wright, who was editor in chief or House & Garden, died yesterday at New England Baptist Hospital. She was 73 years old and had lived in West Chatham since her husband's death in 1959.

title: COURT TO REHEAR DETROIT BUS PLAN
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 16 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit agreed today to rehear full arguments on a school desegregation plan for Detroit and 52 suburban school districts.

title: U.S. Widens Trade Role, Triples Exports to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 16  SovietAmerican trade nearly tripled in the first 11 months of 1972, even before large grain shipments began arriving here. The surge put the United States, for the first time, among the Soviet Union's major Western trading partners.

title: Notes on People
description: A blow was struck by Dr. Bruno Bettelheim, the child psychologist and author, for what might be called boys' liberation. Dr. Bettelheim, in an article in the February issue of the Ladies' Home Journal, said studies revealed that grade school teachers reprimand boys more frequently than girls.

title: Crusaders Beat Blazers On PowerPlay Goal, 43
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (UPI)  Dick Pumple's powerplay goal with 2:57 remaining gave the Cleveland Crusaders 43 victory over the Philadelphia Blazers tonight in a World Hockey Association game.

title: City Is Recruiting Addicts For Treatment in Centers
description: Providing a positive counterpoint to his earlier negative reaction to Governor Rockefeller's suggestion of life prison sentences for drug sellers, Mayor Lindsay yesterday outlined steps the city is taking to increase the number of drug abusers under treatment.

title: Lunokhod 2 on Moon
description: The Soviet unmanned craft Luna 21 has landed on the moon and delivered Lunokhod 2, the Russians' second remotely controlled vehicle, to the lunar surface to begin explorations. Details on Page 14.

title: Neil Gunn, Scottish Author Of More Than 20 Novels
description: LONDON, Jan. 16Neil M. Gunn, an author and playwright, died last night in Inverness, Scotland. He was 81 years old.

title: Female Artillery Brisk A.B.C. Comedy
description: A tone of laconic, goodnatured crustiness makes Female Artillery middling diversion as the Wednesday Movie of the Week. It goes on tonight at 8:30 over the American Broadcasting Company, with 90 minutes running about 30 minutes too long, which is not uncommon for these madeforTV movie specials.

title: Celtics Triumph, 106102, On Havlicek's Late Spree
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 16 (UPI)John Havlicek's 16 points in the fourth quarter led the Boston Celtics to an uphill 106102 National Basketball Association victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight before 10,274 in Memorial Auditorium.

title: COP ON BEAT PLAN STIRRING INTEREST
description: TRENTON, Jan. 16  The image of the cop on the beat painted by Governor Cahill in his annual message to the Legislature is proving popular with city residents and mayorsbut not so popular with some police officials.

title: Rockefeller's Budget
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16Like the couturier who annually moves the feminine hemline and calls it truth, Governor Rockefeller has basted together a state budget that sets a midcalf mode for 197374.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: New York 102, Phoenix 101. Baltimore 112, Los Angeles 104. Boston 106, Buffalo 102. Cleveland 100, Golden State 98. Atlanta 130, Detroit 129 (overtime). Milwaukee 108, Philadelphia 92, Chicago 100, Portland 89. Seattle 125, K.C.Omaha 122.

title: Rage Permeates All Facets of Life in the South Bronx
description: Rage is a condition of life in the South Bronx. It permeates the rubblestrewn streets and the unheated tenements. It blazes in the eyes of youthgang members and smolders in the brooding faces of mothers huddled on predawn lines at welfare centers and stacked in rows of benches in hospital emergency rooms and clinics, where many wait an entire day to see a physician.

title: Rates on Credit Markets Show Tendency to Rise
description: The credit markets continued to reflect yesterday the bullish implications of Vietnam peace and the bearish implications of too much domestic prosperity.

title: '72 Was a Vintage Year For Wine Consumption
description: ALBANY, Jan. 161972 was a very good year for wine taxes.

title: Crisis in Los Angeles
description: For more than twenty years California authorities have known that the peculiar topographical and climatic conditions in Los Angeles and its five surrounding counties were making the automobile an increasing health hazard. Yet until a few years ago so little was done to head off an inevitable crisis that the California Medical Association, not given to hysteria, was moved to warn of a state of chronic and increasing emergency.

title: ISLANDERS DROP 12TH STRAIGHT 10 Drouin Gets North Stars' Goal With Illegal StickGilbert Stops 29 Shots
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 16For the first time in their short, unhappy National Hockey League career, the Islanders tonight held the opposition to one goal. Unfortunately, the New Yorkers didn't score any.

title: Nearby Counties to Get More Money, but Their Welfare Bills Will Rise, Too
description: There is a major contradiction in Governor Rockefeller's 197374 budget from the point of view of the state's suburban counties: they will be receiving substantial new state revenuesharing funds, but their obligations, in the form of new welfare commitments, will be going up as well.

title: Humor Underlies Themes of Dances By Jan Wodynski
description: There always seems to be an undercurrent of humor in Jan Wodynski's work, whether she makes an explicit point of it or not. In the seven dances presented at the Cubiculo Monday evening, she went from the cartoon fantasies of Superantics to the quiet witticisms of Changeover.

title: Reports of Imminent CeaseFire Persist But White House Is Maintaining Silence
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan 16  While reports persisted abroad that a ceasefire in Vietnam was imminent, the Nixon Administration refused today to shed any light on that possibility.

title: Industry Capacity Rate Is the Highest Since '70
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The nation's manufacturing industries operated at 79.7 per cent of capacity in the fourth quarter, the highest capacity utilization rate since early 1970, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Prices Ease Again on Amex and OTC
description: Prices on the overthecounter market and on the American Stock Exchange ended lower yesterday for the third consecutive session in slower trading.

title: WILLIAM WOLFSON
description: William Wolfson, a retired manufacturer of men's clothing and former resident of Scarsdale and New Rochelle, N. Y., died Monday of a heart attack in Miami Beach. He was 75 years old.

title: PreElection Budget
description: Governor Rockefeller has proposed an $8.88billion budget for New York State, up almost $1 billion from the current fiscal year's total. Despite that sizable jump, this is essentially a preelectionyear budget, one that clears away some old bills and holds the promise of massive surplus for a time when Governor Rockefeller may be running for still another term. Indeed, the political nature of the budget reinforces the feeling at Albany that Mr. Rockefeller may well intend to stay on, perhaps in hope of another shot at becoming President in 1976.

title: Last Raids in North Before the Deadline Are Listed by U. S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 17In the final hours of the bombing of North Vietnam on Monday, 87 fighterbomber strikes and four missions by threeplane formations of B52's were flown against targets south of the 20th Parallel.

title: Rome Rabbi Sees Vatican Discourtesy on Meir Visit
description: ROME, Jan. 16The Chief Rbbi of Rome said today that the Vatican had committed a grave discourtesy by allowing a spokesman to play down yesterday's meeting between Pope Paul VI and Premier Golda Meir of Israel.

title: Macy's Names Executives
description: Macy's New York announced the appointment yesterday of two new senior vice presidents. They are Carl Loschert, merchandise vice president, sportswear group, who has been put in charge of merchandising for stores other than Macy's Herald Square; and William McCarthy, vice president for customer service, who is in charge of operations for stores other than Herald Square.

title: RISE IN SOYBEANS LIFTS BEEF PRICES
description: Prices of live beef cattle futures played folow the leader with soybean prices yesterday as both climbed to new highs.

title: Major Items in the Budget
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16Following are the major parts of Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget for fiscal 1974, which begins April 1:

title: Scituate, Proud of Its Historic Symbolism, Is Split by Flag Dispute
description: SCITUATE, Mass., Jan. 16A secretary in the Town Hall motioned toward the American flag and the Scituate town flag, trembling in a slight breeze, and said that the mourning period for former President Harry S. Truman may have helped mute a growing controversy here. People are used to seeing the flags at halfmast since President Truman died, she said, and a lot of them didn't pay any attention. But those who have are very upset. They may be against the war and they may be as angry as anybody, but they don't like the idea of lowering the flag. There's something about using the flag that really bothers them.

title: Calder Finishes Season With Big Gain in Wagers
description: MIAMI, Jan. 16Calder Race Course, which has been open since last May 6, finally ended its eightmonth stand today as Ogden Phipps's Daring Young Man won the $50,000 added Saul Silberman Memorial Handicap  and then pulled up lame.

title: Elmer Anderson Carter Dead; Led State Agency Against Bias
description: Elmer Anderson Carter, former chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, predecessor to the State Division of Human Rights, died yesterday. He was 82 years old and lived at 409 Edgecombe Avenue.

title: TwoWay Benefits?
description: On its face the agreement between the Soviet Government and the General Electric Company for an extensive program of technological exchange and cooperation should help both Russia and the United States in coping with the growing energy crisis. That crisis creates need for the most efficient utilization of fuels and for development of means to generate power with minimum damage to the environment. The pledge of cooperation now reached in developing electric powergenerating equipment holds promise of progress toward both these goals.

title: War Protesters Outline Plans for an Inaugural March
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Final plans for an Inauguration Day antiwar protest march, from the Lincoln Memorial to the Washington Monument grounds, were announced here today by the two sponsoring peace groups.

title: PARKING FEE ENDED FOR STATE WORKERS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16 (AP)Under orders from the Public Employment Relations Board, the state today relented on a controversial parking fee for state employes and said it would refund payments to the workers.

title: Court Calls Hearing Tomorrow On Injunction in L.I.R.R. Strike
description: The Long Island Rail Road and 19 unions were ordered yesterday to show cause tomorrow in Brooklyn Federal Court why a temporary injunction should not be issued requiring them to end the strike while negotiations continue.

title: Jury Still Deadlocked in Trial of Corona
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 16A jury of 10 men and two women reported today it was again deadlocked, this time 11 to 1, in its fifth day of deliberations on the fate of Juan V. Corona, the 38yearold Mexican national accused of murdering 25 migrant farm workers.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 17, 1973

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The youth accused of stabbing a retired policeman to death in a subway station near Times Square had been released from custody in a state marcotics center in early December because his record there had been so good.

title: STATE BUDGET $8.8BILLION; SPENDING UP $933MILLION, BUT NO TAX RISE IS SOUGHT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16  Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today a proposed $8.88billion budget for the new state fiscal year beginning April 1. He said it represented a sound balance between justifiable optimism and realistic caution in assessing the state's fiscal condition.

title: Pragmatic Approach To the Common Market
description: LONDONThe British approach to the Common Market, of which it has at last become a member, is probably more pragmatic and less formalized than that of other partners in the European Community. This is to be expected of a country renowned for its respect for constitutional law and which, nevertheless, doesn't even have a written constitution.

title: MISS PROEM, WINS WORLD CUP SKIING
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 16 (AP)Annemarie Proell of Austria, unbeaten this season, vitrually clinched the 1973 World Cup title skiing today by racing to 1 victory in the women's downhill race over the 3,200meter Oberjoch course, slowed by more than a foot of wet snow.

title: Trudeau's Mother Dies
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 16 (UPI)Mrs. Grace Trudeau, the mother of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, died in a hospital here tonight. She was 83 years old. Mrs. Trudeau, the former Grace Elliotte, was hospitalized last May for a kidney ailment and in August, 1971, with an undisclosed illness. Her husband, CharlesEmil Trudeau, died in 1936.

title: Former General and Secretary Convicted of Trying to Cheat Army
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 16 (AP)Former Brig. Gen. Earl F. Cole and his secretary were convicted in United States District Court today on seven counts of making false statements to cheat the Army.

title: Neither a Disaster Nor a Boon Here
description: The city's budget director said yesterday that the Governor's proposed $8.88billion budget contained virtually no new money for the city.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 16There was a time when Seton Hall University was synonymous with quality track and field. John Moon believes it can happen again, and soon.

title: Space Center Picketed
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 16 (AP)Pickets were posted today at, the Manned Spacecraft Center by operating engineers, who struck in a dispute over contract wages with Kentron Hawaii, Ltd., which holds a heavy equipment operating con tract at the center.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: John Cage, the veteran enfant terrible, will be on hand for a retrospective concert of his music at Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon in Lincoln Center's New and Newer series. The event will be a belated celebration of Mr. Cage's 60th birthday, which was Sept. 5.

title: Rage Permeates All Facets of Life in the South Bronx
description: Rage is a condition of life in the South Bronx. It permeates the rubblestrewn streets and the unheated tenements. It blazes in the eyes of youthgang members and smolders in the brooding faces of mothers huddled on predawn lines at welfare centers and stacked in rows of benches in hospital emergency rooms and clinics, where many wait an entire day to see a physician.

title: Lunokhod 2 on Moon
description: The Soviet unmanned craft Luna 21 has landed on the moon and delivered Lunokhod 2, the Russians' second remotely controlled vehicle, to the lunar surface to begin explorations. Details on Page 14.

title: QuakeAlert System By Soviet Confirmed
description: Soviet observations of seemingly reliable form of advance earthquake warning for Central Asia have now been found applicable to quakes in the Adirondacks.

title: U.S. Confirms Greek Plan To End Direct Military Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) The State Department, confirming a Greek Government announcement yesterday, said today that Athens would no longer receive direct United States military aid.

title: AUSTRALIAN SEES AMITY WITH NIXON
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 16 Prime Minister Gough Whitlam declared today that he expected to get along with President Nixon despite differences between the two leaders on Vietnam.

title: ALLIED CHEMICAL POSTS PROFIT GAIN
description: John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, reported yesterday that preliminary figures indicated substantial increases in earnings for the fourth quarter and full year of 1972, while sales reached record levels for both periods.

title: I.B.M. as the Dream Come True
description: PATERSON, N. J.My interest in the legal dispute that the Justice Department has with International Business Machines Corporation goes beyond the fact that I was raised in an I.B.M. family where several members of our family group received their sustenance and successfully raised their children, thanks in no little way to the admirable vision of Thomas J. Watson Sr.

title: They Help Each Other Face the EnemyFood
description: Twenty nervous people were sitting in a circle in the basement of an East Side church, directly beneath loops of glittery holiday tinsel. But there was no joy on anybody's face. No glad tidings. No good cheer.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL REQUIRED TO BAR RACIAL INEQUITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Labor Department, charg ing the Bethlehem Steel Corporation with failure to overcome the effects of racial discrimination, ordered the company today to make sweeping changes in the seniority system at its plant at Sparrows Point, Md., to assure blacks better job opportunities.

title: H. E. W. Says Some States Use Sex Courses to Curb Illegitimacy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) Despite considerable hostile public opposition, some states are quietly promoting sex education in public schools to curb increasing rates of illegitimate births, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare told Congress today.

title: Bank on Move Ties Up Traffic on L.I.
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, L. I., Jan. 16  People hold up banks all the time, but it's not every day that a bank holds up people.

title: City and Unions Both Paid 127 Labor Leaders in '71
description: After a yearIong investigation, a Manhattan grand jury handed up an unusual report yesterday, charging the city administration with mismanagement for having allowed 127 union officials to remain on the city payroll in 1971 while they were receiving union salaries.

title: Stage: Wesley's Biting Strike Heaven
description: One of the main purposes of the New Phoenix Repertory Company's series of Sideshows is to discover new plays and to get them out into the world as quickly as possible. That purpose is completely justified by Richard Wesley's Strike Heaven on the Face!, which was presented Monday night and yesterday afternoon at the Bijou Theater. This is a play with great timeliness and urgency. Unquestionably, it deserves a full production, which should grow naturally out of this preliminary sketch for a production.

title: Stage: Let Me Hear You Smile Bows
description: There was a play last night at the Biltmore Theater called Let Me Hear You Smile. One had a certain difficulty in even hearing a laugh.

title: 42 Indicted Here; Tied to Policy Ring With Link to Lansky
description: Fortytwo persons were indicted yesterday in connection with a $50million Brooklynbased policy gambling empire linked to Meyer Lansky.

title: Clara Ward, Gospel Singer, 48; Leader of Popular Group Dies
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (AP) Clara Ward, the gospel singer, who performed her first solo at the age of 5 and grew up singing in churches with her mother and sister, died today. She was 48 years old.

title: Musica Sacra Adds Two Secular Works
description: Musics Sacra departed from its avowed subject matter to include two secular works in its concert on Monday night. Richard Westenburg, who directs the series at Central Presbyterian Church, wondered if the adjective sacred couldn't be stretched to encompass Benjamin Britten's Children's Crusade and Carl Orff's Carmina Burana. The former is a setting of Brecht's poem, which is as compassionate as it is harrowing, filled with a sense of humanity that might be considered religious. The case for the Orff cycle was that its medieval poems extol the virof love not war.

title: THIEU EXPECTED TO ACCEPT TRUCE PACT OFFICIALS SAY, THOUGH PROBLEMS REMAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 17President Nguyen Van Thieu is expected to give his approval to the text of a ceasefire agreement brought to him yesterday by Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., and the Government is now going over the details of how it is to be carried out, according to Vietnamese officials close to the presidential palace.

title: JUSTICES BROADEN JEOPARDY RULING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Supreme Court ruled today that its 1970 prohibition against prosecuting a man for the same crime in both state and city courts can be invoked by prisoners who were victims of such treatment before the law was changed.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE_
description: ACROSS

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Failure of motorists to include an extra dollar for the new reflectorized 1973 license plates is causing delays in mailing out the plates for thousands of car owners the metropolitan area, according to Morris Gimpelson, regional director of motor vehicles.

title: Steel Pier Gets 3 New Owners Who Are Betting on Its Future
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 16 Steel Pier, which has presented everything from diving horses to an embalmed whale, got some new owners today who would like to offer a new kind of entertainment.

title: TV: N.B.C. Peking Tour
description: Skillful sensibility of treatment and a fine pictorial sweep marked The Forbidden City, an uncommonly worthwhile hour of television viewing last night over the National Broadcasting Company network. And it simply must be seen in color.

title: Reid Proposes Congress Form An Agency to Compel Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Amid growing discontent on Capitol Hill with what some see as the usurping by the Nixon Administration of the powers of Congress, Representative Ogden R. Reid of Westchester County proposed today the creation of a Congressional budget agency that could compel the executive branch to spend money appropriated by Congress.

title: PURSE OP $25,000 OFFERED IN CHESS
description: Plans for what was deseribe as the richest chess tournament ever, with a total of $25,000 at stake for an anticipated field of 16 grandmasters, were an nounced here yesterday by Lieut. Col. Edmund B. Edmond son, executive director of the United States Chess Federation.

title: STOCKS FALL A BIT AS TRADING SLOWS
description: The stock market settled for a small decline yesterday in the DowJones industrial average after suffering big setbacks in the two previous sessions.

title: ExG.I.'s End Trial By Pleading Guilty To Bombing Camp
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 16The weeklong Federal court trial of two former servicemen charged in a 1970 bombing of an Army training camp ended abruptly here today when the defendants pleaded guilty to reduced counts.

title: A DU PONT AWARD TO MIKE WALLACE
description: Mike Wallace of the Columbia Broadcasting System is the winner in the category, of outstanding reporting in the Alfred I. du PontColumbia University Awards in Broadcast Journalism. He was cited for his work on C.B.S.'s 60 Minutes.

title: MAN RILLS WIFE, SONS AND HIMSELF
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 16A 37  year  old high school science teacher who had been under psychiatric care killed his wife and two young sons with an ax in their home here and then hanged himself, the police reported today.

title: Map Is Said to Hint Hotel Sniper Made Plans for 4 Attacks
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 (AP) A television station says that a marked map found in the apartment of the slain hotel sniper, Mark Essex, indicates that he methodically planned our attacks.

title: A French Town Worried About Selling Wine Is Cool to Elections
description: SETE, France, Jan. 12 Less than two months before a legislative election that threatens to shake a decade and a half of Gaullist rule, Government and opposition politicians are showing signs of hoarseness and ill temper from weeks of angry exchanges of accusations. The national press echoes them and adds to the appearance of a nation in the throes of political fever.

title: State Aide Says Few Fail Food Inspections
description: State Health Commissioner James R. Cowan said yesterday that only a small percentage of food establishments had failed inspection during the first month of the state's new program.

title: TV: C.B.S. Studies Strange Creatures of the Night
description: Some perfectly fascinating camera footage and data on bats the harmless kind and also the vampire speciesare the highlight and finale of a firstrate documentary titled Strange Creatures of the Night. As the season's first National Geographic Society television special (made with Wolper Productions), the hourlong program suggests the magazine itself: instructive, all over the map, often striking and no nonsense. Sponsored by LincolnMercury, it will be seen at 8 tonight on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

title: Pakistani Prisoner Killed; Tried to Escape, India Says
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 16 (Reuters)Sentries killed one Pakistani prisoner of war and wounded one when they tried, to escape from a camp in Uttar Pradesh early today, the Defense Ministry said.

title: GUARD AT TOMBS CLEAR ON 3 COUNTS
description: A State Supreme Court jury last night acquitted Earl Whittaker, a city correction officer, accused of encouraging inmates during a 1970 riot at the Tombs, of two counts of kidnapping and one of unlawful imprisonment.

title: People and Business
description: Yesterday Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith filed a red herring, or preliminary prospectus, with the Securities and Exchange Commission as the manager of an underwriting group for a new mutual fund. It also named the man who heads its investmnt banking division as a dirctor.

title: MET AND CITY OPERA AIDED BY ARTS FUND
description: The Metropolitan Opera has received sums of $194,500 for its student education projects and $200,000 for the Piccolo Met repertory to open next month at the Forum Theater. The grants are in the second series made by the National Endowment for the Arts in its opera program.

title: U.S. Planning Assistance For Yugoslavia Investing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (Reuters)An arm of the United States Government will provide insurance and financial services for private companies investing in Yugoslavia, the first time such Government services have gone to an Eastern European country.

title: Cat Is Willed $10,000
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (UPI) Sing Po, a 12yearold Siamese cat, is the beneficiary of a $10,000 trust fund set up by Claire H. Pease in a will admitted to Probate Court yesterday. The cat will receive $100 a month from the fund, to be paid to Mr. Pease's daughter Rosemary Porter of La Canada, Calif., for the animal's upkeep.

title: BUGNER'S VICTORY BOOED IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP)Joe Bugner, tuning up for next month's fight with Muhammad Ali, retained his European heavyweight boxing title tonight by registering a unani mous 15round decision over Rudy Lubbers of the Netherlands.

title: C.B.S. Gives a Report on Terms of Peace
description: C.B.S. News reported yesterday that it had gained access to portions of the draft agreement to end the war in Vietnam and gave details of provisions for release of prisoners, troop withdrawal, composition of a control commission and signing procedures.

title: Mindel Sheps, Fertility Expert And Biostatistician, Dies at 59
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 16 Dr. Mindel Cherniack Sheps, a physician who became a biostatistician and an authority on biological factors affecting fertility and reproduction, died yesterday in Durham, She was 59 years old.

title: Pigeons Get Invitation To Shan Inauguration
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 16 (AP)  They're shooing the pigeons out of Washington because of Saturday's Presidential inauguration, but only as far as suburban Alexandria.

title: Marcos Proclaims New Constitution; To Rule Indefinitely
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Jan. 17 (UPI)President Ferdinand E. Marcos today proclaimed the ratification of a new Constitution extending his term in office indefinitely.

title: Soprano Displays Insight and Charm In a Lieder Recital
description: Susan von Reichenbach gave her thirdor first, depending on how you countTully Hall lieder recital Monday night and, a few hopefully correctable technical limitations aside, it was a most pleasing affair.

title: 10 Tax Preparers Accused of Frauds
description: NEWARK, Jan. 16A Federal grand jury today returned fraud indictments against 10 persons who prepare incometax returns.

title: Senate Panel Backs 3 Nixon Nominees
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) The Senate Armed Services committee approved today President Nixon's nominees for top positions in intelligence and defense.

title: SENATORS PRESS NIXON ON SECRECY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Senate Democratic Policy Committee, in a fresh challenge to President Nixon's authority, decided today to try to limit the Administration's use of executive privilege to avoid giving testimony to Senate committees.

title: Unitas Still Open to Offers, But Not From Just Anyone
description: Joe DiMaggio and Johnny Unitas sat together at lunch here yesterday and the result was one vote for the designated pinchhitter and one vote against the Baltimore Colts.

title: Teamsters Gaining In Bid to Organize Lettuce Workers
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., Jan. 16 The Western Conference Teamsters announced significant improvements today in its contract with lettuce growers, an area where the teamsters are in competition with Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Union.

title: MILLION PLEDGED FOR A NEW SCHOOL
description: TEANECK, Jan. 16Fairleigh Dickinson University received a million  dollar pledge today from a large North Jersey contractor to help it set up a Center of Building Construction Studies here on its campus overlooking the Hackensack River.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: HOLD THAT TIGER Charley the Tiger stalks Central. Park Zoo, in his cage, that is. If you have seen Charley in the flesh, you may want to see him on the wall. He, or his likeness, to be precise, is hanging on the exhibition room of the Austrian Institute, 11 East 52d Street (PL 9.5165), one of the wildlife artistic preserve titled Animals in Pencil and WaterColors, the work of Joseph Sibal, a Vienneseborn flew Yorker and retired textile and industrial artist who has spent many free hours prowling local zoos.

title: STOCKS FALL A BIT AS TRADING SLOWS
Joint Union Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) A joint legislative conference of the United Auto Workers and the International Association of Machinists was announced today for March 5, 6 and 7. Discussions will cover union campaigns on such issues as national health insurance, consumer legislation, tax retion and environmental protection.

title: MICHAEL J. BARRY
description: Michael J. Barry, father of Msgr. John J. Barry, director of finance for New York Catholic Charities, died Sunday at his home, 3125 Tibbett Avenue, the Bronx. He was 76 years old. Mr. Barry, a retired doorman, was a lifetime member of the Cork Hurling Club here.

title: KNICKS OVERCOME SUNS, 102 TO 101
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 16Another lastgasp victory fell into New York Knick hands tonight as they defeated the Phoenix Suns, 102101, in a National Basketball Association game in which the officiating outraged both teams.

title: EUROPEANS SCORE U. S. MONEY PLAN
description: LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 16Western Europeans indicated today their disagreement with initial American proposals to revamp the monetary system, heralding the first of what probably will be many clashes before greater stability is reached.

title: State Charges City Fails To Close Welfare Cases
description: The state and city clashed over welfare again yesterday when George F. Berlinger, the state's Welfare Inspector General, charged that the city's new computerized system had failed to close a single case out of 5,896 referred by five centers since the system started Nov. 13.

title: Watergate Defendant to Plead He Acted to Forestall Violence
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  A lawyer in the Watergate trial said today that one of the two remaining defendants would attempt to justify his actions on the ground that he had feared violence against President Nixon and other leading Republicans.

title: Suit Lays Blight to F.H.A. Foreclosures
description: A group of block associations representing 250,000 Brooklyn residents filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court charging that the Federal Housing Administration's mortgage  foreclosure program harms the general environment and hastens urban decay.

title: RevenueSharing Head
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) Graham W. Watt, Deputy Mayor of Washington, was named today to head the Treasury Department's Office of Revenue Sharing. Mr. Watts, who is 46 years old, is a native of Elizabeth, N. J. He succeeds Edward A Fox, the acting director, who will return to his post at the Federal Home Loan Bank hoard.

title: Music
description: Jacqueline Du Pr and her husband, Daniel Barenboim, shared the billing at their recital Monday night in Philharmonic Hall, but it was very difficult not to focus all attention on Miss Du Pr's cello playing. She has always been a performer of marked individuality, but on this occasion her work veered dizzily from the extraordinarily good through the questionable to the downright inadmissible.

title: Parkway Link Opens in Woodbridge
description: WOODBRIDGE TOWNSHIP, Jan. 16  The connection from Interstate Route 287 and the new Route 440 eastbound to the Garden State Parkway will be opened here for traffic tomorrow, state officials announced today.

title: Lindsay Meets With Rose on Mayoral Possibilities
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday told Alex Rose, the leader of the Liberal party, that even if he did not run for reelection this year he would organize a political coalition to make sure that a candidate who had pro, gressive leanings and was unbossed would be in the race.

title: BRIBE TALK TAPED, AGENT TELLS JURY
description: An undercover agent testified at a bribery trial in Federal Court here yesterday that he had used a concealed transmitter to taperecord conversations with two defendants accused of arranging for a Queens prosecutor to kill a criminal case.

title: 15YEAROLD MARE BRINGS $170,000
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 16 (AP)  A 15yearold mare in foal to the French champion, Le Fabuleux, was sold today for $170,000 at the Keeneland sale of horses of all ages.

title: Questions and Answers On New Member Rule
description: Following are questions compiled by The New York Times concerning the new rule on stockexchange membership promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, a dispatch about which begins on Page 1. Tentative unofficial answers are based on numerous discussions with people in the Federal Government and in Wall Street.

title: Red Smith Joe, George and One Who Isn't Here
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 16Joe Frazier, naked, pulled on thick white socks and threaded red laces through the eyelets of high shoes. He pulled, a white Tshirt over his head and stepped into bright red trunks. Standing flatfooted, he hunched his shoulders, flexed his arms, twisted left and right from the waist, relaxing the torso, shadowboxing lightly to loosen the muscles. Yank, he called, all right. He sat down, folded a towel across the back of a straight chair and laid a forearm over this padding. Yancey Durham, his manager, came across the room and started bandaging of a aegauze, roll and a anchoring that over the thumb, then taking measured turns around the knuckles and up the wrist, fixing it all with adhesive tape. It was purely mechanical, a fixed and familiar routine that left Frazier free to give his attention to visitors. He chatted easily and as he did one sensed the presence of a man who wasn't there. It is always so. Joe Frazier is here to defend the heavyweight championship of the world against big, unbeaten George Foreman. Yet the man whose name inevitably comes up is the man Joe whipped almost two years agoMuhammad All Cassius Clay.

title: Now Hushed the Voice
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. am an enthusiastic singer of national anthems. PossessedI am not going to change that wordpossessed of sturdy baritone which some have found too selfindulgent but, in which the more thoughtful have recognized Cremona timbre, I have borne my gift through the heedless marketplace.

title: AID TO NEEDIEST HONORS TRUMAN
description: The death last month of former President Harry S. Truman moved many individuals to send memorial gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Stock Car Racers Face Smooth Road
description: BEECH MOUNTAIN, N. C., Jan. 16Bill France Jr., who succeeded his father last son as president of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, indulges the superstition of knocking on wood when things are going right  good advance ticket sales, no weather postponements last year, everyone pulling together for 1973, and so on. The occasion for all the woodknocking was a visit with members of the National Motorsports Press Association at their annual meeting here. Last year was pretty good, he said, not through any magic trick of mine, but because I just walked in at a time, knock on wood.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 1.35 million common shares of the Peoples Gas Company at $38.75 per share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation. The company's stock closed at 38 down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Japanese Outpoints Korean
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Jan. 16. (AP)  Zensuke Utagawa of Japan scored a unanimous 12round decision over Kim Hyun of South Korea tonight to win the Orient featherweight championship. There were no knockdowns. Each fighter weighed 126 pounds.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL REQUIRED TO BAR RACIAL INEQUITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Labor Department, charging the Bethlehem Steel. Corporation with failure to overcome the effects of racial discrimination, ordered the company today to make sweeping changes in the seniority system at its plant at Sparrows, Point, Md., to assure blacks better job opportunities.

title: Assessment of Inflation's Impact on Wages and Profit
description: Wall Street has taken a careful look at President Nixon's Phase 3 wageprice system and has gone into a sinking spell, fearful of renewed inflation. But organized labor seems delighted with the looser and more voluntary Phase 3 program, worked out by Secretary of the Treasury George Shultz, and George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial OrIganizations. The A.F.L.C.LO. is still reserving its position on whether it will support renewal of the basic authorizing legislation beyond April 30, but Floyd Smith, president of the Machinists Union, the second largest union in the federation, has already come out strongly against it.

title: CHOU CHUTE WINS $54,800 HANDICAP
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP)Chou Croute romped to a 14length victory in the $64,800 Santa Monica Tandicap at Santa Anita today.

title: EXTENSION URGED ON SCRIBNER PACT
description: A parade of speakers denounced the Board of Education last night for not being accountable to the public and urged the board to extend the contract of Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

title: ARTHUR L. RUBIN, 70, ACADEMIC AIDE, DIES
description: Arthur L. H. Rubin, a consultant in educational and academic fields, died yesterday at his home, 135 East 54th Street.

title: Philadelphia Teachers in Court; Deadlock in Chicago Continues
description: A judge delayed yesterday any contempt of court action against union leaders of striking Philadelphia teachers. The strike of Chicago teachers rounded out its first week with negotiators at odds on several issues.

title: ROBERT WEBB, 61, OF YOUTH SERVICE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 16 Robert M. Webb, director of the division on youth and community services of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, died today of leukemia in Greenwich Hospital, He was 61 years old and lived at 5 Mill Pond, Cos Cob.

title: U.S. Widens Trade Role, Triples Exports to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 16  SovietAmerican trade nearly tripled in the first 11 months of 1972, even before large grain shipments began arriving here. The surge put the United States, for the first time, among the Soviet Union's major Western trading partners.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Business Briefs
description: U.S Fights Fee Rule of Options Board

title: SENATORS SEEKING A FUEL PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Senators from both parties, concerned over the nation's fuel shortage, proposed today that the Government allow price increases for oil, natural gas and coal.

title: 6 BANK CONCERNS INCREASE PROFITS
KELLER STANDOUT IN PACER VICTORY
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 16 (AP) Indiana's Billy Keller scored a careerhigh 38 points and tied an American Basketball Association record of six 3point goals tonight in leading the Pacers to a 130113 victory over the Denver Rockets.

title: AMERICAN POWER INCREASES PROFIT
description: The American Electric Power Company achieved a new high in earnings in 1972, according to preliminary figures released yesterday. Donald C. Cook, chairman, placed earnings at a new high of $156.3million, equal to $2.63 a share. This was 15,8 per cent higher thane, the $135million, or $2.43 a share on fewer shares, in 1971. Revenues rose 15 per cent to $860.6million from $748.2milLinn a year earlier.

title: Man Slain, a 2d Wounded In East Village Shooting
description: One man was shot dead an another was critically wounded last night in a shooting in the East Village. Early this morning, the police said they still were not clear about the circumstances of the incident.

title: Garden to Hear Anthem At Track Meet, After All
description: The national anthem will be played, it now seems, at the Olympic Invitation track and field meet at Madison Square Garden. Bowing to public protest and private pressure, officials of the meet Feb. 16 reversed their decision yesterday. They said they would be delighted to continue the custom of playing the anthem.

title: ACCORD IS EXPANDED ON ALUNITE VENTURE
description: The National Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh confirmed yesterday that, along with the Southwire Company of Georgia, it had expanded a joint venture agreement with Earth Sciences, Inc., of Golden, Colo. The group aims at development of alunite as an alternate to bauxite for the production of alumina, the raw material from which aluminum metal is refined.

title: Jailed I.R.A. Chief Ends Hunger Strike
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 16Sean MacStiofain, chief of staff of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, ended a 58day hunger strike today.

title: 25 Watch Trenton Rape But Fail to Help Victim
description: TRENTON, Jan. 16 (AP)A 20yearold woman who works for the Trenton Police Department was raped yesterday in full view of about 25 employes of a nearby roofing company who watched intently but did not answer her screams for help.

title: Excerpts From Governor's Message resenting Realistic Budget to Legislature
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16Following are excerpts from the budget message Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today:

title: MRS. LOUIS PFOHL
description: Mrs. Pauline Mathis Pfohl, secretary and treasurer of Plaxall, Inc., plastics manufacturers, headed by her husband, Louis H. Pfohl, died yesterday in New York Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 56 Groton Street, Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

title: Christian Jerusalem
description: Scarcely had Premier Golda Meir of Israel and her brigade of security guards departed from an historic encounter with the Pope of Rome than the various spokesmen began their unseemly quibbling over whether her visit had any meaning at all. Their nervousness reflected the remnants of unreality which still hang over relations of church and state in modern Jerusalem, city that is just too holy to too many people for its own good.

title: Julio Castello Dead at 91; Long N.Y.U. Fencing Coach
description: Julio Martinez Castello, former fencing coach for New York University for 20 years and 1924 coach of the United States Olympic Fencing Team, in Paris, died Monday at his home in Tampa, Fla. His age was 91.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: State to Push Housing in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 16 The State Urban Development Corporation plans to proceed with its controversial ninetown housing plan in Westchester County, Edward J. Logue, president of the state agency, said today.

title: Farmers in Dry Middle East Welcome Snowfall
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 16Farmers of the Middle East from the Jordan Valley to the plains of Syria and Turkey and the limestonewalled fields of Cyprus looked today with thanks at their ancestral hills, all covered with snow.

title: W. KEYSER MANLY
description: W. Keyser Manly, a publicrelations man in the financial field, died yesterday of a coronary attack at New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 315 East 72d Street.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Bill Bradley was selected yesterday by the East coaches for the National Basketball Association's AllStar game at Chicago on Jan. 23. It was the first time for the New York Knicks' player.

title: Youth, 16, Accused of Subway Murder Was Released From Narcotics Center
description: The 16yearold youth accused of stabbing a retired policeman to death in a subway station near Times Square on Sunday had been sent home from custody in a state narcotics center because officials there thought he had been so good ... he had made marvelous progress.

title: Doris Fielding Reid Is Dead; Wrote About Edith Hamilton
description: Doris Fielding Reid, a retired vice president of Loomis, Sayles & Co., investment counselors, died yesterday at her home, 955 Lexington Avenue. She was 77 years old.

title: RESTORING OF CUT IN WELFARE ASKED
