description: ALBANY, Jan. 16Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today a bill that would restore a 10 per cent cut in welfare benefits to more than 1.5 million recipients in the state.

title: 25 Watch as Woman Is Raped In Trenton, but Fail to Help Her
description: TRENTON, Jan. 16 (AP)A 0yearold woman who works for the Trenton Police Departnent was raped yesterday in full view of about 25 employes of a nearby roofing company who watched intently but did not answer her screams for help.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: TRISTAR BACK IN USE AFTER ENGINE TESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI)  The 245passenger TriStar jumbo jetliner was back in scheduled service today following two engine malfunctions that had led to a Government order for an immediate engine inspection.

title: PRINCETON DOWNS TEMPLE, 43 TO 37
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 16Joe Vavricka, a reserve forward, scored 15 points and led Princeton to a 4337 victory over Temple in Jadwin gymnasium tonight.

title: Blessed by Witches, an Occult Show Is Unveiled
description: Eleven witches gathered around an altar in a darkened gallery of the Museum of American Folk Art earlier this week to consecrate wine and bless the occult show that opened there yesterday.

title: Leaders of Legislature React To Budget Along Party Lines
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16The reaction of the legislative leaders of both parties today to Governor Rockefeller's proposed $8.88billion budget was not unlike a political fever chart.

title: Quakes Jar California
description: HOLLISTER, Calif., Jan. 16 (UPI)Two mild earthquakes jarred Stone Canyon yesterday, just 12 miles from the San Andreas Fault. There was no damage.

title: CHOU ROUTE WINS $54,800 HANDICAP
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP)Chou Croute romped to a 14length victory in the $64,800 Santa Monica Tandicap at Santa Anita today.

title: Bridge: A Poor Lead for Beginner Made in Suit Contract Game
description: Beginners are usually advised to search for safe leads against suit contracts, but in particular cases this easy generality may be difficult to apply.

title: Records: Aband Revived
description: After the steady flow of precise but bloodless studio recreations that the big bands of the thirties and forties have been subjected to recently, it is both startling and refreshing to find a group of musicians recalling a band that nobody else has thought about, and doing it in such a way that the project becomes more than mere capitalization on nostalgic memories.

title: U.N. Council to Go to Panama in March
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 16  The Security Council decided today to hold a series of meetings in Panama City beginning. March 15 on matters concerning Latin America.

title: Muskie Urges Mass Transit Aid In Light of Proposed Auto Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Senator Edmund S. Muskie viewed the Environmental Protection Agency's gas rationing proposal for Los Angeles today as another good reason to divert highway user taxes for mass transit construction.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former Somerset County Judge Victor A. Rizzolo, a Republican, and Michael Imbriani, a Democrat, won primaries to run for the Assembly seat vacated by Mrs. Millicent Fenwick, who was named director of consumer affairs. The two men will vie in a general election Jan. 30.

title: THIEU EXPECTED TO ACCEPT TRUCE PACT, OFFICIALS SAY, THOUGH PROBLEMS REMAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 17President Nguyen Van Thieu is expected to give his approval to the text of a ceasefire agreement brought to him yesterday by Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., and the Government is now going over the details of how it is to be carried out, according to Vietnamese officials close to the presidential palace.

title: STOCK EXCHANGES ORDERED TO ADMIT INSTITUTION FIRMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered all stock exchanges to accept as members any brokerage firms doing a predominantly public business.

title: People in Sports: Carlton No. 1 in Pay, Too
description: Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies, the best pitcher in baseball last season but a member of the team with the second worst major league record, agreed to terms yesterday for the 1973 campaign.

title: Chilean Copper Mine Struck
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 16 (AP)More than 9,000 workers at Chuquicamata, the world's largest openpit copper mine, began a 48hour strike today to protest the scarcity of food and other goods. The mine in northern Chile, one of five big copper fields formerly run by three American companies, was nationalized by Chile's leftist Government in mid1971.

title: Cyprus Mines to Acquire Bagdad Copper
description: The Cyprus Mines Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Bagdad Copper Corporation through an exchange of stock.

title: Public Utilities Chef Foresees Transport's Losses Down in '73
description: NEWARK, Jan. 16Transport of New Jersey's operating losses, mostly because of route consolidations, service cutbacks and new state subsidies, should fall off sharply this year, the executive director of the Department of Public Utilities said today.

title: Mrs. Jacqueline P. James Wed To Francis Goodwin 2d Here
description: Mrs. Jacqueline Parsons James of New York, widow of Marquis James, twice Pulitzer Prizewinner for biography, was married here yesterday afternoon to Francis Goodwin 2d of Wethersfield, Conn., founder of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra.

title: The Watergate Spies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16You don't have to be very smart to figure out what's going to happen to politics in the United States if the selfconfessed burglars in the Watergate case are allowed to cover up who hired them to do the dirty work.

title: Seven in Atlantic City Go on Trial as Corrupt
description: CAMDEN, Jan. 16A Federal prosecutor charged today that seven past and present officials of Atlantic City ruled the resort as if it were their private kingdon, enforcing a total feudal system of corruption upon that society.

title: Garden to Hear Anthem At Track Meet, After All
description: The national anthem will be played, it now seems, at the Olympic Invitation track and field meet at Madison Square Garden. Bowing to public protest and private pressure, officials of the meet Feb. 16 reversed their decision yesterday. They said they would be delighted to continue the custom of playing the anthem.

title: Humphrey Asserts Congress and Nixon Near Critical Clash
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that even after the Vietnam war ends, the sources of growing tension between Congress and the Nixon Administration will remain.

title: 400 Celebrate State's Booming County Fair Business
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 17  For the last three days, the walls of the staid old Syracuse Hotel here have looked like a Sunday comic strip. More than 2,500 posters have festooned the walls with such multicolored messages as Boom Boom George Zambelli, Hell Drivers  Wildest Show on Wheels and Everybody Loves a Clown.

title: Housing Starts Climbed By 15% to a Record in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Housing starts reached the record level of 2,355,500 in 1972, up 15 per cent from the record achieved in 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The American Broadcasting Company's telecast of this year's Tony Awards ceremonies on March 25 from 9 to 11 P.M. will have as its theme The Wide World of Broadway and will feature filmed scenes from Broadway hits in overseas productions.

title: Kidney Foundation Criticizes Articles on Care Costs
description: Officials of the National Kidney Foundation disputed yesterday a recent article and editorial in The New York Times that cited Federal reports that had projected annual costs of $1billion in the nineteeneighties to treat 5,000 patients who would otherwise die of terminal kidney diseases.

title: F. D. A. PROPOSES SWEEPING CHANGE IN FOOD LABELING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The Food and Drug Administration announced today sweeping changes in focd labeling practices to give consumers a better idea of the nutritional value of about half of what they eat.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Notes on People
description: Henry A. Schutz. Jr. has been named special agent in charge of the criminal division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York office, its largest. Mr. Schutz will replace C. Frederick Fehl, who is being placed in charge of the Cleveland field office. Mr. Schutz, whose appointment was announced in Washington by the F.B.I.'s acting director, L. Patrick Gray 3d, is 48 years old and has been with the bureau 24 years. He was chief of the generalcrimes unit in Washington until last month, when he moved to the inspection division.

title: BIG BOARD ACCEPTS INSTITUTION FIRMS
description: Directors of the New York Stock Exchange approved institutional membership yesterday for the first time under guidelines set forth by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Finns Extend President's Term Without Election
description: FIELSINKI, Finland, Thursday, Jan. 18 (AP)Finland's Parliament passed legislation early today extending for four years without an election President Urho Kekkonen's current sixyear term, which was due to oexpire on March 1, 1974.

title: Eastern Hockey League
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: NOMINEE IS FACING DELAY IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Three Democratic Senators said today that they would try to hold up Senate confirmation of Caspar W. Weinberger as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare until the middle of February.

title: THIEU REPORTED TO BE OBJECTING ON 4 KEY ISSUES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 18President Nguyen Van Thieu has raised several serious objections to aspects of a proposed Vietnam peace agreement, a wellinformed but unofficial South Vietnamese source said yesterday.

title: 3 and 9 Months Climb
Paris Purifying French: Hit Parade Is Palmares
description: PARIS, Jan. 17 (AP)The French Government began to remove English words from the nation's vocabulary today, banning such expressions as hit parade, tanker and zoning from official use.

title: Stage: Circle Presents New Medea
description: The downtown Circle in the Square made a speciality of both O'Neill and Greek tragedy. It was therefore particularly appropriate that when it moved uptown to its new Circle in the SquareJoseph E. Levine Theater it should have opened first with O'Neill's Mourning Becomes Electra and, last night, follow with a new production of Euripides's Medea, starring a Circle in the Square stalwart, Irene Papas.

title: Japan Plans Postwar Aid to Indochina
description: TOKYO, Jan. 17Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira said today that Japan would extend emergency economic aid to Indochina as rapidly as possible after a ceasefire in the Vietnam war.

title: VIRGINIAN IS FREED IN 1962 RAPE CASE
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 17 (AP)Thomas C. Wansley, 25 years old, a black twice convicted of raping a white woman, was freed on $10,000 bail by a Federal judge today after spending 10 years in prison.

title: Payments by a Contractor Related at Knowlton Trial
description: NEWARK, Jan. 17The Government today described an elaborate system of alleged payments by a contractor to former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton and a second man, including a $25,000 cash payment made in a gasoline station and a secret checking account set up to receive $5,000 a month.

title: Csonka Out of Pro Bowl
description: DALLAS, Jan. 17 (AP)Three members of the Super Bowl champion Miami Dolphins called in sick today and missed Pro Bowl workouts while a fourth was excused from playing in the game. Larry Csonka, complaining of a bad back, was. replaced by a teammate, MerCary Morris, on the American Conference team. Morris, Nick Buoniconti and Bill Stanfill had the flu. The game is Sunday.

title: THIEU REPORTED TO BE OBJECTING ON 4 KEY ISSUES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 18President Nguyen Van Thieu has raised several serious objections to aspects of a proposed Vietnam peace agreement, a wellinformed but unofficial South Vietnamese source said yesterday.

title: CANADIENS DOWN PENGUINS BY 64
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 17 (UPI)Rejean Houle posted the first threegoal effort of his National Hockey League career tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 64 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Future Looks Bleak for the South Bronx
description: Few devastated areas of the city show such outward, visible signs of progress as does the South Bronx. But many who live and work there believe that these physical improvements are too few and too late to halt a spreading malignancy that has resulted from decades of neglect and that has already blighted the lives of 400,000 New Yorkers.

title: Washington BuilderDeveloper Acquired by Donaldson, Lufkin
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., announced yesterday its entrance into the real estate development field through the acquisition of George G. Mulligan & Assodates, Inc., a builderdeveloper of multifamily condominiums in suburban Washington. Anthony H. Harwood, president of DLJ Real Estate, a subsidiary of the brokerage firm, and George G. Mulligan, founder and president of the Washington company, made the joint announcement yesterday. This was believed to mark the first entry of any member firm into the real estate development field.

title: MUSKIE WILL SEEK TO TAP ROAD FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Senator Edmund S. Muskie announced today that he would introduce three bills to tap the Highway Trust Fund to finance urban mass transit projects, assist in controlling air pollution and conserve dwindling petroleum resources.

title: Personal Finance: Buying Protein Cheaply
description: The average housewife has been watching meat and egg prices rise sharply in the last few weeks with worried resignation.

title: McCormack, Redskin Aide, Named Eagles' Head Coach
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) Mike McCormack, a protege of Paul. Brown, Vince Lombardi and George Allen, became head coach of the National Football League's Philadelphia Eagles today. The 42yearold McCormack, who had been on the Washington Redskin staff, signed a threeyear contract.

title: Antitobacco Bills Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, announced today a legislative package to raise taxes on high tar cigarettes and end the $60 to $70million in annual subsidies for the tobacco industry.

title: RALLY BY RANGERS TIES KINGS, 4 TO 4
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17Goals by Jim Neilson and Rod Selling within the last five minutes gave the New York Rangers a 44 tie with the Los Angeles Kings tonight, and averted what would have been New York's first loss to the Kings in three years.

title: Inmont Elects Executives
description: The elections of an executive vice president, a senior vice president and a new member of the board of directors of the Inmont Corporation were announced yesterday. William R. Perdue, Jr., was named executive vice president, Lindsay C. Herkness, Jr., senior vice president, and Sir Joseph Hunt, a director.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT BLAZERS, 1179??
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)Dave Cowens scored 35 point and hauled down 20 rebound tonight as the Boston Celtic extended their winning strea to seven games with a 1179 National Basketball Associatio victory over the Portland Tra Blazers.

title: U.S. Sees Ellsberg Issue As Simple Case of Theft
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17Opening statements in the Pentagon papers trial were delivered today, with the Government charging a simple case of theft of classified documents.

title: Women Smokers Warned Of Fetal and Infant Risks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 There is strong evidence that pregnant women who smoke cigarettes are thereby increasing the risk of death of their babies, a Public Health Service report said today.

title: BLACK WINS PLEA ON BIAS OF JURORS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Black defendants in state criminal trials are entitled to have prospective jurors screened on the basis of possible racial prejudice, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Saigon Aide Bars Accord With Vietcong as an Equal
description: PARIS, Jan. 17In a radio interview broadcast today, Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam of South Vietnam said that his Government would refuse to sign an agreement that mentioned the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government.

title: Music. Harth Is Soloist
description: Twenty years ago, Sidney Harth made his first appearance here as an orchestra soloist with the National Orchestral Association in Carnegie Hall. He was already on the way to a career, having won the Naumburg Award, but the engagement no doubt gave it, an extra push.

title: Hearings on Fund Cuts Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Senator Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia accused President Nixon today of usurping Congressional power over Government spending. The Democratic chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee announced plans for public hearings on recent Administration cuts in farm and rural programs.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: 747 Blows Tires
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 17 (UPI)A Northwest Orient Airlines 747 was delayed many hours yestcrday at the Honolulu International Airport after two of its tires blew out. The huge jet, carrying 300 persons, was taking off when the control tower noticed smoke pouring out of its wheels and brake area.

title: U.S. Planes Step Up Attacks in the South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 18 (AP)The United States command announced yesterday that American war planes had attacked enemy positions throughout South Vietnam in the highest number of strikes in more than a month.

title: Sane or Insane? A Case Study of the T. W. A. Hijacker
description: Garrett Brock Trapnell, whose fiveweek trial for skyjacking ended in a hungjury Monday, was born 34 years ago into a patrician world populated by famous war heroes. His father was a graduate of the Naval. Academy at Annapolis, and his mother attended Radcliffe.

title: Slaying of a Black By Policeman Stirs Rich Jersey Town
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Jan. 17The killing by a policeman of a popular 21yearold black youth who grew up in this affluent white community has left a feeling of anger, fear and frustration among many of the area's residents, particularly the young.

title: ROGERS VOICES HOPE ON MIDEAST FOR '73
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers said last night that number of developments had combined to make 1973 a favorable time for negotiations between Israel and the Arab countries.

title: 2 JUDGES INDICTED AS CASE QUASHERS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17The statewide grand jury today indicted two Municipal Court judges from Atlantic County on charges of conspiring to quash a criminalassault charge against a man who subsequently was sent to prison for trafficking in narcotics.

title: Indiana Man Indicted Here In Slaying of Schoolteacher
description: John Wayne Wilson of Shelbyville, Ind., was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday for the Jan. 2 murder of Roseann Quinn, but his arraignment was postponed for a week to allow a psychiatrist to examine him.

title: Haile Selassie Welcomes Pompidou to Addis Ababa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 17 (UPI)President Pompidou of France flew here today from Djibouti, territory of Afars and Issas, and was cheered by some 20,000 persons on his ceremonial entry into the Ethiopian capital.

title: W ome n Smokers Warned Of Fetal and Infant Risks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 There is strong evidence that pregnant women who smoke cigarettes are thereby increasing the risk of death of their babies, a Public Health Service report said today.

title: Economic Hearings Slated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, announced today that hearings to extend the Economic Stabilization Act be yond the April 30 expiration date will be held Jan. 29 through Feb. 7.

title: Theater: 3 Visionary Plays by Yeats
description: With his Theater at St. Clement's, Kevin O'Connor is reviving the grand tradition of the actormanager. Since he took over last May as artistic director, he has turned St. Clement's (formerly the home of the American Place Theater) once again into a vigorous, active theater.

title: And Now, Phase III
description: WASHINGTONThe rate of inflation in the United States has declined substantially in the last two years. American progress in the struggle against inflation has been the envy and marvel of the rest of the world. But still inflation remains a problem here and the struggle is not over.

title: Dance
description: When Les Ballets Africains first appeared at Harlem's Apollo Theater in 1970, their reception was so triumphant that both they and local residents spoke fondly of their coming home to Harlem. Yesterday the Guinean dance troupe came home again to the Apollo, and if the. cheers of a children's matinee audience prove an accurate forecast of adults' response, their two weeks here should be another love feast.

title: STOCKTON DEFEATS PASARELL, 64, 63
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17 (UPI)Fourthseeded Cliff Richey had no trouble' in downing Bob Maud of South Africa, 63, 60, but Bob Lutz, seeded eighth, struggled to a 36, 64, 63 victory over Colin Dibley of Australia in the first round of the $25,000 Saga Bay tennis tournament today. The event opened the World Championship Tennis pro tour.

title: FASHION TALK
description: All the big events in fashion don't have to involve rarefied clothes at stratospheric prices. Pembroke Squires in his first collection for Main Street has shown that it's possible to chart new fashion directions in as prosaic an area as raincoats.

title: A Rare Spaniel Breed Finds Winner's Circle
description: History was made at the American Spaniel Club's national show on Jan. 7 at the Statler Hilton Hotel when Sedora Quettadene Damon became the first Sussex spaniel in the East to become a champion in more than four decades, Damon, who will be 5 years old on May 13, is owned by Milt and Eunice Gies of Voorheesville, N. Y., near Albany. He was best of breed at the specialty for the third year in a row.

title: SALLIE S. RUST
description: Sallie Sterling Rust, who retired in 1964 from the Ethical Culture Schools after 40 years of service, first as a Latin teacher and later as registrar, died Monday at Brandon, Vt. Her age was 74.

title: Slaying of a Black By Policeman Stirs Rich Jersey Town
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. 3., Jan. 17The killing by a policeman of a popular 21yearold black youth who grew up in this affluent white community has left a feeling of anger, fear and frustration among many of the area's residents, particularly the young.

title: Future Looks Bleak for the South Bronx
description: Few devastated areas of the city show such outward, visible signs of progress as does the South Bronx. But many who live and work there believe that these physical improvements are too few and too late to halt a spreading malignancy that has resulted from decades of neglect and that has already blighted the lives of 400,000 New Yorkers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Jan. 18, 1973 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Screen: 'Death of a Jew':Farce on Israeli-Arab Espionage Opens The Cast
description: With a title like "Death of a Jew," you almost don't need a movie. And in Denys de la Patalliere's "Death of a Jew," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, you almost don't have one. What you do have is an incredible story, told in moving pictures, about a tender relationship between an old Arab police inspector (the late Akim Tamiroff) and a young Israeli spy (Assaf Dayan). The newspaper ads quote one critic as saying that the story "can be appreciated by Arabs as well as Israelis." And I am afraid that an ecumenism at just that level of naivet, is what "Death of a Jew" is all about.Shimon, the Israeli spy, is captured deep inside some unidentified Arab country, and, to make him reveal his contacts he is turned over to the police. When all else fails, even the evil technology of the police chief (Jean Claudio: "It's not a question of courage; it's a question of voltage." Sneer.), the old inspector, Mehdaloun, gets his licks.Mehdaloun hopes to replace Shimon's silence with a gregarious will to live, and thus to talk (so as to stay alive); and to this end he sets about corrupting him with kindness. He plies Shimon with gifts; rooms him in his own apartment; takes him eating, drinking, whoring; and grows so fond of his enemy that he begins calling him "my son."It is all to no avail. Shimon remains tight as a clam. But, irony of ironies, Mehdaloun falls prey to his own scheme! And he is left at the last, entering his dotage, with a new gregarious will to livenot to mention extravagant tastes for room service, vodka straight and compliant Scandinavian blondes.All this is not quite as stupid as it may seem in the abstract. Anyplace but the Middle East (and perhaps North and South Vietnam) it might have furnished a movie plot. A friend, intelligent and much too kind, has suggested analogies all the way from Claude Berri's "The Two of Us" to Bergman's "Persona." Personally, I am put more in mind of certain Shirley Temple movies; but any plot idea that has floated so far must have some buoyancy to sustain it.Assaf Dayan and Akim Tamiroff have been highly engaging actors, but they are both pretty dreadful here. The film is in English, which Tamiroff speaks with a Yiddish accent (somewhat unsettling, under the circumstances), and which all the others speak as if they had learned it at school in France. Denys de la Patalliere, ("Taxi for Tobruk," "Marco the Magnificent") directs as if he hadn't learned anything at all. "Death of a Jew" is the kind of film that seems to advance from scene to scene not by any inner necessity, but rather because everybody at a particular time in a particular place finds himself at a loss for what to do next.

title: Truck Operators Warned Of Risk in 2Part Wheels
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration today cautioned operators of the more than two million trucks equipped with special socalled RH5degree wheels on dangers associated with reassembly after tire changes or other service.

title: MARCOS TIGHTENS GRIP IN MANILA BY NEW CHARTER
description: MANILA, Jan. 17President Ferdinand E. Marcos consolidated his virtually unlimited power today, raising the pros pect of years of authoritarian rule for the Philippines.

title: Casey of S.E.C., Nixon Nominee, Is Among 17 Defendants in Suit
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 (AP)William J. Casey, President Nixon's nominee to be Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, was accused in a Federal suit today of gross mismanagement and flagrant violation of his obligations to a corporation now involved in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Cahill Opposes Life For Drug Pushers
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17Governor Cahill said today that he opposed mandatory life sentences for convicted drug pushers, contending that anyone seeking stiffer prison terms for such offenders must realize that the addicted pusher would do anything, regardless of the penalties, to support his habit.

title: Council Bill Forbids Making Handguns; Passage Expected
description: A bill designed to outlaw the manufacture and assembly here of cheap handguns, commonly known as Saturday night specials, was voted out yesterday by the City Council's Public Safety Committee.

title: Virginia Papers to Be Sold
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 17 (AP)Worrell Newspapers announced today that it had agreed to purchase two of Virginia's largest nondaily newspapers, The Manassas Journal Messenger and The Potomac News at Dumfries. T. E. Worrell Jr., vice president of Worrell Newspapers, said R. Guy Hankins, a native of Richlands, would head the corporation purchasing the northern Virginia newpapers.

title: Teachers to Defy Philadelphia Judge On Ending Walkout
description: A judge ordered 13,000 striking Philadelphia school teachers yesterday to obey his injunction and report back to their classrooms by this morning.

title: 90Day Halt in L.I.R.R. Strike Arranged by Brennan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17A 90day coolingoff period in the Long Island Rail Road strike was announced today by Peter J. Brennan, President Nixon's nominee as the new Secretary of Labor.

title: SOVIET HOPES HIGH ON LUNOKHOD DATA
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17Soviet scientists expressed confidence today that findings of their new moon rover, the Lunokhod 2, would supplement information gathered last month during the manned mission of Apollo 17 in an area only about 140 miles away.

title: TWO MORE INDICTED IN SLAYING OF GALLO
description: Two alleged Mafia figures were indicted yesterday by a New York County grand jury investigating the murder last year of Joseph Gallo in a Little Italy restaurant.

title: Physicist Accuses Soviet in Passport Case but Suggests Collusion
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17Andrei D. Sakharov, the noted physicist and civilrights campaigner charged Soviet authorities today with violating generally accepted lei principles by lifting the citizenship of his former colleagues, Valery N. Chalidze, during a lecture tour in the United States last month.

title: DOROTHY BALDWIN
description: Dorothy S. Baldwin, a psychiatric social worker who retired last November as a consultant to the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, died following emergency surgery on Monday in Suva, Fiji Islands, during a tour of the South Pacific. She was 67 years old.

title: Oil Import Limit Relaxed To Help Ease Fuel Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17In an emergency action intended to relieve the shortage of fuel oil in some parts of the United States, President Nixon today authorized increased imports of crude oil and heating oil.

title: Australia Shifts on Cutting Papua Ties
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17 Australia pulled back today from an earlier commitment to bestow independence upon a reluctant Papua New Guinea next year, but reaffirmed that Canberra would still work toward that goal.

title: Photos of Mars Show Channels, Hinting Water Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Mariner 9 scientists released today photographs of a dry, meandering channel on Mars that they said was the clincher to their theory that water must have played a role in shaping the planet's surface.

title: ARGENTINE CHARGES FILED AGAINST PERON
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 (UPI)  The military Government began criminal proceedings against former President Juan D. Perlin today, charging that recent statements he made in Madrid were instigations to violence.

title: Chess: The Pawn Again Proves  Mightier on the Board
description: The mobility of pawns is slight in comparison with that of the other pieces. Slowpaced, unable to retreat, the pawn bogs down as soon as an enemy pawn blocks its path. In close openings such, as the French Defense or the King's Indian Defense, interlocking chains of pawns may create a pattern or frozen immobility across major areas of the chessboard.

title: People and Business
description: The name of the former Attorney General, John N. Mitchell, is finally back in the title of the old NixonMitchell Wall Street law firm. And Mr. Mitchell himself, who sojourned at the Washington office of the firmMudge Rose Guthrie & Alexanderwhen he left the Justice Department last spring, is back at its Manhattan headquarters at 20 Broad Street.

title: Herbert W. Kurzman, 66, Former BVD Executive
description: Herbert W. Kurzman, a consultant to the BVD Company, Inc., a licensing and manufacturing, organization in the apparel field, died in his office at 350 Fifth Avenue yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 201 East 77th Street.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Reaction must be ambivalent as regards the American League decision to permit pitchers to have more or less permanent pinchhitters carrying their bats for them. It is a move so radical that it has rocked most traditionalists, since it represents a deep and fundamental change in a sport that has been resistant to change over the years. There once was a presumption that baseball was structured with such ideal checks and balances that tampering with the code was unnecessary. Obviously, the diamond fathers no longer are sure. The National League refused to agree to the proposal and will stick to the existing rule on pinchhitters. But that figures. The only thing I really liked about the bold action of the Americans going it alone was that it was a declaration of independence from the tyranny and oppression of the Nationals.

title: SECRET TALKS LAID TO 3 CAR MAKERS
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17 (Reuters) The Justice Department has charged that top executives of the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation held a series of secret meetings at which confidential cost information was exchanged.

title: Dothan Home First In Royal Poinciana As Hialeah Opens
Records: 3 by Brendel
description: Alfred Brendel, the Viennese pianist, has had the kind of career that would be possible only in this age of recordings. His recital and concert appearances have been relatively rare, at least in this country, but he is still an artist who commands a wide, and in some quarters even cultlike, following. The reason is records: Since the fifties Mr. Brendel has turned out an astonishing number of albums, almost invariably of high quality and quite often decidedly more than that.

title: India, Struck by Drought, Is Buying Grain From U.S.
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 17 (AP)The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India had been hit by the worst drought in a decade and was importing at least two million tons of food grains, mostly from the United States.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST DOES DOUBLE DUTY
description: Charity and ecology joined forces the other day for the benefit of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Police in Capital Prepare for Protests
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17With protests against the Administration's policy in Vietnam planned throughout the weekend  ranging from vigils and religious services to marches and rallies  local and Federal authorities are joining forces to insure that the inauguration and its surrounding ruffles and flourishes are not disrupted.

title: 3 Pediatricians Honored
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)The Charles H. Hood Foundation said today that three pediatricians would share its $255,000 Child Health Award for 1972. They are Drs. Henry Kempe of the University of ColoradoDenver, Saul KrugIrian of New York University and. Josef Warkany of the University of Cincinnati.

title: Bronx Holdup Man Is Killed In a Gunfight With Grocer
description: An 18yearold holdup man was shot to death last night in an exchange of gunfire with the 38yearold operator of a grocery store in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, the police reported.

title: Judge in Pentagon Papers Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 Fittingly, William Matthew Byrne Jr. is a Hollywood version of a judgeyoung for a man in his position, ambitious, attractive and a bachelor.

title: Hotel With a Crime Record Is Ordered to Clean It Up
description: The owners of the Hudson Hotel at 16411659 Amsterdam Avenue, near 141st Street, were ordered by State Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam yesterday to eliminate the conditions and evict the tenants that have made the sevenstory structure a notorious haven for crime and criminal activity.

title: Heath Asks Wide Controls In Phase 2 Inflation Fight
description: LONDON, Jan. 17Prime Minister Heath today announced Britain's most comprehensive program of antiinflation measures since World War II, including curbs on prices, wages, rents and dividends.

title: Bus and Car Collide on S.I.
description: A Transit Authority bus and a private automobile collided late yesterday afternoon at the intersection of Manor Road and South Gannon Avenue in the Castleton Corners section of Staten Island. Nine bus passengers were taken to Staten Island Hospital and St. Vincent's Hospital, but no serious injuries were reported.

title: Recently Published Books
description: Recently Published Books

title: Doctor, Walk Thyself
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17For a long time I used to walk five miles daily to work. Such was the power of doctors. Every day in the newspapers doctors said that walking was a smart thing to do. They still say it, although it is very rare to see a doctor walking.

title: Cable TV Blanked Out By Theft of Amplifiers
description: Thieves made off late Wednesday with three amplifiers that feed the main cable lines of Sterling Manhattan Cable Television, Inc., leaving 50,000 cableTV subscribers with blank screens.

title: Rethinking Welfare Reform
description: WASHINGTONCurrent conditions and the political setting now indicate that the Nixon Administration's welfarereform plan should not be reintroduced in the first year of the 93d Congress.

title: PROCESSORS BACK FOOD LABEL RULES
description: Food processors and parka gers yesterday generally supported the new nutritional labeling rules released in Washington by the Food and Drug Administration and particularly applauded the agency for making the guidelines voluntary.

title: R. B. WALKER, LED AMERICAN BRANDS
description: Robert Barney Walker, chairman and chief executive officer of American Brands, Inc., died yesterday, apparently of a heart Ittack, at a hotel in Manhattan. He was 59 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: S.E.C. Sues General Host And 9 Over Armour Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today against the General Host Corporation charging fraud and other illegal acts in its 1969 attempt to acquire control or Armour & Co., the big Chicago meat packer. Nine other companies and individuals were also named in the suit.

title: Market Place:Japanese Drawn ToDreyfusFund
description: Everybody has been talking about Japan as a major new source of investment demand for American securities, but nobody has done anything about it yetexcept the Dreyfus Corporation.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH F.A. CUP

title: Edel to Edit Edmund Wilson Diaries
description: Prof. Leon Edel, the literary scholar and biographer, has been appointed editor of the diaries and journals of the late Edmund Wilson, the critic.

title: To Beat Inflation, Do as the Romans Do: Eat Pasta
description: Smoked Nova Scotia salmon can currently cost the Phase 3 epicure as much as $7 a pound. It is clearly time to look for cheaper ways to feed ourselves. And, as an artful hedge against zooming food prices, pasta is hard to beat.

title: WATERGATE TRIAL IN CLOSED SESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The Watergate trial went into secret session today when a key Government witness was asked to name people he said he had overheard talking on a wiretapped telephone in the offices of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Shift in Air Puts June In January
description: Crocuses may not have been budding in Central Park yesterday, but to many New Yorkers there was spring in the air. The thermometer rose to 60 degrees, equaling a 60year record for the date.

title: IVAN PETROVSKY, LED MOSCOW UNIVERSITY
description: MOSCOW, Jan, 17Prof. Ivan G. Petrovsky, mathematician and Rector of Moscow University, died here Monday. He would have been 73 years old tomorrow.

title: SMALL CONCERNS TO GET TRADE AID
description: Twentyfive major American companies and banks with extensive experience overseas have banded together to help small and mediumsized companies get started in the export business.

title: College Association Elects
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 (AP)Robert E. L. Strider, president of Colby College in Waterville, Ma., is the new chairman of the Asosciation of American Colleges. Mr. Strider was elected yesterday at the organization's 59th annual meeting here. He succeeds the Rev. Paul C. Reinert, president of St. Louis University. Mr. Reinert was elected president of the National Council of Independent Colleges and Universities, an affiliate of the association.

title: Maryland Governor Plans Measure to Aid Reporters
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 17Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland announced today plans to strengthen the state law protecting the confidentiality of reporters' sources.

title: Nashua Women's Rink Wins
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 17 The Nashua (N. H.) Curling Club led the way into the semifinals of the Empire State women's bonspiel today by defeating the Chicago C.C., 105, at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: Urban Cancer
description: Many people will regard The Times series on the South Bronx by Martin Tolchin as a horror story to be quickly put out of their mindsif they don't happen to live the South Bronx or anywhere near it. But this social cancer is spreading; unless checked, it can destroy not just the rest of the. Bronx but the city itself.

title: Manila Trend to OneMan Rule Said to Worry U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Some high Administration officials are reported deeply concerned over the increasing movement toward oneman rule in the Philippines by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Amex Closes Mixed in Slow Trading
description: Stock prices faltered on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and closed mixed in slow trading. They had been slightly higher during most of the session.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam has raised several serious objections to aspects of a proposed peace settlement, an informed source said yesterday. But Mr. Thieu has reportedly accepted the broad outlines of the draft agreement. His objections apparently center on four issues, including the limitations on movements of military units in South Vietnam and North Vietnam's refusal to recognize that part of the demilitarized zone belongs to South Vietnam. [Page 1, Columns 78.]

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Tarpon Is an Elusive Fish
description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West Indies  Leaping high out of the dark waters of a jungle pool, a tarpon shook its head violently in an effort to break free, but my fly remained embedded in its jaw and 10 minutes later the fish was beached.

title: MONIKA KASERER WINS CUP MOM
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 17 (Reuters)  Monika Kaserer of Austria followed up, yesterday's downhill victory by her teammate, Annemarie Proell, by winning the slalom race in the World Cup ski meet here today.

title: Bridge:
description: A new face among the Aces when they defend their Bermuda Bowl world team title in Brazil in May will be Mark Blumenthal of Philadelphia. The 30yearold expert will be the youngest member of the famous American champions, replacing Paul Soloway of Los Angeles, who was an Ace for rather less than a year.

title: CITY MAY OFFER BUILDERS BONUS
description: The City Planning Commission has scheduled a hearing for Jan. 31 on a plan under which builders could make a cash contribution to a fund for the improvement of park areas in order to gain the right to construct larger buildings.

title: Planning Board 5 Votes Against Proposed Bridge Over 51st St.
description: In a reversal of position, Community Planning Board 5 voted yesterday to reject a proposal to build a pedestrian bridge over 51st Street between two buildings on Park Avenue.

title: 90Day Halt in L.I.R.R. Strike Arranged by Brennan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17A 90day coolingoff period in the Long Island Rail Road strike was announced today by Peter J. Brennan, President Nixon's nominee as the new Secretary of Labor.

title: TV: Cole Porter in Paris and a Visitor in London
description: Television's absurdity can almost be charmingsometimes. Last night's example was Cole Porter in Paris, a Bell System Family Theater hour shown on the National Broadcasting Company network.

title: Frank Shorter Gets Sullivan Award
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 17 (UPI)Frank Shorter, the Olympic marathon champion, was presented the Amateur Athletic Union's Sullivan Award today as the 1972 amateur athlete of the year.

title: Unenthusiastic Advance Is Posted by Big Board
description: The stock market, which has been in a slump almost from the moment President Nixon's Phase 3 wageprice system was announced, staged an unenthusiastic recovery yesterday. Prices rose moderately while trading activity slowed to 17,680,000 shares from Tuesday's 19,170,000.

title: Libya Is Seeking 50% of Oil Concession
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 Libya is pressing her largest Western oil concessionaire to hand over 50 per cent ownership immediately under a formula that challenges the participation agreements reached by foreign producers in the Persian Gulf.

title: AD M.H.D. RILEY, 68 OF PACIFIC FORCES
description: KENT ISLAND, Md., Jan. 17 (AP)Vice Adm. Herbert D. Riley, U.S.N., retired, commander in chief of naval forces in the Pacific in the late 1950's, died at his home here today. He was 68 years old.

title: BOND PRICES SHOW A STEADIER TONE
description: The bond market, declining almost without interruption since early January, steadied yesterday, but interest rates in the money market kept on rising. In a major test of the taxexempt sector. New York State auctioned $129.5million of its doubleA bonds to a group that priced them to yield investors about the same, or perhaps a little less, than the bonds would have returned last week, specialists declared. Nonetheless, with the aid of bigger than usual payments for selling the bonds, the issue met a strong response from investors. Only $18.2million remained unsold late in the day, with perhaps an additional $35million estimated as still in Wall Street hands.

title: Honeywell Offers Multics
description: Honeywell, Inc., and the Univac division of the Sperry Rand Corporation, the major competitors for second place in the computer industry, announced major new systems yesterday.

title: Advertising: Erotica for Women
description: Bob Guccione, the successful explorer of the outer limits of contemporary community standards, is now planning for women the kind of sexuallyoriented magazine that he gave men in Penthouse.

title: Veil Over Watergate
description: Chief Federal Judge John J. Sirica spoke for a host of incredulous observers at the Watergate trial when he told defendant Bernard Barker that he simply did not believe his story that $114,000 had arrived in unmarked envelopes from sources unknown. Since then the defense has moved from the incredible to the outrageous. It has presented the court with the extraordinary doctrine that anyone who, correctly or incorrectly, imagines himself or his friends to be in some sort of danger Is thereby justified in breaking the law.

title: Truce on the L.I.R.R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road, busiest commuter line the country, has been rescued from the rust box by the intercession of Peter J. Brennan, the incoming Secretary of Labor. Borrowing a leaf from his predecessor in the Kennedy Administration, Arthur J. Goldberg, unionist Brennan has persuaded his old cronies in the striking nonoperating unions on the Long Island to go back to work at midnight tonight.

title: Man Wounds 2 at Newark V.A. Unit
description: NEWARK, Jan. 17  At just about noon today a man identified as Willie Leonard signed the register at the Veterans Administration offices here, walked past the two guards at the door and up to the reception desk at which Bill Golding was sitting.

title: CORONA CASE JURY ADJOURNS FOR NIGHT
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 17A jury of 10 men and two women adjourned at 5 P.M. today after 44 hours of deliberation in the case of Juan V. Corona, the 38yearold Mexican national accused of murdering 25 migrant farm workers in 1971. It will resume at 9 A.M. tomorrow.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development moved yesterday to force the Jersey City Housing Authority to streamline its management and halt project deterioration. The department's area director, James P. Sweeney, said he would soon assign a fulltime department staff member to oversee the operations of the Housing Authority.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 17 (AP)Ben Jipcho of Kenya, coowner of the world record in the 3,000meter steeplechase, beat Merus Yifter of Ethiopia in the 5,000meter race at the AllAfrica Games today, Jipcho was clocked 14 minutes 7.2 seconds. It was a games record but short of the world mark of 13:13 owned by Emile Puttemans of Belgium. Yifter was second in 14:07.52 and Kenya's Paul Mose third in 14: 08.38.

title: SE. John's Routs Clemson, 8759
description: A strong second half carried St. John's to an 8759 basketbal victory over Clemson last night before 3,159 at Alumni Hall on the Redmen's Jamaica campus.

title: MONIKA KASERER WINS CUP SLALOM
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 17 (Reuters)  Monika Kaserer of Austria followed up yesterday's downhill victory by her teammate, Annemarie Proell, by winning the slalom race in the World Cup ski meet here today.

title: PACIFIC GAS RAISED EARNINGS FOR 1972
description: Revenues of the Pacific Gas SC Electric Company in 1972 reached $1.35billion, compared with $1.26billion in the preceding year, Sherman L. Sibley, chairman of the board, reported yesterday. The rise was attributed to increased electric sales and higher gas and electric rates.

title: Banker, His Wife and Daughter Slain After Missouri Extortion
description: GRANDIN, Mo., Jan. 17 (UPI) A bank president, his wife and 16yearold daughter were found trussed to trees and shot to deaththe bank official with dynamite strapped to his chest yesterday near a farmhouse in the Ozarks.

title: Olga Korbut Woman Athlete of the Year
description: Olga Korbut of the Soviet Union, who won three gold medals, a silver medal and the hearts of the world at the Munich Olympics, was named female athlete of the year yesterday by The Associated Press.

title: Books of The Times
description: A BIRD IN THE HAND. By Donald Wetzel. 149 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $5.50.

title: Cahill Warns Landlords To Adhere to Guidelines
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17  Governor Cahill said today that he would ask President Nixon to restore mandatory price controls if he found that landlords rush to violate the principles of the Federal antiinflation program.

title: Ralph T. Walker Is Dead at 83; Hailed as Architect of Century
description: Ralph T. Walker, who was hailed in 1957 by the American Institute of Architects as the architect of the century, died yesterday at his home on Roaring Brook Road in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: successful when they stripped to the buff); teal, two species of coot, fulvou tree ducks, mocking birds, flickers, cockoos, smoothbilled Ani; the chingching, or Greater Antillean grackle; nighthawks, frigate birds, great blue rerons, tricolored herons, snowy and cattle egrets, ground doves, whitecrowned pigeons, and, flying in and out of Bodden's store in George Town, the little yellow and black Banana Quit.

title: Music
description: Add one more new jazz club to the growing New York jazz scene. This one is in the East Villagethe Jazzboat, on Avenue A between Sixth and Seventh Streets, a softly lit room with touches of nautical dcor, including waitresses who wear round, white sailors' hats.

title: Oil Import Limit Relaxed To Help Ease Fuel Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17In an emergency action intended to relieve the shortage of fuel oil in some parts of the United States, President Nixon today authorized increased imports of crude oil and heating oil.

title: StarSpangled Refuge
description: Patriotism, said Samuel Johnson a couple of centuries ago, is the last refuge of a scoundrel. Today, it is usually the first refuge of politicians like New York City Councilman Matthew J. Troy, who is among the sponsors of a bill to require the playing of the national anthem at sporting events, despite his own doubts about the bill's constitutionality.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In default of a decision by the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of our participation in the Vietnam war, a number of lawyers have engaged in learned debate over whether the (nowrepealed) Tonkin Gulf Resolution and the various military appropriations statutes have been the functional equivalent of a declaration of war authorizing Presidents Johnson and Nixon to carry on America's longest and saddest military campaign.

title: IVAN PETROVSKY, LED MOSCOW UNIVERSITY
description: MOSCOW, Jan, 17Prof. Ivan G. Petrovsky, mathematician and Rector of Moscow University, died here Monday. He would have been 73 years old tomorrow.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Film

title: WATERGATE TRIAL IN CLOSED SESSION
description: WASHNGTON, Jan. 17 The Watergate trial went into secret session today when a key Government witness was asked to name people he said he had overheard talking on A wiretapped telephone in the offices of the Democratic National Committee.

title: More Youngsters Seek SkiJumping Challenge
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 17Seventytwo pound Mark Levasseur questioned ins father last Sunday before climbing the steps alongside the 50meter ski jump here.

title: Heath Asks Wide Controls In Phase 2 Inflation Fight
description: LONDON, Jan. 17Prime Minister Heath today announced Britain's most comprehensive program of antiinflation measures since World War II, including curbs on prices, wages, rents and dividends.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Staten Island Democrats meet today to choose a new leader because of a judicial policy that bars a county leader from being a court clerk. Dante L. Ferrari, chief clerk the Richmond County Surrogate's Court, has resigned the county's Democratic leader because of the policy.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS GET 50,000 ACRES
description: One of the largest remaining tracts of natural wilderness in private hands on the Eastern Seaboardan area comprising onefifth of the Dismal Swamp that lies in Virginia and North Carolinahas been donated to the Nature Conservancy by a forestproducts concern.

title: A.J.C. Urging Repudiation Of Chafee Memo to Chaplaint
description: The American Jewish Congress has called on Navy Secretary John H. Chafee to repudiate an official memorandum urging chaplains to play a strong role in the yearlong evangelical campaign known as Key 73.

title: Connecticut Treasurer Proposes Forming an Investment Unit to Help Towns Redeem HighInterest Bonds
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Jan. 17Connecticut's Treasurer, Robert I. Berdon, proposed today that the state's debtridden municipalities double their indebtedness in a complicated maneuver to provide new income to help pay for bonds they issued in the years when interest rates were very high.

title: 2 Sides in Laos Seem to Expect Truce Imposed by Their Backers
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 17There were growing indications today that the Laotian Government and the Communistled Pathet Lao have resigned themselves to the eventuality of a ceasefire negotiated without them by their respective backers, which could come soon after a settlement is reached for Vietnam.

title: Ballet Theater Performs The Maids
description: Herbert Ross's The Maids, based on the play by Jean Genet, is an unusual ballet and it has had an unusual history. Mr. Ross, now more widely known as a Broadway and Hollywood director, created the work in 1957 in a special workshop organized by Ballet Theater. Yet it was obviously considered too daring then for the company to present it.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three similar murders in three weeks in Greenwich Village involving men who might have been part of the leather bar scene have sent waves of rumors and fear through the area's homosexual community.

title: Basque Guerrillas Kidnap Spanish Industrialist
description: PAMPLONA, Spain, Jan. 17 (AP)AntiGovernment Basque guerrillas carried out another spectacular kidnapping last night and today, seizing one of Spain's leading industrialists and presumably hiding him in France.

title: 2 City Prosecutors See Evidence of Chinese Heroin Connection, but U. S. Aide Calls Their Find Absurd
description: Two city prosecutors reported yesterday that they had broken into a Chinatownbased herointrafficking ring that they said apparently obtained heroin from China.

title: Council Bill Forbids Making Handguns; Passage Expected
description: A bill designed to outlaw the manufacture and assembly here of cheap handguns, commonly known as Saturday night specials, was voted out yesterday by the City Council's Public Safety Committee.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ARROZ CON FLAMENCO The block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues on West 36th Street is scarcely a Gran Via  la Madrid, come midnight. The garment center that clogs it during the day is resting, uneasily, and you can even find parking in the street. It is quiet and outside you cannot even hear the throaty wail, clacking heels and lamenting guitar of the flamenco behind the whitefronted Meson Tio Pepe (2394589), which plays to packed houses Thursdays through Sundays.

title: Cahill Opposes Life For Drug Pushers
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17Governor Cahill said today that he opposed mandatory life sentences for convicted drug pushers, contending that anyone seeking stiffer prison terms for such offenders must realize that the addicted pusher would do anything, regardless of the penalties, to support his habit.

title: The Gradual Evolution of a Girls' School
description: When Grace Institute opened its doors 75 years ago its purpose was to teach workingclass wives how to take better care of their homes and children. The Institute, which started out in an old mansion on West 60th Street, was also to give to needy girls the kind of advantages being offered by industrial schools to boys.

title: ExInvestigator Says Hoffa Had Aid of Ehrlichman and Chotiner
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) A former Justice Department investigator says that James R. Hoffa's release from prison followed a chronology of bribery, threats and political intrigue that still reaches into the White House.

title: BERRIGANS BLOCKED FROM TRIP TO HANOI
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today temporarily blocked the Berrigan brothers from going to Hanoi. Acting at the request of the Justice Department, he stayed a ruling issued earlier in the day by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Antiwar Congressmen May Boycott Inaugural
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)  Large numbers of antiwar Congressmen will boycott President Nixon's second inaugural, a California Democrat said today. Some may join protesters in the streets demanding that the United States get out of Vietnam.

title: Equity Financing
description: Ryder System Inc. directors have approved the purchase of 200,000 shares of the company's outstanding common stock on the open market and in private transactions. The purchases will be made over the next twelve months. The company's stock closed at 40, up , on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Jury Retires for 2d Night In Trial of Tombs Guard
description: Jurors in the Earl Whittaker case retired slfortly before 11 o'clock last night, failing after two days' deliberations to reach a verdict in the case of the prison guard, who was charged with aiding rioting inmates in the October, 1970, Tombs revolt.

title: PAKISTAN SAYS INDIA SLAUGHTERS P.O.W.'S
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 17 Pakistan accused India today of slaughtering Pakistani prisoners held in India since the war between the two nations in December, 1971.

title: People in Sports: Sanderson Is Free Agent
description: Derek Sanderson was given a settlement believed to be $1million and his unconditional release by the Philadelphia Blazers of the World Hockey Association yesterday. The release from a fiveyear, $2.65million contract was announced by Richard Olsen, the club's president, and Bob Woolf, Sanderson's lawyer.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Dark Days in Manila
description: Yesterday was another dark day for freedom in Asia as President Ferdinand E. Marcos extended martial rule indefinitely while proclaiming a new Constitutionone which, even if it is eventually invoked, would give him sweeping new powers. Mr. Marcos' resort to obviously rigged citizens' assemblies to gain a figleaf of public approval for his draconian measures, instead of the plebiscite he originally promised, is a clear indication that his descent into tyranny does not enjoy the neatuniversal acceptance that he has claimed.

title: Press Executives Get Tour of the City
description: The men who manage the news media in the city were given a highlevel glimpse of some high spots of the city's vast government yesterday.

title: Boy, 3, Falls 5 Stories And Is in Fair Condition
description: A 3yearold boy fell five stories from a window in a Brooklyn housing project last night, landed on a grassy plot and was reported in fair condition after he was taken to Cumberland Hospital.

title: F. D. A. PROPOSES SWEEPING CHANGE IN FOOD LABELING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The Food and Drug Administration announced today sweeping changes in food labeling practices to give consumers a better idea of the nutritional value of about half of what they eat.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)The Treasury Department adopted final regulations today requiring banks to keep microfilm copies of all checks over $100 on hand in a move to make it easier to catch whitecollar criminals.The regulations are the last of a series of rules adopted under the Bank Secrecy Act, passed by Congress in 1970 to help the Government in detecting crime carried on through secret foreign bank accounts as well as through domestic accounts.

title: ROGERS VOICES HOPE ON MIDEAST IN '73
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Secretary of State William P. Rogers said tonight that a number of developments had combined to make 1973 a favorable time for negotiations between Israel and Arab countries.

title: Undercover Agent Tells Court of Bribing Archer
description: A special Federal agent who had posed as a Mafia mobster testified at a bribery trial yesterday that he had delivered marked money as a bribe to have a case fixed by Norman D. Archer, an assistant district attorney in Queens.

title: DISMISSAL OF SUIT ON WAR INDICATED
description: A court yesterday recommended dismissal of a lawsuit seeking to declare unlawful and contrary to public policy President Nixon's decision last year to mine harbors in North Vietnam.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: PAPP REPUDIATES U.S.I.A. FILM On HIM
description: Joseph Papp, founder and director of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has repudiated a film about him and his work set for foreign distribution by the United States Information Agency.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SET HIGHS AGAIN
description: Soybean prices, which jumped the daily 10centsabushel limit on Tuesday, made a similar leap yesterday, setting another record on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Mrs. Meir Confers at Geneva With Ivory Coast's President
description: GENEVA, Jan. 17Premier Golda Meir of Israel ended her quick trip to Europe today by having lunch with President Flix HouphoutBoigny of the Ivory Coast.

title: Hanover Bank Net Is Up; Chemical's Profit Down
MARCOS TIGHTENS GRIP IN MANILA BY NEW CHARTER
description: MANILA, Jan. 17President Ferdinand E. Marcos consolidated his virtually unlimited power today, raising the prospect of years of authoritarian rule for the Philippines.

title: First L. I, R. R. Runs Are Scheduled for Early Saturday
description: Strikeharried Long Island Rail Road commuters can expect partial service starting at 12:01 A.M. Saturday and full service Monday morning if striking workers return to their jobs as scheduled, a spokesman for the railroad promised yesterday.

title: FOUR IN BRONX GANG ACCUSED IN MUGGING
description: Four members of a Bronx street gang were held without bail yesterday on charges that included attempted murder in connection with the mugging of a 43yearold man who suffered stab wounds in the head and stomach.

title: Those Going to Inaugural Festivities May Find the Visit Costly
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Anyone who wants to enjoy all the hoopla and festivities surrounding President Nixon's inauguration Saturday ought to bring plenty of money.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: NIXON AIDES' RE ON WOMEN SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Members of a new Government advisory committee reprimand. ed some of President Nixon's top advisers yesterday for what they said was the Administration's failure to understand the main economic problems facing women.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Slumping Nets Topple Rockets, 102 to 92
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 17The Denver Rockets had a shooting game tonight coaches like to forget and the Nets shot with the accuracy Coach Lou Carnesecca would like to see done more often.

title: POLICE PROBLEMS HEARD IN HARLEM
description: I am one of the most frustrated officers in the Police Department, Deputy Inspector William R. Bracey, commanding officer of the 32d Precinct, said last night. He was one of a panel of Harlem police officials meeting with the Harlem Task Force on Crime.

title: YUGOSLAVS REDUCE SCHOLAR'S SENTENCE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17Following criticism in Yugoslavia and abroad, a twoyear prison sentence imposed last July 18 against a Belgrade University law professor has been reduced to nine months by the Supreme Court of Serbia.

title: I.B.E.C. IN CUTBACK; DEFICIT IS POSSIBLE
description: The International Basic Economy Corporation plans to curtail and sell certain of its operations and concentrate on the more profitable businesses.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Jan. 17Nine years ago, Steve Savino was a peewee speed skating champion at the Willowbrook ice rink. So it comes as little surprise that, he's on his way to his third straight national championship.

title: City Pupils Get Right to Contest Damaging Entries in Their Files
description: Acting on a recommendation from Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner, the City Board of Education last night adopted new policies regarding pupil records that will, for the first time, give parents and youngsters the right to challenge derogatory material contained in official school files.

title: Homosexuals in Village Fearful After Series of Similar Killings
description: Three similarly violent murders in three weeks in lower Manhattan involving men the police said were part of the leather bar scene have sent waves of rumors and fear through the area's homosexual community.

title: COUGARS SUPPER 6TH LOSS IN ROW
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP)The New England Whalers set up a solid defense in front of their goalie, Al Smith, and whipped the Chicago Cougars, 42, in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: Keeneland Sales Close With $3.8Million Total
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 16 (AP)  Keeneland broke a record of sorts today when it finished its sale of horses of all ages by drawing $3.8million for 657 horses.

title: 19 DEAD OR MISSING IN IBERIAN STORMS
description: MADRID, Jan. 17 (UPI)The worst storm to hit the west coast of the Iberian Peninsula in 25 years lashed the shores of Spain and Portugal today, sinking dozens of fishing boats, wrecking harbor installations and leaving at least 19 persons dead or missing.

title: Blast Rips Nitrogen Plant In Oklahoma, Injuring Eight
description: PRYOR, Okla., Jan. 17 (AP)An explosion shattered the $2million Cherokee Nitrogen Company plant here tonight, igniting several neighboring industrial plants and threatening other buildings.

title: Waiting for Mr. Thieu
description: Although many signs point to an early ceasefire Vietnam, reports from Saigon indicate that President Thieu is still dragging his feet on an agreement already extensively revised to try to meet his objections. The United States has paid a heavy price in men, material and moral standing for this delay on Mr. Thieu's behalf.

title: Dartmouth Raises Tuition
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 17 (AP)Dartmouth College said today that tuition and room and board rates would be increased, beginning with the summer term. Tuition will go up $70 to $1,000 per each quarter term.

title: Shift in Airliner Financing Will Help U.S. Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17In a development that will provide significant help for the United States balance of international payments, the Japanese Government ExportImport Bank, instead of the United States ExportImport Bank, will finance the sale to Japan of 10 large United States commercial airliners valued at $237million.

title: Rentzel of Rams Indicted On Drug Charges on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP)  Lance Rentzel of the Los Angeles Rams, was indicted today by the Los Angeles County Grand Jury on charges of possession of marijuana and codeine.

title: Bills to Protect Newsmen Gain Support in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The Congressional effort to protect newsmen from forced disclosure of their sources gained momentum on both sides of the. Capitol today with the introduction of new freedomofinformation bills.

title: Jersey City Mayor Urges Vote on RentLeveling Bill
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 18Mayor Paul T. Jordan urged legislators today to pry a rentleveling bill out of the Assembly's Municipal Government Committee for a prompt floor vote.

title: Women of Distinction
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Tenn. (UPI)  CarsonNewsman College, a Baptistsupported school, offers a course in personal development called The Distinctive Woman.

title: Alma Mater Going Coed
description: CARLISLE, Pa., Jan. 19 (AP) Dickinson College, a 200yearold coeducational institution, has decided that the last stanza of its alma mater must go. The stanza includes the lines Men may come and men may go, ever to thy sons a pride.

title: MRS. KITTY CHAYES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Mrs. Kitty Torch Chayes, lawyer for the Office of Economic Opportunity, died in Doctor's Hospital early this morning. She was 74 years old.

title: Army Investigating Death Of a Recruit at Fort Dix
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Jan. 18The Army said today that it was investigating a charge, later diluted, that a drill sergeant had ordered trainees to kick a recruit who had suffered a fatal heart attack while on a march.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear an appeal by John J. Kenny, former Hudson County freeholder, to have a state extortion charge dismissed.

title: Thunder On the Right
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18President Nixon has returned to Washington for the start of his second term, but instead of finding a spirit of rejoicing over this spectacular victory and elation over the impending ceasefire in Vietnam, he found many of his old supporters in a perplexed and critical mood over his recent conduct.

title: HEALTH UNIT LISTS 10 FOOD VIOLATORS
description: Ten restaurants and other foodhandling establishments are on the latest list of violators of the city's Health Code.

title: The Screen:New Theater Showing 'If IHad a Gun'
description: New York is the greatest city in the world for seeing all kinds of movies, but it's also the toughest for a movie to survive in. The competition for audience attention is so fierce that, unless a film is a smash hit, it is almost instantly, a smash flop. The costs of theater operations and advertising are huge. Even with the price of tickets at first-run theaters between $3 and $4 each, most films, including many of the successful ones, lose money on their initial engagements.It simply doesn't pay to open the offbeat American film or the unknown foreign film that can hope for a mixed press at best. A few brave souls do buck the systemmost notably, Dan Talbot, owner of the New Yorker Theater on the Upper West Side. Add now the name of Associated Independent Theaters' First Avenue Screening Room, at 61st Street.The new 200-seat house, which opened yesterday with Stefan Uher's 1971 Czechoslovak film, "If I Had a Gun," has an announced policy of showing what are euphemistically called difficult filmsmost of them local premieresfor engagements of one week each. The idea is to keep the overhead low and the quality high, in order to provide Manhattan audiences with the opportunity of seeing films that might otherwise be missed even in this city, the best of all possible movie-going worlds.The intent, which is noble, is gently and honorably defined in the Screening Room's first attraction, a small, mostly comic memoir of a 15-year-old boy in a Czechoslovak village during the last months of the Nazi occupation. The film is full of memories, including at least one that is not entirely happy: the World War II period recalls so many other films made in Eastern Europe in the postwar, prethaw, Stalinist years, when the only safely noncontroversial subject was the German occupation. More specifically, it recalls other Czechoslovak films made before Alexander Dubcek's brief, brilliant Prague Spring.Like Ivan Passer, Milos Forman and Jiri Menzel in their early work, Stefan Uher, the 42-year-old director of "If I Had a Gun," speaks around and through a screen of official blandness. He has not, admittedly, packed his film with coded messages, with disguised slices of political or social satire. However, the sort of humaneness and wit that the film deals in are muted but real reminders of other freer times and places."If I Had a Gun" is the story of Vlado (Marian Bernat), an intelligent, cheerful boy whose fantasieswhich we share in the film's funniest momentseventually overtake the reality of the humdrum life in his village. Near the occupation's end, Vlado's comic dreams of heroism and yengeance are realized, though with the addition of the kind of terror and sorrow we usually eliminate from our dreams of glory.The film is not, however, especially sad, though its fine, short-focus, black-and-white photography would seem to evoke that mood in this era when almost everything is shot in color. Instead, it has the elegiac tone of a diary that is being read years after the events recorded and that makes no particular differentiation between the tragic and the comic, which time has somehow made equally important.Thus Mr. Uherquite consciously, I assumedevotes no more time or emphasis to a sequence in which Vlado and another younger boy are caught, in youth's equivalent of flagrante delicto, spying on two older girls who are bathing, than he does to the film's melodramatic, penultimate sequence. Memory has sealed but not erased the original feelings of trauma and desperation.In the film's final lines, Vlado recalls that after the liberation he and his friends returned to school: "They said we had been lazy too long." Among other things, "If I Had a Gun" is about the remarkable resiliency of children in ordinary as well as extraordinary, situations. The film, the work of a director new to Manhattan, deserves the protection and the care of the Screening Room.

title: Council Overrides Mayor, Enacts Bill to Add Districts
description: The City Council yesterday overrode Mayor Lindsay's veto of a reapportionment bill designed to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on the Council.

title: SYRIA AND IRAQ SET OIL TRANSIT ACCORD
description: DAMASCUS, Jan. 18 (UPI)Syria and Iraq today reached agreement on transit fees to be paid by Iraq for the passage of its crude oil through Syria to the Mediterranean, official sources said. No details were immediately available.

title: Winter Heat Wave Hits a Record 66
description: A midday temperature of 66 degrees yesterdayeight degrees above the record for the dategave New Yorkers a touch of spring fever to go with their flu.

title: Pope Eases Rule on Oil for Anointment
description: ROME, Jan. 18Pope Paul VI ruled today that any vegetable, oil, not only olive oil, might be used from now on in the sacrament of the sacred anointing of the sick.

title: Energy Issues Stand Out In Otherwise Flat Market
description: Oil and other energy issues, together with some leading glamours, were star performers in a generally flat stock market yesterday.

title: New Jersey Sports Coaches and 1.6 Rule
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18The New Jersey college basketball coaches agreed at their weekly meeting here today that the relaxation of the 1.6 rule by the National Collegiate Athletic Association would hurt junior colleges more than anybody else.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FALL AND RISE OF JIMMY HOFFA. By Walter Sheridan. 554 pages. Saturday Review Press. $10.95.

title: Council Overrides Mayor, Enacts Bill to Add Districts
description: The City Council yesterday overrode Mayor Lindsay's veto of a reapportionment bill designed to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on the Council.

title: Lawrence Tierney Stabbed In West Side Altercation
description: Lawrence Tierney, the film actor, was stabbed in the stomach yesterday afternoon in an altercation that began in a West Side bar and continued on the street. He was reported in satisfactory condition last night at St. Clare's Hospital.

title: G.A.O. Finds Nothing New On McGovern Financing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18, (AP) The General Accounting Office, in its third reply to charges of McGovern campaign finance irregularities raised by the former Republican national chairman, Senator Robert Dole, said today that it had found nothing new to refer to the Justice Departmen.

title: RAY BARRETT
description: Ray Barrett, a National Broadcasting Company radio staff announcer from 1944 to 1967, died Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 65 years old.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: NEW YORK

title: San Antonio Council Votes To Help Hospital in Hanoi
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 18 The council of this traditionally conservative city, which has a large concentration of military bases, unanimously passed a resolution today to help North Vietnam.

title: A.T.&T. TO GRANT 15,000 BACK PAY IN JOB INEQUITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed today to give $15million in back pay and $23million a year in raises to women and minority males against whom it had allegedly discriminated in job assignments, pay and promotions.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball
description: SCORING LEADERS

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, JANUARY 19, 1973
description: International

title: Diarnond Shamrock Expands
