description: The Diamond Shamrock Corpotation said yesterday that it would increases polyvinyl chloride capacity at Dear Park, Texas, by 200 million pounds a year, raising its total capacity to 500 million pounds a year. Industry sources put the cost of the expansion at between $10million and $15million.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CONTINUE TO RISE
U.N. Agency Is Concerned Over Shortages of Grain
description: ROME, Jan. 18The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today that the present grain shortages in various parts of the world were being viewed with concern, although there is no immediate cause for alarm.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The President and His Inauguration

title: Jury Finds Corona Guilty Of Slaying 25 workers
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 18A jury of 10 men and two women today convicted Juan V. Corona, a 38yearold Mexican national, of murdering 25 itinerant farm workers.

title: Thick Ice Crust Imperils 370,000 Reindeer in Siberia
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18Soviet authorities have declared a state of emergency in northeast Siberia, opposite Alaska, after a winter storm covered tundra grazing grounds with a thick ice crust, depriving 370,000 reindeer of fodder.

title: Smith Elected County Chief By Staten Island Democrats
description: The Staten Island Democratic County Committee last night elected James A. Smith, as county leader. Mr. Smith is 61yearold retired municipal worker and served briefly last year as a City Councilman.

title: N.B.A. LineUps AT LOS ANGELES
description: TVCHANNEL 9, 11 P.M.

title: Changes in City's Charter Are Suggested by Wagner
description: Speaking with the reflective and detached air of an elder statesman, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner told the City Charter Revision Commission yesterday that the city's basic problems would not be changed by rewriting its laws of goyernment.

title: EXECUTIVE SILENCE STIRS DEMOCRATS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Senate Democratic Caucus resolved today to make Cabinet officers and other officials of the Nixon Administration subject to possible contemptofCongress citations if they should refuse to appear and testify before Senate committees.

title: 7 Slain at Muslim House In Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Two adults and five children were slain late today in a house once owned, by Kareem AbdulJabbar, the professional basketball player, and used as headquarters by a sect of the Muslim religion to which he belonged.

title: Death of Recruit Spurs Army Inquiry
description: FORT DIX, Jan. 18  The Army said today that it was investigating a charge, Iater diluted, that a drill sergeant had ordered trainees to kick a recruit who had suffered a fatal heart attack while on a march.

title: DURATION UNSURE
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 18The United States and North Vietnam announced jointly today that their chief peace negotiators would meet again in Paris Tuesday to complete the text of an agreement to end the war.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOVEL FLICK Culture never flags at Japan House, the beautiful home of the Japan Society at 333 East 47th Street (8321155), and starting today the very comfortable auditorium will be showing a series of 15 Japanese films adapted from the works of Japanese novelists. Each film is shown Friday at 7:30, Saturday at 2 (except next week's, which will be seen on Thursday and Friday at 7:30), and admission is a $2 contribution. The first film is Shiro Toyoda's 1957 Snow Country, by Yasunari Kawabata. Ryunosuke Akutagawa's Rashomon is scheduled for Feb. 2 and 3, while Shohei Ooka's Fires on the Plain, directed by Kon Ichikawa, appears March 16 and 17. The films, with English subtitles, run through April 28.

title: All Horowitz Former Columnist And Chess Champion, Dies at 65
description: Al Horowitz, chess columnist for The New York Times front 1962, until last year, and three times winner of the United States Open championship, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 80 La Salle Street. He was 65 years old.

title: PROXY FIGHT LOOMS AT PETER PAUL, INC.
description: A proxy fight looms for control of Peter Paul, Inc., manufacturer of chocolatecovered candies with headquarters in Naugatuck, Conn.

title: Times Purchases Assets Of a Florida Weekly Paper
description: The New York Times Company has acquired for cash the assets of the Marco Island Publishing Corporation from William R. Tamplin and Raymond Henle, it was announced yesterday.

title: MET BOHEME DEBUT FOR PILAR LORENGAR
description: Given the number of years Pilar Lorengar has been singing with the Metropolitan Opera, it is surprising that she did not get around to the role of Mimi in Puccini's La Boheme until Tuesday night.

title: U.S. BIDS HIGH COURT BAR BERRIGAN TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)  The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to prohibit the proposed trip to Hanoi by the Revs. Philip and Daniel Berrigan, who are on parole after serving sentences for destruction of draft records.

title: Rhodesia Says That Tribesmen Aided ZambiaBased Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, San. 18  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said tonight that African tribesmen in northeastern Rhodesia had been helping African nationalist guerrillas operating against Rhodesia from a sanctuary in neighboring Zambia.

title: Formal Talks Suspended In Expectation of Accord
description: PARIS, Jan. 18The fouryearold Paris peace confer ence on Vietnam was suspended today after its 174th weekly meeting, in anticipation of what participants hope will be the final private negotiating round between Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho.

title: With a Blast of Trumpets, Republicans Begin Nixon Inauguration Festivities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Republicans kicked off their $4million celebration of President Nixon's second inauguration today with a giant reception at the Smithsonian Museum of History and Technology honoring Vice President Agnew.

title: L.I.'s Aerospace Industry To Make Big Gain in Jobs
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., Jan. 18 With the award of the A10 contract to the Republic Division of Fairchild Industries here, Long Island's ailing aerospace industry will, within the next five years, see the heaviest infusion of money and jobs since the nearby Grumman Corporation first began to develop the controversial F14 fighter a decade ago.

title: Ellsberg Jury Told Data Could Have Aided Enemy
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18An Army staff officer testified today that one of the documents released through the publication of the Pentagon papers could have helped the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong plan last year's Tet offensive.

title: Goldwater and Stennis Tell Saigon Not to Balk
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Two of the Saigon Government's strongest supporters in the United States SenateBarry Goldwater and John C. Stennisurged the Government today not to create obstacles to a peace agreement between the United States and North Vietnam.

title: L.I.R.R. EMPLOYES RETURN TO WORK
description: Employees of the Long Island Rail Road began returning to work early today in line with a truce arranged Wednesday between the carrier and striking unions representing 5,000 nonoperating employes.

title: U.S. Replies to Cuba on Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The United States has responded to the latest Cuban note in the negotiations for an agreement to curb airline hijackings, the State Department said today.

title: REVENUE INCREASES POSTED BY UTILITIES
description: The Southern California Edison Company reported yesteriday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1972. Jack K. Horton, chairman and chief executive officer, placed net intome at $137million, or 8 per cent higher than the $127million earned in 1971. Pershare earnings rose to $2.55 from 1$2.46 on fewer shares, a year earlier.

title: Russians Stop Lunar Car Just Short of a Crash
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18A traffic accident on the moon was reported today to have been barely averted by Soviet ground controllers as they put their remotely guided Lunokhod 2 through its paces yesterday.

title: Records
description: David Amram lives and works in New York, and it shows in the material written for his first rock album, Subway Night (RCA LSP 4820 $5.98).

title: City Raises Income Limits by 20% in Public Housing
description: Higher income limits have been set for entry into public housing projects in the city in an effort to keep them from becoming economic and racial ghettos, Simeon Golar an nounced yesterday.

title: Crepes From a Magic Pan
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: ExMental Patient, Shifted to Tombs, Hangs Self in Cell
description: A 35year old inmate who had spent time in a state mental hospital committed suicide last night in his cell at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men, where he had apparently been transferred after being deemed fit to stand trial.

title: STATE ASKING U.S. FOR SEWAGE FUNDS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18  President Nixon's curtailment of funds provided by new Federal Clean Waters legislation, as well as restrictions in the new law, are delaying the appropriation of millions of dollars of state bond funds for dozens of new sewage treatment facilities in New York State.

title: Bruins Are Upset By Islanders, 97
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP)The New York Islanders scored five firstperiod goals and shook off repeated Boston challenges the rest of the way tonight in a 97 victory over the Biins the biggest upset of the National Hockey League season. The worst team in the N.H.L. picked on the defending Stanley Cup champions to come out of a 12game losing streak.

title: RACIAL BIAS bAlD TO REALTY CHAIN
description: TRENTON, Jan. 18 The State Division on Civil Rights announced today that one of New Jersey's largest realestate companiesMcNerneyTalmo Realty, Inc., of Bergen County  had been found guilty of racial discrimination in the sale of a $129,000 home in Englewood Cliffs in 1971.

title: U.S. Hints Blackmail as Motive in Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)  The Government publicly suggested for the first time today that blackmail was motive behind the alleged bugging of Democratic national headquarters last summer by Republicanfinanced agents.

title: F.D.A. Urges a New Cutback In Amphetamine Output Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Federal Government is moving toward sharp reduction in amphetamine production quotas for the second straight year.

title: Uncle Sam And the TarBaby
description: In The Wonderful TarBaby Story, Joel Chandler Harris described through his bygone Uncle Remus how Brer Fox laid a trap for his enemy, Brer Rabbit, by creating a contraption of tar and turpentine which resembled a provocative doll.

title: Sidewalk Skiers Attract Thousands in Sunshine
description: There were strange doings in front of the TimeLife Building at 50th Street and the Avenue of the Americas yesterday. In temperatures that were about 30 degrees above freezing and under cloudless skies, crosscountry and downhill skiers went through their paces while thousands of the curious gaped. National Ski Week begins its annual 10  day stand today and yesterday the National Ski Foundation joined with New York City's Department of Recreation for a big kickoff for the annual observance.

title: INDIA TAKES OVER STRIFETORN AREA
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 18Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ordered the central Government to take control of Andhra Pradesh to day, following the collapse of the state government under pressure of violent separatist agitations.

title: '72 Exports and Imports Set New Highs in Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 18Japan's exports in 1972 rose 19.3 per cent to a record $30.2billion, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry announced today.

title: JOHN J. FUREY
description: John J. Furey, manager of the advertising acceptability department of The New York Times, died Wednesday evening of a heart attack in the Ely Avenue Queens, station of the IND subway line. He was 55 years old and lived in Lynbrook, L. I.

title: End of Inaction?
description: The order by outgoing Secretary of Labor Hodgson for sweeping changes in a discriminatory jobseniority system at the giant Bethlehem Steel mill in Sparrows Point, Md., provides a welcome indication that reports of the death of the Administration's antibias program may be premature.

title: S.E.C. Chief Denies All Charges in Suit On Mismanagement
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan, 18 (AP)  William J. Casey, President Nixon's nominee as Under Secretary of State for economic affairs, denied today charges of mismanagement and flagrant violation of duties to a corporation he helped found.

title: 2 City Units Monitoring Hiring Of Minorities Are Consolidated
description: Two municipal agencies that review work conditions and minority employment in private industry have been consolidated into a new Bureau of Labor Services, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

title: Rites for Albert Kurzman
description: A funeral service for Albert W. Kurzman, a consultant to the BVD Company, will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, at noon today. Mr. Kurzman, who was 66 years old, died Wednesday.

title: Metropolitan Reattributes 300 Paintings
description: The Odalisque, whose attribution the Metropolitan Museum has said will change from Ingres to a lesserknown artist, is only one of about 300 Old Master paintings that the institution has downgraded in a major reevaluation of its collection.

title: Deadline for DetroitI
description: Early in 1972, William D. Ruckelshaus was asked by leading motor manufacturers to postpone for a year the drastic automobile emissions standards ordered for 1975 models under the Clean Air Act. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency denied the request, and he had good reason to do so at the timejust as the auto companies had good reason to apply for the extension. Now they have appealed to the courts, which may or may not direct Mr. Ruckelshaus to reconsider, and are pressuring Congress to modify the act itself.

title: Britain Plays the Percentages
description: LONDON, Jan. 18  Can Government slow inflation at the same time that it is stimulating the economy to make it grow faster?

title: DURATION UNSURE
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 18The United States and North Vietnam announced jointly today that their chief peace negotiators would meet again in Paris Tuesday to complete the text of an agreement to end the war.

title: Texas Sets a Hearing on Shortage of Gas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan, 13 Because of the current shortage, the Texas Railroad Commission will examine the naturalgas situation at its annual review hearing March 13 in Abilene, Jim C. Langdon, the new chairman of the commission, announced today.

title: U.S. Signs Accord to Help Investment in Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 18The United States today signed an agreement with Yugoslavia to assist and encourage capitalist investment in joint venturesthe first such accord with a Communist country.

title: ExJersey Road Chief Admits Extortion
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18D. Louis Tonti, former executive director of the New Jersey. Highway Authority, pleaded guilty today to one count of a 47count Federal indictment charging him with conspiring to use interstate commerce facilities to commit, bribery and extortion.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST INSPIRES OTHERS
description: Last month, Corinna Marsh, retired and living at 12 East 31st Street on a small pension, sent the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund a check for $5, regretting at the time that it represented only half of her usual $10.

title: Richardson Sees Confidence Crisis In Social Services
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18In a farewell to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, Elliot L. Richardson, the outgoing Secretary, said today that the nation was in a crisis of confidence that American social problems can indeed be resolved.

title: Garden's Road Show Fans Out
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18Those two prime jewels in the crown of Madison Square Garden Corporation, the Knicks and the Rangers, found themselves breakfasting in the same hotel coffee shop this morning, underlying the similarities between the two teams.

title: HIJACKER OF JET GUILTY ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18After six and onehalf hours of deliberation, a Federal Court jury of six men and six women convicted Francis M. Goodell yesterday of hijacking a Pacific Southwest Airlines jet last July 6.

title: Concerts: A Birthday Tribute to Rieti
description: Chronologically speaking, it was a tiny bit premature. Vittorio Rieti will not celebrate his 75th birthday until San. 28. But his anniversary concert on Wednesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall was, of course, no less welcome.

title: Former Bronx Prosecutor Indicted on Bribery Count
description: Mario Merola, the Bronx District Attorney, yesterday announced the indictment of a 30yearold former assistant district attorney in the Bronx on charges of bribery.

title: Cyprus Band Disarms Police
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 18 (AP)An armed band of supporters of Gen. George Grivas, the underground leader who wants to unite Cyprus with Greece, disarmed and beat a police patrol in the port of Limassol today, the Government said. The incident occurred in the midst of clashes between high school pupils. The armed men appeared when the police tried to arrest some of those demonstrating against President Makarios.

title: BHENNANDIFFBRS WITH NIXON VIEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Peter J. Brennan, President Nixon's nominee for Secretary of Labor, expressed today views on key labor issues that diverged sharply from past Administration policies.

title: Lindsay Plans Task Force To Cut SingleRoom Crime
description: Mayor Lindsay plans to appoint a strong local task force to deal with the problems of crime and singleroomoccupancy buildings on the West Side.

title: People and Business
description: John H. Shaffer has been up in the air for the last four years as Federal Aviation Administrator. Now the 53yearold exercutive is leaving his $42,500ayear government job to manage a moving company in the Washington area that he purchased five years ago.

title: RIVER DEATHS RAISE HOMOSEXUALS' FEAR
description: The discovery of the bodies of two young men floating in the Hudson River off Greenwich Village added yesterday to the fears of the homosexual community, already stunned by three recent murders of homosexuals in the area.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lefkowitz Opens Shubert Audit

title: West German Reserves Fall
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 18 (Reuters)West Germany's net monetary reserves declined by about $100million to about $24.6billion in the week ended Jan. 15, the Bundesbank said today.

title: 9 FISHING VESSELS ARE SEIZED BY PERU
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 18 (AP)Peru has resumed seizing foreign fishing vessels, with the impounding yesterday of eight United States tuna boats off the nation's northern coast.

title: CITY BALLET DABBLES IN PIANO AND WINDS
description: Concerto for Piano and Winds is a weak ballet, and its contribution to the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Festival last June, like that, of other minor works in that event, was to help fill out an aural biography of the composer. Stravinsky wrote the score, and this was reason enough to compose a ballet to it.

title: Somber U.S. Trade Picture Painted
description: A somber picture of the problems facing the United States and its key commercial partners was drawn yesterday by a number of prominent executives who were, or still are, responsibld for shaping the country's foreign economic policy.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST EXTENDS OFFER
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation announced yesterday it had extended for 21 days its tender offer to holders of securities of the Talcott National Corporation at the request of the Justice Department.

title: Lions' Walker Calls It Quits
description: DETROIT, Jan. 18 (UPI)Wayne Walker, twice an allpro in his 15 seasons as linebacker for the Detroit Lions, announced his retirement today from professional football. The 35yearold Walker has been hired by the Columbia Broadcasting System for color work during the 1973 season.

title: Franklin Mint Clarification
description: The stock of the Franklin Mint Corporation ended trading on the New York Stock Exchange in 1972 at 23, up 4 points. Because of a transmission error, the closing price of the stock in the annual stock table showed a loss of 4 to 23. The company had a three for two stock split on Jan. 5 and a two for one stock split on Sept. 28. The issue closed at .56 in 1971.

title: CECIL W. TATE
description: Cecil W. Tate, an insurance adjuster here for more than 40 years, died Wednesday in Portola. Valley, Calif., where he lived. His age was 88.

title: GUARD AT TOMBS CLEARED IN RISIING
description: Earl Whittaker, a correction officer, who had been accused of 27 counts of kidnapping, unlawful imprisonment, criminal solicitation and obstructing governmental administration, was acquitted of all charges yesterday.

title: 7 Slain at Muslim House In Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Two adults and five children were slain late today in a house once owned by Kareem AbdulJabbar, the professional basketball player, and used as headquarters by a sect of the Muslim religion to which he belonged.

title: Urban League Asks Inquiry in Slaying Of Black by Police
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 18 (UPI) The Morris County Urban League said today that the fatal shooting of a black youth outside a bar by a white policeman early last Saturday morning in Bernardsville must be thoroughly investigated by the prosecutor's office.

title: N.B.C., 2 COMEDIANS DIFFER ON LAUGH IN
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that Although the comedians Dan Rowan and Dick Martin have been publicly announcing that their Laugh In television program will go off the air after this season, the network has made no such decision.

title: North Makes 5 Demands on U.S. To Spur Korean Reunification
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Jan. 18North Korea today put rorth five demands for United States actions toward the reunification of Korea, including the withdrawal of all American troops from South Korea.

title: Theory Revised on Domestic Animals
description: Using a new method for the precise dating of old bones, California scientists have concluded that man first domesticated the cow and pig in Europe some 9,000 years ago.

title: Store Sales Increase 15%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 TheDepartment of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $726million, up 15 per cent from the year earlier $633million. Total retail store sales were about $8.05billion, up 12 per cent from the year earlier $7.2billion.

title: C. W. POST IS VICTOR OVER C.C.N.Y., 6557
description: C. W. Post won its 11th consecutive game last night, beating City College, 6557, in the loser's gym. City, playing without its leading scorer, Otis Loyd, built a 3327 halftime lead. Lou Indiviglio of City scored 14 of his gameleading 22 points in the first half.

title: A College Super Bowl Taking Root in Money
description: A major college football championship playoff has once again become a possibility. The search for added television revenue could be the deciding factor, even though National Collegiate Athletic Association members have rejected playoff plans many times.

title: Tarsila do Amaral Dead; Brazilian Painter Was 82
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18Tarsila do Amaral, a leading Brazilian painter, died yesterday in So Paulo. She was 82 years old.

title: Bridge: Players on Shortened Cruise Use Time to Help Nicaragua
description: Those who go on bridge cruises do not aim at seeing the worldthey just want to play their favorite game. Some keep right on playing even when the ship is in port, refusing to sample the local tourist attractions.

title: Rates of Interest on Treasury Bills Show Advance
description: The money and capital markets offered a picture of interest rates yesterday that was thoroughly blurred.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: FLAMINGO, Fla.  Snook were all about ussome eight pounds or more  streaking away as we paddled our canoe through a maze of mangrove channels.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today.
AMEX IS STEADY;
description: Prices on the American S lock Exchange and on the overthecounter market finished mixed yesterday in moderate trading.

title: BRAVES TRIUMPH AFTER FINAL HORN
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 18 (AP)Butch Komives tossed in a pair of free throws tonight after the final horn had sounded, giving the Buffalo Braves a 127125 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: People in Sports: Littler to Get Hogan Award
description: Gene Littler, who underwent an operation for cancer but is now back on the professional tour, has been named winner of the Ben Hogan trophy. The award is presented annually to the golfer who has overcome a physical handicap, resumed golf and proved an inspiration to his community.

title: 2 U.S. Sailors Sentenced To Jail Terms in Greece
description: ATHENS, Jan. 18 (AP)Two American Sixth Fleet sailors today were sentenced by a Greek court to eight months' imprisonment each for hooliganism and causing bodily damage. They were held at a United States air base in Athens pending an appeal of their cases.

title: MUSIC BY STARKER FLOWS LIKE HONEY
description: Having been backed up by large orchestras in his two previous appearances here this season, Janos Starker chose to have the stage all to himself Wednesday night at Tully Hall. He played three works for unaccompanied cello, Bach's Suites No. 3 in C and No. 2 in D minor and Koddly's Sonata.

title: Soviet Asks More Nations At ForceReduction Talks
description: MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 19the Soviet Union and its East European allies have proposed an enlargement of the East West talks on force reductior scheduled to begin on Jan: 31 to include all interested European nations plus the United States and Canada.

title: A.T&T. TO GRANT 15,000 BACK PAY IN JOB INEQUITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed today to give $15million in back pay and $23million a year in raises to women and minority males against whom it had allegedly discriminated in job assignments, pay and promotions.

title: 2 Chiefs of Staff for Parks Are Appointed by Clurman
description: Edward Skloot, a 30yearold assistant to Mayor Lindsay, and Herschel Post, a 33yearold former executive director of the Parks Council, have been appointed chiefs of staff by the city's new parks administrator, Richard M. Clurman.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The third annual Latin American Day at Yankee Stadium, scheduled for Saturday afternoon July 21, will take on added significance this year because the club plans a special presentation to Mrs. Roberto Clemente of a bronze plaque in memory of her late husband, who was killed in a plane crash while on his way to help victims of the Managua, Nicaragua, earthquake.

title: Marine Midland Reports Earnings Rise
CHARLES VON DREUSCHE
description: MANASQUAN, N. J., Jan. 18 Charles F. von Dreusche, who retired in 1957 as president of the New York Printers and Bookbinders Mutual Insurance Company (now the Graphic Arts Mutual Insurance Company), died today in a nursing home in Wall Township. He was 81 years old and had lived here.

title: 2 Killed Building Tank
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) Two workmen were killed and six injured today when they fell 48 feet inside a 55,000gallon oil storage tank being built in southwest Philadelphia. Those killed were identified as Newt Maim, 35 years old, of Easton, Md., and Jerry Swinrose, 34, of Edgewood, Md.

title: Lopsided Redistricting
description: By precisely the same lopsided vote as before, members of the City Council have again approved an unconscionable reapportionment plan. This time their action was taken to override Mayor Lindsay's thoroughly warranted veto of a scheme that expands the number of Council seats from 37 to 43 without doing anything useful to overcome that body's glaring deficiencies.

title: New Books
description: FICTIOW

title: KIEINDIENST VOWS AID ON WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst promised today that the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation would cooperate with the Senate investigation of political eavesdropping at the Democratic National Committee's Watergate headquarters.

title: GemTheft Arrests
description: Three persons were arrested yesterday in the theft of jewels valued at more than $100,000 from a Brooklyn church. Details on Page 13.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Transcript of Briefing by Ziegler on the Private Peace Talks
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP)Following is a White House transcript of a news briefing today at which Ronald L. Ziegler, White House press secretary, announced plans for resuming private Paris peace talks next Tuesday:

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: * The Steak Pit, Route 4 Westbound, Paramus, N. J.(201) 8455200.

title: Coryell Gets 3Year Pact To Coach Football Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 (UPI)Don Coryell, head football coach at San Diego State University for 12 years after having replaced George Allen at Whittier College earlier in his Career, was named head coach today of the St. Louis football Cardinals.

title: AD AGENCY INDICTED IN THEFT AT TIMES
description: The Cromwell Advertising Agency and a former employe in the classified advertising department of The New York Times were indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on charges of istealing $274,700 from the newspaper over the last four years.

title: ExCity Inspector Jailed Six Months For Extortion Plot
description: A former inspector in the demolition division of the Department of Housing was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail for his part in what was described as a systematic extortion plot against demolition contractors in the city.

title: Advertising: Time of Affluence
description: Time magazine, with statistics gleaned from the 1970 census, is prepared to back its claim of circulation concentration in affluent neighborhoods and, in effect, is challenging other media to try to match it.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGET TOPS NEW YORK'S
description: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 18Gov. Ronald Reagan presented the California State Legislature today with a budget of $9.258billion, regaining for California the lead from New York as the state with the highest budget. Governor Rockefeller has proposed a spending program of $8.88billion the next fiscal year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Colony Reopens Despite Pickets

title: DICK COSGRAVE
description: ROSEBUD, Alberta, Jan. 18 (AP)Dick Cosgrave, 10time world chuckwagon driving champion between 1926 and 1944 and a Calgary Stampede Arena director, died Thursday at his ranch near here. He was 67 years old.

title: TELEX SEEKS END TO IRK'S ACCORD
description: The Telex Corporation yesterday filed a motion in the Federal District Court in St. Paul to set aside the settlement of the Control Data Corporation's antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Heavy Raids Go On in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 19 (AP)  Heavy United States air raids were flown throtighout South Vietnam for a second day yesterday in stlpport of South Vietnamese troops engaged in the increasing ground fighting.

title: Montgomery Posts 67 to Lead Tucson Golf by a Shot
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 18 (UPI)  Jack Montgomery grabbed the firstday lead in the $150,000 Tucson open golf tournament today with a fiveunderpar 67.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: THIEU'S POSITION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 19Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. left Saigon yesterday with President Nguyen Van Thieu's agreement to the general principles of a ceasefire accord but without resolving disagreements on several questions of carrying out the accord, a source close to the negotiations said today.

title: African Games End As Athletes Seek Priorities for Sports
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan, 18Africa's greatest sports extravaganza, the second AllAfrica Games, ended tonight with great jubilation but without answering the questions that were foremost in the minds of many of the young contestants.

title: Red Smith
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 18All through the sunny day and into the twilight, buzzards wheel in watchful circles over National Stadium, but this is not construed as an omen having to do with Joe Frazier or George Foreman. Joe and George will be swatting each other in Kingston's tidy playpen Monday night, but in spite of press agents' efforts to rile them for the sake of the box office, neither has been shouting about leaving the other for dead. These are two decent, straightforward professionals calmly approaching a job of work. Frazier owns the heavyweight championship of the world, is being paid $850,000 to defend it, and is quietly confident that he can do so successfully. Foreman covets the title and frankly relishes the prospect of earning $375,000 while he fights for it. Neither accepts the idea of defeat because neither has ever lost, as a pro.

title: The Lunts' Furniture In Auction Spotlight
description: Whet some theatrical buffs might consider a million dollars worth of nostalgia will be sold here Saturday, possibly for less than $50,000, when most of the furnishings from the Alfred Lunts' town house are auctioned at Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: WEEKEND DOUBLE IS LINORI'S GOAL
description: Encouraged by the result of his first race in 11 months, Marty Liguori will embark on an ambitious track and fitld assignment tonight and tomorrow afternoon.

title: AIR FORCE PICKS FAIRCHILD ON L.I. TO BUILD NEW JET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Air Force today selected Fairchild Industries, Inc., to produce at its Farmingdale, L. I., plant a new combat aircraft designed exclusively for providing close air support to frontline troops.

title: Dr. Nathan Lazar, 74, Dies; A Professor of Mathematics
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18Dr. Nathan Lazar, a former New York teacher who was professor of mathematics education at Ohio State University from 1950 to 1969, died yesterday. He was 74 years old and lived here.

title: Voter Registration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Legislation to authorize a threeyear $135million program of Federal aid to the states to help increase voter registration was introduced today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST INSPIRES OTHERS
description: Last month, Corinna Marsh, retired and living at 12 East 31st Street on a small pension, sent the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund a check for $5, regretting at the time that it represented only half of her usual $10.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: China Main Turns On Smile for U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 18The chill that descended on China's relations with the United States when President Nixon began intensive bombing of the HanoiHaiphong region of North Vietnam has lifted with the appearance of a series of articles in the Peking press acclaiming the warmth of the American welcome for a visiting Chinese scientists' delegation and an acrobatic troupe.

title: A Craftsman With Muscle
description: Jonathan Bricken played defensive end on the football team at McBurney School and wrestles every day there. Then he goes home and makes jewelry.

title: S.E.C. ASKS EASING OP FUND AD CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today, to ease restrictions on advertising by mutual funds and other investment companies.

title: MRS. SALLY UNDERWOOD
description: Mrs. Sally Evelyn Nicholas Underwood, formerly active in the Drama League of New York, died Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 79 years old.

title: Baking a Pork Dish With Apple Brandy
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Coking Operation Cut
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 (UPI) The United States Steel Corporation reduced coking operations at its Clairton works by 35 to 40 per cent today. The Allegheny County health department said air pollution rose to the danger level overnight when a temperature inversion trapped polluted, stagnant air in the Monongahela Valley.

title: Witness Seeks Immunity In ExSenator's Tax Trial
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18The Federal Government's chief witness in the trial of former State Senator Willard B. Knowl ton refused today to answer any questions until he was granted immunity from prosecution.

title: BUSINESS SURVEY FORECASTS GAINS
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, Jan. 18Sales, costs, prices and profits are likely to continue going up, according to the 14th annual economic survey conducted among the 13,500 member conerns of the New Jersey Manufacturers Association.

title: 2 Questioned in Extortion Killings
description: GRANDIN, Mo., Jan. 18 (UPI)Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and scores of state and local policemen searched wooded Ozark hill country today for extortionists who bound a banker, his wife and their 17yearold daughter to trees and shot them to death yesterday.

title: 10 Called a Part of Brooklyn Heroin Ring
description: Federal authorities in Brooklyn announced narcotics conspiracy charges yesterday against eight men and two women in what they described as the largest heroin retailing operation in the BedfordStuyvesant area, and possibly in the city.

title: Amer. Hockey League, WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES
description: Hershey 7, Springfield 4. Richmond 6, Baltimore 3. Rochester 3, New Haven 2. Virginia 4, Jacksonville 3.

title: Red Sox Sign Cepeda as PinchHitter
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)Orlando Cepeda was signed by the Boston Red Sox today, ostensibly to fill the designated pinchhitter role the club originally had opposed.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Rabbi to Givp Nixon a Kingly Blessing
description: The rabbi who will pray for President Nixon at the inauguration tomorrow plans to pronounce the blessing that the Talmud xescribes when one sees a king and his court.

title: Notes on People
description: Accompanied by Federal narcotics agents who took custody of him in Kabul, Afghanistan, Dr. Timothy Leary was flown to Los Angeles yesterday. Leary, once a leader of drug cultists, was detained by Afghan authorities and delivered to the American agents, although there is no extradition treaty between the United States and Afghanistan. In California, Leary faces charges relating to his 1970 escape from the San Luis Obispo prison, where he had been serving a 10year sentence on a narcotics conviction. He also faces a 1972 indictment charging him with importing 1,000 pounds of hashish. On a stopover in London en route to California, Leary said, I'm going to get lawyer.

title: NEOFASCISTS OPEN MEETINGS IN ITALY
description: ROME, Jan. 18Amid exceptional security measures, Italy's neoFascist party opened a fourday national convention here today in a bid to be accepted by public opinion as a reputable and responsible political movement.

title: NORDIQUES TIED BY RAIDERS, 44
description: QUEBEC, Jan. 18 (AP)The New York Raiders withstood three powerplay goals by Quebec and rallied three times tonight to gain a 44 tie with the Nordiques in a World Hockey Association game that went overtime.

title: GENERAL FOODS SHOWS PROFIT DIP
U.S. Drops the Charges Against 5 of Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP)The Federal Government officially dropped charges today against five of the defendants in the Chicagoseven conspiracy case whose convictions were reversed.

title: Business Briefs
description: BERLIN, Jan. 18  An amicable settlement was achieved today before an official East German tribunal an industrial dispute between an American importing company, the I.M.I. Machinery Corporation of New York, claiming delivery of deficient machines, and Unitechna, the East German state enterprise that sold them.

title: Newsweek, Inc., Appoints New Books Division Head
description: S. Arthur Dembner has been appointed president of Newsweek Books, a division of Newsweek, Inc., that he established five years ago, it was announced yesterday by the magazine's president, Gibson McCabe.

title: Music: Copland's Force
description: To the generation that came of age in the 1930's and 1940's the name of Aaron Copland meant something special, Something that would be hard to put into precise words for recently matured music listeners. Mr. Copland, in a vague but real way, represented American music for many people, though he was hardly the only important composer ti) emerge in those days (Ives and Ruggles had surveyed the land long before, and others might rightfully file claims, too).

title: ExJersey Highway Chief Pleads Guilty to Extortion
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18D. Louis Tonti, former executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, pleaded guilty today to one count of a 47count Fed eral indictment charging him with conspiring to use interstate commerce facilities to commit bribery and extortion.

title: The Strategy of the Old Bombers
description: The lessons of the elevenday bombing blitz against the HanoiHaiphong area are under intensive study in the Pentagon.

title: ExamWeary Yale Freshmen Given Breakfast in Bed
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 18Roseniary Elizondo, still half asleep, peered out from the bunk in her room in Vanderbilt Hall at Yale.

title: Public TV Affairs
description: The other shoe has dropped in public broadcasting, not with a bang but a simper. The Corporation for Public Broadcasting has decided to turn its Public Boadcasting Service into a wholly disowned subsidiary.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 3.1 %
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 14.5 billion tonmiles, 3.1 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 469,697, up 0.7 per cent from last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 7.0 per cent above last year.

title: Turmoil in Rhodesia
description: It is fashionable in southern Africa and elsewhere dismiss with contempt the efforts of black Africans sustain guerrilla movements against entrenched white minority governments. Then something happens to demonstrate that the guerrillas must be taken seriously after all, and that the struggle for selfdetermination and majority rule not only endures but slowly advances.

title: 6 CHANGES ASKED IN POSTAL SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Postmaster General Elmer T Klassen formally proposed to day six Changes in the Posta Service's, mail classification system including one that requires a surcharge for first class mailings that are not ?? standard size.

title: A Case Study in Power
description: His admirers call him an idealist, concerned over the corruption, poverty and disorganization of his country and committed to a new society of development, prosperity and order. His enemies call him a powerhungry dictator with a genius for political deception, a secret disdain for his people's problems, and a determination to keep absolute authority at all costs. But to friends and critics alike, President Ferdinand Edralin Marcos of the Philippines has become the symbol and the person of strength in a nation of uncertainty.

title: SABRES TROUNCE BLACK HAWKS, 51
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 18 (UPI)Gerry Meehan scored two goals tonight and Hugh Harris netted one and picked up three assists as the Buffalo Sabres triumphed over the Chicago Black Hawks, 51, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Rise in Auto Production Scheduled for the Week
description: DETROIT, Jan. 18 (Reuters) The United States auto industry is scheduled to build 215,320 cars this week, according to automotive news.

title: Colony Reopened Despite Picketing
description: The Colony reopened yesterday, and Truman Capote and a number of other regular patrons of the restaurant at 30 East 61st Street, braved the taunts of union pickets to get inside.

title: Jury Finds Corona Guilty Of Slaying 25 Workers
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 18A jury of 10 men and two women today convicted, Juan V. Corona, a 38yearold Mexican national, of murdering 25 itinerant farm workers.

title: Layer and Stan Smith Reach Quarterfinals at Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP)Topseeded Rod Laver of Australia struggled to a 76 firstset victory over Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia tonight, then dominated the second set, 63, to move to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Saga Bay tennis tournament.

title: Moss Plans Bill to Amend S.E.C. NewMember Rule
description: Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California and chairman of a House subcommittee on the securities industry, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to amend the Securities and Exchange Commission's new rule on institutionally owned stock exchange member firms.

title: The Ballet: Lubovitch's Scherzo for Massah Jack
FILIPINOS ASKED TO CLOSE RANKS
description: MANILA, Jan. 18President Ferdinand E. Marcos called upon all Filipinos today to close ranks and comply with the provisions of the authoritarian new Constitution he proclaimed ratified yesterday.

title: R. D. HUNTINGTON JR
description: Robert D. Huntington. Jr., vice president of Trident Managers, insurance brokers in Manhasset, L. I., died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived on Mill Road in Oyster Bay.

title: Kneib of Temple Injured
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) John Kneib, a junior guard and Temple University's leading scorer with a 13.2point average, will miss Saturday night's game with St. John's University at Jamaica, Queens, because of an injury. A team spokesman said today Knelb suffered a right index finger laceration, inflicted by broken glass.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: AIR FORCE PICKS FAIRCHILD ON L.I. TO BUILD NEW JET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Air Force today selected Fairchild Industries, Inc., to produce at its Farmingdale, L. I., plant a new combat aircraft designed exclusively for providing close air support to frontline troops.

title: Briefs on The Arts
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 18The Swedish Royal Opera marked its 200th anniversary tonight with a new opera about its illfated founder, King Gustav III. The work, Tintomara, was composed by Lars Johan Werle and is based on the last days of the king who was shot in the back at a midnight masquerade in the Stockholm Opera House on March 16, 1792.

title: Bribery jury Hears Tapes About Fix
description: A briberytrial jury in Federal Court here listened yesterday to several hours of taperecorded conversations about fixing a criminal case in Queens.

title: TV: Permissiveness Linked to Audience Size
description: In pursuit of television's new permissiveness, what you see is curiously but directly related to where you get it. The rule of venturous thumb seems to be: the smaller the audience, the greater the permissiveness.

title: Rails in 2 Areas to Ask 2% Emergency Rate Rise
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (Reuters) The Western and Southern railroads said today they expect to file a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission on Monday for authority to issue an emergency surcharge increasing freight rates by 2 per cent within the two territories with certain exceptions.

title: Ellsberg Jury Told Data Could Have Aided Enemy
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18An Army staff officer testified today that one of the documents released through the publication of the Pentagon papers could have helped the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong plan last year's Tet offensive.

title: Youth in Branding Case Guilty Of Distributing Amphetamines
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J.  Earl W. Harris Jr. of Brick Township, the youth who once swore he had been branded on the buttocks in a state police barracks, was convicted today of two drug charges.

title: Personal Income in U.S. Climbed 8.6% Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The personal income of American families and individuals rose by $74.4billion last year, a figure much larger than the entire national income of most countries in the world.

title: Rights Commission Calls for Stronger Penalties Against Discrimination in RevenueSharing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Civil Rights Commission has criticized the antidiscrimination sections of the revenuesharing act as too weak and has urged adoption of stronger provisions, including cutting off funds where rights are violated.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 134.9 from 133.4 last week.

title: Equity Financing
description: GambleSkogmo, Inc., said yesterday it would buy all of the 854,920 shares of its common stock tendered by stockholders. The offer, which expired Jan. 10, originally covered the purchase of up to 500,000 shares at $35.50 per share. The company's stock closed at 35, up 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Vocabulary of Presidents
description: MILWAUKEEAs in so many other things that involved the relationship of men to power, the Greeks had a word for ithubris. It would be a good one to cast in slxinch letters of bronze and place on the most prominent wall of every room in the White House.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 19Gen. Alexander M, Haig Jr. left Saigon yesterday with President Nguyen Van Thieu's agreement to the general principles of a ceasefire accord but without resolving disagreements on several questions of carrying out the accord, a source close to the negotiations said today.

title: IMPROVED BRAKES URGED FOR TRUCKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board called today for stronger and more reliable braking systems for trucks.

title: Italy Has East German Ties
description: ROME, Jan. 18Italy and East Germany have agreed to establish diplomatic relations immediately, the Italian Government announced today.

title: U.S. Puts Its Weekly Toll At 2 Killed in Indochina
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18 (UPI)The weekly casualty report issued by the United States command today listed twp Americans as having been killed in action in Indochina, both of them airmen lost over Laos.

title: U.S. Awards $57Million To Help Clean Raritan Bay
description: TRENTON, Jan. 18  The Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had awarded $57million, the largest single water pollutionabatement grant in the agency's history, toward cleaning up Raritan Bay.

title: Feminists Address Rotarians And Walk Into the Lions' Den
description: YONKERS, Jan 18  The women's liberation movement came briefly to the Yonkers Rotary Club this afternoon, leaving most of the Rotarians shaken up a bit, in the words of one, but decidedly unreconstructed.

title: SUPPLY OF MONEY EXPANDS BRISKLY
description: Money and credit continue to increase at historically high rates, data released by the Federal Reserve System showed yesterday.

title: JUSTIN MILLER, 84, LAW DEAN, IS DEAD
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 Justin Miller, a law dean who had served from 1945 to 1951 as president of the National Association of Broadcasters, died yesterday, it a convalescent hospital in Santa Monica. He was 84 years old.

title: 140 Say Israeli Citizenship Bars Their Return to Soviet
description: VIENNA, Jan. 18 (UPI)A news conference held here yesterday by the Israeli Minister of Immigration was disrupted by a group of 40 Russian Jews who said they wanted to return to the Soviet Union but could not because of their Israeli cite. izenship.

title: WILLIAM O'BRIEN, 65; ACCOUNTING PARTNER
description: William J. O'Brien, a founding partner of Alexander Grant & Co., an international company of certified public accountants, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital, Miami, of complications following heart surgery. He was 65 years old and lived at 2 Tudor City Place.

title: Clemente Plaza Proposed
description: A bill to name the Bronx Plaza, at the intersection of Third Avenue and 149th Street, the Bronx, as Roberto Clemente Plaza was introduced in the City Council yesterday by Councilman Barry Salmay. Clemente, the Pittsburgh Pirates' star, was killed in a plane crash off Puerto Rico last Dec. 31.

title: Rose's Fancy Footwork
description: Alex Rose is probably the only politician who could meet with Governor Rockefeller and talk about a mayoral campaign coalition and then, six days later, meet with the Governor's bitter enemy, Mayor. Lindsay, and talk about the same subject. The Liberal party leader's fancy footwork was still another demonstration of the political shrewdness that has made him the longest  reigning political leader in the state and permitted him to parlay his absolute control of a shrinking party into a major voice in the politics of the state and city for nearly 30 years.

title: SQUIRES SET BACK ROCKETS, 116110
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 18 (AP) Bernie Williams pushed the Virginia Squires in front and Julius Erving held off the Denver Rockets by hitting seven of eight free throws in the final 46 seconds to give the Squires a 116110 American Basketball Association victory tonight.

title: Brandt, Starting Second Term, Stresses Problems of Society
description: BONN, Jan. 18  Chancellor Willy Brandt went before Parliament today to deliver a gently worded declaration of policies for his second term that stressed what he described as the need for citizen initiatives to solve social problems.

title: U.S.Italian Extradition Pact Covering Hijackers Signed
description: ROME, Jan. 18  United States and Italian officials today signed a new extradition treaty that covers hijackers.

title: Metropolitan Reattributes 300 Paintings
description: The Odalisque, whose attribution the Metropolitan Museum has said will change from Ingres to a lesserknown artist, is only one of about 300 Old Master paintings that the institution has downgraded in a major reevaluation of its collection.

title: GemTheft Arrests
description: Three persons were arrested yesterday in the theft of jewels valued at more than $100,000 from a Brooklyn church. Details on Page 13.

title: 3 Held in Brooklyn ChurchJewel Theft
description: Three persons were arrested yesterday in the theft of jewels insured for $100,000 from church in Brooklyn on Jan. 10.

title: Goldwater and Stennis Tell Saigon Not to Balk
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Two of the Saigon Government's strongest supporters in the United. States Senate Barry Goldwater and John C. Stennisurged the Government today not to create obstacles to a peace agreement between the United States and North Vietnam.

title: 400 Layoffs Start Today At United Aircraft Plant
description: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 18 Some 400 employes at the Norden division of the United Aircraft Corporation here have been notified that they will be laid off starting tomorrow and continuing through the end of January.

title: Indiana Gelding to Lead Cavalry at the Inaugural
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Clock, a sleek, black gelding, will travel 700 miles to prance down some 20 blocks of Pennsylvania Avenue on Saturday. It will be his fifth consecutive inaugural parace, and he was brought out of retirement to do it.

title: PublicHousing Income Limit Is Raised
description: Higher income limits have been set for entry into public housing projects in the city in an effort to keep them from becoming economic and racial ghettos, Simeon Golar announced yesterday.

title: Action Along the Epidermis
description: LONDONIt is surprising how little notice has been taken of an example of ecological equilibrium that's right under our noses  literally.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: WITNESS IS SEIZED IN TRANSIT CASE
description: The disciplinary hearings of two suspended Transit Authority car inspectors charged with neglecting their duties were interrupted by the arrest of prosecution witness on charges of filing false documents and the near arrest of a general counsel for the authority.

title: LAIRD URGES PACT OH VIETNAM ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Secretary of Defense Melvir R. Laird called today for the negotiation of an agreement between the Soviet Union, China and the United States to hold down future deliveries ?? weapons to Vietnam.

title: Deadline for DetroitII
description: The best opinion among manufacturers, government and scientists alike is that the catalytic converter is at most a temporary solution to the problem of reducing pollution of the air by the automobile. Had there been less urgency, Congress might have given the companies until 1980 or so to produce a working alternative to the internal combustion engineand under that kind of direct pressure they might well have done so.

title: AMEX ENDS WEEK ON BEARISH NOTE
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished the week in a bearish manner yesterday as both lists declined in moderate trading.

title: J. C. HUTCHESON JR., HOUSTON JUDGE, DIES
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 19 (AP)Judge Joseph C. Hutcheson Jr. of United States District Court, first appointed to the Federal bench by President Wilson in 1918, died yesterday at the age of 93. He, was chief judge of the Fifth United States Circuit of Appeals from 1948 to 1959, and although he retired in 1964, he sat on the bench here as late as 1968.

title: Rat Threat Cited in Boston
description: BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP)A city official has asked Mayor Kevin H. White to approve contract for new doors to keep rats out of City Hall. In a letter to the Mayor, Anthony E. Forgione, assistant commissioner of the city's real property department, asked that steel doors be placed between City Hall and its loading dock, Rats in the area have apparently been displaced by demolition and restoration work in the historic Quincy Market behind City Hall.

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary offering of about 1,100,000 shares of ColgatePabriolive Co. common shares is being Completed by John P. Kendall and members of the Kendall family and various Kendall trusts. The shares are part of the 1,750,000 Colgate Shares received by the Kendall interests in the ColgateKendall merger that was completed last August. Colgate said the registration is expected to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in midFebruary. Colgate common closed at 95, down 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Handbook Tells How to Call for Action
description: A handbook with 276 pages of New York City telephone numbersranging from emergency services to bus information  will be appearing in bookstores here beginning late next week.

title: SECRET 1957 STUDY RELEASED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19An Administration review board has overruled the National Security Council and made public a 15year old top secret, highly controversial report that warned the Eisenhower Administration that it was not doing enough to protect the United States against possible Soviet nuclear attack.

title: Official Capital Events Listed for Inauguration
description: Following is a schedule of official inaugural events to be held in Washington:

title: Market in a Mild Retreat; I.B.M. and Energy List Up
description: International Business Machines and selected energy issues moved higher yesterday, while the general stock market staged a mild retreat.

title: Pentagon Paper Secrets Cited in Public Document
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19The Pentagon papers trial, in only the second day of testimony, went right to the heart today of the defense's legal position: that much of the material contained in the top secret papers had long been in the public domain.

title: Agnew Is on Top Now, But Faces a Hazy Future
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 When Spiro T. Agnew takes the oath of office tomorrow for his second term as Vice President of the United States, he will, understandably, be an object of envy.

title: Watergate Trial Is Told G.O.P. Got Wiretap Data
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Government's principal witness in the Watergate trial testified today that he had delivered information gleaned from an illegal wiretap to President Nixon's political organization.

title: Segal Sculptures on Display at Janis
description: There is a sense in which the sculpture of George Segal famous for its lifesize figures cast in white plaster from living modelshas become as immobilized as the frozen mannequins the artist uses. Over the years, the decorthe reallife settings in Which Mr. Segal customarily situates his figureshas begun to seem more important and, often, more interesting than the figures themselves.

title: Space Biologist Suing on MonkeyTest Libel
description: A $2million libel suit brought by the California scientist in charge of tests for the illfated space flight in 1969 of Bonny, a pigtailed monkey, goes to trial in Federal Court here Monday.

title: Pentagon Paper Secrets Cited in Public Document
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19The Pentagon papers trial, in only the second day of testimony, went right to the heart today of the defense's legal position: that much of the material contained in the top secret papers had long been in the public domain.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES.

title: MRS. WILLIAM M'GILL
description: Mrs. Edna Rankin McGill, mother of Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, died yesterday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 74 years old and lived at 2295 Andrews Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Pennsylvania Paper Sold
description: MEADVILLE, Pa., Jan. 19 (AP)The Tribune Publishing Company, publisher of The Meadville Tribune, has been acquired by Thomson Newspapers, it was announced yesterday. Details of the acquisition were not disclosed. The newspaper has a circulation of about 18,000.

title: Sports Today
description: Temple at St. John's, 8 P.M. (Radio WRVR, 8 P.M.); Iona at Seton Hall 2 P.M. (RadioWSOUFM, 2 P.M.); St. Peter's at Fordham, 2:30 P.M. (Radio  WFUVFM, 2:15 P.M.); Wagner at Fairleigh Dickinson, 8 P.M.; East Stroudsburg State at Montclair State, 8:15 P.M.; St. Bonaventure at L.I.U., 8 P.M.

title: Belgian Gas Stations Shut For the Weekend in Strike
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 19 (AP)The Belgian Government ordered all gasoline stations closed this weekend as the nation faced a worsening fuel crisis because of a weeklong strike by oilrefinery workers.

title: Friends of New Orleans Sniper Recall Bullying by Whites at Coast Navy Base
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 19Two years in the Navy, where he experienced racial bullying and harassment such as he had never known back home in Emporia, Kan., produced in Mark James Robert Essex a deep and festering hatred of white society.

title: Vengenance Law Opposed
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Jan. 19 (UPI)  State Representative Daniel Lyon, Democrat of Bernalillo, has introduced a bill into the New Mexico legislature to repeal a law that exonerates a man who kills another man he finds committing an adulterous act with the defendant's wife. The law, derived from English common law, is a statute in New Mexico, Utah and Texas. I don't think we should condone murder, Mr. Lyon said.

title: Hidden Fire Spots Detected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Firefighting apparatus that was patented this week detects hidden burning materials, such as hot ashes and coals, behind walls and partitions by sensing the direction and relative strength of radio waves given off by the hot spots. Norman E. Chasek, president of the International Microwave Corporation, Cos Cob, Conn., was granted Patent 3,711,845. The company has built prototype models of the detector and plans to let firemen try them out.

title: And If They Should Last 1,000 Years...
description: Good Grief! cried the headline in yesterday's Boston Globe.

title: Copiers Multiply Soviet Censors' Task
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 19In their unending battle against underground publishing, Soviet authorities are confronting a new foe: She modern copying machine. In some cases, Soviet intellectuals say, rigorous official methods to control it can be selfdefeating.

title: Olford Resigns as Pastor Of Calvary Baptist Church
description: The Rev. Dr. Stephen F. Olford has resigned as pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West 57th Street, after more than 13 years of service.

title: U.S. and Hanoi Release Photos of Private Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The United States and North Vietnam agreed today to make public here and in Hanoi a series of photographs and some motionpicture film taken at the last session of the private negotiations between Henry, A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho in Paris.

title: Rev. Edward Surtz Dies; A Thomas More Scholar
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UPI)The Rev. L. Surtz, a scholar of English Renaissance literature who taught at Loyola University, died yesterday after a bicycle accident while on vacation in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 63 years old.

title: S. SMITH STEVENS, PHYSICIST, WAS 66
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan,. 19  Dr. S. Smith Stevens, an authority on the physics of sensory perception, died today at Vail, Colo., where he had gone, to attend a conference on brain research. He was 66 years old. He leaves his wife, the former Geraldine Stone; a son, Peter, and three grandchildren.

title: 42 on Force Make Sergeant
description: Fortytwo partolmen were promoted to the rank of sergeant yesterday at a brief ceremony at the Police Academy, 235 East 20th Street.

title: Mrs. Meir Says Tension Marked Talk With Pope
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 19  The first Vatican meeting of a Pope and an Israeli Premier was not entirely comfortable and was marked by moments of tension, the Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, reported in an interview published today.

title: PETER BERDESHEVSKY
description: Peter Berdeshevsky, a sugar chemist and industrialist, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 39 East 12th Street. He was 78 years old.

title: Liguori Wins on 4:03.8 Mile In Comeback at Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19Marty Liguori returned to the track and field limelight tonight.

title: U.S. Output Rose in 1972 As Inflation Rate Slowed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The nation's total output, as measured by the Gross National Product, rose 6.5 per cent last year and inflation was at the lowest rate since 1966, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Open Interest
COLUMBIA TRIUMPHS OVER CORNELL, 6662
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 19Columbia fought off a cold spell early in tonight's basketball game and rallied to defeat Cornell, 6662.

title: Cynical Gesture
description: City Councilman Edward Sadowsky actually described the position of the Council majority in dubbing as a cynical political gesture Mayor Lindsay's fully warranted veto of an outrageous councilmanic reapportionment scheme. The cynicism, the politics and the gesture were all far more on the Council's side than on the Mayor's; and the Council proved the point by passing it over Mr. Lindsay's veto.

title: U.C.L.A. Rolls to No. 58
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (AP) U.C.L.A. moved another step toward college basketball's longest winning streak by routing the University of San Francisco, 9264, tonight. Bill Walton led the Bruins with 22 points and 22 rebounds as they coasted to their 58th consecutive victory, two short of the mark set by San Francisco.

title: CLYDE C. RUFFLE
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 19 Clyde C. Ruffle, general manager of environmental affairs for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 52.

title: Site of Siege Resembles WarTorn City
description: It was a scene that could have been set in a besieged city in wartimea police armored personnel carrier groaning down dark, rainswept streets, men with bulletproof vests and highpowered rifles running in halfcrouches from one parked police car to another, and a standoff confrontation involving desperate men and terrified hostages.

title: SHORT INTEREST OFF ON BIG BOARD
Policeman Dead, 2 lnjured As Robbers Hold Hostages
description: Four robbers trapped in a Brooklyn sporting goods store with an arsenal of weapons and 11 terrified hostages shot and killed a patrolman and wounded two others last night in a raging gun battle with hundreds of encircling policemen.

title: BRIDGE PLAYERS SUE OVER VICTORY CLAIM
description: Six Italian bridge experts who hold one world team title are suing the nonplaying captain of the Aces, an American group that holds the other world title, for $500,000.

title: Belfast Oldster's Advice to Young: Get Out
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 13The morning, boat from Scotland docks at Larne a few minutes after dawn and the passengers switch to the tiny shore train to Belfast.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In pounds sterling per metric ton)

title: Expensive Bag Is So Common Chic May Fade
description: At one count, Barbara Hutton had 55 pieces of Vuitton luggage. Marlene Dietrich flew into New York last month with 23 Vuitton cases that took an entire limousine to transport.

title: Suspects Sought in Capital Slayings of 7 Muslims
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The police were searching today for the slayers of seven persons, five of them children, who were killed executionstyle yesterday in an apparent feud between two sects of Muslims.

title: Nixon Takes Oath Today for 2d Term
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Nixon will be sworn into office for a second term tomorrow, emboldened by his sweeping electoral triumph of last November and a Vietnam peace settlement apparently within his grasp.

title: Last Round in Paris?
description: President Nixon's preinaugural announcement that Henry Kissinger will return to Paris Tuesday for the purpose of completing the text of an agreement once more raises hope that the end of the Indochina waror at least the end of. United States involvementis imminent.

title: Man Guilty in Slaying of Times Driver
description: Carmen Smith, who is charged with shooting and killing a part time driver for The New York Times in November, 1971 was convicted yesterday of firstdegree manslaughter and acquitted of a charge of murder.

title: Reginald B. Hegarty, 66, Whaling Historian, Is Dead
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP)Reginald B. Hegarty, a whaling historian, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 66 years old, and lived in Fairhaven.

title: NEWSPAPER DISPUTE WILL BE ARBITRATED
description: George E. McDonald, president of the New York Mailers Union, No. 6, said yesterday that a dispute over early termination of a threeyear contract with the city's four major daily newspapers would be submitted to arbitration.

title: PERU BOAT SEIZURES PROTESTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The United States has issued a protest to Peru in response to the recent series of seizures of American fishing vessels by Peruvian patrol boats, State Department officials said today.

title: Smith Upset, 64, 62, By Alexander in Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP)John Alexander of Australia stunned secondseeded Stan Smith with his strong serving and eliminated the Wimbledon champion from the $50,000 Saga Bay Tennis Classic tonight, 64, 62.

title: 29 YearOld Patrolman Is First To Die in Line of Duty This Year
description: Patrolman Stephen R. Gilroy, who was shot to death in the gun battle last night in Brooklyn, was the first policeman to be killed in the line of duty this year.

title: System of Plea Bargaining Appears Headed for Change, if Not Abolition
description: Plea bargaining. The Supreme Court says it is constitutional. Other courts, and prosecutors, say it is absolutely necessary. Defense lawyers Say it is often a boon to their clients.

title: 300 Attend Rites for Black Man Killed by Policeman
description: BASKING RIDGE, Jan. 19With quiet dignity, a troubled community paid its final respects today to William Wells, a 21yearold black man who was killed by a policeman's bullet in Bernardsville last Saturday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Frazier Says He'll Stop Foreman

title: ALCOA REPORTS BIG PROFIT RISE
description: The world's largest aluminum company, the Aluminum Company of America, reported yesterday new highs in sales, operating revenues and shipments in 1972. The number two producer, Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., showed higher sales anti net income for the year but not at record levels.

title: Nixon Aides Criticized, By Defense Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)  Melvin R. Laird, the outgoing Secretary of Defense, criticized some of Presdent Nixon's aides today for the way the changeover in Administration officials was conducted.

title: Adjusts Paper Formula
description: The First National City Bank, again bowing to pressure from Washington, announced yesterday, a further modification in its base, or prime, lending rate.

title: Max Adrian, 69, British Actor Of Stage and Movies, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP)Max Adrian, a versatile British actor who had appeared on the stage, in films and on television here and in the United States, died this evening. He was 69 years old.

title: A Time to Begin
description: America is a nation in need of healing. There is deep disagreement as to whether the Vietnam war was necessary and honorable enterprise or a moral catastrophe. But there is no dispute that the psychic wounds which the war has inflicted on this large mighty nation are surpassed in pain and lasting significance only by the wounds which the war has imposed on a small weak nation half the globe away.

title: Tape of $14,500 Alleged Bribe Is Played at Prosecutor's Trial
description: An agent's voice was heard counting out $14,500 for alleged fixers on a tape recording played yesterday at the bribery trial of a Queens prosecutor, a lawyer and a bail bondsman's associate.

title: Thai Chief Fears, Drive on Border After Accord
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 19 (UPI)Premier Thanom. Kittikachorn said tonight that a ceasefire could be extended to Laos and Cambodia about 10 days after it goes into effect in South Vietnam.

title: Policeman Killed, 2 Wounded in Siege In Brooklyn as Robbers Hold Hostages
description: Four robbers trapped in Brooklyn sporting goods store with an arsenal of weapons and 11 terrified hostages shot and killed a patrolman and wounded two others last night in a raging gun battle with hundreds of encircling policemen.

title: Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address
description: A concert work using the text of President Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address was dropped from the official program of President Nixon's Second Inaugural because the Inaugural Committee reportedly considered the words embarrassing in today's context. The full text of the address delivered by President Lincoln at his Second inaugural on March 4, 1865, follows:

title: AUBREY N. HEFLIN
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 19Aubrey N. Heflin, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond since 1968, died on Tuesday evening at his home here. He was 60 years old.

title: Truck Curb and GasTax Rise Planned to Aid London Traffic
description: LONDON, Jan. 19Two plans to ease traffic conges tion in London were announced this week.

title: A City Project Offers Fiscal Training to Minorities
description: My father's dream, said Gilberte Torres the other night, was to become a certified public accountant.

title: CHANNEL 13 GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: John Jay Iselin will be named acting president of television Channel 13 to succeed James Day, who resigned as president Thursday, citing irreconcilable differences with the television station's board chairman, Ethen Allen Hitchcock.

title: OTTO HAGEL IS DEAD; A PHOTOGRAPHER, 63
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., Jan. 19 Otto Hagel, a freelance photographer whose work appeared in many magazines including Life, Time, Fortune and the Ladies Home Journal, died yesterday at the Kaiser Memorial Hospital in. Terra Linda after having suffered a stroke last Sunday. He was 63 years old and had lived here for more than 30 years.

title: Thrusts by Saigon Troops To Gain Ground Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 20South Vietnamese troops have begun series of offensive thrusts on several fronts, apparently in an attempt to improve their positions before a ceasefire goes into effect, it was reported yesterday.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Barcelona Angry and Fearful Over the Use of Natural Gas
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Jan. 19 Several hundred thousand residents of Spain's second biggek city are alternating between panic and rebellion following the death of 33 persons in the last 10 months in explosions attributed to natural gas.

title: GOING OUT Giode
description: ETHNIC The Sephardic Jews, who hail originally from Iberia (and some, from the Middle East and North Africa, too) are the oldest Jewish community in the United Statesthe first arrived in our town in 1654, when it was still Dutch Nieuw Amsterdam.

title: Music: A Concert Fuss
description: Aside from musicians of the Boston Symphony playing in opennecked colored shirts, aside from the spectacle of six pianos lined up in front of the stage and played by as many pianists, aside from, a lively demonstration from the audience pro and con a new piece by Steve Reich, it was a normal evening in Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

title: $145,657 TAX BILL FOR JAILED MAYOR
description: JERSEY City, Jan. 19  The Internal Revenue Service filed a $145,657 tax lien today against John Armellino, former Mayor of West New York, who is serving a fouryear jail term for briberyconspiracy.

title: ExFordham Chancellor to Guide Ramapo Tutoring
description: MAHWAH, Jan. 19Two and a half years after having left the chancellorship of Fordham University to work with educationally deprived students at a small black college in North Carolina, the Rev. Leo McLaughlin is off on a new academic adventure.

title: Corona Jurors Deny Pressure Was Applied to Last Holdout
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 19The jury of 10 men and two women that yesterday convicted Juan V. Corona, a 38yearold Mexican national, of murdering 25 itinerant farm workers kept the trial in the limelight today by disputing the contention of the last holdout juror that she had been pressured to change her mind.

title: O'Neill of the House: A Majority Leader's Perspective
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19I think the day has passed of a Sam Rayburn glaring down the House. We'll never go back to that era.

title: GEN. HAIG RETURNS TO SAIGON TO MEET WITH THIEU AGAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 20Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. returned to Saigon this morning in a further effort to work out several remaining differences with President Nguyen Van Thieu on putting into effect a draft peace accord.

title: A Strange Celebration
