description: LONDON, Jan. 19  Twelve years agoit feels like twentyJohn Kennedy stood on the steps of the Capitol and said: We observe today not a victory of party but a celebration of freedom.

title: Wachovia Increased Its Operating Net In Quarter and 1972
description: The Wachovia Corporation, a onebank holding company based in WinstonSalem, N.C., and parent of the Wachovia Bank and Trust Company, reported yesterday that its operating earnings in 1972 increased 6.4 per cent to $31.6million, or $2.17 per share, from $29.8million, or $2.04 per share for 1971.

title: LILCO HALTS GAS TO 250 CONCERNS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 19All natural gas supplied by the Long Island Lighting Company to 250 of its largest industrial customers has been turned off since last Nov. 1, the longest such period in the history of the company, sources there disclosed today.

title: An Envied Agnew Is Facing Hazy Future
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 When Spiro T. Agnew takes the oath of office tomorrow for his second term as Vice President of the United States, he will, understandably, be an object of envy.

title: Phil King, ExGiant Back, Killed in a Gun Accident
description: Phil King, a running back for the New York Giants during their glory years from 1958 through 1963 when the team won five Eastern Division titles in the National Football League, died in Memphis Thursday of what was reported as an accidental gunshot wound in the head.

title: L. I. R. R. Union Urges Courtesy to Riders
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Jan. 19 The head of the union that includes Long Island Rail Road conductors and trainmen told them here today to be prepared to bear the brunt of the irate commuters when the railroad resumes full service Monday.

title: TEXTRON'S BOARD BACKS A MERGER
description: Textron, Inc., announced yesterday that its directors had approved the acquisition of the Security Corporation of Hartford, the parent company of six fire and casualty insurance companies.

title: Murder Trial Ordered
description: DETROIT, Jan, 19 (UPI)Hayward Brown, 18 years old, was ordered yesterday to stand trial on four counts of assault with intent to commit murder in the Dec. 4 street shootout with the police in which four officers were wounded.

title: U.S. Hopeful That Talks On Troop Cuts Are Near
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The State Department said today that it remained hopeful that EastWest talks preparatory to a conference on troop cuts in Europe could start on Jan. 31 despite differences on where the talks should take place and who should participate.

title: Mrs. Meir Says Tension Marked Talk With Pope
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 19  The first Vatican meeting of a Pope and an Israeli Premier was not entirely comfortable and was marked by moments of tension, the Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, reported in an interview published today.

title: COLETTE BOKY SINGS MARGUERITE AT MET
description: Colette Boky's Marguerite in the Metropolitan Opera's Faust Wednesday night was a game, workwomanlike job. Her soprano is neither rich enough to make a strong impression in the part's lyrical sections nor crisp enough for the more brilliant moments, and she had to strain to encompass the big spinto outbursts. But she does have a feeling for the language and the style, and her singing and acting reveal both conscientiousness and, at times, a certain pale charm.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: TV: 2 Reruns Prove to Be a Blessing
description: Television reruns can be a blessing when the programs are like And the Rich Shall Inherit the Earth and Bighorn! shown earlier in the week.

title: WAR IS PROTESTED ON INAUGURAL EVE
description: Acknowledging that they were tired and battered, antiwar protesters held preinauglural demonstrations here yesterday at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church and at several hospitals and nursing homes.

title: RHODESIAN BLACKS FACE STIFF CURBS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 19The Government published new state of emergency regulations today that allow white provincial commissioners to impose collective fines on African communities without court hearings, or listening to arguments from those affected.

title: Douglas Clarke, an Editor Of Middletown Newspaper
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 19 (AP)Douglas V. Clarke, Sunday editor of The Middletown Times HeraldRecord, who was jailed briefly in 1948 for refusing to give information to an Orange County grand jury, died, apparently of a heart attack, at the newspaper offices, today. He was 57 years old.

title: WOOLWORTH TO BUY GATEWAY INVENTORY
description: The Gateway Sporting Goods Company, a retailer of recreational goods in Kansas City, Mo., said yesterday that the F. W. Woolworth Company had agreed to buy the Gateway inventory in 88 Woolco department stores operated by Woolworth.

title: World Bank Signs a Pact To Issue Bonds in Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (Reuters)The World Bank said today it had signed an agreement in Beirut for the issue of the banks bonds in Lebanon. This is the first offering of its bonds in this country, the bank said.

title: GUNMAN TAKES OVER A PLANE AT AIRPORT
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 19 (UPI)A young man fired at least 20 rounds from a shotgun in the crowded terminal at Standiford Field Airport tonight and then commandeered an Ozark Airlines' DC9 jetliner, holding a mechanic hostage. The gunman demanded a pilot to fly him to an undetermined destination.

title: Antiques Show Gathers. Wares and Buyers
description: The country's most prestigious secondhandgoods bazaar, stocking wares from New England barns, imperial Chinese palaces and just about everything in between, opened yesterday for a 10day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: A Murder Points Up Grim Life In Morningside Ave. Tenement
description: They didn't have to stab hershe was 80 years old and they just could have pushed her down and done anything they wanted, said Mrs. Irma Hastings yesterday as she sat in the Harlem apartment that she and two other persons shared with Mrs. Harriet DeBerry.

title: Committee Posts Please Area's House Freshmen
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Freshman Republican Representatives from the New York metropolitan area generally fared well in the House committee assignmenth handed out this week. As the Republican conference of House members ratified the committee assignments yesterday, state ments began Metropolitan flowing from the freshmen's offices, expressing pleasure at their posts and stressing that their districts can be helped by legislation handled by their new committees.

title: Net Off, Milwaukee Road Votes to Omit a Dividend
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (Reuters) Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad voted today to omit the dividend on its series A preferred stock.

title: Yanks' Lyle Tears Ligament in Ankle Playing Basketball
description: Sparky Lyle, the Yankees' most valuable player last season, has suffered a torn ligament in his right ankle while playing basketball, the team learned yesterday.

title: Illinois Central Industries Will Raise Capital Outlays
description: Illinois Central Industries, Inc., announced plans to spend $128.8million this year on capital improvements, compared with $91.4million in 1972.

title: The Dance: A Balanced Evening With Serenade
description: Because New York City Ballet seems always with us it is easy to take it for granted. Easy but unjust. Almost any night taken at random  and with its almost traditional program switches and lack of casting information the company often does have to be taken at random  is a superb and balanced evening of dance.

title: BRITISH TUG TO AID BOATS OFF ICELAND
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP)The British Government ordered fast oceangoing tug to head for Iceland today to protect British trawlers inside Iceland's disputed 50mile fishing limit.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Second Part of Whitney Show Opens
description: The second installment of the new biennial exhibition of American art at the Whitney Museum, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, opened to the public this week, and already shows ample evidence of being an exhibition of exceptional interest. Still to come  next week  is the third and final installment of the show that, when complete, will fill all five exhibition floors of the museum.

title: WINE TALK
description: The Chevaliers du Tastevin, the most famous of the wine societies, held their big dinner at the Plaza this week and most of the 282 guests came away convinced it had been a pretty good feed. Of course they were emotionally involved: the meal cost $65 a head.

title: Chou Is Reported to Predict CeaseFire Will Come Soon
description: TOKYO, Jan. 19 (UPI)The Chinese Premier, Chou Enlai, said last night that a ceasefire would be declared soon in Vietnam, dispatches from Japanese newsmen in Peking reported today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Rev. Dr. Erich Voehringer, Missionary and Author, Dies
description: KEMPTON, Pa., Jan. 19 The Rev. Dr. Erich F. Voehringer, retired missionary, author and pastor of Grace and St. Paul's Lutheran Church at 123 West 71st Street in New York from 1940 to 1943, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Redding Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: The New Inequality
description: LONDONTo most of us it now seems very strange, almost incomprehensible, that for centuries gross hereditary inequalities of wealth, status and power were universally accepted as a divinely ordained fact of life. The lord in his castle, like the peasant at his gate, both believed that this was where God wished them to remain. If anybody had then suggested that such an arrangement was manifestly unfair he would have been dismissed as a little crazed, not to say blasphemous.

title: 2d U.S. Pilot Accused of Refusing to Raid North
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)The Air Force disclosed today that a second pilot has been charged with refusing to fly a combat mission against North Vietnam during the heavy bombing campaign last month.

title: LAIRD URGES PACT ON VIETNAM ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird called today for the negotiation of an agreement between the Soviet Union, China and the United States to hold down future deliveries of weapons to Vietnam.

title: Ohio State Coach in Hospital
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 19 (UPI)The Ohio State basketball coach, Fred Taylor, was admitted to Riverside Hospital late this afternoon after complaining of chest pains. Doctors said the 48yearold Taylor had not suffered a heart attack, but would be kept indefinitely for observation.

title: The A.T. & T. Bias Settlement Confuses and Angers Workers
description: Telephone company workers reacted with expressions of confusion, anger and considerable skepticism yesterday to news that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had agreed to give back pay and raised to minoritygroup and women employes against whom it allegedly discriminated.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI)Premier Gerald Regan of Nova Scotia said today the American decision to impose duties on imports of Canadianmade Michelin tires would be selfdefeating.

title: Thieu's Daughter, 19, Weds Son of Airline Official
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 (AP)President Nguyen Van Thieu's only daughter married the son of wealthy airline executive today in South Vietnam's most lavish social event of recent years.

title: EUGENE L. WYMAN, LAWYER, 47, DIES
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 19Eugene L. Wyman, a prominent fund raiser for the Democratic party, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his law office here today. He was 47 years old.

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the net asset value of a closedend investment fund's shares as reported by the companies through The Association of ClosedEnd Investment Companies at the close of business Friday.

title: $81,000 PAYMENT CITED IN TAX CASE
description: NEWARK, Jan. 19Eugene G. Rau, chairman of J. Rich Steers, Inc., testified today that $81,000 of the $106,000 the construction company paid for assistance in getting a $10.6million contract with the New Jersey Turnpike Authority had gone to former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none.)

title: TEXTRON'S BOARD BACKS A MERGER
description: Textron, Inc., announced yesterday that its directors had approved the acquisition of the Security Corporation of Hartford, the parent company of six fire and casualty insurance companies.

title: Rhodesia to Impose Stiff Fines On Blacks Helping Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 19The Government published new state of emergency regulations today that allow white provincial commissioners to impose collective fines on African communities without court hearings, or listening to arguments from those affected.

title: Alliance for Progress Arrives at Film Forum
description: Alliance for Progress, a fictional radical political film, opened yesterday at the Film Forum. Its director, a 27yearold Argentine named Julio Luduena, has described his approach, and I think he is worth quoting, in part:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A handbook with 276 pages of telephone numbers for city agencies, consumer information, business advice and more than 600 other categories will be appearing in bookstores next week. It has been put out by radio station WMCA's Call for Action based on its 10 years of directing people with problems to the place where they can be taken care of.

title: Trade Liberalization Seen By Former E.E.C. Official
description: The enlargement of the Common Market has given that body new power in international trade relations, Jean Rey, former president of the Comniission of the European Community, said here yesterday. But the expanded market, he added, also has increased responsibilities.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: RICHARD DEMMERLE, AN AD EXECUTIVE, 53
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Jan. 19Richard L. Demmerle, a publicrelations, advertising and personnel executive, died today at the Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown of injuries suffered in a fall in his home here Monday. He was 53 years old.

title: Art: Great Pots, Each and Every One
description: Pot is one of a number of words that have suffered from adoption into the lingo of the drugandsex culture, although for most people it never was more than the designation of a humble household vessel anyway. But pot has reverential associations for ceramists, who also use it as a kind of password. Talk to a ceramist about ceramics and you're just another outsider, no matter how knowledgeable you may be, but refer to pots in a way that indicates your sensitivity to the best of them, and you're in.

title: Dutch to Lower Flag
description: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 19 (Reuters)The Dutch flag on the 1945 war liberation monument outside City Hall will be flown at half mast for 15 minutes a day until hostilities end in Vietnam, The Hague City Council has voted.

title: People and Business
description: Because of the efforts of Prof. Margaret K. Chandler and 13 students at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, the Columbia Journal of World Business is staying in business. The periodical, which has a circulation of 3,000, was scheduled to be eliminated as a result of the university's austerity program, but the students came up with a way to save it.

title: Nixon Takes Oath Today for 2d Term
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Nixon will be sworn into office for a second term tomorrow, emboldened by his sweeping electoral triumph of last November and a Vietnam peace settlement apparently within his grasp.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Instead of believing it, most people seem to be trying to pretend that 170 must be a typographical error. Instead of accepting the Miami Dolphins' achievement, they're waiting for a correction. Outside of the loyalists in Miami, most people don't seem willing to acknowledge that the Dolphins are the best team in National Football League history. Nick Buoniconti has a theory.

title: KNICKS DEFEATED BY LAKERS, 9588
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19That late game magic so characteristic of the New York Knicka, recently didn't quite come off tonight, but the New Yorkers got closd enough to threaten in a 9588 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers, which ended New York's 11game winning streak.

title: Antiques: On Exhibiting
description: In the postWorld War II days before superhighways and jet travel spurred the growth in size and numbers of antiques shows, a good percentage of the vintage wares sold were ordered by mail. Country shops catered to Sunday drivers who stopped by for a cup of tea and left, warmed by the brew, poorer by a dollat or two and clutching a pedigreed piece of crockery. Dealers, their stocks depleted of foreign antiques after four years of war, survived on whatever they could scrounge in the market place to supplement all those doubleglobe, GoneWiththeWind, roseembellished lamps abundance.

title: Technical Aides at Paris Talks Hold Briefest Session
description: PARIS, Jan. 19  United States and North Vietnamese experts working on details of the proposed agreement for a Vietnam ceasefire met today for four and a half hours, in one of the shortest of their series of almost daily meetings since the beginning of the month.

title: Nets Edge Tams, 107106, As Carter Hits on Layup
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 19A driving layup by George Carter with 22 seconds remaining tonight put the Nets in a celebrating mood for they beat the Memphis Tams, 107106, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: People in Sports: Haller, Phillies Catcher, Retires
description: The fact that he has been traded three times in the last five years has made an unfavorable impression on the mind of Tom Haller, a 35yearold catcher. When they start shuffling you around like that, it's management's way of telling you that you are getting old, he said yesterday in San Mateo, Calif. I've got a lot out of baseball and so maybe it's time to quit and think about other things. Haller, who most recently was sent from the Detroit Tigers to the Philadelphia Phillies, said he would not report to the Phils' training camp in Florida next month. He will devote all his time to an insurance business in San Mateo. He started his major league career with the Giants in San Francisco in 1962, was traded after the 1967 season to Los Angeles and then went to Detroit for the 1972 season. I'm leaving with no regrets, said Haller. The only sad thing about baseball is that once you are done as a player, there are not too many opportunities to stay in the game.

title: Music: Country Style
description: New York is hardly a countrymusic city. Soul music, Latin music, rock, folk and jazz survive and coexist, but the city has been strangely reluctant to accept this major branch of popular music. Unlike most large American cities, for instance, New York has no radio station devoted to broadcasting country music. Occasional clubs or bars that open with music devoted to the Nashville arts either close quickly or turn to the topless.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Department of Labor and Industry said yesterday that it was laying off 100 temporary and parttime clerical employes because of cutbacks in Federal funds. Labor Commissioner Ronald M. Heymann said: We very much regret the necessity of these layoffs. But the action of the Federal office of Management and Budget in Washington has left no choice.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JANUARY 20, 1973
description: Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's emissary, returned to Saigon this morning in a further effort to work out several remaining differences with President Nguyen Van Thieu on implementing a draft peace accord. Arriving from Bangkok, General Haig went directly to the American Embassy and was expected to confer with President Thieu later in the day. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: U.S. Output Rose in 1972 As Inflation Rate Slowed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The nation's total output, as measured by the Gross National Product, rose 6.5 per cent last year and inflation was at the lowest rate since 1966, the commerce Department reported today.

title: Met Appears to Have Traded More Than It Got
description: An inquiry into the art swap between the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Marlborough galleries has uncovered curious legal and commercial problems.

title: Director of Nixon Inauguration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19A student at Curtis High School in Staten Island named Jeb Magruder approached his faculty adviser's office prepared for a scolding. He knew exactly what to do. As soon as he walked into the room, he started talking and drew the teacher, into a long and presumably fascinating conversation. She forgot all about the reprimand. That was more than 20 years ago. The schoolboy is today the director of President Nixon's inauguration, and by all accounts still charming people with a personal style as smooth as melted ice cream.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: BUSH NOW HEADS G.O.P. COMMITTEE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 George Bush, a Connecticut aristocrat who became a Texas oil millionaire, took the reins of the Republican party organization today in an unchallenged but sometimes uncheerful transition.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Dr. Bennington P. Gill, 74, Dies; City College Curriculum Expert
description: Dr. Bennington P. Gill, professor emeritus of mathematics at City College and a leader in curriculum development, died Wednesday in the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Demarest, N.J.

title: Notes on People
description: Paul O'Dwyer, the former City Councilman and brother of the late Mayor William O'Dwyer, said he would formally announce his candidacy for President of the Council in the next few weeks. The 65yearold lawyer whose recent clients include the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, the antiwar activist, said he would run unaffiliated with any of the Democratic party's candidates for the Mayoral nomination, of whom there are expected to be at least a dozen this year. Mr. O'Dwyer, whose pugnacity in party affairs has often nettled New York Democratic leaders, has lost more elections than he has won over the years. But thus far in his new campaign, he said, his chief problem has been renting campaign headquarters space at a reasonable price. He finally found a place, at 14th Street and Fifth Avenue, for $1,000 a month.

title: Briefs on The Arts
description: A projected Brooklyn shopping and entertainment center and a public gardens in Oklahoma City were each given first awards for design last night by Progressive Architecture magazine at a dinner at the Institute for International Education.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REACH NEW HIGHS.
description: The January soybean futures contract rose to another record yesterday of $5 a bushel. The new high compared with Thursday's record of $4.69.

title: Duvillard Takes Giant Slalom For First Cup Victory in Year
description: MEGEVE, France, Jan. 19 (AP)Henri Duvillard, accused in the French press of choking up, cracked a yearlong losing streak today by winning the giant slalom in the Grand Prix de Megeve skiing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 16yearold boy was indicted yesterday for murder and attempted robbery in connection with the fatal stabbing of a retired policeman in a subway station in the Time Square area. The boy, Kevin McDow, of 215 West 135th Street, is scheduled to be arraigned Monday, according to a spokesman for the District Attorney's office.

title: TOKYO REPAYMENT TO U.S. WELCOMED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (Reuters)The United States Treasury today welcomed Tokyo's announced intention to repay earlier than required aid advanced to Japan in the immediate postwar years.

title: Books of The Times
description: YOU AND YOUR PENSION. By Ralph Nader and Kate Blackwell. 215 pages. Grossman. $4.95 cloth; $1.95 paper.

title: Britain Cuts Interest
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Bank of England reduced today its minimumlending rate which had been Britain's highest since the outbreak of World War I in August, 1914.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: January 19, 1973

title: Sharp Increase in Profit Reported by Caterpillar
INDUSTRY PRICES RISING IN PHASE 3
description: Prices began to move up this week in a variety of industries following the loosening of economic controls nine days ago by the Nixon Administration.

title: Grain Disclosure Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) Legislation to require fuller flisclosure of Government plans for future big grain deals with foreign trading partners has been introduced by Senator Henry Bellmon, Republican of Oklahoma.

title: Phil King ExGiant Back, Killed in a Gun Accident
description: Phil King, a running back for the New York Giants during their glory years from 1958 through 4963 when the team won five Eastern Division titles in the National Football League, died in Memphis Thursday of what was reported as an accidental gunshot wound in the head.

title: Rangers, With Villemure, Down Golden Seals 60
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 19Gillis Villemure, in the Rangers' goal for the first time since Dec., 27, notched his first shutout of the National Hockey League sason tonight as New York beat the California Golden Seals, 60.

title: LATE GOAL HELPS BLUES WIN, 2 TO 1
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 19 (AP)Gary Sabourin scored late in the third period to snap a 11 tie as the St. Louis Blues took a 21 National Hockey League victory from the Atlanta Flames tonight.

title: CELTICS TROUNCE SONICS BY 124104
description: BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP)John Havlicek scored 18 points in the first six minutes of the final period and the Boston Celtics pulled away to their eighth consecutive National Basketball Association victory tonight, beating the Seattle SuperSonics, 124104.

title: Concerts Reflect Moods Of Divided Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The differing moods of this inaugural eve could be heard in the sound of music tonight, with an official concert featuring the triumpliant, cannon of Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture at the John F. Kennedy Center, and the drumrolls of Haydn's, Mass in Time of War at the Washington Cathedral.

title: BLACKS FOR NIXON FORM G.O.P. GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Black officials in the Administration and other black supporters of President Nixon, in town for the inauguration, have formed a national organization of black Republicans.

title: Records: By Cole Porter
description: Like most prolific songwriters, Cole Porter left behind a great deal of unpublished, publicly unheard work, when he died. But unlike the unpublished work of some of his peers who wrote only musicnotably Jerome Kern and George Gershwinwhich remains unheard, Porter's unpublished songs can be readily disseminated because he wrote both words and music. The songs are complete. All you have to do is sing them. Which is precisely what is done on Unpublished Cole Porter (Painted Smiles, $4:98), a collection of 15 Cole Porter songs that you've never heard before.

title: Soviet Union's Lunokhod Finds Younger Moon Soil
description: MOSCOW, June 19 (UPI) Soviet ground controllers maneuvered the Lunokhod 2 moon robot along the moon's sea of Serenity and made soil tests showing that it is a relatively young area of the lunar surface the news agency Tass said today.

title: HARRELSON TAKES SLIGHT CUT IN PAY
description: Bud Harrelson and Jon Matlack both had harrowing experiences this winter: Harrelson shot the rapids of the Clorado River and Matlack hung wallpaper in his new house in Westchester County.

title: New York Tech Five Wins
description: Carl Curtiss scored 14 points and had seven assists and three steals to lead New York Tech to a 7064 basketball victory over York College last night at Queensborough Community College.

title: Barrie Beere, a Publisher And Radio Producer, Dies
description: Barrie L. Beere, a publisher and radio producer, died Thursday in an automobile accident near San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. He was 43 years old and lived in Mexico and at 121A East 94th Street.

title: GEN. HAIG RETURNS TO SAIGON TO MEET WITH THIEU AGAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 20Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. returned to Saigon this morning in a further effort to work out several remaining differences with President Nguyen Van Thieu on putting into effect a draft peace accord.

title: INCREASE PLANNED IN CROP PLANTINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Farmers intend to plant 7 per cent more corn and 5 per cent more soybeans for harvest this year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: NEW CABBIES TO GET HIGHER COMMISSIONS
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Commission, acting as an arbitrator, awarded higher commissions for new taxi drivers yesterday in settling the final terms of a longdelayed contract between 70 fleet owners here and their 30,000 drivers.

title: Jack Crawford, ExStar Of National Hockey League
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP)  Jack Crawford, former allstar defenseman with the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League, died today at Cape Cod Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: Bridge: 16 Teams Begin Play Today In Grand National's 2d Stage
description: Sixteen of New York's best bridge teams begin two days of knockout play at the New York Hilton Hotel today in the second stage of a new event, the Grand National. The eventual New York champions will compete in a zonal playoff that leads to a national final in Washington.

title: I.B.M. Says Telex Step Is Without Foundation
description: A spokesman for the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that I.B.M. considered the Telex Corporation's motion to set aside the settlement of Control Data Corporation's antitrust suit against I.B.M. to be without foundation.

title: MRS. NEIL RENARD
description: Mrs. Dorothy Rogovin Renard, an associate of D.T.A. Publicity, a fashion and cosmetics public relations concern, died, apparently of a heart attack, at her home, 110 Riverside Drive, on Thursday. She was 52 years old.

title: Emergency Merger of Banks Is Permitted by State Board
description: Harry W. Albright Jr., New York State Superintendent of Banks, invoked emergency provisions of the state banking law yesterday to approve the merger of the troubled $141  million Jefferson Savings Bank in upstate Watertown with the much larger Community Savings Bank of Rochester. The merger also requires Federal approval.

title: White House Aide Is Chosen by Nixon To Be F.T.C. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (Reuters)  President Nixon named Lewis A. Engman, White House aide, to the Federal Trade Commission today and said that he would appoint him F.T.C. chairman when the Senate confirmed his nomination.

title: NICHOLS, ARCHER SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 19 (AP)  Bobby Nichols and George Archer, former national teamplay champions and longtime fourball partners, tied for the secondround lead today in the $150,000 Dean MartinTucson open golf tournament.

title: Kissinger and Mitchells Enliven a Party
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ford 2d did their best to add a little excitement to the inaugural celebration and, in their way, they succeeded. They managed to have Henry A. Kissinger and Martha Mitchell in the same room at the same time kissing each other.

title: CURB ON PRESS HELD ILLEGAL IN SRI LANKA
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Jan. 19The speaker of this nation's House of Representatives ruled today that a bill to control the press of Sri Lanka was unconstitutional.

title: Times Sq. Bookstores Sue City And Landlords for Harassment
description: Five present or former operators of sexoriented bookstores and coin  operated adult movies in the Times Square area have filed a $4million damage suit charging their landlords and the city with a conspiracy to put them out of business.

title: 200Mile Fishing Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)  Representative William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, says he is introducing a bill to extend the United States fishing boundary from the present 12mile limit to 200 miles offshore.

title: AGED SAID TO LACK MEDICAL SERVICE
description: NEWARK, Jan. 19  An unusual medical screening of 211 elderly residents of the inner city, undertaken by Beth Israel Hospital and an Army Reserve unit, has found that only three of the 211 were without medical problems.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., Jan. 19Asbury Park residents won't stare in disbelief when more than 200 distance runners troop down Ocean Avenue tomorrow morning at the start of the second annual Jersey Shore Marathon Run.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Bazaar de la Cuisine, at 1003 Second Avenue (53d Street), is one of those shops that leaves you convinced, after a few minutes of looking around, that your kitchen is ridiculously underequipped.

title: Inaugural Message
description: In his second inaugural address, President Nixon has pledged himself to carry forward the dominant themes of his first Administration. In foreign affairs, he restated his now familiar beliefs on America's more restricted world role. In domestic affairs, he seeks in more pronounced fashion not only to maintain a conservative policy but also to reverse the steady expansion of the Federal Government's activities.

title: War Scored by Thousands In Protests in the Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20As official Washington celebrated the rites of inauguration, thousands of dissenters demonstrated with marches, speeches, placards and rallies. They were generally orderly protests marked by minor scuffles and a few arrests.

title: SCRIBNER IS ASKED TO TARE VACATION
description: The Board of Education has asked School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner to take a threeMonth vacation starting April 1, in a new, move to bring about his departure from office before his threeyear, contract expires on June 30.

title: Casanova, Con Man
description: We have apparently become bored with the image of Casanova as a great lover. In these pornographic times the great lover has become a cultural antique, like the fabulous drinker of Damon Runyon vintage. Maybe that is why Casanova's factory of My Life, one of the great books of the 18th century and one of the greatest memoirs ever written, has nearly disappeared from view at the very moment it can at last be read in an excellent new translation. A year ago Willard Trask finished the labor of a decade and gave us the final volumes of Casanova's memoirs. Trask's edition (published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich in 12 volumes, $60) was an event in the history of Casanova scholarship. It made available in English for the first time an undoctored version of the text, which had previously existed only in a euphemized version dating from the early 19th century.

title: Shots Punctuate Long Anxious Night As Police Surround Besieged Store
description: It began a little before 6 P.M. on Friday. Four youngmen walked into John & Al Sports Inc. in Brooklyn, and for a few minutes, at least, appeared to be nothing more than customers. Then, nearly simultaneously, they drew guns.

title: PACERS TRIUMPH FOR 5TH STRAIGHT
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 20 (AP) The Indiana Pacers won their fifth straight American Basketball Association game tonight with a 121110 victory over the Virginia Squires.

title: Lefty Gomez Is Chairman
description: MONROE, N. C., Jan. 20 (UPI)Lefty Gomez, a Hall of Fame pitcher, was elected today as chairman of the board of Babe Ruth Baseball International. The election was conducted by the group's board of directors.

title: Those Colorful White Sales
description: January is the month of white sales, though each year the event becomes less white and more colorful with the expanded offering of printed sheets and pillowcases, towels and bedspreads.

title: Numismatics
description: YESTERDAY'S Presidential inauguration renews interest in a rather exclusive numismatic specialtythe collecting of official inaugural medals. It may also usher in a new eraone of unprecedented abundance: More different kinds and greater quantities of medals have been prepared for this inauguration than for any other since the turn of the century. When results of the ongoing nationwide merchandising drive are tallied, it is probable that more people will own a medallic memento of this inaugural than all the others combined.

title: Columbia Wrestlers Beat Cornell on Waller's Victory
description: John Waller scored an 8to3 decision over Mike Olander yesterday in the heavyweight bout to lead Columbia to a 2018 Ivy League wrestling victory over Cornell at University Gym.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: ONCE again the male chauvinist piggishness of the nation's television program directors has destroyed an American family holiday season. Christmas Eve and again New Year's Eve and New Year's Day, the husbands of the United States spent their time in front of their TV screens watching endless hours of football, while American housewives were relegated to the roles of bar maids, sandwich makers, ashtray emptiers and children shushers. (Not to mention timing the family roast so that it was ready between halves.)

title: Mooney Scores an Upset Triumph in Pro Giant Slalom at Hunter Mountain
description: HUNTER, N. Y., Jan. 20None of the three ranking favorites  Harald Stuefer of Austria, JeanClaude Killy of France and Spider Sabich of Snowmass, Colo.was around at the finish today at the fourth Benson & Hedges 100's Grand Prix professional giant slalom races at windy Hunter Mountain.

title: Peter Brook's Birds Fly to Africa
description: PARIS. HIDDEN away in a narrow street in the workingclass section of the Left Bank is the former Gobelin tapestry factory, an unadorned, prosaic building that for the past two years has been the scene of intense artistic activity. Every morning, sometimes even on Saturdays, 10 actors and a worldfamous director hurry in, and climb up several flights of steep, wide stairs to the top floor. There in a space 100 feet long and 100 feet high, with walls and floors that are icy cold, with no windows and no decor (except for some plain cloths hanging from the ceiling to divide the area), they change quickly into work clothes.

title: New Bank Chief: Getting to Know Asia
description: MANILAThe Asian Development Bank has to take care of all Asian countries, and for this our greatest need is additional resources, said Shiro Inoue of Japan in describing his main concern as new president of the bank. He was interviewed at the bank's new headquarters building overlooking Manila Bay during a recess from a series of signing ceremonies.

title: Jessye NormanPeople Look at Me and Say Aida
description: UP to a point, the scenario is pure Paramount Pictures. The young American singer wins a couple of contests, receives help from several foundations, then goes to Europe for one of the big international competitions. She wins first prize, is snatched up by one of Germany's leading opera houses, makes a sensational debut, is summoned as a guest artist to La Scala, Covent Garden, Florence. One of her recordings is nominated for a worldwide prize. She returns in triumph to her native land, sings at the Hollywood Bowl, knocks the Eastern critics dead with Wagner's Wesendonck Lieder at Tanglewood. Lincoln Center acts fast and engages her for a special recital. Welcome home, Jessye Norman.

title: Tammany Requiem: Anawanda Club Death
description: There was a time when there was thunder in the name. That was when Charles F. Murphy, once called the greatest leader Tammany Hall ever had, held court and dispensed patronage from the confessional, a small office at the head of the clubhouse stairs at Second Avenue at 20th Street.

title: The Economy
description: WASHINGTON The United States economy finished 1972 on a strong upbeat, and theforecasts for 1973 are all but unanimous in predicting more of the same. Walter W. Heller, Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, summarizes the situation this way: We will remember 1972 and 1973 as vintage years of United States expansion.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH modern interior paints are easier to work with and more foolproof in application than ever before, doityourselfers sometimes find that the finished paint job still does not turn out quite as good as expected  or the job doesn't seem to last as long as it should. In most cases (assuming a good quality paint was purchased) the fault does not lie with the paint, it is caused by one of three things; (1) The surface was not properly prepared beforehand; (2) the wrong kind of paint was selected for that particular surface; or (3) the paint was improperly applied.

title: Burma: Vital Blackmarket
description: MANDALAY, Burma  On the main street of this sleepy, dusty town in central Burma stands a clocktower erected in 1897 to mark Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee. The plaques commemorating the occasion were removed long ago but the clock continues to keep good time, and across the square, hawkers squatting on the pavement set their smuggled watches by it.

title: Voices of Children Repeats Success
description: One of the most admired works of recent years is George Crumb's Ancient Voices of Children. It was performed by the New York Philharmonic in a Prospective Encounter concert downtown last season. Pierre Boulez, the conductor, decided to bring it uptown to the subscription audiences in Philharmonic Hall, and it was in Thursday night's program.

title: Inauguration Day in Washington Captures Attention of the Nation
Mrs. Daphne Chace Maytham Is a Bride
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 20 Mrs. Daphne Chace Maytham and Wright Montgomery were married here at noon today at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Freeborn Chace Jr. in Greenfield Hill. Robert D. Gage, a Justice of the Peace performed the ceremony.

title: Watergate
description: WASHINGTONThe judge sat, stern, frankly incredulous, peering at the four men lined up before him. They were not exactly cocky, these mentheir lawyer once had called them little soldiersbut they were assured, glib, eager to talk and yet said little. The audience strained at the quick speech, the Cuban accents.

title: RUSSELL G. ELSON
description: CEDAR GROVE, N. J., Jan. 20 Russell G. Elson, Eastern division sales manager for Publicker Distillers Products, Inc., of Philadelphia, died Thursday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge. He was 68 years old and lived here.

title: Winter Travel: A Business That's Going Far
description: Dr. Stanley R. Fine and his family flew to Disney World and Miami Beach last week for a vacation. Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Segal are taking off tomorrow for a twoweek trip to Jamaica. And Mr. and Mrs. Myron Kahn are planning a flight to Mexico City and the Yucatan Peninsula next month.

title: Sports Show to Open Saturday in Louisville
description: The Louisville, Ky., Sport, Boat and Vacation Show will open Saturday at the Kentucky Fair and Exposition Center, running for eight days. Last year, more than 162,000 people attended the show, the sixth largest in the United States.

title: RAIL STRIKE COST HELD STAGGERIIG
description: The cost of the Long Island Rail Road strike to the parties in the dispute, the residents who commute on it and the businesses that depend on it was described as staggering and disastrous by those who are now trying to tote it up. But nobody, it turned out, knows precisely what the figures are.

title: More Ado About Much Ado
description: HARRIS GREEN'S polemic against Much Ado About Nothing last Sunday has the familiar smell of Academe, of those selfappointed guardians of Shakespeare, the scoundrels who have turned hundreds of thousands of schoolchildren against the Bard by insisting there is only one pore way to do his plays. Oh, how familiar is the armchair argumentanother footnote to the Variorum.

title: ISRAELIS PROTECTED BY BAY STATE POLICE
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Jan. 20 Threats against the families of two Israeli consulate officials living here have resulted in what sources call roundtheclock police protection.

title: Canada Finds Little Effect In End of Death Penalty
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 20 (UPI)The abolition of the death penalty in Canada on Dec. 29, 1967, failed to bring any major increase in the number of murders, according to Government statistics.

title: Racing Road Ahead: Higher Quality and Higher Costs
description: The quality of racing this season, for the most part, should be better than it has been for the last few years. Indianapolis is sure to see qualifying laps of 200 miles an hour, and a fleet of new cars promises firstclass competition elsewhere on the Championship Trial of the United States Auto Club. In road racing the L&M Championship of the Sports Car Club of America is now bigtime, threatening to overshadow the CanAm series. Stockcar racing is reducing the number of events, thereby improving the quality. The new International Motor Sports Association is coming along with some exciting weekends. Big purses will attract the best imaginable machinery in drag racing. About Motor Sports

title: Jennifer Brask to Wed
description: CHATHAM, N.J., Jan. 20Mr. and Mrs. R. John Brask have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jennifer Barbara Brask, to R. Jeffrey Carlson, son of Richard J. Carlson of Elizabeth and Mrs. Eleanor B. Carlson of Scotch Plains.

title: Veterans Demanding Flats in Forest Hills Housing Project
description: The poor can improve their lot but the disabled veteran is forever, said Michael Cunningham, chairman of the Veterans Housing Committee of the American Legion.

title: Energy Crisis
description: WASHINGTONMuch of the nation was enjoying unseasonably mild weather, but President Nixon chose last week to take out some lowtemperature insurance to avert a shortage of heating oil this winter.

title: LAWRENCE B. CAREY, EXJERSEY OFFICIAL
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Jan. 20Lawrence Bernard Carey, a banker who was New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance from 1945 to 1948, died yesterday in Muhlenberg Hospital. He was 80 years old land lived here.

title: REFORMS BEGUN BY LEGISLATURE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20Heeding urgings by citizens' groups, the news media and from many of its own members, the State Legislature has undertaken a series of reforms aimed at tightening the committee system and improving the legislative process.

title: SCHENK, BOERJES SET SKATING PACE
description: SKIEN, Norway, Jan. 20 (AP) Ard Schenk of the Netherlands led the allround and Hasse Boerjes of Sweden led the sprints today in the European professional speed skating championships.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST TRACED TO BIBLE
description: Sarah Rabinowitz of Nutley (N. J.) High School's class of '74, sent $10 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund along with this Biblebased injunction: It is time now for peace.

title: Pitt Hires ExEagle Back
description: PITSBURGH, Jan. 20 (AP)Harry Jones, No. 1 draft choice of the Philadelphia Eagles in 1967, has been added to the football coaching staff at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: F.H.A. WILL CLOSE HEMPSTEAD UNIT
description: The scandalridden office of the Federal Housing Administration in Hempstead, L.I. will be closed, and its functions transferred to Manhattan, on the order of Secretary George Romney of the Housing and Urban Development Department.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is interesting to note that the week before the article Softness Detected in Rental Market [Jan. 7] appeared, our office was renting over 140 apartments in 15 buildings.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Co., Inc., the venture banking and financial services firm, has subleased about 30,000 square feet of office space on the 12th and 13th floors at 277 Park Avenue for 12 years. The aggregate rent is about $4million.

title: 4H Club Joins TrailRiding Circuit on Staten Island
description: Jan Perroth, who is 11 years old, awoke with the chickens on a recent Saturday and, within minutes, raced from her home in the Staten Island community of Pleasant Plains, jumped on her gelding and galloped away.

title: Richard Goes to Lilliput
description: GULLIVER travels again! And so does Richard Harris. The Irish actor, whose partially completed Spanish western, Riata, was recently headed off at the pass because of production difficulties, has been signed to star in a liveand  animated musical version of Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels. Producer Josef Shaftel reports that Don Black's adaptation of the 18thcentury classic will soon go before the cameras at London's Pinewood Studios under the direction of Peter Hunt. American National Enterprises, headed by Raeburn Van Coalson, will distribute the film, a service they are also providing for Shaftel'S recently completed musical edition of Alice in Wonderland.

title: Arthur Daley.
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 20It undoubtedly will be the showdown the advertising posteri proclaim, but it sure won't be held in the sunshine. The heavyweight championship fight between Joe Frazier and George Foreman will take place Monday night in the National Stadium, an openair arena from which the sunshine will liave long since fled. Overhead will be floodlights, the stars and the tropical fragrance of Jamaica's soft night air.

title: New ChildCare Project
description: BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP)The state's new Office for Children has announced the creation of a $2.5million project aimed at reducing the number of children entering Massachusetts state institutions. David S. Liederman, director of the office, said the project was to arrange for care of children in their own communities instead of institutions.

title: Selective Thieves
description: WARREN, OHIO, Jan. 20 (UPI)Thieves who apparently did not like wine but had a taste for whisky stole a truck loaded with spirits last week. The police found the truck Wednesday. About 300 cases of whisky were gone, but 600 cases of wine were intact.

title: SHIP CALLED BY SOS FINDS DEAD CAPTAIN
description: The 65year old captain of a Canadian fishing boat that had sent a distress signal saying she was in danger of sinking was found dead last night when a freighter came to her rescue, 195 miles northeast of Bermuda, the Coast Guard said. Four others aboard the 98foot Calm Seas were rescued unhurt.

title: China's Economic Victories Pose Questions
description: PEKING  Although the Chinese press heralded the New Year with an editorial claiming that 1972 had been a year of great victories on the economic front, plenty of evidence suggested that it was not quite the year Peking's economic planners had hoped it would be.

title: MORE COLLEGIANS FIND OWN HOMES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20From 1966 to 1971 the number of college students who lived in their own households increased by almost one million while the number of students living in college housing remained nearly the same, according to a survey released today by the Bureau of the Census.

title: Alexandra Mills to Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Wynne Mills of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Locust Valley, L. I., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandr Mills, to Thomas James Devine of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Andrian G. Devine of Rochester. An April wedding is planned.

title: Julie of The Wolves
description: Julie, an Eskimo girl, runs away from an impossible home life after losing her mother, father and being married off at 13 to a lustful simpleton. When lost and starving on the North Slope of Alaska, she uses all her cleverness and patience to make contact with a family of wolves who ultimately befriend her and help her to live through the long, violent Arctic winter.

title: NEW TRIO PREMIERE HONORS RIETI AT 75
description: Vittorio Rieti will be 75 a week from today and he has already had one program dedicated entirely to his works plus the premiere of a new Trio for piano, violin and cello. The latter took place Friday night at the Hunter College Playhouse, in the Beaux Arts Trio's third and last program of the season there. It is dedicated to the ensemble and was sandwiched in between pieces by Haydn and Dvorak, composers who received special attention in the series.

title: NIXON INAUGURATED. FOR HIS SECOND TERM; SEES WORLD ON THRESHOLD OF A PEACE ERA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Richard Milhous Nixon was inaugurated for his second term as President today and appealed to the nation and to its allies to show greater selfreliance as we stand on the threshold of a new era of peace.

title: A MAFIA INQUIRY STALLS IN ITALY
description: ROME, Jan. 20The Christian Democratic party, Italy's dominant political force, is embarrassed by a parliamentary imbroglio that has the Mafia as a murky backdrop.

title: G.O.P. Reportedly Raised $58Million for Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Republican National Committee members reportedly have been told that a record $58million was raised for the 1972 campaign. One source said only $1million was left.

title: Gebrian of the Mets Named Scout of Year
description: Pete Gebrian, a New York Mets scout for the last 12 years and a 29year veteran of organized baseball, has been selected scout of the year by the New York Professional Baseball Hot Stove League.

title: Miss Mary Wilson, Art Student, Is Married to George Gurney
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 20  Miss Mary Margaret Buckingham Wilson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Mazyck Wilson, was married here this evening to George Gurney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Crocker Gurney of Salisbury, Conn.

title: Nixons Take to Dance Floor to Celebrate
description: WASHINGTON, Sunday, Jan. 21  President and Mrs. Nixon appeared to be dancing their way through the five inaugural balls here early this morning.

title: Prefontaine Wins TwoMile Run
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20Dazzling performances by Steve Prefontaine, Steve Smith and Al Feuerbach got California's indoor track season off to a glittering start today in the 14th annual Sunkist invitation meet at the Los Angeles Sports Arena.

title: Philippines
description: MANILA  Americansand many Filipinoshave long been proud of the Americanstyle system of democracy adopted by the Philippines when the country was granted its independence in 1946. Last week that legacy of a halfcentury of American rule was abolished by President Ferdinand Marcos as unworkable.

title: Brown U. Fills Medical Post
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 20 (AP)Dr. Stanley M. Aronson, an official at Miriam Hospital in Providence, has been appointed dean for medical affairs at Brown University's new medical school. Dr. Aronson, the 51yearold pathologistin chief and director of laboratory medicine at the hospital, has been a professor of medical science at Brown since 1970.

title: Son to Mrs. Neuman
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Neuman of Rye, N. Y., Jan. 1 in the Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N. Y. Mrs. Neuman is the former Miss Nancy Eisen.

title: GIFT TO REEDIEST TRACED TO BIBLE
description: Sarah Rabinowitz of Nutley (N., J.) High School's class of '74, sent $10 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund along with this Biblebased injunction: It is time now for peace.

title: Vehicles Designed for Asian Jungles
description: MANILABehind the glitter of the big cities of Asia lies a vast rural expanse in which nearly 2 billion people live in conditions as primitive as their early ancestors. Men and beasts are the haulers and carriers; transportation is an ox harnessed to a sled or a wheeled dart.

title: Art: Maritime Theme at Exhibitions
description: Water, water all around could be the motto of New Jersey's museums these days, what with two exhibitions devoted to fishing and boats.

title: Japanese Cars: A Global Drive
description: When they invaded the United States a few years ago, the Japanese were not at all interested in doing battle with Americans. It was the Germans, French and British they were after, because they were fighting for a share of the biggest automobile market in the world.

title: Agent Is Key to Thai Sales
description: BANGKOK  Two big markedly different experiences in dealing with the Thai Government last year, one losing out in a bid to supply diesel locomotives, the other winning approval to negotiate the construction of a new airport.

title: Reforms Sought to Reduce Nationalism at the Olympics
description: Officials of the United States Olympic Committee would support a simpler, more serious format for award presentations at the 1976 Olympic Games in order to curtail excessive nationalism.

title: TUQUI II SCORES IN COAST STAKES
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI)Argentinebred Tuqui II raced to a surprise threelength victory today in the 21st running of the $45,000 San Marcos Handicap at Santa Anita for his first United States stakes victory.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: WITH nods to Susannah York, Cicely Tyson, Joanne Woodward, Barbra Streisand (Vincent Canby notwithstanding), Tuesday Weld, Liza Minnelli and Diana Sands, one is stunned at the omission of Dorothy Tutin's name from mention as a contender for Best Actress with her fabulous, finely chiseled, wonderfully widerangine elegantly controlled and touching performance in Ken Russell's Savage Messiah, recently named Best Film of 1972 by Films and Filming.

title: Buyers Scarce When the Price Is $1.8Million, Hospital Finds
description: GREENWICH, Conn.When William T. Grant died last August, he blessed Greenwich Hospital with a gifthis mansion on Long Island Sound. But the hospital has discovered that the blessing is mixed.

title: Seniors Become Music Critics To Choose Their Prom Bands
description: The members of the senior council of the High School of Fashion Industries took their job seriously. They sat at the round table at the edge of the dance floor of the Rose Suite of the Terrace on the Park, the catering establishment that used to be part of the World's Fair at Flushing Meadow, nibbling on pretzels, potato chips and their pencils, concentrating on the music.

title: RANGERS SUBDUE CANE ON RALLY IN 3D PERIOD, 43
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 20Rod Gilbert, who had scored only two goals in his last 20 games, had the last stick on a twice deflected shot from the point tonight as the New York Rangers rallied and defeated the Vancouver Canucks, 43.

title: PENN FIVE EDGES MAHATTAN, 5251.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) Ron Haigler's fivefoot jumper at the buzzer gave Penn a 5251 victory over Manhattan tonight in the second game of a college doubleheader at the Palestra.

title: Linkage and roulette
description: When Richard Nixon accepted his nomination at the 1968 Republican Convention in Miami and said that he would move from confrontation to negotiation with the Soviet Union, it seemed to many that this was the best promise he could make. Yet, even though some of those close to him suggested to me then that it was less close to his political instincts than to his political calculations, and even though it was one of those vague generalities that are the stuff of convention and campaign speechmaking, now, as he begins his second term, it can be said that he lived up to it more than anybody expected most of all, perhaps, Nixon himself.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN BY BLUES, 5 TO 1
description: ST. LOUIS, Jana 20 (UPI)Mike Murphy and Wayne Merrick scored two goals apiece tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 51 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game.

title: MINING IS BANNED IN FOREST REGION
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 20Prospecting and mining of minerals in Minnesota's Boundary Waters Canoe Area have been prohibited by a United States District Court decision that may offer a new protective shield for the nation's wilderness preserves.

title: WEST GERMAN SOCCER
description: Bayern Munich 5, Rotwelss Oberhausen 3.

title: Bewitched, Barbra'd And Bewildered
description: ONCE upon a time, in a far off land called Brooklyn, there lived a girl named Barbara, and to tell the truth, she was no great beauty. Not once did Prince Charming cart her off to the ball, or even to the corner candy store; and no onenot even her mom ever seemed to listen to her. So the melancholy waif made a promise to herself: one day everyone would listen to her. They'd listen because she would be bright and amusing and beautiful and sexy and adorable and talented.

title: Tardy Escort Fails To Delay the Agnews
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Vice President Agnew, an extra on what is almost totally a President's day, was nonetheless a highly visible factor in the inauguration ceremonies today.

title: Soviet Officially Adopts Education Exit Fee
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20  The Soviet leadership, after five months of hesitation, officially made the highly controversial education tax on emigrants the law of the land today.

title: Students Teach Students
description: LLOYD HARBOR, L. I.In an estate cottage that had been converted into a small but intimate college library professors and trustees of the Friends World College here waited with an air of expectation.

title: Industry
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I.The small lobby of the FairchildRepublic Corporation's plant here last Friday was crowded with scores of the unemployed of the aerospace industry. In the purchasing department two floors above, the phones jangled without stop as dozens of small machine shops and subcontractors throughout the metropolitan area called to wish FairchildRepublic well and try for a piece of the action.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Redistricting
description: Few denied that the stated aim of the measureto raise the number of City Councilmen from 37 to 43was laudable. It would increase representation from such black and Puerto Rican areas as Bushwick, BedfordStuyvesant, the South Bronx and East Harlem on a Council that now has only twg black members and no Puerto Ricans.

title: Southern Slugger Scores
description: BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Southern Slugger rallied from far back in a field of eight and won the $8,000 Bruins Handicap on a snowcovered track today at Suffolk Downs. He covered the one mile 70 yards in 1:48, and paid $9.40. Francis Marion was second and Risky Alibhai, the 21 favorite, third.

title: RALLY BY COUGARS TOPS CHAPS,124111
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 20 (AP)  The Carolina Cougars outscored Dallas, 152, in the last 2 minutes today to beat the Chaps, 124111, in an American Basketball Association game, behind the hot shooting of Ted McClain.

title: Joy Johnson Affianced
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 20Mr. and Mrs. Lowell F. Johnson have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joy Carol Johnson, to Michael F. Donahue Jr., son. of Mr. and Mrs. Donahue of Burlington, Vt.

title: L.I.R.R. Workers Flex LongUnused Muscles
description: With some uncertainty and confusion and a great deal of make  do, hundreds of, striking employes of the Long Island Rail Road worked to put the line back into shape last week for yesterday's grand reopening.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: It was with great distaste that I read Thomas Meehan's repellent article, Amos n Andy, Ow wah, ow wah, ow wah (Dec. 31). It usually takes a great deal to offend me: I am not a militant black who pounces on anything black that is touched by the white man. One of the more amazing aspects of this article is that Meehan, in his ecstacy to be devoured by his youth, tries to convince his readers that those Amos n Andy programs were innocent of any racism, on a par with ethnic humor of the day, comparable to the graces of Abie's Irish Rose, or The Goldbergs! And then to insist that all America was laughing along, including us darkies; that the few complainers were eccentric Negroes in Newport News, Va.

title: Henry R. Breck Weds Miss McCrary
description: Miss Wendy Iglehart McCrary was married in St. James' Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon to Henry Reynolds Breck, a partner in the investment banking house of Lehman Brothers. Canon Jeffrey Cave of the National Cathedral in Washington performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at 1A East 77th Street.

title: Brazil's Issues Herald Strides
description: BRAZIL, so often in the backwater of philatelic news, as is most of South America, has suddenly burst out with a varied array of stamps proclaiming the strengths of this LatinAmerican giant.

title: Luther College Marking frig. Its 25th Year With $325,000 Drive
description: TEANECK  Luther College is marking its 25th anniversary with activities that range from conrunity services to fundraising  and with special pride in its students' success stories.

title: British Making Headway in Ulster but Turmoil Persists
description: LONDON, Jan. 20When the British imposed direct rule in Northern Ireland nearly 10 months ago their aim was to inject a neutral peacekeeping authority between the warring Protestant and Roman Catholic communities.

title: Miss Delaporte to Wed
description: MENDHAM, N. J., Jan. 20 Mrs. Lee A. Delaporte has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Louise Delaporte, to Richard Tipton Burns Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Burns. Both families are of Mendham.

title: Regional Director Named For U.S. Mediation Service
description: Paul Yager, a labor mediator for 22 years, has been appointed director of the northeastern regional office of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: Miss Patricia Coward Fiancee of Peter Post
description: ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Jan. 20Miss Patricia Lamborn Coward, granddaughter of the late John Mortimer Coward, former president of the Coward Shoe Company, plans to be married to Peter Lindley Post, greatgrandson of the late Emily Post, a writer on etiquette.

title: Television Reports Of Siege Limited By Area Blackout
description: Television coverage of police action outside the Brooklyn sporting goods store where hostages were being held was not possible Friday evening because the police had prohibited the use of television lights at the scene. In addition, they had cut off electrical power to street lights.

title: Black Food Broker Optimistic on Goals
description: EAST ORANGEA blackoperated food broker's concern has opened its doors here, its ultimate goal being to achieve the nationwide distribution and marketing of edibles manufactured by blackowned companies.

title: RECALL BID FACES DELAY IN ARIZONA
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 20Arizona's Gov. Jack Williams, Republican, will face a recall election later this year if recall organizers succeed in surmounting legal complications.The recall forces are led by the United Farm Workers and include women's rights organizations, environmentalists, and forces in the Democratic party. Earlier this month the recall organization announced that their candidate against Mr. Williams would be Gerry Pollock, 40 years old, an outspoken liberal lawyer who has twice run unsuccessfully for the House against Representative John J. Rhodes, a Republican.The recall effort began last May when Governor Williams, who is serving his third term, refused to veto a farm labor law.

title: Saigon Baits Hook for Big Investors
description: SAIGON, South VietnamYoung, Westerneducated technocrats here talk with an eager glint in their eyes of an imminent foreign investment boom in South Vietnam. It will lift their country out of the wreckage of war, they say, and thrust it into the Asian marketplace alongside such highrollers as Singapore and Taiwan.

title: MAYER TOPS OWENS IN INDOOR NET FINAL
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 20 (AP)Sandy Mayer of Wayne, N.J., defeated Charlie Owens of Tuscaloosa, Ala., 64, 76, tonight in the final match of the $15,000 Birminghan international indoor tennis tournament.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: City Union Asks Severance Pay For All Workers Leaving Jobs
description: District Council 37, with 120,000 municipal employes as members, reported that it has proposed a severance benefit to replace a pension increase negotiated with the city, but blocked by the State Legislature since 1971.

title: Caldwell Students Take MiniCourses During Intersesson
description: CALDWELL  Kathleen Byrne is in Mexico, Frances Kujalciwicz is in Israel, Peggy McCarter is in Florida and Michele Sciortino is in New York. All four young women are students at Caldwell College; and they are participating in the college's first intersession of minipurses, which offer opportunities for travel and study not included in the regular curriculum.

title: Pick a Plan, Any Plan (It's Chess: Better Than Nothing at All)
description: It's often said that a bad plan is better than none, and there is some point to this cynicism; a plan of whatever, quality must involve some kind of integration of a series of moves, whereas disorganized fumbling cannot help but end in disaster.

title: Gaughn, Nazareth Senior, Sets Meet Mark of 4:14.7 for Mile
description: Pete Gaughn, who has been aiming for star status since his sophomore year, took a major stride toward it yesterday in the 17th annual St. Francis Prep schoolboy games at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: C. P. Cavafy
description: The arrival of Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard on the modern Greek translation scene marks quite a definite and definitive stage of a process; the excellence of their work is really worthy of recognition by the Greek Government. Thanks to them we can now say that we have Seferis and Cavafy in English, and in versions not likely to be superseded; one hopes that they will continue this triumphal work and give us a Sekialianos and an Elytis. The volume under review is, as might be expected, thoughtful, respectful to the great poet and felicitous in its choice of phrasing  with perhaps one small reservation about a few Americanisms like to show up and show business, which the old poet himself might have found too slangy. But then this is an American book for American readers, and this observation may not be worth raising.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Who Did It? Is Theme Of Art Show In Suffolk
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.There are many activities in museum life that remain unknown to the publia One of them is the persistent investigation of art works in the museum collections. If sculpture or a painting is under question concerning, say, its origins or authorship, it is customary policy to examine it until the truth about the object can be conclusively established.

title: Dartmouth Six Tops Penn
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 20 (AP)Bill Berry rallied Dartmouth from a 21 deficit with a pair of goals 12 seconds apart late in the second period and the Big Green went on to a 53 Ivy League hockey victory over Penn tonight. Bill Dunbar also had two goals for Dartmouth, which has a 94 wonlost record, 32 in the league. Penn is 84 over all and 14 in Ivy competition.

title: The Kennedy Promise
description: And so, my fellow Americans, ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country, said John F. Kennedy in his Inaugural Address, as everyone knows.

title: Meanwhile, In Manila
description: Peace in Vietnam was at hand twelve days before last November's election, and by odd coincidence peace seemed to be at hand again two days before President Nixon's second inauguration. Curiously enough, now as then, a few small details do remain. still to be negotiated, but on this historic weekend let us be no more cynical than experience warrants.

title: Rhodesian Political Opposition Assails Suppression. of Tribes
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 20  The Government's decision to take tough new measures to suppress unrest among African tribesmen drew strong criticism today from political parties here.

title: Shipping/Mails
Arts Program Enriches Lives of Pupils
description: HACKENSACK  Promptly at. 4 P.M. every Tuesday, 9yearold Tina breathlessly hurries to the Young Men's Hebrew Association building at 211 Essex Street so that she can indulge in her favorite afternoon activity: a drama class that is part of the Y's new Arts Enrichment Program.

title: Museum Adds a Dimension
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I.When the Town of Oyster Bay Supervisor, John W. Burke, cuts the ribbon In front of the old courthouse building on Heitz Place here next Saturday morning opening the new Gregory Museum, hundreds of men, women and young people will be there to see the two years of labor that they have put into the 78yearold structure come to fruition.

title: Paris Police and Leftists Clash As Protests Against War Flare
description: PARIS, Jan. 20Scattered antiwar, antiNixon demonstrations erupted in the heart of Paris tonight, some of them the most violent seen here in recent years, as other protests were held elsewhere in Europe and Africa.

title: Yachting Awards Go To Melges, Mrs. Pegel
description: Harry C. (Buddy) Melges of Zenda, Wis., will be honored tomorrow as the Martini & Rossi yachtsman of the year. A similar prize as yachtswoman of the year will go to Mrs. Jane Pegel of Williams Bay, Wis.

title: Population Increases in 4 Cities
description: Four of New Jersey's biggest cities  Newark, Jersey City, Trenton and Camdenhave registered modest population gains after many years of losing residents.

title: The Unmaking Of Rabbit
description: Paul is 11, and has problems. His ears stuck out, his nose, which was faintly pink, dripped even when he didn't have a cold. And when he was nervous, which was pretty often, he not only blinked, he stuttered. At school they called him Rabbit.

title: So Now I Know From Pastrami
description: I WAS leaning against a fire hydrant in the East Bronx the other day, wolfing a pastrami on rye and a firstrate pickle, and I got to thinking about my old magazine life, when I didn't know, as they say, from pastrami and pickles. They don't have pastrami at La Cte Basque, and if they did, it wouldn't cost a dollar and, besides, you would have to eat it nicely. Among the many other changes in my life since I began training as an NBC news hen, is the size of my bites. They're larger now, and I don't always have a napkin. It isn't that I used to lunch at La Cote Basque every day, but lunch used to be, most definitely, an indoor sitdown affair  one which began in the middle of a day which, in turn, began at 11, or 10:30 if there was a lot to do.

title: British Hotel Fire Kills One
description: EXMOUTH, England, Jan. 20 (AP)One person died and four were missing in an earlymorning fire that destroyed the threestory Imperial Hotel in this western England resort town today. There were 50 guests and employes in the hotel when the blaze started.

title: Israeli Institute Names Head
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 20Maj. den. Amos Horev, chief scientist of the Ministry of Defense, has been elected president of the TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology. He will retire from the armed forces and assume office on Oct. 1.

title: New Hebrides, a Tax Haven
description: PORT VILA, New Hebrides This archipelago of 80 islands, 1,000 miles off the northeast coast of Australia, came to the attention of the Western world in 1774, when Capt. James Cook visitedand namedthe New Hebrides on one of his journeys to the South Pacific.

title: A Drug War Opens For U.S. Market
description: The United States, the world's leading consumer of heroin, is engaged in a critical period of competition against some of the world's shrewdest, most aggressive and highly organized businessmen: the international narcotics syndicates.

title: Mrs. Sultan Has Child
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 20A daughter was born Jan. 14 at the Nassau Hospital in Mineola to Dr. and Mrs. Burton S. Sultan Mrs Sultan is the former Miss Marilyn Ringel of Jamaica Estates, Queens, Her husband is an ophthalmologist in Hempstead. The child has been named Lorna Renee.

title: PreSchool Cutback
description: In the field of education, the Nixon Administration early on pledged to address itself to the years from one to five. But in the current Federal budgetcutting, programs covering these years appear to be losers.

title: Crampton, at 206, Takes 3Shot Lead
Soviet Lunokhod 2 Begins First Excursion on the Moon
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20The Soviet Union's moon rover, after several days of test runs, has taken off on its first excursion. It is heading for mountains that surround the lunar crater to which the vehicle, Lunokhod 2, was delivered by the space craft Luna 21 on Tuesday.

title: Miss Osborn Fiancee
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 20The engagement of Miss Virginia Baldwin Osborn to James Michael Mahood has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William James Osborn Jr. Her fianc is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland William Mahood of White Plains.

title: Gatehouse Renamed Head Of National Horse Show
description: Woodrow G. (Woody) Gatehouse has been elected to his second successive term as president of the National Horse Show.

title: Raising the L.Q.'s of the Retarded
description: An experimental project, aimed at qualifying preschool age Down's Syndrome children for admission into regular public school kindergarten classes  and dispelling myths that have developed regarding the condition appears to be headed for dramatic success in the developmental clinic of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center, at 555 Prospect Place, in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Babyware Seller Agrees To Alter Business Method
description: Bess Myerson, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, announced yesterday that Baby Butler of Long Island, a seller of baby furniture at 11610 Myrtle Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, had agreed after consumer complaints to change its business practices.

title: Nuptials Held for Mary H. Sheldon
description: DOVER, Mass., Jan. 20Miss Mary Hawthorne Sheldon was married here this afternoon to John Russell Twiss Jr. of Washington, for whom Mount Twiss was named in Antarctica for his work with a United States scientific group there. Mr. Twiss is with the National Science Foundation.

title: Queens Cemeteries: Time for Memories
description: If you like cemeteries you will love Queens County; it has got more than its share. About 25 of them according to the Yellow Pages.

title: Mrs. Quinan Is Wed Here
description: Mrs. Karen Bernard Quinan was married here yesterday afternoon to David Allen Wegmann State Supreme Court Justice Arnold Fein performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Briger, friends of the couple.

title: PROTESTERS HOLD VIGILS AND WALKS
