description: Along New Jersey's Route 4 they stood like signposts. On the village green of Wilton, Conn., as President Nixon took his oath yesterday to obey the Constitution, they took an oath to obey their consciences.

title: Bequest of $3Million Is Made to Dartmouth
description: One of the largest individual bequests ever made to Dartmouth College, $3million from the estate of Mrs. Martha Leverone of Chicago, has been announced by Dr. John G. Kemeny, president of the college.

title: LEO E. ALLEN, 74; A CONGRESSMAN
description: GALENA, Ill., Jan. 20 (UPI) Funeral services were scheduled for Tuesday for former Representative Leo E. Allen, who represented the 16th District of Illinois in Congress from 1933 to 1961. Mr. Allen died yesterday in Galena Hospital following a long illness. His age was 74.

title: Legislative Notes: A Candid View on the Disclosure Bill
description: TRENTON Assemblyman Wiliam K. Dickey, a Camden County Republican known for his blunt talk, makes no effort to conceal his reasons for opposing a measure that would force public disclosure of campaign contributions.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Gunmen Holding Out in Brooklyn Siege; Admit Doctor, Free One of 10 Hostages
description: Hundreds of heavily armed policemen maintained a massive but impotent cordon of firepower around a Brooklyn sporting goods store yesterday as four trapped gunmen holding a group of frightened hostages rejected repeated appeals for a peaceful surrender.

title: The World
description: TEL AVIVHe stated explicitly, and this is important, that it is necessary to continue the dialogue between the Church and Israel, and that we must meet and talk. This I unhesitatingly call an historic moment.

title: Maine Is Urged to End Fingerprinting of Papas
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 20 (AP)The practice of fingerprinting Maine's fifthgrade pupils is unnecessary Wand may be unconstitutional as a violation of the right of privacy, Representative Theodore S. Curtis Jr., Republican of Orono, says.

title: Miss Ellen Gibbs Bride of Student
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 20 Miss Ellen Barbara Gibbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert. James Gibbs of Upper Montclair, was married to Andrew Frederick Deibert of Highland Park, this afternoon by the Rev. Lawrence Wynne in the Grace Presbyterian Church.

title: Television
description: THE picture for public television in this country has gone alarmingly dim. Instead of the politically insulated system, protected with some form of longterm funding, that was envisioned in the formative Carnegie Report, the publicTV structure is being drawn iteadily to increasing political control.

title: Friday's Fights
description: New YorkVilomar Fernandez, 131 pounds, Dominican Republic, knocked out Joe Rivera, 130, Puerto Rico, 2 rounds; Jos Sosa, 146, Mendoza, Argentina, outpointed Orestes Lebron, 143, Puerto Rico, 8.

title: Kathleen K. Coffee And Interne Wed
description: In the Roman Catholic Chapel of SS. Faith, Hope and Charity yesterday morning, Miss Kathleen Karen Coffee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Coffee, became the bride of Dr. Robert Joseph Porter Jr.

title: William Riker Fiance Of Diana Sherwood
description: CHATHAM TOWNSHIP, N. J., Jan. 20Mr. and Mrs. David J. Sherwood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Sherwood, to William Wolle Riker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton B. Riker also of Chatham Township.

title: Insanity
description: By convincing jurors that he was mentally ill when committing a lifetime of crimes, and then by repeatedly escaping from the mental hospitals to which the jurors sent him, Garrett B. Trapnell, the accused skyjacker of a TWA jet, has been eluding the institutions of law and psychiatry for some 15 years. With few exceptions he has neither been punished for a crime nor treated for an illness.

title: M'GOVERN HELPS 4 CITY HOPEFULS
description: Senator George McGovern is making available lists of New York campaign volunteers and contributors only to Democratic mayoral candidates who supported him before the state's Presidential primary last June, a former McGovern campaign leader disclosed last week.

title: Cambodia Undone
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  War and corruption have disrupted the economy of Cambodia, causing rice shortages and food riots in a nation that until 1970 was an exporter of rice.

title: Asbestos, the saver of lives, has a deadly side
description: Shipyard work attracted about 4.5million Americans into its ranks at one time or another during World War II, and an estimated 3.25million of those people are still alive. If they think about the experience at all these days it is probably to again remind themselves with satisfaction that things could have been worse. Whether they went into the work simply for a paycheck, or as a kind of emancipation (at some shipyards nearly onethird of the workers were women), or as an alternative to the military draft, those who built and repaired America's ships took comfort in supposing that however dirty and boring the work sometimes became, at least it was safer than being in the front lines.

title: Shallot King Reigns in a Mahwah Farmhouse.
description: MAHWAHA 160yearold, blackshuttered, whiteclapboard farmhouse is the setting for a successful business operated by Raymond Saufroy, better known to gourmet chefs all over the country as The Shallot King.

title: Scattered Delays Mark Return of the L.I. R. R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road experienced scattered delays of up to 30 minutes yesterday as the line carried its first passengers in seven weeks.

title: A Memoir: Managua Before the Quake
description: EVEN before the earthquake two days before Christmas, Central Americans scoffed at me, saying that there are very few people who would call Managua, Nicaragua, their favorite city. It was mine.

title: Sri Lanka, Born in '72, Was Not Born Free
description: COLOMBO, Sri LankaThis country, born in 1972 from the economic and political crises that wracked its predecessor, Ceylon, was in no way born free. A bloody insurrection in 1971 left scars slow to heal.

title: HOG GROWER WINS A BATTLE IN TEXAS
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Jan. 20 A. L. Miner lived alone with his six dogs, about 100 hogs and a few cattle until, he said. the city government started trying to run me out of business.

title: Hanoi Is Said to Report A CeaseFire Agreement
description: PEKING, Jan. 20  A Canadian Member of Parliament visiting Hanoi reported Thursday night that senior North Vietnamese officials said a ceasefire agreement had been reached with the United States.

title: HOWARD W. KLEMANN
description: TENAFLY, N.J., Jan. 20 Howard W. Klemann, former officer of Brooks Brothers, the New York men's wear retailer, died Thursday at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

title: Dance
description: BALLET is one of the most fragile of artsperhaps the most fragile. In the worst performance of Hamlet you can imagine, something of Shakespeare survives. A halftrained orchestra and an inept conductor will still convey something of a Beethoven symphony. But ballet is dependent on tiny; tiny imponderables. I was thinking of this the other week with American Ballet Theater at the New York City Center.

title: Job Discrimination
description: WASHINGTONHow is it possible to redress the injury done to a woman or a black who fails to apply for a wellpaid job because the company's policy against hiring such persons is wellknown.

title: High School Will Stress Medical Vocations
description: Clara Barton Vocational High School, long a girls' vocational school in Brooklyn, will become the, city's first public high school devoted exclusively to medical services this fall. Operating as a coeducational institution it will offer an academic education combined with a curriculum of medical arts leading to a career in health services. The program will include both medical technology and business administration in medical fields.

title: 2 Killed in Bangladesh Fight
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 20 (UPI)  Two suspected gangsters were killed and two wounded in a gunbattle between soldiers and a gang of about 150 gangsters near Cox's Bazar, 200 miles southeast of Dacca, official sources said yesterday.

title: Judith Farber Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Farber of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Rana Farber, to Jeffrey Allen Gelfand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Gelfand of Stoneham, Mass. Miss Farber and her fianc are students at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. She was graduated magna cum laude from City College, and he is an alumnus of Cornell University.

title: A Bay State Woman Prefers Atlantic Flights Solo
description: NORWOOD, Mass., Jan. 20 Transoceanic plane flights raise few eyebrows these days, especially since the advent of jet airliners that cross in a handful of hours and carry throngs of passengers.

title: 9 Killed and 3 Hurt in Crash Of 2 Cars in New Mexico
description: DEMING, N. M., Jan. 20 (UPI) Nine persons were killed and three others injured yesterday when a westbound car crossed the median on a fourlane highway and collided headon with an eastbound auto.

title: FLA. STATE BOWS TO JACKSONVILLE
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP)Leon Benbow and Henry Williams made a total of, five free throws in the last two minutes to give Jacksonville a 7066 victory over Florida State in Florida's hottest collegiate basketball rivalry today.

title: Deborah C. Martin Fiancee of Surgeon
description: TEMPLE, N. H., Jan. 20Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Martin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Colton Martin, to Dr. Norman Alexander Hill of New York, an orthopedic surgeon. He is the son of Mrs. Norman Stewart Hill of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Hill, who was a senior partner in Hill & Co., an investment securities firm.

title: Graham Tells of Reservations Over War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist, said in an interview here that the war in Vietnam was a judgment of God on America and that he had had grave questions about it from the very beginning.

title: Boston U. Six Wins, 72
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 20 (AP)Boston University defeated smallcollege hockey powerhouse Vermont, 72, tonight. The national champion brought their wonlost record to 134. Vermont, which outshot the visitors 40.24, is 96 overall, but remains No. 1 in Division II rankings with a 70 record.

title: A menu of '72 favorites
description: In the past, the year's most requested recipes have remarkably often turned out to be desserts. In 1972, however, readers seem to have lost their sweet tooths (or is it sweet teeth?). With the exception of the redoubtable Maida Heatter's latest piece of ingenuity with chocolate, the moussetorte, the others are all savory dishes. Their choice reflects a growing interest in basics, fundamental techniques and tastes. Seventytwo was the year of the green peppercorn in New York. Readers, as well as restaurants, were quick to take advantage of this new spice, which imparts the taste of pepper to foods without overwhelming them. Bread baking is a trend all by itself. The failure of commercial bakeries to provide an honest loaf has spurred people to make their own. Cornell bread is a famous example of healthy baking. Ed Giobbi's lasagne is an old friend's new way with an old idea. In all of this; there is the makings of one big meal, the meal of the year: lasagne, steak au poivre vert, Cornell bread and moussetorte.

title: Private Sector Steps Up Construction of Apartments
description: Private enterprise returned in force during 1972 to the apartment construction business in New York.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: New Charter Rules Offer Confusion With Bargains
description: Four months after the Civil Aeronautics Board ordered a radical change in airline charter flight rules, travel industry leaders say there is every indication that the decision will have a revolutionary effect on how Americans travel.

title: Yen's Trade Route Is Smooth Sailing
description: TOKYOA year ago, Japanese traders said they felt like ship captains who had begun voyages into uncharted seas and were afraid of the unknowns facing them.

title: John Garnjost to Wed Janet Williams
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 20  Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Williams of North Syracuse have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Marion Williams, to John Tweedy Garnjost, son of Stanley Livingstone Garnjost of Falls Church, Va., and Mrs. Dorothy Tweedy Garnjost of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Key to Apartheid Is Complexity of Laws
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaWhen a black clergyman visited Johannesburg recently, his manner offended a white shopkeeper, who hit him on the head with an ax handle.

title: Navy Surgeon Will Wed Alice Traynor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Traynor of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Traynor, to Lieut. T. Jeffrey Dmochowski, a flight surgeon with the Navy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus Dmochowski of Kinnelon, N.J.

title: Miss Cocozziello Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs, Victor A, Cocozziello of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanne Cocozziello, to Steven Robert Grippo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Grippo of New York. Mr. Cocozziello is chief counsel of the state's Bingo Control Commission.

title: Decorated Soldier Gets Discharge as Objector
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI)A muchdecorated veteran of the Vietnam war who was once a member of the White House security detail was honorably discharged from the army yesterday as a conscientious objector.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday:

title: ATHERN DAGGETT, 69, BOWDOIN PROFESSOR
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 20Dr Athern P. Daggett, a member of the faculty of Bowdoin College for 40 years and acting president of the college from 1967 to 1968, died today in the Maine Medical Center, Portland. Professor Daggett, who had suffered head injuries Jan. 8 in a fall was 69 years old.

title: Cynthia Alston Wed
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 20Miss Cynthia Thompson Alston and Denison Saxton Davis, son of Mrs. Charles P. Luckey and the late Joseph W. S. Davis, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Charles Scott performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Philip Guston Alston. Both families live here.

title: Kenneth Siegel Plans to Marry Miss McEnerny
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20Mrs. Will G. McEnerny has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Clare McEnerny, to Kenneth Alan Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred K. Siegel of New York.

title: FOUR DIE WHEN CAR HITS DISABLED TRUCK
description: WEST DEPTFORD, N. J., Jan. 20 (BPI)Four persons were killed early this morning after their car crashed into a disabled truck parked on the New Jersey Turnpike near here.

title: Phase 2, HeathStyle
description: We have tried to benefit from the experience America, said Prime Minister Heathand his own Phase 2 of Britain's drive to curb inflation seems indeed to be almost a carbon copy of the program President Nixon abandoned last week. Mr. Heath would be more than satisfied if his program, complete with Pay Board and Price Commission, armed with legal enforcement powers, achieved anything approaching the results of Washington's too quickly abandoned Phase 2.

title: McCovey, Giants Agree On Pact for '73 Season
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (UFO Willie McCovey became the first member of the San Francisco Giants to agree to terms for 1973 today when he signed his contract. The salary is reported the same as lie received last season, about $120,000.

title: L.I. Report For Minors Is Critical On Justice
description: WOODMERE, L. I.Th?? first preliminary report in a study of the juvenile justice system by a nationwide women's service organization will be made public this week, and its findings wil?? confirm what many experts have contended for a long time  the system is not working.

title: Ch. Chi Cheng Reel Runs Successful Relay Leg
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (AP)  Two great women athletesMrs. Chi Cheng Reel of Taiwan and Marilyn Neufville of Jamaicamade comebacks today in the Sunkist invitation track meet.

title: Problems of a Lady in Retirement
description: MOST people used to be convinced that there would always be an England, but with the falling pound, the Irish troubles and Britain's entry into the Common Market, that proposition seems less certain. A visit to the Queen Mary, now permanently moored at Long Beach, Calif., should reassure the waverers that at least there will always be Anglophilia and that its home is, the American Southwest. In addition to the Queen Mary, there is London Bridge, reassembled in Lake Havasu City, Ariz., and if Londoners go through with their plan to modernize Piccadilly Circus no one should be surprised to see the leftovers transplanted to Hollywood.

title: Southern University Chief Reported Planning to Retire
description: BATON ROUGE, Jan. 20 (UPI)  G. Leon Netterville, whose refusal to resign as president of Southern University last year was a factor in two months of student protests, reportedly plans to retire within six months.

title: Three Performances Don't Make an Orchard
description: THE allblack production of The Cherry Orchard at the Public is, I am sorry to say, a dull Cherry Orchard, and dull for exactly the wrong reason. The one thing we look for, I think, as Negro performers of the very first rank begin to tackle the major plays of the European tradition is a freshness of eye and ear that will wake up that tradition, relieve it of its staleness, perhaps shatter its bad habits. Never having come this way before, these players come unburdened by overly solemn memories, uncommitted to reproducing the legendary gestures of the past, freed of the sleepwalking that has attached itself to roles grown drowsy through a thousand and one nights of repetition.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: COAST PAPERS GET AUTOMATION PACT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20An arbitration panel here made an award this week settling a dispute over the introduction of new equipment in the composing room of the San Francisco Chronicle and the San Francisco Examiner.

title: What's New in Theater
description: THE PLOUGH AND THE STARS the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center's production of Sean O' Casey's play, got four favorable reviews (Watt, News; Watts, Post; Wallach, Newsday; Gayer UPI), five mixed (Raidy, Newshouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Harris, CBSTV; Klein, WNEWTV; Bookspan, WPIXTV) and two unfavorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Gottfried, Women's Wear).

title: Note: A welcome morn Thin
description: THROUGH sheer weight of numbers, America's tourists have succeeded in wearing their welcome thin in many parts of the United States and are meeting increased resentment from local residents. First, it was Oregon entreating tourists to turn back at the state line, especially if they had any intention of perhaps staying on, and then Colorado told visitors they should come only if they planned to leave no unpleasant reminders of their visit. Antitourist rumblings have also been heard from the National Park Service and the residents of Greater Miami. In the last two instances, however, some protourist voices are being raised, the loudest sometimes belonging those with vested interest.

title: Drug Center Is Accepted
description: LONG BRANCHMatthew Martin has enough to worry about as director of the Chelsea School, a prototype institution set up by the state's Department of Health for youngsters with drug problems.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TODAY

title: MISS PROELL WINS CUP GIANT SLALOM
description: ST. GERVAIS, FranceJan. 20  Annemarie Proell, skiing over rocks and grass on the rugged La Vares trail, caught her balance just in time today and won the St. Gervais giant slalom for her seventh victory in 10 World Cup races this season.

title: Three Missouri Men Are Charged With Murder in Bank Extortion Slayings
description: GRANDIN, Mo., Jan. 20The police announced today that three men had been arrested and charged with firstdegree murder In the fatal shooting on Wednesday of a local bank president, his wife and his oldest daughter.

title: Pounding Away
description: To the Editor: Pound is nuts, said Robert Frost. All America is a lunatic asylum, said Ezra Pound.

title: India's Planning Goes Awry
description: NEW DELHIPresident V. V. Giri, in his inaugural address to Parliament early last year, asked the Indian Government to strive for economic independence: That Government, buoyed by a military victory over Pakistan and a record food production in the preceding year, not only pledged itself to achieve this goal as soon as possible, but also began cutting old economic ties with foreign countries, especially in the West.

title: Inspector's Funeral Set for Patrolman
description: A police inspector's funeral on Tuesday will be accorded Stephen R. Gilroy, the 29yearold patrolman who was slain during the shootout following an attempted holdup of a Brooklyn sporting goods store.

title: Turks Kill Greek on Border
description: ATHENS, Jan. 20 (AP)A Greek fisherman was shot and killed by a Turkish patrol on Maritsa River on the border between Greece and Turkey, and the Athens Government is planning a protest, a Government source said today.

title: Tisch Named President Of Jewish Appeal Here
description: The election of Laurence A Tisch, the builder, as president of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York was announced last night.

title: Dale Lipper Affianced
description: DUMONT, N. J., Jan. 20The engagement of Miss Dale Robin Lipper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julie Lipper, to Andrew Stuart Heffler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Heffler, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Both families live. here.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Job enrichment and job redesign are becoming fashionable new phrases when discussing the seemingly growing discontent of workers in this country today. Interestingly, however, we have found that what is an enriched job to one worker may not be all that attractive to another.

title: AUTO SPARK DEVICE WINS U.S. APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Environmental Protection Administrator, William D. Ruckelshaus, said yesterday that he would permit Chrysler and Ford to keep sparkdelay devices on 1973 cars but would insist on removal of all the other devices that he banned for six auto makers a month ago.

title: St. John's Defeats Temple, 9384, for 8th Victory in Row
description: Billy Schaeffer set an Alumni Hall record for a St. John's player with 38 points last night as the Redmen defeated Temple 9384, before 4,072 fans.

title: SEVEN DRIVERS QUIT MONTE CARLO RALLY
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 20 (UPI)Easy conditions on the first stage of the Monte Carlo rally gave drivers few problems today. Organizers said only seven of the 279 starters had dropped out in the first 24 hours, but predicted a heavier toll as the crews sped toward the snow of the French Alps.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Wall Street, after celebrating record highs in stock averages earlier in 1973, wore a worried look last week.

title: Rich Cloak Hides Poverty in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, LaosVientiane, which is more a country town than a city, has a high proportion of large American cars for its size. It also has stores displaying a wide range of imported goods, from Scotch whiskies to facial tissues.

title: South Vietnam's Optimism Goes Sour
description: SAIGON, South VietnamAt the beginning of 1972 economists in South Vietnam were brimming with optimism. The war had beer tapering off for three years, inflation had been declining, the piaster seemed to be on a plateau of stability and looked as if the rice crop would be big enough to make the country selfsufficient again in its staple food.

title: Cats to Go on Show Feb. 2; Will Include Rare Breeds
description: The 56th annual Empire Cat Show will return to the Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 2, 3 and 4.

title: Australian Ballet Asked Not to Be Sexy in Soviet
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 20 (Reuters)  Soviet authorities have asked the Australian Ballet, which is to tour Eastern Europe in August, to drop any performances that include sex from its program, according to a ballet company official.

title: 4 PAPERS DISPUTE U.S. ON PRESS CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Four newspapers that temporarily suspended publication of the Pentagon papers under court order have warned that they do not feel bound to observe such an injunction under different circumstances in the future.

title: 14 TEAMSTER AIDES INDICTED IN ST. LOUIS
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20Four top officers of Local 600 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters here have been indicted for allegedly embezzling $108,000 in union funds. A Federal official said the indictments were the start of an effort to root out hoodlums from the St. Louis labor scene.

title: MILBURN IS VICTOR IN N.A.I.A. HURDLES
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 20 (AP) Athletes from Alcorn A. and M. took the first five places in the 60yard dash and Rod Milburn of Southern University won his third consecutive 60yard high hurdles title tonight in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics indoor track and field championships.

title: Bangladesh, after the first year: Will it ever be a workable country?
description: DACCA. It is 9:30 P.M. A halfmoon shines in clear blue sky. The sweet fragrance of the nightflowering jasmine pervades the atmosphere. There are no taxis outside the hotel. No motorcycle jinrikishas or pedicabs. I stroll toward the racecourse. The vast esplanade is bathed in silvery moonlight. A huge boatshaped platform erected for Mrs. Gandhi's last visit to the capital glistens in solitary splendor with petuniashaped loudspeakers pointing out on all four sides. Sheik Mujibur Rahman is due to make his firstyearofliberation speech tomorrow (Dec. 16). I notice armed policemen guarding the rostrum, and I quickly retrace my steps. It is only then that I realize that I have neither met anyone on the road nor heard the usual sounds of the city. An occasional truck thunders by, a motorcycle jinrikisha splutters on its hurried journey homewards, nothing more. could be in some remote village: dogs barking in the distance and packs of jackals baying at the moon. But this is Dacca, the capital of Bangladesh.

title: Super Bowl Will Remain In WarmWeather City
description: DALLAS, Jan, 20 (UPI)Pete Rozelle, pro football commissioner, said today that sites for the 1975 Super Bowl and Pro Bowl would be selected next April at a National Football League meeting in Arizona. He said the games Would continue to be played in warmweather cities.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, Jan. 20A student charged with planning to kidnap the United States Ambassador and to hijack an Olympic Airways plane to be used in trade for the release of political prisoners was sentenced tonight to four and a half years' imprisonment.

title: Theft Haul At Building Sites Put In Millions
description: Last year, a brand new $27,000 bulldozer was stolen from a construction site in Suffolk County and sold the next day to a builder in Staten Island for $7,500.

title: State Merges ChildAid Units
description: TRENTON  Each year in New Jersey, more than 30,000 children are abandoned, abused, adopted, neglected, placed in foster homes, receive parole supervision or otherwise need protective and counseling services from the state.

title: Environment Bill Is Set for Showdown
description: TRENTONIn what promises to be a highly unusual and dramatic legislative confrontation, Assembly Speaker Thomas J. Kean will take to the floor tomorrow in an attempt to rescue a measure that would permit individual New Jersey residents to institute private damage suits against environmental polluters.

title: The Second Inaugural
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20In his second inaugural address, framed in the most general of language, President Nixon sketched his determination to bring about for the next four years a national Government patterned after his philosophy of a disengagement of government, reliance on selfhelp at home and abroad and a limit to American involvement in foreign affairs. He did this by taking the language and approach that John F. Kennedy had used at the same podium 12 years ago but turned the meaning around so completely that he repudiated the philosophy of government that Democratic Presidents had brought to Washington for fourfour decades.

title: Olympic Aide Is Slain
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 20 (Reuters)Arthur Forster, vice chairman of the South African Olympic Association, was stabbed to death last night by a man who attempted to rob him.

title: ANAYA KNOCKS OUT PINDER FOR TITLE
description: PANAMA CITY, Jan. 20 (UPI)Romeo Anaya of Mexico knocked out Enrique Pinder of Panama in the third round tonight to win the World Boxing Association's bantamweight title.

title: SHOP TALK
description: CEDAR GROVEParis, Rome and Seventh Avenue fashions notwithstanding, jeans for teenagers are still inand a lot cheaper than many of their fancy domestic and foreign cousins.

title: Naive, ingenious, dispassionate and biased solutions
description: The ArabIsraeli conflict, a contributor to this newspaper wrote recently, is developing into a monumental bore. The reason is not hard to find: there is no more certain formula for tedium than repetitious, selfrighteous sophistry, and these are precisely the qualities which the literature of the Arab  Israeli conflict bestows so bountifully on the wouldbe curious. Of four recent Middle East studies, two fit naturally enough into this tradition, but two others seem strangely interesting.

title: Scott and McDonald Gain Title Court Tennis Final
description: BOSTON, Jan. 20  Gene Scott and Robert McDonald, both of New York, gained the final round of the United States open court tennis championship today at the Boston Racquet and Tennis Club.

title: JEWISH IDENTITY IS TOPIC IN BERLIN
description: BERLIN, Jan. 20The young Berlin Jew shook his head in mock despair. All right, he said, now I know I am alienated. But how does that help me feel any better?

title: Pistol Found at Site Of Muslim Slayings Is Linked to Holdup
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) A pistol found in the Washington, D. C., house where seven members of a Muslim sect were slain Thursday was stolen in a holdup here two weeks ago, the police said today.

title: Aerobee 200 Orbits Earth
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI)Aerobee 200, a sounding rocket with flighttest instruments for the skylab project and the orbiting solar observatory, was placed in orbit today about 150 miles above the earth. The Ames Research Center here said that Aerobee 200, launched yesterday near White Sands, N. M., carried instruments to map Xray radiation from the sun's corona.

title: Olivet Streak Stopped
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Jan. 20 (AP)Kalamazoo rallied for a 5452 college basketball victory today to snap Olivet's 16game conference winning streak in a Michigan Intercollegiate Athletic Association contest.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: When comparative advertisingwhich mentions competitors' products by name gets tougher, the better it will be for the consumer.

title: Letters: The Many Marvels of Bavaria
description: To The Editor: With enjoyment I read through John Brannon Albright's article, The Legacy. of Mad King Ludwig: Wild Castles and Wagner's Music, in the Travel Section of Dec. 3. I have been to the castles and they are as described, albeit the true splendors of those structures will never be conveyed by words alone.

title: BIG 6 MAYORS SCORE GOVERNOR'S BUDGET
description: The Mayors of the States's six biggest cities attacked Governor Rockefeller's proposed $8.88billion budge yesterday saying that it failed to respond to the needs of local governments.

title: Soviet Satellite Launched
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union has launched a new artificial satellite, Cosmos 544, in its space research program, the Tass press agency announced today.

title: Sports Week
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: William G. Ballantine to Marry Constance McLeod on Feb. 3
description: ROSEVILLE, Minn., Jan. 20 Dr. and Mrs. John A. McLeod have announced that their daughter, Miss Constance McLeod, and William Gay Ballantine plan to many on Feb. 3. The futute bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Ballantine of Durango, Colo., editors and publishers of The Durango Herald. Dr. McLeod is assistant professor of family practice at the University of Minnesota Medical School.

title: Labor
description: WASHINGTON  The Secretary of Labor designate said it was pure coincidence. But what a dramatic stroke of good fortune it was that Peter J. Brennan was able to call a press conference on the very eve of his appearance at confirmation hearings of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare committee to announce that he, personally, had arranged a truce in the sevenweeklong strike against the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Music: Early Beethoven
description: In 1800, at the age of 30, Beethoven came to the end of a chapter in his composing life and never again returned to the material and style that had made it sparkle. He stopped writing chamber music for woodwind instruments and in doing so abandoned a medium that had drawn from him much ingratiating melody and colorful scoring.

title: Racial Change Slashes Valuesand
description: PHILADELPHIAWhen Howard and Mary Hurtig moved here from Atlanta in 1970, they wanted to live in a racially integrated neighborhood.They were delighted to find that as many blacks as whites owned spacious, luxurious stone houses in Wynnefield, a triangleshaped corner of West Philadelphia that offers enviable beauty as well as convenience to downtown.

title: ZIMMERMANN WORK GIVEN U.S. PREMIERE
description: Bernd Alois Zimmermann, a German composer who died in 1970, is not yet as well known in this country as he should be, His Stille and Urnkehr for chamber orchestra, which received its first American performance Friday night in Tully Hall by the Juilliard Orchestra, made an impressive, moving impression. Seven and a half minutes long, it is scored for winds in fours, a small string ensemble weighted toward the bottom and a discreetly exotic assemblage of percussion. The dynamics are prevailingly hushed, with fragmentary coloristic figurations embellishing a recurrent jazz rhythm on the side drum and an always pervasive if not al ways sounded note of D. The idiom seems far removed from the brilliantly aggressive serialism that marked his opera, Die Soldaten, but the piece makes a similarly strong, individual impact. Written only a few weeks before Mr. Zimmermann's death, it perhaps inevitably hints at a meditative acceptance of the end.

title: Foreman, Facing Frazier Tomorrow Nigh Seeks Success Where All Failed
description: HOW RIVALS COMPARE

title: MEDICAL COMPLEX PLANNED IN HOUSTON
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 20 (AP)A planned $200million doctors center has been announced by K. S. (Bud) Adams, owner of the Houston Oilers football team.

title: Group of Scientists Warns Against Ending Ban on CancerCausing Food Additives
description: A group of scientists has warned against scrapping a controversial law that prohibits the use of cancercausing food additives. If anything, they said, the law should be strengthened and expanded to include cancerinducing chemicals in air, water and other aspects of the human environment.

title: Music
description: MODERN music? It is indeed Procrustean bed that can take into its covers, simultaneously, the newest work of Pierre Boulez and the magic theater of ForemanSilverman. The Boulez work, . . . explosante/fixe . . ., received its world premiere in Tully Hall on Jana 5, under the auspices of its commissioning agent, the Chamber Music. Society of Lincoln Center. Boulez is one of the leaders of the international avantgarde, and everybody in the audience knew more or less what to expect. Nor were they disappointed. But Doctor Selavy 8 Magic Theater, Which has been running at the Mercer Arts Center for a while, and which has been put together by Richard Foreman, with music by Stanley Silverman, was also promptly called avantgarde, and that raises some questions.

title: PakistanChina Flights
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 20 Pakistan International Airlines began operating twiceweekly service from Karachi and Islamabad to Peking today.

title: The President
description: WASHINGTON  As Richard Nixon stood atop the temporary stands outside the east front of the Capitol, he looked out over a massive audience composed of contributors, Congressmen and other allies. He could neither see nor hear the sullen crowd of demonstrators gathered near Union Station several blocks away to protest the lingering Vietnam war.

title: Winter Green
description: You are most aware of them on a gray winter day with a raw wind blowing. Walking, you come to an old hillside meadow with a rocky slope beyond, and there are the hemlocks among the rocks with the white pines spilling down the slope and taking over the meadow. There are scattered hardwoods, too, on up the slope; but they stand gray and bare to the wind. It is the pines and the hemlocks that catch the eye.

title: Blast in Osaka Injures 71
description: OSAKA, Japan, Jan. 20 (Reuters)Seventyone people were injured17 seriouslyin an explosion at a paintmaking factory here today, the police reported.

title: A Taste for Artifice
description: THE exhibition called The Painterly Photograph, 18901914, which Weston Naef (with the assistance of Suzanne Boorsch) has organized at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, consists of 65 photographic prints drawn from the personal collection of Alfred Stieglitz that forms part of the permanent, one hopescollection of the museum. It Is the kind of exhibition that gives us an exceptionally vivid glimpse of a particular period, and not primarily because of its visual documentation of people and places (though the show contains plenty of revelations of that kind) but because of the highly selfconscious implementation of an esthetic attitude which it reveals.

title: Point of View
description: HONG KONG  Asia's share in world trade, which is still dominated by the big industrial countries remains small  most certainly less than 10 per cent. For the most part poor and predominantly agricultural, Asian countries rarely have the purchasing power to import either consumer goods or industrial machinery. The exports they can offer are primary products, for which the terms of trade have been in longrun decline for the past 10 years.

title: Food Labels
description: WASHINGTONBack in the Gay Nineties, Congress passed a bill to insure that tea be tested for puritya simple act that has evolved into a giant umbrella of laws over a maze of consumer products. Last week, responding to increasing complaints that the umbrella was leaky, the Federal Food and Drug Administration moved to tighten existing controls over the contents of foodstuffs, mainly through a dozen new relabeling practices.

title: Singapore, Switzerland of the East
description: SINGAPORE The Singapore Government is battling with the kind of problem that almost every other country in the world wishes it hadhow to maintain a rate of growth in gross national product of 11 per cent.

title: Rockefeller Appoints a Panel on Electric Power
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20  The appointment of a sevenmember committee on electric power research to advise the State Atomic and Space Development Authority on the development of electric power resources compatible with the environment was announced by Governor Rockefeller today.

title: The Budget
description: ALBANY  The state's annual fiscal roundelay began last week with Governor Rockefeller's submission of his proposed $8.88billion budget for the state fiscal year that begins April 1. The 15th budget submitted by Mr. Rockefeller since he got a hammerlock on the Governor's chair in 1958, it is also the largest in the state's history.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE nation's economy is off to a fast start this year, maintaining the strong momentum that gathered force in the final quarter of 1972, but that glowing fact is creating no particular excitement. Much more significant events seem to at hand.

title: City Is Cracking Down on Scofflaws With OutofState Plates, and It Is Costing Them Sizable Sums
description: The city's Parking Violations Bureau carne upon a case last September of an East 78th Street business executive who had accumulated nearly 200 unpaid parking tickets here on four cars that were registered in Vermont.

title: Dave Anderson
description: O, say, can you see that in the current controversy over the national anthem in sports, patriotism isn't the issue. Habit is.

title: Policewoman Subdues a Gunman at Air Terminal
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 20 (UPI)A policewoman subdued early today a young soldier, absent without leave, who sprayed a crowded airport terminal with shotgun pellets and then tried to hijack a jetliner.

title: INDIANA TOPPLES MINNESOTA, 8371
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind, Jan. 20 (AP)Indiana scored 12 straight points midway in the final half and 8 straight at the finish in beating sixthranked Minnesota, 8371, and moving to a tie for first in the Big Ten today.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  A revealing glimpse into President Nixon's state of mind on the inflation issue is provided by an unreported episode connected with the announcement of the Phase 3 program of wage and price control, or decontrol.

title: It's a Graffito in Latin, And It's a Palindrome
description: ROME, Jan. 20Scholars of antiquity and addicts of word play rejoice!

title: Circassians Keeping Traditions Alive
description: HALEDONMuchir Abaza leaped into the air and, with a graceful sweep of his arm, plunged a dagger into the wooden floor.

title: More Short Stories, Fewer Short Stories
description: For some years now, I have begun each new semester by asking writing students what magazines they read. As recently as eight or ten years ago, they favored The New Yorker and other magazines which publish fiction and book reviews fairly regularly. Now most of them look at me uncomprehendingly when I mention that magazine or Harper's or the Atlantic, or The Nation and New Republic and Commentary and the Sunday Times. Those are periodicals that they see when they are home on vacation, if they have parents who subscribe to one or two of them. What do the students themselves read? A news magazine, Time or perhaps Newsweek, which they can get on a cheap student sub, Rolling Stone, maybe the Village Voice, occasionally Playboy or Esquire, and some underground comics.

title: 8 Feign Insanity in Test And Are Termed Insane
description: STANFORD, Calif., Jan. 20Can the sane be distinguished from the insane in psychiatric hospitals?

title: Where Do We Go From Here?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Now that President Nixon has been sworn in for four more years, and the Vietnam war is about to be sworn out, what are the chances for reconciliation in America, or at least for a period of comparative calm?

title: Community Role On Drugs Urged
description: MONTCLAIR  Drugprevention programs can be effective only if they are backed by the community and if the young people they are trying to reach are involved directly in planning such projects.

title: A Transcript of President Nixon's Second Inaugural Address to the Nation
description: Following is the transcript of President Nixon's second inaugural address, as recorded yesterday by The New York Times:

title: Cleveland Mayor Fighting Order on Nazi Armbands
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 20Members of the National Socialist White People's party, also known as the American Nazi party, have won a Federal court order permitting them to wear swastika armbands while attending Cleveland City Council meetings. But getting to the meetings is a different problem.

title: Vandals Start King Manor Fire
description: King Manor a historical landmark in Jamaica, Queens, was saved from destruction last week by an alert benchsitter.

title: Ecologists Chided as Anticity at Parley
description: The language of ecology is being increasingly used to justify keeping the poor out of the suburbs, a number of planners and activists charged at a national conference on the Environment of the Open Society here last week.

title: 6Mile Dam Planned for Leningrad to Put an End to Years of Baltic Flooding
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20Almost every year Leningrad is threatened with flooding, and Soviet engineers have now begun work on an ambitious project to protect the nation's second largest city once and for all against the constant inroads of the Baltic Sea.

title: Computer Link Helps Colleges
description: NEW BRUNSWICKBorn amid strife a few years ago, New Jersey's college computer network has grown into a system serving students, faculty and administrators of 26 member institutions.

title: George C. Marshall
description: The third volume of Forrest Pogue's biography of George C. Marshall covers the culminating phase in its subject's career. The later yearsthose of the China mission and of Marshall's service as Secretary of State and Secretary of Defensewere clouded by controversy, and during them he was subjected to abuse and calumny by ambitious and unprincipled men. But the years 194345 were years of fulfillment, during which the greatest of American Chiefs of Staff saw the army that he had raised committed to the struggle against the Axis, in accordance with the strategical plan that he had devised and persuaded his allies to accept.

title: Republic Is to Hire Thousands on L. I.
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I.The small main lobby at the Republic Division of Fairchild Industries was packed by 9 A.M. last Friday. In two and a half hours, some 65 persons filled out applications kfor employment on the largest aerospace project assigned to a Long Island company in nearly a decadethe Air Force A10A close support fighter.

title: STOCKTON VICTOR OVER ALEXANDER
description: MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP)  UnSeeded Dick Stockton was guaranteed his biggest payday as a professional today by defeating John Alexander 63, 62, in the semifinals of the $50,000 Saga Bay tennis tournament, a World Championship Tennis event.

title: HORACE G. OLIVER
description: LEONIA, N. J., Jan. 20Horace G. Oliver, who retired as an account executive in 1963 for Hornblower & Weeks, the Stock Exchange firm since merged to become Hornblower & WeeksHemphill & Noyes, died Thursday in Englewood Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In his article Controls Meeting Wide Popularity [National Economic Survey, Jan. 7], Hendrik S. Houthakker concluded that labor and business are supporting wageprice controls because these controls undermine market competition. He drew analogies between the current wageprice control program and the programs of regulatory agencies which, he said, act as substitutes for competition.

title: Philadelphia Pair Triumphs
description: BOSTON, Jan. 20William J. Clothier and Bert O'Neil of Philadelphia won the United States senior amateur court tennis doubles championship today by defeating Dr. Carl Fischer and Hastings Griffin, also of Philadelphia, 61, 46, 61, 61, at the Boston Rocquet and Tennis Club.

title: Animal Hospitals Offer Care on a 24Hour Basis
description: VERONA  Public demand for better health care is well known. Not so well known is the fact that the public is demanding better health care for their petsand getting it.

title: Wealth Gap Widens in Asia
description: HONG KONG  The contrasts between rich man and poor man seem starker in Asia than anywhere else. While some of its countries were achieving spectacular industrial growth last year, others were gripped by hunger amid a vast rice shortage.

title: Owen Wingrave Reborn
description: MENOTITS The Old Maid and the Thief has been around for so long as a stage piece that most people have forgotten that it was written for radio. The same composer's Amahl and the Night Visitors was commissioned by the NBCTV Opera, and it has had enough repetitions on the video screen to keep its origins in mind,, But it, too, has found a home in the theater and opera house. One or two other operas that began their existence in a television studio have been reborn onstage, and this is happening now to Benjamin Britten's Owen Wingrave. His operatic version of the Henry James story was written for the British Broadcasting Corporation, premiered on TV in England in 1971 and premiered here by WNET Opera Theater shortly thereafter. This spring it will be produced at Covent Garden. Americans will also be able to see it on a stage next summer, for it will figin the of the Santa Fe Opera.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: REGISTRATION is now going on at the School of Visual Arts, 209 East 23d Street, for a group of photography courses that is being offered during this coming spring semester, which starts on San. 29. There will be 16 classes in still photography and seven in film making. The photography courses will include a number of basic classes, several intermediate workshops, two on blackandwhite printing, and others on color, the nude, commercial photography and similar related topics. The film courses range from an Introductory course to several on directing, animation, television and advanced cinematography. All classes will meet from 6:40 to 9:40 P.M. from Monday through Thursday nights, and most are limited to 20 students. Tuition charges are from $100 to $135 for each. For more inthe above address, or call (212) OR 97350.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: From Philadelphia to Los Angeles and from Minneapolis to Jacksonville new office buildings are rising to change the skylines of metropolitan areas around the country.

title: Point of View
description: The much discussed trade imbalance between Japan and the United States appears to have almost peaked out. If we can maintain the current emphasis on bringing about a more balanced trade, we will be well along the road to stable and mutually beneficial economic relations, not only with our biggest trading partner, the United States, but also with other countries.

title: Dominions' Links To Britain Strained
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Sir Morrice James, British High Commissioner (Ambassador) in Australia, thinks Britain and Australia and New Zealand are still a happy family.

title: Nation Without Power
description: If anyone still needs evidence that this country's jerrybuilt system for supply and distribution of fuels and energy has collapsed, look around. From the Rocky Mountains to the Atlantic, schools and factories are threatened daily with midwinter closedowns for lack of heating oil. As emergency stocks become available, trucking lines find themselves so short of diesel fuel that they may not be able to deliver what there is. Were it not for a fortuitous few days of unseasonable warmth, the Northeast would be an icy disaster area.

title: Nancy Gough Byrne Is Married To Ens. John Robert Hammett
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 20Miss Nancy Gough Byrne and Ens. John Robert Hammett, U.S.N., were married here this afternoon in the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Joseph H. Gilmore.

title: Congressmen Hail Theme But Ask for More Details
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Members of the Congress that has challenged President Nixon to share governmental authority fidgeted through his second inauguration today and then applauded its theme but pleaded for specifics of his program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 23 Men on Liferaft, One Bet From Disaster
description: There are 23 men in the room, neatly dressed and proud, but they huddle around the table like shipwreck survivors on a sharkthreatened liferaft.

title: School Safety Study Urges Deemphasis Of Punitive Factors
description: Any safety program in the New York City school system must emphasize human relations factors rather than punitive factors if it is to have longrange benefits, according to a study released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: State's Relief Rolls Down 2% Lavine Discerns Stabilization
description: A continuing decline in relier rolls across New York Statedown 39,546 persons, or 2 per cent, from last March's record has led Abe Lavine, State Commissioner of Social Services, to describe the situation a trend toward stabilization.

title: New & Novel
description: The Scent Of Apples

title: Dotty signs of spring
description: Spots in front of your eyes? Its not necessarily flu. Polka dots are making their annual appearance, adding a little spice to the winter scene. Blue dots. Black dots. Brown dots. They all breakout into pleats on dresses with their own cardigans or suits so soft they're almost dresses. If they infect you with spring fever, well then, dash over to the bank for some credit and go on a shopping spree. A yelllow Jaguar XKE perhaps? Or how about a new Steinway? You can dream, can't you? And if the fever lingers on, just remember: If polka dots are here, can spring be far behind?

title: Cards Will Select 5th in Draft
description: DALLAS, Jan. 20 (AP)Don Coryell, new coach of the St. Louis Cardinals, got his team off to a fine start today with victories over San Diego, Buffalo and Chicago in the National Football League lottery for order of firstround draft selections.

title: Young L.I. Legislator Looking Ahead
description: BAY SHORE, L.I.Thomas J. Downey, believed to be the youngest elected official in the state, began his second year in the Suffolk County Legislature recently and stopped to review his new career.

title: Hardcore grows fashionableand very profitable
description: With a budget of $25,000, a handful of $75to$100aday actors and actresses and a vivacious, gifted sexual performer he signed to a year's contract, Gerard Damiano, a veteran pornographic film producer, spent six days early this year shooting a 35 mmcolor film in Miami.

title: ChineseSupported Rebels Gain in Burma
description: RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 20 (UPI)A Chinesebacked insurgent army has seized a sizable amount of territory in northeast Burma and is expanding its influence south toward the Golden Triangle border area with Thailand and Laos, according to informed intelligence sources here.

title: AEROS TOP BLAZERS ON 4GOAL RALLY, 43
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) The Houston Aeros, spurred by a secondperiod brawl, battled back from a threegoal deficit today to defeat the Philadelphia Blazers, 43, in a World Hockey Association contest.

title: Music Orgy: Doing Six Bach Concertos
description: DUTCH NECKTo Elmer and Beatrice Reinthaler, making music is almost as vital as breathing.

title: Harvest of Black Bears State's Lowest in Years
description: ALBANY (UPI)  In 1972 hunters took fewer black bears than they had in recent previous years.

title: The Biographer's Trip to the Pas Is Dj Vu with a Difference
description: ENRY JAMES was the archetypal American flaneur in Europe, loitering elegantly in many cities, visiting country houses, assiduously searching out old ways. His life, from 1843 to 1916, began in the era of the stagecoach and ended in the age of the motor car; and he had had, in that leisurely Victorian world, the patience and personal vision that so many of us have lost. We whiz over the world at 35,000 feet and look at beauty through camera lenses. James, the master of mores, always had his Murray in his hand, and he read whatevery was related to the genius loci.

title: Radosta of Times Wins Two Awards for Writing
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 20 John S. Radosta of the New York Times sports department won two prizes today in the annual writing competition of the Eastern Motorsports Press Association. One was a first prize in the column category and the other was a second prize in the spot news division.

title: The spirit of '76
description: Kenneth O'Donnell, David Powers and Joe McCarthy are practitioners of an old and honorable literary form. Neither history, nor literature, nor memoir, it is rather the publicrelations release or directmail, salesbrochure form  here executed in epic length, sold through retail outlets just as though it were a real book, and currently insinuating its way up the bestseller lists.

title: CHICAGO TEACHERS OFFERED NEW PACT
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP)The Chicgo school board made a new contract offer today to striking teachers that included the teachers' union demand for a 2 per cent pay rise, one of three major issues in the dispute that has closed the city's schools since Jan. 10.

title: A. B. Smith 3d And Miss Kidd Plan Marriage
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Adm. Isaac Campbell Kidd Jr., Chief of Naval Matriel, and Mrs. Kidd have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Angelique, de Golian Kidd, to Alan Bronson Smith 3d, a lawyer with the Department of Justice here. He is the son of Col. A. Bronson Smith Jr., U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Smith of Columbus, Ohio, and Bay View, Mich.

title: G. R. Medalie Fiance Of Betty Diane Slavin
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 20 Miss Betty Diane Slavin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Slavin, plans to be married here in July to George Robert Medalie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Medalie of Scarsdale, N. Y. The parents of the bridetobe have announced the engagement.

title: Taiwanese Investors Show a New Confidence
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  An American importer visiting Taiwanese textile mills a year ago found the Taiwanese preferred to keep their finances relatively liquid rather than reinvest in needed new machinery. The gloomy atmosphere stemmed more from Taiwan's expulsion from the United Nations and other diplomatic difficulties, he said, than from the newly imposed American textile quota.

title: Hawks Overcome Cavaliers, 96 to 84
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 20 (UPI)The Atlanta Hawks blew two big leads but saved a 9684 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: A Castle of Bone
description: A huge sow with hanging dugs bursts squealing from a cupboard which, a moment before, contained only an old pigskin wallet. So begins an exhilarating, troubling book, unlike any other, and unforgettable. Certainly, it is for children, and about children: Ones who say Jesus!, scratch their groins, have far more complicated feelings than children in books are usually given credit for, and whomthough we aren't told their ages, last names, parents' jobs, or what town they live inwe end up knowing better than we do many people in real life.

title: BISHOPS REQUEST BREAK FROM SPAIN
description: MADRID, Jan. 20  The Roman Catholic Church of Spain, closely involved witt Spanish political regimes foi centuries, completed approval today of a document backing separation from the state except for financial aid.

title: From West to East by Rail
description: HELSINKIA rail transport land bridge linking Europe and Japan across the vast stretches of Siberia is beginning to attract attention as a viable alternative to longer and more traditional sea routes.

title: Health
description: WASHINGTONThe millions of Americans who smoke cigarettes were offered another reason last week for kicking the habit. In its annual report to Con gress on the subject, the Public Health Service gave new substance to the charges that the cigarette is a hazard to babies not yet born.

title: Two Stars on One Knick Door
description: Special recognition has finally come to Dave DeBusschere and Bill Bradley, the Knick roommates. When the 23d National Basketball Association AllStar game is played Tuesday night in Chicago Stadium, DeBusschere will be a starter for the East for the first time and Bradley will play in his first allstar game.

title: Nancy Schoeffler Planning to Marry
description: HALESITE, L. I. Jan. 20 Mr. and Mrs. John W. Schoeffler of Halesite have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Louise Schoeffler, to Gordon Semmes Walmsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Miller Welmsley of New Orleans. A wedding in June is planned.

title: OneWay Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20A woman in Oklahoma writes that she caught herself talking to her cat recently and has been worried ever since about whether her sanity is failing.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Everyone likes shortcuts In a recent issue of Horticulture, Earl H. New, from Middle Tennessee State University, Murfreesboro, describes his quick way to root African violet leaves and cuttings of episcia.He uses the Jiffy 7 Peat discs, which when soaked in water for a few minutes, swell to form a peatpot. Mr. New suggests dropping the peat pellet into a sandwichsize plastic bag and adding water sufficient to make it swell. (Try a halfcup at first). Then to be sure there is not too much moisture in the pellet, squeeze gently to remove excess water.

title: BOY BURIED IN BOX SAVED BY HUNTERS
description: NANSEMOND, Va., Jan. 20 (UPI)Police searched the. Tidewater area of Virginia today for a Portsmouth man wanted for the apparent kidnapping assault of a 13yearold boy held captive eight days in an underground plywood box.

title: Headliners
description: I would not try to critique what Governor Rockefeller said to his legislature, said Governor Cahill of New Jersey last week. But in his response to a reporter's question, Mr. Cahill (left) took issue with proposals that convicted drug pushers be given mandatory life sentences. Mr. Rockefeller made just such a proposal two weeks agoand some New Jersey legislators are considering taking the same tack. Differentiating between pusherentrepreneurs and pusheraddicts, Mr. Cahill suggested that those favoring harsher treatment must realize that the addicted pusher would do anything, regardless of the penalties, to support his habit.

title: Boat Show Lists Start On Friday
description: Get your boat shoes and sneakers out. The National Boat Show takes over the Coliseum at 5 P.M. next Friday for a 10day run. That means 200,000 square feet of exhibit space and 2 miles of aisles to cover if you want to see the latest in powerboats, sailboats, inflatable boats, accessories for boats, engines and instruments and many of the celebrities in the sport.

title: 5 More Cardinals Sign
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (UPI)The St. Louis Cardinals neared the halfway mark in signing their 40man roster today when five more players agreed to terms for 1973. The five are Rich Folkers and Charlie Hudson, pitchers; Ray Busse and Dwain Anderson, shortstops, and Mark Hill, a catcher. The Cards now have signed 18 players, including three who received more than $100,000Bob Gibson, Joe Torre and Lou Brock.

title: Miss Michele Carver McKellar Is Fiancee of Paul T. DuVivier
description: FREDERICK, Md., Jan. 20  Mr. and Mrs. Forrest B. MacKellar of Frederick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Michele Carver MacKellar, to Paul Trimble DuVivier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Fuller DuVivier of Washington and L. I.

title: WOODCOCK LEAVES DEMOCRATIC POST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Citing the pressure of union business, Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers, has stepped down as head of the. Democratic party's delegate selection review panel for its quadrennial national conventions.

title: UConn Six Tops Holy Cross
description: STORRS, Conn., Ja. 20 (AP) The University of Connecticut defeated Holy Cross, 64, in hockey tonight.

title: Picket for Prostitution
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 20 (UPI)A heavyset woman carrying sign advocating legalized prostitution was the lone picket who showed up for the opening of the Hawaii Legislature last Wednesday.

title: El Paso's Own Energy Crisis
description: HOUSTON  Across the nation, evidence mounts that fuel supplies are running thin.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
Metropolitan Briefs
description: A private foundation has given the state a 146acre tract of land in the Adirondack Park between Lake Placid and Ray Brook in Essex County, Governor Rockefeller's office in Albany announced yesterday. The gift was made by the Simon and Annie Davis Foundation of New York City in memory of its late president, Abraham Davis.

title: Photography
description: ONE thing you will surely find at the Metropolitan Museum's new exhibition, The Painterly Photograph, 18901914, is lots and lots of Maurice Maeterlinck charm. There are misty forests lit by a crepuscular light. There are wan and delicate ladies clad in medieval gowns and suffering strange and indescribable sorrows. There are mysterious naked people, both male and female, who are certainly not to be touched, or scarcely even seen, since they are always hiding their faces and vanishing into mysterishadows.

title: ...The Completion
description: WASHINGTONThe Administration signaled last week that the Vietnam war was about over. Henry Kissinger, the White House announced, would return to Paris this Tuesday for the purpose of completing the text of an agreement. Although caution was still the rule, most Washington observers were ready to believe that the longsought agreement was finally near.

title: Business Discovers Pacific Islands
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Except for developers of tourism and dealers in such exotic commodities as natural pearls, trochus shells and coconut products, the international business conununity through the years has been content to leave the South Pacific islands to specialists and wandering traders.

title: Manager of Soviet Factory in Urals Airs Complaints
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20  A Soviet factory manager has warned that Soviet consumers are going to have to wait decade for a sufficient supply of household airconditioners because one ministry wants to monopolize the production.

title: Had Powerful Post
description: Mr. Allen, whose Congressional career included terms as senior Republican member and chairman of the powerful. House Rules Committee, was also a member of the Committee on Committees and of the Joint Republican Steering Committee.

title: Pop Folk Poets A Band of Loners
description: AMERICA is still a land of loners, for all the homogenization of the plastic culture and the retribalization of the electronic culture. And nowhere do those loners breed more tenaciously than in the field of folkpop. The hillsand the cities, tooare full of wandering minstrels, itinerant instrumentalists and allpurpose musical eccentrics. College campuses, at least on warm days, are full of them, picking and wailing in a variety of more or less authentic indigenous idioms. They glorify the land and its people in a way that might give great comfort to Mr. Nixon, if only he and the other politicians full of rhetoric about bringing us together could get past the pervasive antiestablishment sentiments of their songs.

title: The Dance
description: To a large extent, the dance groups that appear usually in the concert series at the LouisNikolais Theater Lab derive their training or their inspiration from choreographers Alwin Nikolais or Murray Louis. Friday night's concert at the Lab (344 West 36th Street) offered a change in the form of Dances We Dance, a program by Betty Jones and Fritz Ludin.

title: Great Swarnp Jazz Band Gets an Indoor Home
description: BRIELLE  The Great Swamp Jazz Band will come in out of the cold next weekend. For most of the past year, the sixman group has been playing at such outdoor shopping centers, the opening of a bank and what the band's coleader, Mark Heter, refers.to.as the opening of a bit of pavement (a mall in Hackehsack).

title: Mrs. Towsley Is Rewed Here
description: In the chapel at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday morning, Mrs. Alice Catherine Towsley was married to Col. Charles Kissam Allen, U.S.A., retired. The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay performed the ceremony.

title: ASHER OUTBOWLS JOHNSON IN FINAL
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 20Barry Asher, who had been sixth and second in two previous events this year, captured the $77,777 Showboat invitation bowling tournament today. The triumph, Asher's seventh in Professional Bowlers Association competition, was worth $11,111, to him.

title: Dance: Special Way With Sylphides
description: The American Ballet Theater has always had a special way with Michel Fokine's Les Sylphides. This was the last production of the ballet to be personally supervised by Fokine himself, and it was the very first ballet on Ballet Theater's very first program.

title: RICHARD HARRITY, PLAYWRIGHT, DIES
description: Richard Harrity, playwright and author, who had been the American National Theater and Academy's television producer in 194748, died Friday of a heart ailment in Franklin, N.H., where he lived. His age was 65.

title: REAGAN NOMINEE TO COURT OPPOSED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20Gov. Ronald Reagan's nomination of his former executive secretary to a vacancy on the California State Supreme Court has drawn criticism from some lawyers and law school faculty members who question the nominee's qualifications.

title: The World
description: LONDONPrime Minister Edward Heath unveiled his new longrange plans for combating inflation last week and it all looked so Nixonlike that some people in London suggested a possible infringement of American copyright laws.

title: The program called for fun By Norma Skurka
description: Architects use the word program to describe what it is that clients tell them they need in a house. From it, they carve out the interiors and design the shell that is the exterior to produce an environment tailored to that family's lifestyle. The owners of this second home in the Hamptons told architects Gwathmey & Siegel that they were an active family with three children who liked swimming, sunning, playing basketball. There would be weekend guests, both children and adults. They would need a room for a maid or overseer for the children. And the owners needed solitude occasionally, a place to be by themselves. It was a complex program, says Charles Gwathmey, yet the house is remarkably simple, a rectangle that honestly expresses the program. The house has few windows on the entrance side. This insures privacy. The back is a wall of windows opening on a dining terrace, deck and swimming pool with views of a pond and the ocean beyond. The interiors are crisply modern. Most furnishings are builtin and the colors are clear and bright. A 35foot skylighted ramp rise through the center of the house.

title: 25,000 Volunteers to Aid Cerebral Palsy Telethon
description: Twentyfive thousand people in eight citiesan army of volunteers for charityare preparing to take part next weekend in what has become a massive annual mobilization for charity: the Greater New York United Cerebral Palsy telethon.

title: Paterson School Aids the Deprived
description: PATERSON  For the 4yearold who Can easily reach the pintsized handle on the big front door, for the secondgrader who learns counting by clambering over a shiny gym horse and for the parents of both, who become as important as professionals in their children's education, the Dale Avenue Early Childhood Education Center spells success where failure was often implied.

title: Exalting Lovely Flounder
description: Flounder is prolific, but it need not be prosaic. Preparation normally reserved for its exalted cousin, the sole, can be as successful for flounder. Its abundance may keep the price within reach.

title: Tass Stresses Peace
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The Soviet press agency Tass reported the inauguration of President Nixon today in a 350word dispatch from Washington that stressed the President's references to world peace and to domestic policies.

title: Panel Analyzes Japan's Trade
description: Four business executives, two Japanese and two Americans headquartered in Tokyo, met last month with The New York Times bureau chief, Richard Halloran, to discuss Japanese economic problems, particularly trade relations with the United States. Excerpts from their discussion follow:

title: Mediate Wins at Lincoln
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Jan. 20 (AP) Mediate won the $5,000 Foster Purse today at Lincoln Downs. Mediate scored by 1 lengths over Persian Warrior and paid $18. The sevenfurlong event was timed in 1:33 3/5. Darien Fats, the 910 favorite who finished third, broke a leg and had to be destroyed after a fall just beyond the finish line.

title: Bangladesh Convalesces
description: NEW DELHIBangladesh, born a year ago as a result of war with Pakistan, survives economic chaos largely because of international aid. Almost everything  food, industrial raw material and consumer goodsmust come from outside.

title: Police in Suffolk Recover $30,000 in Stolen Gold Wire
description: BAYSHORE, L. I., Jan. 20 A stolen shipment of gold wire and gold paste used in the aerospace industry and valued at $30,000 was recovered last night with the arrest of a truck driver at the Bayshore Inn motel here, according to Samuel Fierro, chief of the Suffolk County rackets bureau.

title: A New Path for Shostakovich?
description: WITH the death of Stravinsky, Shostakovich may well be, alas, the World's Greatest Living Composer. And, again alas, his new Symphony No. 15, available in recordings from Moscow and Philadelphia, may well be one of Shostakovich's most significant works. The 15th, completed in 1971 and at first touted as an enigma, turns out to be a thinly disguised recapitulation of the composer's artistic life, in the personal genre of Mahier's late symphonies, Berlioz's Symphonic fantastique or Strauss's Sinfonia Domestics. It is neither as transfiguringly grand as the best Mahler nor as banal as the Strauss (to bracket the issue), but it does succeed as do few recent works in sustaining its musical thought over a traditionally symphonic time span. That achievement alone is worth noting.

title: State Awards Contract To Elevate L.I.R.R.
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20 (AP)The State Department of Transportation has awarded a $26million contract for the elevation of 3.3 miles of the Long Island Rail Road, Governor Rockefeller's office announced today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Democrats Pick Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Joe Carter, press secretary and aide to the Governor of Oklahoma, will become communications director for the Democratic National Committee, the committee announced today.

title: EDUCATING NEEDY GOAL OF ORT PLAN
description: The American ORT Federation announced a fiveyearplan yesterday to give needy children in Israel, particularly those of African and Asian Jewish background, a vocational high school education.

title: VICTOR SHEN IS DEAD; BRIDGE CHAMPION, 64
description: Victor Shen, one of New York's leading bridge players, died Friday of a heart attack at his home, 251 West 74th Street. He was 64 years old.

title: The Oldest Postwar People
description: The unique generation gap was manifest on the college campuses in the late 1960's, when the senior citizens of a new generation looked with horror on what their elders had wrought, and clamored, often with more vigor than wisdom, for their own role.

title: Bench Is Recovered And Eager for Action
description: Johnny Bench appears completely recovered from last month's lung surgery and promises that he will be in active competition by the first week in February.

title: Criminals At Large
description: When Martin Smith's Gypsy in Amber was published, about a year and a half ago, it made a strong impression, an impression now reinforced by CANTO FOR A GYPSY (Putnam's, $4.95). Roman Grey, the gypsy antiques dealer who is the hero of Smith's series, is to the gypsy world what Harry Kemelman's Rabbi David Small is to Judaism. Both solve crimes that confront them; both are walking encyclopedias about their people and their way of life and thought. And all this is not supererogatory; it is germane to the mystery at hand and helps solve it.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: The Legend of John Brown
description: He is one of the enduring American legends. His name will go marching on in fourfour time as long as Americans can carry a tune. But the trouble with legends is that they shorten the focus on a man's life. In legend, John Brown lives only as he appeared in that last act: sweeping across the bridge to Harper's Ferry, Navy Colts in his waistband and bowie knives in his boots, with a puny little army of 21, white and black, to face the armed might of Virginia; a grim, gaunt fanatic, rising 60, trapped like an old lion: and at the end swinging from the gallows which Emerson said he had made more glorious than the cross.

title: Miss Waterhouse Planning Bridal
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Jan. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Richard Waterhouse Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Bradley Waterhouse, to Robert Gunther McCullam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCullam of New Providence.

title: Watergate Jury Sees Parade
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) The sequestered jury in the trial on the breakin at the Democratic National headquarters in the Wategate complex last June received special permission today to watch the inaugural parade. The jury's eight women and four men were clustered at a window of the United States District Courthouse 9n Constitution Avenue near Pennsylvania Avenue when President Nixon's motorcade passed by.

title: Anne Calihan Miller Is Affianced
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 20  Mr. and Mrs. Harold Chalmers Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Calihan Miller, to Charles Shaw Arensberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Covert Arensberg, of Pittsburgh and Trappe, Md.

title: Nobody Called It the Schmidt
description: PARISThe two Italian laborers at work these recent days in the Cour du CommerceSt.Andr know a little something about the dark history of the terrain they're tearing up. But most of the little they know is wrong, which puts them in a class with practically the whole neighborhood.

title: Thomas VBrunkard Dies; Was Secretary to Lehman
description: Thomas V. Brunkard, who was executive secretary to Herbert H. Lehman from 1933 to 1963, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 301 East 66th Street.

title: What Are We To Think of Deep Throat?
description: TRYING to write honestly about pornographic films is like trying to tie one's shoe while walking: it's practically impossible without sacrificing stride and balance and a certain amount of ordinary dignity, the sort one uses with bank tellers who question a signature. Almost any attitude the writer adopts will whirl around and hit him from the other side.
