description: MUSICOLOGY Orazio Vecchi wrote L'Amfiparnaso in the late 1500's (first production, 1594, in Italy) and this has caused some soulsearching among people who worry about such things. Was it the first opera? Was it not? If not the first opera, was it the last preopera, perhaps?

title: Staff of Sold I.B.M. Unit Voices Dismay
description: And I wore a bright pink shirt into the office on Tuesday. They had said to hell with me. In my own childish way I was saying to hell with them.

title: Brain Surgery to Alter Behavior Stirs a Major Medical Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Man's brain is his last citadel of freedom and individuality, but even this is now under assault, according to critics of a practice called psychosurgery.

title: U.S.CHINESE TIES IMPROVE SLOWLY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 21In a year of gradually improving relations, the United States and China have come a long way toward the normalization of trade as well as diplomatic and other contacts.

title: MRS. A. M. CONNEEN JR.
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 21Mrs. Mary McGuiness Conneen, widow of Andrew M. Conneen Jr. who was New York contracting manager for the Bethlehem Steel Company, died yesterday in a nursing home here. She was 82 years old and had lived until 1968 in East Orange, N.J.

title: 1,175 Pupils Will Attend Classes in a New United Nations School Here Today
description: After 25 years of wandering about New York like a refugee being shunted from one country to another, the United Nations International School has finally found a home.

title: Robbers Give Up Vow to Die For Victory and Paradise
description: A twoday ordeal of blazing gunfights, death and terror at a Brooklyn sportinggoods store ended dramatically yesterday afternoon with a daring roof escape by nine remaining hostages and, several hours later, the peaceful surrender of four trapped gunmen.

title: British Aircraft's Chief Here for Concorde Talks
description: LONDON, Jan. 21 (Reuters)The chairman of the British Aircraft Corporation flew to New York today to discuss vitally needed American orders for the Concorde supersonic jet orders that are now said to be in danger of falling through.

title: Whore the Peace Talks Stand: Some Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21President Nixon's statement in his inaugural address yesterday that the Vietnam war was looming to an end was his first public comment on the war since his election, and it reinforced expectations here that a settlement was near. Following is an assessment, in quesionandanswer form, of the current situation.

title: TV: Earthiness Links Pair of A.B.C. Documentaries
description: Two televised documentaries due tonight over the American Broadcasting Company have even more in common than high quality.

title: GEN. KARL DAY, 76, A MARINE AVIATOR
description: EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Jan. 21Lieut. Gen. Karl S. Day, Marine Corps Reserve, retired, a pioneer of Marine Corps aviation, died. Friday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola. He was 76 years old and lived here.

title: W. RUTHERFORD LANE
description: FLAT ROCK, N. C., Jan. 21  W. Rutherford Lane, who founded the Lane Paper Co. in Charlotte, died yesterday. He was 78 years old.

title: University Officials Apprehensive Over the Outside Threats to Their Authority
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21Three years ago, Stanford University students staged an antiwar sitin at the university's administration building. As a last resort, the university called in the Palo Alto police to eject the students, and, in the words of a highranking university administrator, once we invited the police in, we just couldn't get them out.

title: CRAMPTON TAKES GOLF BY 5 SHOTS
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 21 (AP) Bruce Crampton of Australia, who is usually grim and dour as he goes about his work, got so far out in front in the Dean MartinTucson open golf tournament today, that he was smiling. He won by five strokes with a score of 277.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Democratic Struggle
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21  The June Democratic primary for Governor, an election that New Jersey Democratic leaders already have denigrated as a political exercise in futility, is shaping up as another bitter confrontation between the party's regular leaders and a coalition of reform Democrats, most of them from the party's liberal wing. Although most Democratic leaders insisted for the record today that their ultimate objective was the defeat of Governor Cahill's bid for a second term, they concede privately that the chances of defeating the Republican Governor are becoming increasingly difficult and that their immediate and more realistic objective is control of the Democratic party.

title: COMPANIES FEAR LABORCOST RISE
description: Some of the nation's largest manufacturing companies last week indicated their concern over the possibility of a surge in the size of pacesetting labor settlements during the first six months of 1973.

title: Robbers Give Up Vow to Die For Victory and Paradise
description: A twoday ordeal of blazing gunfights, death and terror at a Brooklyn sportinggoods store ended dramatically yesterday afternoon with a daring roof escape by nine remaining hostages and, several hours later, the peaceful surrender of four trapped gunmen.

title: Burning Refuse Is Called A Solution to Fuel Crisis
description: All the talk about the energy crisisoil and gas from Algeria and Russia, a steppedup nuclear power program, solar energy and wayout methods ot producing power  bring nothing but smiles to the face of Robert M. Beningson.

title: Dining Out With the Children
description: Dining out en famille may be a treat for the mother who's stuck in the kitchen or the father with a taste for fine food, but it often holds little charm for their children.

title: Sabbath Laues Is being Tested in Woodstock
description: WOODSTOCK, N. Y., Jan. 21 Chief Constable William Waterous did not have to give a summons to his brother, Herb, the florist, but he did manage to cite or warn most of the town's merchants today in the latest test of the state's controversial Sunday Blue Laws.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SKIEN, Norway, Jan. 21 (AP)Ard Scher, the 1972 triple Olympic gold medalist from the Netherlands, won the $10,000 first prize today in the first European allround professional speedskating championships with 174.913 points.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Of a total of 101,000 new homes and apartments started in New York State last year, 33,50Ualmost onethirdwere in New York City, the State Division of Housing reported yesterday.

title: Advertising: Cigar Rift Grows
description: The news today from along tobacco road is that the makers of big cigars don't want to be tarred (or nicotined either) with the same brush as the makers of little cigars, if any tarring is done.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SOMERSET, N. J., Jan. 21The countdown is at four for Paul Smith, Rutgers Prep's basketball wizard.

title: Pennsy Case Is Lawyers' Dream
description: The Penn Central may not be the greatest railroad in the world, but it is a gravy train for lawyers.

title: Italian Trial of 20YearOld Corruption Scandal Expected to Be Delayed to Death
description: AREZZO, Italy, Jan. 21The biggest trial ever held in Italy is unfolding here in an aura of utter futility.

title: Air Force Doctors Said to Take Part In Indochina Raids
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Two military, physicians have charged that some of their medical colleagues have actively participated in dozens of bombing raids over Southeast Asia, in violation of international law, military regulations and the Hippocratic oath.

title: Danish City Wooed by Neighbors
description: AALBORG, DenmarkOn a hillside visible from the rooftop restaurant of Aalborg's tall new White House Hotel are the tombs of the Viking warriors who established this ancient port city and used it as a base for their raids on England, France and Germany.

title: Red Smith
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 21The tale began two and a half centuries ago on an island called perfidious Albion, history made a oneday stop about half a century ago on the island of Cuba, and now another chapter unfolds on this swatch of mountain and forest thrusting up from the blue Caribbean. Many wonders have come to pass in the long line of succession from James Figg to Joe Frazier, and by no means the least improbable was the choice of this tropical playground for a fistfight between two Olympic champions from the United States for the heavyweight championship of mankind. Yet if the situation seems implausible, the factor that brought it about is easy to understand money. With promoters in New York and elsewhere bidding for the match, a group called National Sports, Ltd., owned principally by the government here, swung a bank loan and put up guarantees $850,000 for Frazier, the unbeaten champion, and $375,000 for George Foreman, his undefeated challenger.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: NIXON IS PRAISED AT CAPITAL RITES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 President Nixon marked the first full day of his second term by serving as host today for 300 inauguration workers and members of his new Administration at a White House worship service.

title: Bigger, Gun, Truth, Protected Physician
description: The wounded gunman he was treating, Dr. Thomas W. Matthew said yesterday, and the gunman's three friends pointed their guns at him every place he moved.

title: NORWEGIAN GAINS FIRST PRO VICTORY
description: HUNTER, N. Y., Jan, 21Otto Tschudl, a former Denver University star by way of Norefjll, Norway, scored his first victory as a professional today by winning the slalom of the $20,000 Benson & Hedges 100's Grand Prix at the Hunter Ski Bowl.

title: Bill Would Release Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Legislation to require Congressional approval for the impoundment of funds by the executive department was introduced by Representative Richard Fulton, Democrat of Tennesee. The bill would require the President to notify Congress within 10 days if appropriated funds are not being spent. Unless approved by both the House and Senate, the impoundment could last no more than 60 days.

title: CREDIT RATES RISE ON A BROAD FRONT
description: The money and capital markets yesterday maintained their negative appraisal of the prospects for combining boomlike economic growth with subdued inflation.

title: ExFoes' Amity Stressed By Pompidou and Brandt
description: PARIS, Jan. 22  Ten years af ter President Charles de Gaulle and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer signed a treaty of friendship between the historic archenemies of continental Europe, their successors met today and congratulated each other on the strong bonds that link France and West Germany.

title: Loser Was Too Anxious
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 22 (AP)I knew George Foreman was big and strong, but I didn't realize he was that strong, said Joe Frazier tonight after being stopped for the first time in his boxing career.

title: Chiang's Son Bars Talks With Peking
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 22 (UPI)  Premier Chiang Chingkuo said today that his Government would never negotiate with the Chinese Communists.

title: House Democrats Given Vote on Committee Heads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 House Democrats made a hefty dent in the seniority system today, voting to make all committee chairmen subject to an automatic vote of the party caucus.

title: Peronist Candidate Slain In Buenos Aires Suburb
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 22 (UPI)  Julin Moreno, an Argentine labor leader and Peronist candidate for Congress, was assassinated today less than 24 hours after his party had opened its campaign for the general elections in March.

title: Collins MatchPlay Victor
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP)Bill Collins of Purchase, N.Y., won the 10th annual Professional Golfers' Association winter matchplay championship today, defeating Stan Brion of West Palm Beach, 5 and 4, in the 36hole final. Collins won $2,000.

title: Scientist, Plaintiff in Libel Suit, Says Brain Probes Don't Hurt
description: A California scientist, suing for $2million in libel damages after being accused of savagery in brain probes of live animals, testified in Federal Court yesterday that the brain was insensitive to pain.

title: Hearings on News Sources
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)  Hearings will begin Feb. 1 on possible legislation to protect the confidential status of reporters' sources and unpublished notes Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier, Democrat of Wisconsin, who is chairman of a House Judiciary subcommittee, announced today.

title: Washington Post May Buy TV Station in Connecticut
description: The Travelers Corporation said it has reached a preliminary agreement to sell its Hartford, Conn., television station, WTICTV Channel 3 to the Washington Post Company.

title: Unitas Is Traded to Chargers, But Says He May Not Report
description: John Unitas, the quarterback who will be 40 years old on May 7, was traded yesterday by the Baltimore Colts to the San Diego Chargers for what both sides said were future considerations. When reached in Tallahassee, Fla., where he was fulfilling a public appearance obligation, Unitas seemed unsure about the deal.

title: Rutherford and College Considering Land Swap
description: RUTHERFORD, Jan. 22In an effort to reduce a critical school  overcrowding problem and ease parking and congestion, the borough is studying the feasibility of exchanging 100 acres of meadowland for part of the Fairleigh Dickinson University campus here.

title: BANK EARNINGS UP FOR FIRST CHICAGO
description: The First Chicago Corporation, parent company of the First National Bank of Chicago, the second largest bank in that city, reported yesterday sharp increases in its operating earnings for both the fourth quarter and the full year of 1972.

title: Plan Offered by Finance Aide of New York
description: The city's finance administrator, Richard Lewisohn, said yesterday that he had submitted to the New York Stock Exchange a plan for New York City to go into the stock brokerage business through the purchase of a seat on the exchange.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Notes on People
description: The Air Force intends to promote Brig. Gen. Jeanne M. Holm to major general, making her the first woman to hold that rank in the history of the armed services. The intention was announced in Washington by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, who said the promotion was being recommended to President Nixon. General Holm, a 51yearold officer who joined the Army as a private 31 years ago, said she was surprised and astonished at the news, which, she said, she had heard only after Mr. Laird's announcement.

title: 3 Americans Suspended By Canadian Trotting Body
description: WINDSOR, Ontonio, Jan. 22 (AP)Canadian Trotting Association judges handed major suspensions to three American horsemen at Windsor Raceway yesterday for violations of association bylaws.

title: A New Hussein Proposal on Jerusalem Is Reported
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 18. King Hussein of Jordan is prepared to open negotiations with Israel on ti peace settlement if the Israelis will indicate some flexibility on the critical issue of Jerusalem, in the view of authoritative sources here.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SLUMP $5BILLION
description: LONDON, Jan. 22  Prices on the London Stock Exchange dropped more than $5billion today as investors continued to show deep concern about Phase 2 of the British Government's program to combat inflation.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 41

title: Rangers' Rookie Shoots With a Seasoned Touch
description: The most accurate shooter in the National Hockey League for the first half of the season has never led the league in anything. He is not a gunner or the stature of Phil Esposito or Rod Gilbert, or a fancy shotmaker such as John Bucyk. In fact, the leader is a rookie, Steve Vickers of the Rangers. His percentage of getting a goal for every three shots (32.9 per cent, exactly) is by far the highest figure recorded since the N.H.L. started this recordkeeping eight years ago.

title: Wells Fargo Held Up, Bettors Rescue Track
description: Three bettors came to the rescue of a Boston race track Sunday after Wells Fargo was locked out of its safe and unable to deliver $600,000 to Suffolk Downs.

title: Guard Slays Alleged Thief At Machine Shop in Bronx
description: A burglar entering a Bronx machine shop was shot and killed early yesterday by a protectionagency guard summoned by a silent alarm, the police said.

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS AMENDMENT BILL
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22  The Assembly today approved a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would permit a defendant in a felony caseother than a case punishable by the death penalty or life imprisonment  to waive indictment by a grand jury and to consent to be prosecuted on an information filed by the District Attorney.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Snow reports received here over the weekend indicate that a good amount of new snow has fallen throughout the Alps during the last week.

title: Two Donors Each Gave Nixon $250,000 in Secret Fund Drive Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Walter H. Annenberg, the Ambassador to Britain, and the founder of a computer company, each gave $250,000 to President Nixon in his secre?? campaign fund drive last year.

title: Apollo 17 Crewmen Address Small Gathering in House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) The three Apollo 17 astronauts were greeted today by a small but enthusiastic audience in the House chamber. Fewer than 100 House members were on the floor.

title: Gold Starts Prosecution Of 214 as Relief Cheats
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold began yesterday the prosecution of 214 Brooklyn welfare recipients on fraud charges. He also announced the indictment of two brothers charged with cheating the city of $300,000 by the illegal cashing of 3,000 rent checks intended for landlords.

title: AMTOTE IS GIVEN CONTRACT BY OTB
description: The Offtrack Betting Cotporation has selected American Totalisator, Inc., as the winner of its computersystem horse race, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: 3.7 MILLION CARS RECALLED BY G.M. TO CORRECT FLAW
description: DETROIT, Jan. 22  The General Motors Corporation recalled today 3.7 million 1971 and 1972 cars, its fullsize Chevrolet, Pontiac, Buick and Oldsmobile models.

title: Housing Official Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) The White House announced today that President Nixon had accepted with deep regret the resignation of David Maxwell as general counsel of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Maxwell will return to private industry.

title: Notes on People
description: The Air Force intends to promote Brig. Gen. Jeanne M. Holm to major general, making her the first woman to hold that rank in the history of the armed services. The intention was announced in Washington by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, who said the promotion was being recommended to President Nixon. General Holm, a 51yearold officer who joined the Army as a private 31 years ago, said she was surprised and astonished at the news, which, she said, she had heard only after Mr. Laird's announcement.

title: Druggist Kills Holdup Man
description: A druggist, Louis Frratangelo, shot and killed an alleged bandit who attempted to rob his Long Island City, Queens, store yesterday afternoon, the police said. The druggist was wounded in his right hand by the gunman at the Calstra Pharmacy, 1202 36th Avenue. The victim was later identified as Steven Rodriguez, 24 years old, of 40.02 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City.

title: Four Held for Murder in Brooklyn Siege
description: The four men seized in the 47hour weekend siege and shootout at a Brooklyn Sportinggoods store were held without bail yesterday on charges of murdering a policemanwhich could lead to a death penaltyand of kidnapping 10 hostages.

title: Justices Back Full Secrecy Of Documents on Security
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Citizens cannot use the Freedom of Information Act to gain access to unclassified sections of secret and top secret national security papers, the Supreme Court held today.

title: Records: Rock Again
description: Repackaging is a major delight for record companies. It enables them to resurrect aging records of some hit group, put them in either different or chronological order, give them a trendy new cover and put them in the marketplace all over again. It's a valid premise, of course, because the rock n roll generation is rapidly changing and inquisitive.

title: Required Helmets Cut Little Ice With Skiers
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. K. Jan. 22 (AP)  The giant slalom event in the seventh Corcoran Cup races was canceled yesterday when the United States and Canadian teams in the CanAm ski series rebelled at wearing safety helmets.

title: Lyndon Johnson: Controversial President
description: I SHALL not seek, and I will not accept, the nomination of my party for another term as your President, Lyndon Baines Johnson told a startled nationwide television audience the night of March 31, 1968.

title: Saigon Draws a Blank On TraceTalk Photo
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 (UPI)South Vietnamese newspapers are forbidden by Government order to publish the names or the pictures of North Vietnamese leaders.

title: JUDGE MENTIONED
description: A judge was mentioned, but not by name, in a narcotics discussion on a tape recording played yesterday at the trial of a Queens prosecutor and two codefendants accused of sharing a $15,000 bribe to fix a gunpossession case.

title: Study Says C.U.N.Y Y. Practices Discrimination Against Women
description: Women at City University are subjected to social and professional sexdiscrimination, from undergraduate classrooms to the university's highest administrative offices, it was charged in the university's first examination of the status of women at C.U.N.Y.

title: Chess: The Best Move Is Always The One That Wasn't Made
description: The Chessplayer is a difficult creature to please. The club regular who has just landed his Sunday punch, flooring the club champion for the first time, might be expected to enjoy his elation for at least a week. But does he? No. After five minutes of a postgame analysis that turns up moves he did not consider, he is already sulking.

title: CZECH WORKERS QUIZZED ON PAST
description: PRAGUE, Jan 17Dear comrade, the letter begins. In completing an evaluation of all our workers, we find that our information is out of date and that it is necessary for you to fill out this personal questionnaire.

title: Airline Is Learning to Live With Threats
description: WOODBRIDGE TOWNSHIP, Jan. 22On an average of twice a week, Eastern Airlines booking agents in the line's northern regional reservations office here find their routine interrupted abruptly by a phone call from a possible bomber or hijacker.

title: Court Says Clinic Run by 3 Doctors May Do Abortions
description: The Appellate Division in Brooklyn overturned yesterday in a 4to1 decision a Westchester County State Supreme Court ruling that had enjoined the Dobbs Ferry Medical Pavilion, Inc., from performing abortions.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 76336

title: Larry Oliver, Actor, 93, Dead; Was Senator of Born Yesterday
description: Larry Oliver, who in, 1946 originated the role of the bribetaking Senator Hedges in Carson Kanin's comedy Born Yesterday, starring Judy Ho day and Paul Douglas, died yesterday in a nursing home in Englewood, N. J. He was 93 years old and had lived in the Actors' Fund Home in Englewood.

title: BUNKER SETS RISE ON NASDAQ RATES
description: Prices continued to rise yesterday in a wide range of industrial and consumer products, following the Nixon Administration's recent relaxation of economic controls. The Bunker Ramo Corporation said subscriber service rates for NASDAQ (National Association of Securities Dealers automated quotations) securities information will be raised on Feb. 1. Industry sources said the increase would average about 9 per cent or 10 per cent.

title: Orlando Papers Consolidate
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 22 (UPI) The Orlando Sentinel and The Orlando Star began publishing toady as a consolidated allday newspaper. William G. Conomos, the publisher, said The SentinelStar would publish the same number of daily editions as in the past, Monday through Friday, but would publish only morning editions on Saturdays, Sundays and some holidays.

title: Mahavishnu Group: Jazz Predominates Over Indian Mood
description: John McLaughlin must be unique among artistic devotees of things Indian, in that his Mahavishnu Orchestra, which performed Sunday night in Philharmonic Hall, partakes so little of the actual sound of Indian music.

title: CHURCH GROUPING LIQUIDATES STOCK
description: GENEVA, Jan. 22The World Council of Churches announced today that it had liquidated its investments in United States, British, Swiss and Dutch companies doing business with whiteruled African countries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Morgan Estate On L.I. Sound Sold

title: Pride and Relief Are Felt By Police on Siege Result
description: A sense of pride and relief permeated most levels of the New York City Police Derpartment yesterday following the 47hour confrontation with four gunmen over the weekend.

title: Little Watergate
description: The kind of bizarre politics that characterized the Watergate burglary in Washington has apparently been practiced in New Jersey as well. Authorities there are investigating an alleged attempt to ruin a Democratic Assemblyman by planting narcotics in his automobile and home. Kenneth A. Gerwertz, the legislator in whose house the drugs were found by police acting on an anonymous tip, has charged a cold, calculated, wellplanned plot And the police are sufficiently impressed by the circumstances to indicate the imminent arrest suspects, including close associates of James M. Turner, a Republican State Senator.

title: Sales Also Advance
SUSAN J. ELLITHORP
description: PALATINE BRIDGE, N. Y., Jan, 22Susan J. Ellithorp, a daughter of John S. Ellithorp Sr., who was a vice president of the Beechnut Packing Company in nearby Canajoharie, died today at the Bassett Memorial Hospital in Cooperstown. She was 64 years old and had lived here since retiring from Green Mountain Junior College, where she had taught English and history.

title: Fixed Fees Hit by Official of Connecticut
description: Robert I. Berdon, treasurer of Connecticut, called yesterIday for elimination by the New York Stock Exchange of its system of fixed commission charges for brokerage transactions.

title: Lawton Carver, an Editor And Restaurateur, Was 69
description: Lawton Carver, former sports editor of the old International News Service and later a restaurateur and food columnist, died yesterday at his home, 303 East 37th Street. He was 69 years old.

title: John & Al's Steps Back From Moment in the Sun
description: At 11:25 A.M. yesterday the police began dismantling the gray wooden sawhorses that had fenced off several city blocks around John & Al Sports, Inc., at the border of the Bushwick and BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: SOYBEANS FUTURES CONTINUE STRONG
description: Many leading commodity futures contracts continued to move to new high levels yesterday.

title: Cardinals Shocked Reaction Mixed
description: Reaction to the Supreme Court decision on abortion fragmented yesterday along predictable lines, as leaders of the Roman Catholic Church assailed the ruling while birth control and women's rights activists praised it.

title: Leader of Hanafis Calls for Muhammad Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The leader of the Hanafi community of Moslems here today blamed the Black Muslims for the slaying last Thursday of seven of his followers, including three of his children, and he, in effect, declared war on the Black Muslims.

title: Political Funding Law Is Criticized by Stans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)President Nixon's chief campaign fundraiser, Maurice H. Stans, has denounced as absolutely ridiculous some provisions of the law requiring disclosure of political finances and contributions.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Rosemarie Heyer, whose last theatrical appearance was in the musical Coco with Katharine Hepburn, is turning her artistic talents these days to designing women's clothes. Her fashions can be seen at The Other Woman on the second floor at 136 West 72d Street, where the cozy atmosphere is more like the apartment where she started her business than the shop and workroom it is.

title: Iceland Evacuates 7,000 on Isle After an Ancient Volcano Erupts
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Tuesday, Jan. 23Seven thousand people were being evacuated from an offshore Icelandic island early today as a volcano that had, been quiet for more than a thousand years erupted.

title: House Democrats Given Power T o Vote on Committee Chairmen
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 House Democrats made a hefty dent in the seniority system today, voting to make all committee chairmen subject to an automatic vote of the party caucus.

title: F.C.C.'s Johnson Hits TVRadio License Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Nicholas Johnson, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that the Nixon Administration's proposed broadcast legislation was a very simple deal designed to keep material unfavorable to the Administration off the air.

title: EUGENE G. STATTER
description: Eugene G. Stetter, former president of the New York Securities Dealers Association who managed the overthecounter trading department of MabonNugent & Co., stockbrokers, died yesterday at his home, 20 Korwel Circle in West Orange, N. J. He was 66 years old.

title: STEEL OUTPUT ROSE BY 2.7% LAST WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 20 hit its highest level since the week ended May 29, 1971, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet has set the dateFeb. 15for its auction of 146 minor old masters from the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The paintings include works from the schools of Tintoretto, Vandyke, Gainsborough, Boucher and others, as well as more recent works, by Corot, Diaz, Harpignies and Theodore Rousseau.

title: Saigon Mood: Too Many False Hopes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan, 22In a gloomy broadcast this evening, the Saigon radio said that the ceasefire agreement believed to be near completion will not likely bring us a genuine and lasting peace.

title: New Champion Exchausted
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 22 (UPI)George Foreman, the new world heavyweight boxing champion, had to he carried bodily from the ring tonight at National Stadium.

title: Police Find Possible Link in Drug FrameUp Case
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22State police investigators reported tonight that the alleged conspiracy to frame a Democratic New Jersey legislator by planting drugs in his home may be connected with a libel suit filed by the victim against three prominent Gloucester County Republicans.

title: Rudolf to Fill In for Schippers
description: Max Rudolf, former music director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, will conduct its Carnegie Hall concert tomorrow night in place of Thomas Schippers, whose wife died this month. The program, with Dino Ciani as piano soloist, will substitute a Rossini overture and Carlos Surinach's Melorhythmic Dramas for Walton's Symphony No. 2.

title: Belgian Filling Stations Shut
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 22 (AP) The Belgian Government ordered all gasoline stations to close at midnight tonight until a settlement is reached in last week's walkout by 5,300 oilrefinery workers demanding higher wages. The action was taken to preserve supplies.

title: New Champion Reveals Blessed Ability as Promised
description: Last summer, George Foreman told Joe Frazier:

title: Narcotics Policeman Held On Marijuana Charge Here
description: An undercover narcotics squad policeman on vacation from duty at the Brooklyn North Division was arrested early yesterday morning on the Lower East Side and was charged with possession of about an ounce of marijuana.

title: ExTimes Editor Is Named To Bicentennial Stamp Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 David Lidman, former makeup editor and stamp news editor of The New York Times, was named chairman of the Philatelic Advisory Panel of the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission today. Fourteenyearold Vicki Sibum of East Stroudsburg, Pa., was also named to the panel.

title: Heavy Government Toll Near Saigon Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 23 (AP)North Vietnamese troops have reportedly inflicted heavy losses on South Vietnamese forces in more than a week of fighting about 40 miles northwest of Saigon.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Thirtyseven longhaired or bearded youths yesterday filed an appeal in Federal Court in Newark and in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third District Philadelphia, seeking a temporary restraining order against the New Jersey state police from harassing longhaired travelers in New Jersey.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Pilgrims' Jet Crashes in Nigeria; 180 Are Feared Dead, a Record
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 22  A chartered jetliner carrying Nigerian Moslems home from a pilgrimage to Mecca crashed and burned today while landing in fog in northern Nigeria, and it was feared that 180 people had been killed.

title: Dow Index Off by 7.38; Trading Activity ls Slow
description: The malady known as blue Monday revisited Wall Street yesterday as stock prices went into a progressive decline during the afternoon. Trading activity slowed noticeably.

title: A Personal Politician
description: He was larger than life, almost a caricature of the Texas caricature that he could never shake, but he never lost his humanity, because with Lyndon Johnson everything was really personal.

title: Developer Agrees to Buy Morgan Estate on L.I. for $3.8Million
description: ASHAROKEN, LI., Jan. 22A realestate broker announced an agreement today for the sale of about 400 acres of undeveloped waterfront land here to a developer who plans residential community.

title: DAYIDOFF BALKS AT BEING WITNBSS
description: Sid Davidoff, the former City Hall aide who used to run Mayor Lindsay's team of political advance men, disclosed yesterday that he had refused to waive immunity from possible prosecution and testify before a grand jury.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LOST YOUTH The more senior (risking a double comparative) citizens among us may remember the GermanAmerican, or Joe King's Rathskeller, where, during college days, they used to take dates, cheaply, or go stag and drink beer and sing stein songs and maybe carve initials in the furniture. The G.A. was a clich place that grows even better as it recedes into the past. Built in the late 1800's, it was nothing if not Teutonic, in deference to the large GermanAmerican population that surrounded it (it's at 190 Third Avenue, near 17th Street) and athletically exercised in one section, taking off the beer weight put on in another.

title: Service by Soviet Liners To Resume Here in June
description: A 25year freeze on Soviet passenger shipping in the Port of New York is to be lifted on June 11, with the first of three calls by the passenger liner Mikhail Lermontov.

title: A Helpful Phone Company Operated by Mom and Pop
description: NEWPORT, N.Y.In this sparsely populated dairy country in the foothills of the Adirondacks, Leo G. Foss owns and operates the telephone company, a position that gives him considerable status.

title: Favoring of Mellons' Property Is Denied by Appraisal Concern
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22The nation's largest mass appraisal company, which sets values for property tax purposes, described today as irresponsible charges that its work in Westmoreland County, Pa., was suspect.

title: Bridge: In Grand National Play Here 2 Major Upsets Stand Out
description: The quarterfinal stage of the New York preliminaries to the new Grand National championship played Sunday at the New York Hilton was marked by two major upsets and one miniupset.

title: FairCatch Rule Is Made Fairer
description: Army lost a 20yard runhack after a kickoff by Duke in the second half of their football game in 1967 when Charlie Jarvis of Army shaded his eyes from the sun just before receiving the kicked ball. Officials ruled that Jarvis had raised his arm for a fair batch, which is permitted on a kickoff as well as on a punt, and Army was forced to take over from the spot where Jarvis caught the ball. Next fall; officials in college football should be able to distinguish between a faircatch signal and a protection from bright sun. The National Collegiate Athletic Association Football Rules Committee ordered last week that a faircatch signal be made by raising an arm over the head.

title: Music: The Flair of Jessye Norman
description: What do we make of a 27yearold soprano whose debut recital in New York comes under Lincoln Center's Great Performers banner? Or whose triumphant moments can range so widely in style and technical demands as to Include both the subtly witty songs of Satie and the heavy outpourings of Wagner?

title: Soviet Union Proposes a FourPoint Agenda for Planned All Europe Security Conferenc??
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 22 (AP)The Soviet Union today offered a fourpoint agenda for the allEurope security conference under preparation in Helsinki.

title: Pilgrims' Jet Crashes in Nigeria; 180 Are Feared Dead, a Record
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 22  A chartered jetliner carrying Nigerian Moslems home from pilgrimage to Mecca crashed and burned today while landing in fog in northern Nigeria, and it was feared that 180 people had been killed.

title: Arthur Daley
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 22It was unbelievable. In little more than 4 minutes, George. Foreman destroyed Joe Frazier tonight, and the man who supposedly couldn't lose never had even one ghost of a chance for victory. So there is a new heavyweight champion of the world and he won it with authority in an explosive demonstration of overpowering punching skills.

title: Advertising: Data on Deception
description: A Washington communications lawyer is urging the Federal Trade Commission to use consumer research to determine what advertising is truly misleading.

title: Vladimir Pojidaeff, 53, Dies; A Pioneer U.N. Translator
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 22Vladimir Pojidaeff, a United Nations staff member who helped organize its interpretation services, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 53 years old.

title: AbdulJabbar and Barry to Miss N. B. A. AllStar Game Tonight
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 22  Kareem AbdulJabbar and Rick Barry, two of basketball's greatest stars, definitely won't play iin tomorrow night's 23d Annual National Basketball Association AllStar game, to be televised nationally (Channel 17 in New York) at 9 P.M. New York time.

title: National Guidelines Set by 7to2 Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The Supreme Court overruled today all state laws that prohibit or restrict a woman's right to obtain an abortion during her first three months of pregnancy. The vote was 7 to 2.

title: Jefferson and Nixon
description: Maybe they did some things better in the old days. On March 4, 1801, for example, Thomas Jefferson, dressed plainly and without ostentation, walked from his boarding house to the new Capitol in Washington, accompanied only by the Secretary of the Navy and the Secretary of the Treasury. There was apparently no crowd but the members of Congress, who were assembled in the Senate chamber to hear the Inaugural Address of the third President of the United States.

title: Jobless Veterans' Rate Dropped Sharply in '72
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) Unemployment among veterans of the Vietnam war era fell substantially in 1972, the Labor Department said today. The rate dropped from 8.1 per cent in December, 1971, to 5.5 per cent last month, which was lower than the rate for male nonveterans of the same age.

title: Equity Financing
description: Philadelphia Electric Company directors yesterday announced the proposed sale in April of $50million of common stock and $75million of a new series of $100 par cumulative preferred through negotiated sale to underwriters. The company's common closed unchanged at 23 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Withdrawal of 100 G.I.'s Leaves 23,700 in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 (UPI)American military strength in South Vietnam dropped to its lowest point in more than eight years last week, the United States command said today.

title: TV: An American Family Is a Provocative Series
description: For the series An American Family, currently being presented on the Public Broadcasting Service, the William C. Loud family permitted television crews to film its daily life from May, 1971, to the following New Year's Eve. The filming was done in and outside the Louds' eightroom ranch home in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Statements by 2 Cardinals
description: Following are statements issued by Cardinal Cooke and John Cardinal Krol, Archbishop of Philadelphik and president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, in reaction to the Supreme Court decision on abortions:

title: Guinea Says Cabral's Slayers Seized His Aides
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Jan. 22 (Agence FrancePresse)President Skou Tour of Guinea asserted tonight that the assassins of Amilcar Cabral, the West African nationalist leader, kidnapped and tortured Mr. Cabral's top aide, Aristide Pereira, and several of his assistants.

title: Waldheim Denies Charge By Soviet on Press Office
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22  Secretary General Waldheim today denied Soviet charge that the United Nations press office engaged in international misrepresentation and was motivated by bias.

title: NATION IS SHOCKED
description: Shock, sorrow and the sense a historic leader lost were the mourning themes of public officials and private citizens cross the nation last night as word spread that Lyndon Baines Johnson was dead.

title: National Guidelines Set by7to 2 Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The Supreme Court overruled today all state laws that prohibit or restrict a woman's right to obtain an abortion during her first three months of pregnancy. The vote was 7 to 2.

title: Geritol Ads Result in Fines of $812,000
description: After nearly 14 years of jousting over the meaning of tired blood, that rundown feeling and iron power, a Federal judge has assessed fines totaling $812,000 against the companies that make and advertise Geritol, saying they flagrantly violated Federal Trade Commission orders to stop deceptive advertisin.

title: Australia and New Zealand Hail U.S. Treaty as a Positive Force
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 22The new Labor party Prime Ministers of Australia and New Zealand, meeting fox the first time as heads of governments, today hailed the ANZUS mutualsecurity treaty between their countries and the United States as a stabilizing and progressive force in Asia and the Pacific.

title: Palestinian Guerrillas Seek Audience With Pope Paul
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 22The Palestine Liberation Organization, the overall guerrilla organization, has decided to request an audience with Pope Paul VI to thank him for rais ing the problem of Palestinian refugees with Premier Golda Meir of Israel.

title: AID FOR NEEDIEST NEARS A MILLION
description: Legacies and Trust Gifts of $100,000 Are Received More than $100,000 was recorded yesterday by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in gifts, legacies and trust fund payments, bringing the total raised so far to nearly $970,000. The 61st annual appeal began Dec. 10 and will end March 1.

title: Saints Pin 32 Defeat On Raiders
description: The Minnesota Fighting Saints built a good lead in the opening period, yielded in the second, then struck quickly in the final session to defeat the New York Raiders, 32, in a World Hockey Association same at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: KISSINGER IN PARIS; CEREMONIAL SITE CHOSEN FOR TALKS
description: PARIS, Jan. 22  Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight, and it was announced that his talks tomorrow with Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam would be moved to the ceremonial setting of the International Conference Center.

title: When Mamie Left
description: LANDGROVE, Vt.The rate of suicide, both successful and unsuccessful, is on the increase, and being among the number of those who recently attempted it but failed, I assume for myself the right, or rather the duty, to speak on the subject, hazarding guess at the same time for the reasons for this ominous trend.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Drug Clerk, 19, Shot Dead By Brooklyn Holdup Man
description: A 19yearold drugstore clerk was shot and killed by a holdup man in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: Leader of Hanafis Calls for Muhammad Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The leader of the Hanafi community of Moslems here today blamed the Black. Muslims for the slaying last Thursday of seven of his followers, including three of his children, and he, in effect, declared war on the Black Muslims.

title: American Financial To Make an Offer For Major Insurer
description: The American Financial Corporation announced yesterday it plans to make an immediate exchange offer for National General Corporation's $40 common stock warrants expiring 1978 and will later make an exchange offer to holders of National General common stock. The first tender offer will be for up to 4 million warrants at a price of $6.75 each, or a total price of $27million if all 4 million are tendered. American Financial said it will reserve the right to accept warrants tendered in excess of 4 million or to accept only 4 million on a pro rata basis.

title: J. B. SNOW, FOUNDER OF SPEIDEL PAPERS
description: RENO, Jan. 22 (AP)John Ben Snow, a founder and former chairman of the Speidel Newspaper chain died last night at Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs. He was 89 years old.

title: Teachers' Group Reports Drop In U.S. Share of School Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)The Federal Government provides a smaller percentage of the money needed to operate public elementary and high schools now than it did in the school year before President Nixon tookoffice, the National Education Association said today.

title: L.B.J.
description: The shocking news of the death of Lyndon B. Johnson will sadden every American, regardless of party, who reveres the Presidential office. Coming so soon and so suddenly after the loss of Harry S. Truman, who had been the only other living exPresident, Mr. Johnson's death leaves a sorrowful void in the American scene.

title: San Antonio Council Cancels Plan to Help Hand Hospital
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan 22 (UPI)The City Council, stung by voter criticism of a resolution passed last week to ask for donations to rebuild Hanoi's bombdamaged Bach Mai hospital, voted unanimously today to rescind the resolution.

title: Bout With Foreman Year Off, Says Ali
description: DEER PARK, Pa., Jan. 22 (UPI)  I didn't realize I whopped Joe Frazier so bad, said Muhammad All tonight after learning George Foreman was the new titleholder.

title: Books of The Times
description: LESSER LIVES. By Diane Johnson. 232 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $7.95.In an essay that Edmund Wilson once wrote on the novels of Thomas Love Peacockit appears in Classics and Commercials  there are two paragraphs toward the end that refer to Peacock's daughter Mary Ellen and her illfated marriage to George Meredith. In the first, Wilson wrote that Peacock was upset when his favorite daughter, who had been educated on the model of his heroines, both in literature and outdoor sports, married the young George Meredith. And in the second he wrote: Nor did Meredith and his bride get along together. They were both sharptongued and selfwilled, and they had very little money to live on. They tormented one another unbearably. Mary Meredith, at the end of nine years, ran away to Capri with another man, but soon came back to die in England.

title: Costs of Kidney Therapy: Two Fundamental Questions Raised
description: A dispute over projected longrange costs for treating patients with terminal kidney diseases under existing Federal legislation has put into sharp focus, perhaps for the first time, two fundamental questions: Can America afford to deliver to all its citizens the therapies that medical researchers have developed in recent years? I not, why should doctors spend th?? taxpayers money to find new treat ments, some of which are expensive?

title: Casts of 17 Shows Give $10,000 for Bach Mai
description: Cast members of 17 Broadway and Off Broadway shows gave up their pay for last Saturday; Inauguration Day, as a contribution to rebuild Hanoi's bombedout Bach Mai Hospital.

title: INDIANA DEFEATS MICHIGAN STATE
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 22 (UPI)Indiana strengthened its bid for the Big Ten basketball title tonight by defeating Michigan State 9789. The Hoosiers now own a 40 wonlost record in Big Ten play. The Spartans stand 23.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: PRICES SLIP AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Stock prices continued to drop yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in restrained trading.

title: Saigon Puts All Troops on Full Alert To Counter Expected Drive by Enemy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 23South Vietnamese troops throughout the country have been put on full alert and security measures here and in the other major cities are being sharply intensified in anticipation of Communist attacks before the expected signing of a ceasefire agreement.

title: Elevator Builders Tentatively Agree To Terms in Strike
description: Striking elevator constructors and the Elevator Constructors Association of New York City reached a tentative agreement early yesterday which, if ratified, could end a walkout now 206 days old.

title: Charge Cuts Income
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway reported yesterday a 17 per cent gain in operating earnings for 1972, but extraordinary charges sliced deeply into net profits.

title: 20% OF HANOI RAZED, 2 WITNESSES REPORT
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 22Two Swedish members of an international group invited by North Vietnam to inspect bomb damage said on their return here today that about 20 per cent of Hanoi was destroyed by American B52 raids last month.

title: Four Held for Murder in Brooklyn Siege
description: The four men seized in the 47hour weekend siege and shootout at a Brooklyn sporting goods store were held without bail yesterday on charges of murdering a policemanwhich could lead to a death penaltyand of kidnapping 10 hostages.

title: Judge Queries Watergate Witness Who Can't Recall to Whom He Sent Wiretap Data
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The judge in the Watergate trial, saying that neither side was developing all the facts, questioned a witness today about his delivery of wiretapping data to President Nixon's campaign organization.

title: Sled Dog Races Spur Resort Hopes of Tiny Town in Minnesota
description: ELY, Minn., Jan. 22Hike! the driver yelled and 14 growling dogs burst off the starting line in the fourth annual AllAmerican Championship Sled Dog Races.

title: Harlem Leaders Back Life Terms for Drug Sale
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22Governor Rockefeller held a news conference today on his controversial proposals on drug trafficking, and presented five Harlem leaders who, he said, supported his idea of mandated life prison sentences for illicit drug dealers.

title: Resignation by Lacey Expected From the U.S. Court in Newark
description: NEWARK, Jan. 22United States District Court Judge Frederick Bernard Lacey was reported today to be ready to resign from the bench, possibly when the current court session recesses for the summer at the end of June.

title: PILOTS FOR C.I.A. THREATEN STRIKE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 22 (UPI)Pilots for Air America Inc., one of the American companies that contract flying services to the Central Intelligence Agency in Southeast Asia, threatened today to go on strike.

title: 3d of L.I.R.R. Commuters Absent as Full Runs Start
description: Nearly one Long Island Rail Road commuter in three stayed away from the trains yesterday morning, as full railroad service resumed on the first weekday since the sevenweek strike ended.

title: Former F.H.A. Aide on L.I. Gets 10 Years for Bribery
description: Donald C. Carroll, who was appointed in 1971 to reform the Hempstead, L. I. office of the Federal Housing Administration, was sentenced yesterday to 10 years' imprisonment for accepting bribes.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: SCRIBNER WARNS 2 QUEENS BOARDS
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has warned two local school boards in Queens that their refusal to participate in an ethnic staff census could jeopardize all Federal aid amounting to about $150million annuallygranted to the entire city school system.

title: WOMAN, 60, SLAIN IN A BRONX SCHOOL
description: A 60yearold woman, was found fatally stabbed in the James Monroe High School in the West Farms section of the Bronx last night. She was tentatively identified as Bea Wunsch of 249.18 40th Avenue, Bayside, Queens, a cafeteria employe.

title: BIG BOARD TO STUDY DIRECTOR NOMINEES
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its nominating committee would consider recommendations for five public directors and five securitiesindustry directors for election to the exchange's board later this year.

title: Effect of Ruling On States' Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Following is a table showing how each state is affected by the Supreme Court's decision today on abortion.

title: Ruling Seems to Forestall Abortion Debate in Albany
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22The United States Supreme Court's abortion decision today appeared to quash the hopes of Right to Life and other antiabortion groups for a fullscale debate in the Legislature again this year on repealing the state's liberalized abortion law.

title: Jersey Police Find Link in FrameUp
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22  State police investigators reported tonight that the alleged conspiracy to frame a Democratic New Jersey legislator by planting drugs in his home may be connected with a libel suit filed by the victim against three prominent Gloucester County Republicans.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 76336 Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or The fourth and Milwin $2.50.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: DENVILLE, N. J., Jan 22It's great. As a learning experience you can't beat it, said the young assistant golf pro about the minitour, a series of 36hole tournaments in the South.

title: Bill on Pollution Amended To Prohibit Private Suits
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22Thomas H. Kean, the Speaker of the Assembly, succeeded today in striking amendments from a bill that would allow individuals to file private damage suits against polluters.

title: People in Sports: Tops in Sailing
description: A pair of Wisconsin sailors walked off with the year's top yachting laurels given yesterday by Martini & Rossi to the sport's outstanding male and female for 1972. Harry C. (Bud) Melges of Zenda, Wis., was named yachtsman of the year, and Mrs. Jane Pegel of Williams Bay, Wis., yachtswoman. The 42yearold Melges scored 104 points by virtue of his Soling Class victory in the Olympics, as well as the world championship in iceboating. At his award presentation, he gave equal credit to his Soling crew, Bill Bentand Bill Allen.

title: Aircraft Pullout to Be Slow, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 Pentagon planners report that United States air power is scheduled to be withdrawn from Southeast Asia very slowly in the initial period following any ceasefire in the Indochina war.

title: ACCOUNTING UNIT PICKS 4 MEMBERS
description: Four members of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the new sevenman fulltime salaried body that will set the rules for corporate reports, were named yesterday as the auditing professionsomewhat more slowly than it had hoped moved to set up new machinery.

title: Men's Clubs Are Yielding to Women
description: Lectures on gourmet cooking and facelifting are given at the Tulsa Club. Flowerprint smocks may be seen exiting the once allmale squash courts where Princeton University alumni play. And the elite Union League Club now gives tours to secretaries of its members.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified sages distributed in metropolitan New York and adjacent territory.

title: Cardinals Shocked Reaction Mixed
description: Reaction to the Supreme Court decision on abortion fragmented yesterday along predictable lines, as leaders of the Roman Catholic Church assailed the ruling while birth control and women's rights activists praised it.

title: Ruling Seems to Forestall Abortion Debate in Albany
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22The United States Supreme Court's abortion decision today appeared to quash the hopes of Right to Life and other antiabortion groups for a fullscale debate in the Legislature again, this year on repealing the state's liberalized abortion law.

title: I.B.M. Introduces Machine To Enter Data Into Computer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a machine that enters data into a computer by using a new reusable storage device called the diskette. The diskettes resemble a small phonograph record and sell at $40 for five.

title: Net Redemptions Shown By Funds for Full Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (Reuters)Investors cashed in $170.1million more of mutual fund shares than they bought in December, and $1.7billion more in all of 1972, the Investment Company Institute reported today. It marked the first time in the industry's history that redemptions in a full year exceeded sales.

title: STRICKEN AT HOME
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 22 Lyndon Baines Johnson, 36th President of the United States, died today of an apparent heart attack suffered at his ranch in Johnson City, Tex.

title: At Forum: Happiness, Skepticism
description: George Foreman, a man said, drawing out the name of the new heavyweight champion slowly in a tone that combined shock, disbelief and awe.

title: Foreman Stops Frazier In 2d Round, Wins Title
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 22 George Foreman knocked Joe Frazier down six times in two rounds tonight and won the world heavyweight championship in a stunning upset.

title: Soviet Gets Youth Look For Boxing
description: Hit the bag! a photographer yelled at a stocky Russian yesterday in the New York Athletic Club, where the Soviet Union boxing team tuned up for its match against American amateurs next Saturday in Las Vegas.

title: VANDALS DAMAGE ST. LOUIS SCHOOLS
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 22 Nearly threefourths of the 4,100 public school teachers in this city went on strike today, while the Board of Education struggled to keep most schools open despite widespread vandalism by students.

title: Glares Are Traded at WeighIn
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 22 Joe Frazier and George Foreman met eyeballtoeyeball today in the most momentous confrontation since Golda Meir's audience with Pope Paul VI. It was only the weighin for their fistfight for the heavyweight championship of the worlda holy but empty formality in division that has no maximum limitbut they traded glares so freighted with menace that the temperature around them dropped 20 degrees.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: CHILE COPPER RULING LOST BY KENNECOTT
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Jan. 22The Hamburg State Court lifted an injunction against the delivery of 3,500 tons of Chilean copper ore today in a ruling against the Kennecott Copper Corporation.

title: Jersey Catching Up
description: Last November, Governors Rockefeller and Cahill jointly announced that the Port Authority would spend approximately $650 million for mass transportation under a plan they were submitting for legislative approval. The plan, they said, was a dramatic and significant breakthrough in their effort to involve the Port Authority in mass transportation. It would eliminate the 1962 covenant prohibiting the use of Port Authority bonds for mass transit purposes from all future Port Authority bond issues.

title: THICH THIEN HOA, LED MILITANT BUDDHISTS
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, Jan. 23 (AP)  Thich Thien Hoa, the leader of the oncemilitant An Quang faction of the United Buddhist Church, died today. The 55yearold monk had been hospitalized for a month, reportedly with a heart ailment.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Subway Inspection Work Is Questioned at Hearing
description: In a proceeding marked by shouting and bitterness on both sides, the Transit Authority resumed yesterday what promises to be one of its longest, bestattended and most acrimonious disciplinary hearings.

title: Lacey Expected to Resign As U.S. Judge in Newark
description: NEWARK, Jan. 22United States District Court Judge Frederick Bernard Lacey was reported today to be ready to resign from the bench, possibly when the current court session recesses for the summer at the end of June.

title: Atlantic Commission
description: A West German Cabinet minister who is both a dedicated European and a staunch defender of the Atlantic Alliance has made a proposal that could help resolve differences on trade and other matters between the United States and the European Economic Community. Helmut Schmidt, Bonn's Finance Minister, envisions an AmericanEuropean royal commission of experienced, knowledgeable citizens who would meet periodically to analyze the prospective priorities of our common policies.

title: No ExPresident Alive For 6th Time in History
description: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson's death leaves the nation without a living former President for the sixth time in its history.

title: Excerpts From Abortion Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Following are excerpts from the majority opinion, written by Justice Harry A. Blackmun, in Jane Roe v. Henry Wade, the Texas abortion case, and from the dissent written by Justice Byron R. White:

title: STRICKEN AT HOME
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 22 Lyndon Baines Johnson, 36th President of the United States, died today of an apparent heart attack suffered at his ranch in Johnson City, Tex.

title: The Energy Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  We had heard about the energy crisis, of course, but had not expected it to strike so close to home. You never do. It's always the other fellow's neighborhood that will get it, you tell yourself.

title: STUART M. SPERRY
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 22 Stuart M. Sperry, a retired investment broker who was member of the New York Stock Exchange for 30 years, died today at Lawrence Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Jaycee Week Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) President Nixon today proclaimed this week as National Jaycee Week and said it was a time for the expression of America's gratitude for tile many significant contributions of the organization's 325,000 members.

title: Shot Wounds TeenAger Fixing Car in a Driveway
description: COPAIGUE, Jan. 22 (UPI) A teenager working on a car in the driveway of a friend's house was shot in the leg late last night by his friend's nextdoor neighbor, the Suffolk County Police reported.

title: Two Secret Donors Gave Nixon Drive $250,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Waller H. Annenberg, the Am bassador to Britain, and the founder of a computer comparry, each gave $250,000 to President Nixon in his secret campaign fund drive last year.

title: Ousted Interior Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Harrison Loesch, the recently dismissed top official for Indian affairs, in the Department of the Interior, is the new minority counsel for the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee. Senator Paul J. Fannin, Republican of Arizona, the ranking Republican, announced the appointment today. Mr. Loesch had been Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Public Land Management.

title: KISSINGER IN PARIS; CEREMONIAL SITE CHOSEN FOR TALKS
description: PARIS, Jan. 22  Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight, and it was announced that his talks tomorrow with Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam would be moved to the ceremonial setting of the International Conference Center.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon to Send Budget To Congress Monday
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPDPresident Nixon plans to send his budget for the 1974fiscal year to Congress next Monday.

title: Securing Press Freedom
description: Recent court decisions that have sanctioned the jailing of newsmen for refusal to disclose their confidential sources present a real and growing threat to the guarantee of press freedom which is fundamental to the American democratic system.

title: President Is Named by Gimbel
description: The 130yearold Gimbel Brothers departmentstore dynasty yesterday named its first nonfamily member as its president.

title: KIVITT IN COPPELIA WITH MISS GREGORY
description: Cynthia Gregory and Ted Kivitt were the dynamically exciting and warm Swanilda and Franz in Copplia Sunday evening. The performance by American Ballet Theater principals at City Center, however, lacked a certain dimension in characterization, though one ignores much in the presence of soaring technique.

title: Kuwait Buys Participation Of 25% in an Oil Venture
description: KUWAIT, Jan. 22 (Reuters)Finance and Oil Minister AbdelRahman alAtiqui said today that Kuwait would pay $150million for a 25 per cent interest in the oil holdings here of the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company.

title: Household Helpers Who Evoke Images Of Good Old Hazel
description: The ideal, of course, was Hazel. Good old Hazel. She decided what George and Dorothy Baxter would eat and when and whether or not young Harold could store his snowballs in the freezer. She played baseball with the neighbor children and occasionally spent her off Sundays taking Scout troops to the zoo.Yes, Hazel was the maid (when not the cook, the outfielder, the housekeeper, the social worker or the chauffeur). As portrayed by Shirley Booth on television, she loved the Baxters and ran, their house, and the Baxters loved her back. She was an essential if periodically tyrannical member of the family.

title: People and Business
description: Fabian Linden, who keeps tabs for the Conference Board on the public's expectations and intentions, said yesterday that consumer optimism rose markedly after the elections last November. While he still noted some consumer hesitancy, he observed that more people think current business conditions are good (33 per cent compared with 29 per cent in the previous bimonthly poll) and fewer pebple complain that jobs are hard to find (25 per cent compared with 27 per cent).

title: Hayes Suggests Banker Restraint on Loans
description: Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, called on the nation's bankers yesterday to exercise restraint in extending commitments to make loans in the future.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: FLAMINGO, Fla.Following a day of rain, a cold wind blew out of the north, bringing nearfreezing temperatures to the citrusgrowing areas north of Flamingo, and it did not seem likely that we would do very well with snook.

title: Dance: With 2. Troupes
description: Dimitri Romanoff's staging of La Fille Mal Gardee is always a joy for the ballerina. It is light, insubstantial stuff, but fun.

title: Convicts Start Hunger Strike
description: McALESTER, Okla., Jan. 22 Most of the 1,875 prisoners at the Oklahoma state penitentiary near here began a hunger strike today in a demonstration against prison conditions, Park Anderson, the warden, said. He said that no attempt would he made to force the prisoners from their cells. A hunger strike by 13 inmates last July lasted five days.

title: SECRECY DEBATED IN ELLSBERG TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22The Pentagon papers case moved today into arguing the distinction between a document labeled top secret and one that contains some of the same information, but is not labeled top secret.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, JANUARY 23, 1973
description: Henry A. Kissinger arrived in Paris last night and it was announced that his talks today with Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam would be moved to the ceremonial setting of the International Conference Center. There was no official word on how long completion of the ceasefire agreement would take, but the choice of the center suggested that the two sides considered tomorrow's session important. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Museum Wing Will Cost $15Million
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has revealed that its American Bicentennial Wing will cost $15million to build.

title: ESSEX RELAY UNIT PUT IN CLUB RACE
description: The fastest collegiate milerelay team in the East will: note run in the feature relay at the 66th Wanamaker Millrose Games Friday night at Madison Square Garden because it is not wanted.

title: OIL IMPORTS CAUSE PENTAGON CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Assistant Secretary of Defense Barry J. Shillito said today that because of oil and gas imports, interruption of the sea lanes now carries a far larger threat to this nation's security, economy and wellbeing than heretofore, when our own production base was a guarantee of continued secure energy supply.

title: NATION IS SHOCKED
description: Shock, sorrow and the sense of a historic leader lost were the mourning themes of public officials and private citizens across the nation last night as word spread that Lyndon Baines Johnson was dead.

title: $37,626 Superfecta
description: The Superfecta at Yonkers Raceway last night paid $37, 626. Gerhard Hanover, paid $94.60 to win, summaries on Page 34.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Home of Film Maker Searched

title: 37 Youths Tell Court the Police Harass LongHaired Travelers
description: NEWARK, Jan. 21Thirtyseven youths, all of them longhaired or bearded, today filed an appeal in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third District, in Philadelphia, seeking a temporary restraining order against the New Jersey state police from harassing longhaired travelers in New Jersey.

title: 265 Flu Deaths in California
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP)  London flu and pneumonia have claimed 265 lives in California, the health authorities reported today.

title: MRS. EDWARD MANUEL
description: Mrs. Patricia Beers Manuel, wife of Edward A. Manuel, a partner in the New York law firm of Trubin, Sillcocks, Edelman & Knapp, died Sunday of cancer in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 39 years old and lived in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Foreman Stops Frazier In 2d Round, Wins Title
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 22 Under Caribbean skies that had never witnessed anything remotely like it, big George Foreman smashed Joe Frazier to the floor six times tonight and won the heavyweight championship of the world in 4 minutes 35 seconds.

title: COURT TO REVIEW STATE TUITION AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The Supreme Court agreed today to review a 1972 New York State law providing aid to parochial schools.

title: Business Briefs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Tulsa, Okla., against the Telex Corporation.

title: Neil Young's World Reflected in Songs And Fans' Welcome
description: On a previous Carnegie Hall appearance, the audience for Neil Young (who regard him as something of a cult figure) was so appreciatively unruly, shouting out song requests, that Mr. Young was visibly distressed. That particular concert was a solo affair, but on Sunday evening Mr. Young appeared with a backup group of musicans at the same hall.

title: Former I.R.A. Man Extradited To Ulster by a Court in Dublin
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 22A Dublin court today ordered the extradition to Northern Ireland of Anthony Doherty, once a leading member of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army. A lawyer for Mr. Doherty, who is free on bail, said after the hearing that he would appeal.

title: Southern Company Reports 21.4% Advance in Profits
description: The Southern Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1972.

title: Two Are Killed by Police in Gun Battle
description: A suspect in a bank robbery and another man were killed and two police detectives were wounded early today in a blaze of gunfire that erupted after detectives closed in on the wanted man in a bar and grill in Brooklyn.

title: Brooklyn School Renamed For a Slain Policeman
description: A public school in a high crime area of the East New York section of Brooklyn was renamed yesterday for Patrolman Robert Bolden, who wash killed on Jan. 22, 1971. P.S. 345, at 111 Berriman Street, and formerly called the Liberty School, became the Patrolman Robert Bolden School.

title: U.S. COURT UPHOLDS SCHOOL BUSING RULE
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 22 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit upheld today a lower court decision ordering the transfer of 33,000 students from Prince Georges County in Maryland to curb racial segregation.

title: 3.7 MILLION CARS RECALLED BY GM. TO CORRECT FLAW
description: DETROIT, Jan. 22  The General Motors Corporation recalled today 3.7 million 1971 and 1972 cars, its fullsize Chevrolet, Pontiac, Buick and Oldsmobile models.

title: Italy Begins 2Tier System In ForeignExchange Deals
description: ROME, Jan. 22Italy today inaugurated a new twotier foreignexchange system aimed at stemming the flow of capital to other countries and strengthening the lira.

title: South Korean Pullout Begun
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 24 (Reuters)President Park Chung lice announced today that South Korea would immediately start withdrawing its 38,000 soldiers from South Vietnam following the conclusion of a peace agreement there.

title: Abortions at Any Time Sought in State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23  A bill that would allow abortions at any stage of pregnancy was introduced in the Legislature today by lawmakers who led the successful fight for a liberlized abortion statute in 1970.

title: Hiss Named Top Rookie By USAC
description: Mike Hiss, a Californian who comes as close as anyone can to being the glamour boy of the United States Auto Club, has been desigated rookie of the year in USAC's championship division. Hiss, previously honored as rookie of the year in the Indianapolis 500, was chosen for the Valvoline Award on the basis of his performance over the championship season. His record included strong finishes in three 500mile racessecond at Ontario, sixth at Pocono and seventh at Indy.

title: Ondine 318 Miles Behind In CapetoRio Sailing Race
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 23 (AP)Huey Long's decision to take his boat Ondine through the horse latitudes the Southern Hemisphere's doldrumsin the CapetoRio race today put him in 14th actual position and 33d over all. The shortest route from Capetown to Rio de Janeiro lies through these latitudes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 24, 1973

title: Gas Leak in Somerville Causes 100 Families to Evacuate Homes
description: SOMERVILLE, Jan. 23  In a freezing drizzle last night 100 families numbering about 350 people were hastily ordered to leave their homes because of the rupture of a 12inch highpressure gas main nearby.

title: Rents Help Send Up Price Index Here
description: Higher rents and homeownership prices were major factors in a rise of threetenths of 1 per cent in December of the Consumer Price Index for the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area, it was reported yesterday by Herbert Bienstock, regional director of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: People in Sports: Spitz Adds a Laurel to Crown
description: Mark Spitz, who won seven gold medals and set seven swimming records at theOlympics in Munich, was named yesterday the male athlete of 1972 by an overwhelming vote in The Associated Press poll. The mustachioed Californian garnered 405 votes to 62 for Jack Nicklaus, the runnerup. Steve Carlton, the star pitcher of the Philadelphia Phillies, was third with 61.

title: War Leaves Deep Mark on U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23America is moving out of Vietnam after the longest and most divisive conflict since the War Between the States. But Vietnam is not moving out of America, for the impact of the war there is likely to influence Amercan life for many years to come. Though it is probably too early to distinguish between the temporary and the enduring consequences, one thing is fairly clear: There has been a sharp decline in respect for authority in the United States as a resuit of the wara decline in respect not only for the civil authority of government but also for the moral authority of the schools, the universities, the press, the church and even the family.

title: Initialing: Basic Accord on Text
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23In diplomatic practice, the initialing of an agreement means that the chief negotiators have concurred on the language of the text.

title: 4 RESTAURANTS FAIL HEALTH INSPECTIONS
description: The Village Gate, for more than 15 years a popular Greenwich Village night spot at Thompson and Bleecker Streets, was among four restaurants cited yesterday by the Health Services Administration for failing to correct violations of the city's Health Code.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Consumer Prices Rise 3.4% for Year
Four Widows: The White House Is Their Common Bond
description: WASHINGTON, Jana 23 One woman reads mystery stories into the night. One woman goes to bridge luncheons, but doesn't stay to play. One woman stood tearfully beside her two daughters today and dabbed at her eyes. And one woman was in Athens, en countering fresh grief.

title: Alexander Onassis, Only Son Of the Magnate, Dies of Injuries
