description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP)The Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association dismissed Roy Rubin as coach tonight and replaced him with Kevin Loughery, who will be playercoach.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There are surely times when a physician's desire to relieve his patient's suffering conflicts with his mission to prolong his patient's life. It is not always easy to determine when these two goals are in conflict, however.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: SOUTHERN RAILWAY INCREASES DIVIDEND
description: The Southern Railway's directors yesterday increased the regular quarterly dividend from 40 cents to 43 cents a share, the maximum permissible under Phase 3 guidelines, after the road's president, W. Graham Claytor, reported record earnings and operating revenues for 1972.

title: RANGERS, BRUINS BATTLE TONIGHT
description: In a dramatic homecoming and schedulemaker's dream, the Rangers will be back in Madison Square Garden tonight and face their longtime tormentors, the Boston Bruins.

title: CHARLOTTE COMFORT OF HEWITT SCHOOL
description: Mrs. Charlotte Walrath Comfort, headmistress of the Hewitt School, 45 East 75th Street, from 1942 to her retirement in 1969, died Monday in Sarasota, Fla, She was 69 years old and was the wife of Lowell R. Comfort, retired controller of the Ward Baking Company.

title: METREVELI SURGE BEATS VAN DILLEN
description: LONDON, Jana 23 (UPI) Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., frittered away a comfortable lead en route to defeat tonight against Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union in the guarterfinals of the Rothmans $50,000 indoor tennis tournament.

title: MARYLAND ROUTS L.I.U. FIVE, 10073
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 23 (AP)Fourthranked Maryland outscored Long Island University, 214, in the first seven minutes of the second half tonight and went on to defeat the Blackbirds, 10073.

title: Communists Reported to Press Attacks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 24 (UPI)An increase in Communist ground attacks throughout South Vietnam was reported early today shortly before it was announced that agreement had been reached on a ceasefire and that it would go into effect this weekend.

title: A RELIGIOUS GROUP IN PRISON BACKED
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 23 (AP)Two highranking Federal prison officials were cited for contempt today on the ground that they refused to carry out a judge's order to have the Church of the New Song recognized as a religious group in every Federal prison.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Major Hanoi Officials Reported Moving Into South, Perhaps to Establish a Capital
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23United States intelligence sources report that Hanoi has, moved officials from its Ministries of Health and Educetion into South Vietnam's northernmost province in recent weeks, possibly to establish a Communist capital there for the South.

title: SchoolAssignment Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama, introduced today a constitutional amendment to prevent any public school student from being required to attend a particular school because of his race, creed or color.

title: Rockefeller and G. O. P. Leaders Seek Consensus on NoFault Bill
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders sought agreement today on a single no fault auto insurance bill that would present a consensus and avoid a repetition of last year's burial of the issue under a plethora of divisive bills and debate.

title: Brooklyn Couple Are Shot to Death Near Marine Park
description: A young man and woman were found shot to death last night on the edge of Marine Park in southern Brooklyn.

title: SPURT TAPERS OFF IN PRICE INCREASES
description: A spurt of price increases that began soon after Phase 3 of the Nixon economic program was announced almost two weeks ago tapered off yesterday.

title: DROPPING OF CHARGE APPEALED IN DEATH
description: LYONS, N.Y., Jan. 23 (AP) The dismissal of a murder charge against a man who had been accused of kiting his wife and tossing her body into a clambake pit is being appealed by the Wayne County district attorney.

title: TV: In Pursuit of Geese
description: Its awesome aerial photography alone would have justified The Incredible Flight of the Snow Geese, a rewarding 60minute documentary shown last night on the National Broadcasting Company network. The program, which traced the birds' annual winter emigration from Canada to Texas, was a joy and firstrate family viewing.

title: NOVELO, A VIOLINIST OF MEXICO, PERFORMS
description: Hermilo Novelo, a violinist, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night as the second performer in the Concert Artists of Mexico series presented by Carnegie Hall with the Cultural Counselor of Mexico in New York.

title: ROBERT HELLER, 74, MANAGEMENT AIDE
description: Robert Heller, a management engineer and efficiency expert who helped reorganize procedures for Congress, the Pentagon and some of the country's largest corporations, died Monday at Delray Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived at Bratenahl, Ohio.

title: Advertising: Man in the Street
description: A few weeks ago, Smitty Zunker, a young commercial real estate and vitamin salesman in Houston, left his office in the Galleria Shopping Center for a cup of coffee and was accosted by what he describes as an attractive young lady.

title: Utility Cites Its Costs
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York reported yesterday a sharp decine in net income for the quarter and full year of 1972.

title: Slain Patrolman Is Honored By 7,000 Comrades at Rites
description: An army of policemen poured into the narrow streets of Greenpoint yesterday to attend the funeral of Patrolman Stephen Robert Gilroy, who was killed in action last Friday.

title: Britain Is Merging BOAC And BEA as Giant Airline
description: LONDON, Jan. 23A merger of the British Overseas Airways Corporation and British European Airways into a new airline was announced today by the British Airways Board. The board, which runs BOAC and BEA, both stateowned, said it was going to phase out their names and replace them with the single name of British Airways. Operationally, however, they will remain separate entities.

title: U.S Envoy Is Held Hostage by Gunmen in Haiti
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Wednesday, Jan. 23 (UPI)At least two gunmen burst into the residence of United States Ambassador Clinton E. Knox late last night and seized him as a hostage in what officials called an attempt to gain freedom for several Haitian political prisoners.

title: Concert: Flute and Harp
description: A program whose focus was the fluteharp combination made a decidedly pleasant evening at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday. John Wion, first flutist of the New York City Opera orchestra as well as a member of the New Amsterdam Ensemble, and Susan Jolles, harpist, formed the constant factor, being joined by others from time to time.

title: In which Mr. Clurman, the new City Parks Administrator, is taken, over the coals for what he said. He then says it again.
description: Richard M. Clurman's inaugural address as the new Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs sent a chill up the spine of every thoughtful New Yorker.

title: TROOPS TO LEAVE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23President Nixon said tonight that Henry A. Kissinger and North Vietnam's chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, had initialed, an agreement in Paris today, to end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia.

title: Crusaders Set Back Jets, 5 to 4, On Clearwater's Overtime Goal
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 23 (UPI) Ray Clearwater's second goal of the game with 29 seconds gone in suddendeath overtime tonight gave the Cleveland Crusaders a 54 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Funeral Being Held at Church That Johnson Attended Often
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The National City Christian Church, where a funeral service will be held Thursday former President Lyndon B. Johnson, is the church that he attended most often here. He attended his last. service as President there and heard a prayer that he had written for the occasion.

title: PACERS TOP NETS FOR SIXTH IN ROW
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 23The Indiana Pacers stretched their winning streak to six games by staging a secondhalf rally to defeat the New York Nets, 110103, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: A Tree Grows in Texas
description: A 1967 visitor to Lyndon Johnson's ranch in Texas vies told by the then President: This is the tree I expect to be buried under. And when my grandchildren see this tree I want them to think of me as the man who saved Asia and Vietnam and who did something for the Negroes in this country. Yet I have lost twenty popularity points on Vietnam and ten on the Negro question.

title: Virginia Man Surrenders In Case of Imprisoned Boy
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Jan. 23 (AP)Richard Ausley, a Portsmouth carpenter charged with abducting and sexually assaulting a 13yearold boy who was found imprisoned in a buried wooden box, surrendered today to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Panel Here to Pick Mayoral Candidate
description: Former Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet announced yesterday the formation of a nonpartisan committee to seek the bestqualified candidate for Mayor and to muster support for him.

title: Soviet Publishes Fees for Emigration
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23The Soviet Union followed up the publication of its controversial immigration law today by making public the detailed regulations and the scale of fees to be paid by emigrants as reimbursement for a free higher education.

title: HORSES & EQUIPMENT
description: STAKES winning it stakes pieced broodmare 1963. In foal to Bold Favorite. Also 2yr old filly by Dancers Imagethis mare. $100,000 the pair. Call Lew Plaskett at (401) 467911)

title: Records: Holiday Treat
description: The records by Billie Holiday that have been appearing concurrently with the release of Lady Sings the Blues, the film about her, have mostly been reissues.

title: KID ORY, 86, DEAD; JAZZ TROMBONIST
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 23 (AP)Edward (Kid) Ory, the Dixieland jazz great who wrote Muskrat Ramble and gave Louis Armstrong one of his first jobs, died of pneumonia and heart failure in a hospital here today. He was 86 years old.

title: METREVELI SURGE BEATS VAN DUB
description: LONDON, Jan. 23 (UPI) Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., frittered away a comfortable lead en route to defeat tonight against Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union in the quarterfinals of the Rothmans $50,000 indoor tennis tournament.

title: TRANSIT AIDE SUES POSTEL IN A FEUD
description: The general counsel of the Transit Authority began a $275,000 personal suit against City Councilman Robert I. Postel yesterday, charging false imprisonment and other matters arising from an acrimonious disciplinary hearing the authority has been holding for the last two weeks.

title: 5thMan Theory Doubted In Siege at Brooklyn Store
description: The police disclosed yesterday that the gunmen who holed up for 47 hours with nine hostages in a Brooklyn sporting goods store had apparently arrived there in a commandeered gypsy cab after locking its driver in the trunk.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REGISTER DECLINES
description: The ebullience vanished from the soybean futures market yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after one of the most spectacular advances in history.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Vietnam

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The results in this year's Hall of Fame balloting by the Baseball Writers Association will be announced today. The leading candidates to gain the required 75 per cent of the votes are considered to be three pitchersWarren Spahn, Robin Roberts and Whitey Fordall of whom became eligible for the first time. Others thought to have a chance were Ralph Kiner, Bob Lemon and the late Gil Hodges.

title: Trinity's Bells Ring Out News of Accord
description: As soon as President Nixon ended his Vietnam peace announcement last night, Larry King, the organist at Trinity Church, went to an octaveandahalf keyboard in the sanctuary and began pealing the. 10 bells in the tower of the historic church at Broadway and Wall Street.

title: State Will Get U.S. Aid To Curb Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., Republican of New Jersey, announced today that New Jersey would receive a $475,000 Federal grant to help fight water pollution.

title: Scoring Leaders
description: NAT'L. HOCKEY LEAGUE

title: Music
description: About halfway through Lee Luvisi's allBeethoven recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, something clicked not in the pianist's performance, for that had been clicking beautifully all along, but in this listener's head. Mr. Luvisi's approach to the Sonata in A (Op. 101) and the Six Bagatelles (Op. 126) kept evoking something specific, but one could not pin it down.

title: Mass of Thanksgiving Is Celebrated by Cooke
description: Departing from his custom of celebrating weekday masses in his private chapel, Cardinal Cooke offered a noontime mass of thanksgiving for peace yesterday before 500 worshipers in St. Patrick's Cathedral and prayed that the impending ceasefire would bring lasting peace with justice in Southeast Asia.

title: EMANUEL SCHWARTZ, PSYCHOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Emanuel K. Schwartz, psychologist and psychotherapist who had been dean of training since 1950 at the Postgraduate Center for Psychotherapy, a nonprofit outpatient clinic here, died Monday night at his home, 12 East 87th Street. He was 61 years old.

title: Grand Jury Indicts 11 for Failure to File Taxes of Employes
description: NEWARK, Jan. 24  Eleven businessmen, including a former Internal Revenue Service agent, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of failing to file or falsely filing withholding and Social Security taxes deducted from their employes.

title: 2 Bombs in Belfast Cause Damage but No Injuries
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  Two bombs exploded within an hour of each other in Belfast today, wrecking a downtown motor vehicle bureau and damaging an auto supply company. There were no injuries in either blast.

title: Town That Paid High Price Recalls Its Dead
description: BEALLSVILLE, Ohio, Jan. 24The wind whips through the wires up on Cemetery Hill here these days, rustling the long dried grass and banging the rope on the new metal flagpole.

title: Mrs. Bernheim New Head Of the Community Council
description: Mrs. Leonard H. Bernheim yesterday was elected the woman president of the Community Council of Greater New York since its founding in 1925 as the Welfare Council.

title: ST. JOHN'S SCORES OVER SETON HALL
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 24St. John's took an early lead and rolled to a 10777 basketball victory over Seton Hall tonight. It was the Redmen's 12th victory in 14 starts.

title: Dog Judge Started as a Veterinarian
description: The first woman to receive a veterinarian's degree from the University of Pennsylvania was Dr. Josephine Deubler. She gained that distinction in 1938. It was a natural for her to break the sex barrier because veterinary medicine has always been part of her life. Her father and uncle were V.M.D.'s and so are her brother and two cow: sins.

title: S.E.C. as PriceFixer
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has sought to dispose of the hot issue of institutional membership on stock exchanges by an artful compromise.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 History shows that there is a major war every 22 years, the Army captain said. Maybe our cadets will escape the next one.

title: People in Sports: Loughery Is Seeking Saint of 76ers
description: Kevin Loughery, named to replace Roy Rubin as coach of the Philadelphia 76ers Tuesday night, planned to hold his first practice session today with the hapless Sixers, who have lost 47 of their 51 games in this National Basketball Association season. The new coach plans to stress defense.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Jan. 24No one threw his cap into the air or ordered a round for all at the bars of the officers and noncommissioned officers clubs here and at nearby Maguire Air Force Base last night.

title: PRICES RETREAT IN SOYBEAN MEAL
description: Two rumors cominated commodity futures trading yesterday and had impacts on prices, one involving soybean meal and the other involving world sugar.

title: Arkansas State Picks Aide
description: JONESBORO, Ark, Jan. 24 (AP) Gary Withrow, a former coach at TexasEl Paso and Kansas State, was named offensive line coach today at Arkansas State.

title: TRAFFIC COP WINS DASH AT HIALEAH
Fairbanks Is Reported Ready to Join Patriots
description: BOSTON, Jana 24 (AP)Chuck Fairbanks, who led the resurgence of football at Oklahoma, has accepted a job offer from the, New England Patriots of the National Football League, WBZ television reported tonight.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Suga is not the name of an artificial sweetener, but of one of the most attractive new beauty salons in town, and in turn, of its owner, Suga Yuske.

title: Canadian Government Offers Stricter Foreign Investing Bill
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 24The Government proposed to Parliament today a revised, expanded bill designed to control foreign investment in Canadian business.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Citizens Budget commission announced the election of William S. Renchard as chairman of the board and chief executive officer and Roderic L. O'Connor as president. Mr. Renchard, a banker here for more than 40 years, is chairman and a director of Chemical Bank and its parent holding company, Chemical New York Corporation.

title: Worsley, 43, Decides To Vacate the Nets
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 24 (AP)Gump Worsley, 43  year  old National Hockey League goaltender, is retiring from the Minnesota North Stars, General Manager Wren Blair announced today.

title: Author Denies Libel in Article On Experimental Use of Monkey
description: Scathing criticism, yes. Libel no. That in essence was the position taken yesterday it Federal Court by a New Yorkbased animal welfare group being sued for $2million in libel damages by a California brain research scientist.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
... and the Kissinger Role
description: In his impressive account yesterday of how agreement was reached on the war in Vietnam, Henry A. Kissinger observed almost parenthetically that no one in the war has had a monopoly of anguish and ... no one in these debates has had a monopoly of moral insight. If there was a defensive note in the comment, there need not have been; for Mr. Kissinger, emerging from his long ordeal of negotiation, clearly deserves the respect and admiration of the country.

title: THO IS JUBILANT
description: PARIS, Jan. 24  Le Duc Tho, North Vietnam's chief representative at the negotiations on a ceasefire, declared today that the agreement initialed yesterday was basically the same as the draft reached in October, before the talks collapsed.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Her Veal Dish: It Takes Timing
description: VEAU DES GOURMETS

title: U.S. ENVOY IN HAITI FREED BY CAPTORS
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 24The United States Ambassador, Clinton E. Knox, was released unharmed today after being held at gunpoint for nearly 20 hours in his residence.

title: City Allows a 45Day Variance On Sales and Use of Dirty Oil
description: To prevent a possible heating fuel shortage, the city will permit for the next 45 days the storage and use here of dirtier fuel oils than are normally allowed under its airpollutioncontrol code.

title: $19.6Million Deficit Is Reported in Management of City's Urban Renewal
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that Curmco, the corporation set up in 1962 to manage cityowned properties on urbanrenewal sites, had run up a deficit of $19.6million in the past three and a half years.

title: ANDREW KORTINA
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., Jan. 24Andrew Kortina, an executive analyst with the mathematics and systems division of the Exxon Corporation in Floral Park, died of cancer yesterday in Bayonne Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 1123 Peachtree Lane.

title: Rhodesia Reports Killing Of 7 Guerrillas in North
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Rhodesian security forces have clashed with nationalist guerrillas, killing seven, the security forces' headquarters said today.

title: Stanton Calls for an Absolute Newsman's Privilege
description: Frank Stanton, vice chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, called yesterday for Federal legislation to create an absolute newsman's privilege.

title: Market Place:
description: It was the same old story yesterday in this market of big men with nervous stomachs. Another glamour favorite, Walt Disney Productions, bit the dust after the company confirmed reports that its latest quarter's earnings would trail those of the yearearlier period.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: NICKLAUS FAVORED IN GOLF ON COAST
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 24The golf tournament they formerly called a clambake begins here tomorrow, with 344 players forming 172 proamateur teams.

title: Some Suggestions for the New Man at the U.N.
description: As a new Ambassador prepares to represent the United States at the United Nations, it is a good time to reflect on what the essence of his job should be, that is, on what these two great unions might do for the other in the nineteenseventies.

title: Johnson Lies in State in Capitol Rotunda
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The body of Lyndon Baines Johnson lay in state here today after thousands had quietly watched it borne in solemn procession to the Capitol.

title: PRICES SHOW DROP ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market dipped yesterday after opening strong. Profittaking seemed to be the reason rather than any reaction to the Vietnam ceasefire agreement.

title: U.S. Foreign Trade Deficit Topped $6Billion in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The United States deficit in foreign tradeonly the second in this centurysoared to $6.4billion last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Oriana Fallaci, an Interviewer Who Goes for the Jugular in Four Languages
description: When Oriana Fallaci was a little girl, her mother, the wife of a poor Florentine cabinetmaker, would put her on a table in their modest home and implore: Oriana, you must work, you must have a profession. You must not wash dishes like me.

title: Impact of Paris Accord on Prisoners, Armed Forces and Politics in Indochina
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The release of American prisoners of war is to begin by midFebruary under the peace agreement, with all the prisoners returned by the end of March.

title: Mistrial Motion Is Rejected In Trial of H. Rap Brown
description: Lawyers for H. Rap Brown asked for a mistrial yesterday in his robbery trial here in State Supreme Court and the motion was denied.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 24On the evening of Dec. 4 the Chicago Symphony Orchestra gave a program of Mahler and Mendelssohn. Two nights before 800 sat down to a dinner given by Norton Simon, the food executive. And a few days later Columbia and Rutgers met in a track meet while several dozen children were bouncing around the gym floor, shooting baskets and yelling as only small children can.

title: FLORIDA RAILWAY IS SUED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed a suit charging fraud against the Florida East Coast Railway and two of its top executives in setting up an exchange offer of the railway's securities.

title: Artistry of FischerDieskau
description: Dietrich FischerDieskau, who has the biggest repertory of any singer who ever lived, who has made more recordings than anybody else in history, who continues to look younger as the years go on, returned to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. With Guenther Weissenborn at the piano, the celebrated baritone sang a program devoted exclusively to the songs of Brahms.

title: Rangers Top Bruins, 42
description: In an emotional setting for Which some fans paid $75 a ticket, the Rangers last night smothered the Boston Bruins, 42, with a methodical, positional game plan.

title: ... Motivations ...
description: An offhand quip by Mr. Kissinger at yesterday's briefing may well turn into the most revealing and provocative of all his remarks about the final phases President Nixon's war policy in Vietnam. Asked whether twelve days of saturation bombing of North Vietnam's cities and countryside late last month provided the final impetus to the agreement, the Presidential adviser wisely declined to speculate on North Vietnamese motives. Then he added, I have too much trouble analyzing our own.

title: Tho Does Not Expect To Attend the Signing
description: PARIS, Jan. 24Le Duc Tho hinted tonight that neither he nor Henry A. Kissinger, the United States negotiator, would attend the ceremony Saturday for formal signature of documents.

title: Wyoming Is 23d State To Ratify Equal Rights Plan
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Jan. 24 (AP)Wyoming, known as the Equality State because it was the first state to grant women the right to vote (in 1869) today became the 23d state to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution.

title: Suit Arrives Without Pants
description: BARNSLEY, England (UPI) Ray Wilde's new suit was delivered to his home without the pants. He strode into the clothing shop where he bought it wearing shirt, tie, jacket, shoes, socks  and his under: shorts. He stopped traffic en route but got the pants.

title: Great, Not Dismal
description: The Nature Conservancy, an extremely useful organization that has already rescued several hundred thousand acres of ecologically significant lands from destruction, scored its greatest success the other day in saving the Great Dismal Swamp. Through its intervention and the generosity of the Union Camp Corporation, a forestproducts concern, 50,000 acres of this unique wilderness, straddling the VirginiaNorth Carolina border, will be turned over to the Interior Department for preservation as a national wildlife refuge.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 41

title: Gilroy Fund Established
description: Members of emergency squad 8 announced yesterday that they were establishing a fund for the family of their fellow patrolman, Stephen R. Gilroy, who was slain last week at the siege of the Brooklyn sportinggoods store. The squad asked that donations be sent to their headquarters at 10 New Montrose Avenue, Brooklyn, N. Y. 11211.

title: PENGUINS SCORE OVER LEAFS, 52
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Byron Hextall scored two goals to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 52 National Hockey League victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Operating Revenues Top $20Billion Level for First Time
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries had their best year ever in 1972, according to an unaudited preliminary annual report released yesterday.

title: Signing: Convoluted Move
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 24Because the Saigon and Vietcong authorities do not recognize each other, the signing of the Vietnam stettlement in Paris on Saturday will involve a somewhat convoluted procedure, in the words of Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Blacks Reelect Stokes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) Representative Louis Stokes, Democrat of Ohio, has been unanimously reelected chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, it was announced today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Xerox Asks F.C.C. Waiver On Time Slot for America
description: The Xerox Corporation has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission for waiver of a section of the F.C.C.'s primetime access rule that would make it possible for Xerox to rebroadcast its America television series at an early hour next fall.

title: SENATE RECESSES AIDED KNOWLTON
description: NEWARK, Jan. 24 Some legal invoices that the Federal Government contends were phony bills to cover up payments made by a construction company to obtain a highway contract were prepared by a State Senator during recesses at Senate sessions in the Capitol building.

title: 2 Die in Phantom Crash
description: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 24 (AP)An F4 Phantom fighterbomber crashed yesterday in the desert 60 miles north of here killing both crewmen, the Air Force announced. The victims were Capt. James D. Libertone, 28 years old, of Bosier City, La., and Capt. Richard F. Meacham, 29, of Rockingham, N. C. All Air Force spokesman said the craft based at Nellis Air Force Base here was maneuvering in a simulated dogfight with another jet when it crashed on Mormon Peak Tuesday. There was no collision, he said.

title: Jabbar Talks of Islamic Strife Linked to Slayings
description: MEQUON, Wis., Jan. 24 Islam is for all people, Kareem AbdulJabbar was saying. Elijah Poole has taken certain tenets, certain demonology that he's made up ...

title: 3 SLAIN, ONE HURT IN SHOOTINGS HERE
description: A 36yearold man was arrested yesterday and charged with the double murder of Brooklyn couple found shot to death at their parked car Tuesday evening near 3068 Gerritsen Avenue by the Plumb Beach Channel at the edge of Brooklyn's Marine Park.

title: Johnson's Washington Recalled As Time of Restless Volubility
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 They used to tell the story here about the first thing the late Everett McKinley Dirksen did when he took over the Senate minority leader's job and the radiophoneequipped limousine that went with it.

title: RapidAmerican Accepts A Million McCrory Shares
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation said yesterday that about 1.8 million shares of the common stock of McCrory Corporation were tendered in response to RapidAmerican's offer to buy one million at $32 a share, which expired yesterday. The company said that it had accepted one million tendered McCrory shares on a pro rata basis.

title: Survivor Tells How 7 Moslems Died in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The gunmen who killed seven Hanafi Moslems at their headquarters here last Thursday entered the house under a false pretext and then methodically killed their victims onebyone, according to a relative of a survivor.

title: Many Offices to Shut In Honor of Johnson
description: Many government and other services will close for all or part of today to observe a period of mourning for former President Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Albany Mall Proves Dazzling to Inhabitants
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24 More than 10 years since it was first proposed, the vast site for the South Mall is still clogged with vacant structures, exposed beams, swirling cranes, shattering piledrivers and the debris of 2,000 construction workers.

title: Obha, flyweight King, Dies in Auto Accident
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 25 (AP)Masao Obha, the World Boxing Association's flyweight champion, was killed this morning when his car crossed a road divider and collided headon with a truck on a highway, the police reported.

title: MARIUS BEWLEY OF RUTGERS DIES
description: Dr. Marius Bewley, a professor of English at Rutgers University and advisory editor of The Hudson Review, a literary quarterly, died yesterday at his home, 22 Fort Place, St. George, S. I., after a brief illness. He was 57 years old.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of two million shares of common stock of the Canteen Corporation at $22 a share was made yesterday by underwriters managed by Lazard Freres, Kuhn Loeb, Merrill Lynch and Paine Webber. The sharps being sold represent the initial step in the divestiture of Canteen by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation under an agreement with the Department of Justice. After this offering, I.T.T. will own four million, or about 67 per cent, of the outstanding shares of Canteen. I.T.T. has until Sept. 24 to completely divest itself of the Canteen stock.

title: Hanoi Celebrates Truce Accord On the Streets and in the Palace
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The news of the ceasefire accord was heard on the streets of Hanoi this morning, broadcast by the streetcorner loudspeakers that only a few weeks ago warned that American bombers were coming.

title: COMMONWEALTH OIL SUES PPG ON VENTURE
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had filed an action against PPG Industriee, Inc., its partner in a joint venture formed in 1967 to build and operate one of the world's largest olefin pants in Puerto Rico.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (UPI)The Chicago Cougars the World Hockey Association said today that Ed Short was dismissed as general manager and the club was talking with Derek Sanderson, the center, who recently settled with the Philadelphia Blazers of the W.H.A. for $1million.

title: Capital Subdued After a Long Agony
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24This time there was no dancing in the streets, no honking of horns, no champagne lifted in salutation, no slapping on the back in short, no jubilation.

title: Belgian Doctor in Abortion Case Gaining Support
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 24A strong wave of support has developed in Belgium for a gynecologist and leading fighter for liberalization of the abortion laws, who was arrested Jan. 17 on charges of performing more than 300 abortions between April and December, 1972.

title: Ousted Monte Carlo Drivers Halt Rally by Blocking Roads
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 24 (AP)  Angry Monte Carlo Rally competitors among 140 eliminated from the event in a controversial decision threw the rally into chaos today by forming roadblocks against leading teams.

title: Art: Final Part of Whitney Biennial
description: The third and final section of the Whitney Museum of American Art's biennial opens to the public today on the fourth floor, which means that the entire exhibition space is now filled to the top with the works of art, near  art, non  art, anti  art, pseudoart and younameit that make up this survey of what is going on just now. The final section is by far the most solid of the three, which is a comment on the relativity of solidity in the context of the moment.

title: Edison in Inventors Hall of Fame
description: WEST ORANGE, Jan. 24 (UPI)In the paneled library here where Thomas A. Edison thought about devices like the phonograph, the motion picture camera and the incandescent lamp, The Wizard of Menlo Park was honored today as the first member of the National Inventors Hall of Fame.

title: The Criminal Element
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24I was walking the streets thinking of Diogenes the other night when Sleek John stepped out of the shadow of a gingko tree and, gun in hand, said, This is a stickup.

title: Connecticut Warned on Court Reform
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 24Chief Justice Charles S. House, in what was called an unprecedented appearance before a joint session of the General Assembly, advised the legislators today to move slowly befor venturing to make changes in the judicial branch of government in Connecticut.

title: Records: Fine Brahms
description: There is something about Johannes Brahms's religious music that makes a certain kind of modernday listener just a little nervous. Perhaps it is the experienceif one has been lucky enough to have had the experienceof sitting through several piously weakminded performances of The German Requiem in suburban churches, with the orchestra reduced to a slicksounding organ and the chorus trying desperately to compensate in saintliness for what it lacks in musicality.

title: Bridge: Some Hands Are Difficult For Instant PostMortems
description: In the majority of deals a good player can determine in a few seconds, looking at all four hands, what the result should be in a specified contract. For other deals, two or three minutes will usually suffice. But now and again the postmortem analyst hits his head against a really tough one. A good example is the diagramed deal from the Reisinger team championship.

title: 125,000 Shares of Levitz Sold by Two of Its Officers
description: Two officers of the Levitz Furniture Corporation have sold 125,000 shares of stock, according to the latest insiders report published by the New York Stock Exchange. The sellers were Leon J. Levitz, the company's largest shareholder, who sold 100,000 shares leaving 1,705,432, and his son Gary, a vice president, who sold 25,000, cutting holdings to 418,178. Ali spokesman for the company said both officers were selling shares to diversify their holdings.

title: Cable Contract to I.T.T.
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that a Spanish subsidiary had been awarded a $10million contract to manufacture buried and aerial telephone cable for Venezuela.

title: Miss Lynn Is 2d After First Test In U. S. Skating
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 24 (AP)Janet Lynn, fourtime senior women's champion, was in second place today after the school figures in the 1973 United States figureskating championships.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State incometax refunds totaling $357,663 were mailed yesterday to 4,682 taxpayers who filed early, Tax Commissioner Norman F. Gellman said. Last year the Tax Department issued nearly $375million in refunds to more than 4.6 million taxpayers. The figures are expected to larger this year because many taxpayers failed to claim a special withholding allowance in 1972 and too much income tax was deducted from their pay.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: THO IS JUBILANT
description: PARIS, Jan. 24  Le Duc Tho, North Vietnam's chief representative at the negotiations on a ceasefire, declared today that the agreement initialed yesterday was basically the same as the draft reached in October, before the talks collapsed.

title: Pope Expresses Joy as World Capitals Welcome Coming Truce in Vietnam Fighting
description: In statements characterized by expressions of relief and hope for enduring peace, world leaders and governments yesterday welcomed the impending cessation of hostilities in Vietnam.

title: Ruckelshaus Says Car Industry Causes Excessive Gasoline Use
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 William D. Ruckelshaus, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that the automobile industry caused excessive consumption of gasoline  and, by implication, smog  through unnecessary weight and gadgetry on cars.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Member of Regents Board Shifts to Education Council
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) Stephen K. Bailey, a member of the state Board of Regents since 1967, submitted his resignation today to become vice president of the American Council on Education in Washington.

title: Minimum Wage Rise Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) A bill providing a threestage increase in the minimum wage, from the present $1.60 an hour to a proposed $2.10, was introduced in the House today by three Republicans and two Democrats. For most nonfarm workers who were in jobs coveed by the minimum wage law before 1966, the level would rise to $1.80 on the first day of the second full month after the law is enacted; to $2 a year later, and to $2.10 a year after the second step became effective.

title: Theater: The Jockey Club Stakes Opens at Cort
description: There is something almost irresistible about highcamp, pseudo  upper  class English comedy acting. And there is an awful lot of it in William Douglas Home's The Jockey Club Stakes, which meandered into the Cort Theater, blandly, blithely and merrily. It claims to be here for only a limited engagement of four weeks. I suspect the engagement will soon lose its limitations.

title: She Became a Chef Despite Male Prejudice
description: You are a tall, 21yearold blonde. You have just finished college. You are a woman who loves to cook, and you want to become a chef. You have a problem.

title: BARSE MILLER DIES; ARTIST AND TEACHER
description: PLANDOME MANOR, L. I., Jan. 24Barse Miller, a painter known for his watercolors and an art professor at Queens College, died Monday while on a teaching cruise near Mazatlan, Mexico. He was 68 years old and lived at 190 Bayview Road and at Rangemark, Birch Harbor, Me.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 25, 1973

title: Spahn Elected to Hall of Fame

title: Mills Set Tax Reform Work
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that his Ways and Means Committee would begin work on tax reform on Feb. 5, with full public hearings to begin Feb. 26. The committee chairman said in a brief House speech that panels of the committee would hold meetings Monday through Friday Feb. 5 to 9, and again Feb. 19 to 23.

title: THE VIETNAM AGREEMENT AND PROTOCOLS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Following, as made public by the White House today, are the texts of the Vietnam ceasefire agreement initialed in Paris yesterday by Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho, and of the four accompanying protocols detailing means of carrying it out. The accord and three of the protocols have been drafted in two versions. The fourparty versions will be signed Saturday morning. Because South Vietnam is unwilling to imply recognition, of the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government, twoparty versions mentioning that Government will be signed in the afternoon only by the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Stocks Tumble Despite Accord

title: ' Innocent Bystanders,' Spy Thriller, Recalls the 1960's
description: Paramount Pictures has provided film critics with an unusually detailed plot synopsis for its "Innocent Bystanders." I've read the synopsis and I've seen the picture, and I still don't know exactly what is going on, or why, through perhaps 60 per cent of Peter Collinson's new movie, which opened yesterday at local theaters. The confusion is probably intentional and not entirely unprofitable. But it results less from the extraordinary complexity than from the general inconsequence of everything that happens in the film."Innocent Bystanders" is a spy thriller, reminiscent of the nostalgia-drenched late 1960's, about an over-age British secret agent (Stanley Baker) who has to bring back alive one Kaplan, a brilliant Russian scientist, now defected and living modestly as a goat herder in Turkey. Opposed to Baker are his boss (Donald Pleasence), his young replacements (Sue Lloyd and Darren Nesbitt), a chief American secret agent (Dana Andrews), a conniving Turkish hotel keeper (Warren Mitchell), and an organization of Russian Jews who don't like Kaplan. Baker must also deal with his own self doubts and with a hostage, an innocent bystander (Geraldine Chaplin) who is not what she seems.Indeed, nobody is what he seems. Everybody either has a cover or is a coverwhich doesn't much matter, because "Innocent Bystanders" is the sort of movie in which shooting enemies in one scene become drinking companions in the next, without changing sides, and for no better reason than that the screenplay calls here for bullets and there for booze.The actual film-making is never quite as pleasantly casual as the screenwriting (by James Mitchell, from a novel by James Munro). Peter Collinson ("The Penthouse," "Up the Junction," "The Italian Job," etc.) is noted for a ponderously flashy technique. But despite its involvement in his silly cinema of obtrusive montage, improbable camera angles and forced perspective, "Innocent Bystanders" may well be Col-movie.Almost everything in the movie seems to come from some other movie  from "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich," from a whole generation of hard-nosed disillusioned spy films, perhaps even from "North by Northwest," with its own elusive Mr. Kaplan. Stanley Baker's characterization owes a lot to James Bond and a little to Richard Burton, and although not one of his better roles, it allows him enough dignity at least to keep his reputation intact.But Geraldine Chaplin's performance is so reticent and so appealing as to constitute a small personal triumph. She is saddled with the movie's dumbest sequence (restoring Baker to his long lost masculinity, just by holding hands with him) but she is also granted its only moments of quiet intelligence. She fills these moments with a delicate intimacy that contrasts with everything else in the film and that really does suggest a reservoir of feeling to oppose the lives around her that are wasted in mere action.

title: Screen: A Domestic Comedy by Ozu:The Cast ' Flavor of Green Tea,' 1952 Film, Arrives Effect of Time Makes It Social History
description: Donald Richie, the Japanese-film expert, tells us that the late Yasujiro Ozu took meticulous care in his choice of settings, especially the small details that, according to Mr. Richie, were always intended to emphasize character rather than environment. This is true, but the passage of time has added an environmental significance to the details originally picked to give dimension to character.In Ozu's 1952 film, "The Flavor of Green Tea Over Rice" (another Ozu title to challenge Western patience even when his film does not), the environment that Ozu more or less took for granted, since he always made his films in their own time, seems now to play a more interestingor at least more obvious partin the drama.All of the Ozu films we have seen in this country ("Tokyo Story," "Late Spring," "End of Summer," "Floating Weeds") have been social comedies, but they have been told entirely in terms of character. More than any of these other films, "The Flavor of Green Tea" looks as much like a social history as it does a classic Ozu work.The movie, which opened yesterday at the Quad Cinema 3, is essentially a comedy, what the Japanese call a tsuma-mono, or wife film, about an upper-middle-class marriage, one that has been arranged in the old-fashioned way and now is falling gently apart as the childless couple approach middle age.She (Michiyo Kogura) gives every indication of being a rather mean-spirited snob. Among other things, she sleeps apart from her husband in an awful American-style bedroom that seems to be constructed entirely of chintz.However, he (Shin Saburi) gives every indication of being as thickheaded and boring as she says he is.That is, at the beginning. The revelationthe surpriseof the film is not that they are eventually reconciled, but that they become such appealing characters, touched by a kind of nobility.As important as the revelations of characterto me anywayis the casual picture of the world in which they occur. I am not sure if it is factually true, but I have the impression that more of this film is set in public places, that is, locations outside the home that is the emotional center of any Ozu film, than in the films of his released here earlier.What we see of Japan in 1951 and 1952 defines the time in a fashion I am not sure I would have been as aware of had I seen the film in 1952.It is a world only seven years removed from Hiroshima. Nobody in an Ozu film, seems directly affected by the American occupation, but the American influence is everywhere, in second-hand clothes, in cigarettes, in the liberation of women.The world of this film is more geographically open than those of the other Ozus, but the economy of narrative and technique is practically quintessential. Ozu never wastes our interest on connecting scenes if we can take them for granted. When he does show us a man proceeding, say from one office to another, it becomes important, perhaps as an acknowledgment of time lost or as a sort of film equivalent to the white space between the chapters in a novel.No one shrug or sigh or smile is more or less dispensible than another gesture, which explains why minor characters are so important in Ozu films.One of the funniest and most moving scenes in "The Flavor of Green Tea" is the scene in which the operator of a pinball parlor (Chishu Ryu) talks gloomily about his success. "This is trash," he says in effect. "It degrades the national spirit," and then he goes on to remember, as if with nostalgia, the beautiful nights during the war in Singapore."The Flavor of Green Tea" is not great Ozu. There are timesespecially in its subplot about a girl who refuses traditional wedding arrangementswhen it is almost formula comedy.No true Japanese formula comedy, however, would punctuate its climactic reconciliation scene, set in the kitchen that the wife is discovering for the first time, with the image, seen only out of the corner of the camera eye, of a can of Wesson oil.

title: Hijacked Fabric Recovered
description: NEWARK, Jan. 24 (AP) Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today seized more than $65,000 worth of hijacked fabrics here and arrested Ira B. Jacobs, 65 years old, of West Orange, and his son, Jeffrey P. Jacobs, 24 of Orange.

title: Fur Coats Donated to Foster Wildlife Preservation
description: Several women who believe that fur looks better on the wild animal it comes on have donated their fur coats fur jackets, fur hats and furcovered bags to the New York Zoological Society to stimulate interest in wildlife preservation.

title: Laos and Cambodia: A Maze of Factions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Division among Cambodians who oppose the Government has complicated efforts toward Cambodian ceasefire, Administration officials said today. But the situation in Laos, they said, was simpler since leftist opposition to the Vientiane Government is vested in the Pathet Lao.

title: Police Captain Is Shot Halting Mugging on IND
description: An offduty police captain was shot in the left hand last night as he stopped a mugging on a subway train in the Bronx, the police reported. Two muggers escaped.

title: Rams Dismiss Prothro; Knox Is Selected Coach
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 Chuck Knox, Detroit Lions' offensive line coach and a former New York Jet assistant, was named head coach of the Los Angeles Rams today, replacing Tommy Prothro.

title: Music: A Difficult Work
description: Elliott Carter's String Quartet No. 3, given its first performance on Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall, is an enigmatic, fiercely argued, extraordinarily difficult workeven for Mr. Carter, who has never tried hard to please the casual, feetup listener.

title: GEORGE W. COUCH JR.
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 24George W. Couch Jr., vice president for marketing of the brewing division of AnheuserBusch, Inc., of St. Louis, died here yesterday. He was 50 years old and lived in St. Louis.

title: Edward Weintal of U. S.I. A., ExNewsweek Writer, 71, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Edward Weintal of the United States Information Agency, who had been an awardwinning diplomatic correspondent for Newsweek magazine, died today of a fractured neck suffered in a riding accident. The 71yearold Mr. Weintal fell from a horse during his customary morning ride through Rock Creek Park with Egidio Ortona, Italian ambassador to the United States.

title: Woman, 85, Is Found Slain in Ransacked Apartment
description: An 85yearold greatgrandmother was strangled yesterday and her shabby $56amonth apartment was ransacked in what appeared to be a robbery attempt in a welfare tenement at 651 East Fifth Street, on the Lower East Side.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM INCREASES SALES
description: The Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation reported yesterday gains in sales for the fourth quarter of 1972 and for the year. Net income for the quarter was almost twice as high as in 1971, but net for the full year fell well behind the 1971 level.

title: Highlights of Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Following are highlights of the Vietnam agreement, as set out in the text and in a news conference today by Henry A. Kissinger:

title: A Happy Mood Grips 22 Families of P.O.W's on L.I.
description: BALDWIN, L.I., Jan. 24 The first phone call Mrs. Jane Storms, sister of an Air Force prisoner of war, made last night after she learned her brother may be coming home was to cancel a fullpage advertisement scheduled for tomorrow publicizing the plight of the men being held in Southeast Asia.

title: ROCKETS SUBDUE COLONELS, 9887
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24 (UPI)Warren Jabali scored 26 points tonight to help the Denver Rockets to a 98.87 victory over the Kentucky Colonels, the Rockets first victory in Kentucky since the formation of the American Basketball Association.

title: Arthur Kevess, Translator And Editor of Folk Songs
description: Arthur Kevess, a translator and editor of foreign folk songs, died of cancer Tuesday in MemorialSloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 56 years old and lived at 140 Cadman Plaza West, in Brooklyn.

title: Rep. A.spin Asks S. E.C. Inquiry on Ash
description: Representative Les Aspin asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to investigate whether Roy L. Ash had violated the law by unloading more than 85,000 shares of Litton Industries stock on the basis of inside information not available to the public.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Even in retrospect it is obvious that no ringsider with a respect for the truth would ever have had the effrontery to say: I knew all along that George Foreman would beat Joe Frazier with a quick knockout. It would have been much too idiotic for advance contemplation because it was the least likely eventuality.

title: Watergate Judge Assails Argument by Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Chief Judge John J. Silica of the United States District Court said today it would be ridiculous to allow a defendant in the Watergate trial to argue that he had acted under duress.

title: 20 Olympians in Meet
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Twenty Olympians, including Frank Shorter plus Dave Wottle, Robert Taylor and Randy Williams, will compete in the fifth annual Astrodome Federation national indoor track meet Feb. 10.

title: Specialist Tom Davis: First to Fall in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Eleven years and 31 days ago, on a dusty road in the hamlet of Duc Hoa near Saigon, the United States suffered its first Vietnam combat loss.

title: Some Leaders in Congress Fear a ShortLived Truce
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Congressional leaders, including some prominent opponents of the Indochina war, gave President Nixon a standing ovation after a lengthy White House briefing this morning on the negotiated truce in Vietnam.

title: Saigon Politics: Its Future Rests on a Fragile Base
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The political future of South Vietnam, at least in the first 90 days after the signing of the cease fire agreement Saturday, will rest in part on a fragile threeparty National Council of National Reconciliation and Concord whose eventual establishmentif it is establishedwill symbolize the heavy compromise worked out in the peace settlement.

title: Jackson's Eyelid Is Split In Mishap at Knick Drill
description: Professional athletes in contact sports are always subject to injuries. But it's not supposed to happen in practice sessions.

title: I.B.M. INDEX DEAL CHARGED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Government charged today that the Control Data Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation had made a secret agreement to destroy, before the Government could learn about it, an index to thousands of documents that would be valuable in the Government's antitrust case against I.B.M.

title: EXTORTION PLEA CHANGED IN TRIAL
description: CAMDEN, Jan. 24 (AP)Florence Clark, one of the defendants in the extortionconspiracy trial of seven present and former Atlantic City officials, today changed her plea from innocent to no defense to the conspiracy charge in Federal Court here.

title: Rosenbaum Views Rockefeller As Better Than Agnew for '76
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The new Republican state chairman of New York said today that Governor Rockefeller would be a tremendously viable candidate for President in 1976.

title: Big Board for a Ban on the Third Market
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange at a meeting yesterday called for legislation to outlaw the third market, the overthecounter market for stocks listed on the exchange.

title: CANADIENS SINK ISLANDERS, 6 TO ??
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (UPI)The Montreal Canadiens scored four goals in the second period and went on to their 12th game in a row without a defeat to night as they beat the New York Islanders, 61. It was the sixth straight victory for Wayne Thomas, a rookie goalie.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Turnpike Overcomes Hurdle to Extension
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 24 (AP)The New Jersey Turnpike Authority won a court round today in its planning for the proposed Toms RiverSouth Brunswick Expressway.

title: MARY BUYCK FREUND
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24 (UPI)Mary Buyck Freund, artist and landscape architect, died Monday. She was 84 years old.

title: New Books
description: Fiction

title: DEMOCRAT BACKED BY C.O.P. AS JUDGE
description: In an unusual political reversal, New York State's Republican leaders are seeking Federal judgeship for a Democrat who failed to win election last year to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)  The Federal Trade Commission turned down today a petition from an antismoking group that wanted it to move immediately against radio and television commercials for little cigars.

title: Education Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) William F. Pierce, former Michigan deputy school superintendent, was appointed today a deputy commissioner in the Office of Education. He will be in charge of occupational and adult education.

title: CeaseFire Supervision: 4 Nations to Have a Role
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The detailed ceasefire accord described today by Henry A. Kissinger provides for a complex series of truce supervisory teams intended to bring an end to major warfare in Indochina.

title: News Adds Joy to Diamond Ball
description: Right up to the evening before the event, it looked as though the Diamond Ball would observe its 14th birthday in its usual manner, as elegantly and unfussed as things can be done these days, Then President Nixon announced the Vietnam ceasefire.

title: U.S. ENVOY IN HAITI FREED BY CAPTORS
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 24The United States Ambassador, Clinton E. Knox, was released unharmed today after being held at gunpoint for nearly 20 hours in his residence.

title: Rail TonMileage Shows A Rise of 14.3% for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 16 billion tonmiles, 14.3 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 516,062, an increase of 11.5 per cent above last year.

title: CutRate Tickets For L.I.R.R Riders
description: Reduced admission tickets for Long Island Rail Road riders to the boat show, are available at the following ticket offices:

title: Lemmings Fails Early, Recovers Later
description: There is a severe dichotomy in National Lampoon's Lemmings, the musical revue that opened last night at the Village Gate. The first act, a headlong, supposedly comic assault on sex and politics, suffers from a serious case of the puerilities.

title: Chinatown Gets 33Shop Arcade, and Even Pizzeria Has a Pagoda
description: A blocklong Chinatown arcade that was an oldclothes market is about to reopen as an Orientflavored street of 33 shops and eating placesincluding a pizzeria with a pagodaroofed oven.

title: PACERS TRIUMPH AT BUZZER, 9694
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (AP) Indiana's Billy Keller sank a 20foot hook shot as time ran out tonight, giving the Pacers a 9694 American Basketball Association victory over the Kentucky Colonels.

title: METREVELI LOSES TO ASTIE, 76, 74
description: LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) Arthur Ashe won a battle of tiebreakers and Marty Riesser overcame frustration caused by a disputed line call as both Americans advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 Rothmans indoor tennis tournament today.

title: Albany Guns Fire Salute
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25 (AP)Four howitzers were fired at oneminute intervals at noon today in front of the State Capitol to deliver a 21gun salute to former President Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: New Chief Hopes to Unveil New Attitude, New Products
description: For probably the first time in its 63year history, the National Boat Show will have two openings, one tonight at 5 (sneakily called a preview) and one tomorrow morning at 10 (with the Mayor cutting himself in). With a new managing director, it may be only the beginning of a host of new ideas.

title: Nixon Going to Florida
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (Reuters)President Nixon will leave tomorrow for a weekend at his home in Key Biscayne, Fla., the White House announced today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Jan. 25Seton Hall and Fairleigh Dickinson, inexcusably, were beaten again in basketball this week. What was unexpected was that Rutgers lost to Lafayette in overtime, easily defeated Delaware and has been tagged the favorite over Columbia at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Seton Hall has also been picked to win over Georgetown.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS MEET ON MAYORAL RACE
description: The Republican state chairman and the five county leaders here discussed yesterday the possibility of nominating a Democrat as a bipartisan Mayoral candidate in this year's election.

title: Pact Reached in Chicago In 2Week Teacher Strike
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25Union and school board negotiators reached agreement today on terms for ending a strike that has closed the school system here since Jan. 10.

title: FATHER OF MOSLEM IN SLAYING ROBBED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Thee Charlotte, N. C., home of the father of a survivor of the slaying of seven Moslems here last week was robbed yesterday, the Charlotte police have told policemen here.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS 100 MORE JUDGES FOR DRUG COURTS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25Governor Rockefeller proposed a $55million program today to expand the state's court system by giving him the power to appoint 100 State Supreme Court justices on a temporary basis.

title: Music
description: Threequarters of a century after his first significant works were written, Charles Ives continues to tickle the creative fancy of many composers. One of the more obviously tickled is Lejaren Hiller, whose String Quartet No. 6 (1972) had its first performance Wednesday night at the New York Cultural Center. The Concord String Quartet performed the piece with a brashness of attack that seemed aptly Ivesian.

title: Head Situation: Confused
description: Something of a race seems to be shaping up on whether the Coast Guard, which must develop regulations on wastetreatment devices for boats, will do so in time for the boating season. If the Coast Guard acts in time, boatmen who donot want to install holding tanks will be able to use other devices.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Joseph Paul, the chairman of the California Committee of Two Million, died last March, but his goal, to save the state's last freeflowing rivers from the dambuilders, was reached in late December when Gov. Ronald Reagan signed into law the California Wild and Scenic Rivers Act.

title: Great News for Hunan Fans
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).  Uncle Tai's Hunan Yuan, 1059 Third Avenue (between 62d and 63d Streets), TE 80850.

title: Nude Photos of Mrs. Onassis Ruled Not Obscene by Judge
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 25 (UPI)An Italian judge ruled today that a group of published pictures of Mrs. Jacqueline Onassis in the nude were not obscene.

title: HOLDUP MAN KILLED IN FUNERAL PARLOR
description: An employe shot and killed one of two holdup men who invaded a Harlem funeral parlor yesterday, the police reported.

title: FORMULA DROPPED BY IRVING TRUST
description: The Irving Trust Company, acting under pressure from Washington and with the greatest reluctance, suspended yesterday use of a formula that ties its prime lending rate directly to its openmarket costs of funds.

title: VIENTIANE HOPES
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 25Senior Laotian Government officials said today that they understood there was a secret agreement between North Vietnam and the United States under which Hanoi would withdraw 60,000 of its troops from Laos and a lesser num ber from South Vietnam.

title: Johnson Buried at Texas Ranch
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Jan. 25  Lyndon Baines Johnson was buried today in a country graveyard on the northern bank of the Pedernales River. His coffin was lowered into the earth under an aged, twisted oak next to the graves of his mother and father on the former President's ranch.

title: Bridal Held for Diana M. Sweeney
description: The marriage of Miss Diana M. Sweeney, a former reporterresearcher with TimeLife Books, to James Pierpont Morgan Jr., a government securities trader for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., took place here last evening. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Victor L. Baer in the chapel at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: People in Sports: 76ers Subtract Their Only AllStar
description: It didn't take long for Kevin Loughery, the Philadelphia 76ers' new coach, to begin revamping his team. Yesterday Loughrey sent the 76ers' only allstar, John Block, a forward, to the Kansas CityOmaha Kings for Tom Van Arsdale, a forwardguard, and a thirdround draft choice. Then Loughrey and his general manager, Don DeJardin, looked south to Atlanta and picked up Jeff Halliburton, another forwardguard, for a 1973 thirdround draft choice. Neither official would say whether the thirdround pick in the Kansas City deal was for this year or not.

title: ROCKETS UPSET BUCKS BY 129125
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 25 (AP) The Houston Rockets snapped Milwaukee's eightgame winning streak tonight with a 129125 National Basketball Association victory despite Kareem AbdulJabbar's 48 points.

title: Moses' Advice for a Better New York: Don't Let Anybody Pretty Be Mayor
description: With rhetorical flourishes and casually recalled illustratons from his own decades in city and state government, Robert Moses told the State Charter Commission yesterday that all that was needed to run New York City better was better people.

title: Hadl of Chargers Goes To Rams for 2 Players
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP) The Los Angeles Rams, who suffered through a mediocre season with a sorearmed Roman Gabriel at quarterback, today acquired John Hadl from the San Diego Chargers for Coy Bacon, a defensive end, and Bob Thomas, running back.

title: $11Million in LSD Seized
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 25 (Reuters)  The San Diego police have announced the seizure of $11million worth of LSD and the arrest of 11 persons. The 236 grams of the drug were found in a suitcase in the home of one of the defendants after ?? two month investigation. The ??l were arraigned yesterday and released on bail ranging from $10,000 to $200,000.

title: Virgin Island Team Scores Olympic Sailing
description: COWPET BAY, St. Thomas The sailing team had just returned from the Caribbean championships in St. Croix and was sitting around the patio of the St. Thomas Yacht Club here when the talk turned to the 1976 Olympics.

title: Nixon Orders New Efforts To Finds Jobs for Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) President Nixon ordered today a renewed Federal effort to find jobs for returning veterans.

title: VIETCONG OFFICERS ICE DUE IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 26Vietnamese Communist military personnel will be flown to Saigon aboard American helicopters Sunday or Monday to join a ceasefire commission created by the Vietnam peace accord, a wellinformed American source said yesterday.

title: For Asian Development: Important Opportunity
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 25  The last shot of the Vietnam war will signal the beginning of new opportunity for the leaders of Asia, aided by the major powers, to come to grips with the basic problems of excessive population and poverty, which are already threatening the breakdown of many of their societies.

title: U.S. Cuts Pay Raises for Hospital Employes Here
description: A wage and benefit increase if 8.3 per cent for 33,000 employes of voluntary hospitals here has been reduced to 5.5 per cent, the Cost of Living Council said in Washington yesterday.

title: Knicks Struggle to Defeat Braves, 9992
description: A 9point streak at the beginning of the game that seemed more amusing than important, at the time, enabled the Knicks to score a 9992 victory over the Buffalo Braves last night at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 19,553.

title: DR. FOELLING, FOUND INFANTBRAINDEFECT
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. 25 (AP) Ivar A. Foelling, who won the 1962 Kennedy Prize of the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation, for pioneer studies in infant brain disease, died today. He was 84 years old.

title: TWO UNIONS SETTLE is ENGINEROOM ISSUE
description: A dispute between two ship officers unions over automatic engineroom controls was settled yesterday after it delayed the sailing of the MooreMcCormack Lines freighter Mormaclynx for two days.

title: Pan Am Denies Making Decision on Concorde
description: Spokesmen for Pan American World Airways and the British Aircraft Corporation denied yesterday a report that Pan American had decided against buying the AngloFrench supersonic Concorde airliner.

title: Conference in Paris Starts Work on Plan To Preserve Venice
description: PARIS, Jan. 25 (AP)Preparatory work began here today on a largescale international program to save Venice from decay and destruction.

title: House in Utah Rejects Equal Rights Measure
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 25 (AP)Utah's House of Representatives has defeated a resolution ratifying the Federal equal rights amendment while the legislature in neighboring Wyoming has become the 23d state to ratify the amendment.

title: BRONX MAN IS SLAIN RESISTING ROBBERS
description: A 57yearold man was stabbed to death by two assailants yesterday when he resisted a robbery on a Bronx street corner, the police said.

title: Yugoslav Student's Film Stirs Demands Teacher Be Punished
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan 25A student's film, said to have offended President Tito in an especially rude manner, has touched off an uproar in Yugoslavia's movie world.

title: Events Today
description: Opera

title: Mosque Near Siege Area Is Focal Point for Blacks
description: For the last three years, in a threestory building at 52 Herkimer Place in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the Ya Sin Mosque has been a gathering spot and place of worship for a growing number of predominantly black Brooklynites who have converted to orthodox Islam and become Sunni Muslims.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.  Walter (Valentine) Kelly, 157 pounds, Las Vegas, outpointed Jose Martin Flores, 158 A, San Diego, 10 rounds.

title: TB TESTS PLANNED FOR SOUTH BRONX
description: The Hunts Point Community Corporation in the South Bronx announced a drive yesterday to screen all 70,000 residents in Hunts Point for tuberculosis because the rate of active cases there runs about three times the national average.

title: VIETCONG OFFICERS ARE DUE IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 26Vietnamese Communist military personnel will be flown to Saigon aboard American helicopters Sunday or Monday to join a ceasefire commission created by the Vietnam peace accord, a wellinformed American source said yesterday.

title: 8TH SKI RACE WON BY MISS PROELL
description: CHAMONIX, France, Jan. 2 (AP)  Annemarie Proell, th?? defending World Cup champion sped to her sixth straight down hill triumph of the season i?? the Kandahar ski race toda?? while the United States mad?? its best showing this seaso?? with two skiers in the top 10.

title: Lawyer Charged With Stealing Client's Inheritance of $219, 560
description: A former assistant United States attorney who now has a substantial estate practice here was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday on a charge of having stolen virtually all of the inheritance of one of his clients, a total of $219,560.

title: Look Back In Puzzlement
description: The Paris agreement extricates the United States from the Indochina war and sets a pattern for possible peace between Vietnam's two halves. But, in itself, it insures neither peace nor unification of that country nor does seem to guarantee a certain ceasefire in neighboring Laos and Cambodia.

title: India's Quarter Century
description: As the United States reassesses its global role after a decade of obsessive preoccupation with Southeast Asia, one of the many areas that deserve a fresh look is the Indian subcontinent, where the world's most populous democracy today uneasily celebrates its 25th anniversary as a republic.

title: German Marks Sold by Fed Bank Here to Bolster Dollar
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold substantial quantities of German marks in the foreign exchange market here yesterday, according to informed banking sources.

title: A Palestinian Arab Is Killed In Cyprus Bomb Explosion
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 25 (AP)A Palestinian Arab was killed in an explosion in a Nicosia hotel room early today, apparently while handling a number of bombs, police sources said.

title: L.I. Speed Champion Revs Up to Cross Atlantic
description: Next time you're flying the Atlantic and chomp into good chunk of sourdough bread or a crunchy roll, think of Antonio Rodrigues and his speedboat records.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Joseph Paul, the chairman of the California Committee of Two Million, died last March, but his goal, to save the state's last freeflowing rivers from the dambuilders, was reached in late December when Gov. Ronald Reagan signed into law the California Wild and Scenic Rivers Act.
