title: RENT STRIKE OVER, NEWARK ASSERTS
description: NEWARK, Jan. 25The Newark Housing Authority announced tonight that the nation's longest publichousing rent strike had ended, but a group of tenants disputed the agreement and declared that the strike would continue.

title: Johnson Buried at Texas Ranch
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Jan. 25  Lyndon Baines Johnson was buried today in a country graveyard on the northern bank of the Pedernales River. His coffin was lowered into the earth under an aged, twisted oak next to the graves of his mother and father on the former President's ranch.

title: Voices of Conscience
description: Throughout the long years of America's illfated involvement in the war in Indochina, the peace symbol remained a persistent expression of determination and hope. As time went on and the yearning for an end the bloodshed grew in intensity, that symbol's message became emblazoned in the minds and hearts of millions. It formed a nonpartisan bond for many who agreed on little else.

title: CORNELL PROTEST SEEKS, FAIR SHAKE
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 25Jon. T. Anderson, Cornell University's athletic director, said tonight that he had filed a complaint with the Eastern College Athletic Conference over the eligibility of a Boston University hockey player, to give our players a fair shake.

title: Graft Issue Stirs a Legal Controversy
description: NEWARK, Jan. 25  The two top lawenforcement officials in New Jersey disagreed sharply over how business concerns that pay off public officials should be treated after they have turned state's evidence to help convict corrupt officials.

title: MAYOR HOPEFULS WOOING SUPPORT
description: Four Democrats who say they would like to be Mayor wooe?? middleclass support in Queens last night through organization politicians there.

title: $83,928 Worth of Hatteras Luxury
description: Hatteras is exhibiting its allnew model, the 38 Flying Bridge Double Cabin. The new fiberglass luxury boat manufactured by A.M.F.Hatteras Yachts, features a large flying bridge with seating for seven persons. J. B. Hargrave designed it.

title: COMMONWEALTH OIL SUES PPG ON VENTURE
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, Inc., has an nounced that it had filed an action against PPG Industries. Inc., its partner in a joint venlure formed in 1967 to build and operate one of the world's largest olefin plants in Puerto Rico.

title: A 3Party Government Is Formed in Belgium
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 25 (AP)Premier Edmond Lehurton announced today the formation of the first coalition Government of Belgium's three major parties since 1945.

title: Big Engine Lays Claim To Throne
description: If the Queen of the show has no objections, a highpowered engine with 950 horsepower will lay claim to the throne marked King.

title: Officials Doubt a Plot by Blacks to Kill White Policemen
description: The sniper fire that left six dead and 15 wounded in New Orleans early this month has again raised the question whether a national conspiracy exists among blacks to kill white policemen.

title: PROF. HERBERT HEATON
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (AP) Herbert Heaton, professor emeritus of history at the University of Minnesota, died yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: Agriculture Aides Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Two new assistant secretaries of agriculture and a new general counsel of the Agriculture Department formally took office yesterday. Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz administered oaths to Clayton Yeutter, assistant secretary for marketing and consumer services; William Erwin, assistant secretary for rural development; and John A. Knebel, the new general coupsel.

title: ChrisCraft Theater
description: While Chris  Craft will have seven boats at the show, it also builds 45 other models, which will not be shownexcept in its theater. Two screens will show a series of slide films on each of 11 boats and individual slides on all others.

title: Records: French Singer
description: American poprock music has always had a happy balanceofpayments situation: its exports far outweigh its imports. Only the British, spearheaded by the Beatles, have been able to withstand and fight back.

title: London Is Seeking to Ease Immigration for Whites
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  The British Government proposed preferential treatment today for white immigrants from Canada, Australia and New Zealand over nonwhites seeking to enter Britain from other Commonwealth countries in Asia, Africa and the West Indies.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUT OF THE PAST There's nothing like a good run of somebody's something new to stir up interest in somebody's past. Ingmar Bergman, for instance. His generally acclaimed Cries and Whispers, his newest film, is running at Cinema I, Third Avenue and 60th Street PL 36022). What with Bergman interest at a fever pitch, Janus Films has taken 10 films of earlier Bergman, 1950 through 1963, and put them into a series to run from today through Feb. 8 at the Playboy Theater, 57th Street, near Avenue of the Americas (JU 64448).

description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: LAFAYETTE TOPS COLUMBIA, 7764
description: Walt Kocubinski scored 29 points to lead Lafayette to a 7764 victory over Columbia in University Gym last night. The Leopards' victory was their fifth straight.

title: Five Short Film Dramas Have Lucidity
description: There must be poets whose life's ambition is to write short poems. And there have been great composers whose ultimate masterpieces were art songs, four or five minutes long. But nobody aspires to make short movies, especially short fiction movies, if he can make long ones instead. Short movies usually come at the beginning of a film maker's career, when he lacks money and needs experience, and they are a kind of apprenticeship, or schooling, in which he learns the potentials of his craft.Taken at this level, the program of five short movie dramas that opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum is very good and honorable and promising work. None of the films is brilliant, or very polished, or especially innovative. But at the same time, they are all intelligent, and lucid, and technically idiomatic  while avoiding the easy symbolism and pretentiousness of effect that seems the curse of the medium and a particular temptation to young directors.I suppose the greatest virtuosity, at least in concept, belongs to Philip Shafer's "The Man Who Knocked Me Down," which consists entirely of a single 11-minute take from the viewpoint of a subjective camera that goes out for a walk, gets knocked down by a madman on a Greenwich Village street, and then has to listen to his plans for reshaping the world. The concept works very well, partly because John Bottoms plays the madman with enough variety to sustain the film's concentration and partly because Shafer knows just how seriously to take his visual trick.Stephen Witty's "A Game of Catch," a kid's fantasy, and W. Boon Collins's "Kettle of Fish," an adult's slice of unnerving reality, are dramatically the least assuming of the films. Neither seems wholly realized as a movie, though "Kettle of Fish," another Village confrontation, deals pleasantly with its large cast of slightly drunken, vaguely dispirited characters."What Fixed Me" is the most ambitious of the Whitney movies. Filmed by Tom Rickman in Kentucky, it attempts to occupy the mind of a sensitive boy, son of a brutish backwoods preacher and of a young mother who dies trying to escape from the father. It is a rather literary film, complete with a cautionary folk song ("Old Dan Tucker") on the sound track, but good at building a frame of mind out of the process of storytelling.Dick Bartlett stars his own stepmother, Mary Bartlett, in "The Odyssey of Gloria Twinson" as the contented, supernaturally ordinary middle-aged proprietor of a small-town gift shop. It is her ne'er-do-well novelist sister Renata (Ann Priest) who messes things up for Gloria, moving in with her, drinking, bitching, and repeatedly playing her tape-recording of their late father's last coughs and death rattle.Renata eventually takes off to do her own thing  cause a scandal, as it happens  and Gloria begins to think she would like to do her own thing too, if only she could figure out what that might be. Gloria and Renata really are originals. And so is Dick Bartlett, whose manner of dry deadpan humor is as good a style for the short dramatic film as any I've seen.

Selection committees are hardly ever required to determine the best players in a club, a city, the country or the world.

The Democrats' Committee on Committees will continue to nominate the senior member of each committee as its chairman, but under the new procedure adopted this week each nomination is to be automatically voted on by the entire caucus of the party.

title: ROOSEVELT WILL USE ABRAHAM FACILITIES

title: 4 Arabs and 2 Jews Indicted By Israelis in Espionage Case
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 25Four Arabs and two Jews suspected of key roles in what Israel says was an espionage and sabotage ring directed by Syrian intelligence were indicted today in Haifa District Court.The most serious charges against them, punishable by life imprisonment, are committing an act with the intention of aiding the enemy in its war against Israel and passing information to the enemy with the intention of injuring the security of the state. A life sentence in these instances would result in at least 20 years imprisonment. The trial begins Feb. 11.

This was produced by the New York Shakespeare Festival, which last night offered his second play, Siamese Connections.

title: 100Man P.O.W. Airlifts Expected to Start Feb. 10

title: New Jersey Briefs

title: Mariner's Temple Burns

The Fire Department said there was medium damage to the basement and first and second floors of the church, at 12 Oliver Street on the Lower East Side. The cornerstone of the building is dated 1843.

title: 'Life Study':Screen Love Story Is All Too Vulnerable
description: Nothing works the way it should in "Life Study," Michael Nebbia's all-too-vulnerable love story about Angelo Corelli, a moody young Italian-American boy who wants to make movies "about the way things are," and Myrna Clement, who, at 17, is rich, eccentric, lonely and pregnant, though not by Angelo.Myrna falls in love with Angelo at first sight, when he walks into her uncle's painting class at the New York Art Students League. It's a measure of the imagination of Myrna (and of the film) that she immediately sees Angelo as a knight in shining armorand that Mr. Nebbia insists that we see it too.The way is thus immediately prepared for a film that attempts to honor squareness but ends up by demonstrating it.Angelo has these flat-footed, conveniently coherent dreams that establish the fact that he blames his father for his mother's death in childbirth, nine months after Angelo caught them making love. As Angelo is riddled by Roman Catholic guilt and keeps a plastic Jesus, on the dashboard of his convertible, Myrna fights against the burden of her WASPness. "Daddy," she says on the telephone, "Why don't you follow Christ's example and give away all your money?" Myrna, who is always a bit cute, becomes intolerable when given access to a telephone. She calls Angelo late one night to ask, "Isn't it awful about Abelard?"Mr. Nebbia, the director, and his screenwriter, Arthur Birnkrant, present Angelo and Myrna straight, without humor. They obviously feel affection for a girl who'd say, seriously, that she wants to be married "in a meadow, by a river, facing the rising sun, at dawn." If they cared more, however, they might have given the girl the wit to recognize that if it's dawn, the sun had damn well better be rising.Bartholomew Miro Jr. plays Angelo. Erika Peterson is Myrna, and a girl named Ziska is the worldly model who represents the flesh opposed to Myrna's spirit. I haven't the faintest idea if any of them can act."Life Study," which opened a week's engagement yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room, pretty much defines the purposes of the new theaterperhaps too well. It is neither good enough nor strong enough to compete in the commercial market.However, it is the first directorial effort of Mr. Nebbia, whose talent as a cinematographer ("Alice's Restaurant") should earn him the right to fail publicly as a director.

title: Mayor of Yonkers Decides Not to Run for a 3d Term
description: YONKERS, Jan. 25Mayor Alfred B. DelBello said today that because of financial considerations he would not run for a third term this fall.

title: Red Smith
description: The reason why the American League has taken the hat away from the pitcher is that the owners have no faith in baseball as entertainment. They haven't been selling tickets and they think the fault must lie with the game, for they know themselves to be sagacious, enterprising, farsighted, shrewd, dynamic, welldressed and charming. If there were anything wrong with their merchandising methods, a smart cookie like Alexander Cartwright, or anyway Al G. Spalding, would have pointed it out before now. The thing to do, therefore, was to offer the customers a different game that they would like better. Then what, they asked themselvesfor they are logical men who could pursue a syllogism through the Great Dismal Swamp without dropping a minor premisethen what would the customers like better than the game they have loved for a century? More hitting and scoring, they answered themselves. (They had to answer themselves because nobody else did.) Well, if they put up a pinchbatter when it was the pitcher's turn to hit, would there then he more hitting and scoring and cash customers? Nobody could answer that, either, so they said, Let's do it.

title: George Graff Is Dead at 86; Wrote Lyrics for Irish Eyes
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP)George Graff, who wrote the lyrics to When Irish Eyes Are Smiling, died yesterday at a hospital in East Stroudsburg. He was 86 years old.

title: Schoolchildren Earn and Save To Give to the Neediest Cases
description: Children's concern for children has always been a mainstay of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Chaparrals, at Dallas. (RadioWHN, 8:35 P.M.)

title: Bar Unit Inspects Courts on Ability to Try Pushers
description: Members of the State Bar Association toured the narcotics courts on the ninth floor of the Civil Court Building yesterday. They were trying to find out whether the courts could handle the vast increase in the number of cases they would have to process if Governor Rockefeller's recent proposals on drug trafficking became law.

title: Market Place:
description: The stock market should have gone up. President Nixon had announced the longawaited ceasefire in Vietnam and Wednesday was going to be the day of the peace rally, when investors would shake off the apathy of war and don the euphoria of peace.

title: Computer Snarl in Allotment Agency Is Inducing French Social Insecurity
description: PARIS, Jan. 25A building that looks like a temple of efficient modernitynine stories of glass walls enclosing a formidable computer and 4,000 masters and slaves to direct it and to do its biddinghas fallen victim to a modern illness that the French call gigantisme.

title: Fruehauf to Quit Modular Housing Business
description: The Fruehauf Corporation, a leading producer of truck trailers, announced yesterday that it was getting out of the modular homebuilding business since there was no mass market for such housing.

title: Nonenforcement Treaty
description: The same myopic lineup of Arab and African nations that blocked forceful antiterrorist action at the United Nations last fall has reformed at Montreal, together with the Russians and French, to obstruct efforts to put teeth into three existing antihijacking conventions.

title: Lefkowitz Opens Inquiry Into Art Sales by the Met
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has opened an inquiry into the legality and prudence of recent sales of paintings by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Oil Earnings Mixed
description: The oil industry turned in a mixed earnings pattern yesterday.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Cleveland Museum has acquired a particularly fine and not previously exhibited Madonna and Child, an Italian Gothic sculpture of the 14th century, which museum officials have tentatively attributed to Andrea Pisano, better known for his reliefs for the bronze doors of the Baptistry in Florence.

title: THO IS LEAVING FOR HANOI TODAY
description: PARIS, Jan. 25  Preparations were under way today for the final act in the five long years of Paris peace talksSaturday's signing of the agreements ending the Vietnam war.

title: Washington Pays Final Tribute to Johnson
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25With solemn words and music this city paid a final tribute today to Lyndon Baines John son, the New Deal Congress man who became the 36th President of the United States.

title: Navy Memo Assailed Testing of F14
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Senator William Proxmire released today a Navy memorandurn sharply criticizing the Grumman Corporation and the Hughes Aircraft Company, asserting that they had failed to carry out an aggressive, positive testing program for the F14 fighter airplane.

title: SPREE BY COUGARS TOPS RAIDERS, 92
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP)Dan Lodboa scored three goals and Rick Morris and Bob Whitlock two each tonight as the Chicago Cougars romped to a 92 victory over the New York Raiders in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Bill Moyers
description: WASHINGTONI was in Minneapolis, filming a public television show with Chippewa Indians, when the radio flashed the news of President Johnson's death.

title: G.E. Urges U.S. to Simplify Energy Rules
description: The General Electric Company has called on the Nixon Administration to simplify the multiplicity of regulations controlling energy supplies as the best way to avert a national energy crisis.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: FireRetardant Rule
description: The Coast Guard has amended the Federal regulations for fiberglass boats under 100 gross tons carrying less than 150 and more than six passengers for hire to require that they be constructed with approved fireretardant resins. This amendment went into effect Jan. 11.

title: M'DONNELL'S NET RISES IN QUARTER
description: Results of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in the fourth quarter last year were the best since 1969, contributing largely to the 38 per cent rise in 1972 earnings and the 31.7 per cent in sales, according to the annual report issued yesterday at St. Louis headquarters.

title: A Tribute to Television
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Every once in a while the common concerns, sorrows and ideals of the Republic somehow cry out to be heard and understood, and it is then, If we watch and listen, that we understand and appreciate the power and possibilities of television as a unifying force in the nation.

title: Bronx Bookmaker Is Held In Attempt to Bribe Police
description: A longtime Bronx bookmaker and restaurateur was arrested yesterday on a bribery charge when two detectives who had arrested him on charges of possessing and selling heroin said that he offered them $1,000 to forget the charges.

title: Republic Steel's 1972 Net Increases by $2.65 a Share
description: The Republic Steel Corporation reported yesterday 1972 sales of $1.6billion, compared with $1.4billion in 1971. Net income soared to $43.1million, or $2.66 a share, from $136,452, or 1 cent a share, in 1971.

title: Extensive TV Coverage Of Signing Is Arranged
description: The television networks will provide videotaped and live coverage of the signing of the Vietnam agreements in Paris tomorrow.

title: Cadmium Price Raised
description: The American Smelting and Refining company announced yesterday an 8.3 per cent increase in the price of cadmium, a metal used mainly in electroplating. The new price is $3.25 a pound, which the company said was well below the base price established under pricecontrol regulations.

title: Nina ShortChanged on Cruise Around Globe
description: After a year of planning a fiveyear voyage around the world on a sailboat, refurbishing a schooner inside and out, quitting their jobs, selling their house, a boat and two cars and taking their three children out of school, two Northport, L. I., couples ran into a crisis they could not solve: money.

title: Superman's Alive, Living in Curacao
description: WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Netherlands Antilles  Ben Van Dalen is a construction engineer at the huge Shell Oil refinery on this Caribbean island. He owns the two largest charter boats here and is a legendary fisherman and fishing captain, something between Paul Bunyan and Superman with a Dutch accent.

title: QUOTAS BLAMED FOR FUEL CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)  A Ford Foundation researcher said today that this winter's fuel shortages were a result of President Nixon's refusal to end oil import restrictions. He said that the shortages could be setting consumers up for higher prices.

title: Warner Plans to Buy Stock
description: Warner Communications, Inc., announced yesterday that its executive committee had approved the purchase on the open market of up to one million of its common shares subject to favorable action by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Election Is Set for Feb. 27 For Bronx Assembly Seat
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25Governor Rockefeller today ordered that a special election be held on Feb. 27 in the Bronx for the seat in the 85th Assembly District vacated by Anthony J. Mercorella, who resigned following his election to the New York City Council.

title: Wheeler: Right Man for the Right Time?
description: Bob Wheeler doesn't buy the business that a sub4minute Wanamaker Mile is impossible, even after 65 futile races.

title: Advertising: In Marketing Today the New Password Is Positioning
description: Jack Trout, introduced as Mr. Positioning himself, was the leadoff speaker yesterday as the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association devoted a day to exploring the current big buzzword.

title: British Football
description: SCOTTISH LEAGUE

title: F.B.I. HEAD ASSAYS COAL OF JUSTICE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the object of the criminal justice system should be the protection of society, not just the protection of the rights of the accused.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 26, 1973

title: Bar Unit Inspects Courts on Ability to Try Pushers
description: Members of the State Bar Association toured the narcotics courts on the ninth floor of the Civil Court Building yesterday. They were trying to find out whether the courts could handle the vast increase in the number of cases they would have to process if Governor Rockefeller's recent proposals on drug trafficking became law.

title: Institutional Membership Still Opposed by Dreyfus
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, managing organization for one of the largest mutual fund enterprises in the country, renewed its opposition to stock exchange membership for firms that control the destinies of mutual funds, pension funds and other financial institutions.

title: SALES AT RECORDS FOR CHAIN STORES
EQUITY FINANCING
description: Directors of the Babcock & Wilcox Company yesterday authorized acquisition of 500,000 shares of the company's common stock for use in a stockoption plan and for possible acquisitions. The stock closed Wednesday at 23.

title: For a New Westchester
description: A rare item of good news on the public housing front is the decision of the New York State Urban Development Corporation to resume work on planning low, and middleincome housing projects in Westchester County.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: NEW YORK

title: GURT'S PIANO ASSETS FOCUSED ON CLARITY
description: Joseph Gurt, an Australian who studied at the Juilliard School and now teaches at Eastern Michigan University, gave a debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, and he seemed to have all the assets of a firstrate pianist except one. The fundamental virture of his playing lay in its clarity, made up of a firm, precise articulation and a very discreet use of pedal.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Jersey Superior Court Judge Herman D. Michels in Newark ruled yesterday that the New JerseyNew York Waterfront Commission was entitled to look at airline cargo theft records. He denied a motion by American Airlines, Trans World Airlines, United Airlines, Eastern Airlines and Flying Tiger Line to bar access to the records to the commission. The commission has sought access contending that some airlines had minimized their theft estimates.

title: EXAGGERATION MARS COMPARONE RECITAL
description: Elaine Comparone, a harpsichordist who made a brilliant debut here in 1970 and won further praise with a second New York recital in 1971, made her third local solo appearance on Tuesday night in the Introductions series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Boat Show Calendar
description: TODAYBoat show open for public preview, 5 P.M.; American Boat & Yacht Council meeting, Japan and Italy Rooms, Coliseum, all day; Northeastern States Boating Administrators' Conference, Law Enforcement Section, Netherlands Room, Coliseum, 10 A.M.1:30 P.M.; Northeastern States Boating Administrators Conference, Canada Room, Coliseum, 10 A.M.1:30 P.M.; ChrisCraft Corporation press luncheon, New York Yacht Club, 37 West 44th Street noon; Marine Trades Association of New York hospitality suite for all trade visitors opens in Philippines Room, Coliseum, duration of show; Johnson Outboards press breakfast, Blue Room, Essex House, 9 A.M.; Evinrude open house, James Bond Suite, the Plaza, 7.10 P.M.; Olin Marine Safety Award reception, Blue Room, Essex House, 5:308 P.M.; Perkins Engines reception, Garden Room, Essex House, 58 P.M.; Mercury Marine reception, BarbizonPlaza, 57 P.M.

title: Vukovich Gets Indy Ride
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (UPI) Two more cars were entered in the Indianapolis 500 today by Jerry O'Connell of San Jose, Calif. Billy Vukovich is assigned to both of the turbocharged DrakeOffenhauser machines.

title: U.S. Plans to Lift Embargo On Pets and Exotic Birds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)  An embargo imposed last August on imports of pet and exotic birds may soon be lifted, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 2 Patrolmen Who Are Brothers Shot in a Brownsville Attack
description: Two policemenbrothers assigned to the same radio carwere shot and wounded in burst of automaticweapon fire that tore into their vehicle in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn last night.

title: Ferry Sinks Off South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 25 (UPI)A 76ton ferry boat with more than 100 passengers aboard ran aground and sank in dense fog off the southwestern tip of Korea today. Rescue efforts suspended at nightfall after policemen had recovered 13 bodies. Unofficial sources said the death toll could be much higher.

title: Saigon Is OverEquipped in Planes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25Racing against the time when a ceasefire goes into effect, the United States has swamped the South Vietnamese Air Force with hundreds of warplanes it can neither fly nor maintain.

title: Support for Housing Projects Found in Westchester Survey
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 25A survey conducted by Oliver Quayle for the State Urban Development Corporation shows that more than half of all Westchester County residents would favor the construction of 100 low and moderateincome apartment units in their own towns.

title: Curtis F. McClane Dies; State Mediator Was 57
description: Curtis F. McClane, a member of the Board of Mediators and FactFinders of the State Public Employment Relations Board, died Wednesday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia  Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Barriers to Branch Banking Giving Way
description: All over the United States, the structure of banking is in flux. Old barriers to bank expansion, many of them with roots deep in the frontier politics of the 19th century, are falling as bankers struggle to meet the economic and technological challenges of the sevties. In Chicago today, for example, the Illinois Bankers AssociaEconomic tion is voting on Analysis a proposal that would allow limitedarea branch banking and bank holding company operations for the first time in that state. At present, banks in Illinois are required to conduct practically all their operations that involve public contact under one roof.

title: Family Quarrels Bedevil Police
description: Don McNeil opened a door and got shot the other day.

title: Holland Doing What Comes Naturally
description: I'll never cease to be amazed at Holland's compatibility with water. Surrounded by it  and occasionally overrun with it  the Netherlands (lowlands) have spent the six centuries Before Christ and much of modern times keeping the seas at bay. Now, they have taken their finger out of the dike and are letting the water back in.

title: It's a Banner Year For Ethel Ennis
description: Ethel Ennis was supposed to take her first sewing lesson last Wednesday night in her home town, Baltimore, but she had to miss it because she was in Philadelphia on the Mike Douglas television show.

title: Kal Kan Loses Dogfight With Alpo
description: A panel of the National Advertising Review Board has found Kal Kan dog food advertising permeated with false disparagement and unsubstantiated claims against a competitor (Alpo), and although Kal Kan Foods disagrees with the findings it has agreed to replace the specific advertisements and commercials.

title: Lefkowitz Opens Inquiry Into Art Sales by the Met
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has opened an inquiry into the legality and prudence of recent sales of paintings by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: A TRUCE AWAITED
description: PARIS, Jan. 25A high diplomatic source said today that Cambodia would halt her offensive military operations by Sunday on the strength of American assurances that Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho had reached an understanding during their negotiations that the ceasefire in Vietnam would be extended to Laos and Cambodia as well.

title: MAYOR HOPEFULS WOOING SUPPORT
description: Four Democrats who say they would like to be Mayor wooed middleclass support in Queens last night through organization politicians there.

title: MRS. JAMES M'DONNELL
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Jan. 25Mrs. Kathleen Hassett McDonnell, the wife of James R. McDonnell, who retired Jan. 1 as vice president and actuary of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Boca Raton, Fla., where the McDonnells had been vacationing. She was 67 years old and lived at 77 South Park Avenue.

title: American Dies in Shelling Of Air Base Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 26In a surge of Communist ground attacks throughout South Vietnam, a barrage of rockets was fired early today into the Bien Hoa Base near Saigon, killing one American and wounding nine.

title: Snead Leads Senior Golf By Shot With 6Under 66
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Va., Jan. 25 (AP)Sam Snead, trying for his sixth Professional Golfers' Association seniors championship, carded a sixunderpar 66 today and took the firstround lead over the East Course of the P.G.A. National Golf Club. Snead had birdies and one bogey.

title: Quarter Little Changed
Chief Negotiator Is Unsure of Poltical Will to Reform
description: PARIS, Jan. 25  Jeremy Morse, who is in charge of drafting an accord to revamp the world monetary system, said today that some progress was being made, but he indicated doubt as to whether there was sufficient political will to achieve reform.

title: EXTREMISTS ACTIVE IN '72, GRAY ASSERTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that extremist groups continued their efforts to stir up racial unrest in 1972.

title: Public to Preview National Boat Show's Bright New Image
description: The Aussies are here. With them is a wide range of motors and sailboats, boating equipment and accessories, and water sports equipment heretofore unavailable or of limited availability in the United States. It is the Australians' first appearance at the show.

title: Bad Weather in Texas Cats TV Broadcasts
description: Bad weather in Texas prevented the three television networks from broadcasting the burial service for former President Lyndon B. Johnson in its entirety yesterday.

title: Profit and Revenue Rise At Long Island Lighting
description: The Long Island Lighting Company had earnings of $56.2million, tir $2.20 a share, last year compared with $50.2million in 1971, the company reported yesterday. This represents the 20th year of increased earnings for the company.

title: DR. JEAN BEASLEY
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 25 Dr. Jean Tallman Beasley, pediatrician, died yesterday at YaleNew Haven Hospital. She was 51 years old and lived at 272 Bayberry Lane.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Yugoslavia Aims at Stronger Police
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 Plans for stronger and broader central police powers are being hinted by federal authorities of Yugoslavia as part of a recent overall tightening of discipline in the country.

title: Shoemaker Is Injured In Santa Anita Mishap
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI)  Bill Shoemaker, the career leading jockey, and Jerry Lambert were injured in a ninthrace spill at Santa Anita today and were taken to a Hospital.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Highway Authority has awarded two contracts totaling nearly $15million for construction work on the widening of the Garden State Parkway from the Raritan toll paza in Sayreville to the Asbury Park loll plaza.

title: Snead Shoots Another 66, Leads Seniors by 7 Shots
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 26 (UPI)Sam Snead, his age and his golf game both In the 60's these days, shot a 66 today to take a sevenstroke secondround lead in the $40,000 Seniors golf championship.

title: Air Riders Take Search in Stride
description: A neatly dressed woman in her fifties, heading south for a winter holiday in Miami, was stopped by an Eastern Airlines security agent at La Guardia Airport the other day because she had tripped a gundetection device.

title: A Dismissed C.B.S. Aide Files $2Million Bias Suit
description: A former publicity woman for C.B.S. News, saying she had been discriminated against, filed a $2million suit here yesterday charging that the Columbia Broadcasting System and C.B.S. News had discharged her partly because of her close friendship with a black reporter.

title: Dave Anderson
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Jan. 26Quickly, he slid off the long white pants, took off the white jacket and reported the scorer's table.

title: Dance: Balanchine's Don Quixote
description: When I first saw George Balanchine's Don Quixote, I saw its concept rather than its achievement. I hoped that in a repertory situation it might be able to grow up as a theater piece. Two years agothe last time I saw itI raised doubts as to whether its growth was appreciable. Now I know. The work is an insufferable bore, and it would be to the New York City Ballet's advantage if it were to be dumped forever.

title: MARCOS CHARTER CHALLENGED BY 5
description: MANILA, Jan. 26Five senators asked the Supreme Court today to prohibit the martial law Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos from in terfering with the performance of our lawful duties as senators of the Philippines.

title: Reserve Unable to Slow Money Growth in week
description: Monetary expansion accelerated this week, despite efforts of the Federal Reserve System to slow it down, the central bank reported yesterday.

title: Press Said to Look Ahead
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 (AP)Political columnists and sports writers violate Maryland law by predicting the future, according to Judge Robert Gerstung. Agreeing with an attorney whose client was accused of violating a law against fortune telling, Judge Gerstung said he could find no difference between fortune tellers and the media prognosticators. He firied the woman $10.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 26 (AP)  A young United States team with emphasis on teenagers could finally turn the tide tomorrow and deal the Soviet Union its first defeat in the fifth of the international boxing matches. For the first time, the American forces have strength throughout the weight divisions, ranging from 106 pounds to heavyweight. However, the American entrants are almost all youngsters, 17 years old and younger.

title: POLICE REINFORCE BROOKLYN PATROL IN HIGHRISK AREA
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday authorized 1,000 extra tours of duty for policemen in 11 precincts in the Brooklyn North Command during the next 30 days following the shooting of two policemen in Brownsville Thursday night.

title: SOLDIER ON PATROL IN ULSTER IS SHOT
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 26Terrorists fired tonight on a British Army patrol in Lurgan, 20 miles west of Belfast, and one soldier was struck in the back by a bullet. He was taken to a hospital where his condition was reported as very serious.

title: New Capital for British HondurasAlmost
description: BELMOPAN, British Honduras, Jan. 26  It is clear that Belmopan won't be built in a day, so the little things are important in this settlement hacked out of the jungle a few years ago things that tell of, the birth of a city and a new capital.

title: MAYOR ADVOCATES SHIELD FOR PRESS
description: Mayor Lindsay urged yesterday the enactment of Federa legislation to protect newsmer from being forced to divulge confidential sources of information.

title: Antiques: China Trade
description: MILTON, Mass.  What served as mere ballast, protecting the precious tea cargos on ships returning from Canton, China, to Boston a century and more ago, has become in recent months the new focus for a small but enterprising museum here and the subject of an enlightening, of controversial, book by a Boston author.

title: An Old Hand at Truces
description: When Maj. Gen., Gilbert Hume Woodward was last in charge of overseeing an Asian ceasefirethe one in Koreahe honed and developed a gift for negotiation and coolness under insult, innuendo and harangue.

title: PRICERISE SURGE CITED BY BUYERS
description: The nation's businesses have been confronted with a flurry of price increases this month, according to a survey of purchasing agents.

title: MARILYN COCHRAN WINS CUP SLALOM
description: CHAMONIX, France, Jan. 26 (AP)  Marilyn Cochran, flu eldest sister of the United States' No. 1 skiing family, too?? her country's first World Cup victory of the season in the Kandahar special slalom today.

title: At Dart Board, Women, Too, Are on Target
description: Anna Adames is a barmaid. Adele Nutter is a vision therapist. Lauren Lidz is a secretary. One of them is also the reigning United States champion woman dart thrower. Will the real champ please stand up? It may seem a bit obvious, but the champ is the vision therapist, Miss Nutter. She is a slender 35yearold Greenwich Village resident who earns her living prescribing exercises for people with crossed eyes or other vision problems.

title: WINE TALK
description: For years, American winemakers have battled  unsuccessfully  to force European vintners to bottle their wine according to United States standards of fill: pints, quarts and gallons.

title: Warm Spell Arouses Concern Over Fate of Crops and Plants
description: Unusually mild winter weather, while good for strolling and sunning, has begun to arouse concern over possible damage to crops and plants in the threestate metropolitan area.

title: E.C.A.C. Basketball
description: AT PROVIDENCE, R.I.

title: People and Business
description: Donald E. Weeden, chair man of Weeden & Co., and James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, do not see eye to eye on the role of the third market. But they are friendly antagonists.

title: Kickback Charges Disclosed by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an exceptionally rare move, today released some details of a case charging a number of major Wall Street brokerage firms with making kickbacks to a state official in return for ousiness.

title: PerfumeBrewing Amateurs Can Do
description: Add another possibilityperfume mixingto the doityourself craze that's intriguing the country these days.

title: In Praise of East Fifth
description: Late last spring, after 22 years therein, W. H. Auden announced he would be leaving his Lower East Side apartment for a cottage in Christ Church, Oxford, England. Naturally, it was assumed that he was leaving because he couldn't stand the neighborhood any longer: Gem Spa had dried up, the. Electric Circus had been unplugged, and the Fillmore was filled no more. Now Auden, too, would be leaving.

title: Trial of Four Accused of Killing Policeman Ended by Hung Jury
description: State Supreme Court Justice Hyman Barshay in Brooklyn declared a mistrial yesterday when the jury became deadlocked in the case of four men charged with the murder last March of an offduty policeman in a Fort Greene butcher shop.

title: Laver Is Upset by Dibley In $50,000 Tennis Tourney
description: LA COSTA, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP)Unseeded Colin Dibley of Australia caught topseeded Rod Laver off guard tonight and upset his countryman, 64, 63, to move in to the final of the $50,000 World Championship of Tennis tournament. Earlier, secondseeded Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., beat Australia's Roy Emerson in the other semifinal match, 75, 26. 64.

title: N.A.S.D. Tells BunkerRamo It Wants to Buy NASDAQ
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday it has told the BunkerRamo Corporation that it is interested in buying the NASDAQ system.

title: Regular Soldier, as War Wanes, Getting Ready for the Next One
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C.Long before the ceasefire agreement was initialed, they chucked out the souvenirs of this war  the stubby AK47 rifle, the Ho Chi Minh sandals made from old tire casings, the Montagnard crossbow; even the mahogany desk plaque with Well Done? engraved in shiny brass.

title: People in Sports: Gabriel Hopes Rams Trade Him
description: Roman Gabriel, the Los Angeles Rams quarterback, apparently miffed that the club traded away two players to acquire John Hadl from the San Diego Chargers this week, asked yesterday to be traded to Washington, where he could rejoin George Allen, former Rams' coach, who was dismissed by the club two years ago. Gabriel said there would be no news conference, and his lawyer said that the 32yearold quarterback would not accept calls. However, a Rams' spokesman said Gabriel called the club office in the morning and quoted him as saying: If anybody asks, tell those who are interested that I want to be traded to the Washington Redskins. Tell anybody who asks that is my wish.

title: Container Shipping Gains
description: Container shipping, a dimension in ocean transport only 15 years old, is about to reach maturity.

title: Gloucester County Is on Brink of Development Boom
description: WOODBURY, Jan. 26One of the last undeveloped counties in the Eastern megalopolisNew Jersey's Gloucester County, across the Delaware River from Philadelphiais on the verge of a population, employment and building boom.

title: Slim Talbot, 77, Stuntman For Gary Cooper, Is Dead
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 26 (AP)Slim Talbot, who spent nearly 10 years as a standin stuntman for Gary Cooper, the movie star, died of cancer yesterday. He was 77 years old.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Soybean futures climbed the 10centsabushel limit and then remained at that level with virtually no selling.

title: Record Vaulter Rises to the Occasion
description: At 10 o'clock last night, the lights at Madison Square Garden went dim, Toby Wright played the first strains of the National Anthem and Steve Smith, mobbed by a band of eager autographseekers, stood up on the, wooden chair on which he had beensitting.

title: Art: Metaset A an Serene Collages
description: Any man who flunked freshman math three years running and dropped Philosophy I as a precautionary measure after the first lecture is hardly the ideal reviewer for the mathematicalphilosophical project called Metaset A by Marian Warzecha at the LandryBonino Gallery, 7 West 57th Street. But I feel safe in urging a visit all the same. In addition to Metaset A, which fills the gallery's front room, Mr. Warzecha is exhibiting a group of more conventional collages of the kind that first brought him to attention in this country in the Museum of Modern Art's Fifteen Polish Painters exhibition of 1961. The collages can serve as an escape hatch or esthetic parachute for anyone who finds Metaset A tough going.

title: CELTICS WIN 10TH IN ROW, 139 TO 126
description: BOSTON, Jan. 26 (AP)The Boston Celtics built a big secondperiod Iead on the shooting of John Havlicek and Don Chaney and gained their 10th consecutive victory, tonight, a 139126 National Basketball Association decision over the Houston Rockets.

title: U.S. Names General to Head Delegation to Four Power CeaseFire Commission
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26Maj. Gen. Gilbert H. Woodward, a tough 55yearold veteran of negotiations with the North Korean Communists, has been designated to command the United States delegation to the fourpower joint military commission that will help supervise the coming Vietnam ceasefire.

title: The Morning the Volcano Awoke Iceland Isle: Grass Was Burning
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Jan. 26The wind shifted to the east and blew hard all last night through the Vestmannaeyjar, an island group off the southern coast of Iceland.

title: I.B.M. Charged by U.S. With Destroying Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Justice Department accused the International Business Machines Coproation to??ay of deliberately destroying ??ocuments the Government ays are necessary in an anti??onopoly suit it filed a7ainst the giant corporation four years go.

title: RALLY PRIZE GOES TO FRENCH TEAM
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 26 (UPI)  Jean Claude Andreut and Michele Petit of France won the Monte Carlo rally today in the closest finish in its 62year history. The victors ?? a 1, 2, 3 sweep of Alpine Renaults to their second tri?? in three years.

title: Urban Warfare?
description: In the same rundown area of Brooklyn where other shootings have occurred in recent days, machinegun fire ripped into a police squad car on routine patrol night before last. Two officers were wounded, miraculously not seriously; gunmen were reported by officials to have sped from the scene in what was described as a definite ambush.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: You said in an editorial (Jan. 5) that Prime Minister Jack Lynch of the Republic of Ireland would use his five days in this country to dissuade IrishAmericans from contributing funds ostensibly for relief in Northern Ireland but used to buy guns, and ammunition for the Irish Republican Army Provisions's. You were quite right. Mr. Lynch has been on television shows here saying exactly that and suggesting that those who wished to help the beleaguered Nationalists of Northern Ireland should do so through the Irish Red Cross. He omitted to say that the Irish Red Cross has no jurisdiction in Northern Ireland and in fact can distribute no reliefand has distributed noneto the Nationalists of Northern Ireland during the of turmoil since 1969.

title: Jury Is Told Nixon Aides Knew of Watergate Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Evidence that $199,000 in campaign funds was paid to a defendant in the Watergate trial with the approval of two ranking Presidential advisers was read to the jury today.

title: CEASEFIRE TEAMS AWAITED IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26Polish and Canadian diplomats said today they were doubtful that the international commission intended to supervise the ceasefire in South Vietnam would be able to establish a functioning headquarters within the time specified in the protocols of the peace agreement.

title: For the Vietnamese, No Cessation of Pain
description: SAIGON, South VietnamFor most of the people of South Vietnam the end of the warif it is the end of their waris coming far too late for rejoicing.

title: The Number Is 61 As U.C.L.A. Plays Notre Dame Today
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 26 A chance to prevent the longest winning streak in collegiate basketball history is a shot that comes once in a lifetime, so grab at it, according to Digger Phelps, coach of Notre Dame's young team.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: TAY NINH REPORTS ATTACK BY ENEMY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 27Communist troops reportedly attacked Tay Ninh city west of Saigon this morning as they stepped up their assaults throughout South Vietnam in preparation for tomorrow's ceasefire.

title: Boat Show Is Set for Launching
description: Will the National Boat Show break its alltime record for attendance421,800 set in 1969? If yesterday's weather and optimism at the Coliseum show's preview are any criteria, the answer is a resounding yes.

title: WOMAN SAID TO ASK APOLOGY BY SINATRA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Maxine Cheshire, a Washington Post columnist, is asking Frank Sinatra to apologize publicly for unspeakable, unprintable remarks that she said he made about her at party during the inauguration weekend, sources close to the case said today.

title: NET SOARS 35.6% AT SCOTT PAPER
2 Youths Seized in Fatal Stabbing of Japanese
description: The police yesterday announced the arrest of two of three youths believed to have been involved in the fatal New Year's Day stabbing of a 24yearold Japanese man.

title: Store Sales Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $702million, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $624million. Total retail store sales were about $8.25billion, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $7.2billion.

title: Honor for Johnson Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  A resolution to rename National Airport here after the late fermer President Lyndon B. Johnson was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia.

title: Protest Halts Work on a Harlem School
description: A Harlem group demanding more hiring of minoritygroup people and more contracts for minority concerns, prevented a builder from continuing work on a school site yesterday, just as the Board of Education was concluding talks to satisfy similar demands on the same builder from a BedfordStuyvesant group.

title: Pike Hails the Good News, but...
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Members of Congress from New York were delighted last week when the Air Force announced that Fairchild Industries, Inc. at Farmingdale, L. I., had been selected to produce a new combat aircraft.

title: I. T. T. Is Seeking Publisher
description: G. P. Putnam's Sons, a 135yearold general book publishing company, may soon be acquired by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, a huge conglomerate.

title: Yoga Exercise Fad in Soviet Is Vigorously Attacked
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 26A lively controversy appears to be building up in the Soviet Union over the yoga system of exercises, whose mysteries have been attracting a growing number of practitioners here, especially among scientists and engineers.

title: U.S ASKS CAUTION ON INTEREST RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 26The Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends today urged financial institutions, including commercial banks, not to raise their interest rates solely on the basis of higher marginal costs of funds from sensitive market sources.

title: After 20Year Wait, Scanner Is Patented
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26After a 20year wait, the Singer Company got two patents this week for inventions that it believes many other companies have put to work. The patents cover character recognition apparatus and methods for reading typed and handwritten documents, Patents 3,713,099 and 3.713.100 are assigned to the Character Recognition Corporation, of Morton Grove, a Singer subsidiary formed to hold them. Harold S. Hemstreet, then a Singer employe, filed the applications Feb. 10, 1953. Issuance was delayed by interference with rival applications in the Patent Office.

title: PRICE CONTROLS END FOR DRUGS, LIQUOR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 26The Cost of Living Council announced today that mandatory price controls on food would not apply to medicines, Alcoholic beverages and animal feed, including soybean products.

title: Fort Monmouth Hospital Gets Ready To Give Freed P.O.W.'s Best Care
description: FORT MONMOUTH, Jan. 26 Final touches were being put today on plans at Patterson Army Hospital here to receive and care for freed Army prisoners from Vietnam whose homes and families are in the New Jersey and New York metropolitan area.

title: PostVietnam Priorities
description: Administration officials have confirmed that, so far as they are concerned, there will be no postVietnam peace dividend to be used for meeting the needs of the cities and other longneglected domestic problems.

title: CANUCKS DEFEAT ISLANDERS BY 51
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 26 (UPI)Don Tannahill scored his 16th and 17th goals of the season tonight in leading the Vancouver Canucks to a 51 National. Hockey League victory over the. New York Islanders.

title: SAFETY OF PRISONERS IN SAIGON DOUBTED
description: LONDON, Jan. 26Amnesty International expressed fear today for the safety of political prisoners in South Vietnam.

title: City Buys Flatbush Park
description: The city purchased a 6.7acre park in Flatbush, Brooklyn, from the Society of Friends yesterday for $1.9million to permit its continued use by athletic groups and residents of the neighborhood. Onehalf of the price will be defrayed by grant from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Notes on People
description: The Bangladesh Embassy in Washington said its first ambassador to the United States, M. Hossain All, would arrive here Monday. Mr. Ali, who is 48 years old, has been High Commissioner to Australia for Bangladesh. Before the war against Pakistan, he was Deputy High Commissioner for Pakistan in Calcutta, India. In April, 1971, while he was in Calcutta, Mr. Ali left the Pakistani foreign service and joined the Bangladesh liberation movement. His wife and three children are accompanying him to Washington. The United States formally recognized Bangladesh as a nation last April.

title: NIXON COMMITTEE IS FINED $8,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  The Finance Committee to ReElect the President was fined $8,000 today for, illegally spending money during last year's Presidential campaign.

title: East Adds Giacomin To N.H.L. Star Squad
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (Canadian Press)Ed Giacomin, a New York Rangers goalie, was selected today to join his teammate, Gilles Villemure, and form an allNew York goaltending tandem on the East Division squad that will face the West Tuesday night in the National Hockey League's 26th annual AllStar game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Swedish Businessman Weds Princess Xenia
description: BONN, Jan. 26Princess Xenia Sophie Charlotte Cecilie of Prussia, 23 years old, was married today to Per Edvard Lythander, 27, a Swedish businessman, in a simple ceremony performed by a justice of the peace in Bremen.

title: City Loses and Wins in Welfare Suit
description: The United States Court of Appeals yesterday dismissed major sections of a city lawsuit against welfare costs mandated by the Federal and state governments, but it ordered a hearing on one of Mayor Lindsay's most persistent complaints about the city being shortchanged in state welfare assistance.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation directors have authorized a threemillion commonshare issue to help finance the company's construction program, it was announced yesterday. Pending approval by the approval by the New York Public Service Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission the stock will be sold at competitive bidding on March 22. The utility's stock closed at 17, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Last Man
description: In a war that has never made much sense at best, it seems uniquely, senseless that soldiers and civilians are being killed in these waning hours between President Nixon's announcement Tuesday of a peace agreement and the, moment this evening when the ceasefire formally takes effect. For the families of these final victims of the war, the circumstances lend an added poignancy to their grief.

title: What Blacks Can Expect
description: ALBANYThere is not a great deal of indication that President Nixon will carry on any differently in the next four years: than in, the last, especially when it comes to matters concerning American blacks.

title: ArtStudy Growth Noted in Parley Here
description: The annual meetings of the College Art Association have a twofold interest. They offer members of the academic art profession  art historians, museum scholars and artistteachers  an uptodate sense of the changing configuration of art studies. They also offer an opportunity  or, as the case is more likely to be nowalays, a gauge of the lack of opportunity  for seeking out new employment possibilities.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Beginning tomorrow three blocks of Orchard Street on the Lower East Side, where the uptown decendants of yesterday's immigrants have converged for years in search of bargains and nostalgia, will be converted to a Sunday pedestrian mall.

title: The Last Tango
description: PARISThe second Indochina war is ending as it began, in obscurity and contradiction. It is like a Pirandello play, confounding appearance and reality. But as in Pirandello, there is profound theme to be found amid the confusion.

title: Police Volunteers Provide a Rear Guard
description: The man with the goatee, wearing a planter's hat and high boots, looked more like riverboat gambler than a policeman, but he had one pistol strapped to his left ankle and two at his waist. When the new volunteer police tours began last night, he was behind the wheel of his Bahama yellow 1971 Plymouth Duster following a 79th Precinct radio car on its rounds in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Edward G. Robinson, 79, Dies; Famed as Films' Little Caesar'
description: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 26 Edward G. Robinson, whose tough sinister appearance on movie screens concealed the soul of a gentle man, died today at the age of 79.

title: Bridge: The Lengthier the Bidding, The More Clues for Lead
description: The lengthier the bidding, the more clues are available to the opening leader. If West had taken a little more time to make a crucial lead on the diagramed deal from the Grand Nationals here, he would have defeated a grand slam and helped his team oust one of the topranked groups.

title: Hartke Offers to Compromise on Controversial Legislation on Trade Quotas and Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Senator Vance Hartke, coauthor of the controversial BurkeHartke trade and tax bill, offered today to compromise on two key points of the legislation.

title: 3D Into 2D: Drawings by Sculptors
description: 3D into 2D: Drawing for Sculpture, the title of the exhibition on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, sounds promising. But there is less of an idea here than meets the idea.

title: 4 Die in Lagoon
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)The authorities recovered the bodies of four youngsters who apparently fell through thin ice while playing on a lagoon on the city's South Side last night. Three of the victims were identified as Benjamin Barfield, 9 years old, his brother, Ronnie, 7, and Robert Bennett 10. The fourth boy was tentatively identified as Isaac Ivey, 10.

description: LONDON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Arthur Ashe of Miami and Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., floundered today in the semifinal round of the Rothmans $50,000 indoor tennis tournament.

title: Despite Killings and Court Order, Mississippi Penitentiary Still Uses Armed Trusties
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 19 Mississippians used to chuckle when they told such Stories as the one about the state peni tentiary prisoner trusty who was sent alone to Arkansas on prison business and vanished. Former Gov. Ross Barnet is said to have sighed and asked, If you can't trust a trusty, who can you trust?

title: CAMBODIA CONFIRMS A TEST CEASEFIRE

title: WLIWTV Returns Monday
description: WLIWTV, the educational television station in Garden City, L. J., will resume broadcasting at 12:30 P.M, Monday, after being off the air a week. Last Monday night the station, Channel 21, suffered a loss of broadcast signal because of a burnout in an adapter on a tower at Mitchel Field.

title: J. CARROL NAISH, ACTOR, 73, DEAD
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP)  J. Carrol Naish, the screen, television and stage actor who was a master of dialects, died Wednesday in Scripps Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Insider Charges Upset ExChannel 13 President
description: James Day, who resigned last week as president of Channel 13, has protested, in a memorandum to stiff members there, allegations, made by station insiders to The New York Times about the reasons for his resignation.

title: Coming Up for Air
description: One of the fiercest battles in the last Congress ended in a stalemate. The Senate voted to open up the sacrosanct Highway Trust Fund to permit the use of $800million a year for mass transit. Since the fund currently has annual revenue of $5.8 billion, that was hardly huge diversion from the normal flow of money for highways. Even so, the House Public Works Committee and the highway lobby refused to yield a cent. As a result, Congress failed to renew the Federal Highway Act.

title: Why Blacks Turned Right
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.From beneath the social rubble of the tumultuous 1960's there has emerged an interesting trend in black political thinking. The black drive for social reform which became the militant black power movement in the latter part of the decade has now taken a turn in the opposite direction. The AfroAmerican community, once considered a hotbed of radicalism, is rapidly becoming new conservative force in American politics.

The case will be assigned to another judge sitting in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: GAMBINO NEPHEW IS BELIEVED DEM
description: A partially decomposed body believed to be that of Emanue Gambino, nephew of Carld Gambino, the reputed Math boss, was found wrapped in blanket in a fourfoot grave Colts Neck, N. J., yesterday afternoon by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: The President's Men'33 and '73
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.There seems to be a return among commentators to using brain trust as a covering description for White House Assistants. It seems to me as inappropriate now as it was in Franklin D. Roosevelt's Presidency. It has always been the contention of those who were helpers before and during the campaign of 1932 that the brain trust ended its work when Roosevelt was elected. True, all those who afterward worked around the White House Were called brain trusters; but the group was so enlarged then that the term no longer had any meaning.

Abzug, speaking at a news conference called by the National Association for the Repeal of Abortion Laws, said yesterday that she would work to get through Congress a bill that would go further than the Supreme Court had in its recent decision upholding abortions.

title: The Screen: 'Trick Baby':The Cast
description: I don't know what you might expect from a movie title like "Trick Baby," But what you get is the story of a pair of engaging con men who lie themselves to their glory and to their doom, during a couple of fateful days in the grimier reaches of Philadelphia. Directed by Larry Yust, and essentially the work of not terribly well-known talents, "Trick Baby" opened yesterday at the DeMille and Juliet 2 Theaters.Both Blue Howard (Mel Stewart) and his young companion White Folks (Kiel Martin) are black, but only Blue looks it. White Folks, son of a white father and a black mother, is so white that he can passmainly as one Johnny O'Brien  and passing is the essence of his game. Folks plays white and Blue plays blackoppressed black  and their victims, their marks, play at economic exploitation with greater or lesser degrees of racist venality."We got them squeezed between us . . . With your complexion and my brains, the sky's the limit," boasts Blue, the prospect of $90,000 inner-city real estate con almost as certain for him as tomorrow's breakfast. But a little later, with the mob after his head, and tomorrow's breakfast likely to be a last meal, if he lives that long, he pulls another cona rather beautiful one, and just for a night's lodgingand confesses that he still needs his calling: "Lying takes my mind off my troubles."Despite the crudity of its racial stereotypes, especially its white racial stereotypes, "Trick Baby" seems most interesting in its understanding of race relationswhich I assume are at issue in the friendship, almost love, between Blue and Folks. Folks really is white. The film says he's black, and he manages a few soulful turns of phrase, but your eyes and your ears tell you he's white. At the movies, that is all you have to go on. The point is that relations between Folks and Blue are absolutely normal, not very competitive, resilient, and rich in a kind of mutual professional appreciation. The playing of the cons is funny, but very restrained, and the two con men seem to demonstrate viabilityhowever precarious it may be.There are enough things wrong with "Trick Baby" to fill a bad review, and yet I think it deserves a good one. Half its characterizations are absurd (the female leads, Beverly Ballard and Vernce Watson, suffer particularly) and the other half are very fine. Much of the spoken rationalization is nonsense, but the physical action is often very true, not especially violent, but exciting.Larry Yust indulges in too much flashy sound montage and in the obtrusive cross-cutting into sequences that seems the curse of the newer movies. But he and Isidore Mankofsky have a lovely sense of place and perspective for the camera frame and, in the slums of Philadelphia, a bleak and fascinating cityscape in which to exercise it.

Reserve assets are used to pay off official debts with other countries. Most of the reserves are in gold.

title: Screen: Wives in 'Limbo':Robson Views P.O.W. Families at Festival
description: If it has nothing else  and Mark Robson's "Limbo" hasn't  you might at least expect topicality of a film about the problems facing wives of American servicemen who are either missing in action in Vietnam or prisoners of war. By using something less than the sheerest art, Robson manages to make this story ("torn from today's headlines," we are told) resemble any number of dreadful World War II tearjerkers."Interestingly, however, "Limbo" does demonstrate the impotency of so much of the liberal opposition to the war that is now, apparently, coming to an end.Robson is, I take it, a liberal. He certainly was back in the late ninteen-forties when he directed such films as "Champion" and "Home of The Brave."In that optimistic time, political and social issues were clear cut. War against bigotry was simply an extension of the war against Hitler. It was cosily patriotic. The good, voting liberal had not yet had to wrestle with the unruly, rising consciousnesses of all sorts of impatient groups, with, for example, the new black philosophy that says to hell with integration, we'll do it by ourselves.A lot of liberals lost heart in the nineteen-fifties and sixties. It is not fun being ridiculed by the people you had always wanted to protect. Robson, for reasons of his own, has devoted most of his later career to big-budget nonsense on the order of "Peyton Place," "Von Ryan's Express" and "Valley of The Dolls." Watching "Limbo," you can speculate why.The mind that made it is, I suspect, outraged by the war but seems afraid to say so. It is as split in mood as a lot of other people may be split in their sympathies  feeling sorrow for the American P.O.W. fliers, yet overwhelmed by fury with those who continued to go on bombing missions.The liberals protested but mostly with a politeness born, I think, out of memories of World War II, and even Korea, when wars were declared and the stakes were easy to define. There is a similar liberal sort of politeness in 'Limbo," which is as obvious in its narrative structure and physical look as in anything that anyone says.The screenplay, by Joan Silver and James Bridges, set on an Air Force base in Florida, is about three wives who are three points of view, good, bad and all mixed-up.The good wife (Kathleen Nolan) is middle-aged, Catholic, the mother of four, faithful to her husband and angry about the war.The bad one (Katherine Justice) is rich, beautiful, Southern, an all-out patriot and so spoiled that she refuses to believe the eyewitness report of her husband's death.The confused one is Kate Jackson, married only two weeks before her husband's departure, and now hopelessly in love with a nice, honorable, out-of-work space technician.The situations are real enough, but Robson entombs them in a lot of bogus domestic complications, photographed and acted in a simplistic romantic style that denies any sense of real topicality and urgency. If Vietnam were a war like any other (which it is not), there might be a small point to this approach.Only occasionally does the film seem to be about a special, very confused moment in history, but Robson tends to flub these moments too, as in the sequence in which three American wives visit the North Vietnamese embassy in Paris. He opens the sequence with some nice old chop-chop music that 40 years ago used to identify a stock shot of wicked Shanghai.Robson's heart is in the right place, but his movie is unimaginative, phony and ineffectual. It opened yesterday at the Festival.

title: BANKERS IN ILLINOIS REJECT BRANCH PLAN
description: Members of the Illinois Bankers Association rejected yesterclay, by a vote of 639 to 317, a proposal that would have endorsed limited branch banking and bank holding company operations in the state. Under present Illinois law, banks are required, for all practical purposes, to conduct their operations under one roof.

title: Air Riders Take Search in Stride
description: A neatly dressed woman in her fifties, heading south for a winter holiday in Miami, was stopped by an Eastern Airlines security agent at La Guardia Airport the other day because she had tripped a gundetection device.

title: Records: Jazz Singing
description: No term is quite as vague as jazz singerunless it is the word jazz itself. Most jazz instrumentalists who also sing can justifiably be called jazz singers because they use their voices the way they use their instruments. Louis Armstrong and Fats Waller were outstanding examples. Even a singer on the level of Benny Goodman can transfer his instrumental jazz instincts to a voice that is, to put it kindly, limited.

title: Opera: A Fine Macbeth
description: What with a new conductor and everybody new to his or her role at the Metropolitan Opera, Verdi's Macbeth assumed a new look on Thursday evening. It was the first time this season that the opera was given. No matter what one thinks of the Neher production  those costumes! really!it is a wonderful opera that never fails to make an impact.

title: Basque Kidnappers Release Spanish Industrialist Unhurt

title: Phase 3: Raising Prices Appears Easier
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26In the two weeks since the start of the third phase of wageprice regulation (controls is now taboo), the Nixon Administration has done nothing to dispel the spreading impression that raising prices will be easier than it was during the second phase. Watch what we do, not what we say, says a key official. He concedes, however, that so far there has been nothing to watch. The Cost of Living Council had an opportunity to open the figurative closet door a crack this week and give the oil industry a peep at the stick the possibility of Federal interventionthat Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz has threatened to swing against those who breach the price standards. The opportunity occurred when two major oil companies, first Mobil and then Exxon, raised fuel oil prices.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Federal District Judge George L. Hart Jr. refused today to grant a new trial to former Senator Daniel Brewster, who had been convicted of accepting an illegal gratuity. Brewster said that he would appeal.

description: The screen brightens to show a young woman in evening dress and a young man in white tie, kissing her raised, gloved hand. She says, in a deep Southern accent, This is tha en.

description: WASHINGTON, Ian. 27 (AP) Parris C. Lind, a paralyzed businessman who runs a chain of 81 gasoline stations in four states, was named Handicapped American of the Year today by the President's Committee on employment of the handicapped. Mr. Lind, who lives in Boise, Idaho, will receive the President's Trophy, the nation's highest tribute to the courage and determination of the handicapped.

title: A Reluctant G.I.'s Life and Death
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo.The house ?? Penn Street where Charley Stockbauer used to live sits ?? a historic crossroads of America.
