description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.  One of the largest adult education systems in the state has started its spring semester with an increased number of occupational training courses.

title: With New Loran, Who Needs People?
description: For hundreds of years navigators have struggled to sight their sextants along the horizon despite a rolling deck beneath them. With the introduction of electronic aids, the navigator could stay under cover. The positioning task became easier and the accuracy of the fixes was usually better than that computed from sextant observations in rough weather.

title: Waldheim Offers U.N. Aid In Recovery for Vietnam
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 (Reuters)  Secretary General Waldheim offered the help of the United Nations today in the urgent priority task of rehabilitation and reconstruction in Vietnam.

title: France
description: On a visit to Paris last week to mark the 10th anniversary of the signing of a treaty of friendship between France and West Germany, Chancellor Willy Brandt went to the Arc de Triomphe to place a wreath on the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. It was a subtle departure from protocol in that the soldier had been killed by German arms and only former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer had been accorded the privilege on the occasion of the original signing of the treaty.

title: Pascack Hospital Gets a V.D. Unit
description: WESTWOOD  Pascack Valley Hospital is now the fourth private hospital in Bergen County to have a veneral disease clinic open to the public. The others are Englewood Hospital, Hackensack Hospital and Valley Hospital in Ridgewood.

title: Mother Accused of Kidnapping in Italy
description: A 32yearold Brooklyn woman who went to Italy to take her 9yearold daughter away from her estranged husband there Was held on kidnapping charges here yesterday  accused of having carried off another girl by what her lawyer Said was a mistake.

title: Mrs. Murphy Bride Of Kevin Casselman
description: Mrs. Ruth Zagat Murphy, widow of. Dr. Albert J. Murphy, was married at her home here yesterday to Kevin M. A. Casselman of Los Angeles. The Rev. Dr. Donald Szantho Harrington of the Community Church of New York performed the ceremony at noon.

title: SHOP TALK
description: CHATHAMSeconds of the fine stoneware it makes can be acquired in the shop operated here by Chatham Potters. The firstquality, perfect pieces that fill stoneware orders from all over the world (even, surprisingly, from Japan) are not on display; however, they are available, at twice the price of seconds, for those who want them.

title: PUBLIC HOUSING CURB SCORED IN CAROLINA
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 27An unusual coalition of bankers, building developers and representatives of poor blacks joined state and local officials this week in criticizing the Nixon Administration's moratorium on subsidized housing.

title: Mrs. Bonner Has Nuptials
description: Mrs. Barbara Bonner was married here last evening to Dr. Charles W. Socarides. The Rev. Thomas Pike performed the ceremony in the chapel of Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: Chess: For Al Horowitz, Esthetics Was a Prime Consideration
description: Al Horowitz, who was The Times's chess columnist for 10 years and who died Jan. 18, was an international master and one of America's foremost players in the nineteenthirties and forties. The world championships that the United States team won in 1931, 1935 and 1937 were due in large part to the terrible swath he cut through the European players. At home, he won the U.S. Open Championship three times.

title: MOODY, WITH 206, LEADS BY 4 SHOTS
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 27Orville Moody, the former Army sergeant who surprised the golf world by winning the 1969 United States Open, gained nine strokes on Billy Casper today and took a fourstroke lead after 54 holes in the Bing Crosby tournament.

title: Visions Of Cody
description: Jack Kerouac's On the Road was the Huckleberry Finn of the mid20th century. Kerouac substituted the road for the river, the fast car for the slow raft, the hipster in search of freedom for the black slave in search of freedom. At one point, Kerouac even planned to write a black boy into his story to insure the comparison with Twain, then changed his mind. While Huck and Jim were floating down America's milewide aorta, while Sal Paradise and Dean Moriarty were roaring across America's heart, they were helping to change the course of American prose.

title: Senator Wins a Ms.
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP)The term Ms. is entering official Journals of the Massachusetts Senate this year. Senator Anna Buckley, Democrat of Brockton, requested that she be referred to in the official records of Senate proceedings as Ms. Buckley, and Senate Clerk Norman L. Pidgeon has honored her request.

title: Linda Munroe Fiancee
description: WOODBURY, L.I., Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Munroe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Jane Munroe, to William Wardell Them, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Them of Curwinsville, Pa.

title: Corona's Attorney, Criticizing Prosecutor, Seeks a New Trial
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Jan. 27Richard E. Hawk, attorney for Juan V. Corona, the .38year old Mexican labor contractor who was convicted on Jan. 18 of murdering 25 migrant farm workers, will present motions for a new trial to Judge Richard E. Patton at the Solano County hall of justice here early next week.

title: The Early Asimov
description: When reviewing science fiction (or science writing, or speculative writing about science or about science fiction), it becomes necessary from time to time to organize an Isaac Asimov festival. So prolific is this extraordinary man  on his 50th birthday he celebrated the publication of his 100th book and so illustrious that it is easy to set his efforts aside with the feeling that everyone will find out about the book anyway, and besides he'll have another one out in a few minutes.

title: Miss Clarissa Reed Hammond Fiancee of Thomas H. Endicott
description: MANCHESTER, Mass., Jan. 27Mr. and Mrs. William C. Hammond Jr., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clarissa Reed Hammond to Thomas Hart Endicott, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Endicott 2d. Both families are of Manchester. The wedding is planned for summer at Hancock Point, Me.

title: State HousingUnit Aid Set at $5Billion
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Governor Rockefeller today announced that since its inception the State Housing Finance Agency had financed the construction of nearly $5billion worth of housing, education and health facilities.

title: Goldberg's Accessories To the Fact
description: The marine equipment exhibit of Goldberg's Marine Center is believed to be the largest ever shown here. According to Charles Goldberg, vice president, the 500squarefoot display on the third floor features a large portion of the store's 6,000 boating accessories.

title: I.R.Y.U.'s Big Step Into Reality: 2 Small Boats Make Olympics
description: Among the six classes chosen by the International Yacht Racing Union for the 1976 Olympic Games are the 470 and the Tornado, replacing the Star and the Dragon, which had been in the Games since 1932 and 1948, respectively.

title: The Congress
description: WASHINGTON  There was an almost audible sigh of relief on Capitol Hill last week when the declaration of a Vietnam accord wiped out the chief stimulus of the Congressional movement to recapture power from the White House. Yet, curiously enough, by halting combat in Indochina, President Nixon may have increased the prospects of an allout battle with Congress.

title: Crashes Spur AirLab Work
description: POMONA  Twelve miles west of Atlantic City, the Federal Aviation Administration operates a laboratory where, according to engineers assigned to it, business picks up every time there is a plane crash.

title: Awaiting Fate in British Columbia
description: VANCOUVER, B.C.With British Columbia's first socialist government in power only five months, snip, businessmen in the province say they feel like a man already convicted but still awaiting sentence.

title: A TROOPER IS SLAIN AFTER CHASING CAR
description: RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 27  A 27yearold state trooper was shot and killed here this evening after chasing a speeding motorist to his home.

title: Nuala D. Bole, R. J. Gibbons Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Lewis Bole of Maidstone, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nuala Deirdre Bole, to Raymond John Gibbons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Gibbons of WoodRidge, N.J.

title: Hudson Club Remakes Huge Ice Yacht
description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt loved the Hudson River and its 306milelong valley. He probably loved it as much in the softness of spring as he did through the green of summer and into the paintbrush hues of fall. As much or possibly more, F.D.R. loved the valley and its river in winter, when the Hudson lay beneath thick layers of black ice. President Roosevelt loved river ice, too, for he was an iceyachtsman.

title: The Summaries
description: 60Yard Dash1, Lester Pruden, Princeton, 6.4 seconds; 2, Steven Wilk, Princeton, 0:06.4; 3, Larry Mass, Rutgers, 0:06;5; 4, Ken Erfler, William Paterson, no time; 5, Larry Eason, Trenton State, no time.

title: Colombian Gadfly, Female Version
description: BOGOTA  Consuelo de Montejo, who recently lost control of El Periodico, the national newspaper she founded last March, plans to try again with five new papers.

title: USAC Builds Higher Fence To Hold Drivers to Its Races
description: One of the richest assets a racesanctioning club has is the prestige of its leading drivers, men whose names are big gate attractions. This is why clubs dislike letting their licensed drivers run in races sanctioned by rival prganizatlons. Why, the reasoning goes, should we help. the opposition? When a race has a full internatonal sanction on the calendar of the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile there is no problem about a driver's getting permission from his home club. to run that raceadmission is automatic. This explains why A. J. Foyt of the United States Auto Club can run in NASCAR's Daytona 500 and why Peter Revson of the Sports Car Club of America can run USAC's Indianapolis 500.

title: Politics

I don't think that charisma is of any importance. At the moment, I'd say anybody who's pretty shouldn't be eligible.

title: Ellen de Jonge Sets Bridal Date
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Jan. 27Miss Ellen Dedorah de Jonge plans to be married in August next year to Michael Stephen Bradfield, who on his 21st birthday earlier this month applied for admission as a partner in Lloyd's of London, one of the youngest to have taken this step in the history of the 200yearold firm.

title: Stored Ford Cars Found To Meet Pollution Rules
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency has told the Ford Motor Company that it may sell more than 9,000 Mavericks and Comets, in storage since last May, because final pollution tests on the automobile engines showed they met 1973 standards.

title: Woodcock Optimistic on Peaceful Settlement in Auto Industry Negotiations
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27  There Is a better chance for labor peace in the automobile industry this year than in any recent negotiating year, Leonand Woodcock, the president of the United Automobile Workers, said recently in an interview.

title: The Flying Bandeirantes
description: SAO JOSE DOS CAMPOS, BrazilA new generation of Bandeirantes, or pioneers, is being turned out here in this capital of Brazils young aviation industry. The Bandeirante, named after the 19thcentury explorers, is Brazil's first turboprop executive transport plane designed specifically to open up the country's vast hinterland.

title: STUDENTS LOBBY ON AIR DISCOUNTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27College students have begun an intensive lobbying campaign for Congressional approval of legislation authorizing domestic airlines to continue discount fares for young travelers.

title: YALE WILL EXTEND MARXIST'S CONTRACT
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 27The Yale philosophy department has recommended a oneyear contract renewal for Kenneth Mills, a controversial black assistant philosophy professor who was suspended from Yale last year for holding a second teaching job, and has advised him that his chances for any additional extension of contract are slim.

title: New & Novel
description: Any Number Can Play

title: Some Lessons From Phase 2
description: WASHINGTON  C. Jackson Grayson Jr. is that rarest of American birds, the tameduck price regulator.

title: Where Have You Been, Bolet?
description: To sit in a desperately cheerful New York hotel room with Jorge Bolet is to know the meaning of absolute contradiction. The Cubanborn pianist is simply too imposing and disquieting a figure to meld easily with screaming redandorange curtains, and wildly patterned bedspreads. He demands a far more austere settingpossibly a somber Buy uel set, with dark, musty wallhangings, shadowy chandeliers, ornate furnishings, sinister rugs.

title: Cobble Hill Is Examining The Concerns of Women
description: For the next four months, an Anglican church in Brooklyn will be the scene of weekly workshops on issues of concern to women. Organized and staffed by residents of Cobble Hill, the Women's Interests Symposium is aimed at taking an objective look at the issues facing women. The symposiums began this month with introductions to consciousness raising.

title: Space Is Needed For Space Show
description: NEWARK The planetarium at the Newark Museum has been enriched by a gift of fullsized Apollo space equipment and threedimensional lunar landscapes. The realistic gear, including a lunar lender and command module, was donated by the American Broadcasting Company, which used it to simulate moon landings on telecasts of the Apollo flights.

title: New Alger Novel, First Since 1910, Due Friday
description: New York City is the setting of a novel to be published Friday that, not surprisingly, contains examples of the blight of urban decay: kidnapping, extortion, slander, false arrest, several beatings, mugging, robbery and assault.

title: Patagonia: Not a Marx Brothers Gag but Real Ingmar Bergman
description: THEY say that Magellan, on his way around the earth, dawdled on a beach far down the South American coast and saw large footprints there, left, presumably, by natives. He forthwith christened the land Patagonia, from patagn, the Portuguese for big footed, and Patagonia it has remained to this day.

title: Jane Hansford Plans Nuptials
description: ROCLIESTER, Jan. 27Mr. and Mrs. Van Buren Nelson Hansford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Cory Hansford, to Andrew Robert Lear of Dallas and Warren, Vt., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Lear of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Wallace Put on Regular Diet
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 27 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama remained in satisfactory condition and was put on a regular diet today, a day after he underwent surgery to improve bladder drainage. It was the Governor's sixth operation since he was wounded by an assassin last May 15 in Laurel, Md.

title: J. RICHARD GEAMAN
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Jan. 27J. Richard Geaman, patent counsel for the Cities Service Company, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 1922 Winding Brook Way. His age was 47.

title: First Pick For Giants: 38th Player
description: It's quite possible that before 10 A.M. Tuesday, when the National Football League draft begins, the picture will look quite differently to the New York Giants, who are busy talking trades that could bring them additional draft choices.

title: Cruise A Fjord Tomorrow
description: Scandinavia is a boatman's paradise. It has an abundance of tideless sheltered waterways, breathtaking scenery includes includes picturesque archipelagoes and magnificent fjords and longer daylight hours to devote to the pleasures of boating.

title: All That Glitter Is Goldie's
description: LOS ANGELES. DUMB? Not a chance. But then we all suspected that she was fictitious, the Goldie Hawn of LaughIn, that elfin stammerer with pink tulle for brains who somehow resembled a Pekingese after cosmetic surgery. And the real Goldie is perfectly frank about it.

title: Montclair State Scores A Powerless Triumph
description: ST. MARY'S CITY, Md. Jan. 27 (AP)Montclair Stato defeated St. Mary's, 3633 tonight in a college basketball game suspended at halftime because of a broken scoreboard clock.

title: School of the Sailor: Landlubber to Old Salt
description: Steve Colgate is a 37yearold graduate of Yale University who has been to sea in many ships. He was the foredeck chief on American Eagle. in the 1967 America's Cup trials and the tactician on Heritage in 1970. He the was a crew member with the 1968 United States Olympic team on the 5.5Meter yachts and he has crewed five times on transAtlantic ocean racers. A seafaring portfolio worthy of Davey Jones.

title: Mendham Couple Explore the State's Revolutionary Past
description: MENDHAMFew are the hobbies that are not rewarding, and among those who would attest to this are Mr. and Mrs. Fred Bartenstein Jr. of Ledell Road, whose avocation is probing the crannies of the Revolutionary War period.

title: Lewis Walker 3d Is Dead; Chairman of Talon Zipper
description: MEADVILLE, Pa., Jan. 27Lewis Walker 3d, chairman of the Talon division of Textron, Inc., makers of zippers and other products, died last night in St. Vincent Hospital in Erie. He was 59 years old and lived here.

title: Roy Rubin: It Will Take Long Time to Heal
description: It took Roy Rubin 105 days to lose 45 pounds, 47 games and his job.

title: Haiti
description: MEXICO CITY  A few years ago, Haiti was the mysterious island nation where Tonton Maroutes, the dread police, roamed the streets intimidating and eliminating real and imagined enemies of the regime of Franois Duvalier, Presidentforlife.

title: Bikeways Spread on Coast as More Take to Cycling
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27The 444mile California Aqueduct will soon bring more than water down the broad valleys that cut a northsouth corridor through the center of the state.

title: A sordid existence devoted to beauty
description: With his sinister pseudonyms, his troubled history, his relatively unknown and pretentious writings, Frederick William Rolfe (Baron Corvo) became a legendary figure in English literature after his death in 1913. In an article in the early twenties, Sir Shane Leslie evoked the memory of this phantom of the nineties. Then, in 1934 came A. J. A. Symons's The Quest for Corvo. In reading this masterpiece of biographical detective work, the reader is fascinated more by the author's research than the subject itself. Donald Weeks's apparently definitive work on Rolfe focuses on the man himself and his lugubrious career.

title: Wrong Flag Embarrasses British Concorde in Angola
description: LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP)Officials of the British Aircraft Corporation are trying to find out who was to blame for their supersonic Concorde flying into a Portugese colony displaying the flag of an antiPortuguese guerrilla movement.

title: Chronology of the War in Vietnam and Its Historical Antecedents From 1940
description: Following is a chronology of the Vietnam war and its historical antecedents:

title: Gardens
description: WHEN the John C. Wilsey's expanded their home to include a family, room, Dr. Wilsey suggested, Why not add on a greenhouse.

title: Classmate to Wed Robin Lynn Wright
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Jan. 27Miss Robin Lynn Wright and Reeves Cecil Westbrook, second year law students at Yale University, plan to be married March 17.

title: NORDIQUES WIN, 31 SNAP 5GAME SLUMP
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP)The Quebec Nordiques jumped to a twogoal advantage in the first period and went on to post a 31 World Hockey Association victory over the New England Whalers tonight.

title: Reconciliation...
description: At the close of his extraordinary televised press conference explaining the terms of the. Vietnam settlement last week, Henry Kissinger concluded his statement with a fervent expression of hope and determination that could not have failed to move his listeners, regardless of their position during the long, divisive conflict that now finally appears to be ended. It was a sentiment that the President himself would have done well to voice.

title: Canoeists Circumnavigate City, Discover Nature Still Exists
description: Fun is not to be found . . . you bring it with you. This axiom was well illustrated recently by six adventurous men who embarked on a 120mile, fiveday canoe trip on the waters around New York.

title: Workaday World Comes to the Classrooms
description: NEW BRUNSWICKCareer education has begun to acquaint pupils in New Jersey with the workaday world waiting for them.

title: We Shall Overcome
description: Lyndon Baines Johnson, the 36th President of the United States, was in some ways a tragic figure. He had great gifts, aspired to do noble deeds, worked with heroic energy and intensity, accomplished much, and was finally brought low by a cataclysmic error of judgment. His extraordinary life was a drama of classical proportions.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Amanda Phillips Married
description: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 27 Dr. Elizabeth Amanda Phillips, a fellow in hematology at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, New York, was married here this afternoon to Jack Kaufmann, who is with the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood. The Rev. Gerald Snapp performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel of the Annie Wright School.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: ISRAEL HIGH SCHOOL OPENED BY ZIONISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Zionist Organization of America announced today the establishment of a technical high school in Israel as an initial step in a $10million program to help narrow the educational gap between Israeli youths of Western and AfroAsian backgrounds.

title: From Avon to Zodiac, Inflatables in a Boom
description: They're here, the inflatables, from Avon to Zodiac, more than a dozen international companies vying for position in what shapes up as an exciting trend in the world of boats and boating.

title: Sales Pitch for Youngsters
description: To the Financial Editor: James Neal Harvey (In Defense of Children's TV, Jan. 14) seems to feel that all is well in the world of children's TV and, besides, it isn't very important anyway.

title: Cognac Is Sequel To Ocean Legend
description: When the legendary Sam Griffith, regarded by many as the father of modern ocean racing, won the first MiamiNassau race in 1956, about the last thought that could have entered his mind was that a French cognac firm would name a world offshore powerboat championship trophy after him. And that racers would spend millions of dollars and wreck innumerable boats in pursuit of that trophy.

title: An Advance Group From Hanoi Stops At Laotian Airport
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sunday, Jan. 28Nineteen North Vietnamese officers and one civilian member of the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government arrived here from Hanoi today in transit to Saigon, and the leader of the group said he was optimistic that the peace that went itno effect this morning morning would be durable.

title: Long Beach, Army And Rutgers Score
description: Long Beach State and Rutgers figured to win and did in yesterday's college basketball triple  header at Madison Square Garden.

title: Parent and Child
description: Some months ago, having dinner with an ardently liberal professor in Janesville, Wis., I was asked why I continue to live in FearCitybytheSea. I had just told him of a recent dinner conversation at our apartment in Greenwich Village during which my wife and I had reviewed for our two young sons the streets they should avoid in order to lessen the odds against their being mugged.

title: Safety Winners Listed by Mercury
description: A Florida Coast Guard Auxiliary flotilla, a daily newspaper in Ohio and a state Conservation Department are winners of the 15th annual Gold Cup awards for boating safety.

title: Batouala
description: Batouala is the leader (or mokoundji) of a small tribe of Bandas who live and die under an oppressive French colonial rule about the time of the Great War; they are resigned to the new lifestyle that clashes so stridently with the one that had done so well for their ancestors. For them, the war simply means that there is a reduced market for rubber, so there is less work on the plantations or making roads for the Bandas to do. Beyond that: Germans, French. French, Germans: aren't they all still whites? So, why change? The French have enslaved us. Now we know their qualities and faults. That's already something, I assure you, even though I'm well aware that they amuse themselves with us as Paka the wildcat does with a mouse. That is all the attention that the War deserves.

title: Movies
description: THERE are a lot of little things wrong with Paul Newman's movie of The Effect of Gamma Rays on ManintheMoon Marigolds, some of them attributable to Alvin Sargent's screenplay and some deriving from Paul Zindel's original play. It is easy to pick at details  overstated or contrived moments, irrelevant transitional scenes, some crudelydrawn minor characters. Yet the film as a whole is powerful and affecting. Sargent and Newman have made some miscalculations, but they have succeeded in liberating the material from the confines of the stage, and they have intelligently refashioned the play, retaining its best qualitiesthe insights into character, the strong sense of familyand eliminating some of its melodramatic excesses.

title: Ford Calls Its Turbine A Better Marine Idea
description: A marine version of a gasturbine engine, already providing power for some of the industry's most prestigious boats, is being displayed by Ford Motor Company.

title: The Death and Life of Malcolm X
description: In a piece called White Standards and Negro Writing (The New Republic, March 9, 1968) Richard Gilman states that there is a growing body of Negro writing which is not to be thought of simply as writing by Negroes. It is not something susceptible of being democratized and assimilated in the same way that writing by Jews has been. And he ends his article with the following statement: The kind of Negro writing I have been talking about, the act of creation of the self in the face of that self's historic denial by our society, seems to me to be at this point beyond my right to intrude on.

title: Dance
description: AFRICAN BALLET THEATER'S season at the City Center 55th Street Theater, which ends tonight, has been more remarkable for its performances than for its new productions. The company itself seems to get stronger every season.

title: Shoemaker Has Operation After Santa Anita Mishap
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP)Bill Shoemaker underwent surgery today for a fractured right thumb suffered in a spill yesterday at Santa Anita and will be sidelined more than two months, doctors said.

title: When Port Was Wine
description: My life was very simple once, a long, long time ago When I walked on floors instead of decks and put thingsnow I stow. And ropes were ropes instead of lines and all the ships were boats. I'd never seen a floating home or nuns or gongs afloat, And heads were on the top of folks instead of underneath And hatch was what young chickens did and sailor's palms were leaves.

title: Portable Oxygen Can Go Aboard
description: Many people who had been restricted by respiratory and heart problems will be able to enjoy boating this season, thanks to a new safety devicea portable oxygen system.

title: Letters
description: The measure of a man

title: DEMBINSKI RIDES 2 SHOW WINNERS
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., Jan. 27  Tom Dembinski, a student at the Kent School in Kent, Conn., could do no wrong in the junior jumper division today at the opening session of The Hill horse show.

title: Notes
description: The worst part of a plane trip for many passengers occurs on the ground; getting to or from the airports of major cities often involves expensive cab rides or uncomfortable bus rides over congested roads. Now, in an effort to alleviate the problem, several major cities, some in the United States but most in Europe, have completed or are building rapid transit links between their airports and city centers.

title: The illusion of invulnerability
description: This is a useful small book. It is useful because it addresses itself to a most interesting question: Why is it that able men who have been called upon to make great national policy decisions in times of crisis have so often made what clearly seem in retrospect very bad decisions?

title: Oakland Estuary Is Opened
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI)The Oakland estuary of San Francisco Bay was opened to all shipping traffic last night, more than a week after thousands of gallons of oil seeped into the water from nearby storage tanks. Capt. H. J. Lynch of the Coast Guard said the job of mopping up the last traces of oil would continue for another week.

title: 6 Policemen Seized in Gambling Drive
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 27Six Baltimore police detectives and two former detectives, including one who retired as a highly decorated member of the force, have been arrested by the F.B.I. after being indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of receiving payment of up to $400 a month from three alleged gambling rings.

title: JACK LEVENTHAL
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 27Jack Leventhal, founder and partner of J. Leventhal & Brother, a wholesale and retail furrier, died yesterday of a head ailment at Hollywood Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: N.B.A. LineUp
description: AT BOSTON

title: POOR BEATS 3 FOES IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 27Tom Poor of Boston, won three matches today at 4 A.M., 1 P.M. and 8:20 P.M. in reaching the semifinal round of the 31st Atlantic Coast squash racquets tournament at ChalfonteHaddon Hall.

title: The President
description: WASHINGTONInauguration . . . peace in Indochina . . . the death of a former President. This unprecedented coming together of events and symbols in a mere six days underscored the belief that an era had passed and a new order was being ushered in  one that Richard Nixon seemed determined to mold according to his own philosophy and his reading of last year's election returns.

title: Ballads from America, legends from Iceland and Ireland
description: These two little books of verse have the smell of pine cones in a forest. They are pleasing to look at, too, with colorful pictures that move along in step with the words. Period pieces, they are rustic and romantic in mood, with an innocent, childlike tone.

title: Lovely Smile Triumphs
description: LINCOLN, R.I., Jan. 27 (AP) Lovely Smile won the $7,500 Blackstone Valley Handicap by half a length at Lincoln Downs today. The 5yearold mare covered the five furlongs in 1:01 2/5 and paid $6.

title: Dan Horn Goes to Browns As a Backup Quarterback
description: DENVER, Jan. 27 (AP)The Denver Broncos of the National Football League have traded Don Horn, a quarterback, to Cleveland Browns for future considerations in 1974, the Broncos announced today.

title: Freeze on Funds Shatters a Dream In East Harlem
description: Mrs. Alice Kornegay stood on East 127th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues and pointed toward the largely vacant block to the north.

title: Tolls to Cut Traffic Urged
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) Studies prepared for Pennsylvania and Philadelphia recommend new toll schedules on the Walt Whitman and Benjamin Franklin bridges that would favor car pools and penalize lowoccupancy cars at rush hours, it was reported this week.

title: Son for the Petkes
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Jan. 27A son was born Jan. 14 to Capt. Jon Petke, a Marine Corps helicopter pilot, and Mrs. Petke at the Mission Hospital. Mrs. Nike is the former Miss Mary Ballard Hobart. The child has been named Jonathan Hobart. Captain Petke is stationed at the Marine Corps Air Base at El Toro.

title: Swiss Set Speed Limit
description: BERNE, Jan. 27 (AP)A speed limit of 62 miles an hour has been imposed on nearly all nonurhan Swiss roads in a move to reduce traffic accidents.

title: Packable, Portable, Sailable
description: The Stowaway boasts that it is nonsinkable. It can also be stashed in two duffel bags.

title: Virgin Islands: Fun on Land or Sea
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas  The condominium craze has gone to sea.

title: Miss Hess Married To John Sylvester
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Jan. 27 Miss Elizabeth Rice Hess and John McFall Sylvester were married here this afternoon by the Rev. A. Theodore Eastman in the Episcopal Church of the Mediator.

title: Allegations Against Ash Focus on Accounting for Hughes and Origin of Litton Industries
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 Charges of scandalous business conduct when he was building his fortune as a young man hang as a cloud over the reputation of Roy L. Ash as he assumes the important duties of director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Nixon Administration.

title: WEST GERMAN SOCCER
description: FIRST DIVISION

title: MentalAid Proposal A Mixed Bag For Island
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.  A twosentence statement in Qovernor Rockefeller's budget message earlier this month points the way toward a new concept for community mental health treatment in New York State that Long Island officials have been seeking for nearly a half decade.

title: Nuptials Held For Kim Smith And John Niles
description: SHARON, Conn., Jan. 27Miss Maureen Kimberley Smith was married here this afternoon to John McCrea Niles. The Rev. Clement Greenan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. William F. Buckley.

title: Medical School Gets RareBook Trove
description: NEWARK  Many original editions of classic medical books, all published in Europe and America from the 15th to the 19th centuries, have been made available to the students and faculty at the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry on Bergen Street here.

title: Guttenberg on Hudson: Terra Made Cognita
description: GUTENBERGGermanior Good HillLis an independent little town of some 5,000 inhabitants, perched high above a river and, enjoying one of the most spectacular views in the world. It has all the tourist attractions: quaint, ramshackle houses in pastel colors set close together along narrow streets; Old. World craftsmen at work in tiny shops; churches with mosaic decorations and unusual stainedglass windows. Stained glass appears all over town; even the poorest little Guttenberg cottage will boast a stainedglass pane in a firststory window or an entire stainedglass fanlight over the door. As is so often the ease in the region of Guttenberg, the population is mixed: lots of Slovaks (there's a Catholic Slovak church and a Protestant one), lots of Germans and lots of Swiss. The Swiss emigrated years ago from the canton of St. Gallen, bringing their ancient skills and traditions and beginning the embroidery industry that is so important in Guttenberg today.

title: Japanese Boxer Is Dead
description: AGANA, Guam, Jan. 27 (AP)  Noburo Oyakawa, a 22yearold Japanese boxer, died today, about 18 hours after he collapsed during a bout here. An autopsy was ordered.

title: Numismatics
description: INTEREST in Chinese numismatics seems to be expanding at an even faster rate than the growth of general foreign coin collecting. One highly visible sign of this is the increasing number of Chinese coinage displays set up by amateurs at coin shows. And now, for China buffs and beginners who want go a step further, there is a special exhibit of Chinese coinage at the American Numismatic Society's museum in upper Manhattan (on Broadway, between 155th and 156th Streets). Called An American in China: the L. Irvine Moffett Collection, it might well be subtitled Chinese Coins YOU

title: Some Lessons From Phase 2
description: WASHINGTON  C. Jackson Grayson Jr. is that rarest of American birds, the tameduck price regulator.

title: Robert Derecktor + Wally Frank = Aluminum Salty Goose
description: Robert Derecktor of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Wally Frank of Darien, Conn., have pooled money, talent and previous boat names to build themselves a new boat. Her name is Salty Goose, out of Old Salt and Salty Tiger, Frank's two previous boats, and Grey Goose and Wild Goose, yachts designed, built and sailed by Derecktor.

title: Peace And the Campus
description: HANOVER, N.H.This has been a bad winter for skiing and the beautiful campus of Dartmouth College has been decked out in dirty sludge rather than the white drifts of snow usually associated with the Winter Carnival. So there was not even the call of the slopes to deflect students attention last week from the coming of a ceasefire in Vietnam.

title: U.S. Trade Talks Stir Ill Feeling
description: WASHINGTONTrade negotiations between the United States and Canada have been all but suspended for a year. Nevertheless, illfeeling, sometimes bordering on rancor, is still close to the surface.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: EDMONTON, AlbertaCanada has more foreign ownership than all of the European countries combined, and each year the level has been increasing. Ahnost across the industrial and naturalresource structures, American corporations, which account for about 80 per cent of foreign ownership in Canada, dominate.

title: Sally Williams Fiancee
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 27Mr. and Mrs. John R. Williams have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Bernhard Williams, to Stephen A. Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic W. Thompson of Saddle River.

title: Millburn: Storybook Town
description: MILLBURN  We are a storybook suburb, said Edward F. Lonergan, a hardware merchant on Millburn Avenue for 58 years. We have several major shopping areas, fantastic schools, gorgeous homes and very little welfare or unemployment.

title: German Expressionism: A Time for Reappraisal
description: EXPRESSIONISM  that is, German Expressionism and its Austrian counterpart is the one modern movement which, critically speaking, has never been given its due. Although Expressionism figures importantly in all art histories, it seems never to have excited the same fervid critical attention that has been awarded to most movements in the history of modern art from Cubism to American Abstract Expressionism.

title: Culpepper to Get Directors' Award
description: The National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers has named Donnell Culpepper of the Long Beach (Calif.) Independent PressTelegram as the recipient of its 1972 N.A.E.B.M. Directors' Award.

title: Motor Shop In Jersey Tunes Class
description: When winter has its icy grip on northern waters, boatmen here find time to do the chores that will keep their outboard motors functioning smoothly. Some who don't know how to find their way to Roselle Park, N. J., and the motorcraft repair shop where they learn from Heinz Ricken, an instructor in the Millburn adult school.

title: Soviet Union
description: MOSCOW  The Soviet Government entered a remarkable law on the books last week. It said, in effect, to Soviet citizens: Put your cash on the barrel and you can emigrate. Never before had Soviet legislation raised the possibility of leaving the country for good so succinctly.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: It seems only yesterday that marketeers and agencies were eagerly marching in unison to a new El Dorado called the youth market. You don't hear much about it now, because it rained on their parade.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ONE longstanding pressure point on the economic scene was finally removed last week with the signing of the ceasefire agreement in the Vietnam war, but others were becoming tighter and more irritating in the business and investment worlds.

title: PLEDGES TO THIEU BY U.S. REPORTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 28The United States has given official and private assurances to Saigon that it will intervene immediately if the Communists commit any blatant violations of the Vietnam ceasefire, a wellinformed South Vietnamese official said yesterday.

title: ARTISTRY ON CELLO DISPLAYED BY GREEN
description: Donald Green, a young cellist who made his New York recital debut Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a superior artist. A student of Aldo Parisot and currently enrolled at Yale, he boasts a deft technique (once past some intonational insecurity in the opening Bach Gamba Sonata No. 2), a comfortably rich tone that is never exploited for its own sake and a winning ability to project a composer's intentions with no sacrifice of recreative personality.

title: Sports Week
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: STUDENTS LOBBY ON AIR DISCOUNTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 College students have begun a?? intensive lobbying campaign for Congressional approval of legis lation authorizing domestic air lines to Continue discount fare?? for young travelers.

title: Romance: A Casualty Of the Sea
description: It is the dead of winter and young men's fancies are being turned on again by the boating industry.

title: Two Schools Plan for Change
description: ENGLEWOODEugene M. Dea, the acting headmaster at Collegiate School in New York, has been chosen to head the coordination program of the Englewood School for Boys and Dwight School for Girls, which share major educational facilities and programs on East Palisade Avenue here.

title: Jersey's Pollution Sheriff
description: SEWAREN, N. J.  Sheriff Joseph DeMarino of Middlesex County has hundreds of deputies in his fight against pollution. The sheriff, a resident of neighboring Port Reading, has been involved in the fight against pollution for more than a decade as both a private citizen and a governmental official.

title: Publishers Elect President
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP)Gerald T. Tache, publisher of The New Bedford StandardTimes, has been elected as the first president of the Massachusetts Newspaper Publishers Association. The new association replaces the Massachusetts Newspaper Information Service, which for 25 years served as a watchdog over press freedoms in the state.

title: SCHOOLS WILL GET AUXILIARY PATROL
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that 317 communityservice officers under the Model Cities program would soon complete training at the Police Academy and be assigned to reinforce security in city schools.

title: The hot flash of recognition
description: Feelings of depression, indecisiveness, irritability and such are common enough in the middle years that most men may recognize some part of themselves (a man I know calls it the hot flash of recognition) in any classic description of the male climacteric. There is the view that midlife depression is endemic in our society, and that it has to do with the need to be taken care of.

title: Jumping Boats: James Bond Film Goes to Any Length
description: James Bond has done it againeluded a band of treacherous rascals, this time by soaring through the air in an outboard boat to vault a highway in a spectacular leap of 110 feet.

title: Stamps
description: The Revolution was effected before the war commenced. The Revolution was in the minds and hearts of the people. This radical change in the principles, opinions, sentiments and affections of the people was the real American Revolution.

title: Indoor Midget Auto Racing At Convention Hall Today
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 27A special Sunday  afternoon program of indoor racing for threequarter midget race cars has been scheduled for tomorrow in Atlantic City Convention Hall. The first qualifying race will start at 2 o'clock.

title: Mayor, a Sail Buff, Opens Boat Show in Sea of Power
description: Mayor Lindsay (a sail buff) opened the 63d National Boat Show yesterday surrounded by power. In the lobby of the Coliseum were two oceanracing champions, a recordsetting speedboat and its driver, a Stinger engine and the Coast Guard Auxiliary and United States Power Squadrons.

title: A Classic Case: Obsession Overcomes Desire
description: To the best of my knowledge there has never been a general classic boat cluband now I know why.

title: For the Inca, a New Day Is Dawning
description: LIMA, PeruIf one subject is unmentionable publicly and certain to provoke lively arguments privately among the diverse people of Latin America it is racewhich is a problem in every land to some degree.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: BRITAIN UNCOVERS A PHONE SCANDAL
description: LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP)Government investigators have uncovered a nationwide racket by British telephone operators who for years have been making free calls all over the world. The Post Office, which runs British telephones, is said to be losing $4million a year in revenue.

title: Nautical Greeting Can Come in Any Shape as Columbus or Vikings Can Tell You
description: Nothing can accelerate your imagination faster than seeing a bobbing bottle with a note stuck in it. That thrilling moment happened to me one morning while fishing on Long Island Sound.

title: A New Hall On Hudson Would Ease Show Jam
description: If developments go according to schedule and prayers are answered, the National Boat Show will be moving into new, bigger quarters in 1976.

title: MFG Line Puts Sails In Business
description: Richard L. (Dick) Gibbs, general manager of Sail MFG, has so many trophies he stores them in baskets. This veteran of class racing in Interlakes Thistles and most recently in catamarans, designs sail craft and tests them from the viewpoint of a man who has been a sailing enthusiast since he can remember.

title: AROUND THE
description: The Northeast experiences a January thaw every year, but this year's is more prolonged than most. What this means to plants, is usually a little stirring, and maybe some early shrub bloom, but for the most part, the buds remain tight until normal sprouting time.

title: American M.P.'s Grumble About Communist Facilities
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (UPI)  Disgruntled American military policemen complained today that the United States was providing better facilities for the North Vietnamese coming to Saigon than are given to United States soldiers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Sanders Tells of Outboard Victory
description: The winner of last November's world outboard championship at Lake Havasu, Ariz., Johnnie Sanders is telling 'em how it was done at the Johnson Outboards stand at the show. With his wife, Melinda, also an outboard racer, he is relating the experiences of his record 174 laps in eight hours in his Scotticraft boat.

title: The Giant's Shadow Lengthens
description: SAO PAULO, BrazilDid Columbus go over the edge when he reached Latin America? Most North American opinion molders seemed to think so last year, apparently holding steadfast to the belief that the Western hemisphere ends somewhere south of Miami.

title: Mary Landon Plans Bridal
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 27Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George K. Landon Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Taylor Landon, to Robert Fergusson Barkley, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. H. Barkley of Hamilton, Tex. An August wedding is planned.

title: 63d National Boat Show Drops Anchor
description: Questions are for answering at the 63d National Boat Show, especially if they're nautical, but the one most people ask is the hardest: How do they get all those boats into the Coliseum? The best way to find out is to ask a modelship builder how he gets a threemasted schooner into a bottle. The concept is about the same.

title: Miss Judith Dubben Plans Spring Bridal
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. T., Jan. 27Mr. and Mrs. Robert Maxwell Dubben of Pleasantville and Sagaponack, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith York Dubben, to William Bradford Ryland Jr. of New York, son of Mr. Ryland of Richmond and the late Mrs. Ryland.

title: 4 Rob Hulan Jack at Knifepoint in Harlem
description: Hulan E. Jack, former Harlem Assemblyman and Borough President of Manhattan, was robbed of $76 at knifepoint last night at the front door f his residence on West 110th Street by four young men who escaped on foot.

title: TWOGOAL SURGE NEAR END DECIDES
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27The New York Rangers had their hands full today as they fended off lastperiod rally and beat the Detroit Red Wings, 63, in Olympia Stadium.

title: Defense Spells Out Jet Needs
description: Weeb Ewbank, coach of the New York Jets, believes that a secret is something only HE knows. So at this time of year, with the National Football Leagug draft coming up on Tuesday and Wednesday, he's naturally playing his cards close to his chest.

title: It's a Boat, a Sled, a Plane... It's Hovercraft!
description: Someday the era we are living in may become known as the Recreational Revolution. The advent of more leisure time coupled with a high standard of living has triggered many new innovations in recreation.

title: A Builder Looks Backand Moves Forward
description: There is a certain alchemy for success in residential building and developing. Some men don't have it, and what should be gold turns to dross. Others possess it and create housing empires with seeming ease. One of these is a man whose name is probably unfamiliar to most New Yorkers, although he is marking his 50th year in the industry.

title: Electric Boat Is Nonpolluting
description: PORT SALERNO, Fla.On the treeshaded bank of a quiet bay called Manatee Pocket in this little fishing village 35 miles north of Palm Beach, an effort is being made to restore some peace and cleanliness to the country's waterways.

title: Waldheim Trip Stirs Hope In Pakistan for P.O.W.'s
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 27 (Reuters)The visit of Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations to the subcontinent next month has raised hopes here of a nreakthrough in the unresolved human consequences of the 1971 IndianPakistani war.

title: SHOP TALK
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.The merchandising philosophy at Whimseys, a general store that specializes in handmade clothes and toys, is deceptively simple.

title: Arkansas for the Bee
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 27 (AP)The Arkansas House has approved, 89 to 0, and sent to the Senate today a bill to designate the honey bee as the state insect. When the bill was brought up by Representative Albert Tom Collier of Newport, his colleagues responded by emitting buzzing sounds.

title: Home Improvement
description: EVERY overhead garage door  regardless of whether it is a sectional rollup type or a onepiece canopy type has three things in common: (1) There Is a large spring, or pair of springs, that help to balance the door. (2) These springs are installed in such a way that they are wound up or stretched as the door is closed (lowered) and the tension thus built up serves to counterbalance the weight of the door and help to lift it when it is opened. (3) The door has metal rollers or small wheels projecting out from the sides and these rollers ride in tracks at each side of the door.

title: 7 Parties In One Day Are Routine For Caterer
description: MAPLEWOOD  The office in Cleo Johns's catering establishment has a scrapbook prominently displayed on her desk. There are letters from Senators thanking her for the gracious formal dinner she prepared and served, as well as praises from steady customers, such as Allied Chemical and Alexander's, the department store.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read with considerable interest the article Buildings Nourish a Love Affair with the City [Dec. 31], by William Gale. I, too, have had a lateblooming love affair with the city, and my researches indicate that there were a few minor inaccuracies in Mr. Gale's article.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: MONTREALThe Canadian Government's legislative program for the new session of Parliament, announced on Jan. 4, promises further steps in developing a policy toward foreign investment. This sounds the bell for another round in the debate on what is an appropriate Canadian foreigninvestment policy.

title: George Elbogen, Leader In Silk Industry 50 Years
description: George Elbogen, a leader in the silk industry for more than 50 years, died Friday at his home, 150 East 69th Street. His age was 84.

title: Freeze on Federal Housing Subsidies Affects 52 Projects in City
description: The freeze on new Federal subsidy commitments for lowincome and middleincome housing has halted or changed plane for 52 projects throughout the city, according to city and state officials.

title: BERGHORN TAKES SKIJUMP HONORS
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 27Enterprise and energy by Palisades, Interstate Park's maintenance crews enabled the host Ramapo Mountain Ski Club today to present winter as usual on the 50meter jumping hill.

title: New and Recommended
description: C. P. CAVAFY: Selected Poems, translated by Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard. (Princeton, $7.50.) At last an English translation worthy of the wry, melodious verses of the Hellenistic bard of Alexandria, one of the great modern love poets.

title: Alan Berlin Marries Diane Lester
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Jan. 27In Temple BethEl here this evening Miss Diane Ruth Lester, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis J. Lester, became the bride of Alan Stuart Berlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Berlin of Wyncote, Pa. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: News of the Rialto
description: THE late Erich Maria Remarque, whose landmark novel, All Quiet on the Western Front, told the story of the First World War from the German side, wrote, it turns out, one play in his life and that was about the Germany that went up in flames in 1945.

title: Maryland County Scheduled to Put CourtOrdered School Integration Into Effect Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Maryland's Prince Georges County school system, the nation's 10th largest, is scheduled to implement a courtordered desegregation plan Monday after the Supreme Court yesterday denied the County Board of Education's petition to stay the order.

title: Soviet Hails Vietcong Leaders and Sees Ultimate Triumph of Their Cause
description: MOSCOW, Jan 27  The Soviet Union's leaders pledged continued support to Vietcong leaders today and expressed confidence that their cause would ultimately triumph in South Vietnam.

title: Housing
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y.Lowincome housing in northern Westchester County had looked dead. A controversial state plan to build a total of 900 units of low and moderateincome housing in nine Westchester towns100 units, or apartments, in eachhad been temporarily suspended by Governor Rockefeller just as last fall's legislative election campaigns were heating up. And as the moratorium deadline of Jan. 15 approached, there was speculation that the plan, which had kept much of the plush suburban county in an uproar all last would be allowed expire quietly and gracefully.

title: Cannery Row Building Burns
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP)One of the aging buildings along Cannery Row, made famous by the John Steinbeck novel of that title, has heen destroyed by fire. A Fire Department spokesman said that the building, more than 35 years old, was formerly the CalPack cannery.

title: Alan Payne Succeeds the Late Bill Tripp...
description: Wonder what became of Alan Payne, who came so close to winning the America's Cup as the Australian designer of GRETEL I and II? He has become Columbia Yachts newest designer, succeeding the late Bill Tripp, whose highfreeboard, shortoverhang designs have become practically synonymous with racing and cruising Columbias.

title: Cost to a People
description: It began as that dirty little war and it expired with those clean massive strikes of eightengined fury. It was an undeclared war for illdefined objectives against a foe who never quite fit the concept of enemy and became known instead as the other side of a four sided Paris peace table. It was the war of euphemisms: of incursion, escalation, pacification and protective reaction, for which Americans crossed the seas shouting leave your neighbors alone until they perceived honor in a vague and ambiguous sheaf of agreements that allowed them simply to leave.

title: If every criminal knew he would be punished if caught...
description: The proposals by Gov. Nelson Rockefeller for high mandatory minimum sentences for drug dealers, The recent study released by U. S. Attorney Whitney North Seymour on disparities in sentences among judges and continued rumors of judicial corruption in various places are symptomatic of rising popular concern over the relationship between public safety and judicial behavior. The criminalcourt judges are well on their way to becoming the objects of the same intense scrutiny once reserved for the police, but with one important difference. The police always had many vocal supporters; the judges are likely to have none.

title: M. C. Magnes to Wed Elizabeth Giuliano
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 27Miss Elizabeth Ann Giuliano and Michael Charles Magnes plan to be married in June.

title: South Street Seaport: The Best of Yesterday for Today
description: A million people visited the South Street Seaport Museum last year, and a million people came away better human beings.

title: Model Rail Show Aids Y
description: MADISONAn elaborate modelrailroad show, one that has attracted 10,000 visitors since 1965, is being presented once again at Bill Hopping's home here.

title: SMITH IS BEATEN IN TENNIS FINAL
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP)Colin Dibley of Australia, capitalizing on a blazing serve, overcame Stan Smith, 63, 76, for the $10,000 top prize in the final of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: A matter of space
description: It used to be that floor plans clued you in to what a house would be like (despite the fact that the layman never was very adept at reading them). But today, architects are designing such complicated dwellings with multilevel spaces (the twostory house of tradition is likely to be composed of five or more levels today), alternating double and singleheight ceilings, angled walls, roof decks, recessed balconies, interior columns, ramps and bridges crisscrossing space that threedimensional model is a must if the client is ever to understand how the house will function before he actually walks through it.

title: Art
description: THE art of Fernand Leger is so familiar to us, so firmly established both In the museums and in the musee imaginaire of our critical and historical literature, that we very often forget how impatient the artist was with the easy acceptance his work had won for itself long before he died in 1955. More than most painters of his generation in the School of Paris, he was troubled by the fact that his art had become, both physically and spiritually, the possession of what he called a minority of privileged individuals. His political sympathies, which were more or less Communist, harbored a deep concern for what he was unembarrassed to call the people, yet he was acutely aware of the cultural barriers that separated the kind of art he practiced from the characteristic interests and pleasures of the working classes. He felt these barriers had somehow to be dissolved; that modern art hadin some senseto become more socialized and functional if it were ever going to be something more than a private pleasure of the wealthy and professional classes. And he understoodmost of the time, anyway that solutions to the problem lay as much in the realm of esthetics as in that.

title: Defensive Police Shots Kill a Girl, 16
description: A plainclothes patrolman shot and killed a 16yearold girl on a Brooklyn street early yesterday in what the police called quick defensive reaction to second girl with her who allegedly pointed a loaded sawedoff shotgun at him.

title: Alberta Oil Sands Risk and Hope
description: EDMONTON, Alberta With conventional oil reserves continuing to decline, some minerals experts in this wealthy province are showing new interest in the rich oil sands along the banks of the Athabasca River, 200 miles north of here.

title: HIDING OF U.S. SPY DENIED BY WILSON
description: LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP)Former Prime Minister Harold Wilson denied today a report that he hid an American spy in his residence outside London where he met with Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin in 1967 for secret talks on Vietnam.

title: The author of the following reviews is a critic and shortstory writer.
description: Novels about leaving detested, usedup wives and beloved kids have by now become so entrenchedand so predictable in plotamong American male writers that it's useless to deplore them as a genre, but hope it's still constructive to regret on occasion the manner in which this allAmerican experience is conveyed in fiction. My favorite continues to be Warren Miller's beautiful 1950's version, The Way We Live Now, but its followers seem to have progressively deteriorated as they've proliferated. Most novelists today don't seem to be able to bring them off without equipping their wifedeparting heroes with elaborate fantasies or superpicaresque adventures to mask the actual emotions of the passage, and it's in this latter respect that Joe Flaherty's novel has some heartening surprises.

title: Brazil Plans Major Road
description: BRASILIA, Jan. 27 (AP)Brazil plans a 2,000mile highway north of the Amazon River as the core of a network linking the country to French Guiana, Surinam, Guyana, Venezuela, Colombia and Peru, the Government has announced.

title: All Quiet Along the Potomac?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  It rained quietly and steadily in Washington the day the guns stopped in Vietnam. From the Lee Mansion and the Kennedy grave on the Virginia slope, across the Potomac to the Congressional building on Capitol Hill, everything was blurred and quiet.

title: Hrafkel's Saga
description: Walkers Saga and Maildun the Voyager are both derived from old translations rather than from original sources. Their secondhand antiquity fails to set the reader's heart on firebecause, in both cases, something important has been left out.

description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., Jan. 27The engagement of Miss Toby Ruth Goldstein to Todd Niles York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd N. York of East Farms, East Hills, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Julius Goldstein of Roslyn Heights. A wedding in the summer is planned.

description: HONG KONG, Jan. 27A new birth control drive is under way in China, where the population is believed to be increasing by more than 15 million each year.

description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 27Dr. Max N. Pusin, a psychiatrist, and Mrs. Pusin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Russett Sue Pusin, to Samuel Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Feldman of Millburn. Miss Pusin is a senior at Brandeis University and her fianc is a senior at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Peru's Day of Reckoning
description: LIMA, Peru  Nature is once again demanding payment from Peruvians for the incredible wealth exacted by them since time immemorial.

title: Irish Setters Make Gain, But Poodles Remain No.1
description: The continued popularity of the Irish setter, which, made a spectacular 30.4 per cent increase over 1971, and the rise of the Doberman pinscher into the top 10 highlighted the 1972 registration figures issued last week by the American Kennel Club. The Akita and Bichon Frise, which were accepted into the stud book Iast October, increased the total breeds to 118. Although poodle registrations dropped 37,592, they will dominated the list with 218,899. The poodle has been in first place since 1960, when it pushed the beagle from the top spot. The beagle had been No. 1 since 1953. The beagle, with 57,050, a decrease of 4,197 from 1971, is in third place.

title: Miss Shultz Engaged to Capt. Takesono
description: LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 27The Rev. Paul T. Shultz Jr., a retired Episcopal priest, and Mrs. Shultz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Shultz, to Capt. Jerald S. Takesono of the Air Force Dental Corps, who is stationed at Hickam Air Force Base in Honolulu.

description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday. that an autopsy had shown that the body found Friday in a grave near Colts Neck, N. J., was definitely that of Emanuel Gambino, a nephew of Carlo Gambino, the reputed Mafia leader.

description: Sam Donner, a New York and Florida builder, died Thursday aboard the Michelangelo, returning from a cruise to Rio de Janeiro. He was 60 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

description: RIO DE JANEIROThe increasing flow of Portuguesespeaking Japanese officials and businessmen to Brazil has given rise to a popular anecdote about a local banker who met a Japanese industrialist.

description: Back in 1970, Bowdoin College, a highly selective institution in Maine, attracted attention with a new policy: The college no longer would require applicants to submit their College Board test scores as part of the admissions procedure.

title: Photography
description: THERE are times when the inclusion of an artist's work within exhibits concerning one particular movement or another can have the unfortunate effect of distorting his or her overall statement. Such would certainly seem to be case with Doug Prince, whose representation in the Museum of Modern Art's Photography into Sculptureand in a subsequent group show at Light Gallery overemphasized one aspect of his work and effectively disguised the diversity of his concerns.

description: Pete Gaughn was upset by George McKay in the 1,000yard run in meet record time of 2 minutes 14.3 seconds; Bill Dabney finished third in the 600, and Jay Meisler erased the meet mark in the high jump with a 6foot8inch leap.

Finlay performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

description: ASHAROKEN, L. I. Residents of this tiny village are troubled by the impending sale and development, announted last week, of a waterfront estate that includes about 80 per cent of Asharoken.

description: SOUTH BRUNSWICK George Segal's exhibition of sculpture at the Sidney Janis Gallery in Manhattan is attracting attention from critics and art lovers, but not many of them know that all the work comes out of a former chicken coop in New Jersey.

title: Ice
description: Ice is the mark of winter, the hard, cold, gleaming element of the long night, the short day. But how define it?

title: Johnson, Virtually Penniless in 1937, Left a Fortune Valued at $20Million

title: Yale, Penn Sextets Battle To 2.2 Tie in Overtime
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 27Yale and Penn battled to a 2.2 overtime tonight in an Ivy League hockey game.

title: Shakespeare and DNA
description: BERKELEY, Calif.Five years ago Edwin Chargaff of Columbia University wrote one of the many reviews of The Double Helix, James Watson's autobiographical account of his and Francis Crick's discovery of the structure of DNA. In his review Chargaff, who had himself laid some of the groundwork for that discovery, observes that scientific autobiography is a most awkward literary genre. Must such works, he says, give the impression of having been written for the remainder tables of bookstores, reaching them almost before they are published? The reasons for this, according to him, are not far to seek: scientists lead monotonous and uneventful lives and often do not know how to write. Moreover, there may also be profounder reasons for the general triteness of scientific autobiographies. Timon of Athens could not have been written, Les Desmoiselles d'Avignon not have been painted, had Shakespeare and Picasso not existed. But of how many scientific achievements can this be claimed? One could almost say that, with very few exceptions, it is not the men that make science, it is science that makes the men. What A does today, B or C or D could surely with him tomorrow.

title: At Track, Liberation Goes Slow
description: When Jackie Cord shipped her one horse stable to Yonkers Raceway last Friday, sev eral heads turned as she moved toward the stall allotted her in lower Barn C.

title: Spain
description: For years a thorn in the side of the Franco regime in Spain has been the desire for independence on the part of the Basque community in the northwestern quarter of the country. To push their demands, the Basque separatists, whose ancient nation is now divided between Spain and France, formed an organization, quickly outlawed, known by its initials E.T.A.which in the Basque language stand for Basque Nation and Freedom. E.T.A. has carried out bombings and, more spectacularly, kidnapping of industrialists that the Socialistoriented group claims have been oppressing the people economically, culturally and politically. claims have been oppressing the people economically, culturally and politically.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 TheUnited States formally proposed today that the 12nation conference on guaranteeing the peace in Vietnam be convened on Feb. 26.

description: In a paid advertisement in this section last Sunday, Albert Shanker, President of the United Federation of Teachers, made a direct attack on the activities of Marilyn Gittell, director of the Institute for Community Studies at Queens College. This is Dr. Gittell's reply:

description: MARACAIBO, VenezuelaIt all began for Venezuela on Dec. 14, 1922, when a gang of oilfield roughnecks using primitive equipment were sinking a well in a malarial swamp near here.

title: Canada's Boom Reverberates
description: MONTREALFor Canadian business, 1972 was a rather good year, and most indications are that 1973 will be better. The two dark clouds on the economic horizon continue to be inflation and high unemployment, which presumably contributed to the Government's losses at the polls three months ago. But as the new year began, most people seemed to agree with a Winnipeg broker who said:

title: COOPERATION SEEN WITH PRESS PANEL
description: The privately financed press council being set up to monitor the national news media appears likely to receive the cooperation of at least half of the major news organizations.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Hans Morgenthau's review of The Diffusion of Power shows he dislikes it: that is his privilege. But he also undertook to deal with matters of substance: the strategic significance of Southeast Asia; the nature of revolution and counterrevolution; and the role of American public opinion in Hanoi's strategy. On none of these does he deal with the evidence and argument in my book.

title: Governor on Drugs
description: ALBANYExcuses are intolerable That has been Governor Rockefeller's reaction to criticism of his proposed legislation which would mete out life imprisonment for narcotics pushers and for users who commit violent crimeswith no chance of parole or for plea bargaining.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (ERIC) SLOANE: (THE) LITTLE RED SCHOOLHOUSDMost schoolboys carried ... penknives. These were originally used for making quill pens ... they were a necessary part of early American school equipment. Which seems to explain why the old desks were so carved up with knifed initials.

title: More Companies Offer Kits for Home Building
description: When we were growing up, my two brothers and I used to spend our summers in the little lobster port of Friendship, Maine, renowned in the eyes of those who follow the sea and the men who venture upon it as the home of the Friendship Sloop.

title: The Court Landmark Ruling on Abortion
description: The issue has been as sensitive and emotional as any in, the realm of justice, provoking mass picketing, vitriolic rhetoric  even a strong stand by the President himself.

title: In a Welsh Cottage, Yearning for the Joys Of Modern Materialism
description: IT is hardly surprising that barons and earls have usurped all the credit for the Middle Ages. Although the traveler admires many a stone fortress once occupied by royalty, he encounters medieval peasants only in the art museum, where they are depicted at cattle herding and village wedding feasts as happy, if ignoble, savages. Yet the humble folks outside the castle walls were obviously of sterner stuff than their masters. For the castles today are mostly ruins gingerly preserved by Do Not Touch signs, while the peasants, on the other hand, built homes that have endured.

title: HISTORIAN REPORTS '40 ROOSEVELT PLAN
description: LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP)President Franklin D. Roosevelt wanted to buy the French fleet after the fall of France, a move that might have precipitated earlier American entry into World War II, according to a British historian.

title: Linda S. Pergament Is Betrothed
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Jan. 27Mr. and Mrs. Murray Pergament have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Sue Pergament, to Richard Andrew Horowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Horowitz of East Hills, L. I.

title: Miss Hope Hamburger Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Miss Hope Hamburge? to Donald M. Sagman has been announced by Carlton J. Hamburger and Mrs. Phyllis Hamburger of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Sagman of Newport News, Va.

title: Maritimers Again Look to the Sea
description: HALIFAX, Nova ScotiaWe Maritimers who always looked to the sea for prosperity have come full circle, Premier Gerald Regan was telling a visitor, A hundred years ago the tall, homemade Nova Scotia merchantmen brought us good times. Now, they will return with the coming of new cargo ships and super tankers.

title: M'KELLEN TAKES U.S. SKATING TITLE
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 27After finishing third the last two years, Gordon McKelen Jr. of Lake Placid, N.Y., finally captured the National senior men's championship today at the United States figure skating championships at the Metropolitan Sports Center.

title: Cuba: How Sweet It Isn't
description: MIAMI  As sugar goes, so goes the country, says an old but still valid Cuban maxim.

title: THAILAND IS SEEKING A GUERRILLA TRUCE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 27 (Reuters)  Col. Narong Kittikachorn, son of the Thai Premier, Thanom Kittikachorn, has disclosed that he is seeking negotiations with Communist guerrillas in northern Thailand.

title: Brazil Creates an Industrial Boom That Bigger Nations Can't Ignore
description: SAO PAULO, BrazilThis Serious Green Giant elbowed eloser to the world's major industrial powers last year, smashing all economic records in the way. But breaking tecords is no novelty for Brazil.

title: 2 Key L.I. Legislators Expect NoFault Passage
description: ALBANY  Despite another strong lobbying assault expected from accident lawyers, the chances of a nofault insurance bill passing into law this year are considered excellent by the two Long Island lawmakers who are chairmen of the Legislature's insurance committees.

title: A combination of selfexpression and applied physics
description: Joseph Wechsberg's latest book is actually a declaration of love. His title is an assertion of faith.

title: Peking's Clean, 4YearOld Subway Has a 5Cent Fare but Few Ride It
description: PEKING, Jan. 27There can be few subways in the world that still boast a 5cent fare, and fewer still that adorn their station platforms with spittoons.

title: Industries Cut Back
description: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Jan. 27 (UPI)Twentyeight industries in a fourcounty area of eastern Ohio cut back operations today to curtail air pollution. They acted after a warning had been issued by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.

title: SchoolBus Safety Spurs Parent Unit
description: HILLSDALESpearheaded by Dr. Sheldon N. Feinberg, a 42yearold Hillsdale pediatrician, and Dr. Arthur L. Yeager, a 43yearold Westwood dentist, a group of parents have formed an organization dedicated to achieving increased safety for the more than 600,000 New Jersey children who travel daily on school buses.

title: Letters: Selling Vermont
description: To the Editor: The Dec. 24 article, Vermont Letter: Glad You're Not Here, by Kay Avery, reminded me of a piece of research a former faculty member of Vermont Technical College in Randolph Center, Vt., told me he had made. It appears he dug into the life habits of the Indians who used to inhabit Vermont and found that the majority of them regularly left their homes in the winter and took over the homes of Pennsylvania Indians and other Indians farther South, while the latter Indians made their winter homes in Florida. Although I don't really be lieve the story, I like the point it makes: The Indians had better sense than all the whites who affect to love Vermont, winter and all, as Kay Avery does.

title: 1Cylinder Diesel Ran 43,000 Hours
description: Johnson & Towers, Inc., of Camden, N. J., has something unusual at the show: A onecylinder Detroit diesel engine, model 171, built over 30 years ago, which has accumulated over 43,000 hours of operation. The original design is still used today in up to 16 cylinders.

title: Cynical Argentines Recall The Golden Age of Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES  Cynical Argentines often liken their countrymen to three mena worker, Government official and businessman  drifting down a river in a rowboat toward a waterfall.

title: MRS. VERNON THOMSON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) Mrs. Helen Davis Thomson, wife of Representative Vernon W, Thomson, former Governor of Wisconsin, died today in Arlington Hospital, following a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 64 years old.

title: College Presidents
description: Among those most shaken by the tremors that rocked higher education during the turbulence of the late 1960's was the college president, who traditionally had enjoyed job security while ruling with a free and often autocratic hand. As student unrest and financial instability spread, there were increfsing demands that the president be held accountable for his performance and for institutional failures. Moreover, it became apparent that instead of allowing a president to serve an indeterminate term, it might be better to have a periodic change and an infusion of fresh thinking at the top.

title: Scars of the Past...
description: Good evening. I have asked for this radio and television time tonight for the purpose of announcing that we have today concluded an agreement to end the war.... With these words of President Nixon last Tuesday, the images of a tragic decade began to recede into history: The proliferating tombstones at Arlington National Cemetery ... the tangled bodies of the Mylal massacre ... the horror of a young woman over the death of a fellow student at Kent State University ... the terror of a naked, napalmed Vietnam child ... the ravaged remains of Quangtri City ... and the face of a President whose ambitions, for nation and self, were frustrated by a war he sought to end by escalation. Last Monday, scant hours before Mr. Nixon's announcement, Lyndon Baines Johnson died in San Antonio.
