description: BOSTON, Jan. 27Smetana's The Bartered Bride is a famous and widely admired opera, but this country has paid little attention to it in recent decades and New York City not at all since it was staged by the New York City Opera in the nineteenforties. It was something of an event that the redoubtable Sarah Caldwell should turn her attention to it and present it with her Opera Company of Boston last night at what is variously known as the Orpheum or Aquarius Theater.

title: New showdown in the West:
description: SHERIDAN, Wyo. It's a little like a plastic surgeon coming up to Richard Button and saying, Say! With a little work I could really make a beautiful woman out of your wife.

title: Movie Course Enlists Experts
description: TRENTON  Motion pictureminded youngsters in nine school districts throughout the state are meeting with highly skilled professional filmmakers through a pilot project administered by the state's Department of Education.

title: Air Controllers May Act To Protest Hiring Freeze
description: Leaders of the nation's 19500 air traffic controllers who brought much of the country's air service to a halt with slowdowns in 1968, 1969, and 1970are threatening to stage another one.

title: The Dream and the Deal
description: The Federal art projects of the nineteenthirties, which subsidized activities in writing, the theater, and music as well as in the visual arts, have somehow passed into the folklore of American culture without ever quite winning a respectable place in the official cultural histories of the period. They are an endless source of fascinating anecdote among the people who knew them at first hand, either as participants or observers, but for the most part they have remained undigested, if not indeed unexamined, so far as our historical understanding of the New Deal era is concerned. A curious mixture of nostalgia, uncertainty, and even shame has relegated the projects to the realm of myth, which the political and cultural exigencies of a later period have, until recently at least, conspired to leave undisturbed. The suspicion persists that they may have signified something important, for the future as well a for the past, but little attempt has been made to discover what precisely that importance may be.

title: Drug Clinic Open Nights So Addicts Can Work
description: Alan Berkowitz goes to a high school in Queens during the day and spends his nights at the only fulltime evening drug program in the state.

title: In the Last Decade, Fewer Women's Clubs With Fewer Members
description: The younger women will join the junior club, but when the time comes to move into the adult one, they don't want to admit that they're that old; also, they've often had enough club activity to last a lifetime.

title: The Boom in Art for Corporate Use
description: A partner in a law firm that recently moved to a new Wall Street skyscraper explained the appearance of colorful geometric and neorealist lithographs on the office walls.

title: P.O.W. Kin in Tristate Area Rejoice
description: At 7:30 Saturday, evening a Casualty Assistance Calls Officer from the Department of Defense phoned the home of Mrs. Loyal Goodermote to tell her that the name of her son, Wayne K. Goodermote, a Navy lieutenant, was included in the list of prisoners of war issued by North Vietnam.

title: Campaign for Neediest Passes $1Million Mark
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund topped $1million yesterday, with contributions from more than 12,000 donors adding up to $1,004,424.37.

title: U.S. SKATING TEAM LED BY MILITANOS
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 28Figure skaters from the East will Make up more than half of the United States team that will be sent to Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, to compete in the world championships, Feb. 27 through March 4.

title: Attache Is Robbed
description: Horst Riedl, 40 years old, an East German attache to the United Nations, was robbed yesterday in the men's room of the basement of the Howard Johnson's Restaurant at 1551 Broadway. Mr. Riedl told the police a boy about 16 years old, and a young man of about 22, holding a pistol, forced him into an alcove, pulled his wallet from his pants pocket and fled. Between $15 and $50 was in the black billfold, the police said.

title: Voters Urged to Prepare For SchoolBoard Polls
description: The New Jersey School Boards Association is starting a campaign to remind voters that they are about to choose 800 board members in the state's 518 districts with elected school boards. The theme of the statewide drive is Care about children? Care about your community?

title: Baseball Dinner Keeps a Tradition, Ousts Woman
description: A 23yearold woman reporter with Sports Illustrated was escorted out of the traditionally allmale annual dinner of the Baseball Writers Association of America last night.

title: Riot Follows Peaceful Parade in Ulster
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Jan. 28British troops used rubber bullets and water cannon tonight to control rioting teenagers after ceremonies marking the first anniversary of the killing of 13 Roman Catholics by British soldiers.

title: Orchard St. Tries Mall, but Sales Lag
description: The sidewalks of Orchard Street flaunted their bargains as usual yesterday: the outdoor stands of shoes and slips and sealing wax; the overhanging displays of colorful clothing, plasticlace tablecloths and redwhiteandblue tapestries of John F. and Robert F. Kennedy flanking such a picture of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Bea Benjamin Here From South Africa, Projects Soft Voice
description: Bea Benjamin, a singer from South Africa who has performed with Duke Ellington here and in Europe, made strong first impression at a concert Friday night at Studio Rivbea, 24 Bond Street.

title: Music From Marlboro
description: The Music from Marlboro series offered an elegant, introverted evening of chamber music Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The participants were Ruth Laredo, pianist; Jaime Laredo, violinist, and Jeffrey Solow, a young cellist from Los Angeles.

title: Fast State Action Due on NoFault Bill
description: The Republican leaders of the Legislature said yesterday they were planning to put the nofault autoinsurance issue to a relatively quick floor vote within a matter of weeks provided a consensus measure could be agreed upon this week, as expected.

title: A.C.L.U. to Help Ocean College Editor
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., Jan. 28A college newspaper editor who published a scatogical picture of Santa Claus and an experimental medical column containing sexual advice is back on the job while Ocean County Community College officials mull further action against him.

title: 8 CITY POLICEMEN TO BE TRIED BY U.S.
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28  Eight New York City policemen and 24 other defendants, described in a Federal indictment as gambling syndicate operators, will go on trial in Federal Court here tomorrow on charges of conspiracy and aiding and abetting interstate racketeering.

title: Pokorny Takes Net Title
description: BREMEN, West Germany, Jan. 28 (Reuters)Peter Pokorny of Austria beat Tadeusz Nowicky of Poland, 76, 61, 36, 46, 63, to win the West German rinternational indoor tennis championship today. Mrs. Ingrid Bentzer of Sweden won the women's title by beating West Germany's Heide Orth, 62, 16, 63.

title: Typecast Sold at Auction For Record $725,000
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 (UPI)  The champion mare Typecast brought the highest price paid at auction in thoroughbred history when she was sold for $725,000 today to representatives of a British bloodstock agency at the dispersal sale of stock belonging to the estate of Fletcher Jones.

title: Long Wait Over for 1,925 U. S. Families
description: Jo Anne Flora has been waiting for six years. Her husband, Sgt. 1st Cl. Carroll E. Flora Jr., was listed as missing after he fell, from a medical evacuation helicopter near the Demilitarized Zone and disappeared.

description: BRUSSELSWilly Schlieder, the Common Market's antitrust chief, wields a pretty big stick these days as he goes to bat for 250 million consumers in what he freely concedes is an Americaninfluenced campaign against the trusts.

In their workshops and Board of Education summer programs and associations with local groups, they have been letting young people from 8 to 19 or so do what they want on filmfree and with professional guidance.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Division of Environmental Quality lifted an airpollution watch yesterday after 33 hours. The weather watch, issued for 12 north Jersey counties because of a large mass of stagnant air, was canceled owing to a gradual improvement in ventilation expected today, along with strong winds, precipitation and lower pollution levels.

description: CAIRO, Jan. 28 (Reuters)Egypt's War Minister, Gen. Ahmed Ismail, has been appointed commander in chief of the Jordanian, Syrian and Egyptian fronts, it was announced tonight.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Records: A Fan of Goetz
description: George Bernard Shaw didn't stick with music criticism, but he did practice that dubious craft long enough to leave some five volumes of collected musical writings. Shaw's critical efforts were distinguished by perhaps the deftest pen in the history of the profession, of course, but his musical judgments are still worth reading, as well.

title: Communists Pose a Threat to Tanaka
description: TOKYO, Jan. 28  When Japan's Parliament gets down to work tomorrow, there will be more Communists in it than ever before  and the ruling conservatives are piripirion pins and needles.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Truce Team Eager but Behind Schedule
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 29Two Soviet airliners flew into Tan Son Nhut Air Base yesterday afternoon carrying Hungarian and Polish soldiers and political officers who will represent their countries on the international commission to supervise the ceasefire.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 19 editorial Deadline for DetroitI states that it would not be unreasonable for the Federal Government to grant a oneyear extension to the automobile manufacturers in their efforts to meet pollutant emission standards now required for 1975 and succeeding models. Such an extension would have serious repercussions on the economic and social fabric of New York City.

title: State Recovers $3Million For Mental Patients' Care
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that his office had recovered $3,501,375 last year for state costs of caring for mental patients in state hospitals in the metropolitan area.

title: He'll Be Coming Home But Both Parents Died
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 28 (UPI)The homecoming of Lieut. Comdr. Frederick R. Purrington of the Navy, a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for seven years, will be a hollow one. His father and mother have both died and he does not know it.

title: Hogan Is Perturbed Over Whether to Seek a 9th Term
description: Frank S. Hogan, who ha been Manhattan's District At torney for 31 years, faces a problem as he decides Whethet to seek a ninth term. If he does run, he will almost certainly face a challenge in the Democratic primary from William J. vanden Heuvel, chairman of the city's Board of Correction and a frequent Hogan antagonist on the question of crime and punishment. That's the problem for Mr. Hogan.

title: Nixon Aide Reported Being Forced Out
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's appointments secretary, who has been linked to political espionage activities of the Republican reelection committee, has reportedly decided to leave the White House staff.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 29, 1973

title: COMEDIAN CAPTURES OPEN JUMPER TITLE
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., Jan. 28  Comedian, an 8yearold chestnut gelding owned by the Southern Born Stables of Pawling, N. Y., won two of the three classes today and captured the open jumper championship at the closing session of the twoday The Hill horse show.

title: STEVE E. WITKOWSKI, OLYMPICS' TRAINER
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 28Steve E. Witkowski, head athletic trainer for United States teams at two Olympic Games, and at Wesleyan University for the last 41 years, died today of cancer. He was 65 years old and lived in Cromwell.

title: McGovern Backer to Head California Democrats
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 28The California Democratic party remained solidly in the hands of the liberal faction today with the election of Assemblyman John Burton, who was cochairman of the delegation backing Senator George McGovern for President at the Democratic National Convention, as chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee.

title: An Army Colonel From Michigan Is Last American to Die in War
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28Lieut. Col. William B. Nolde, 43, of Mount Pleasant, Mich., was identified by the Pentagon today as the last American to die in the Vietnam war.

title: Cochran Takes Hahnenkamm Ski
description: KITZBUHEL, Austria, Jan. 28 (AP)JeanNoel Augert of France, coming back from injury, won the special slalom today while Bob Cochran of Richmond, Vt., became the first American skier to win the prestigious Hahnenkamm Trophy.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A friend counted nine frogs in the guest bathroom, but thats just part of it. Julia Montgomery estimates there are about 100 others scattered about her Park Avenue apartment. No real frogs, of course. Porcelain frogs. Ivory ones. Frogs scattered on wallpaper.

title: Bulova Earnings Gain
description: The Bulova Watch Company yesterday reported third quarter earnings of $2,489,000, compared with $1,270,000 for the equivalent period a year ago. Third quarter sales, for the period ending Dec. 31, rose to $55,130,000 from $39,821,000.

title: SHARED REVENUE TO AID EDUCATION
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28 Most of the expected $145.8million in Federal revenuesharing funds that New Jersey will receive for the period from Jan. 1 1972, to July 1, 1974, will go to education.

title: C,C.N.Y. TURNS BACK HUNTER FIVE, 6863
description: Otis Loyd, a senior guard led City College to a 6863 basketball victory over Hunter yesterday at Hunter's gym. Loyd scored 20 points to pace the Beavers who now have a 69 wonlost record. He was voted the Thomas Hunter award as the game's most valuable player.

title: Prix d'Amerique to Dart Hanover
description: PARIS, Jan. 28Dart Hanover, an American standardbred owned by a Swedish industrialist, Ulf Moberg, and trained in Italy by William Casoli, won the 49th edition of the $160,000 Prix d'Amerique, Europe's premier trotting race, at odds of 36 to 1 at Vincennes today.

title: Paul B. Barringer Jr., 85, Lawyer, Was a L.I. Mayor
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Jan. 28Paul B. Barringer Jr., a former law partner of Jackson, Nash, Brophy, Barringer &, Brooks, died yesterday at the Hilaire Farm Nursing Home in Huntington. He was 85 years old and lived here.

title: Lessons of War: Vietnam Spurs a Sweeping Review of Tactics and Weapons
description: This is the last of three articles on the United States willed forces in the aftermath of the Vietnam war.

title: Tensions of Talking
description: Negotiations are a means to an end. Serious problems can arise when nations spend so much of their creative energies on getting talks started that they grow inarticulate about how the talks should end, about the desired outcome. This is a looming danger in the twelvenation Vietnam peace conference which the United States is moving to get under way Feb. 26. seems already to be the fate of the longawaited EastWest talks to reduce military forces deployed in Central Europe.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER LEAPS BY 52
description: All the elements that combine to make a streak in hockey  a lucky shot, a quick answer to an opponent's goal, a hot goalie and a confidence developed by a club that has been there beforeled last night to the Rangers' 52 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: 4 Halt a Christening Party, Taking Cash, Jewels, Furs
description: A christening party in Jamaica, Queens, was interrupted early yesterday by four gunmen who escaped with $2,900 in cash; $6,000 worth of jewelry and some furs, according to the police.

title: John Sellers Dips Into a Varied Bag For Cookery Songs
description: Blues and gospel singing were added this weekend to the usual piano fare at the Cookery, University Place and Eighth Street. Teddy Wilson plays piano there every night from Monday through Saturday, and Dick Hyman takes over the keyboard on Sunday evenings. But Saturday the music began at 3 in the afternoon with Brother John Sellers dipping into his varied song bag for folk songs, pop songs, memories of Bessie Smith, Pearl Bailey and Mahalia Jackson and, most frequently, for gospel songs.

title: REV. FABIAN FLYNN
description: UNION CITY, N. J., Jan. 28The Rev. Fabian Flynn, who directed Catholic Relief Service in Germany, Austria and Hungary after World War II, died today in St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken. He was 68 years old end lived in St. Michael's Monastery here.

title: Cahill Budget Would Keep Taxes at Present Levels
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28  Governor Cahill will recommend to the New Jersey Legislature tomorrow an election year state budget of $2.4billion that avoids new or increased taxes, thus precluding any major new programs that would require much in additional state funds.

title: Priest to Head Harlem Group
description: A white Roman Catholic priest was installed yesterday as the president of a mostly black and predominantly Protestant organization of religious leaders in Harlem. Msgr. Owen J. Scanlon, pastor of St, Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, is the first white as well as the first Catholic to head the Ministerial Interfaith Association of Harlem. He has worked in the Harlem community for 40 years.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Every New York City bus and subway car will be airconditionedeven the IRT cars whose design has resisted that amenity so farby the end of 1980, Mayor Lindsay and Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said.

title: Nixon Urges Public To Seek Budget Lid
description: MIAMI, Jan. 28President Nixon disclosed today plans for cuts in longstanding programs of aid to hospitals, schools and urban areas in appealing to the nation to put pressure on Congress to hold down Federal spending.

title: CITY'S JAILS FOUND IN PERIOD OF HOPE
description: The city's prisons and other correctional institutions are entering a period of hope in terms, of fundamental change and improvements, according to the final report for 1972 of the Board of Correction, released yesterday.

title: Clark, a Little America, Awaits First Prisoners
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Jan. 28The bumper stickers here read, P.O.W.'s never have a nice day. Plaques on the screen porches of officers' bungalows silently remind, P.O.W.M.I.A.

title: 100 PLANE STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 About 100 American planes, including B52 bombers, attacked suspected Communist positions and supply lines in Laos after the Vietnam ceasefire went into effect, Administration officials said today.

title: Hospital Center Dedicated
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Jan. 28 (UPI)Brookline Hospital dedicated today a $500,000 intensive care and cardiac care unit and an expanded surgical complex.

title: 3 Killed and 8 Hurt By Mine in Zambia On Rhodesia Border
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 28Three persons were killed and eight were injured Friday in landmine explosion at Kasungula, at the western end of Zambia's 400mile border with Rhodesia, it was reported here today.

title: Vallee Files for Office
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (UPI) Rudy Vallee, the entertainer, filed a petition with 535 signatures yesterday to run for seat on the City Council in the April 3 election, but officials said it was unlikely that he would have the necessary 500 valid signatures after the names were checked.

title: Fanny Proves Role Of Women in Rock Is Not in the Kitchen
description: The test for Fanny is, perhaps, to shut your eyes. Fanny is a female rock n roll group in a rock world that is maleoriented, not to say chauvinist, and prefers its women performers to stick to singing or at least the piano. A guitarbassdrumspiano (and organ) group such as Fanny, which began a stint at Max's Kansas City on Friday, is very much the exception, despite a tradition going back to the allgirl orchestras of the nineteenforties.

title: Rare Earth Metals Formed
description: The Aluminum Company of America and the Molybdenum Corporation of America said yesterday they had completed called of a new company leaned Rare Earth Metals Company of America. The new company will install a pilot electrolytic cell to produce misch metal, a mixture of rare earth metals, in Washington, Pa., and a full scale plant is expected to be in operation by 1974.

title: In Quang Tri Area, the War's Greatest Battleground, Truce Begins in Name Only
description: QUANG TRI, South Vietnam, Jan. 28The artillery stopped firing at this greatest of all South Vietnamese battlegrounds at 8:05 this morning, five minutes late.

title: 18 Hurt as 6 Tornadoes Sweep Into Central Florida
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 28 (UPI), Half a dozen tornadoes ripped)l through central Florida today, tearing the roof off an apartment house, damaging homes, throwing trees about like toothpicks and injuring at least 18 persons. No deaths were reported.

title: Chief Judge William McRae Jr. Of U. S. Court in Florida Is Dead
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 28 (UPI)  Chief Judge William A McRae Jr. of a United States District Court in Florida, who ordered Jacksonville's schools desegregated in 1970, collapsed last night, apparently of a heart attack, and died in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Bernard E. Hamilton, 75, ExJersey Banking Aide
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 28Bernard E. Hamilton, who was from 1943 until his retirement in 1965 New Jersey's deputy commissioner of banking and insurance, died today at the Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge. He was 75 years old and lived at 68 Dryden Road here.

title: BreastFeeding in Public a Growing Trend
description: Mrs. Ira Silverman is a 27yearold fulltime mother and parttime career woman. She has fed her son, now 14 months old, in a restaurant and at dinner party. On neither occasion, although her son was being breastfed, was she embarrassed.

title: RAIDERS ROOTED BY SHARK SIX, 92
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP) The Los Angeles Sharks got goals from seven different players in the first two periods today and went on to crush the New York Raiders 92, in a World Hockey Association game.

title: TITO OBTAINS A JOB FOR BANNED WRITER
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28President Tito has personally interceded in behalf of Mihailo Mihajlov, a Yugoslav dissident, to help him find employment in response to a plea made two months ago.

title: Janice Devine, 64, Author, Was a DevinAdair Editor
description: Janice Devine, an author and since 1965 an editor and publicity woman for the DevinAdair Company, book publishers, died Saturday in Polyclinic Hospital. She was 64 years old, the widow of Frank Devine of The Daily News editorial staff, and lived at 410 West 24th Street.

title: Prosecution Tested In Watergate Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Demands for the appointment of a special prosecutor in the Watergate case began a week after five men were caught in Democratic headquarters on June 17.

title: MRS. H. C. BARRY
description: SAG HARBOR, L. I., Jan. 28  Mrs. Beth Short Barry, widow of Mayor H. C. Barry, died after an auto accident Friday. She was 85 years old and lived on Jermain Avenue.

title: GRAND PRIX TAKEN BY E. FITTIPALDI
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 28 (AP) Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, the 1972 world champion, took the lead on the 85th lap and won the Argentine Grand Prix today by less than four seconds ahead of Francois Cevert of France.

title: Wallace Celebrates Wife's 34th Birthday
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 28 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, recovering from surgery, sat up today and celebrated, the 34th birthday of his wife, Cornelia.

title: INDIANS END SITIN AT COAST BUILDING
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Jan. 28Nearly 150 Indians and supporters took over the Washington State Game Department building for about five hours today but began leaving this evening after being assured that their grievances would be heard tomorrow.

title: Members of Congress Are People
description: WASHINGTONIn all of the current attention to the powers and effectiveness of Congress, one major factor that defines the behavior of the legislative branch of the United States is often overlooked: It is comprised of human beings. However much noise it makes about how it is going to change, and whatever apparent change takes place, the institutional arrangements and procedures of Congress have been and will be affected by some recognizable attributes of human nature. Old Adam is alive and well and answering (sometimes), quorum calls.

title: Other News About Indochina
description: TRUCE OBSERVERS  An advance party of North Vietnamese and Vietcong representatives arrived in Saigon but refused to leave the aircraft in protest against a requirement that they fill out South Vietnamese landing cards. Hungarian and Polish soldiers and political officers also arrived. [Page 13.]

title: NETS ARE ROUTED IN DENVER, 10677
description: DENVER, Jan. 28 (AP)The Denver Rockets outscored the New York Nets, 3714, in the third period and went on to a 10677 American Basketball Association victory today. It was the lowest score Denver had held an opponent to this season.

title: ExMarine, Freed in Rape Case, Held in Attempt to Kidnap Child
description: An unemployed former marine, whose 1968 conviction for rape while on duty in Okinawa was reversed in an unusual courtmartial procedure, was arrested last night on a Brooklyn street after he allegedly tried to kidnap, a 2yearold boy from his mother's arms.

title: FIGHTING DECLINES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 29  The South Vietnamese Government said today that the Communists committed hundreds of ceasefire violations during the first 22 hours of the formal truce but indicated that almost all of them were minor.

title: Entertaining in the Suburbs The Paper Plate Is Beginning to Take Hold
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.  Five years ago, an average suburban dinner party meant a white tablecloth, silver candlesticks, the good china, beef Wellington and a hostess who spent long hours in the kitchen and in concentraing on the table setting to make it all perfect.

title: Pressure Rises as Competition Increases
description: The industry is going through a shakeout, Mr. Bowen said, but the business overall is as good as ever.

title: Rapid Rate Rise Creating Bond Market Uncertainty
description: With shortterm interest rates shooting up faster than at any time in the last three and a half years, the securities markets have become skittish. Most observers think interest rates will move still higher. A. G. Becker & Co., for example, described the short term money market is unquestionably in a state of disarray.

title: Houses Burn as Hot Ash Rains on Icelandic Isle
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland Jan. 28 (AP)Fires raged through the night and early morning today in the ghost town on Heimaey in the Vestmannaeyjar Islands off Iceland as hot lava ashes and stones carried by wind from the erupting Helgafell volcano rained on the town.

title: Cochran Takes Hahnenkamm Ski
description: KITZBUHEL, Austria, Jan. 28 (AP)JeanNoel Augert of France, coming back from injury, won the special slalom today while Bob Cochran of Richmond, Vt., became the first American skier to win the prestigious Hahnenkamm Trophy.

title: Screen: Feminine View
description: Relations between the fine arts and the movies have always seemed uncomfortable at best. And when practitioners, or mere students of the fine arts take up the movies, the results may be good or they may be a form of highminded or opportunistic intellectual slumming.

title: Communist Delegates Balk at Saigon Procedure and Stay on Plane for Day
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 29After a war of nerves that lasted almost 24 hours, the South Vietnamese Government this afternoon agreed to allow a group of vietcong military representatives to leave a plane at Tan Son Nhut airport without filling out immigration forms.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Czech Writers Still Defy Authorities
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 17  The Czechoslovak writers who were the first to recognize and promote the liberal aspects of the 1968 Prague spring appear five years later to be the last to accept its demise.

title: Rieti, at 75, Honored by Musica Aeterna With Premiere of His Triple Concerto
description: The celebration of Vittorio Rieti's 75th birthday, which has been going on in recent concerts around town, continued Saturday alight when the Musica Aeterna Orchestra offered the premiere of Rieti's Triple Concerto for Violin, Viola and Piano and also played his Serenata for Violin and Orchestra.

title: Jersey Bridal For Mrs. Ross
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., Jan. 28Mrs. Beatrice Chaikind Ross, widow of Dr. Daniel Ross, was married this afternoon at her home to Dr. Henry Ralph Winkler, senior vice president for academic affairs at Rutgers University. Rabbi Harvey Fields of Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple in New Brunswick performed the ceremony.

title: NEWS INDEX
Metropolitan Briefs
description: One man was killed and as many as three others were missing from a wrecked 38foot charter fishing boat blown ashore about one mile from Brick Township in Ocean County, N.J. State police here identified the known victim as Jules F. Sengebush, 60 years old, of Bridle, N.J. His body was discovered on a deserted beach by a Coast Guard helicopter.

title: Personal Finance
description: Mrs. Ida Marshall of Monroe, N.Y., will be able to collect her Social Security retirement benefits in a few years but seems upset about all the money it has cost her.

title: DON QUIXOTE CODA GETS A RARE ENCORE
description: Encores in classical ballet performances are an established practice among Soviet companies, but they are rare or nonexistent in other major ballet companies we have seen here. Nonetheless, Eleanor D'Antuono and Ted Kivitt, dancing their first Don Quixote pas de deux of the American Ballet Theater season Saturday night at City Center, felt compelled to repeat the coda of the pas de deux for reasons best known to themselves.

title: Cahill Budget Would Keep Taxes at Present Levels
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28  Governor Cahill will recommend to the New Jersey Legislature tomorrow an election year state budget of $2.4billion that avoids new or increased taxes, thus precluding any major new programs that would require much in additional state funds.

title: Brooklyn Siege, for Murphy, Was an Ordeal of Decisions
description: One of the nine hostages who were held by four gunmen for 47 hours in a sportinggoods store in Brooklyn had a hidden gun and, when the gunmen left the room briefly, he whispered to the police over a special telephone line that the hostages were planning to escape.

title: Other News About Indochina
description: COMMUNIST TEAMSAn advance party of North Vietnamese and Vietcong representatives arrived in Saigon but refused to leave the aircraft until South Vietnamese dropped a requirement that they fill out landing cards. Two American planes flew to Hanoi to pick up about 150 military men who will help supervise the truce. [Page 13.]

title: Tokle Places First In Skiing Jumpoff
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 28Art Tokle Jr., the fairhaired son of the former national ski jumping champion, finally earned a victory today by taking jumpoff honors in the annual Bear Mountain Sports Association's tournament.

title: ...and in Food Sales
description: With food prices skyrocketing, shoppers are more concerned than ever to get nutrition value for their money. The new labeling regulations announced the other day by the Food and Drug Administration are a partial remedy for what is now an astonishing lack of information at the retail level.

title: EXTRA DUTY TOURS FOR POLICE SET UP AFTER 2D AMBUSH
description: Extra tours of duty for all policemen were authorized last night by Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, who said six alleged members of the Black Liberation Army were being sought in the wounding of four policemen hi two ambushes here in less than 72 hours.

title: 100PLANE STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 About 100 American planes, including B52 bombers, attacked suspected Communist positions and supply lines in Laos after the Vietnam ceasefire went into effect, Administration officials said today.

title: MUSLIMSECT WAR IS DENIED BY LEADER
description: Minister Louis Farrakhan, a national spokesman for the Nation of Islam, denied yesterday that the group was at war with other Muslim sects or involved in such incidents as the killing in Washington last week of seven members of the Hanafi sect.

title: New Xerox MiniComputer
description: The Xerox Corporation unveiled yesterday a new minicomputer designed for scientific and commercial applications. The Xerox 530 will lease for $760 a month and sell for $21,700, the company said.

title: Owner Dies in the Wreck of a Charter Fishing Boat
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP, Jan. 28  One man was dead and up to three others were reported missing today after a wrecked charter boat was blown ashore about a mile from this Ocean County municipality.

title: Events Today
description: Concerts

title: Strikes by Teachers Reflect a Deep Crisis in Urban Schools
description: For a time last week, strike by teachers closed the publi?? schools in three of the nation' largest cities.

title: Hanoi Crowds Turn Out At Dawn to Hear News
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 28 (Agence FrancePresse)Hundreds of thousands of people thronged the streets of Hanoi shortly after dawn today to hear the Vietnam radio announce over its public address system that hostilities had officially come to an end.

title: Malcolm Says Governor Errs on LifeTerm Plan
description: City Correction Commissioner Benjamin Malcolm said last night that Governor Rockefeller's proposed program of life terms for pushers of hard drugs was unrealistic and might produce riots in the city's jails.

title: Couple Is Abducted In Car in Brooklyn; 3 Men Rape Woman
description: A young Brooklyn couple on their way home from a date were taken by three men on a twoandahalfhour ride early yesterday morning, during which time the girl was raped and forced to commit sodomy, according to the police.

title: Close U.S.Europe Tie Asked By German Finance Chief
description: BONN, Jan. 28 (AP)Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt cornplained today of a lack of close United StatesEuropean economic cooperation and asserted that world monetary reform would remain totally illusory anti the United States balance of payments deficit was corrected.

title: Fed Confident of Curbing Money Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The nation's central bank is confident that it can keep growth of the nation's money supply and other monetary aggregates within moderate limits this yearmore successfully than last yearand has every intention of doing so.

title: Advertising: Now for Vitamins
description: At long last, Casimir Furk is going to get his due. It's overdue.

title: GRAND PRIX TAKEN BY E. FITTIPALD
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 28 (AP) Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil the 1972 world champion, took the lead on the 85th lap and won the Argentine Grand Prix today by less than four seconds ahead of Francois Cever?? of France..

title: Governor Links More College Aid to a Shift of Control
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Governor Rockefeller and the State University are developing a plan to increase state financial aid for the 38 community colleges while shifting major control over most, if not all, of them from local government to the colleges' trustees and the state.

title: NETS ARE ROUTED IN DENVER, 10677
description: DENVER, Jan. 28 (AP)The Denver Rockets outscored the New York Nets, 3714, in the third period and went on to a 106.77 American Basketball Association victory today. It was the lowest score Denver had held an opponent to this season.

title: Negotiator Behind Truce Scenesn
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 28During the October news conference in which he proclaimed that peace is at hand, Henry A, Kissinger noted that none of the issues involved in the negotiations were simple.

title: Brooklyn Landlord Slain In Brownstone He Owned
description: Nathan Herman, a 75yearold landlord, was found slain yesterday in his apartment in a fourstory brownstone he owned in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Met Guaranteed Traded Painting
description: In the secret exchange of art with the Metropolitan Museum that is now under investigation, Frank Lloyd of Marlborough galleries got an ironclad guarantee.

title: A Series of Strikes by Blacks In South Africa Stirs Concern
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28A series of strikes by black workers has brought warnings that South Africa could be in for a period of serious industrial unrest.

title: Water Closes Brooklyn Street
description: A water main break forced the police to close off the intersection of Howard Avenue and Fulton Street in Brooklyn early yesterday morning. The break occurred at 5:15 A.M. and sent water gushing onto sidewalks and into some nearby basements, the police said. Sections of pavement buckled.

title: City Will AirCondition All Its Transit
description: Every city bus and subway car will be airconditioned by 1980even the IRT cars whose design has resisted that amenityMayne Lindsay and Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday.

title: Nicklaus Wins in 3Way Playoff
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 28Jack Nicklaus, given new life when Orville Moody missed a 2foot putt on the last regulation hole, won the Bing Crosby golf tournament today in a threeway, suddendeath playoff with Moody and Ray Floyd.

title: Tokle Places First In skiing Jumpoff
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 28Art Tokle Jr., the fairhaired son of the former national ski jumping champion, finally earned a victory today by taking jumpoff honors in the annual Bear Mountain Sports Association's tournament.

title: My SonPerhaps Yours
description: WESTPORT, Conn.Once I was prepared to go Governor Rockefeller one better than his proposal to imprison all drug sellers for life without chance of parole. Once I seriously considered taking my rifle and killing a drug peddler. I didn't know his name or what he looked like. All I knew was that he someonewas selling heroin to my son and killing a family in the process.

title: Red smith
description: Now that Warren Spahn has been stuffed and mounted for display in the baseball pantheon in Cooperstown, the world of belles lettres, poesy division, is entitled to know the authorship and original version of a rondeau that has been compared by some authorities with Gray's Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard and by others with Shakespeare's 24th Sonnet. It has been misquoted as often as the injunction against painting the lily and mistakenly attributed to a variety of bards from Laotsze to Edgar A. Guest. It was composed on Sept. 14, 1948, with the Boston Braves (later the Milwaukee Braves and still later the Atlanta Braves) on a winning streak that would clinch the National League pennant. Spahn was a 15game winner that year and Johnny Sain finished 2415.

title: Bethsheva Cohen, Student, Marries
description: Miss Bethsheva Cohen, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Eugene J. Cohen of New York, was married here last evening to Michael Goldenhersh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Goldenhersh of East St. Louis, Ill.

title: Portions of Message
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28Following are excerpts from Governor Cahill's budget message:

title: ROBERT M. YOUNGS
description: Robert M. Youngs, who retired in 1971 as executive committee chairman of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, oil and gas producers, died yesterday in All Souls Hospital in Morristown, N. J. He was 80 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N. J.

title: Navy Cargo Plane Crashes
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 28 (AP)A United States Navy Hercules plane crashed and burned on landing near the southPole today, according to reports reaching Auckland. The crew of nine and two passengers aboard were said to be unharmed. The plane, which had left here with cargo for the United States Antartic base, crashed on the ice runway there while making a groundcontrolled approach in reduced visibility, the reports said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 28 (UPI)Imperturbable Sam Snead scored a 15stroke victory today in the Professional Golfers' Association Seniors tournament.

title: PRAVDA SAYS SOVIET RUSHED HANOI ARMS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (Reuters) The Soviet Union rushed some of its weapons, including antiaircraft missiles and fighter planes to North Vietnam to counter the last major United States bombing campaign there, Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, said today.

title: In What Was Biafra, Business Is Booming Amid Harsh Poverty
description: ENUGU, NigeriaFrancis Ilo opens his wellstocked New Life Supermarket at about 6 A.M. six days a week, and business is very, very good.

title: 8 New York Police To Be Tried Today As Racket Plotters
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28  Eight New York City policemen and 24 other defendants, described in a Federal indictment as gambling syndicate operators will go on trial in Federal Court, here tomorrow on charges of conspiracy and aiding and abetting interstate racketeering.

title: Fighting Rages Along Route 1 After Truce
description: TRANG BANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 28At exactly 8 A.M. today the American Armed Forces Radio began reading President Nixon's proclamation of thanksgiving for the end of the war in Vietnam and the beginning of a new era of world peace.

title: Text of Nixon's Radio Address on His Plans for the Federal Budget
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 28Following is the text of President Nixon's radio address as taped for broadcast to the nation today:

title: Marvin Cross, 80, Dead; Textile Industry Leader
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 28Marvin R. Cross, a leading figure in the cotton textile industry for 50 years, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Nixon Aide Reported Being Forced Out
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's appointments secretary, who has been linked to political espionage activities of the Republican reelection committee, has reportedly decided to leave the White House staff.

title: Laotian Premier, in India, Voices Hope for Early Truce
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 28 (AP)Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of Laos, expressed hope here today that there would be an early ceasefire in the civil war in his country and said that he was counting on India to play an indispensable role in restoring peace there.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: A Friend Indeed
description: NORTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Jan. 28 (AP)Mrs. Mary Machado, a widow, went through her old lottery tickets at the suggestion of a friend the other day and discovered one worth $50,000 as a result of an Oct. 12 drawing: She said she had a habit of putting her tickets in a drawer and forgetting them.

title: DR. JACOB FRIEDMAN, NEUROPSYCHIATRIST
description: Dr. Jacob H. Friedman, a neuropsychiatrist who headed the geriatric service at Bronx State Hospital and was assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died Saturday of a heart attack in Montefiore Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 2925 Grand Concourse in the Bronx.

title: Chiefs Win Roller Derby
description: Trailing 65 to 49, the New York Chiefs rallied for 20 points and defeated the San Francisco Bay Bombers, 6965, yesterday in a Roller Derby encounter at Madison Square Garden.

title: HORSES & EQUIPMENT
description: Horses & Equipment 3995

title: Japan's Shipbuilding Gains
description: TOKYO, Jan. 28The Japanese shipbuilding industry, hard hit by upward revaluation of the yen a year ago, has begun to revive at a time when the Government is showing reluctance to permit export of new ships.

title: SCOFFLAW WARRANTS WILL BE ISSUED SOON
description: The Lindsay administration has decided to ask the city's Criminal Court to issue warrants for thousands of persons who have ignored summonses for violations of the city's administrative code and other noncriminal infractions.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
SplitLevel Controls
description: The difficulties created by the Administration's overfast transition to Phase 3 of wageprice controls are reflected in the reduction just ordered by the Cost of Living Council in last June's pay arbitration award for 33,000 workers in New York City voluntary hospitals.

title: WINGS END STREAK OF CROSS, 42
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 28 (UPI) Nick Libett scored one goal and set up another today as the Detroit Red Wings broke Montreal's 13game undefeated streak by defeating the Canadiens, 42.

title: Gallows Reappears in Morristown
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 28It looked like the set from Boris Karloff thriller: A gloomy fog over the Morris County Courthouse, a chilly rain and the famous LeBlanc Gallows, named for one of New Jersey's most celebrated murder cases.

title: Enshrinement Is Voted For Highpockets Kelly
description: Two oldtime players George Kelly, a first baseman, and Mickey Welch, pitcherand an umpire, Billy Evans, were named yesterday to baseball's Hall of Fame.

title: '54 and '73 Pacts Strongly Alike
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28The agreement that Secretary of State William P. Rogers signed yesterday in Paris bears a remarkable resemblance in its basic provisions to the Geneva accords of 1954.

title: Tensions in Dutch Church Flare at Clerical Meeting
description: NOORDWIJKERHOUT, The Netherlands, Jan. 28Differences within the Roman Catholic Church in the Netherlands and between its strong liberal wing and the Vatican came into the open here at a threeday meeting that ended inconclusively tonight.

title: Armenian Held in Coast Slaying of Turks
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 28 (UPI)  A land developer who said 26 members of his family had been killed in Turkey and the Soviet Union was held today in the shooting deaths of two Turkish consular officials.

title: Bridge: Although He Won Few Events Victor Shen Earned Respect
description: New York's quietest and most unassuming bridge experta title for which there is not much competitiondied 10 days ago. His name was Victor Shen, and his character and his bridge ability commanded respect from all who knew him. The fact that he won only one major title, the Goldman pairs in 1962, was due not to any lack of competence but to the consideration that he seldom played with partners of his stature.

title: EXTRA DUTY TOURS FOR POLICE SET UP AFTER 2D AMBUSH
description: Extra tours of duty for all policemen were authorized last night by Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, who said six alleged members of the Black Liberation Army were being sought in the wounding of four policemen in two ambushes here in less than 72 hours.

title: Mrs. Court Victor in Final Despite Suffering an Injury
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP) Mrs. Margaret Court pulled a calf muscle midway through the match but fought on to win the $25,000 British Motors women's pro tournament with a 75, 67, 75 triumph over Mrs. Nancy Gunter of San Angelo, Tex., yesterday.

title: EARNINGS RAISED BY NORTON SIMON
description: Two major companies yesterday reported higher earnings for their most recent fiscal quarter.

title: Books of The Times
description: A WALDEN TWO EXPERIMENT. By Kathleen Kinkade. Foreword by B. F. Skinner. 271 pages. Morrow. $7.95.

title: Ardsley Rink Retains Title In New York Curling Final
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 28The Ardsley Curling Club Rink, skipped by Edward A. Brandt, retained its New York State men's championship today, defeating St. Andrew's Curling Club, 104, in nine ends. Ardsley completed the bonspiel, at St. Andrew's Golf Club with a 30 wonlost record in the final roundrobin.

title: HORSES & EQUIPMENT
description: Horses & Equipment 3995

title: FIGHTING DECLINES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 29  The South Vietnamese Government said today that the Communists committed hundreds of ceasefire violations during the first 22 hours of the formal truce but indicated that almost all of them were minor.

title: The Political Struggle
description: PARISIn thinking about the ceasefire in Vietnam, Americans quite naturally wonder whether the enforcement apparatus will be swift and effective enough to stop Communist violations. But it is important to recognize that the other side has its own interest in enforcement of the Paris agreement.

title: Hartke Plans to File Suit On Criticism by a U.S. Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, plans to file series of suits holding various persons liable for conspiring to defame him after his refusal to be searched before boarding commercial planes, Mr. Hartke's office said today.

title: Miss Tchertkoff Wed To Harold Jay Glatzer
description: Miss Adrienne Bonnie Tchertkoff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Tchertkoff of Tenafly, N. J., was married here yesterday to Harold Jay Glatzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark L. Glatzer of New York. Rabbi Elliot Rosen performed the ceremony at Patricia Murphy's Candlelight Restaurant, One Fifth Avenue.

title: Nixon Urges Public To Seek Budget Lid
description: MIAMI, Jan. 28President Nixon disclosed today plans for cuts in longstanding programs of aid to hospitals, schools and urban areas in appealing to the nation to put pressure on Congress to hold down Federal spending.

title: Liberation Unit Rated as Murderous
description: They call themselves the Black Liberation Army and they move from city to city with great mobility, financing their activities with holdups and other criminal activity.

title: Frazier Excels in Last Period With 12 Points
Agnew Is Off for Saigon On 7Nation Asia Tour
description: ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE, Md., Jan. 28 (AP)Vice President Agnew departed today for Saigon on a sevennation Asian tour just 15 hours after the start of the Vietnam ceasefire.

title: SENATE TO WEIGH AUTO DEFECT BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Legislation to force automobile manufacturers to correct safety defects without charge has gained impetus from the refusal of major companies to bear the cost of two such recalls.

title: Black Is Ordained Catholic Bishop in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 28 A mildmannered black man born in a small Alabama town became today the Auxiliary Bishop of Mississippi's 90,000 Roman Catholics in a ceremony marked by Old World pageantry set to a soul beat.

title: Prixd' Amerique to Dart Hanover
description: PARIS, Jan. 28Dart Hanover, an American standardbred owned by a Swedish industrialist, Ulf Moberg, and trained in Italy by William Casoli, won the 49th edition of the $160,000 Prix d'Amerique, Europe's premier trotting race, at odds of 36 to 1 at Vincennes today.

title: Malign Neglect
description: A succession of leaks by the usual wellinformed sources is preparing Congress and the American people for the impending bad news about drastic cuts in education expenditures. The dire predictions seem part of a campaign to make the impact less painful when the ax falls.

title: STARS CONVENE FOR FIR AWARDS
description: Citations for movie achievement in 1972 were presented last night by the New York Film Critics at a reception for award winners and their guests at Sardi's Restaurant, 248 West 44th Street. The awards, ilk the form of silver plaques, represented the 38th annual poll by the 21 critics representing 15 newspapers, magazines and other media.

title: Baseball Is Saluted By Satire
description: With an assist from such New York luminaries as Joe DiMaggio and on Blomberg, the local baseball writers staged their 50th annual dinner and show last night before a sellout crowd of 1,200.

title: Amer. Hockey League
description: SATURDAY'S GAMES

title: Rock: Winter and Reed
description: The Edgar Winter and Lou Reed concerts Saturday night promised to epitomize presentday rock n roll realities. At least the album covers of Mr. Winter's and Mr. Reed's most recent records made such promises.

title: Van Doren Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for Mark Van Doren will be held at P.M. tomorrow in St. Paul's Chapel on Columbia University's Morningside Heights campus. The service will include readings of Dr. Van Doren's poetry by the poet John Hollander, a former Van Doren student who is a professor at Hunter College. Dr. Van Doren died Dec. 10 at the age of 78.

title: Thieu Letter Thanks U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28President Nguyen Van Thieu has written a letter to President Nixon expressing his heartfelt gratitude for the great sacrifices that the United States has made throughout so many years to help us defend our freedom ana our right of selfdetermination.

title: Japanese Launch Rocket
description: UCHINOURA, Japan, Jan. 28 (AP)  Japanese scientists launched a fourstage rocket from the Uchinoura space center in southern Japan today to test satellite orbiting techniques.

title: DATA HELD DELETED IN A MERGER STUDY
description: Certain details critical o conglomerate mergers wen withheld by the Federal Trad( Commission in its release of study of nine large corporation: actively engaged in acquisition: in the late 1960's, it was chargec yesterday by Stanley E. Boyle one of the authors of the study.

title: A Step Toward Cuba
description: The United States effort to perpetuate the isolation of Cuba in the Western Hemisphere is a conspicuous anachronism in 1973, one of those aloof standoffs that does no one any good. It has been an anachronism at least since President Nixon's historic trips to unblock the American stalemate with the People's Republic of China and to expand and improve relations with the Soviet Union. Even before those journeys, the Cuban quarantine was steadily eroding.

title: Manila Frees More People Detained By Martial Law
description: MANILA, Jan. 28 (UPI) The Philippine Government announced today the release of another group of persons detained under a martiallaw decree, including Mayor Florencio Bernabe of suburban Paranaque.

title: 76ERS BOW, 10196, TO BRAVES' RAM
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) The Buffalo Braves scored the last 8 points of the game and defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 10196, today.

title: Truth in the Marketplace
description: American capitalism has moved a considerable distance from the old let the buyer beware philosophy, but the consumer still often needs added help from the Government to meet the seller on even terms. Unfortunately, the consumer's foremost champion in the Nixon Administration has resigned prematurely. Miles W. Kirkpatrick, who led an American Bar Association study the feckless Federal Trade Commission and was then asked by Mr. Nixon to head up that body, has chosen leave the commission well in advance of the expiration of his term.

title: Brooklyn Siege, for Murphy, Was an Ordeal of Decisions
description: One of the nine hostages who were held by four gunmen for 47 hours in a sportinggoods store in Brooklyn had a hidden gun and, when the gunmen left the room briefly, he whispered to the police over a special telephone line that the hostages were planning to escape.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Dance: Special Ballerina
description: The American Ballet Theater offered a brandnew trio of principals in its production of Coppelia Saturday afternoon at the City Center 55th Street Theater. It was a bright and cheerful performance and certainly helped a rainy afternoon.

title: STATE IS BANKING ON ITS LOTTERIES
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28New Jersey's daily and weekly lotteries are being counted on to provide $69.5million for education and state institutions during the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Skydiver Is Killed in Jump
description: BIDDEFORD, Me., Jan. 28 (AP)Thomas Delaney, a 34yearold skydiver from Boston, was killed yesterday when his parachute failed to open during a jump. Officials said that Mr. Delaney and a second skydiver, Robert Champagne, 30, of Biddeford, had jumped from a plane at 3,600 feet over Biddeford Airport. After a 10second free fall, they pulled their parachute cords and Mr. Delaney's chute failed to open. Mr. Champagne landed safely.

title: Bolet's Fans Jump for Joy, With Reason
description: JORGE BOLET, pianist. At Hunter College.

title: NASTASE CAPTURES MIDLANDS NET FINAL
description: OMAHA, Jan. 28 (AP)Ilie Nastase won his third straight Midlands international tennis tournament today when Jimmy Connors had to retire with an ankle injury while trailing, 05, in the opening set.

title: MSGR. JOHN J. CALDWELL
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 28 Msgr. John J. Caldwell, pastor emeritus of the Romany Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, died yesterday while visiting in Ormond Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived at 8 Carman Road.

title: Irish Sad, but Indiana Is Happy
description: Notre Dame didn't make the college basketball news it wanted Saturday in South Bend, Ind., but another resident from that city, Tom Abernathy, did.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: ORDERS ADVANCE IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: Heavy buying in the fourth quarter helped push machine tool orders in 1972 to their second highest level for any year to date.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Democrats Held Likely To Restore Johnson
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28When Lyndon Johnson live and the war in Vietnam cotinued, national Democrat raced each other to escape the long shadow that their last President had cast on the party Already, however, many Democrats see his reputation being redeemed and his influence restored in deatheven to the point, some say, that by the time the next President is nominated, Mr. Johnson could be the supreme model for Democratic candidates.

title: Zaire Reports Peking Loan
description: KINSHASA, Zare, Jan. 28 (AP)President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zare told a mass meeting today that Peking had granted his country a $100million longterm loan at no interest.

title: TenA ger and Man Die As Ulster Violence Flares
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Tuesday, Jan. 30 (AP)  Two persons were killed and part of a major shipyard was set ablaze yesterday in shootings and bombings in Northern Ireland.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GEM SESSION There's an enormous diamond969.9 carats, according to preciousweight watcherson view for such as you and me in the American Museum of Natural History's Roosevelt Memorial Hall, 79th Street and Central Park West (8731300). Set in the center of the lobby (no admission charge here), the Star of Sierra Leone looks something like an oversize ice cube. It is the third largest diamond ever discovered and belongs to Harry Winston, the diamond man, who, after this last public showing of it uncut, will make a number of expensive fingerweight diamonds of it. It will be on display through Feb. 11. If you want a package gem deal, you can see in the museum's fourthfloor Hall of Minerals two famous sapphiresthe 500carat Star of India and the 120carat Midnight Star and the 100carat DeLong Star ruby. Diamonds, by the way, are also the geologist's best friend; they are the only things from the earth's depths to come up unchanged. Open 10 to 5 daily except Sundays, 1 to 5. Museum admission, pay what you will.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Housing Program In City Criticized

title: Spivak Recalls Famous Guests In 25 Years of Meet the Press
description: WASHINGTON  James A. Farley was the first to do it, and perhaps 1,500 more have followed in the last 25 years 10 Presidents, 15 Prime Ministers or Premiers, two Kings, one Shah and an Emperor; and Hubert H. Humphrey, who holds the record of having done it 22 times.

title: 11 in Argentine Bus Killed
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, Jan 29 (AP)A bus dropped into a 90foot ravine near this city, killing 11 persons and injuring 25, the police reported today.

title: A Good Feeling Surges Over Home in Brooklyn
description: It's been five Christmases, three family deaths, two marriages, two nieces and one nephew since Army Sgt. James Alexander Daly, taken prisoner in South Vietnam in January, 1968, has seen his family and their threestory home on block of neat brownstones in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: LiquoriSzordy kowski: Round 2 May Be Friday
description: The best mile of the indoor track and field season may be run Friday night in Toronto, and Marty Liguori issued a tough, early notice yesterday to at least one rival in the race to keep his arms and legs where they belong.

title: LINDSAY ORDERS POLICE TO SPEED RECRUIT TRAINING
description: Spurred by the ambush shootings of four policemen in less than a week, Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a drastic speedup in the training of police recruits.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Census Survey
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Administration is planning for the largest social science research project ever undertaken in the United Statesa Census Bureau survey of one million households in 1975.

title: WILLIAM B. SANDLER
description: Former Municipal Court Judge William B. Sandler died here Sunday. He was 71 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street.

title: U.S. Wrestlers Grim In Drills for Russians
description: By the middle of his third workout yesterday, Dave Pruzansky's shoulders glistened With sweat and his face grimaced from strain.

title: NEW AIR ANALYZER FINDS POLLUTANTS
description: A new kind of air pollution analyzer that combines a laser and a computer to detect and measure minute quantities of up to 20 pollutant gases in five minutes has been developed by a Bell. Laboratories scientist who is quitting his job to help manufacture the device commercially.

title: Publish, and Be Damned
description: Selfcensorship may well be graver threat to a free press in America than anything the Government is able to do. That is the trouble with the Twentieth Century Fund's wellintentioned plan to establish a press council to monitor the performance of national news organizations.

title: Opel Tops VW in Germany
description: FLENSBURG, West Germany, Jan. 29 (Reuters)Adam Opel A.G., a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, displaced Volkswagenwerk A.G. in newcar registrations for 1972, figures from the Federal Motor Office showed today. Opel had 466,200 new registrations last year, up from 403,000 in 1971, while VW's total fell to 414,700 In 1972 from 478,200.

title: Contract Before Strike Deadline Expected in the Dress Industry
description: As negotiations continued yesterday for a new threeyear contract in the dress industry, both sides expressed optimism that an agreement would be reached by the time the old contract and a strike deadline expired at midnight tomorrow.

title: Events Today
description: Opera

title: For L.I. Wife of P.O.W., Dawn Comes at Midnight
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 29Carol Baker, wife of Air Force Capt. David E. Baker, remembers the exact minute the telephone call came. It was five minutes to midnight Saturday night, she said.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The ability of anadromous fish, among them salmon, shad and alewives, to return unerringly after years at sea to the stream of their birth to spawn, has puzzled biologists for many decades.

title: Service Complaints By Users of Phones Fell Sharply in '72
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29The number of consumer service complaints against the New York Telephone Company declined sharply last year, the Public Service Commission chairman, Joseph C. Swidler, reported today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: L.I.R.R. Is Picketed Over Hair

title: Earnings Climb 11%
description: The Continental Can Company led a parade of metals companies yesterday that reported higher sales and revenues for 1972.

title: McGuire Ready to Bring P.O.W.'s Home
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J. Jan. 29 The largest military air command departure and arrival point on the East Coast stood poised today to play a role in the return of military prisoners of war from Vietnam.

title: RAP BROWN TRIAL GETS 12TH JUROR
description: H. Rap Brown, a white skull cap over his shaved skull, stood at the defendants table in State Supreme Court here yesterday as the 12th juror was sworn at his trial on charges of armed robbery and attempting to murder policemen.

title: Maryland County Begins School Desegregation Plan
description: MARYLAND PARK, Md., Jan. 29Last week, Gene Dunlap's son Scotty was a sophomore at Crossland High School; today he was a sophomore at Central High School, and at lunchtime he called his father to bring over his gym shoes so he could try out for the basketball team.

title: Associated Brewing Sets Sale of Piels to Rheingold
description: The Associated Brewing Company of Detroit announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to sell its Piels Brothers, Inc., brewing operation to Rheingold Breweries, Inc. Merger Neither company News would disclose the value of the sale, but an Associated proxy statement mailed over the weekend listed the Piels operations as $6million of Associated's $22million assets.; Both Piels and Rheingold operate plants in Brooklyn, and it has been learned that Rheingold will shift the Piels production to its own plants, if the agreement becomes final.

title: Blacks Are Turned Away At a Jackson, Miss., Church
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 29Two groups that included blacks were turned away yesterday when they tired to attend a service at the First Baptist Church.

title: LARGE SOCIAL CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Nixon Administration's new budget proposes a sharp pruning of Federal social programs that, in effect, calls for the repeal of major initiatives of the Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

title: Behind the Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 With his new budget, a political document like all budgets, President Nixon is not merely continuing his long argument with Congress over how much money the Federal Government can safely spend. More fundamentally, he is attempting to seize a political initiative. He is trying to alter. so drastically the trend of Government spending, the standards that govern it and the manner in which it is controlled that all of the coming arguments on the subject will have to be fought out on his terms.

title: Budget Plan Would Raise Hospital Costs of Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Nixon Administration plans to seek legislation that would require the elderly to pay a sharply increased share of their hospital costs, a change that seems sure to trigger opposition from senior citizens and to lead to a fight in Congress.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Nixon's budget proposes the elimination of dozens of popular education programs, including the dismantling, as a Federal program, of the landmark Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.

title: Business Briefs
description: Exchange Members Back Institutions

title: Agriculture
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29One of the largest cuts in President Nixon's new budget was in spending proposals for the Department of Agriculturea total reduction of $563million.

title: Egyptian Plane Hits Mountain in Cyprus, Killing 38 Aboard
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 30 (UPI)  An Egyptian airliner carrying 38 persons, including eight Americans, crashed into the side of a mountain in northern Cyprus last night, killing all aboard, a spokesman for the airline said today.

title: Hearing Slated on Increases in Price of Heating Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 George P. Shultz, the Secretary of the Treasury, announced to day that the Cost of Living Council would hold public hearings next week on the recent increases in the wholesale price of heating oil.

title: U.S. INFORMS IRAN OF CONCERN ON OIL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29The United States and Britain have expressed diplomatic concern to the Shah of Iran over his abrupt announcement that Iran will take over full control of Western oil company operations there by 1979.

title: Arthur Daley
description: It began as something of an accident. There was an unusual empathy between Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, the first commissioner, and the baseball writers. None of the judge's successors ever was able to continue a like relationship, but Landis and the pressbox tenants formed something of a mutual admiration society. So when he invited a group of New York writers to dinner one night in Chicago late in the 1923 season, they asked him to be their guest the next time he was in their town. Thus was set in motion that annual midwinter social highlight, the dinner and show of the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America. The original intention had been to limit the first to the judge and a handful of friends. But it soon got out of hand, as have all dinners since. The first drew a gathering of 250 in the Hotel Commodore. On Sunday the same writers' group proudly held its golden anniversary dinner in the Hotel Americana before a turnaway assemblage of 1,200.

title: LARGE SOCIAL CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Nixon Administration's new budget proposes a sharp pruning of Federal social programs that, in effect, calls for the repeal of major initiatives of the Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

title: Man Who Damaged the Pieta Is Confined
description: ROME, Jan. 29Lazlo Toth, who last May seriously damaged Michelangelo's Pieta, was declared a socially dangerous person today and confined to a mental hospital for at least two years.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Chess: Mobility or Material? It's Mostly a Matter of Timing
description: An advantage in mobility always seems to be a tenuous thing; pawns and pieces can be counted, but no one has yet established a reliable method for quantifying mobility. So, when the question arises whether to sacrifice material for the sake of exploiting superior mobility, the answer has to be given on the basis of intuition.

title: SAMUEL MILLER DIES; LAW FIRM PARTNER
description: Samuel Miller, a partner in the New York law firm of Scribner & Miller and former chairman of the board of trustees of Pace College, died Saturday at his home in Bronxville, N. Y. He was 81 years. old.

title: Mayoral Candidate Group Reports Error on Its List
description: The name of Arthur B. Krim, chairman of United Artists Corporation, was included because of a stenographic error on published lists of a committee formed to seek a nonpartisan candidate for Mayor, the group's organizer, former Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet, said yesterday.

title: Both Sides Rest in the Watergate Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Both sides in the Watergate trial rested today with the fudge and the prosecution taking different positions on the possibility of highranking Presidential aides' being involved in spying on the Democrats.

title: Soccer League Makes Vast Revisions for '73
description: With the addition of the Philadelphia franchise last week, the North American Soccer League announced yesterday changes for the 1973 season involving divisional play, playoffs, homeandroad games, and revisions in the collegiate draft Feb. 12.

title: Albany Will Get Bills to Bar Inequities in Social Security Rise
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29  The Democratic minority in the State Senate announced today that they would submit a package of bills designed to correct gross inequities resulting from the recent Social Security increase, which, they said, would endanger the Medicaid and welfare eligibility of thousands of elderly people.

title: 2% PRICE INCREASE PLANNED BY XEROX
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it planned to increase rental rates by an estimated 2 per cent on most of its copiers, duplicators, facsimile equipment and engineering products, beginning March 1.

title: DEFICIT IS HALVED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon presented Congress today with a budget containing a list of more than 100 cutbacks or outright terminations of Government programs and said he could accomplish the great majority of these himself without Congressional action or concurrence.

title: Ron Lyle: New Fight Every Day
description: To introduce Ron Lyle, the Madison Square Garden boxing promoters arranged a special news conference yesterday.

title: Mills Expects No Tax Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (Reuters)Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that if the Administration held spending to the $268.7billion level of the President's budget there should be no need for a tax increase. He made the comment in brief remarks on the House floor while discussing the budget. He generally expressed approval of Mr. Nixon's plans to hold down spending,

title: Dance: Ballet Theater
description: The American Ballet Theater season that ended at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Sunday was one of the most successful in the company's history. With a threeweek boxoffice gross of $266,000, the company broke the house record for an extended engagement. However, the figures do not alone tell the story. The company was dancing extremely well.

title: F.B.I. Did No Full Study Of Reported G.O.P. Spy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Federal Bureau of Investigation has made no attempt to investigate fully the political espionage and sabotage activities allegedly conducted last year by Donald H. Segretti, a California lawyer, who reportedly acted under the direction of the White House and Republican reelection officials.

title: NET AND REVENUE UP FOR TEXAS EASTERN
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation reported yesterday new highs in 1972 earnings. The preliminary annual report placed operating revenues at $785.3million against $734.1million a year earlier. Net income hit a new high of $77.7million, or $3.20 a share, against $68.1million, or $2.91 a share on fewer shares, in 1971.

title: Saigon Troops Selectively Ignore Truce
description: CAM LONG, South Vietnam, Jan. 29 South Vietnamese forces were openly ignoring the ceasefire agreement in the area northwest of Saigon today, but on a relatively small scale and selectively.

title: A.B.C. to Focus on Laser Bomb
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)The United States is planning a steppedup effort to produce a laser bomb, a nuclear weapon that would he simpler and smaller but as powerful as the hydrogen bomb.

title: Jewish Soviet Physicist Tells of Cost of Leaving
description: A Soviet physicist who said he had paid a $40,000 fee to leave the Soviet Union with his wife and child asserted at a news conference here yesterday that he was only an example of the thousands of Jewish intellectuals who were being harassed because they wanted to emigrate to Israel.

title: Bridge: More Killing Defense Offers Suggestions on Discarding
description: Some six years ago, a book entitled Killing Defense established Hugh Kelsey, a young Scot, as a major bridge writer. The sequel, More Killing Defense, has been published in New York by Hart. The price of $2.45 is high for a 192page paperback, but the quality of the work justifies it: Kelsey's lucid writing and clear presentation fully maintain the standards of his three previbooks.

title: Bronx Man, 69, Is Shot By Youth Mugging His Wife
description: A 69yearold retired man was shot in the chest yesterday as he went to the aid of his wife who was being mugged in the hallway of their home in the Bronx.

title: Egypt's Parliament Lays Student Unrest to Leftists
description: CAIRO, Jan. 29The Egyptian Parliament, acting quickly, last night endorsed a report naming leftists as the people principally responsible for recent student unrest that led to a day of violent clashes with the police.

title: BANK BRANCHING GAINS IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29The New Jersey Senate today passed a package of three bills that would permit commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations to open branch offices statewide.

title: Chile Calls the Military
description: For the second time in three months, President Salvador Allende has called highranking military officers into the Government of Chile in an effort to quell public opposition to his policies. He has placed an Air Force general in charge of the distribution of food and other essential consumer goods, assisted by three Army officers and a Navy captain.

title: Zambia Urges U.N. Censures in Dispute
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 29Zambia asked the Security Council today to condemn Rhodesia, charging that the whiteruled African nation had carried out aggressive acts, economic blackmail and military threats that could create a new Vietnam situation in southern Africa.

title: SILVER FUTURES POST 3CENT GAIN
description: Silver futures gained about 3 cents an ounce yesterday in trading on the Commodity Exchange, a move traced to the issuance of the yearly Handy & Harman silver market review. March silver closed at $2 an ounce, up from $1.97 1/10.

title: The Georgetown Blacking Factory
description: WASHINGTONOn the C.B.S. Evening News, Monday, Jan. 8, 1973, Dan Rather announced to the twenty million faithful followers of the Cronkite show that the reported rift between the President and Henry Kissinger was past the rumor stage to the fact stage. He thereby elevated to gospel that which had been for weeks the speculation of Washington commentators and columnists.

title: PAN AM MAY DROP CONCORDE OPTIONS
description: With three days left before the contract deadline, all indications yesterday were that Pan American was ready to drop its options for eight Concorde supersonic airliners.

title: Israelis Said to Intercept 8 BoobyTrapped Letters
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 29  Eight boobytrapped letters mailed in Turkey on Jan. 25 were intercepted today by Israeli postal sources, a police spokesman said.

title: They Take Walks in the Moonlight Without Leaving the House
description: Buck Rogers, move over. Anne and Anthony Woolner have landed their house on a North Salem, N.Y., hilltop.
