And the semitransparent dwelling, looking almost like a spaceship of the future, is becoming known as the only home around where you can take walks in the moonlight without going out of doors.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Australian National Playwrights Conference, which is being modeled after the successful American one at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., will be held in Sydney and Canberra trim Feb. 19 to March 19.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary aid index, Page 39

title: Ellsberg Prosecutor Tied to Studies of Pentagon Papers' Impact
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29The Government acknowledged in court today that it had done many analyses to determine whether the national defense had been affected by the publication of the Pentagon papers and that all of them had long since been turned over to the chief prosecutor in the EllsbergRusso case.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: PROSECUTOR AND 2 GUILTY OF BRIBERY
description: An assistant district attorney and two confederates were convicted last night of taking a $15,000 bribe to fix a criminal case in Queens.

title: British Government Thinks U.N. Should Oversee Vietnam Peace
description: LONDON, Jan. 29The Britsh Government believes that ??he problem of maintaining the ??eace in Vietnam should even??ually be turned over to the United Nations.

title: Berkey Trust Suit Seeks Divestitures By Eastman Kodak
description: Berkey Photo, Inc., yesterday filed a $300million antitrust suit against the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, N. Y.

title: After the Longest Wait, Snow Finally Falls Here
description: The first snowfall of the winter blustered across the metropolitan area yesterday morning, capriciously burying some suburban sections under 46inch accumulations and lightly feathering others, including the city, where less than 2 inches were recorded.

title: LINDSAY ORDERS POLICE TO SPEED RECRUIT TRAINING
description: Spurred by the ambush shootings of four policemen in less than a week, Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a drastic speedup in the training of police recruits.

title: Next Vietnam Parley
description: PARIS, Jan. 29  Plans are advancing to nail down the Vietnam accords with international guarantees, even though, at least at the outset, the ceasefire may be proving fragile, to use President Nixon's word.

title: $14Billion Set in Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Although the estimated Federal budget deficit will decline by $12.1billion in the new 1974 fiscal year, Treasurys borrowing in the money market will decline by a smaller amount and will he about $14billion, it was estimated today in President Nixon's budget.

title: White House Says Nixon Aide ls Leaving But Denies Pressure
description: MIAMI, Jan. 29  The White House confirmed today that Dwight L. Chapin was leaving as President Nixon's appointments secretary, but denied that he was being forced out or that his departure resulted from his reported links to political campaign espionage by Republicans last year.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: $5.19Million Asked From U.S.

title: Trials of Leftists Ignite Anger in Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 25Two former deans of law and political science at the University of Ankara are now shoveling snow and digging ditches at the Mamak military prison where they are serving sixyear sentences for crimes of political opinion.

title: Justice Orders Arbitration Of Press Dispute at News
description: State Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Chimera ruled yesterday that a dispute between the Daily News and New York Printing Pressmen's Union 2 regarding two new, highspeed color presses must be arbitrated.

title: Area Resorts Warm Up With New Snow Blanket
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y. Jan. 29Winter, in all its glistening white glory, finally came to the ski country today. And, as it arrived, it showed no favorites. Substantial new blankets of snow were reported from Pennsylvania's Poconos to Canada's Laurentians. The storm sent area ski operators, some of whom had not even been able to open this winter, into flurry of activity. As many as 20 inches of prized dry snow dropped on Onset Mountain in southern New Hampshire. Even such banana belt resorts as Great Gorge and Vernon Valley in New Jersey got 16 and 18 precious inches, respectively.

title: Bearding the Lions at Italy's Operas
description: ROMEGone forever are the days when the hardtoplease opera enthusiasts of Parma, awesome in their fury, would chase tenors the entire infamous halfmile from the Lions' Denterm for the Teatro Regioto the railroad station because of a botched Verdi aria. This season, the irascible fans of Parma, reputedly the world's most exacting operagoers, tepidly listen to Polish, Spanish, Bulgarian and Japanese singers. A National Autonomous Union of Lyrical Artists, founded by a homegrown baritone, Giussepe Zecchilli, recently stopped a performance of Un Ballo in Maschera in the Lions' Den for 20 minutes to protest what it called an invasion of Italian opera houses by foreign talent.

title: Bank Robbers in Quebec Flee on Snowmobiles
description: GRANBY, Quebec, Jan. 29 (UPI)  Two armed men wearing goggles robbed a bank of $7,000 today and roared off on snowmobiles.

title: RentLeveling Measure Sent to Assembly Floor
description: The Assembly's Conference Committee cleared a controversial rentleveling bill for floor action yesterday as tenant complaints about rent increases, some of them calling for as much as 50 per cent more a month, continued to mount.

title: The Dance
description: Two more contrasting attitudes toward popular music could scarcely be demonstrated than those of Julie Finch and Dianne McIntyre. Miss Finch finds it a warm stimulus to movement, but Miss McIntyre detects in its happy cadences the fetters of a people's sensibility. Both made convincing cases for their attitudes in separate concerts Sunday evening.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOLDIER. By Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, retired. With James T. Wooten. 495 pages. Illustrated. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $10.95.

title: Wiltwyck Counters Strike
description: The Wiltwyck School for Boys reported full operations yesterday at all of its facilities in Westchester and New York City despite a strike of employes that began Friday. T. George Silcott, executive director, said that supervisory and administrative personnel were maintaining services at the school's principal residence, which serves 130 boys on the Eleanor Roosevelt Campus in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The school was struck after members of Local 1707, Community and Social Agency Employes, rejected a tentative contract.

title: Juilliard Quartet Dashing In an Unscheduled Piece
description: Dietrich FischerDieskau and the Juilliard String Quartet were to have been guest artists with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, but the baritone became ill and it was up to the quartetplus members of the societyto furnish the program. In place of the singer's scheduled performance of a new Samuel Barber song cycle and seven Wolf songs, the ensemble hastily improvised Dvorak's A major Piano Quintet.

title: 4 in Brooklyn Siege Indicted in Killing
description: The four gunmen who surrendered on Jan. 21 after a 47hour siege of a Brooklyn sporting goods store during which one policeman was killed, two were wounded and 13 hostages gained safety were indicted yesterday on murder and other charges.

title: For Greek Cook, Baking Moussaka Was a Kind of Therapy
description: WESTPORT, Conn.In the old days James and Mary Margarites ran a GreekAmerican grocery store, and their sons, Emmanuel and Paul, would help out after school.

title: City Severance Pay Urged In Lieu of Stalled Pensions
description: A special panel recommended yesterday that the city contribute $24million a year for severance pay or higher welfare benefits for I40,000 municipal employes as a substitute for improved pensions that have been blocked by the Legislature for two years.

title: Amnesty for Draft Resisters Is Expected to Be Divisive Political Issue for Years
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Like the Vietnam war itself, the issue of amnesty for those who refused to fight seems likely to be a divisive and emotional part of the American political scene for many years.

title: Court Orders Senate Vote But Declines to Set Date
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29  Legal efforts to force an early special election to fill two State Senate vacancies apparently failed today in State Superior Court.

title: CITY POLICE TRIAL SELECTING JURORS
description: NEWARK, Jan. 29  Under extraordinary courtroom conditions, selection of a jury began today in the trial of eight New York City policemen and more than 20 other defendants under Federal indictment charging them with conspiracy and aiding and abetting an interstate gambling operation.

title: LOCAL UNIT PLANS TO TRY A TEACHER
description: The superintendent of Community School District 16 in Brooklyn said yesterday he would bring formal charges against a teacher who had given an interview to a newsman on school preimses without obtaining permission from district officials.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: President Suspends Quotas On Meat Imports for 1973
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP)  President Nixon signed today a proclamation implementing his decision to suspend meat import quotas for 1973 in an effort to hold down rising meat prices, the Florida White House said.

title: Dolphins' Scott Accepts 4Wheel Spoil of Victory
description: Jake Scott, the Miami Dolphins' safetyman who was named the outstanding player in the. recent Super Bowl game, thanked a lot of people here yesterday when he received his prize, a new automobile, and added, I think I'll give Bill Kilmer an extra set of keys.

title: Records: Steve Goodman
description: Steve Goodman's new album, Somebody Else's Troubles (Buddah Records BDS 5121, $5.98) is an example of. the fun and opportunity available today to the young singer and composer. (Fun and opportunity that comes, in Mr. Goodman's case, after five years of hard work in small folk clubs.)

title: Grant to Help Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) A grant of $337,071 to Harvard University in support of new program of humanities fellowships for lawyers in the teaching profession was announced today by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: ONION OIL PROFITS RISE IN QUARTER
WHEELCHAIR USER BARRED BY SUBWAY
description: Taking the subway from his Brooklyn Heights home to work in Times Square has become a bit more taxing since Friday for Francis Perry, a wheelchairbound, 30yearold cerebral palsy victim.

title: SAIGON AND THE VIETCONG CHARGE FIGHTING GOES ON; U.S. AIDES TERM IT LIGHT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 30The South Vietnamese Government and the Communists accused each other of scores of additional ceasefire violations yesterday, but American analysts described the fighting that continued around the country as scattered light activity that was gradually diminishing in intensity.

title: Contractor Says Graft In Atlantic City Was 5%
description: CAMDEN, Jan. 29 (AP)  A 79yearold plumbing contractor testified in Federal Court here today that his company paid 5 per cent of all money received for work it did for Atlantic City between 1952 and 1969 to a deceased former city and Atlantic County official.

title: MAURICE C. WILSON
description: Maurice C. Wilson, retired commercial manager for Manhattan of the New York Telephone Company, died Sunday in the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park. He was 79 years old and lived at 18804 64th Street, Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Dow Closes Below 1,000, First Time Since Nov. 15
description: The stock market sagged again yesterday in moderate trading and closed at its lowest level since midNovember.

title: A Top Heroin Smuggler Is Given 20Year Sentence, the Maximum
description: Auguste Joseph Ricord, whom the Government called the largest trafficker in heroin ever brought to trial in the United States, received the maximum 20year prison sentence in Federal Court yesterday for conspiracy to smuggle narcotics.

title: TIMES CO. NET UP 26C A SHARE IN '72
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday 1972 operating earnings of $12.3million, equal to $1.06 a share, compared with $9.4million, or 80 cents a share, in 1971. Revenues increased to a record $330.5million from $290.2million in 1971.

title: TWO COMMUNISTS JAILED IN ATHENS
description: ATHENS, Jan. 29  Two leaders of a breakaway Communist group were found guilty today by an Athens tribunal of attempting to topple by force the established system and social order in Greece and were sent to jail for more than 12 years each. Communism has been outlawed in this country for nearly a quarter of a century.

title: East Stars Are Favored On Paper and Garden Ice
description: Because the National Hockey League's AllStar Game now is staged on a rotating basisand not at the home of the Stanley Cup championNew York finally will see the league's annual midseason affair.

title: Islanders Discharge Goyette as Coach and Appoint Ingarfield as His Successor
description: Phil Goyette's silent suffering ended yesterday when he was dismissed as coach of the Islanders, the club that is last in the National Hockey League with six victories in the first 50 games they ever played.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: TV: Olivier and Welles
description: Frequently touted as a prominent yardstick for the intellectual content of television, The Dick Cavett Show has an almost startling capacity to be depressing. Perhaps 10 commercial breaks in the course of 90 minutes would annihilate any show's pretensions to seriousness. But the problem only begins there.

title: Urban Development
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Nixon served notice today that he would end by next July 1 the Federal commitment to urban development programs enacted by Democratic Presidents in the last four decades.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: McAFEE, N. J., Jan. 29The winter vacation season is in full swing, and that conjures up mental images of Caribbean beaches, fishing, sailing, swimming, gourmet meals, deluxe quarters and firstclass nightclub life.

title: The Better to Hear
description: Incredible as it may seem, in a day when electronic miracles have become commonplacewhen man can eavesdrop on outer space and ocean bottomsthe design, marketing and discussion of hearing aids is more superstitionridden than in the days of ancient Greece when slaves and citizens went about with punctured seashells strapped over their cars.

title: Stage: 3Act Drama by LeRoi Jones
description: LeRoi Jones (Imamu Amiri Baraka) wrote A Recent Killing in 1964. It was his first fulllength play and it remains his only threeact play. Over the the years it has been considered for production by many commercial managements. Finally, the work has reached the stage under the sponsorship of the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, where last weekend it began a scheduled threeweekend engagement.

title: Highlights of the Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Following are highlights of President Nixon's budget for the fiscal year 1974:

title: A.E.C. Plans Fee Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission announced today plans to sharply increase its fees for licensing power plants and other facilities used in the nuclear power industry.

title: Johnson Was Informed About Trace, Wife Says
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jane 29 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today that her husband knew a ceasefire agreement had been reached before his death last Monday. She said he had been told personally by President Nixon.

title: People and Business
description: Gerald Tsai Jr., the Shanghaiborn money manager who became perhaps the bestknown mutual fund executive during the era of the gogo funds in the late nineteensixties, has resigned as head of the Tsai Management and Research Corporation, effective Feb. 28. He will be succeeded as president and chief executive officer by Irwin Lainoff, who is presently executive vice president.

title: Rutgers Forces Bateman to Resign and Relieves Athletic Head
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 29 Dr. John Bateman, football coach at Rutgers University for 13 seasons, resigned today at the request of the university president, and Albert W. Twitchell, athletic director for the same number of years, was relieved of his duties.

title: Congress Regards Cuts As Threat to Its Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Nixon's proposal today to hold spending to $268.7billion in the 1974 fiscal year and to trim or eliminate a number of social programs enacted under Democratic Administrations was viewed in Congress as a challenge to the lawmakers' authority to decide how Federal money should be spent.

title: Lon Not Truce Does Not Seem To Reduce Clashes in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 29The Cambodian Government s suspension of offensive action by its armed forces today appears so far to have had no effect on the fighting in Cambodia.

title: Bond Interest Rates Continue to Climb
description: The credit markets, in a reaction that apparently had little connection with either the ceasefire in Vietnam or with President Nixon's budget message, continued in a slump yesterday. Taxexempt bond yields rose particularly sharply. Sereral major new bond issues that had been brought to market last week were permitted to trade without any, support from under. writers yesterday, and prices sank. These setbacks set the stage for today's sales of tripleA Texas Power & Light Company bonds in the corporate bond sector and of tripleA Illinois and California issues in the taxexempt area.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Tams, at Memphis. (TelevisionChannel E (cable), 9:05 P.M., and Channel 9, 10 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 7:30 P.M.)

title: After the Longest Wait, Snow Finally Falls Here
description: The first snowfall of the winter blustered across the metropolitan area yesterday morning, capriciously burying some suburban sections under 16inch accumulations and lightly feathering others, including the city, where less than 2 inches were recorded.

title: NATO and Warsaw Pact Agree on Details for Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The United States, the Soviet Union and 17 of their allies cleared away the last obstacles today to the start on Wednesday of preliminary EastWest talks in Vienpa on finding ways of reducing each side's military forces in Central Europe.

title: F.B.I. Did No Full Study Of Reported G.O.P. Spy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Federal Bureau of Investigation has made no attempt to investigate fully the political espionage and sabotage activities allegedly conducted last year by Donald H. Segretti, a California lawyer, who reportedly acted Under the direction of the White House and Republican reelection officials.

title: KNOWLTON'S AIDE PREPARED '68 TAX
description: NEWARK, Jan. 29 (AP)A tax attorney for former State Senator Willard B. Knowltop testified today that he prepared a tax return for the Bergen County official in 1968, the year Mr. Knowlton allegedly failed to file a return.

title: Buddhist to Appeal Ruling
description: BELLAIRE, Tex., Jan. 29 (UPI)A Buddhist priest says he will appeal a ruling by the city building inspector who said the priest, Calvin Chan Vasallo, cannot hold services in his frame home. The inspector said that Buddha's University Church must be in a masonary building with offstreet parking, instead of in a back room.

title: MARCOS CURBING CAMPUS ACTIVISM
description: MANILA, Jan. 29President Ferdinand E. Marcos has ordered a crackdown on what he considers agitation and subversive activity in colleges and universities, the Information Department said today.

title: Plunge Kills Dance Teacher
description: A 26yearold man fell or jumped to his death at 9:30, A.M. yesterday from the roof oft a 12story building at 207 West 25th Street, the police of the West 20th Street station reported. He was identified as William F. Pierce, a dance instructor and a member of Actors Equity. He lived at 114 Seventh Avenue at 17th Street.

title: Economists Laud Cuts
description: The initial reaction by economists to President Nixon's 1974 budget, which was delivered to Congress yesterday, was one of muted optimism tinged with fears about a possible resurgence of inflation.

title: Canadian Trade Surplus Off From YearAgo Level
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Canada's trade surplus declined to $1.20billion in 1972 from $2.10billion in 1971, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: Woman Dies, Man Injured In Jamaica Apartment Fire
description: A woman was burned to death last night and a 46yearold man was slightly injured when fire swept through basement apartment in a twoandahalfstory frame house in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Civil Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Administration's 1974 budget proposes an increase of $629million in funds for civil rights.

title: PROSECUTOR AND 2 GUILTY OF BRIBERY
description: An assistant district attorney and two confederates were convicted last night of taking a $15,000 bribe to fix a criminal case in Queens.

title: U.S. Says 56 Prisoners Remain Unaccounted For
MRS. I. E. GOLDWASSER
description: Mrs. Edith Goldstein Goldwasser, wife of Dr. I. Edwin Goldwasser, a former assistant superintendent of schools and onetime executive director of the Federation for Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York, died yesterday at her home, 250 East 73d 1Street, She was 84 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The ability of anadromous fish, among them salmon, shad and alewives, to return unerringly after years at sea to the stream of their birth to spawn, has puzzled biologists for many decades.

title: 10 Die in Rest Home Fire; Arson Is Laid to a Resident
description: PLEASANTVILLE, Jan. 29Ten of the 16 elderly residents of a rest home, including a 106yearold woman, died early this morning when fire swept the twostory, woodframe building. Late tonight a 22yearold man described as having lived in the home was arrested and charged with arson by the state police.

title: Dreyfus Fund Stock Offered At $12.48 a Share in Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29 (Reuters)Daiwa Securities today began offering 1.2 million shares of the Dreyfus Fund at $12.48 I(share under the blockoffer system.

title: Research
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29For federally supported research and development, the watchwords for the next year appear to be relevance and economy.

title: Flood of Mail Delayed Sniper Attack Warning
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29 (AP)A local television station received a letter warning of a New Year's Eve sniper attack on a police station, but because of the holiday mail crush, the letter was not received until after the incident, Station WWL reported tonight.

title: One Killed, Two Wounded In Shootout at Harlem Bar
description: One man was killed and two others were wounded early yesterday in an exchange of six shots in front of Harlem bar and grill at 3415 Broadway, the police said.

title: New York Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Nixon's budget today requested $6.2 million to begin the Federal takeover of the Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor, but no money to revise the planning or to start construction of facilities for the vast urban park.

title: U.S. Copter Pilot Dies Of Wounds After Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29 (AP)A United States helicopter pilot, wounded while flying an aircraft reported to bear marks of neutrality, died today. He was the first American killed in Vietnam since the ceasefire went into effect.

title: Prices Off Again on Amex and OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over  thecounter market declined yesterday for the sixth consecutive session in dull trading.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Mixed Force, With US. Advisers Guards Key Highway as War Goes On in Laos
description: MUONG KASSY, Laos, Jan. 29While the war in Vietnam may be sputtering to a ceasefire, the war in Laos continues.

title: Rein on Economy Is Called U.S. Goal
description: The basic thrust of the Nixon Administration's economic policy in 1973 will be to slow the rate of economic expansion so as to avoid a new outbreak of inflation, Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday.

title: Crusaders Beat Whalers In Battle for First Place
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (AP)Jim Wiste's breakaway goal with 3 minutes 34 seconds left sparked the Cleveland Crusaders a 32 victory over the New England Whalers tonight and broke a firstplace tie between the two clubs in the Eastern Division of the World Hockey Association.

title: Dollar Off Sharply In Trading Abroad
description: The United States dollar declined sharply yesterday in nervous foreign exchange markets around the world.

title: N.H.L. Approves Franchises In Washington, Kansas City
description: The National Hockey League's Board of Governors approved yesterday franchises in Kansas City and Washington for the 197475 season. The franchises were granted conditionally last June and this move gives the green light to organizational, plans.

title: Joseph W W. Ballantine, 83, Dies; Was a Foreign Service Officer
description: Joseph W. Ballantine, a retired Foreign Service officer who directed the Office of Far Eastern Affairs in 1944, died yesterday in the Van Doren convalescent home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 83 years old and lived at 129 East 10th Street.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Notes on People
description: For the next three days Mayor Vladimir Promyslov of Moscow will be the guest of Mayor Walter Washington of Washington. During the visit, Mr. Promyslov, who often invites his American guests to tour the Moscow subway, will be invited to look at the plans for the Washington subway, which is under construction. When Mayor Washington visited Moscow in 1970, he was permitted a surprise meeting with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, but there was no indication whether Mr. Promyslov would meet President Nixon in Washington.

title: Budget Plan Would Raise Hospital Costs of Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Nixon Administration plans to seek legislation that would require the elderly to pay sharply increased share of their hospital costs, a change that seems sure to trigger opposition from senior citizens and to lead to a fight in Congress.

title: SAIGON AND THE VIETCONG CHARGE FIGHTING GOES ON; U.S. AIDES TERM IT LIGHT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 30The South Vietnamese Government and the Communists accused each other of scores of additional ceasefire violations yesterday, but American analysts described the fighting that continued around the country as scattered light activity that was gradually diminishing in intensity.

title: HUSSEIN REJOINS MILITARY FRONT
description: CAIRO, Jan. 29Ten days before a scheduled meeting With President Nixon in Washington, King Hussein of Jordan appears to have taken a long step toward ending his isolation in the Arab world by making Jordan once more a part of the military front surrounding Israel.

title: Military Commission Bogs Down Over Vietcong's Refusal to Present Credentials
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 30  The military commission that is to help monitor the Vietnam ceasefire held its first meeting yesterday, but it immediately became bogged down in a procedural dispute as the Vietcong delegates refused to present their credentials, wellinformed sources said.

title: Rivalry Is Family Affair For Outboard Companies
description: This is the year for Johnson Outboards. Last year it was Evinrude. Side by side on the first and second floors at the National Boat Show, the staunch rivals in the world of outboard engines compete with ferocious friendliness. They have to because they have the same bossOutboard Marine Corporation.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Advertising: System Defended
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29In a strongly worded speech that marked the reemergence of the phrase creeping socialism in polite advertising circles after an absence of several years, an industry leader today called for the establishment of an organization to resell the free enterprise system to the American people.

title: A Certain Smile Has Vanished in Marseilles
description: MARSEILLES, France, Jan. 19 1 Blond Dominique, her back to the bar of the jampacked cafe called The Unexpected in the Arab quarter here, is reading the latest strike manifesto to her enthusiastic fellow workers at the top of her voice:

title: Lodge Says He Saw Little Prospect of a Truce Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Henry Cabot Lodge, the former United States Ambassador in Saigon and onetime chief delegate to the Paris peace talks, says he doubted the possibility of a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: DEFICIT IS HALVED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon presented Congress today with a budget containing a list of more than 100 cutbacks or outright terminations of Government programs and said he could accomplish the great majority of these himself without Congressional action or concurrence.

title: Chaos Marks Pretrial Hearings On '71 AtticaUprising Charges
description: WARSAW, N. Y., Jan. 29 (AP) An indictment was torn up, epithets were yelled, defendants refused to walk and ?? stenographer was kissed and the judge remained unruffled through it all.

title: Tax Credits Urged By Rabbinical Unit For School Tuition
description: MONSEY, N. Y., Jan. 29 The largest Jewish Orthodox rabbinic body in the country, citing serious financial difficulties confronting allday Jewish schools, today appealed to Congress to pass a measure to give tax credits to parents for the tuition they pay these schools.

title: Ottawa Demands Release Of Citizen Held by Hanoi
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (Canadian PressThe Canadian Government has demanded the immediate release by Hanoi of a Canadian farm expert held captive in North Vietnam since 1968, the department of External Affairs said today.

title: Crime.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Federal programs to reduce crime, especially those aimed at controlling drug abuse, are among the few that will receive substantial increases in funding under the Nixon Administration's proposed budget, which was released today.

title: Campaign Seeks to Ban Books by Cleaver From Town's Schools
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Jan. 29 The people of this attractive old Fairfield County town are angry and divided over a campaign to ban two books from classrooms and school libraries.

title: Kerner Trial Is Delayed
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI)The illness of two jurors delayed today the trial of former Gov. Otto Kerner and former State Revenue director Theodore J. Isaacs on bribery, charges.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: 1951 AllAmerican Is Slain By Gunmen in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29Patterson Cannamela, a 43yearold former allAmerican at the University of Southern California and professional football player, was fatally shot by gunmen during the robbery of an appliance store here yesterday.

title: Construction Tapered Off Near End of Record Year
description: The nation's construction industry had its best year ever in 1972, but the boom showed signs of tailing off in December, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Poll Majority Feel President Achieved Peace With Honor
description: A majority of Americans agree with President Nixon that the United States is achieving peace with honor in Vietnam, according to a special nationwide Gallup poll conducted last Thursday  two days after Mr. Nixon's announcement of a settlement.

title: Environment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29In his Budget Message today, President Nixon requested just over $1billion more for the Environmental Protection Agency in the fiscal year 1974 than he did last year.

title: Highlights of the Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Following are highlights of President Nixon's budget for the fiscal year 1974:

title: Job Cutbacks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The new budget indicates, and the new Budget Director, Roy L. Ash, confirms, that in his second term President Nixon will strive to reduce the number of Federal employes year by year.

title: Military
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Department of Defense expects to spend $79billion next year, an increase of $4.2billion over the current year's total, despite the ceasefire in Vietnam.

title: Planning Boards Promised Wider Role
description: Local community boards will play a more active role in city planning, the newly named chairman of the City Planning Commission said yesterday.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Julie Schafler finds her way of life has changed since she set herself up as the outlet for a group of 30 or so talented artisans, Her apartment, for example, hardly reflects her private life any more, but rather provides a neutral setting for the rugs, hangings, cushions, and other special oneofakind pieces that are, she says, of themselves works of art.

title: ABOLITION OF VOTE ON SHERIFF URGED
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 29 Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian today proposed abolishing the office of elected sheriff and transferring the sheriff's staff into a farlessindependent county department.

title: Deep Sleep Star Arrested in Paterson
description: PATERSON, Jan. 29Joseph Rose, star of the Xrated film Deep Sleep, was free on $500 bond today after a middleofthenight arrest and a predawn arraignment that irked a Municipal Court judge.

title: MitchellLama Here Held LuxuryHousing Subsidy
description: The city's MitchellLama program, though it once produced middleincome housing as intended, has deteriorated into a vehicle for subsidizing luxury housing, according to a study published yesterday.

title: GEN YAKOV DORI, HAGANAH LEADER
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 29  Lieut. Gen. Yakov Dori, the last commander of the Haganah, the Jewish defense organization during the British Mandate, and the first Chief of Staff of Israel's defense forces, died in Haifa today after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Conscription Lottery Scheduled for Spring
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI)  Although Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird has officially ended the draft six months ahead of schedule, the Selective Service System will still hold another conscription lottery this spring.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The South Vietnamese Government and the Communists accused each other of scores of ceasefire violations yesterday, but American analysts described the fighting that continued around the country as scattered light activity whose intensity was gradually diminishing. The fighting is definitely on a downward trend, a highranking American official said, more noticeably in some areas than in others. There are no major units fighting. Nothing decisive is happening. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary offering of 1,5 million shares of Avis, Inc., common at $47 per share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Lazard Freres, Kuhn Loeb, Paine Webber, and Merrill Lynch. The shares are being sold as part of International Telephone and Telegraph Co.'s divestiture of Avis. Subsequent to the offering, I.T.T. will own 3.1 million shares of Avis or about 52 per cent of the outstanding shares. I.T.T. closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 54, down .

title: DOCTORS FOUND ANATIONAL UNION
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 29 (AP)The first national union of physicians and dentists has been formed here with the goal of fighting interference by outside parties in medical care.

title: Knicks Subdue Warriors, 9784
description: The situation was ripe for a letdown, but the New York Knicks, led by Dave DeBusschere and Walt Frazier, wouldn't let one develop at Madison Square Garden last night as they defeated the Golden State Warriors, 9784.

title: Victims of Mistaken Raid Sue Police for $1Million
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP)An attorney for a Winthrop woman and her daughter filed a $1million suit today in Federal District Court in connection with a mistaken police narcotics raid on their home.

title: G.O.P. CONGRESSMEN URGE TIES WITH CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Twelve Republican Congressmen urged President Nixon and Congress today to take immediate steps for normal United States relations with Cuba, broken off on Jan. 3, 1961.

title: NIXON OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CEASEFIRE
description: MIAMI, Jan. 29  The White House said today that it was not surprised that fighting was continuing in South Vietnam and expressed optimism that the ceasefire would be scrupulously adhered to.

title: Excerpts From President Nixon's Budget Message as Presented to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Following are excerpts from President Nixon's Budget Message as presented to Congress today:

title: CITY LISTS 7 PLACES AS FOOD VIOLATORS
description: Seven foodprocessing establishments were named yesterday by the city's Health. Services Administration as violators of the Health Code.

title: Fairbanks's Top Aide Gets Oklahoma Post
description: NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 29 (AP)  Barry Switzer, who devised Oklahoma's recordbreaking Wishbone offense, was chosen today to become the Sooners' new head football coach.

title: ,Campaign Seeks to Ban Books by Cleaver From Town's Schools
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Jan. 29 The people of this attractive old Fairfield County town are angry and divided over a campaign to ban two books from classrooms and school libraries.

title: JOHN W. MERSHON
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 29John William Mershon, chairman of the board of the Stamford Federal Savings & Loan Association and former plantfacilities manager for the Yale & Towne Manufacturing Company, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 27 Dolson Place.

title: Manpower
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Nixon has arrested the rapid growth of the Federal manpower programs and is moving to turn over control of Federal jobtraining and employment services to the state and local authorities.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: BOYLE'S PENSION IS CUT BY U.M.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The ousted president of the United Mine Workers of America, W. A. Boyle, was denied a lifetime pension at his full $50,000ayear salary today as antiBoyle insurgents who defeated him in last month's election widened their austerity campaign at the union's headquarters.

title: Jets Get 2 Saints To Help Defense
description: On the eve of today's pro football draft, the Jets traded their second and third round choices for two established players from the New Orleans Saints who could go a long way toward solving New York's defensive weaknesses.

title: RACE STUDY PANEL DENIES POLITICS
description: Governor Rockefeller's study group on horse racing will meet here today to discuss the latest draft of what it calls an extraordinarily complex report.

title: Police by Hundreds Comb 2 Boroughs for 6 Suspects in Ambush Shootings
description: Hundreds of patrolmen and detectives, working extra shifts on overtime, bolstered a force of regularly assigned policemen in a hunt yesterday for six black militants suspected in the ambushing of four policemen since last Thursday.

title: RACE STUDY PANEL DENIES POLITICS
description: Governor Rockefeller's study group on horse racing will meet here today to discuss the latest draft of what it calls an extraordinarily complex report.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Sugar Refinery Is Planned In Staten Island Pier Area
description: Plans for the construction of a $40million sugar refinery in the Stapleton section of Staten Island have been announced by MPS International. According to William A. Fiorito, president of MPS, his company has been awarded a construction and operations contract for the refinery by the Columbia Sugar Corporation. The new plant, which will require 18 months to build, will be in the part of the Staten Island water front now occupied by cityowned Piers 13 to 16.

title: HEARING IS DELAYED FOR CAR INSPECTORS
description: The muchdelayed disciplinary hearing of two Transit Authority car inspectors was recessed again yesterday to allow the authority to seek an opinion in State Supreme Court about whether one of the men could be required to testify.

title: PENNSY SEEKS LEASE OF 114 NEW DIESELS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (UP)  The Penn Central Railroad said today it wants to lease 114 new diesel electric freight locomotives at a cost of $49.9million over a 15year period.

title: FourNation Truce Group Holds Its First Meeting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29The new fournation international control commission held its first meeting this morning and discovered that for the time being the organization was paralyzed.

title: MONTGOMERY WARD SETS UNIT IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29 (AP)The Finance Ministry has approved establishment in Japan of wholly owned subsidiary of Montgomery Ward & Co. of the United States, officials said today.

title: Highs and Lows
description: MONDAY, JAN. 29, 1973

title: No Kiss, No Prayer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Went downtown the night the war ended wearing a peppermintstriped, icecreamconeshaped party hat and carrying a genuine Klaxon noisemaker and looking for pretty girls to hug and kiss in deliriums of joyous celebration, as the fancier newspapers used to say in the better old days.

title: Saigon Troops Selectively Ignore Truce
description: CAM LONG, South Vietnam, Jan. 29  South Vietnamese forces were openly ignoring the ceasefire agreement in the area northwest of Saigon today, but on a relatively small scale and selectively.

title: The Nixon Budget
description: In the first budget of his second term, President Nixon has sought, in his words, to chart a new course for America. Indeed, he is trying to reverse the course public policy that this country has pursued for forty years and turn back toward the traditional Republican philosophy of Presidents Harding, Coolidge and Hooverbefore the Great Depression shook the nations faith unrestricted free enterprise and before Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal greatly expanded the social role of government.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Truce Holds Little Hope For a Village in Vietnam
description: TRUNG LAP, South Vietnam, Jan. 18  Life in this village has been like a nightmare for its people during the war, They do not seem likely to fare much better after a ceasefire.

title: HENRIETTA E. OLDING
description: Henrietta E. Olding, a former chief of audit for Upper Manhattan for the Internal Revenue Service and a former national secretarytreasurer of the American Federation of Government Employes, died Friday in a Cincinnati nursing home. She was 86 years old and had lived at 400 Central Park West until last year.

title: SENATE CONFIRMS PENTAGON CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Senate confirmed today President Nixon's nomination of Elliot L. Richardson to be Secretary of Defense.

title: Miss Durr Upset By Kerry Harris At Washington Net
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Kerry Harris of Australia upset fifthranked Francois Durr of France tonight 46, 63, 64, in the opening round of the Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament.

title: MALCUZYNSKI PLAYS IN BENEFIT CONCERT
description: Carnegie Hall was filled Sunday night as Witold Malcuzynski gave a benefit concert to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America. With his long, silvery hair, his patrician manner and the intense concentration he projects from the keyboard, Mr. Malcuzynski certainly looks the part of the virtuoso pianist, and in most of his programs here over the last 30 years he has matched those appearances with performances of flair and brilliance.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: LiquoriSzordykowski: Round 2 May Be Friday
description: The best mile of the indoor track and field season may he run Friday night in Toronto, and Marty Liguori issued a tough, early notice yesterday to at least one rival in the race to keep his arms and legs where they belong.

title: Spong a Wilson Scholar
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Former Senator William B. Spong of Virginia has been named a guest scholar of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, it was announced today.

title: Rail Holding Unit Gains
description: Seaboard Coast Line Industries, Inc., a railroad holding company, reported yesterday consolidated net income of $82.4million, or $5.96 a share, for 1972. Earnings for 1971 were $55.1million, or $4.66 share, before a $28.4million extraordinary charge and $16.3  million non  recurring credit.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: WILLIAM E. ERDMAN
description: William E. Erdman, a vice president and director of Harris, Upham & Co., who had represented the brokerage house on the American Stock Exchange since 1960, died Sunday in White Plains Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 177 East Hartsdale Avenue, Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Fire in Jersey Rest Home Kills Woman, 106, and 9
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. J., Jan. 29Ten of the 16 elderly residents of a rest home, including a 106yearold woman, were killed when fire destroyed the twostory, woodframe structure early today.

title: Truce but No Truce . . .
description: The Vietnam tragedy pursues its course. Casualty rolls, American and Vietnamese, cannot yet be closed after all. Political machinery for ceasefire supervision, so intri cately elaborated in advance, seems clogged with feuds over credentials, landing permits and protocol. The gov ernments say ceasefire but the fighting sputters on.

title: Shimmering Colors In Ravel Enhanced By Bogas at Piano
description: Ondine, with its delicate overlay of shimmering colors, would appear to be a danger ous choice for a concert open er, but Roy Bogas needed no warmup time at his Alice Tully Hall recital Monday night. Al though the West Coast pianist made his solo debut here only last April, he has been per forming in public for most of his 39 years, and his playing has the suavity, control and assurance that can come only from long experience.

title: Bridge: Altman and Sontag Put End To U.S. Victory Drought
description: When the United States won the world team cham pionship in 1970 a 16year period of nonsuccess came to an end. A drought of similar length in international pair contests ended in London during the last weekend when two young New York partnerships took the top two places in a major invitation event.

title: American Brands Posts Records
Speculum Musicae Eloquent in Playing Pieces to Entertain
description: A surprising number of this century's toughest and most uncompromising musical minds have written pieces devised simply to entertainnot pre cisely the kind of highclass supper music turned out by Mozart, perhaps, but light works, for all their (at the time) advanced musical syn tax. Speculum Musicae, a group of young musicians specializ ing in contemporary chamber music, played four such 20th century divertimentos at its Hunter College concert Mon day night as part of the Young Concert Artists Series.

title: Dow Closes at 992.93
description: The stock market was buf feted by more selling yesterday and slipped lower in moderate trading.

title: Stennis Is Shot in Robbery In Front of Home in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 United States Senator John C. Stennis was shot here tonight in an apparent robbery on the sidewalk in front of his home.

title: EUROPEANS MOVE TO BACK MONEY
description: PARIS, Jan. 30For the first time since last July, European central banks had to buy dol lars today to keep the value of their currencies from breach ing upper limits.

title: Base on Coast Prepares For Arrival of P.O.W.'s
description: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Jan. 30For the re turning prisoners of war, the first glimpse of North Amer ica will be the headlands connected by the bridge across the Golden Gate, with the lights and towers of San Francisco behind.

title: Research for Power
description: The Federal Government can no longer avoid the re sponsibility, even under the tightest of budgets, of finding ways of generating more energy to meet this country's pressing needs. Periodicand belatedrelaxations of oil import quotas will at most tide a chilled nation over another winter. The heart of the energy problem must be addressed through a comprehensive research effort; this should have top priority in President Nixon's national energy policy.

title: Ants, Men and HBombs
description: In the wake of the Vietnam war at least its international phaseand in advance of the second SALT agreement and Mutual and Balanced Force Reduc tions, it is interesting if not heartening to examine previous efforts to limit the means by which men kill each other.

title: Deaths
VAN DOREN SERVICE HELD AT COLUMBIA
description: A hundred of Mark Van Doren's friends and colleagues gathered in St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus yesterday afternoon for a memorial service for the ,English professor and scholar who died Dec. 10 at the age of 78.

title: Dance: Polish Folk Company Returns
description: Mazowaze is back and bet ter than ever. Poland's most famous folk dance and song company has always been a treat for the folkdance en thusiast but this time it has returned with a more bal anced program and, in one opinion, better dancing.

title: Producers Raise Polyester Resins, Aluminum Prices
description: Industrial prices continued to move up yesterday as Reich hold Chemicals, Inc., increased by about 5 per cent the price of polyester resins that go into such products as fiberglass boats, buttons and bowling balls.

title: Ludwig Stossel, Actor, 89; TV's Little Old Winemaker
description: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 30Lud wig Stossel, a character actor known in the nineteensixties as the little old winemaker of television commercials, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old. His widow, the for mer Eleanore Birn, survives.

title: Lesbians Who Try to Be Good Mothers
description: On a recent Tuesday eve ning, nine women gathered in an attractively furnished duplex apartment in the East Village. They ranged in age from 22 to 47. One was mannish in appearance. Two looked like movie starlets. Most of them had been mar ried at least once, and one had been to the altar twice.

title: Notes on People Chapin to Join Airline
description: Dwight L. Chapin, who is President Nixon's appoint ments secretary, will join United Air Lines as director of market planning. The an nouncement of Mr. Chapin's new job was made by the air line a day after the White House denied Mr. Chapin's departure was a result of his reported links to political campaign espionage by Re publicans last year.

title: TV: N.B.C. Offers a Study of Military
description: The first of a twopart N.B.C. News White Paper, called And Now the War Is OverThe American Military in the 70's, was presented on the National Broadcasting Company network last night at 10 o'clock. The second hour will be offered on Feb. 20. The executive producer and writer of the project is Fred Freed.

title: MAN, 45, CHARGED IN 44 SEX CRIMES
description: A 45yearold Sanitation De partment chauffeur was ac cused yesterday of a series of sexual assaults on young girls in Brooklyn, four of whom re portedly identified him as their assailant.

title: Public TV's Freedom Is Called Stunted
description: John W. Macy Jr., former president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, said yesterday that in public tele vision the endeavor to estab lish freedom of expression, with balance and responsibil ity, has at this point failed.

title: Bond Market Gains
Army Cancels Plan to Buy 70 Jets Over Leak of Bids
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Army Secretary Robert F. Froehlke, citing Pentagon viola tion of a promise to Congress and secret bids leaked to indus try, cancelled plans today to buy 70 executive jets worth more than $40million.

title: LeadPaint Bill Advances
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Senate Health subcom mittee approved today a $300 million bill designed to aid states and cities in removing leadbased paint from inner city homes. Sponsors said that many children had become ill from eating paint chips in such homes.

title: 250 Fans at Draft Get Chance to Quiz Rozelle
description: Professional football has reached such a lofty level of popularity that some of its fans get excited about sitting in a hotel ballroom and watch ing a draft whose most ani mated action is a league of ficial walking a downandin pattern through a maze of tables and telephone wires.

title: Elie Wiesel: Archivist With a Mission
description: When Elie Wiesel is asked what he does, he is likely to recall his childhood in Sighet, a small town in the Carpathian Mountains of Hungary.

title: CONGRESS POWER BACKED BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Ralph Nader, the consumer activist, urged Congress today to reassert its constitutional powers and thus prevent Presi dent Nixon from developing a doityourself Congress right in side the White House complex.

title: 3Continent Racing Series Is Seen Outdated
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30The World Cham pionship for Makes, an an nual series of 11 races on three continents that begins this weekend with the Twen tyFour Hours of Daytona, is rather an anachronism, and it will need revising if it is to survive. With attendance declining, promot ers cannot pay the astronomical appearance fees demanded by the manufacturers, and contractors are reluctant to build $50,00075,000 cars unless they are reimbursed by the tracks. Ferrari, for example, has declined to run at Daytona this year for an offered fee of only $2,500.

title: SIHANOUK IS VISITING HANOI TO MARK TET
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodion head of state, flew in here today from Peking for a weeklong visit.

title: Task Forces Hold First Meeting On Better Education in Schools
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30 The first of a series of task forces de voted to improving education in public schools throughout the state met today to begin planning how to teach the basic educational skills, known in simpler times as the three R's.

title: China Is Reported Buying U.S. Cotton
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 China is buying United States cotton for the first time in more than 20 years, a trade source in Memphis said today. He said reports indicated that total purchases would range to 500,000 bales worth $80million.

title: Gulf and Sun Oil Gain in Quarter
description: Earnings reported yesterday by the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Sun Oil Company pro vide additional evidence that the oil industry has not yet found solutions to all its prob lems of recent years.

title: NIXON' ECONOMIC REPORT PREDICTS SLOWER GROWTH AND SAYS IT IS DESIRABLE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  President Nixon's Economic Re port to Congress disclosed to day that the Government wants and expects the rapid expan sion of the economy to begin slowing after midyear.

title: GIBSON DISMAYED BY NIXON ACTION
description: NEWARK, Jan. 30  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and officials of other New Jersey cities expressed dismay today at Presi dent Nixon's announced inten tion to phase out Model Cities programs, which have become an integral part of local gov ernment in the nation's most urbanized state.

title: Nixon Reported to Favor Connally in '76
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  ??resident Nixon told a recent ??isitor that he thought John B. ??onnally, his former Treasury ??ecretary, would make an ex ??ellent Republican Presidential ??andidate in 1976, according to ??igh Republican sources.

title: CORNELL CRITICIZED ON HIRING POLICIES
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 30 Policies of hiring women for faculty and administrative po sitions at Cornell University has been criticized by a study com mittee of the Cornell Board of Trustees.

title: Protestant Militant Executed by I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 30The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility to night for the killing last night of a 28yearold member of the Ulster Defense Association, a militant Protestant group.

title: '73 NOFAULT BILL OFFERED BY G.O.P.
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30A modi fied nofault auto insurance bill that was accorded good chances of passage was disclosed today by the Legislature's Republican leaders, who estimated that the program would eliminate 70 to 75 per cent of autoaccident cases from the courts.

title: DR.R.A.VONDERLEHR; LED DISEASE CENTER
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 30 (AP)  Dr. R. A. Vonderlehr, director of the National Center for Dis ease Control from 1947 to 1952, died after a stroke Sun day. He was 75 years old. Survivors include his widow and a daughter, Mrs. Bryant G. Smith.

title: ARAB RULE OF JEWS OPPOSED BY DAYAN
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30 De fense Minister Moshe Dayan expressed opposition today to any peace settlement that would allow Arab rule over Israeli settlements founded in territory occupied during the 1967 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Role of Designated PinchHitter Is Revised
description: The American League made two critical changes yester day in the role of baseball's newest player, the designated pinchhitter: He now may be used at times on defense and he also may be replaced at times by the pitcher.

title: MRS. HENRY MAYER
description: Mrs. Ruby Prager Mayer, wife of Henry Mayer, a lawyer, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at 142 West End Ave nue.

title: Mail Burns in Fiery Crash
description: COMMERCE, Ga., Jan. 30 (AP)An oil tanker and a mail truck carrying thousands of letters and parcels collided on an interstate highway near here today, and most of the mail went up in flames as the trucks caught fire. The mail was being taken to Philadel phia from Atlanta, postal au thorities reported, when the accident occurred on Inter state 85.

title: DEADLINE TONIGHT IN NEWARK TALKS
description: NEWARK, Jan. 30 The Newark Teachers Union and the Board of Education went into their 40th or 50th bar gaining session since Oct. 20 today with the city offering to continue the current contract in force until an agreement is reached on a new one.

title: Record Ship Order Is Placed in Britain
description: The largest order for mer chant ships ever placed in British yards has been nego tiated by Harland and Wolff, Ltd., Belfast, and two sub sidiaries of the Maritime Fruit Carriers Company, Ltd., Haifa, Israel, spokesmen for both par ties announced yesterday.

title: SHOP TALK A Dining Room That Showed It Was an Excellent Traveler
description: What must have been one of the most fashionable din ing rooms in Paris in 1936 when Marc du Plantier com pleted it for his own home, became, if not the most fashionable, certainly one of the most expensive in New York when it went on view this month at the Sonnabend Gallery, 924 Madison Avenue (at 74th Street), with a price tag of $30,000.

title: Rival Leader Tells of Efforts to Convert Black Muslims
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Two decades ago, Hamaas Abdul Khaalis became a Sunni Moslem and, on the advice of his teacher, infiltrated the Black Muslims.

title: Retaliatory Power Sought
description: The president of the Patrol men's Benevolent Association wants the Police Department here to equip men on patrol with shotguns, automatic weap ons and bulletproof patrol cars with improved twoway radios.

title: AIR FORCE SECRETARY IS SILENT AT HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Air Force Secretary Robert C. Seamans Jr. invoked executive privilege today and refused to say whether he abolished the job of a controversial cost ex pert after seeking or receiving White House advice.

title: China Order Reported
description: China was reported yester day to be buying cotton from the United States for the first time in more than 20 years. The purchases, through a London dealer, were placed at 500,000 bales, worth $80 million. Page 5.

title: Equity Financing
description: A nonregistered secondary of 56,800 shares of M. Lowenstein & Sons common at 21 was made by Shields & Co. The company's stock was down  at 21 on the Big Board.

title: How to Get Nailed to the Mast for $173,982
description: For a compulsive window shopper, there's no better place to run amuck than the National Boat Show.

title: JOHNSON DOCTORS BARRED SURGERY
description: Openheart surgery to re lieve Lyndon B. Johnson's car diac symptoms was ruled out because the former President had extensive heart damage and because of a series of recent attacks from a serious bowel disease, four of his physicians said in a joint statement issued yesterday at Brooke General (Army) Hospital in San An tonio, Tex.

title: BANK ON L.I. CHARGED WITH RELIGIOUS BIAS
description: The State Division of Human Rights has ordered a Long Is land branch of the Franklin National Bank to reinstate an employe who was dismissed after. having taken Passover off without permission.

title: VIETNAM COMBAT STEADILY EBBING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 31The level of fighting in Vietnam dropped substantially yesterday and to day and American analysts said the postceasefire combat was slowly dying out.

title: People and Business I.B.M. Critic Leaves Memorex
description: One of the most outspoken critics of the International Business Machine's dominant position in the computer in dustry, D. James Guzy, has resigned without explanation from his $78,000ayear job as executive vice president of the Memorex Corporation.

title: Pan American Cuts Deficit for Year
description: The Southern Pacific Com pany, the nation's second largest railroad after the Penn Central, reported yesterday record operating revenues and profits for 1972. Pan American World Airways, Inc., the larg est airline after United and Trans World Airlines, reported a $28.9million loss for the year. This was about $3million less than most industry observ ers had expected and was after taking into account a $24.9million tax credit.

title: Records: Hackett's Jazz
description: Bobby Hackett, the jazz cornetist, has joined the growing list of jazz stars who have removed them selves from the usual chan nels of recording and record distribution. Instead of making their disks for an established company to be sold through retail record outlets, these dissidents now make their own records, issue them on their own labels and, as a rule sell them by mail only.

title: Public TV Reported Lagging in Minority Hirings
description: Only minimal progress has been made by public television in the hiring of minoritygroup employes, and the governing boards of public TV stations are almost exclusively com posed of male whites, accord ing to a study by the United Church of Christ.

title: Offensive Lineman, Woods, Obtained
description: It was no surprise to anyone that the New York Jets went for Burgess Owens, a 6foot1 inch, 195pound cornerback from the University of Miami, as their firstround pick in yes terday's player draft. That was a case of love at first sight.

title: SCHOOLS WARNED ON SAFETY FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The Office of Education has cautioned school security spe cialists not to count on Fed eral money to help reduce vio lence in the schools.

title: ST. JOHNS WINS ITS 11TH IN ROW
PETER ROBINSON
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 (AP) Peter Robinson, vice presi dent of West Coast TV pro graming for National Broad casting Company, died yester day of a heart attack at his home in Reseda, a suburb.

title: P. BEN KAUFMAN
description: P. Ben Kaufman, a lawyer here since 1928, died Saturday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 345 East 57th Street.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Winners in state lotteries are eligible to deduct the cost of buying losing lottery tickets against their winnings when listing deductions on their incometax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday. However, losers just lose, even with the tax collector. A gambling loss for losing tickets, says the I.R.S., can be listed as a gambling deduction only if the taxpayer can also list some winnings.

title: BOYLE'S DAUGHTER DROPPED BY U.M.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The new leadership of the United Mine Workers dis missed today from the union payroll another member of the family of the former union president, W.A. Boyle.

title: Cubans Mark CeaseFire By Burning Effigy of Nixon
description: HAVANA, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  Cuban students last night burned a huge effigy of Presi dent Nixon at the end of a day of celebration marking the Viet nam ceasefire.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 19414
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win S225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Syria Says That Israeli Planes Were Driven From Her Area
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30 (AP)Syria said today that Is raeli planes attempted to pen etrate Syrian airspace during the day but were driven off by Syrian jets.

title: Nixon's Science Plan
description: President Nixon plans to revamp the entire top echelon of the Federal science estab lishment in one of the most fundamental reorganizations since that machinery began developing a quarter of a century ago. Page 20.

title: Pilot of Cessna Lands In the Hudson Safely
description: The pilot of a Cessna150 based at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey ran into engine trouble last night over the Hudson River and crash landed in the icy water about 200 feet off 34th Street.

title: Santa Fe Elects Chairman
description: Santa Fe Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday that its board of directors had elected John S. Reed chairman and chief executive officer. He will continue as president of the holding company and as presi dent and chief executive offi cer of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway. In his new post he succeeds Ernest S. Marsh, who retires today.

title: A Marine Returns From the Officially Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  A marine private who was be lieved to have been killed in the battle of Khe Sanh in 1968 and buried in a military cemetery in St. Louis has turned up alive as a prisoner of war held by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.

title: McDonnell Gets Jet Order
description: Scandinavian Airlines an nounced yesterday it had or dered 16 McDonnell Douglas super DC9 twinjets and taken an option on an additional four for a total value of $105mil lion, the largest order ever placed at one time by SAS.

title: Concert
WOMAN ESCAPES, EXTORTION FAILS
description: JACKSON, Tenn., Jan. 30 (UPI)The police arrested a Jackson man today for ques tioning in a $200,000 bank ex tortion attempt that; was bun gled by a man in highheeled shoes and a wig.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 20%, RISE OFFERED DRESS WORKERS
description: A contract agreement giving 60,000 dress industry workers in the city and the rest of the Northeast raises of 20 per cent over three years was reached yesterday by negotiators for the International Ladies' Gar ment Workers' Union and five employer groups.

title: DELAY OF MONTH SET ON S.B.C. RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today a month's stay of its rule that taxexampt securities sold to brokerdealers by banks and other financial institutions must be delivered no later than 10 business days after the settle ment date.

title: 20%, RISE OFFERED DRESS WORKERS
description: A contract agreement giving 60,000 dress industry workers in the city and the rest of the Northeast raises of 20 per cent over three years was reached yesterday by negotiators for the International Ladies Gar ment Workers Union and five employer groups.

title: Nixon's Science Plan
description: President Nixon plans to revamp the entire top echelon of the Federal science estab lishment in one of the most fundamental reorganizations since that machinery began developing a quarter of a century ago. Page 20.

title: Last F111 Fighter Craft Ordered by the Air Force
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) The Air Force said today that it had ordered its last F111 swingwing fighterbomber and that a $29million budget item for the plane in the fiscal year 1974 was intended only to modify existing models.

title: News Summary and Index
Court Aide's Lobbying Sparks a Furor
description: The remarks of a State Su preme Court official urging sev eral hundred prospective jurors to lobby for an end to the un animous  verdict rule has created a legal controversy in volving the Appellate Division, the State Supreme Court, the Legal Aid Society and a num ber of individual trials, includ ing that of H. Rap Brown.

title: SUSPECT CHARGED IN FIRE FATAL TO 10
description: PLEASANTVILLE, Jan. 30 A slight, pale, darkhaired youth with a history of mental illness was arraigned today on charges of arson and murder in the deaths yesterday of 10 patients at a sheltered care home here.

title: EXTENSION URGED FOR INTEREST TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treas ury for Monetary Affairs, told Congress today that there are no plans to change the tax on foreign securities from the present rate, which adds an annual interest charge of 0.75 per cent, but that the Treasury is willing to make a major change regarding new issues.

title: OnceMaligned Old China Hands Honored by Colleagues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The old China hands of the United States diplomatic corps, whose reports on the rise of Chinese Communism in the nineteenforties brought them under fire years later, were the guests of honor today at an emotional luncheon at the State Department that reflected Washington's changing atti tudes, toward China.

title: U.S. Delays Arms Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The resumption of the United StatesSoviet talks on limita tion of strategic arms is being delayed from Feb. 27 until March 12 at the United States request, the White House dis closed today. Changes in the American negotiating staff were given as the reason for the delay.

title: Ellsberg Judge Says U.S. Must Give Data to Defense
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30The judge in the Pentagon papers case ruled late this afternoon that the Government had some evidence tending to prove the innocence of the defendants. He then ordered that this evidence be turned over tonight to the defend ants, Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr.

title: Supervision of CeaseFire Remains Stalled by a Dispute in Military Commission
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 31Efforts to begin supervising the Viet nam ceasefire remained blocked yesterday as the FourParty Joint Military Commission con tinued to be embroiled in a dis pute over how to hold its first formal session.

title: The Astronaut Who Never Really Gave Up Donald Kent Slayton
description: The story of Donald K. Slayton's comeback in the space program is one of quiet perseverance and keen com petitiveness.

title: Glossary of Terms in the U.S.Plan
description: Following is a glossary of terms involved in the United States plan for monetary reform: MONETARY RESERVESReserves held by individual nations in gold, foreign exchange, positions with the International Monetary Fund and Special Drawing Rights.

title: Giants Select Linebacker Who Throws Hard, Too
description: Brad Van Pelt, the first player drafted by the New York Giants this year, has only one mark against him: the fact that he was still available, when the Giants exercised their rights on the 14th turn of the second round.

title: L.I. Marine Listed as A.W.O.L.  Is Returning as Prisoner of War
description: BRENTWOOD, L. I., Jan. 30 A Long Island Marine sched uled to be returned from a North Vietnamese prison camp to face possible charges of de sertion will be treatedat least for the time beingthe same as any other repatriated P.O.W.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Interest rates on home mortgages rose slightly in December, the Government said today. According to the Federal Loan Bank Board, the average effective interest rate charged borrowers buying new homes with conventional mortgages increased from 7.65 per cent in November to 7.66 per cent in December.

title: Keep It Local
description: It is my belief that never before in our national history has voluntarism and the voluntary ethic been so im portant to preserving what is best and most valuable in American society. At issue is our national response to the often necessary and seemingly in escapable growth of centralized gov ernment and the concomitant sub inergence of the individual, the community and the states to Wash ingtonbased authority.

title: Berlinger Charges Wide Fraud At Welfare Center for Cubans
description: George F. Berlinger, the state's Welfare Inspector General, said yesterday that a review of al leged abuses at a New York City center for dispensing wel fare assistance to Cuban refu gees showed an unusually high incidence of fraud by recipi ents and laxity by the city's welfare agency.

title: Violent Crimes Increase
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) The state police reported today that the first nine months of 1972 saw major jumps in re ported violent crimes over an equivalent period the year be fore. Murder increased 20.7 per cent during the period; forcible rape was up 18.8 per cent, and atroc??us assault rose by 20.9 per cent, the police said.

title: Shadow and Substance
description: The new Nixon budget mixes shadow and substance. It puts one in mind of a famous Washington budgetcutter who came home from the office one day to be met by his jubilant son. The boy sang out, Daddy, I saved a quarter today. How did you do that, son? I walked home instead of taking the bus, the boy answered. Why didn't you save a dollar? asked the great budget  cut ter. You could have walked instead of taking a taxi.

title: Uniform State Pension Plan Proposed
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30A state commission established by the Legislature two years ago recommended today that the eight retirement systems for one million public employes in the state adopt a uniform pension plan for all public employes hired after July 1, 1973.

title: SALT LAKE CITY WITHDRAWS BID
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 30 (AP)  This Utah city with drew its bid today to hold the 1976 Winter Olympics, but there remained a chance that another United States city would be in the running.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: EAST STARS BEAT WEST SEXTET, 54, IN N.H.L. STRUGGLE
Buffalo Boy, 7, Shot to Death
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 30 (AP)A 7yearold boy walking home from school today was shot to death, the police reported. In vestigators said the boy, Kevin Davis, was walking with his brother, Michael, 9, and his sis ter, Jacqueline, 10, when the shots were fired.

title: Israel Says That Man Slain In Madrid Was an Agent
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 30The Gov ernment acknowledged tonight that the Israeli citizen who was shot to death in Madrid last Friday was an agent of Israel's security services.

title: William L. Satire, a Nixon Aide, To Join The Times as Columnist
description: William L. Safire, a special assistant to President Nixon, will join The New York Times as a columnist, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times, announced yesterday.

title: SCHOOL AIDE OFFICE OCCUPIED BY BLACKS
description: NEWARK, Jan. 30 (AP)  About 300 black students oc cupied and extensively damaged the office of the acting school superintendent today after a controversial black teacher was restored to his post at Vails burg High School.

title: Election Year Budget
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30Annual state budgets proposed by New Jersey Governors are as pre dictable as the morning rush hour traffic jam along the ap proaches to the Lincoln Tunnel. One year they ask for higher taxes to pay for ambitious new programs, while in the next they call for economy in gov ernment and fis cal retrenchment. For Governors who want to be re elected, as is the case with William T. Cahill, the quintessential budget in an election year is one that avoids new taxes but still somehow comes up with at tractive new programs on which they can ride back into office.

title: Advertising: Small Cigars Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The television advertising of small cigars carefully fabri cated to be inhalable was called an affront and a textbook case of corporate ir responsibility today by Sen ator John V. Tunney, a new member of the Commerce Committee and its consumer subcommittee.

title: Local Boards Get New Power, But Their Chiefs Are Skeptical
description: Local community boards are being asked to recommend and review capitalbudget proposals for their districts under what Mayor Lindsay described yes terday as a new and bold ap proach to city government.

title: Newspaper Guild Honors 2 for Series on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  The Newspaper Guild has announced that Carl Bern stein and Bob Woodward of The Washington Post were win ners of the Guild's 1972 Hey wood Broun award for their se ries on the Watergate breakin and bugging of Democratic National Headquarters.

title: 8 Youths Arrested In Brooklyn Killing Of a Landlord, 75
description: Eight youths were arrested early yesterday and charged with the Sundaymorning kill ing of a 75yearold Brooklyn man. The police said five of the eight youths were tenants in buildings the victim owned.

title: S. I. Development Bill Is Offered To Meet Residents Objections
description: Albany, Jan. 30  A new version of legislation designed to create a public benefit cor poration for the development of more than 10,000 acres in South Richmond on Staten Is land was introduced in the Leg islature today by Senator John Marchi, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

title: 73 NOFAULT BILL OFFERED BY G.O.P.
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30A modi fied nofault auto insurance bill that was accorded good chances of passage was disclosed today by the Legislature's Republican leaders, who estimated that the program would eliminate 70to 75 per cent of autoaccident cases from the courts.

title: Jazz Piano
