description: There is such a wealth of good piano jazz to be heard in New York nowwhat with Ellis Larkins at Gregory's, Teddy Wilson and Dick Hy man at the Cookery, Marian McPartland at the Cafe Car lyle, to cite a few choices that the appearance of one more good jazz pianist is not apt to be quite the earth shaking event it might have been a year or so ago. But Dave McKenna, who is now playing at Michael's Pub, is something special even in New York's currently glitter ing jazz piano scene.

title: Elie Wiesel: Archivist With a Mission
description: When Elie Wiesel is asked what he does, he is likely to recall his childhood in Sighet, a small town in the Carpathian Mountains of Hungray.

title: Boom Reflected in U.S. Reports
description: The Government published new evidence yesterday of the nation's surging economic boomand of new inflationary pressures as well.

title: Liddy and McCord Are Guilty Of Spying on the Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Two former officials of Presi dent Nixon's political organi zation were convicted today in the Watergate trial of plotting to spy on the Democrats during last year's campaign.

title: Books of The Times Bragging Up the U.S.A.
description: AMERICAN REVIEW 16. Edited by Ted Solo. taroff. 274 pages. Bantam. Paperback, $1.95. Because I believe that American Review (formerly New American Review) plays crucial part in our literary life, I was prepared, if necessary, to write a sermon to that effectciting the shrinking market for original short stories and unusual ar ticles; the I'llreadanybody'sstuff policy of the magazine's editor; the number of talented new people I've found in its pre vious 15 issues; the noncliquish catholicity of its selections; the fact that the famous writers who are frequently found in its pages are not merely dining out on their names but sweating like everyone else; and so on.

title: Ellsberg Judge Says U.S. Must Give Data to Defense
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30The judge in the Pentagon papers case ruled late this afternoon that the Government had some evidence tending to prove the innocence of the defendants. He then ordered that this evidence be turned over tonight to the defend ants, Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr.

title: Council Panel Criticizes Lindsay on Provisionals
description: The Lindsay administration was accused yesterday of hir ing provisional employes under questionable and illegal prac tices at the expense of thou sands of civil servants. The charges were made in a draft report submitted by the City Council's Civil Service and Labor Committee.

title: Hof Line for Addicts Established by State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30Gover nor Rockefeller announced today that a tollfree hot line to the Narcotic Addic tion Control Commission had been established so that any addict can be guaranteed en rollment in a treatment pro gram within 48 hours.

title: Treasure in Peril
description: It was to be expected that public hearings on the Adirondack Park Agency's landuse plan for private properties within the park would reveal considerable local opposition. They did, especially in the northern counties of the state, where opponents have been con centrating on the plan's imagined threat to the area's economic potential.

title: Computer Group Urges Relief on I.B.M.'s Role
description: The Computer Industry As sociation has proposed to the Government an eightpoint early relief program to re tain competition within the in dustry while the Justice De partment's antitrust suit against the International Busi ness Machines Corporation is being fought in the courts.

title: South Korea Hails Returning Soldiers As Pullout Is Begun
description: SUWON, South Korea, Jan. 30  The first contingent of South Korean troops with drawn from Vietnam after the ceasefire returned home today to a heroes welcome.

title: RED DYE IS CALLED A PERIL TO BIRTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)  A red dye, used in every thing from lipstick to soft drinks and pill coatings, came under attack today from two fronts that contend it may rep resent a threat to human re production.

title: BREZHNEV HAILS VIETNAM ACCORD AS TURNING POINT
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist leader, today hailed the Vietnam ceasefire agreement as an important turning point in international affairs that not only would have a positive ef fect on SovietAmerican rela tions but also could influence settlements in world trouble spots such as the Middle East.

title: What War Has Meant to Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30What did more than a decade of war accomplish for South Vietnam?

title: Nixon's $80Million Aid for Arts Is Hailed
description: The inclusion in President Nixon's 1974 budget of a rec ord $80million for the arts, more than doubling the amount of the previous year, is a tribute to the combined efforts of national, state and local arts organizations in pushing for Federal support of culture.

title: Metropolitan Briefs Tax Deductions Allowed in Lotteries
description: Winners in state lotteries are eligible to deduct the cost of buying losing lottery tickets against their winnings when listing deductions on their income tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday.

title: $900,000 Mistake in Check Is Rectified in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 30 (AP) The office of the Secretary of the State received a record pay ment of $900,020 yesterday from a person applying to be come a notary public.

title: 2 DEMOCRATS SEE CURB ON MEDICARE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Congress may enact an Ad ministration budget proposal to have the elderly pay more for their Medicare benefits, two leading Democratic members of Congress said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Turnpike Chief Engineer Denies Knowing of Payoff on Contract
description: NEWARK, Jan. 30  The chief engineer of the New Jer sey Turnpike testified today at the trial of former State Sena tor Willard B. Knowlton that to his knowledge there was no money paid or outside influ ence exercised in the award ing of a controversial $10.6mil lion contract to a New York construction company.

title: RED DYE IS CALLED A PERIL TO BIRTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)  A red dye, used in every thing from lipstick to soft drinks and pill coatings, came under attack today from two fronts that contend it may rep resent a threat to human re production.

title: Legislators Fire Questions At Governor on Drug Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30Governor Rockefeller today promoted and defended his proposed legisla tion for dealing with traffickers in hard drugs in a rare appear ance before a legislative hear. ing where  in an even rarer instance  he submitted to barrage of questions from law. makers.

title: British Soccer
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: For high lido at Asbury Park and Belmar, N. J., deduct 34 minutes from Sandy Hook time.

title: Suspect in Fire ExMental Patient
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., Jan. 30A slight, pale dark haired young man with a history of mental illness was arraigned today on charges of arson and murder in the deaths of 10 patients at a sheltered care home that burned here yesterday.

title: 1972 PROFIT DOWN AT MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fen ner & Smith, Inc., the big brokerage house whose televi sion ads proclaim it is bullish on America, reported yesterday that its earnings declined in 1972 while revenues rose to a record $723million.

title: U.S. Will Pay 9O% of Cost Of New Bridge at Newburgh
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP) The Federal Government will pay 90 per cent of the cost of the new NewburghBeacon Bridge, but drivers will still have to pay the state a toll to use the facility, Governor Rockefeller's office announced today.

title: Man With Arrest Record Is Found Slain in Brooklyn
description: A 38year old Long Island man with a history of arrests for truck hijacking, receiving stolen goods and rape was found shot to death early yes terday morning near the Brook lyn Navy Yard.

title: Laotian Reds Urge Private Truce Talk
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 30 Communist delegates to the Laotian peace talks pro posed today that private meetings between their side and representatives of the Government begin tomorrow. They suggested that the ses sions be held alternately at the residences of the delega tion chiefs without newsmen present.

title: Jack MacGowran, Interpreter Of Beckett and O'Casey, Dead
description: Jack MacGowran, one of Ire land's foremost actors and a renowned interpreter of the works of Samuel Beckett and Sean O'Casey, died yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel, where he had been living while ap pearing in the current produc tion of O'Casey's The Plough and the Stars at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: White House Supports a Bill Ordering Free Repair of Auto Safety Defects
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Nixon Administration, in a shift of policy, threw its support today to legislation that would compel manufacturers to bear the cost of correcting safety defects in automobiles.

title: 10 REPORTED KILLED IN A QUAKE IN MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 30 (UPI) A short, violent earthquake today shook the areas north and west of Mexico City kill ing at least 10 persons and in juring at least 100. Widespread damage and panic was reported by Government officials.

title: Harvard Raises Tuition $200
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 30 (AP)Tuition will go up $200 during the next academic year at Harvard College, Radcliffe College and the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, Harvard University announced today. The increase brings yearly tuition at Harvard to $3,200. Undergraduate fees for room and board will increase from $1,745 to $1,825 a year.

title: Legislators Fire Questions At Governor on Drug Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30Governor Rockefeller today promoted and defended his proposed legisla tion for dealing with traffickers in hard drugs in a rare appear ance before a legislative hear ing where  in an even rarer instance  he submitted to a barrage of questions from law makers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Last November the Mayor's Com mittee on Executive and Judicial Com pensation, composed of six distin guished business executives and pro fessional men, recommended what it termed a modest increase of $2,500 in the salaries of the 257 judges of the New York City Civil, Criminal and Family Courtsan increase well with in the then existing Federal Pay Board limits.

title: Harvard Raises Tuition $200
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 30 (AP)Tuition will go up $200 during the next academic year at Harvard College, Radcliffe College and the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, Harvard University announced today. The increase brings yearly tuition at Harvard to $:3,200. Undergraduate fees for room and hoard will increase from $1,745 to $1,825 a year.

title: 24 Die in Crash in Hungary
description: VIENNA, Jan. 30 (Reuters) Twentyfour people were re ported killed today when a pas senger train crashed into a bus at a level crossing near Kec skemet, in Eastern Hungary. The Hungarian press agency said that 20 were seriously in jured.

title: Glover, Nebraska Guard, Chosen
description: A player of unquestioned ability but highly questionable availability  Brad Van Pelt and a player whose pro po tential is widely doubted but whose college credentials are impeccable  Rich Glover  were the two players the New York Giants were able to draft in the first four rounds yes terday.

title: A Marine Returns From the Officially Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  A marine private who was be lieved to have been killed in the battle of Khe Sanh in 1968 and buried in a military cemetery in St. Louis has turned up alive as a prisoner of war held by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.

title: Heath Arrives in Washington For Meetings With Nixon
description: WASHINGTONJan. 30 (AP) Prime Minister Heath of Britain arrived in Washington tonight for two days of talks with President Nixon starting Thursday on questions ranging from economic and monetary problems to the rebuilding of wardevastated Indochina.

title: VIETNAM COMBAT STEADILY EBBING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 31The level of fighting in Vietnam dropped substantially yesterday and to day and American analysts said that postceasefire combat was slowly dying out.

title: Armenian Denies Killing 2
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 30 (Reuters)Gorgen Yanikian, an Armenian accused of slaying two Turkish consular officials Saturday, pleaded not guilty when he appeared in Municipal Court today. The Turkish offi cials were Mehmet Baydar, con sul general at Los Angeles, and his vice consul, Bahadir Demir.

title: Odalisque Back, Under a Cloud
description: The naked young lady known as the Odalisque in Gray is back from Paris with her name under a cloud, but it is by no means certain that she is no longer pure.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The United States Postal Service has announced a rul ing that assures nonprofit cultural organizations access to special thirdclass bulk mail rates. They may mail items at 1.7 cents apiece, al most 72 per cent less than the nonprivileged rate.

title: BREZHNEV HAILS VIETNAM ACCORD AS TURNING POINT
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist leader, today hailed the Vietnam ceasefire agreement as an important turning point in international affairs that not only would have a positive ef fect on SovietAmerican rela tions but also could influence, settlements in world trouble spots such as the Middle East.

title: Mafia Figure Loses Fight To Bar Deportation to Italy
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (UPI)Russell A. Bufalino, 67 years old, a reputed Mafia fig ure from Kingston, Pa., lost to day a 14year legal fight to avoid deportation to Italy as an alien.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 30For Charles Boutsika ris and his son, Toni: George Boutsikaris and his son, Tom; Harry Boutsikaris and his son, Tom, and for Gregory Bout sikaris and his son, Gregory, fencing is a family affair.

title: REGINALD A. COOK
description: YARMOUTH, Me., Jan. 30 Reginald A. Cook, who retired in 1959 as investment officer for the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association in New York, died yesterday in Port land. He was 78 years old and had moved here from Mont clair, N. J., last fall.

title: Ashe Upset by Chanfreau, Tanner Defeats Borowiak
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 30 (AP) Arthur Ashe was upset in the first round of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Hot Line for Addicts Established by State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30Gover nor Rockefeller announced today that a tollfree hot line to the Narcotic Addic tion Control Commission had been established so that any addict can be guaranteed en rollment in a treatment pro gram within 48 hours.

title: Continued Growth in Tie With Soviet Is Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Nixon Administration officials believe that a more rapid de velopment of relations with China may turn out to be one of the major dividends for Washington from last week's Vietnam settlement.

title: Mrs. Thomas J. Dodd, 65, Dies; Widow of Connecticut Senator
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 30Mrs. Grace Murphy Dodd, widow of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, died last night at Law rence Memorial Hospital here. She was 65 years old and lived in Old Lyme.

title: Liddy and McCord Are Guilty Of Spying on the Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Two former officials of Presi dent Nixon's political organi zation were convicted today in the Watergate trial of plotting to spy on the Democrats during last year's campaign.

title: Market Place: Mutual Funds Key Personnel
description: You own shares in mutual fund A, bought recently after a check of the fund's record. You learned that the fund's net asset value per share gained about 15 per cent a year, on the average, over the last 10 years. What's more, you did more than just call a brokeryou went to a business library and checked the most recent years to see how the fund did in the bear market of 1969 and 1970.

title: News Summary and Index
Laotian Reds Urge Private Truce Talk
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 30 Communist delegates to the Laotian peace talks pro posed today that private meetings between their side and representatives of the Government begin tomorrow. They suggested that the ses sions be held alternately at the residences of the delega tion chiefs without newsmen present.

title: Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera has generally had a notable sup ply of Verdi baritones, but it can always use another one if he is good enough. Such a singer turned up Monday night in the person of Ingvar Wixell, who made a very im pressive debut in the title role of Rigoletto. He is Swedish, a member of the Royal Opera in S??ockholm and the Deutsche Oper in Berlin, and he has sung in several major Euro pean houses as well as with the San Francisco Opera for four seasons.

title: S.E.C. Decision Is Due On Variable Insurance
description: The Securities and Ex change Commission, in a decision that may determine whether billions of dollars in new money may be pumped into the stock market, is expected to release its report today governing the sale of a new stock marketoriented productvariable life insur ance. Key findings are ex pected to deal with sales charges.

title: Thieves Shoot at Two Policemen In Queens After Cars End Chase
description: Two young men fired three shots from a small pistol at two city policemen last night following a fiveblock car chase in the Rosedale section of Queens. The police reported that no one had been injured and that the two youths had fled on foot across the city line into Valley Stream in Nassau County.

title: BUDGET FUNDS CUT FOR ACCELERATOR
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 30 The Cambridge Electron Ac celerator, a pioneering research tool for unraveling the myster ies of highenergy physics, will cease operation in highenergy physics in the next fiscal year and will close unless a conver sion proposal is accepted.

title: West Germany Tells Its Diplomats Not to Snub East Germans
description: BONN, Jan. 30  West Ger many's diplomats have received new orders detailing a special etiquette to be observed in contacts with East German dip lomats at overseas posts.

title: DR. ROBERT MAKORSKY
description: VERONA, N. J., Jan. 30 (AP) Dr. Robert C. Makorsky, chairman of the chemistry de partment at Bloomfield College. died Sunday. He was 48 years old.

title: 12 Departments in H.R.A. Pared to 5
description: A reorganization of the Hu man Resources Administration that would consolidate 12 ma jor departments into five was announced yesterday by Jule M. Sugarman, Administrator of the superagency.

title: U.S. Selects Space Crew For Flight With Russians
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has named the United States crew for the first international manned space flight, which is scheduled for 1975.

title: Uniform State Pension Plan Proposed
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30A state commission established by the Legislature two years ago recommended today that the eight retirement systems for one million public employes in the state adopt a uniform pension plan for all public employes hired after July 1, 1973.

title: Holders of First Leisure File Suit for $20Million
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 Reu ters)The First Leisure Corpo ration was sued today by a group of shareholders for $20 million in damages for alleged misappropriation of the com pany's assets and earnings.

title: W.C. Fields Honored: Dog Is Kicked and Child Abused
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 W. C. Fields, who was known to his scandalized childhood neighbors as Whitey Duken field, scOUrge of the streets and bane of the North Side Philadelphia saloonkeepers, left the city of his birth un der something of a cloud sometime in the eighteen nineties.

title: Civilian P.O.W.'s Get Help if They Are Silent
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philip pines, Jan. 30Returning Amer ican civilian prisoners of war will be given the same medical examinations and treatment that returning soldiers receive, but they will be ejected from the program if they make pub lic statements, a State Depart ment spokesman said here to day.

title: People in Sports: Yale Liberates a Department
description: Yale University yesterday named Joni E. Barnett direc tor of physical education, making her apparently the first woman in an American coeducational university to hold that position. Mrs. Bar nett, the mother of two boys and the wife of an assistant state attorney, will assume her duties in June, following the retirement of Dr. T. Erwin Blesh.

title: Peking and Taipei, in a Shift, Now Court the Splintered Taiwan Independence Movement
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 30 The Taiwan independence movement among native Tai wanese dissidents abroad, badly splintered as a result of Presi dent Nixon's initiatives toward Communist China, now finds itself being courted by both Taipei and Peking instead of being assailed as traitorous.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Stennis Is Shot in Robbery In Front of Home in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 31Senator John C. Sten nis was shot here last night in an apparent robbery on the sidewalk in front of his home.

title: TEAMSTER OFFICIALS GAVE FUNDS TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The president of the Interna tional Brotherhood of Team sters, Frank E. Fitzsimmons. and other union officials gave Pres ident Nixon's campaign a total of $9,500 just before the No vember election, newly filed Federal reports show.

title: Grayson, at Senate Inquiry, Backs Easing of Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Dr. C. Jackson Grayson Jr., former head of the Price Com mission, said today that he agreed with the easing of con trols under the third phase of the Nixon Adiministation's eco nomic program and hoped that all controls would be removed by April, 1974.

title: Judge Sets a Minority Quota for Bridgeport Police
description: BRIDGEPORT, Jan. 30The police department here was or dered yesterday by a Federal judge to hire and promote black and Puerto Rican police men at a significantly quick ened rate.

title: 90,000 Prisoners
description: The eagerness with which Americans anticipate the release of 555 prisoners of war in the wake of the Vietnam ceasefire makes it easier to understand the growing impatience in Pakistan over the continued detention of some 90,000 Pakistani war prisoners in India more than a year after the conclusion of hostilities on the Indian subcontinent.

title: 3Month Increase Is 16c a Share
description: The United States Steel Cor poration, the nation's largest steel producer, reported yes terday that its net income in the fourth quarter last year rose to $54.7million, or $1.01 a share, from $46.4million, or 85 cents, the year before.

title: TAXI OWNERS CITE FLAGUP LOSSES
description: Taxicab drivers are stealing more than $3million a year from their employers here, the taxi industry says, and more often than not they are doing it with the compliance of their passengers.

title: MONETARY PLAN  PUBLISHED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Government published today detailed and farreaching pro posals for reform of the world monetary system. The mechan isms in the plan are new in many respects.

title: W. and J. Names Coach
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Jan. 30 (AP)Patrick E. Mondock was named head football coach at Washington and Jefferson Col lege today.

title: Official Ban Ignored
description: In the wake of the ambush of four New York policemen in less than 72 hours, uni formed patrolmen have routine ly been going on duty armed with extra, unauthorized per sonal weapons for selfprotec tion.

title: The New Economic Philosophy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30President Nixon has been talking ever since the November election about changing the philosophy and direction of the Ameri can Government in his second term, but it wasn't until his budget was pub lished that the capital really took him seriously.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
7,000 Visit Johnson Grave
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Jan. 30 (UPI)More than 7,000 persons visited the gravesite of former President Johnson during the weekend, a park official said today.

title: Nixon to Revamp the Science Establishment
description: Emerging details of a plan by President Nixon to revamp the entire top echelon of the Federal science establishment show it to be the most funda mental reorganization of that machinery since it began de veloping a quarter of a cen

title: 12 Mayors, Alarmed at U.S. Budget, to Meet Here on Monday
description: Mayors of a dozen of the country's largest cities, fearful that President Nixon's proposed Federal budget would cripple housing, social services and antipoverty programs in their communities, will meet at Gracie Mansion on Monday to orga nize opposition to the cutbacks.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: W. C. Fields Honored: Dog Is Kicked and Child Abused
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 W. C. Fields, who was known to his scandalized childhood neighbors as Whitey Duken field, scourge of the streets and bane of the North Side Philadelphia saloonkeepers, left the city of his birth un der something of a cloud sometime in the eighteen nineties.

title: TESTIMONY IS TAKEN IN DRUGS FRAMEUP
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30 (AP) State Senator James M. Turner, Republican of Gloucester, testi fied for four hours today before a state grand jury investigating the planting of amphetamines in the home and car of Assem blyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, Democrat of Gloucester.

title: Official Ban Ignored
description: In the wake of the ambush of four New York policemen in less than 72 hours, uni formed patrolmen have routine ly been going on duty armed with extra, unauthorized per sonal weapons for selfprotec tion.

title: Matuszak First Choice in N.F.L. Draft
description: John Matuszak, a giant whose suit size is 50 long and whose waist is 34 inches, was the first player selected yester day in the National Football League's annual draft of college athletes.

title: China Order Reported
description: China was reported yester day to be buying cotton from the United States for the first time in more than 20 years. The purchases, through a London dealer, were placed at 500,000 bales, worth $80 million. Page 5.

title: Retaliatory Power Sought
description: The president of the Patrol men's Benevolent Association wants the Police Department here to equip men on patrol with shotguns, automatic weap ons and bulletproof patrol cars with improved twoway radios.

title: Baritone at Philharmonic
description: Siegmund Nimsgern will re place the indisposed Dietrich FischerDieskau as soloist in Mahler's Rckert Songs with the New York Philhormonic tomorrow and Friday night. The 32yearold German bari tone will be making his debut with the orchestra, although he had already been engaged to sing with it next season.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SENIOR SERVICE The City Center of Music and Drama, 131 West 55th Street (2468989), has for several years been doing special per formances for 65's and older, a feature of which, entertain ment aside, is that seats in the orchestra and the first 10 rows of balcony are sold at $1.50 each with the rest of the balcony, for those who feel up to highrise climbing, at $1 a seat. They are also shown during the day at a time when those in the audience can use special transportation fares between rush hours.

title: Excerpts From the Brezhnev Address
description: Following, as distrubuted in English by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, are ex cerpts from a speech deliv ered yesterday by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party chief, at a dinner in honor of the North Viet namese negotiators in Paris:

title: Real Estate Firm Must Pay Refund
A BRITISH LABORITE EXPECTED IN HANOI
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)  James Callaghan, former Brit ish Home Secretary and Chan cellor of the Exchequer, is to visit Hanoi next month, an in formed Western source here said today.

title: Gracious Living for the Knicks
description: Yesterday was a great day for the New York Knicks. For a change, they didn't have to play roundball. What're you going to do with a day off? Dave DeBusschere was asked. We get to travel, he said, trying to sound thank ful. This was Monday night in Madison Square Garden.

title: Shellfishing Ban Extended
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 30 (UPI)The Rhode Island De partment of Health has extend ed a ban on shellfishing in up per Narragansett Bay because of heavy rainfall. The depart ment said yesterday that the ban, put into effect last Wednesday, would be extended to Feb, 9.

title: RICHARD CROOKS OF N. Y. EXCHANGE
description: Richard M. Crooks, who served three terms as chairman of the Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange, died yes terday of a heart attack at his home, 19 Brandywyne Street, Brielle, N. J. He was 67 years old.

title: Reconstruction Days
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Perhaps for the very first time after any major war the factual and technical groundwork for an immediate start on the task of reconstruction and development has already been prepared in advance of the end of a war. In published form, the study is known as The Postwar Development of the Republic of Viet nam. (1970)

title: Job Equality for Women Backed in Nixon Report
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The Nixon Administration said today that the national objec tive of providing maximum employment, which is em bodied in the Employment Act of 1946, applies equally to men and to women.

title: Report Gives Example of Alternative Criteria
description: As an example of the use of alternative qualifications for a city job, the City Coun cil Civil Service and Labor Committee cited the Lindsay administration's search for an administrative associate.

title: 5 IrishBorn New Yorkers Are Jailed Again in Texas
description: FORT WORTH, Jan. 30 (UPI) The five Irishborn New Yorkers who the authorities feel have evidence about a gun running scheme to Northern Ireland resumed yesterday their indefinite term in the Tarrant County jail.

title: National Safety Panel Asks Warning Label on Alcohol
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) The National Safety Council asked brewers and distillers yesterday to label alcoholic beverage containers with a cau tionary statement saying ex cessive drinking will impair driving ability.

title: Insurgent Democrats Reported Urging Byrne to Enter Primary
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30  An Influential group of young New Jersey Democrats, apparently dissatisfied with the present field of candidates for their party's nomination for Gover nor, were reported here today attempting to persuade Superi or Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne to enter the June pri mary.

title: . . . Meanwhile in Laos
description: As the fighting spasmodically subsides in South Viet nam and the last United States troops prepare to with draw from that still unresolved conflict, continuing American air activity over Laos is a painful reminder that the United States still hasn't wholly extricated itself from the wider Indochina war.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Agnew, in Saigon, Affirms U.S. Support
description: SAIGON, South Vietnanm, Wednesday, Jan. 31  Vice President Agnew arrived in Saigon yesterday for discus sions with President Nguyen Van Thieu on postwar relations between the United States and South Vietnam.

title: Head of Malcolm X College To Leave His Post in June
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) Dr. Charles Hurst Jr., charged with mismanaging $1.3million in Federal funds given to Mal colm X College, said yesterday he was resigning as president of the black school.

title: MONETARY PLAN PUBLISHED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Government published today detailed and farreaching pro posals for reform of the world monetary system. The mechan isms in the plan are new in many respects.

title: Botanic Center Planned
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) Plans were announced today for a $5million education center that backers say will attract more than a million visitors a year to the Chicago Horticultural Society's Botanic Gardens. The education center will have a greenhouse, exhibi tion halls, two open courts, a halfacre exhibit area, a 30,000 volume reference library and collections of plants from all parts of the world.

title: Text of the President's Annual Economic Report to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Following is the text of President Nixon's annual Economic Report, made pub lic by the White House today:

title: ELEVATOR UNION AGREES ON PACT Ratification of Contract Ends 7Month Delay for City's Construction Industry
description: A sevenmonth labor dispute that had caused massive tieups in the city's construction in dustry ended last night when members of the Elevator Con structors Union ratified a new threeyear contract.
